preface.title: PREFACE
preface.p: The publication of the English translation of Ibn Ezra’s long commentary on Exodus, whose length is equal to that of the other four books of the Pentateuch, has given me a sense of accomplishment. This was a very formidable task that has taken many years. Ibn Ezra’s style makes translation very complicated, and this is compounded in Exodus by its length. As his comments become longer, Ibn Ezra becomes more difficult to understand.

The long commentary, as opposed to the short commentary, was chosen because it is the version included in the Mikra’ot Gedolot on the Pentateuch. A contributing factor is that Ibn Ezra’s chief protagonist, Nachmanides, used it. A full and scholarly discussion of Ibn Ezra’s short and long commentaries appears in the Introduction that follows.

The long commentary on Exodus is unique. All Ibn Ezra’s other works on the Pentateuch, the Prophets, and the Hagiographa are of the short variety. This affords the opportunity to make comparisons and is therefore a work of special importance.
I want to thank everyone who helped in getting this difficult job done. May the Almighty grant us life, health, and the strength to complete the task.
Arthur M. Silver
24 Tevet, 5756
January 16, 1996

preface.title: FOREWORD
preface.p: Students of Biblical exegesis are aware that there are two commentaries on the Book of Exodus ascribed to Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra, a long commentary referred to as pirush ha-arokh and a short commentary referred to as pirush ha-katzar. The long commentary (henceforth referred to as L.C.) is about four times the length of the short commentary (henceforth referred to as S.C.) and equals in size Ibn Ezra’s commentaries on all of the other four books combined. The S.C., on the other hand, is about the same length as each of the other four commentaries on the Pentateuch that Ibn Ezra composed.

There is no question that the S.C. was composed by Ibn Ezra. It mentions Ibn Ezra’s other commentaries on the Pentateuch in places that the L.C. does not. Thus the S.C. mentions Ibn Ezra’s comments on Genesis in Ex. 1:11; 22:7; 25:18; and 30:16; his comments on Leviticus in Ex. 3:18; 12:16; and 20:20; his comments on Numbers in Ex. 3:1 and 27:19; and his comments on Deuteronomy in Ex. 14:4; 19:12,17,23; 20:1,18; 21:10; 22:15; 32:22; and 34:5.

Furthermore, the S.C. contains the characteristic anti-midrashic criticisms that are frequently not found in the L.C. (see Ex. 2:10,12; 13:18; 19:13,17; 25:31). There is also a greater tendency to explain difficult terms by reference to Arabic (Ex. 2:13; 6:13; 7:27; 9:21; 12:9; 16:1; 23:19; 24:6; 25:29; 36:8). In addition, “The grammarian Ibn Janah is referred to as ‘Rabbi Jonah,’ as he is in the commentaries on the other books of the Pentateuch, whereas in the L.C. he is referred to as ‘Rabbi Marinus,’ the title used by Ibn Ezra when referring to him in the books he wrote in France: the commentaries on Daniel; the Minor Prophets and Esther; and in the grammatical works Sefat Yeter and Safah Berurah” (Etan Levine).

Thus stylistically speaking, the S.C. fits in very well with Ibn Ezra’s other commentaries on the Pentateuch. They form, as it were, a perfect set. We would thus expect the standard editions of Ibn Ezra’s commentaries on the Pentateuch to consist of five relatively short commentaries. However, this is not the case. The Mikra’ot Gedolot edition of the Pentateuch has the long rather than the short commentary to Shemot. The same is true of the Vat. Ebr. 38 manuscript (probably composed in the fifteenth century) of Ibn Ezra’s commentary on the five books of Moses.

The fact of the matter is that the S.C. on Exodus seems to have been unknown, or at least unavailable, to the Jewish public after the introduction of printing. In 1839, Samuel David Luzzato came across a manuscript of Ibn Ezra containing the S.C. His teacher, Rabbi Yitzchak Shemuel Reggio (Yashar), one of the founders of the Rabbinical Seminar of Italy, obtained the manuscript and published it in 1840. Other editions were put out by Y. L Krinsky, Y. L. Fleischer, and A. Weiser.
While there is no doubt about the authorship of the S.C., some scholars have questioned Ibn Ezra’s authorship of the L.C.

Rabbi Joseph ben Eliezer Tov Elem, a fourteenth-century author of an important commentary on Ibn Ezra known as the Tzafnat Pane’ach, argues that the L.C. is not the work of Ibn Ezra. He writes that he “found in the land of the Christians a commentary on Exodus ascribed to Ibn Ezra that was as large as Ibn Ezra’s commentaries on the other books (of the Torah).” However, he “found other works,” that is, another commentary on Exodus (the reference is to the S.C.), in the beautiful country (the Land of Israel) and Syria.”

Tov Elem then goes on to note that some remarks in the L.C. contradict Ibn Ezra’s comments in the S.C. Rabbi Joseph does not list the contradictions. However, compare Ibn Ezra’s comments in the long and short commentaries to Ex. 5:9; 11:21; 13:22; and 15:22. Also compare the L.C. on Ex. 18:7 and Gen. 23:7, and the L.C. on Ex. 34:28 and Deut. 10:1.

The L.C. repeats a number of comments found in Ibn Ezra’s commentary on Genesis and in his introduction to the Pentateuch (see Gen. 27:19 and Ex. 31:18; Introduction to the Pentateuch and Ex. 12:2). Rabbi Joseph argues that it is not the style of Ibn Ezra to repeat himself.
In Ex. 12:9 we find: “Behold, I the writer add to the words of this sage as I heard from his mouth.” Rabbi Joseph claims that this shows that Ibn Ezra did not write the L.C.

Rabbi Joseph concludes that all of the above indicates that the L.C. was not composed by Ibn Ezra. He argues that it was put together by one or a number of Ibn Ezra’s students who gathered Ibn Ezra’s notes or used an earlier edition of Ibn Ezra’s short commentary on Shemot, elaborated upon them, and thus gave birth to the L.C. on Shemot.
Although Rabbi Joseph ben Tov Elem’s theory was accepted by the nineteenth-century scholar Shelomo Yehudah Rappaport, the preponderance of scholarly opinion holds that I.E. is the author of the L.C.

I believe that most of the evidence points to Abraham ibn Ezra as the author of the L.C. on Exodus which bears his name. The fact that the L.C. is four times as long as each of Ibn Ezra’s other commentaries on the Torah is by itself not a convincing argument that he did not write this work. This is especially so in view of the fact that fragments from a L.C. on Genesis are extant and have been published. The latter proves that Ibn Ezra’s commentary on Exodus is not sui generis. In fact, it is possible that Ibn Ezra hoped to write a L.C. on all five books of the Torah. Be that as it may, it appears that Ibn Ezra wrote two long commentaries, one on Genesis and one on Exodus and that the one on Exodus survived.

The fact that a student added a note to Ibn Ezra’s comment on Ex. 12:9 does not prove that the entire work was composed by a student or students. On the contrary, the fact that the student or copyist bothered to point out that the comment which follows was not written by Ibn Ezra indicates that what precedes and follows his quote did. Furthermore, Ibn Ezra’s students occasionally inserted their comments into his other works as well. (See Mal. 1:12 and Ps. 119:103. For a full listing see Melamed, Ezra Tzion. Mefareshe Ha-Mikra, Vol. 2, p. 535. Jerusalem, 1978.) Is one to say that these works did not originate with Ibn Ezra because of the insertions?

The fact that some of the interpretations in the L.C. contradict some of those in the short commentaries is not proof that these commentaries are not the work of one hand. First of all, the contradictions are not in basic philosophical outlook. If the S.C. believed in God’s corporeality while the L.C. did not, or if the S.C. claimed that astrology is not a true science while the L.C. believed that it was, then it would indicate that these two commentaries are not the work of the same person. However, these are not the sorts of contradictions that differentiate the long and short commentaries. We have differences in the interpretation of Biblical verses. Thus the L.C. explains God’s statement, About midnight will I go out into the midst of Egypt (Ex. 11:4) as referring to God’s decree while the S.C. says it refers to God’s messenger. No author is totally consistent over the years. Indeed, it would be strange for an author to repeat himself exactly in a later book. Furthermore, I.E. was constantly on the move. He may not have had copies of his earlier books with him when he wrote his later books. In fact, it is almost certain that they were not in front of him when he wrote, for when Ibn Ezra repeats himself he never does so exactly, as would an author who has his earlier writing in front of him.

In his comments on Ex 3:6 Ibn Ezra writes, “I have already explained in the Sefer Hashem.” Had a student of Ibn Ezra composed the work, he would have written that this is already explained in the Sefer Hashem. It is highly unlikely that one of Ibn Ezra’s students would assume the mantle of his teacher. Incidentally, the phrase u-khvar pirashti, or the like, is one of Ibn Ezra’s idiosyncratic expressions. Its use here is further proof of Ibn Ezra’s authorship of the L.C.

It should also be noted that when Nahmanides (d. 1273) quotes Ibn Ezra’s comments on Exodus he quotes from the L.C. (See Nahmanides’ commentary on Ex. 2:1,25; 3:2,13; 4:1; 14:19; 28:30). If the L.C. was not the work of Ibn Ezra then Nahmanides would most probably have heard any doubts about authenticity and would not have quoted from it as Ibn Ezra’s.

Furthermore, the L.C. contains the ideas and words of Abraham ibn Ezra. Despite its length, practically each sentence and almost every word in this work bear all the idiosyncrasies of Ibn Ezra. Moreover, the ideas and the theology of the L.C. are the same as those of the S.C.

Like all medieval Jewish philosophers, Ibn Ezra believed that God was incorporeal. He interpreted metaphorically all Biblical verses that speak of God. Thus in commenting on Gen. 1:23, Ibn Ezra writes, “We know that the Torah spoke the language of man, for it was given to human beings who speak and hear. Now a human being cannot speak of things above or below him without employing human terminology. Hence Scripture uses such terms as the mouth of the earth (Num. 16:30), the hand of the Jordan (Num. 13:29), and the head of the dust of the world (Prov. 8:26).” (See Secret of the Torah, a translation of Ibn Ezra’s Yesod Morah.) He makes the same point, employing almost though not exactly the same words, in his comments on Ex. 19:20 and in his Yesod Morah.

Ibn Ezra stresses the fact that ideas not words are what count. Thus he notes in chapter one of the Yesod Morah, “The prophets do not preserve the exact wording when they repeat something. They only preserve its substance. For that is what is important.”

He similarly explains in his commentary on Gen. 5:29 why Noah was called No’ach (rest), not Menachem, even though Scripture tells us that Noah was so called because Lemach his father said, This same shall comfort us (yenachamenu) in our work. Ibn Ezra there observes, “Comfort is a relaxation (or rest) of the heart’s pain. The Hebrews are more concerned with the idea expressed by a word than with its etymology.”

This is precisely how Ibn Ezra resolves the differences in wording between the Decalogue in Exodus and that of Deuteronomy. Ibn Ezra writes, “Know, words are like bodies and their meanings are like souls” (Ex. 20:1). He goes on to say that the words used are unimportant if the meaning remains unchanged.

Similarly, Ibn Ezra says that it makes no difference whether Scripture employs full or defective spelling. Thus in the introduction to his commentary on the Torah he writes, “I will not make mention of the reasons offered by the Masoretes as to why certain words are at times spelled full and at other times defectively because all their reasons are of a midrashic nature. The fact is that Scripture sometimes fully and clearly spells out a word and at other times omits an unpronounced letter for the sake of brevity. Since the Masoretes claim to be able to explain the reasons for full and defective spellings, let them tell us what spelling the scribes should have used in writing Scripture.” He makes the same point employing similar language in Ex. 20:1.

In Ex. 3:15 Ibn Ezra explains the numerical significance of the letters making up the divine name. What he writes there is parallel to what he writes in his Sefer Ha-Shem and in chapter eleven of the Yesod Morah.

Ibn Ezra was an astrologer, and many of his Biblical interpretations are based on astrological beliefs. He thus hints that the flood came about as a result of unfavorable heavenly conjunctions (Gen. 14:4), and that Noah took the “aspects” into consideration when he sent the raven and doves from the ark (Gen. 8:5). He also offers an astrological interpretation for Laban’s teraphim (Gen. 14:19).

We find the same astrological influence in the L.C. Ibn Ezra thus offers an astrological interpretation for the breastplate and the urim and thumim worn by the high priest (Ex. 38:6). Incidentally this interpretation is essentially the same as the one he offers for these objects in chapter nine of his Yesod Morah. He also speaks of the influence of the stars in his comments on Ex. 20:14 and 14:2. Ibn Ezra’s explanation of the idol Baal-Zephon in Ex. 14:2 is in keeping with his explanation of Laban’s teraphim in Genesis; that is, Ibn Ezra interprets them as astrological objects.

In his comments on Ex. 29:18 Ibn Ezra claims that it is wrong to seek medical care for natural illnesses. He goes on to say that Scripture criticized King Asa of Judah for seeking the aid of physicians rather than that of the Lord. Ibn Ezra makes this same point in chapter seven of the Yesod Morah.

On Ex. 20:1 he claims there is a reason behind each and every commandment in Scripture and that an intelligent person can discover these reasons. He makes the same point in chapter eight of the Yesod Morah.

Ibn Ezra on Ex. 20:1 notes that Abraham, who lived before the revelation at Sinai, kept only the rational laws. He makes the same point in his comments on Gen. 26:5 and in chapter five of the Yesod Morah.

In his comments on Gen. 27:19, Ibn Ezra writes, “Prophets are divided into two groups. One group consists of God’s messengers concerning commandments; the other, those who foretell the future.” He refers to the first type of prophet as sheli’ach be-mitzvot and the second type as navi ha-atid. Ibn Ezra follows this distinction in his notes on Ex. 12:1, where he notes that the commandments were revealed only through Moses and Aaron, for they alone were prophets of the law (nevi’e ha-torah).

In Ex. 14:30 Ibn Ezra says that and Israel saw the Egyptians dead upon the sea-shore is to be read as if written: and Israel upon the sea-shore saw the Egyptians dead. He makes the same point in chapter five of the Yesod Morah.

Ibn Ezra believed that reason plays an essential role in interpreting Scripture. In his comments on Ex. 20:1 he argues that Biblical statements which contradict reason are not to be taken literally. He makes the same point in the introduction to his commentary on the Torah and in the Yesod Morah (chap. 7, p. 10). He writes in the former, “Every precept, be it minor or major, must be weighed in the scale of one’s heart wherein the Eternal has planted some of His wisdom. Thus if there appears something in the Torah that is intellectually impossible to accept or contrary to the evidence of our senses, then we must search for a hidden meaning. This is so because intelligence is the basis of the Torah. The Torah was not given to ignoramuses. Man’s intelligence is the angel which mediates between him and his God.”

Although Ibn Ezra consistently emphasizes reason he often exhibits a simple faith and takes issue with those who do not interpret certain Biblical narratives literally. He disagrees with those who interpret Scripture’s account of the Garden of Eden symbolically. Ibn Ezra writes, “Note, the story of the Garden of Eden is to be interpreted literally. There is no doubt that it happened exactly as described in Scripture (Gen. 3:24).”

He comments similarly on the verse telling us that the Lord made garments of skin for Adam and Eve (Gen. 3:21). There he notes, “One should…not bother to inquire into this matter. We ought to believe that God made garments of skin for Adam and Eve. Who can recount all of God’s mighty acts? Who can tell of all of His wonders? There is no end to God’s greatness.”

The same trusting faith is displayed by Ibn Ezra in his remarks on the verse which relates that Moses’ staff turned into a serpent when cast on the ground (Ex. 4:3). Ibn Ezra notes that some commentators attempt to explain this phenomenon “scientifically.” However, he disagrees with their explanations, insisting that the verse deals with a miraculous occurrence.

When the rabbis of the Talmud offer an interpretation of a Biblical text which does not contradict its plain meaning, Ibn Ezra accepts the Rabbinic interpretation even though other interpretations of the text are equally plausible. Thus in the introduction to his commentary on the Pentateuch (pp. 18 and 19) Ibn Ezra writes, “However, with regard to verses which deal with laws, statutes, and regulations, if we find two possible interpretations for a verse and one of them is in keeping with the interpretation of the transmitters of tradition, all of whom were righteous men, then without reservation and with all our might we will rely on the truth of their words.” Ibn Ezra makes the same point in his comments on Lev. 22:22 and Deut. 5:25; 6:3; 25:5. He makes similar points in his L.C. on Ex. 12:2,8,22.

Ibn Ezra not only accepts Rabbinic interpretations whenever they appear to follow the plain meaning of the text, he goes a step further and defends the Rabbinic tradition against attacks made upon it by the Karaites. (See his Introduction to the Pentateuch; Lev. 7:23; 23:11; 25:9,20.) We similarly find this to be the case with the L.C. (See Ex. 12:1; 34:21; 35:2.)

Although Ibn Ezra engages in anti-Karaite polemics and refers to them as Sadducees and heretics, he occasionally quotes their interpretations with deference. (Compare Gen. 9:26; 28:12; 49:27; Lev. 16:1; 23:15.)

Ibn Ezra believes that many of the Biblical narratives are not in chronological order. He thus points out that Abraham’s call to leave his father’s house occurred before Terah left Ur of the Chaldeans even though Scripture tells us of Terah’s departure before it relates God’s call to Abraham (Gen. 12:1). He similarly notes (Gen. 38:1) that the incident of Judah and Tamar (Gen. 38) occurred before Joseph was sold into bondage even though Scripture records it after the account of Joseph’s enslavement (Gen. 37).
Ibn Ezra also points out that Lev. 25:1; 26:25,46; Num. 3:1; 19:2; Deut. 31:1; and Deut. 31:15 are not in chronological order.

He makes similar remarks on Exodus in his L.C. He thus explains that the command to record God’s eternal war with Amalek was given in the fortieth year of Israel’s sojourn in the desert even though it is recorded in Ex. 17:14.

Ibn Ezra maintains that Jethro came to the wilderness of Sinai in the second year following the Exodus from Egypt. He thus argues that Ex. 18, which tells of Jethro’s journey to Sinai, is out of chronological order. Ibn Ezra likewise maintains that Korah’s rebellion, recorded in Num. 16:17, actually took place as soon as the tabernacle was erected and Aaron was chosen as high priest (Ex. 32:29).

There are certain stylistic idiosyncrasies which reveal the L.C. to be the work of Ibn Ezra. For example, Ibn Ezra often employs a mem in the sense of “to.” Thus in Gen. 1:5, Ibn Ezra writes, “Erev (evening) is close in meaning (karov mi-ta’am) to choshekh (darkness).” He similarly writes in Gen. 2:11, “The Gihon is close to the Land of Israel (karov me-eretz yisrael).” In commenting on the word afilot (Ex. 10:31), Ibn Ezra writes, “The word afel (very dark) in Even very dark, and no brightness in it (Amos 5:20) is close in meaning to it (karov me-menu).”

When Ibn Ezra defines the meaning of a word he occasionally employs the term kemo (literally, like). (Compare, Gen. 45:11; 46:13; Lev. 24:23; 27:14; Num. 22:35; Deut. 29:8. We find that he employs the word kemo in the same way in the L.C. See Ex. 9:16; 10:8; 14:7.)

When I.E. wants to introduce a refutation of a given argument he occasionally uses the formula ve-im ta’an to’en…u-teshuvatam (if one should argue…they would answer) (Gen. 18:13) or the like (Lev. 24:43). Similarly, in the L.C. in Ex. 12:2 Ibn Ezra reads, ve-im ta’an ha-to’en…ha-teshuvah (if one should argue…the answer is).

When Ibn Ezra wants to point out that an interpretation is impossible he occasionally uses the term ekh (how). Thus in taking issue with those who identify the serpent with Satan, he writes: “How (ekh) is Satan to crawl upon his belly or eat the dust of the ground (Gen. 31)?” Ibn Ezra employs similar language in the L.C. on Ex. 15:22. There he takes issue with those who say that the booths in which the Israelites are commanded to dwell during the festival of Sukkot are in commemoration of the clouds of glory which covered the camp of Israel during their sojourn in the desert. He notes that Scripture explicitly states that the booths recall Israel’s dwelling places in the desert of Sinai. He then goes on to say, “How (ekh) did Israel dwell in clouds?”

I.E. often quotes verses from memory. In so doing, he occasionally errs. (See Ibn Ezra’s quotes from Ps. 94:4 in Gen. 36:24 and from I Kings 14:3 in Num. 32:49.) We find the same pattern in Exodus (L.C.). (See Ibn Ezra’s quote from Lev. 25:39 in Ex. 1:14 and his quote from II Kings 8:22 in Ex. 34:6.)

Ibn Ezra occasionally uses sarcasm, word plays, and puns at the expense of those with whom he disagrees. (See Gen. 9:21; 12:13; 20:16; 28:17; 36:31; Is. 7:3; Amos 3:15; Job 5:7.) We find the same sarcasm and puns in the L.C. (See Ex. 4:31; 13:13,20; 20:23; 21:35; 34:21.)

Ibn Ezra’s interpretations are often extremely down to earth. He explains that Isaac sent Esau out to hunt for food because he was very poor and had little livestock at home. He thus notes that Isaac loved Esau because he needed him to provide food for his table. Ibn Ezra explains that Esau despised the birthright because Isaac had nothing to leave him.

Ibn Ezra likewise believed that Rebecca spoke like a typical mother when she took upon herself any curse that Isaac might place upon Jacob. He likewise notes that Abraham, Jacob, and other Biblical characters were not above bending the truth when they had to.

The same down-to-earth interpretations are displayed in the L.C. Thus Ibn Ezra notes that God arranged for Moses to be raised in Pharaoh’s palace and not among the Hebrew slaves so that he would grow up with the personality of a nobleman rather than that of a slave (Ex. 2:3). Ibn Ezra similarly explains that the Israelites did not turn and fight the Egyptians who pursued them because slaves do not ordinarily wage war against their masters (Ex. 14:13). He further writes that God sentenced the generation that left Egypt to die in the desert because they did not have the emotional stamina to conquer the promised land, as they were born and bred in slavery (Ibid.).

What remains to be decided is which commentary came first; that is, did Ibn Ezra first write a S.C. and then decide to elaborate upon it, or did he write a L.C. and then decide to abridge it? Students of Ibn Ezra are divided on this point. Nevertheless, by examining and analyzing the works one can arrive at a satisfactory answer.

There is some textual evidence that the S.C. preceded the L.C. The scholar Y.L. Fleisher points out that in the S.C. on Ex. 25:31, I.E. refers to those who believe that the word te’aseh (be made) should be spelled with a yod as chasere da’at (lacking intelligence). However, in his L.C., I.E. notes that the wise men of Tiberias, who carefully went over every word in Scripture, maintain that the word te’aseh in Ex. 25:31 is spelled with a yod. I.E. does not take issue with the wise men of Tiberias. He merely notes that in the Spanish editions of the Torah the word is spelled without a yod. He then goes on say that according to the rules of grammar the word should be spelled without a yod, and if the Tiberian reading is correct then te’aseh in Ex. 25:31 is an exception to the rule.

It is thus clear that when I.E. wrote the S.C. he was not aware of the opinion of the Tiberian scholars, but he was aware of it when he wrote the L.C. This indicates that the S.C. came first. Otherwise we have to assume that I.E. was aware of the opinion of the Tiberians, mentioned them in his commentary, and then forgot their opinion, referring to those who held a similar opinion as “lacking intelligence.” That hardly makes sense.

Furthermore, if one writes a long commentary and abbreviates it, then a comparison of the two works indicates that one is an abridged version of the other. This is not the case with the L.C. and S.C. While there are parallels between the commentaries, and some materials of the S.C. are in the L.C., the short commentary does not seem to be an abridged version of the long commentary. It thus appears that I.E. wrote a S.C. on the Pentateuch and then a long commentary.

Finally, it is clear that the S.C. on Exodus fits in with I.E.’s comments on Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy. They form a set. Thus there is no doubt that I.E. wrote and completed a short commentary on the Pentateuch.
We also have a second version of I.E.’s Introduction to the Pentateuch plus fragments of a long commentary on Genesis in addition to our L.C. on Exodus.

Unless there is some compelling evidence to the contrary, which there is not, the normal course of human events would dictate that I.E. first completed a short commentary on the Pentateuch and then set out to work on his long commentary. However, for one reason or another he was never able to complete his work.

One would reach the same conclusion if the opposite were true, that is, if we had a long commentary on the entire Pentateuch and a short commentary on Genesis and Exodus. In that case, we would say that I.E. first completed his long commentary and then started work on a short commentary which he never completed.

The latter becomes even more compelling when we consider the fact that at the age of sixty-four I.E. became ill and promised to write a commentary on the Pentateuch if God would restore him to health. Furthermore, in the L.C., in his poem introducing the Torah portion Yitro, I.E. alludes to his weakened condition. He speaks of the loss of half of his strength and of being a prisoner of hope, i.e., hoping to be restored to full health.

Finally, I.E. refers to his commentary on Exodus as “the very ark…which the author prepared for himself.” The “ark” alludes to a coffin. I.E. is apparently saying that his commentary will serve as his memorial. This certainly appears to be the writing of a person who feels that his life is drawing to a close.

In conclusion, the likely scenario is that I.E. completed what we now consider the short commentary on the Pentateuch, and then started writing his long commentary. He was able to complete only the commentary on Genesis, which is lost except for a few extracts, and the long commentary on Exodus, which we have. He died before he could write any more.
H. Norman Strickman
Touro College
24 Tevet, 5756
January 16, 1996

chapter.title: CHAPTER 1
chapter.p: May the writer and the reader be strong and steadfast1 in the very ark2 which is the house which the author prepared for himself.
I now begin to explain the Torah portion, Shemot; which opens the second Book of the Torah.

1. NOW THESE ARE. Our book opens with a vav3 because the end of Genesis relates that Joseph saw the children of the third generation (Genesis 50:23).4 Scripture notes that Joseph’s brothers were few in number when they descended to Egypt but that they were fruitful and multiplied there (Exodus 1:7).

The word elleh (these) and el (these) are employed equally with the masculine and the feminine. We thus find, For all these abominations (ha-to’evot ha-el)5 (Leviticus 18:27) and then afterward, any of these abominations (ha-to’evot ha-elleh) (Lev. 18:29). We similarly read, unto these men (la-anashim ha-el) (Gen. 19:8); These four (arba’at elleh) were born to the giant (II Samuel 21:22); and what can I do this day for these (la-elleh) my daughters (Gen. 31:43). The same is the case with the word laz (that one).6 We thus find, that Shunamite (ha-shunammit ha-laz) (II Kings 4:25) and this young man (ha-na’ar ha-laz) (Zechariah 2:8). The fact that the word elleh is penultimately accented indicates that its heh is superfluous.7 It is like the heh of laylah (night)8 and the heh of nachlah (brook) in the Brook of (nachlah) Egypt (Numbers 34:5).9

[THE NAMES OF.] Shem (name) is masculine. Its plural form is shemot (names), for the tav is used for both the masculine and the feminine.10 Compare, mekomot (places)11 and avot (fathers). The mem is similarly used as a masculine and feminine plural. Compare, nashim (women) and pilagshim (concubines).12 We also find some nouns employing both the tav and the mem in the plural forms. Compare, nefashim (souls) (Ezekiel 13:20) and nefashot (souls)13 (Ezek. 13:18). We similarly find, levavot (hearts) (II Chronicles 28:9) and levavim (hearts).14 Compare, al livvehen (upon their hearts)15 (Nahum 2:8).

[Into Egypt.] The heh of mitzrayemah (into Egypt) is in place of the word el (to). Compare, dotayenah (to Dothan) in nelekh dotayenah (let us go down to Dothan) (Gen. 37:16); and yerushalayemah (to Jerusalem) in and brought me in the vision of God to Jerusalem (Ezek. 8:3).16
WITH JACOB. Et ya’akov means with Jacob.17 Compare, In that day the Lord made a covenant with (et) Abram (Gen. 15:18).

EVERY MAN CAME WITH HIS HOUSEHOLD. Beto (his household) refers to those who came out of his loins. The term bayit (house, household) in Scripture never refers to a wife.18 Every man came with his household (beto) is proof of this, for the wives of the tribes are not included in the seventy who descended into Egypt.19 Do not permit the verse and (the high priest shall) have made atonement for himself, and for his household (beto) (Lev. 16:18) to cause you any difficulty.20 For according to the plain meaning of the text, beto (his household) refers to his father’s house. Beto (his household) must be so interpreted because the high priest made three confessions on the Day of Atonement.21 The priest’s helpmate, who is his wife, is included in the term for himself. She is included with him because a husband and a wife make a “man.”22

2. REUBEN. When a word beginning with a letter that is vocalized with a mobile sheva (sheva na), e.g., the zayin of Zevulun, has a bet, vav, kaf, or lamed prefixed to it, the prefix ideally should also be vocalized with a mobile sheva.23 However, due to the impossibility of sounding two mobile sheva’im in succession these prefixes are vocalized with a chirik rather than with a sheva. Hence if the word zevulun has a bet prefixed to it we say bi-zevulun (in Zebulun), If zevulun has a kaf or lamed prefixed to it we say ki-zevulun (like Zebulun) or li-zevulun (to Zebulun). However, if the word has a vav prefixed to it then it is vocalized with a shuruk rather than a chirik. We sound the vav as if it had an alef preceding it and pronounce the word u-zevulun (and Zebulun) for the word is sounded as if it were written alef vav plus zevulun.24 However, if we deal with a word whose first letter is a yod, an example being the name yehudah, then the yod is silent, for the yod is one of the quiescent letters.25 Compare, biyhudah (against Judah) in Let us go up against Judah (Isaiah 7:6) and kiyhudah (like Judah) and liyhudah (of Judah) in Of Judah, Nahshon (Num. 1:7). In the latter case the yod is silent and is not perceived or felt when the word is enunciated. The same is also the case when a vav is prefixed to the word yehudah. The word is pronounced viyhudah.
The tribes are here listed in order of their births.26

3. ISSACHAR. Because the two sins in yissachar (Issachar) are written in succession only one is sounded. Compare, the word machtzetzrim (did blow) (I Chron. 15:24), which is pronounced machtzerim.27 We do not find a similar case with regard to the sin in Scripture.28

It is customary for the Hebrews to pronounce a vav prefixed to the labials which are related to the vav, namely, the bet, mem, peh with an alef added to it,29 and to vocalize the vav with a shuruk. Compare, u-faru (and they shall be fruitful) in and they shall be fruitful and multiply (Jeremiah 23:3); and u-male’u (shall be full) in and the houses of the Egyptians shall he full of swarms of flies (Ex. 8:17). The word u-vinyamin (and Benjamin) is similar. Benjamin is listed before the children of the handmaidens30 because he was a son of one of Jacob’s wives.

4. DAN. Names are connected to each other in Scripture in six different ways. All of these styles are correct. One way of listing names is, Elam, and Asshur, and Arpachshad (Gen. 10:22).31 A second manner is, with carbuncles, purple, and richly woven work, and fine linen (Ezek. 27:16).32 A third way is, carnelian, topaz, and smaragd (Ex. 28:17).33 A fourth way is, Dan and Naphtali, Gad and Asher.34 The fifth is, Myrrh, and aloes, and cassia (Psalms 45:9).35 The sixth way is, Adam, Seth, Enosh (I Chron. 1:1).36

5. WERE. The word yehi (let it be)37 should have been vocalized like the word yirev (the multitude)38 in and the multitude of the burdens against him (II Chron. 24:27). However, since the heh is a guttural, the word yehi is vocalized with a segol39 beneath the first yod and the word is read yehi. Furthermore, the final yod of yehi should have been pronounced with a sounded sheva nach (a quiescent sheva) as is the case with the word yirev. The word should thus have been pronounced yihey. However, because of the difficulty involved in the enunciation of the word in the aforementioned manner, the yod40 was silenced and we vocalized the heh with a chirik. Hence the word is pronounced yehi (sheva beneath the yod) as in, Behold, would it might be (yehi) according to thy word (Gen. 30:34), or yehi (segol beneath the yod), as in For He spoke, and it was (va-yehi) (Ps. 33:9). The accent is placed on the last syllable of yehi and a sheva is placed beneath its yod41 because the word is used often in conversation, as in So be (yehi khen) the Lord (Ex. 10:10). Therefore only this root and the root of va-yechi in And Jacob lived42 (Gen. 47: 28) are found to have an imperfect yod prefix vocalized with a sheva43 when conjugated in the kal. The reason for this is that two letters of the two roots va-yechi and va-yehi consist of the quiescent letters yod, heh, the root of one being heh, yod, heh and that of the other chet, yod, heh. Now since the yod and the heh are quiescent letters and are at times not pronounced at the end of a word, the yod prefix is vocalized with a sheva. We do not find any such other case in the kal.
THAT CAME OUT OF THE LOINS OF JACOB. Loins allude to the male organ which is located near the loins.44 It is similar to and Saul went to cover his feet (I Sam. 24:4).45

The offspring of Jacob who descended to Egypt really numbered sixty-nine, not including Jacob who should be counted first. The Pentateuch therefore first states et ya’akov (with Jacob), the meaning of which is as we have noted earlier.46 In the first listing of Jacob’s descendants in the Torah portion va-yiggash (then Judah came near unto him) (Gen. 44:18), Scripture states, And these are the names of the children of Israel who came unto Egypt, Jacob and his sons47 (Gen. 46:8). Thus with Jacob, all the souls of his sons and his daughters (descended from Jacob and Leah) were thirty and three (Gen. 46:15).48 The verse Thy fathers went down into Egypt with threescore and ten souls49 (Deuteronomy 10:22) is proof that Jacob is counted among the seventy, for Jacob had a soul. Similarly, Joseph and his two sons who were in Egypt are also included in the seventy.50

6. AND JOSEPH DIED AND ALL THAT GENERATION. A father and his son comprise two generations.51 Proof of this52 is the fact that after Job’s fortune was changed for the better, he lived a hundred and forty years and saw four generations53 (Job 42:16). Furthermore, our sages tell us that there were ten generations from Adam to Noah and ten generations from Noah to Abraham (Abot 5:2, 3). Now the years of each of the aforementioned generations were different one from the other.54 The meaning of And Joseph died is that he died in his greatness.55 Similarly, his brothers also did not see the evil days which followed.56
[AND ALL THAT GENERATION.] This refers to the Egyptians. For Scripture goes on to note, Now there arose a new king over Egypt, who knew not Joseph (v. 8).
7. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL WERE FRUITFUL. They produced children as a tree produces fruit.57

AND INCREASED ABUNDANTLY. Va-yishretzu (and increased abundantly) is similar to the word yishretzu (swarm) in Let the waters swarm (yishretzu) (Gen. 1:20). However, in the first instance58 the verb is independent.59 It is like the verbs went, sat, stood, and lay. In the second instance60 the verb is dependent upon something else. It is like the verbs ate, kept, and hired. We thus say, he ate the bread, he kept the thing, and he hired the donkey. The latter are called transitive verbs. Now yishretzu (swarm) in yishretzu ha-mayim (Let the waters swarm) is a transitive verb, while va-yishretzu (and increased abundantly) is an intransitive verb. Thus the root shin, resh, zadi is sometimes transitive and sometimes intransitive. It is like the root of the word shav61 which is at times intransitive as in and (God) will return (ve-shav) and gather (Deut. 30:3) and at times transitive, as in that then the Lord thy God will turn (ve-shav) thy captivity (Ibid.). It is possible that the word va-yishretzu alludes to the fact that the Israelite wives gave birth to twins and even more.62 I myself have seen the quadruplets that a women gave birth to. Physicians tell us that a woman can have as many as seven fetuses in her womb at one time.
AND MULTIPLIED. They did not die in proportion to that of a large nation.63
AND WAXED EXCEEDINGLY MIGHTY. They had strong bones.64

[EXCEEDINGLY.] The phrase bi-me’od me’od (exceedingly) indicates that there could not possibly have been any more of them.65 The bet of bi-me’od me’od is like the bet of ba-rishonah (first) in and they took their first journey (Num. 10:13), for we also encounter the term with out the bet in they shall set forth first (rishonah) (Num. 2:9).66

AND THE LAND WAS FILLED WITH THEM. The land of Goshen, also known as the land of Rameses.67 Rameses is sounded with a quiescent sheva beneath the ayin, for the first sheva in Rameses, the sheva beneath the ayin which is connected to the resh, is called a sheva nach. The second sheva, the one beneath the mem, is called a sheva na (mobile sheva)68 because the lips seem to begin to first move when it is uttered.69

8. NOW THERE AROSE A NEW KING. This is to be taken literally without any embellishments.70 Scripture reads, and there arose (va-yakam) because the new king was not of the royal seed. It is like that my son hath stirred up (hekim)71 my servant to lie in wait against me (I Sam. 22:8).
9. AND HE SAID UNTO HIS PEOPLE. The Egyptians.72

BEHOLD THE PEOPLE. The word am (people) is not in the construct with bene yisrael (the children of Israel). The term bene yisrael explains am and provides additional information concerning its meaning.73 It is like the words That I Am in the phrase I Am That I Am (Ex. 3:14)74 and the words Abraham and Isaac in the verse The God before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac did walk (Gen. 48:15).75

FOR US. When the word mi-mennu (for us) is in the plural76 the books of the Babylonians77 adhere to the grammatical rule78 and always omit the dagesh in the nun in order to differentiate between mi-mennu in the plural and mi-mennu in Out of him79 (mi-mennu) shall come forth the cornerstone (Zech. 10:4). In the latter, nu is a third person singular suffix and has a dagesh placed in the nun in accordance with the grammatical rule.80 However, all the books coming out of the Land of Israel81 have a dagesh in the nun of mi-mennu both in the singular and in the plural because the nun of mi-menni (from me)82 in the singular has a dagesh despite the rule.83 For the nuns of ani (I) and necheni (hath led me) in the Lord hath led me (Gen. 24:27)84 do not receive a dagesh.

Now the word min (from) is doubled,85 the nun of mi-menni receives a dagesh to make up for the missing nun of the second min, and the word is read as if written mi-menni. The nun of the first min is represented by the dagesh in the second mem of mi-menni86 and the nun of the suffix ni serves as if it were in the place of the one speaking.87 Similarly, the nun of mi-munnu in the plural, spelled mem mem nun nun vav (Gen. 23:6), receives a dagesh and is read as if written mi-mennu.88 The reason that the nun of mi-mennu (of him) in the singular receives a dagesh is to compensate for the swallowed heh,89 for it is only in a few instances when the verb yishmor (he will keep) is combined with a third person suffix that we say yishmero (he will keep him). The same is true of the word yikre’o (he shall be called) in whereby he shall be called (Jer. 23:6) and the word yirdefo (shall pursue him) in The enemy shall purse him (Hosea 8:3). The usual form of the third person suffix is yishmerehu (preserve him) (Ps. 41:8). Thus yishmero (he will keep him) is a shortened form. It is similar to hinnehu in and, behold, he (ve-hinnehu) was at his work (Jer. 18:3), in which hinnehu is a compound of hinneh (behold) and hu (he); and to ve-hinneh nitzav (and, lo he stood) (Num. 23:6).90 At other times an additional nun is added,91 as in yeshacharuneni (they will seek me earnestly) and yimtza’uneni (they will find me) in They will seek me earnestly, but they shall not find me (Proverbs 1:28). Similarly, the word tevarakhani (may bless me) in that thy soul may bless me (Gen. 27:19) is pronounced tevarekhanni because of the dagesh in the nun.92 We also find an extra nun in the word yekhabbdaneni (honoreth Me) in whoso offereth the sacrifice of thanksgiving honoreth Me (Ps. 50:23) and in the words yesovavenhu (He compassed him about), yevonanehu (He cared for him), and yitzrenhu (He kept him) (Deut. 32:10).93 At other times the third person heh suffix is swallowed by the nun, as in yishmerennu94 (kept it in) in and its owner hath not kept it in (Ex. 21:29).

10. COME (HAVAH). The word havah (give) in Give me my wife (Gen. 29:21) is in the masculine and as such is properly used there.95 It is similar to the word lekhah (come) in come, I pray thee with us.96 In the feminine we say havi, as in Bring (havi) the mantle that is upon thee (Ruth 3:15), and lekhi (go), as in Go and get thee in (I Kings 1:23). Now because these words are used often the masculine form is employed both as a plural and as a feminine singular.97 Scripture thus reads, Come (havah), let us go down (Gen. 11:7);98 Come (havah) I Pray thee, let me come in unto thee (Gen. 38:16).99 It is like Come (lekhah), let us make our father drink wine (Gen. 19:32).100
LET US DEAL WISELY. Let us search for a wise way to prevent them from multiplying.101
WITH THEM. The word lo (with them) is to be rendered, because of them.102 It is similar to the word li (of me) in say of me (Gen. 20:13).103

Note that all perfect and imperfect verbs imply a verbal noun.104 In other words, even though a noun derived from a verb is missing in the text it is implied in the verb. For example, ve-hinneh berakhta varekh (and, behold, thou hast blessed them altogether) (Num. 23:11)105 and And when He hath blessed, I cannot call it back (Num. 23:20), the meaning of which is: And when he hath blessed a blessing, I cannot call it back.106 The same is true of But in the multitude of counsellors they are established (Prov. 15:22). The complete version of the latter is: But in the multitude of counsellors, counsel is established.107 Similarly, when there befalleth us any war (v. 10) is to be interpreted as, when there befalleth us any accidents of war.108

Rabbi Merinus109 says that and get them out of the land means, and we will get us out of the land. He believes that Pharaoh said and get them out of the land so that Satan would not ensnare him in the utterances of his mouth.110 However, I see no need for this interpretation.111

11. TASKMASTERS. Missim (taskmasters) is a plural. Its singular form is mas. This word is similar in form to pittim (pieces of bread) (Lev. 2:7) and pat (piece of bread) (Gen. 18:5).112 The word comes from a stem whose second and third root letters are identical.113
[TO AFFLICT THEM.] To cause the semen of the men to dry up.114

STORE-CITIES. Miskenot means store-cities. Ha-sokhen (this steward) in unto this steward (Is. 22:15)115 and sokhenet (companion) in and be a companion for the king (I Kings 1:2) are similar.116 For the meaning of the latter verse is, let her be in charge of the king’s treasury so that no one will know that she lies in thy bosom.
RAAMSES. Has a pattach beneath the ayin and does not refer to the place where Israel dwelt.117
12. BUT THE MORE THEY AFFLICTED THEM. Even though they were afflicted.118
THE MORE THEY MULTIPLIED. As they did in the days when they were not afflicted.119

AND THE MORE THEY SPREAD ABROAD. They were fruitful and increased above and beyond the norm.120 Yifrotz (they spread abroad) is like poretz (breaketh) in And whoso breaketh through a fence (Ecclesiastes 10:8).121

13. TO SERVE. Pharaoh devised many evils with which to afflict the Israelites. First he ordered them to do his work.122 When he saw that this did not diminish their greatly increasing numbers he gave permission to the Egyptians and their princes to work them harder than slaves are normally worked. The latter is, as Onkelos explains, the meaning of the term be-farekh (with rigor). It is totally wrong to employ the form perukhim (broken) in liturgical poetry.123 When Pharaoh saw that the above measures did not stop the Israelites from increasing, he called the midwives (v. 13), the ones who were in charge of all the other midwives, and commanded them to kill all the males that were born.

14. AND THEY MADE THEIR LIVES BITTER. It is known that the tav, in a majority of instances, is the sign of the feminine plural and the mem of the masculine plural. Compare, mo’adot (seasons) (II Chron. 8:13) and mo’adim (seasons) (Gen. 1:14).124 According to the Spanish scholars verbal forms are kept and do not drop any of their root letters.125 However, this is not the case with nouns. Nouns are only employed as found in Scripture,126 for the singular of mo’adot (seasons) is mo’ed, not mo’adah as the person who thinks he is so brilliant believes.127 The latter would maintain that the plural of makom (place)128 is mekomim129 and the singular of mekomot (places) is mekomah.130 Perhaps he will open his eyes and see that the plural of bekhor (first-born) is bekhorim, as in To Him that smote Egypt in their first-born (bekhorehem) (Ps. 136:10).131 However, we also encounter the form bekhorot (firstlings) in and the firstlings of thy herd (Deut. 14:23). Now, shall the singular of bekhorot be bekhorah?132 The same is the case with levenim (bricks).133 Its singular is levenah,134 not leven.135

[IN MORTAR AND IN BRICK.] To build houses and fences.136 They also had to plow, harvest, prune, and pick olives. This is the meaning of and in all manner of service in the field. Scripture then alludes to all the other types of work which Israel did to fulfill the needs of the Egyptians by the general term in all their service.

WHEREIN THEY MADE THEM SERVE. The word avedu (they made them serve) is to be read as if written twice. Our verse is to be read as if it were written: wherein they made them serve, they made them serve with rigor.

When a verb from the root ayin, bet, dalet is not followed by a bet it refers to work performed by a slave. This is the meaning of avadatikha (I have served thee) (Gen. 30:26).137 However, when the verb is followed by a bet it has one of the following two meanings. It means for the sake of, as in va-ya’avod yisrael be-ishah (and Israel served for a wife) (Hos. 12:13).138 Its other meaning is illustrated by thou shalt not make him to serve (lo ta’avod bo) with rigor,139 which is like which hath not been wrought with (lo ubbad bah) (Deut. 21:3).140 Which may neither be plowed (lo ye’aved bo) (Deut. 21:4)141 is similar, for we find, And the land that was desolate shall be tilled (Ezek. 36:34).142 In a like manner Scripture reads, As with the lender, so with the borrower (nosheh vo) (Is. 24:2).143

15. AND THE KING OF EGYPT SPOKE TO THE HEBREW MIDWIVES. These midwives were in charge of all the other midwives. For there can be no doubt that there were more than five hundred midwives.144 These two midwives were in charge of all the other midwives and saw to it that they gave a tax to the king from the money they collected for their services. I have seen such a practice in many places. The opinion that the two midwives were mother and daughter was handed down by tradition, for it is correct.145

16. WHEN YE DO THE OFFICE OF A MIDWIFE TO THE HEBREW WOMEN. Whoever comes from the family of ever (Eber)146 is called a Hebrew. One is called a Hebrew because of his faith.147 Hence the children of Eber (Ever) in the father of all the children of Eber (Gen. 10:21) refers to those who came from the side (ever) of the river.148 The side of the river refers to one of the banks of the river.149

[THE BIRTHSTOOL.] Ben Kuraish150 says that the alef of ovnayim (birthstool) is superfluous because ovnayim comes from the same root as banim (sons).151 The meaning of ovnayim is birthstool. Ovnayim is similar to afsayim (ankles)152 in waters that were to the ankles (Ezek. 47:3). In reality, however, ovnayim is similar to ba-ovnayim (at the wheel)153 and the alef is a root letter.
THEN YE SHALL KILL HIM. In secret so that it will not become known, because he was committing an act of violence.154

[THEN SHE SHALL LIVE.] The word va-chayah (then she shall live) is irregular and presents a very difficult grammatical problem. The rules of grammar require va-chayetah155 because the heh of the root156 changes to a tav,157 as it does in the construct in the case of the word chayat (beast of)158 in and to every beast of the earth (Gen. 1:30). The reason for the change is that the heh and the tav are similar in appearance when written. The only difference between them is the extension of the dot that is within the heh. For the letter tav is first a heh. It is only when the dot is extended that it becomes a tav.159 However, the tav and the heh are pronounced completely differently.160 They also have different names.161 This proves that our form of the letters is the original Hebrew script.162

Generally speaking, the root of the word chai (lived) and the root of the word chayyim (life) are in doubt, for the grammarians have concluded that the root of the word chai (lived) in And Arpachshad lived (Gen. 11:12) is chet, yod, yod. The word tam (spent) in how that our money is all spent (Gen. 47:18) is similar, for it comes from the root tav, mem, mem.163 The grammarians also agree that the plural of the root chet, yod, yod is chayyim (life). However, in my opinion we are dealing with an irregular root.164 If this is not so165 let someone show me a case where this root is conjugated in the imperfect according to the paradigm of chet, gimel, gimel, namely, achog (I will celebrate), tachog (you will celebrate), yachog (he will celebrate), la-chog (to celebrate).166 If the root of chai were chet, yod, yod, it should be conjugated achoy, yachoy, la-choy in the imperfect or like sov (go about) or sobu (walk about) in Walk about Zion (Ps. 48:13) and sobbi (go about)167 in Go about the city (Is. 23:16). This is proof that the word chai comes from a root ending in a heh. The fact that we do not find the root of chai conjugated in any of the above-mentioned forms is proof that it belongs to those verbs whose stems end in a heh,168 for we say echeyeh (I will live), nichyeh (we will live), eheyeh (I will be), tiheyeh (you will be), yiheyeh (he will be), all of which come from the root heh, yod, heh. Now if this is the case it comes from the root chet, yod, heh and is like the word haya (was).169 The fact that we find the word chai (lived) employed as a third person perfect in arpachshad chai (Arpachshad lived) (Gen. 11:12) does not disturb us.170 We are not bothered by the aforementioned even though it appears that chai comes from a double root.171 What forced me to come to this conclusion is the fact that I saw that there is no root in Hebrew that ends in a vav.172 The word shalev (at ease) (Job 16:12) does not disprove my contention.173 Its vav is in place of a heh,174 since the letters alef, heh, vav, yod interchange. Proof that what I say is correct is the word shalu (secure) in Wherefore are all they secure that deal treacherously (Job 12:1). For the root of shalu is shin, lamed, heh.175

I will now explain to you why a vav is never employed as a third letter of a root. The latter is so because the vav serves as a third person singular suffix, as in the words avdo va-amato (his man-servant nor his maid-servant) (Ex. 20:14). The vav also serves as the sign of the plural, as in peru u-revu (be fruitful and multiply) (Gen. 1:22). There are also superfluous vavs, as in beno be’or (the son of Beor) (Num. 24:3).176 Now if the vav was also used as the final letter of a root it would be confused with one of the three types of vavs that we have just mentioned, namely, the vav indicating a third person singular suffix, the vav indicating a plural, and the superfluous vav; we could not then ascertain the meaning of the word.177 The same is also true of the yod. The yod cannot serve as the final letter of a stem because it is used as a first person singular suffix, as in the word yadi (my hand) (Gen. 42:37). It is also employed as a first person plural suffix, as in the word yadai (my hands) (Deut. 9:15). It is also the sign of the plural construct, as in yede (the hands of) in The hands of women full of compassion (Lamentations 4:10). It is used as the sign of the feminine imperative, as in de’i and re’i (know and consider) (I Sam. 25:17). It is used to indicate relationship, as in ha-ivri o ha-ivriyah (a Hebrew man or a Hebrew woman) (Deut. 15:22). The yod is also used superfluously in verbs, as in ha-magbihi (that is enthroned) (Ps. 113:5) and in le-hoshivi (that He may set him) (Ps. 113:8).178 It is used superfluously with nouns, as in beni atono (his ass’s colt) (Gen. 49:11)179 and also with particles, as in zulati (save) (Deut. 1:36) and minni ephrayim (out of Ephraim) (Judges 5:14).180 For these reasons the yod is not employed as a final root letter lest it be confused with one of the above-noted yods. Therefore I maintain that the word va-chayah (then shall she live) is irregular and is a variant of va-chayetah. It belongs, as I have already explained, in the family of verbs ending in a heh.
17. BUT THE MIDWIVES FEARED GOD. The alef in va-tirena (feared) is not sounded lest the verb be thought to come from the root resh, alef, heh.181
BUT SAVED. Even more than at first, they now worked with all of their strength to save the children. Otherwise what need was there for Scripture to be so verbose?182

18. AND THE KING OF EGYPT CALLED FOR THE MIDWIVES, AND SAID UNTO THEM. You deserve to die183 because you have not obeyed my command.184 There is no difference in the form of the word va-tomarnah (said) in which the vav is vocalized with a pattach when it is in the third person perfect, like the word va-tokhalnah (did eat) in And the ill-favoured, and lean-fleshed kine did eat (Gen. 41:4), and when it is used as a second person perfect.185 The meaning of our verse is: Why have ye done this thing and preserved the man-children alive?
19. AND THE MIDWIVES SAID UNTO PHARAOH. We have not violated your command because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women; they have greater vitality.

The yod of the word chayot (lively) in For they are lively does not have a dagesh. This is correct Hebrew usage. Compare, davot (ill), ravot (satiated), and alot (giving suck) in the flocks and herds giving suck are a care to me (Gen. 33:13). However, the yod in the word chayyim does receive a dagesh because chayyim is an adjective. Compare, ve-nitpesem chayyim (we shall take them alive) (II Kings 7:12) in which the yod in chayyim (alive) is like the yod of ha-ivriyyim (the Hebrews) in the God of the Hebrews (Ex. 3:18). The word chayyim (life) also receives a dagesh when it is a noun, as in etz chayyim (a tree of life) (Prov. 3:18). Similarly, the tzadi of tzitzim (flowers) in and open flowers (II Kings 6:18) receives a dagesh.

AND ARE DELIVERED. Ve-yaladu (and are delivered) is a feminine perfect. The third person perfect has the same form in the masculine and the feminine. Compare, tavu (did spin) (Ex. 35:25) and tzave’u (did service) (Ex. 38:8).

20. AND GOD DEALT WELL. When a root begins with a yod, the yod does not always drop out when the verb is conjugated,186 The word va-yetev (dealt well) is an example. At other times a vav is substituted for the yod, as in va-yoshev (He maketh to dwell) in And there He maketh the hungry to dwell (Ps. 107:36). The root of va-yoshev is yod, shin, bet, as the root of va-yetev is yod, tet, bet.187
And God dealt well is explained by what follows next, i.e., He (God) made them houses. The meaning of He made them houses is similar to that the Lord make thee a house (II Sam. 7:11).188

21. AND IT CAME TO PASS, BECAUSE THE MIDWIVES FEARED GOD. Because the midwives did not fear the king of Egypt but feared the Lord, the Lord dealt well with them. Note that the verb yare’u (feared) is neither transitive nor intransitive, because its meaning is, to be afraid of someone.189 Hence the correct way of saying “feared the Lord” would be yare’u me’et Adonai.190 Obadiah used a short form when he said, yare et Adonai (fear the Lord) (I Kings 18:12).191 It is for this reason that the word nora (revered)192 does not come in the nifal form as the words nolad (was born) (I Chron. 2:3), nishbar (broken) (Ps. 51:19), and ve-nidkeh (and contrite) (Ibid.) do.193 The intelligent will understand why.194

22. AND PHARAOH CHARGED. All who occupy the throne of Egypt are called Pharaoh in the Egyptian language.195 Scripture does not relate the name of this Pharaoh as it does in the case of Pharaoh-neco (Jer. 46:2) who was so called in the tongue of his people.196 The same is the case with Pharaoh Hophra (Jer. 44:30).197
THAT IS BORN. Ha-yillod (that is born) is an adjective. It is like gibbor (warrior) and shikkor (drunk).
chapter.ftnote: 1 This poem is found in Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed editions omit it as they do many of the other poems which introduce Torah portions in I.E.’s Commentary on Exodus. Some manuscripts open with the following introduction: Abraham’s commentary on the book of Exodus, finished in the year 4913 (1152-53 C.E.), is as precious as onyx. However, other commentaries give the date 4927 (1166-67 C.E.) as the date of the manuscript’s completion. E. Levine notes, “Some writers have held that the 1152-53 date refers to the long commentary whereas the inscription 1166-67 refers to the short commentary; others have maintained that the 1152-53 refers to the short commentary and the 1166-67 refers to the long commentary which was written precisely between 1159 and 1167 C.E.” See Foreword.

2 In Hebrew, ba-aron be-kemutzot. The reference is to I.E.’s commentary on Exodus. Commenting on the word ba-aron (in a coffin) in Gen. 50:26, I.E. explains, “The reason why ba-aron is vocalized with a kamatz is that it signifies the coffin which he had prepared for himself.” (See notes on Gen. 50:26.) The word aron can refer to an ark or to a coffin. I.E. is being a bit morbid.

3 The book of Exodus opens with the word ve-elleh which literally means, and these are, and is so translated by I.E. The question thus arises, why open a book with a connective? Indeed, Deut. 1:1 opens with elleh ha-devarim and not with ve-elleh ha-devarim. Similarly, Exodus should have read elleh shemot and not ve-elleh shemot.

4 Genesis concludes by relating that Joseph saw the children of the third generation, i.e., that he was fruitful. However, it does not tell us about the fate of his brothers. The latter is related to us at the beginning of Exodus where we are told that the children of Israel were fruitful, and increased abundantly (Ex. 1:7). Thus the opening part of Exodus is connected to the closing section of Genesis. Hence the connective vav.
5 The word to’evot (abominations) is feminine.
6 It too is employed both with the masculine and the feminine.
7 The basic word being el. The heh added to the word has no meaning.
8 The basic word being layil.
9 The usual form is nachal.
10 Hence the word shemot can be a plural masculine. I.E. makes this point because generally speaking only feminine plurals end in a tav.
11 Its singular is makom, which is masculine.
12 These words are obviously feminine.
13 Nefesh is feminine.
14 Levav (heart) is masculine.
15 Livvehen is made up of the plural levavim plus the suffix for their.
16 Yerushalayemah is equivalent to el yerushalayim (to Jerusalem) and dotayenah to el dotan (to Dothan). Similarly, mitzrayemah is equivalent to el mitzrayim (to Egypt).
17 Et is usually placed before the direct object. Here it is used as a preposition meaning with.

18 The Talmud uses the term bayit (house) as a synonym for wife. Cf. Sabbath 118b: “Rabbi Jose said, I never called my wife, my wife but I called her my house.” Also see Yoma 2a, “Beto zo ishto (His household [Lev. 16:18] refers to his wife).”

19 Gen. 46:8-27 lists the seventy descendants of Jacob who came to Egypt. Women are not enumerated. In fact they are specifically excluded (Gen. 46: 26). This proves that beto does not mean one’s wife.

20 The Pentateuch states that on the Day of Atonement the high priest shall make atonement for himself and for his household. Prima facie, “his household” seems to refer to the wife of the high priest. See end of note 18.

21 The Torah states that the high priest shall make atonement for himself, and for his household and for all the assembly of Israel (Lev. 16:18). According to the Talmud the making of atonement refers to confession of sins (viduy). Cf. Yoma 36b. The three confessions offered by the high priest were on behalf of himself (for himself), on behalf of the house of Aaron (his household), and on behalf of the people of Israel (and for all the assembly of Israel).
22 Cf. Yevamot 63a: “Any Jew that has no wife is not a man.” Also see Gen. 1:27, And God created man…male and female created He them.

23 The bet, vav, kaf, and lamed are prepositional prefixes. They are usually vocalized with a mobile sheva. I.E. explains the rules of the vocalization of the prefixes in this note because a connective vav is prefixed to many of the names of the sons of Jacob listed in our chapter.
24 Vav is the sign of the shuruk. I.E. explains that a shuruk is sounded as if spelled alef vav; i.e., it is pronounced ooh.

25 The quiescent letters are the alef, heh, vav, and yod. These letters surrender their consonantal function by coalescing with surrounding vowel signs at the end of a syllable or word. Thus the yod following a chirik or tzere is not sounded as a consonant. Hence the term quiescent letters.

26 In the order in which they were born to their mothers. First Leah’s children are listed in the order of their birth. Then Rachel’s son Benjamin is listed. The children of the wives are followed by the children of the handmaids. The latter are also listed in the order that their mothers bore them. Joseph is listed last because he was in Egypt when the others arrived there (Krinsky).
27 The word is spelled with two tzadis in succession. However, only one tzadi is sounded. Similarly, yissachar is pronounced yisachar.
28 There is no other instance in Scripture where two sins are written in succession and only one is pronounced (Krinsky).
29 See note 24. The vav is a labial. Before a labial the vav is not pronounced like a labial but is pronounced “ooh” so as not to have two labials back to back.
30 Even though he was born last.
31 A connective vav (and) is placed before each of the names that follows the first name (Krinsky).
32 A connective vav is placed after the first two names in a list.
33 A vav is placed before the last name in the list.
34 Our verse. A vav is placed before each of the second names in a list.
35 The vav is omitted before the last name. The verse literally reads, Myrrh, and aloes, cassia are all thy garments.
36 No connective vav is employed.
37 Va-yehi (were) is the word yehi with a conversive vav.

38 When a word from a root that ends in a heh is conjugated in the shortened third person imperfect kal form, the yod prefix is vocalized with a chirik and the first root letter with a segol. Compare, yiven (he will build), yigel (he will uncover). Thus yehi should have been vocalized yihey.
39 It is so vocalized when a pausal.
40 That is, the last yod.
41 That is, the yod prefix.
42 From the root chet, yod, heh.
43 An imperfect yod prefix is usually vocalized with a chirik in the kal.
44 In other words, loins is a euphemism for penis.
45 Here feet is a euphemism for penis.
46 See I.E.’s comment on verse 1.

47 Gen. 46 lists the descendants of Jacob who came to Egypt. Like Ex. 1:4, it gives their number as 70. In introducing the names of those who came to Egypt it tells us that the list includes Jacob and his sons.
48 Those descended from Jacob and Leah actually numbered 32. They number 33 only if Jacob is included in the count.
49 Translated according to I.E. Since Jacob had a soul he must be included in the 70 souls that came down to Egypt.
50 Even though Joseph is mentioned after the number 70.
51 In other words, a generation does not refer to a fixed number of years.
52 That a generation does not refer to a fixed number of years.

53 The four generations come to 140 years (Weiser). However, elsewhere in Scripture four generations come to more than 140 years. For example, the four generations that the Israelites dwelt in Egypt lasted 210 years. For other interpretations see Netter and Krinsky.

54 The ten generations from Adam to Noah comprised more years than the ten generations from Noah to Abraham, for the antediluvian patriarchs lived much longer than the postdiluvian patriarchs. See chapters 5, 10, and 11 of Genesis. We thus see that a generation does not comprise a fixed number of years.
55 Joseph’s death is reported before Scripture relates the rise of the new king over Egypt. Hence the implication that Joseph died while still serving in his royal position (Weiser).
56 Their deaths are also recorded as occurring before the rise of the new king (Weiser).
57 In other words, were fruitful means produced children.
58 Va-yishretzu in our verse.
59 It is intransitive.
60 Yishretzu in Gen. 1:20.
61 Its root is shin, vav, bet.

62 Since the root of va-yishretzu is shin, resh, zadi our verse is to be rendered, the children of Israel swarmed (va-yishretzu); i.e., they multiplied like insects. See also Rashi, quoting Shemot Rabbah, that they bore six children at each birth.
63 They multiplied because they had a low death rate.
64 I.E. renders va-ya’atzmu (and waxed mighty) as, and they had (large) bones, for va-ya’atzmu comes from the root ayin, tzadi, mem meaning bone.
65 This is the reason that the word me’od (exceedingly) is repeated.
66 The bet is superfluous. The text could have read, me’od me’od (exceedingly), and the meaning would have remained the same. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 1:1 and the notes thereto.
67 Rameses where Israel dwelt is not to be identified with the store-city Raamses (v. 12) which Israel built for Pharaoh. See I.E. on Gen. 47:1.
68 Or vocative sheva.
69 Na means to move. A sheva na opens a syllable. The lips begin to move when a new syllable is pronounced.
70 Contra the opinion in the Talmud a new king refers to the old king whose “decrees were new” (Sotah 11a).
71 Literally, set up or made to arise. Saul accused his son Jonathan of wanting to place David on the throne of Israel. We thus see that to arise refers to a new dynasty.
72 His people does not refers to his advisers or nobles. It refers to the common people (Krinsky).

73 The text reads am bene yisrael (the people of the children of Israel). Prima facie, am is in the construct with bene yisrael, and the meaning of our text is the people of the children of Israel. I.E. disagrees. He holds that our text is to be interpreted as follows: the people, i.e., the children of Israel.
74 That I Am elaborates upon I Am. The phrase is to be understood as I Am, that is, That I Am.
75 Abraham and Isaac elaborate my fathers.
76 The word mi-mennu may mean from him or from us (of us).
77 Literally, the Easterners.
78 When the suffix nu, meaning us, is added to a verb in the plural no dagesh is placed in the nun. Compare, shamarnu (we kept), and katavnu (we wrote) (Filwarg).
79 I.E.’s rendition. J.P.S. translates as out of them.
80 The nun signifying the third person singular always receives a dagesh. Compare, yishmerenno (Filwarg).
81 Literally, the Westerners.

82 The text has mi-mennu. This appears to be a scribal error. It is clear from the context that we should read mi-menni (Filwarg, Krinsky). I.E.’s point is that mi-mennu in the plural receives a dagesh despite the rule because mi-menni in the singular also should not have received a dagesh.
83 That the suffixed nun generally does not receive a dagesh.
84 We thus see that the nun of the first person suffix (ni) does not receive a dagesh.
85 Mi-menni (from me) is a contraction of min min ni (from from me).
86 There is a dagesh in the second mem of mi-menni and the word is therefore pronounced mi-mmenni. The mem is doubled to make up for the missing nun of the first min. See previous note.
87 It is a first person suffix.

88 In other words, the reason for the dageshim in mi-mennu in the plural is the same as that of mi-menni. The first dagesh (in the second mem) compensates for the missing nun of the first min, and the second one (in the nun) compensates for the missing nun of the second min. For mi-mennu is a compound of min min nu (nu being short for anachnu) in the same way that mi-menni is short for min min ni.
89 Ho (heh, vav) is the usual third person suffix. This suffix is missing in mi-mennu (of him). The dagesh in the nun compensates for the missing heh.
90 Ve-hinnehu is the long form. Ve-hinneh is the short form, for ve-hinneh nitzav is short for ve-hinnehu nitzav.
91 Two nuns rather than one nun are suffixed to a verb ending in a first person pronoun.
92 The dagesh doubles the nun.
93 The verbs quoted by I.E. from Deut. 32:10 are third person singular.
94 A third person singular suffix. The nun is doubled to compensate for the missing heh.
95 Jacob was speaking to Laban. Hence havah, which is a masculine singular imperative, is properly used. J.P.S. in our verse translates havah as come.

96 There is no such verse in Scripture. I.E. is probably referring to Num. 10:29 which reads, come thou with us. I.E.’s point is that both havah and lekhah come from stems that have a yod as their first letter and a heh added to their roots in the masculine singular imperative form; i.e., at times we say havah and lekhah in place of hav and lekh.
97 Havah is a masculine singular form. Nevertheless, it is also used when the rules of grammar call for havu (in the plural) or havi (in the feminine singular).
98 Here havah is used as a plural.
99 Havah is here employed as a feminine.
100 Here lekhah is used as a feminine. The usual feminine form of this word is lekhi. Lekhah is ordinarily masculine.
101 Nitchakkemah (let us deal wisely) is a hitpa’el. Hence I.E.’s comment. Cf. Rashi, “Let us consider wisely what to do with them.”
102 The literal meaning of lo (with them) is, to him. Hence I.E.’s comment.
103 Literally, to me. However, here it means because of me.

104 The term used by I.E. is shem ha-po’al. I.E. uses this term for both a noun and an infinitive (Weiser). I.E.’s point is that there are instances in which a noun or an infinitive should follow a verb but it does not.
105 Here the shem ha-po’al (in this case the infinitive) barekh is stated in the text.
106 Here the noun barakhah (blessing) is omitted from the text. However, it is implied by the verb u-verakh (and when he hath blessed).
107 This is how the verse would read if the noun etzah (counsel) was stated rather than implied in the word yo’atzim (counsellors).
108 Tikrenah (there befalleth) is a plural. Milchamah (war) is a singular. Hence I.E. suggests that the verse be read as if the noun korot (accidents) were written between tikrenah and milchamah.
109 Jonah ibn Janach.

110 Pharaoh employed euphemistic language because he was afraid that Satan would use what he said against him and cause the Egyptians to be expelled (to go up) from Egypt. Cf. Sotah 11a and Rashi on this verse.
111 The text is to be taken literally. And get them up out of the land means: Israel will leave Egypt and return to their homeland (Krinsky).
112 Both words come from a double root and are similarly vocalized.
113 The root of missim is mem, samekh, samekh. The root of pat is peh, tav, tav. Both are double roots and are similarly vocalized.
114 They tried to overwork them to the point that they would lose their virility.
115 According to I.E. ha-sokhen should be rendered, the one in charge of the treasury (or store), not this steward, as translated by J.P.S.
116 I.E. quoted from memory. The text reads, and be a companion unto him. Be that as it may, I.E.’s point is that sokhenet refers to a person in charge of the store (treasury).
117 See the last part of I.E.’s comments on verse 7 and the notes thereto.
118 The Hebrew literally reads, and as they (ve-kha’asher) afflicted them. I.E. interprets this to mean even though they afflicted them.
119 The Hebrew literally reads, so they multiplied. I.E. interprets this to mean so they multiplied as in days of old.
120 They were abnormally fertile.
121 They broke the rules of the natural rate of increase, so to speak, as one breaks through a wall.
122 The building of Pithom and Raamses.
123 The stem peh, resh, kaf (the root of perakh [rigor] is never found in this form in the Bible (Weiser).
124 Mo’adot is feminine. Mo’adim is masculine.
125 The root assigned to a verb is consistent throughout the conjugation. Thus one stem will not be assigned to the singular and another to the plural.
126 Their singulars and plurals are often grammatically inconsistent.

127 I.E. does not identify the grammarian that he is referring to. This grammarian held that a word with a feminine plural ending must similarly have a feminine ending in the singular. Mo’adot is a feminine plural form. Mo’ed is a masculine singular form. These two forms are inconsistent. The unnamed sage thus postulated that a female form mo’adah existed, the plural of which is mo’adot. However, no such form is found in Scripture.
128 Makom is masculine.
129 There is no such word. The plural of makom is mekomot. Mekomot has a feminine ending.
130 There is no such noun. However, there would be if Hebrew were consistent, because mekomah is a feminine form. We thus see that the plural and singular forms of nouns are not consistent.
131 Bekhorehem (their first-born) is the word bekhorim with the pronominal suffix.
132 Its singular is bekhor. Thus we see once again that the singular (bekhor) and the plural (bekhorot) are based on different forms of the noun.
133 A word found in our verse. All that preceded was written to explain this word, for levenim is feminine even though it has a masculine ending.
134 Levanah is feminine.
135 There is no such word. However, there would be if Hebrew singular and plural forms were consistent.
136 The mortar and brick were employed in the building of houses and fences.
137 Jacob used this term when speaking to Laban. What he meant was, I slaved for you.
138 The bet following va-ya’avod has the meaning of: for the sake of. Thus be-ishah means: for the sake of a woman.

139 There is no such verse. I.E. apparently combined Lev. 25:39 and Lev. 25:43. The literal reading of Lev. 25:39 is, thou shalt not work with him. The words with rigor come from Lev. 25:43. I.E.’s point is that in this case the bet (bo) has the meaning of with him.
140 Here too bah is the indirect object, for the meaning of lo ubbad bah is: which hath not been wrought with (Weiser).
141 Here too bo is the indirect object, for the verse literally reads: which may neither be plowed in, i.e., land that no one worked with.

142 When the Bible wants to say that it is the land per se that is worked rather than somebody working with the land, it leaves out the bet, the indirect object. Hence when the bet is there it represents the indirect object (Filwarg).
143 Here too vo (bo) is the bet of the indirect object and means with him (Weiser).
144 The number “five hundred” is not to be taken literally (Weiser). What I.E. means is that there must have been hundreds of midwives to serve the Israelite population.
145 The Talmud identifies the midwives (Shiprah and Puah) with Jochebed and Miriam, the mother and sister of Moses. Cf. Sotah 11b.
146 Eber (ever) was the ancestor of Abraham (Gen. 11:14-29). Hence his descendants are known as ivrim (Hebrews).

147 One who adopts the faith of Abraham, even though he is not a biological descendant of ever, is also called a Hebrew (Filwarg). Krinsky explains: One is called a Hebrew both by virtue of descent from ever and also because of his or her belief in the faith of Abraham. Hence descendants of ever who do not believe in the faith of Abraham are not called Hebrews.
148 See Josh. 24:2 which, according to I.E, reads: Your fathers of old time dwelt on the side of the river. The reference is to the eastern side of the Euphrates.

149 That is, the Euphrates. The word ever in Hebrew can refer to a person or to the side of a river. Gen. 10:21 reads, And unto Shem, the father of all the children of Eber (ever)…also were born children. Now Shem lived before Eber was born. I.E. assumed that Scripture would not report someone as being the ancestor of a person not yet born. Hence Eber in this verse cannot refer to a person. It refers to those born on one of the sides of the Euphrates. This interpretation contradicts the one I.E. gives in Genesis and elsewhere in Exodus. Cf. Gen. 10:21 and Ex. 21:2. Krinsky suggests emending “hence” to “or.” In other words, I.E. offers an alternative interpretation to the one he gave in Genesis and will offer later on in Exodus. Filwarg, on the other hand, suggests emending the text to read: Hence they err who say that the children of Eber, in the father of all the children of Eber, refers to those who came from the side of the river. For the side of the river refers to one of the sides of the river. In other words, ever cannot refer only to the western bank of the river where Abraham came from. A river has two sides and ever might refer to the eastern bank of the river, which is not the place that the Hebrews originally came from.
