150 An eighth-century North African grammarian.
151 The root of which does not have an alef. Hence the alef of ovnayim is superfluous. For I.E’s concept of superfluous letters, see his comments on Gen. 1:1 and the notes thereto.
152 The basic word is passayim. Hence the alef is superfluous.

153 The reference is probably to Jer. 18:3. However, there the reading is al ha-ovnayim. I.E. probably quoted from memory. Ovnayim in Jeremiah refers to a double stone (even) wheel. Hence the alef is a root letter. According to I.E. ovnayim are birth stones.
154 An act of cruelty and injustice even by the standards of the times.
155 Va-chayah is masculine. Va-chayetah is feminine. Since the Bible speaks of a daughter the latter form should have been used.
156 In a root ending in a heh.
157 In the third person feminine perfect.
158 From the root chet, yod, heh.

159 The heh is open on the left side with the exception of a tiny line (referred to as a dot by I.E.) at the bottom. The tav is closed on both the right and left sides. Thus by drawing from the small line (the dot) to the top of the letter, the heh becomes a tav.
160 The letters cannot be confused when spoken because they are sounded differently. But they can be confused when written, for they have similar forms.
161 Hence a person cannot mistake one for the other. Upon hearing heh, one will not think he heard tav.

162 There is a controversy in the Talmud (Sanhedrin 22a) over whether the original script of the Torah was identical to the script currently in use (the so-called Assyrian script), or whether the Torah was originally written in a script known as “Hebrew script.” In the Assyrian script the heh and the tav resemble each other. In the “Hebrew script” they are totally different. The fact that the Torah substitutes a heh for a tav because they resemble each other shows that the Torah was originally written in the Assyrian script. Historically speaking, the opinion that the Torah was given in “Hebrew script” is right, for all Hebrew writing extant from the period of the first commonwealth is in the “Hebrew script.”
163 Similar in that both words have a doubled root letter.

164 In the third person and participle kal forms, the word chai is written as if it came from the root chet, yod, yod. On the other hand, it is conjugated in the other kal forms as if it came from the root chet, yod, heh.
165 If this root is not irregular.
166 This is the form of a double root in the kal imperfect.
167 Another example of a double root. For the root of sov or sobbi is samekh, bet, bet. Sov and sobbi are imperative forms.

168 That is, its root is chet, yod, heh. I.E. is usually not this verbose and repetitious. Filwarg suggests that from “the fact” until “for we say” is an explanatory gloss that was incorporated into the text. The original reading was: This is proof that the word chai comes from a root ending in a heh., for we say echyeh, nichyeh, etc.
169 That is, it is conjugated according to the paradigm of hayah.
170 It does not disprove I.E.’s contention that the root of the word is chet, yod, heh.
171 Chai is the normal conjugation of the word if it comes from the root chet, yod, yod. I.E. is not disturbed by this because he believes this root to be irregular. See note 155.
172 Or in a yod. See further in I.E.’s note.
173 Shalev appears to come from the root shin, lamed, vav.
174 Hence its root is shin, lamed, heh.
175 Shalev is the noun form of the verb shalu. Hence the root of shalev must be the same as the root of shalu.
176 The usual form is ben. Hence the vav of beno is superfluous.
177 We would not be able to tell whether the vav is a root letter or a suffix (Krinsky).
178 The normal forms are ha-magbi’ah and le-hoshiv. Hence the yods are superfluous.
179 The usual form is ben. Hence the yod is superfluous.
180 The usual form is zulat and min. Hence the yods are superfluous.
181 If the alef is sounded, va-tirena is pronounced va-tir-enah and appears to come from the root resh, alef, heh, meaning: and they saw. The root of va-tirena is yod, resh, alef.
182 But saved the man-children coming after and did not as the king of Egypt commanded them appears to be redundant unless it adds something new.
183 Following Filwarg, who emends ha-nakhon to hinkhen.
184 The king was not asking a question when he said, why have ye done this thing, etc. What he meant was, why have you violated my command and thereby incurred the death penalty.

185 The second and third person feminine perfects are formed by adding a conversive vav to the corresponding imperfect form. Thus va-tomarnah may mean either “and they said” or “and you (plural) said,” for tomarnah means either “they will say” or “you (plural) will say.” However, they differ in the regular perfect, for the normal second person form is amarten and the regular third person form is ameru. The same, of course, applies to the word va-techayyenah (and have saved). Indeed, I.E.’s comments are directed to explain this word, for va-techayyenah in our verse means “and ye have saved” while in verse 17 it means “and they saved.” Hence I.E.’s paraphrase: “why have ye done this thing and saved.”
186 In the hifil.

187 In most instances the first yod of a root beginning with a yod changes to a vav when the word is conjugated in the hifil. However, va-yetev, which comes from the root yod, tet, bet and is a hifil form retains its yod. Hence I.E.’s comment.
188 Wherein “house” refers to an important family (Weiser).

189 The verb yare means to be afraid of someone. The one who is frightened does nothing to the source of his fright. Hence the verb is not transitive. On the other hand, the frightened person does nothing to himself; i.e., he does not scare himself. Hence the verb is not intransitive (Weiser).

190 The text reads yare’u…et Elohim. Et connects a transitive verb with the direct object. However, yare, as I.E. has noted, is not transitive. Hence I.E. notes that et is short for me’et., the literal meaning of our text being: were afraid of God.
191 Here too et is short for me’et.

192 As a verb. Nifal is the passive form of the kal. Since the verb yare is not transitive it does not have a nifal counterpart. The word nora (revered) is thus not a nifal verb even though it has the form of a nifal.
193 These are all nifal verbs.

194 The intelligent will understand that nora is not a nifal verb even though it comes in that form (Krinsky). However, I.E. uses this formula when he hints at some secret meaning. He apparently does so here. However, it is hard to ascertain what he is hinting at.
195 In other words, Pharaoh is a title. It is like the word king or tsar.

196 He was called Pharaoh-neco in Egyptian. I.E. comments thus so that we should not think that neco is a Hebrew adjective modifying Pharaoh, i.e., that Pharaoh-neco means Pharaoh the lame. Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 41:10 and the notes thereto.
197 Pharaoh is a title and Hophra a personal name. It is similar to King Hophra.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 2
chapter.p: 1. AND THERE WENT. Because of their great number the Israelites lived in many cities. All of the latter were called the land of Rameses.1 Perhaps this woman was in another city.2
A DAUGHTER OF LEVI. Son of Israel.3 She was the sister of his father.4

The person who says that wheat sown in another field will succeed, while wheat planted in the same field will not,5 does not speak the truth.6 The main reason that close relatives are forbidden to have sexual relations with each other is to sanctify Israel.7

2. AND THE WOMAN CONCEIVED. There is no doubt that Aaron was older than Moses.8 Our sages similarly received a tradition that Puah9 and Miriam are one and the same person.10 It is also written, And his sister stood afar off (v. 4).11

Now we know that the four hundred-year period12 which ended in Israel’s redemption started with the day that Isaac was born, for Isaac alone is considered to be Abraham’s seed.13 Now Isaac was sixty years old when he begot Jacob,14 and Jacob was eighty-five years old when he begot Reuben,15 and one hundred and thirty years old when he descended into Egypt.16 If we add the sixty years of Isaac to the one hundred and thirty of Jacob we come up with a hundred and ninety years. We are thus left with two hundred and ten years.17 We then subtract the seventy years that Joseph lived afterwards18 and we are left with one hundred and forty years. Now Levi was forty-three years old when he came down to Egypt19 and he outlived Joseph by twenty-two years.20 Thus one hundred and eighteen years are left. For the verse states, So Joseph died, being a hundred and ten years old (Gen. 50:26).21 Now when did the new king reign? For how many years did the Israelites build the store-cities? Behold close to the birth of Moses it was decreed that all male children be put to death.22

Ben Zuta23 says whoever relates a story will not out of respect mention the most honored first.24 Therefore when Scripture states, and she (Jochebed) bore unto Amram Aaron and Moses, and Miriam their sister (Num. 26:59), it indicates that Miriam was the youngest.25 Now the “blind one” (Ben Zuta) forgot Shem, Ham, and Japheth, concerning whom it is written, and Noah begot Shem, Ham and Japheth (Gen. 5:32). Now Japheth was the eldest of the three.26 Furthermore, Scripture states, There they buried Abraham and Sarah his wife (Gen. 49:31) even though Sarah was buried in the cave of Machpelah thirty-eight years27 before Abraham was interred there.

Note that the nun is often dropped or is swallowed by a dagesh when it is the first root letter of a verb, as in the case of the nun of gesh28 in gesh holah (stand back) (Gen. 19:9) and va-yiggash (came near)29 in Then Judah came near unto him (Gen. 44:18). The nun is also dropped when it serves as the middle letter of a root,30 as in the case of af (anger)31 in And anger also went up against Israel (Ps. 78:21). Observe, the middle nun is swallowed. Therefore the peh of appo (his wrath) in that his wrath was kindled (Gen. 39:19) and the peh of appekah (thine anger) in Thine anger is turned away (Is. 12:1) receive a dagesh. The same is true of the nun of the root nun, tav, nun in the word titti (that I give) (Gen. 29:19), for titti is like tinti32 because its final tav33 is not a root letter. It is rather like the tavs of shivti (my downsitting) (Ps. 139:2), lekhti (when I went) (I Kings 2:8), and lidti (I delivered) (I Kings 3:18).34 It is also so at the end of the word,35 as in tet (to put) in to put the dread of thee (Deut. 2:25) and in titti (that I give) in that I give her to thee (Gen. 29:19). The same is true of nouns. The word for daughter (bat) should have been banah since the feminine of ben (son) is banah. However, in this case it would have been confused with the verb banah (hath built), as in that hath built (banah) a new house (Deut. 20:5). A tav was therefore substituted for the heh.36 It is similar to givirah (lady) and geveret (lady) as well as to atarah (crown) and ateret (crown) in which we find both the construct and the absolute forms used in the absolute.37 Compare, ateret (crown of) in A crown of glory (Prov. 4:7). It should be noted that the nun was also dropped for the sake of easing the pronunciation of the word.38 Hence the word is enunciated bat (daughter). The word bitto (his daughter) in Rachel his daughter (Gen. 29:6) is similar to the word amitto (his truth) which is the word emet (truth) with the third person pronominal suffix.39 Compare, chasdo va-amitto (His mercy and His truth) (Gen. 24:27). Thus the tav is the sign of the feminine and the nun is swallowed up.40 The plural of truth is emunot, and not amitot or amitiyot.41 Similarly, the plural of daughters is banot, not batot or battim.42
AND THE WOMAN CONCEIVED. Scripture does not mention the birth of Miriam and Aaron because there was nothing special about their birth.43

When the word tov (good)44 is used with reference to a mature man it probably refers to the soul, as in “good with the Lord and good with man.”45 Or it may refer to the eye, as in a bountiful (tov) eye (Prov. 22:9).46 It may also refer to the body or its form, as in “of good form,47 and good to look upon.”48 However, because we find it used with regard to a child, viz., that he was a goodly (tov) child, we can only explain it as referring to the child’s form, that he was better than all who are born.49

THREE MONTHS. Some say that Moses was born in the seventh month following his conception.50 However, this interpretation like so many others is Midrashic,51 for the Egyptians had no way of determining when the woman52 conceived. In my opinion Scripture relates the months that she was able to hide the child53 since it is impossible for anyone to predict when a women will give birth.54 It is also far-fetched to say that Moses was born in the seventh month following conception because those so born are undersized.55 Those born in the eleventh month are healthier and live longer, as most children are born close to the ninth month.56 One who knows the time of conception is able to ascertain the time of birth, and one who knows the time of birth can ascertain the time of conception. This was established by the ancients. I myself have tried it five times.57 For the degree and place of the moon and its constellation at the moment of conception is also the degree of the constellation that flowers at the moment of begetting The degree which flowers at the moment of impregnation will also be the degree at which the moon will be found at the time of birth.58 Now the time set aside59 for carrying a child is two hundred and fifty nine and a third days.60 The median time for pregnancy is two hundred and seventy-three days.61 The maximum time for being with child is two hundred and eighty-seven days.62 Those learned in astrology will admit this.63 The birth of the tribes64 does not refute this,65 because the order of their listing is no proof that they were born prematurely.66 We find many such instances in the Torah.67 It is therefore possible that Rachel gave her handmaid to Jacob when Simeon was born, that Issachar was born before Asher,68 and that Dinah was Zebulun’s twin.69 Hence the phrase and afterwards in and afterwards she bore a daughter (Gen. 30:21) is similar to And after that came forth his brother (Gen. 25:26). For and she conceived is not mentioned for each one. Also, And it came to pass, when the seasons were come about (I Sam. 1:20) refers to three seasons.70

3. [HIDE HIM.] The tzadi of hatzefino (hide him), like the kof in the word yikkrekh (happen to thee) in there shall no punishment happen to thee (I Sam. 28:10), receives a dagesh so that these words may be clearly pronounced.71 The peh in hatzefino should have received a dagesh. However, it does not because the tzadi is vocalized with a mobile sheva. Hatzefino is a hifil infinitive. There is no reason to speculate as to why Jochebed did not hide him for a longer period of time.72 Perhaps the Egyptian neighbors heard his voice,73 for the Hebrews were not the only inhabitants of the land of Rameses.74 For it is written, but every women shall ask of her neighbor (Ex. 3:22).75
[AN ARK OF BULRUSHES.] The words tevat gome (an ark of bulrushes) are penultimately accented because the cantillical note is placed on the first syllable of the word gome (bulrushes).76

AND DAUBED IT. The heh of va-tachmerah (and daubed it) is silent. It is like the heh of the word lah (it) in and called it (lah) Nobah, after his own name (Num. 32:42).77 The word va-tachmerah (and daubed it) is derived from the word ba-chemar (with slime).78 Chemar (slime) is a red sticky clay which is found in the Land of Israel. The word chemar (slime) in full of slime pits (Gen. 14:10) is similar. This substance is called al chamara in Arabic. Jochebed did this79 for she said, “Let me not look upon the death of the child.”80 Perhaps the sister81 of Moses prophesied that she do this.82 God’s thoughts are very deep. Who can know His secrets? By Him alone are actions weighed.83 Perhaps God arranged things so that Moses would grow up in a royal house and his spirit would thereby be exalted through learning and practice.84 He would thus not possess a base spirit habituated to being in the house of slaves. Do you not see that Moses killed an Egyptian because the latter committed an act of violence85 and that he saved the daughters of Midian from the shepherds because they were acting violently in trying to water their flocks with the water which the women had drawn?86 One more thing: had Moses grown up among his brothers and had they known him from his youth they would not have feared him because they would have considered him as one of themselves.87
IN THE FLAGS (BA-SUF). Compare, The reeds and flags (va-suf) shall wither (Is. 19:6). Suf refers to a plant that grows in the Nile.
4. AND HIS SISTER STOOD AFAR OFF. The word va-tetatzav (stood) is irregular because a missing silent letter88 has been substituted for a yod89 between the two tavs.

Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen90 says that a tav is suffixed to the words laredet (to descend) and la-geshet (to approach) because the first root letter of these words is missing.91 That is also the case with the word la-da’at (to know).92 This word is vocalized with a pattach because the ayin is a guttural.93 Now in the word le-de’ah (to know)94 the tav was changed to a heh,95 as in the case of the word tenah (rehearsed)96 in Whose majesty is rehearsed above the heavens (Ps. 8:2).
5. AND THE DAUGHTER OF PHARAOH CAME DOWN. From her palace.

TO BATHE IN THE RIVER. As was the custom of Egyptian women. Scripture notes that her maidens walked by the riverside — the meaning of yad (side, place) here is the same as that of yad (place) in Thou shalt have a place (Deut. 23:13)97 — because it goes on to say that she sent her handmaid (Amatah), who was one of the maidens, to fetch the ark.98 For a princess would not go among the flags, and the ark was placed far from the shore so that no one passing by would touch it. Furthermore, from a grammatical point of view the word amah (handmaid) cannot mean an arm, because its mem does not have a dagesh while the mem of ammah (cubit) in A cubit shall be the length thereof (Gen. 30:2) does.99 Additionally, ammah (cubit) in A cubit shall be the length thereof refers to a measure and not to an arm.100

6. AND SHE OPENED IT, AND SAW IT. After stating, and saw it, Scripture goes on to elucidate further.101 Our verse is thus similar to And the house of David shall be as a godlike being, As the angel of the Lord before them (Zech. 12:8).102

AND BEHOLD A BOY THAT WEPT. Moses’ limbs were as large as if he were a fully developed boy.103 Pharaoh’s daughter noticed that Moses was circumcised.104 She took pity on him because of his beauty.105 This is the meaning of that he was a goodly child.106

7. THEN SAID…THAT SHE MAY NURSE. The first yod in roots whose first letter is a yod occasionally change,107 as evidenced in the word todi’a (you shall inform) which comes from the root yod, dalet, ayin and is spelled with a vav.108 In other cases a silent missing letter109 which is at times written and at times omitted110 is substituted for the yod and placed between the prefix and the middle root letter. This is the case with the word ve-tenek (that she may nurse)111 in that she may nurse the child for thee.
8. AND PHARAOH’S DAUGHTER SAID TO HER: GO. Lekhi (go) is like shevi (sit).112 These words are the imperative forms of va-yelekh (and he went) and va-yeshev (and he dwelt).

9. TAKE. Helikhi (take) is like heniki (nurse)113 because the roots yod, lamed, kaf and heh, lamed, kaf are two roots with one meaning.114 For the heh is not one of the implied vowel letters.115 Therefore the other heh is also like it.116 Furthermore, the alef and likewise the yod and the vav are found in the middle of a word at times written and at times silent, that is, pronounced but unwritten,117 but the heh is always visible when in the middle of a word. The words be-latehem (with their secret arts) (Ex. 7:22) and be-lahatehem (with their secret arts) (Ex. 7:11) are not, as I will explain,118 one and the same word.119

AND PHARAOH’S DAUGHTER SAID. Saadiah Gaon says that helikhi (take) is a composite of two words.120 However, the Gaon spoke incorrectly. It is, as I have noted, one word following the paradigm of ve-henikehu (and nurse it) in and nurse it for me. The word is in the hifil. The Gaon also said that helikhi is a composite of the words he and lakh,121 the meaning of he being the same as he (behold) in Behold (heh), I will also bring thy way upon thy head (Ezek. 16:43).122 However, we do not find the form lekhi used in Scripture when a female is being addressed. The form employed by Scripture is lakh.123 Helikhi (take) is thus one word.

AND NURSED IT. Va-tenikehu comes from a root wherein the middle radical is dropped and the other two remain.124 Observe, we have in our verse two roots with one meaning.125 It is the same case with the word hetivi (make good) in make good melody (Is. 23:16) which is an imperative following the paradigm of helikhi (take) and the word hetivu (they have well) in they have well said all that they have spoken (Deut. 15:25), which is like hevi’u (they brought) in And they brought yet unto him (Ex. 36:3), which is a word that drops its middle root letter.126

10. AND HE BECAME HER SON. This is similar to And these are the sons of Michal,127 and to Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel (Ezra 3:2; Haggai 1:1). Zerubbabel was the son of Pedaiah the brother of Shealtiel (II Chron. 3:17-19). He is called the son of Shealtiel because Shealtiel raised him.

[MOSES.] Moshe (Moses) is a Hebrew form of an Egyptian name. Moses was called Monyos in Egyptian. The name is so written in a book on agriculture which was translated from Egyptian into Arabic. This is also recorded in the books of the Greek scholars. Perhaps the daughter of Pharaoh learned our language, or she asked some one for its Hebrew version.128 Do not be perplexed as to why moshe was not called mashuy,129 as nouns do not keep their forms as verbs do.130

11. THAT HE WENT OUT UNTO HIS BRETHREN. The Egyptians,131 for he was in the king’s palace.132 One of his brethren means one of his family, as in for we are brethren (Gen. 13:6).133 Our clause is to be so understood because Scripture has already noted that the man was a Hebrew.134
13. STRIVING. Nitzim (striving) is a nifal adjective.135 The complete form is nintzim (striving).136 Compare, nirim (seen).137
TO HIM THAT DID WRONG. To him that acted violently.
14. SAYEST THOU TO KILL ME.138 Sayest thou in thy heart.139
SURELY. Akhen (surely) means if so.

15. HEARD. The land of Midian was subservient to Pharaoh; hence Moses had to herd sheep and not live among people and be recognized.140 It was at the time that his youngest son was born that God told Moses that Pharaoh and his servants from whom he had fled were dead. Upon hearing this Moses said, and (God) delivered me from the sword of Pharaoh (Ex. 18:4), as Moses feared Pharaoh as long as Pharaoh lived.141 After noting and (Moses) dwelt in the land of Midian, Scripture goes back and explains why Moses dwelt in Midian.142 Moses first sat down before the specified well.143 It is like And Jacob went out from Beer-sheba and went to Haran (Gen. 28:10). After stating the aforementioned the Pentateuch backsteps and states, And he lighted upon the place, etc. (Gen. 28:11).144

NOW THE PRIEST OF MIDIAN. The reference is to Jethro and not Reuel.145 The term kohen (priest) in Scripture refers to one who ministers either to the Lord or before an idol. That they may minister unto Me in the priest’s office (Ex. 28:41)146 and the priests of the Lord (Is. 61:6) are proof of this. Jethro, as I will explain, was a priest of the Lord.147

17. AND THE SHEPHERDS CAME. The mem of va-yegareshum (and drove them away) has the same meaning as a nun.148 If va-yegareshum was spelled with a nun, the nun might be confused with a superfluous nun.149 Similarly, the word tzonam (their flock) is spelled with a mem so as not to combine two nuns.150

18. AND WHEN THEY CAME TO REUEL THEIR FATHER. Reuel was their grandfather, while Jethro, who was also known as Hobab, was the father-in-law of Moses.151 This is evidenced in these verses: even from the children of Hobab the father-in-law of Moses (Judges 4:11); And Moses said unto Hobab, the son of Reuel the Midianite (Num. 10:29).
19. AND THEY SAID. They embellished what Moses had actually done.152 Or the water which they had drawn was insufficient for their flocks.153

20. AND HE SAID UNTO HIS DAUGHTERS. A grandfather is often called a father. Examples of the aforementioned are: O God of my father Abraham (Gen. 32:9)154 and Nebuchadnezzar thy father (Daniel 5:18).155 Similarly, a grandson is called a son. Examples of the latter are: The daughters are my daughters, and the children are my children (Gen. 31:43)156 and And thou his son, O Belshazzar (Dan. 5:22).157
AND HE SAID. Behold, Scripture is being brief. It does not mention that they called Moses,158 for we may logically infer that they did so.
CALL HIM. Kiren (call) is irregular, as it does not follow its normal paradigm.159
21. AND MOSES WAS CONTENT. Perhaps Jethro the son of Reuel was then absent and is therefore not mentioned by Scripture.160

22. AND SHE BORE A SON, AND HE CALLED HIS NAME GERSHOM; FOR HE SAID. He refers to Moses. Zipporah is the Cushite woman of whom Scripture later speaks.161 Do not believe what is written in the book called The History of Moses.162 I will give you a general rule: We should not rely on any book not written by prophets or by the sages who transcribed traditions passed on to them. We definitely should not rely on these books163 when they contradict reason. The same applies to The Book of Zeruhbabel, The Book of Eldad Ha-dani,164 and similar compositions.

23. THAT THE KING OF EGYPT DIED. Moses was now able to return to Egypt.165 The Israelites repented. Ezekiel notes that the Israelites worshipped the idols of Egypt.166 It was because of this that the Lord afflicted them. As a punishment for not serving God they served cruel masters.167
24. AND GOD HEARD…[AND GOD REMEMBERED.] The meaning of and God remembered is that the time for their redemption had come.168
25. AND GOD SAW. The violence which the Egyptians openly practiced.169
AND GOD TOOK COGNIZANCE. Of what was done in secret.170
chapter.ftnote: 1 All of the cities where the Israelites dwelt were in the land of Rameses.
2 The woman whom the son of Levi married lived in another city. Hence our verse reads, And there went… that is, he went from his city to another city and took a woman from there.
3 Jacob the patriarch. Cf. Num. 26:59.
4 The man spoken of in our verse is Amram and the woman, Jochebed. Levi begot Kohath and Jochebed. Kohath begat Amram. Thus Amram married his aunt Jochebed. See Ex. 6:16-20.
5 This scholar explains that the Bible prohibits incestuous marriages because such relationships produce defective offspring. Some moderns agree.

6 Amram married his aunt Jochebed. Marriages to aunts were eventually prohibited by the Pentateuch (Lev. 18:12). Nevertheless, the result of this relationship was Moses, a perfect physical and spiritual specimen (Krinsky, Filwarg).

7 If sexual relations with close relations were permitted, people would overindulge in sex because these relatives are readily available. Maimonides offers a similar explanation for the prohibition of having sexual relations with close relatives.

8 This is the reading of Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed manuscripts read, “There is no doubt that what we noted (kemo she-hizkarnu) is correct. For Aaron was older than Moses.” This sentence is obviously difficult to unravel, for what bearing does the fact that Aaron was older than Moses have upon Amram marrying his aunt? Krinsky and Netter attempt to explain it and in my opinion fail to do so. The reading of the Vatican manuscript appears to be correct, and the words kemo she-hizkarnu are most likely a gloss by a scribe who thought that “there is no doubt” refers to what I.E. said earlier namely, that Amram married his aunt.
9 One of the midwives (v. 15).
10 Sotah 11b.
11 Which shows that Miriam was older than Moses.

15 Jacob came to Egypt at the age of 130 (Gen. 47:9). Joseph was 39 at that time: he was 30 when he stood before Pharaoh (Gen. 41:46), and seven years of plenty and two of famine passed between the time that he first stood before Pharaoh and Jacob’s arrival in Egypt (Gen. 45:11). Jacob was thus 91 years older than Joseph. Joseph was six years younger than Reuben since Reuben was born in the eighth year of Jacob’s stay with Laban, and Joseph in the fourteenth year of that stay (See I.E. on Gen. 30:23 and the notes thereto). Thus Reuben was 45 years old when he came to Egypt, and Jacob 85 when he begot Reuben.

17 The Israelites were to be strangers in a foreign land for 400 years (Gen. 15:13). I.E. believes that those 400 years began with the birth of Isaac. It was a 190 years from Isaac’s birth to the descent of Jacob to Egypt. If we subtract 190 from 400 we are left with 210.

18 Seventy years passed (actually 71 years, I.E. prefers to use a round number) between the time that Jacob descended to Egypt and Joseph’s death. Thus 140 years are left from the 400 years. Joseph was 39 when his father came to Egypt. He died at the age of 110 (Gen. 50:26). Thus Joseph lived for another 71 years.

19 Levi was Leah’s third son. Assuming that Leah had Reuben, Simeon, and Levi in three consecutive years, I.E. concludes that Levi was two years younger than Reuben. Hence he was 43 years old when he came to Egypt since Reuben as previously noted, was then 45.

20 Levi lived 137 years (Ex. 6:15). Levi was three years older than Joseph (notes 15 and 19). Thus when Joseph died at the age of 110, Levi was 113. Hence Levi outlived Joseph by 24 years. I.E.’s figure of 22 years is inexact.
21 The fact that Joseph lived 110 years enables us to establish that from Isaac’s birth to the death of Levi, only 118 out of the 400 years remained.
22 I.E.’s point is that the Israelites were enslaved for relatively few of the 400 years.
23 A tenth-century Karaite scholar.
24 Thus whoever is mentioned first in a Biblical narrative or list is the eldest. This paragraph ties in with I.E.’s opening comment on verse 2.
25 Since Miriam is mentioned last.
26 See I.E. on Gen. 10:21.
27 Abraham was ten years older than Sarah (Gen. 17:17). Sarah died at the age of 127 (Gen. 23:1). Abraham was then 137. Abraham died at the age of 175 (Gen. 25:7); 175 minus 137 is 38.
28 Its root is nun, gimel, shin.
29 Its root is nun, gimel, shin. The dagesh in the gimel compensates for the missing nun.
30 Of a noun. See further.
31 From the root alef, nun, peh.
32 That is, it comes from the root nun, tav, nun. If the final nun was not dropped, titti would have been written tinti.
33 That is, titti comes from the root nun, tav, nun. It does not come from a root ending in a tav, for its last tav is a first person suffix.
34 In all of these cases the last tav is a first person suffix.
35 Not only does the first nun of the root nun, tav, nun at times drop out but its final nun is also omitted at times.
36 Hence the basic word for daughter is banat, not banah. I.E. will soon explain why the nun was dropped from banat, the Hebrew word for daughter being bat.

37 Bat is usually in the absolute. However, its form is that of a word in the construct. We find the same thing with the word geveret. Givirah is in the absolute; geveret is in the construct. Nevertheless, the construct form is used in the absolute. Similarly atarah and ateret. So too, bat means both daughter and daughter of.
38 Not only was the heh of banah changed to a tav, but its nun was dropped. Thus banah became bat.
39 Bitto comes from the root bet, nun, heh. Emet comes from the root alef, mem, nun. In the words emet and amitto the nun is missing. Hence bitto is like amitto.
40 The tav of bat takes the place of the heh of banah. Additionally, the nun is dropped, hence the word bat.
41 Showing that the root of emet is alef, mem, nun.
42 Which shows that the basic word for daughter is banah. The plural of banah is banot, whereas the plural of bat is batot or battim. I.E.’s intention here was to explain the form bat in verse 1.

43 It appears from our verse that Moses was Amram and Jochebed’s firstborn as Aaron and Miriam’s births are not mentioned. However, this cannot be the case since we have already seen that they were older than Moses. I.E. explains that there was no reason for Scripture to tell of their births as nothing extraordinary happened when they came into this world. However, when Moses was born he was put into the Nile and discovered by Pharaoh’s daughter.
44 Moses is described as “ a goodly (tov) child,” hence I.E.’s comment.
45 Cf. I Sam. 2:26: And the child Samuel grew on, and increased in favor (tov) both with the Lord and also with men.
46 Literally, a good eye, i.e., generous.
47 I Kings 1:6.
49 He was better looking than any other child. See I.E. in his short commentary.

50 The Bible tells us that Moses’ mother hid him for three months. The question arises, why did Jochebed hide Moses for three months? Why not two or four or five months? These commentaries assume that the Egyptians knew when Jochebed conceived and that they would come to check on the sex of her child nine months later. Hence they assume that Moses was born six months after conception and his mother hid him for three months, i.e., until the time the Egyptians would come to check the birth and ascertain the sex of the child. Cf. Rashi and Rashbam.
51 It looks like a literal interpretation but upon reflection it is Midrashic.
52 Jochebed.
53 Moses.
54 In other words, the Egyptians had no way of knowing when Jochebed would give birth just by looking at her.
55 Literally, “because those then born are short.” However, Moses, as the verse tells us, was a perfect specimen.

56 I.E. obviously believed that a woman can carry a fetus for 11 months. His point is that the longer a child spends in the womb the healthier it will be. Hence Moses, who was “good,” could not have been premature. It is interesting that I.E. does not consider the possibility of divine intervention in making Moses a perfect specimen though born prematurely.

57 I.E. might be referring to his personal life. If this is the case then we may conclude that he had fathered five children by the time he composed the long commentary on Exodus. See the introduction to Vol. 1 of this work. It is also possible that people consulted I.E. to make horoscopes for their children and that the reference is to the latter. In this case we, of course, have no hint as to how many children I.E. had.

58 A flowering constellation is one that is present at the moment of conception. The point is that the moon will be in the same place in the sky and will have the same constellation as its background at birth as it did at conception. Hence if one knows the moment of conception, one can ascertain the time of one’s birth. Similarly, if one knows the time of birth, one can figure out the time of conception.

59 I.E. reads, ha-kotzev, (the time set aside). However, since I.E. gives three time periods, what he must mean is the minimum time. Filwarg suggests reading ha-katan (the minimum) in place of ha-kotzev.
60 About eight and two-thirds of a month.
61 A little more than nine months.
62 Nine and a half months.
63 Some versions have “teach this;” i.e., they read yoru rather than yodu.
64 Jacob’s 12 sons.

65 Jacob begot 12 sons from four wives in seven years. The Bible lists their births in succession. The Midrash assumes that none of Jacob’s wives were pregnant at the same time. Hence it appears that they were born seven months apart since there are 84 months in seven years, and 84 divided by 12 is 7. See I.E. on Gen. 30:23 and the notes thereto.

66 The interpretation that Jacob’s children were born seven months apart is based on the theory that their births are listed in Genesis in the order of their occurrence; i.e., Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah were born first, to Leah. Rachel then gave Bilhah to Jacob, and Bilhah bore Dan. And so on with the rest of the sons of Jacob. I.E. says that the latter is not necessarily the case. It is possible that Bilhah was given to Jacob when Simeon was born and that Scripture does not note this earlier because it wanted to record that Leah had four sons before she “left off bearing.” See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 30:23 and the notes thereto.
67 There are many instances in Scripture where what happened later is listed first and what happened earlier is listed later.
68 In Gen. 30:13 Asher’s birth is recorded before that of Issaschar (Gen. 30:18).

69 After recording that Leah gave birth to Zebulun, Genesis tells us, And afterwards she bore a daughter, and called her name Dinah (Gen. 30:21). Prima facie, it appears that Dinah was born some time after the birth of Zebulun. I.E. argues that this is not so. He suggests that afterwards means a few moments later, as it does in Gen. 30:21.

70 The reference is to the birth of the prophet Samuel. According to the Talmudic sage Mar Zutra, Samuel was born six months and two days after he was conceived. The Bible tells us that Hannah, Samuel’s mother, prayed for a son and that “seasons (tekufat) of days came to pass, and Hannah conceived and bore a son (I Sam. 20). Mar Zutra explains that tekufot (seasons) refers to six months (a tekufah, a season is three months) and days, to two days. Cf. Rosh Ha-Shanah 11a. I.E. disagrees. According to him, seasons refers to three seasons (nine months). Hence Samuel was not born prematurely.

71 A letter with a dagesh in it is emphasized; i.e., the word is sounded hatzefino (dagesh in tzadi) rather than hatzpino (no dagesh in the tzadi). I.E. makes this point because there is no grammatical reason for a dagesh to be placed in hatzefino or yikkrekh.

72 I.E. comments thus because he disagrees with the exegetes who believed that Jochebed carried Moses for six months and hid him for three months because the Egyptians were about to come and check on the baby’s birth and sex. See note 50.
73 Hence Jochebed could no longer hide him.
74 There were also Egyptians living there and they would report the birth of the child. I.E. does not believe that a Hebrew would inform on a Hebrew.
75 The meaning of the verse is: but every Hebrew woman shall ask of her Egyptian neighbor. We thus see that the Hebrews had Egyptian neighbors.

76 I.E. points out that not only gome is penultimately accented; so is tevat. The problem presented by the latter is that tevah (tevat is tevah in the construct) is usually ultimately accented. I.E. explains that when two words are connected by cantillical notes and the second word is penultimately accented, so is the first word. This is so even though the word is ordinarily ultimately accented.

77 According to the rules of Hebrew grammar, a heh which serves as a pronominal suffix is vocalized with a mappik and is thus sounded. However, this is not the case with the pronominal heh in va-tachmerah. I.E. thus points out that the mappik is occasionally omitted from the heh which serves as a pronominal suffix.
78 It comes from the same root. In other words, the verb va-tachmerah is a denominative of chemar.
79 Placed the child in an ark which she then put among the flags in the river.
80 She acted in a manner similar to that of Hagar. See Gen. 21:16.
81 Miriam.

82 Miriam was a prophetess. It is possible that Miriam was instructed by God to tell her mother to do this, that, as I.E. goes on to say, the Lord arranged it that Pharaoh’s daughter find Moses and bring him up in the royal palace.
83 Cf. I Sam. 2:3.

84 Moses would develop into an aristocratic person by learning and practicing the habits of the nobility. I.E. here reflects medieval thinking on the superior quality of the ruling class and their practices.
86 Ex. 2:16, 17. Both actions show nobility of character.
87 That is, familiarity breeds contempt.
88 The first tav of va-tetatzav is vocalized with a tzere. The tzere is sounded as if a yod, a silent letter, followed it, hence the phrase a “missing silent letter” for the tzere.
89 I.E. believes that the root of va-tetatzav is yod, tzadi, bet, and that its tav prefix is vocalized with a tzere rather than with a chirik to compensate for the missing yod.
90 Moses ibn Gikatilla, an eleventh-century Spanish philologist and Bible commentator.
91 The root of la-redet is yod, resh, dalet. The stem of la-geshet is nun, gimel, shin. The yod is dropped in the infinitive and according to Rabbi Moses is compensated for by the tav.
92 From the root yod, dalet, ayin.

93 Hence the word is pronounced la-da’at and not la-de’et. I.E. makes this point because he wants to show that la-da’at and la-geshet belong to the same form even though they are vocalized differently.
94 This word is found in our verse. It comes from the root yod, dalet, ayin, and is an infinitive. Prima facie, it should have been written la-da’at.
95 Thus le-de’ah is a variant of la-da’at, and what I.E. said about the latter applies to the former as well.
96 The root of tenah is nun, tav, nun. The infinitive form is tet (or te-nat). In te-nah a heh has been substituted for the tav. Hence le-de’ah and la-da’at are similar to tet (te-nat) and te-nah.
97 Yad means a hand. However, here as in Deut. 23:13 it means a place. Thus yad ha-ye’or means side of the river (place of the river), not hand of the river.
98 I.E. makes this point because there is an interpretation that amatah (her handmaid) means her arm.
99 Hence they are not one and the same word, even assuming for the moment that ammah (cubit) means an arm.
100 Even if we should connect the word amatah with ammah, ammah does not mean her arm. It means her cubit.

101 Our verse literally reads: And she opened it, and saw it, the child. The child appears redundant, for it is preceded by and saw it. I.E. explains that Scripture is trying to be especially clear. Hence the Pentateuch goes on to explains that it refers to the child.
102 Angel of the Lord goes on to explain a godlike being.
103 Scripture describes Moses as a na’ar (a boy). However, he was a yonek (an infant), hence I.E.’s comment.
104 Thus Pharaoh’s daughter identified him as one of the Hebrews’ children.
105 In other words, Pharaoh’s daughter saved Moses because of his beauty.
106 See I.E.’s comment on verse 2.
107 In other words, the yod in peh yods are either occasionally dropped or changed to a yod.
108 In the hifil the yod changes to a vav.
109 A tzere. See note 88.
110 See note 88. When the tzere is followed by a yod the silent letter is visible. When the tzere is not followed by a yod the silent letter is missing.
111 From the root yod, kof, nun. The yod of the root is swallowed by the tzere.

112 Lekhi is vocalized with a tzere beneath the lamed. The usual way of vocalizing this form (the imperative) is with a sheva. I.E. points out that this is also the case with the word shevi. It is usually vocalized with a sheva. However, in Jer. 29:5 we find its plural form vocalized with a tzere. The reason for the change from sheva to tzere is that these words come at the end of a verse.

113 The word ve-henikehu (and nurse it) is a combination of ve-heniki (and nurse) and oto (it). I.E. points out that both helikhi and heniki are one and the same form, that is, peh, yod, hifil imperatives.

114 The word helikhi (take) literally means go. I.E. maintains that there are two roots in Hebrew for the word go, heh, lamed, kaf, as in the word halakhti, and yod, lamed, kaf, as in the word va-yelekh. I.E. believes that the root of helikhi is yod, lamed, kaf, the heh being the heh of the hifil conjugation. See note 112.

115 The alef, vav, and yod are implied in the vowels kamatz, cholam, and tzere; i.e., the words vocalized with these vowels are sounded as if followed by an alef, vav, or yod. Now when a letter is implied in a vowel it is occasionally omitted. If the heh was an implied letter then it is possible that the root of helikhi is heh, lamed, kaf with the heh implied. For the heh of helikhi is not a root letter. It is rather the heh of the hifil imperative.
116 That is, the heh of the root (the other heh) should have appeared in the word helikhi; i.e., if helikhi came from the root heh, lamed, kaf the word should have been spelled hehlikhi.
117 See note 115.

119 The first word is spelled without a heh, the second one with a heh. Prima facie, they are the same word with the missing heh implied. I.E. says no. He believes them to be two distinctive words with roots of their own.
120 That is, it is not a hifil imperative from the root yod, lamed, kaf but rather a composite of the words he and lekhi.
121 He means here is. Compare, he lakhem zera (lo, here is seed for you) (Gen. 47:2). Lakh (lekhi in the feminine) means to you. He lekhi thus means here is to you; i.e., take it.
122 J.P.S. translates, Lo, I will also bring, etc.
123 If the word helikhi is a composite then it must be made up of the words he (here is) and lekhi (to you). However, the word for “to you” in the feminine is lakh, not lekhi.
124 That is, it is an ayin vav. Its root is nun, vav, kof.

125 There are two words similar in meaning and from two different roots in verse 8. They are: ve-henikehu (and nurse it) from the root yod, nun, kof, and va-tenikehu (and nursed it) from the root nun, vav, kof.
126 Hetivi (make good) comes from the root yod, tet, bet. Hetivu (they have well) comes from the root tet, vav, bet.

127 Michal had no children (II Sam. 6:23). However, her sister Merab’s children are listed in the Bible as her children because she raised them (See I.E.’s commentary on Gen. 36:2 and the notes thereto.) Similarly, Scripture considers Moses to be the son of the daughter of Pharaoh since she raised him. It should be noted that there is no verse that reads, “and these are the sons of Michal.” Scripture reads, and the five sons of Michal the daughter of Saul (II Sam. 21:8). I.E. quoted from memory. Cf. Weiser.

128 I.E. was bothered as to how Pharaoh’s daughter was able to coin a Hebrew name for the child which commemorated the way in which he came to her. He answers that she either knew Hebrew or asked a Hebrew to coin a name which expressed her feelings.
129 Mashuy means drawn. Since Moses was drawn from the water, he should have been called mashuy, not moshe.
130 Verbs are conjugated according to paradigms. However, nouns do not always follow strict forms. See I.E.’s comment on Ex. 1:14 and the notes thereto.
131 Moses considered the Egyptians his brethren because he was brought up as an Egyptian.

132 Scripture reads, that he went out, because Moses went out of the palace (Krinsky). Or I.E. is explaining why Moses considered the Egyptians his brethren. He did so because he was brought up in the king’s palace.
133 Abraham said this to his nephew Lot. We thus see that the term “brethren” can refer to a member of one’s family.
134 Our verse reads, a Hebrew, one of his brethren. If one of his brethren means a Hebrew then the Bible is being redundant. I.E. thus explains that one of his brethren means a member of his family.
135 That is, a nifal participle. I.E. refers to nifal participles as adjectives.

136 The root of nitzim is nun, tzadi, heh. In nitzim the nun of the root is missing because the nun in nitzim is the nun of the nifal. If the word were written with the nun of the root present, it would be written nintzim.
137 From the root resh, alef, heh. In nirim the entire root is present.
138 Rendered literally. J.P.S. translates this as Thinkest thou to kill me.
139 To kill me. That is, sayest thou (attah omer) means thinkest thou. The man was not accusing Moses of actually stating his intention of killing him.
140 Moses was afraid that he would be identified and handed over to Pharaoh. therefore he chose an occupation which kept him away from populated areas.

141 Moses named his youngest son Eliezer. He derived the name from the Hebrew words El (God) and ezer (help). Moses so named his son because, he said, For the God of my father was my help, and delivered me from the sword of Pharaoh (Ex. 18:4). According to I.E., Moses gave this name to his son after learning that Pharaoh was dead and could no longer harm him.

142 I.E.’s point is that Moses did not dwell in the land of Midian prior to being invited by Jethro to dwell with him after having saved his daughters from the shepherds. I.E. notes that here as in other places Scripture describes in a general way what happened and then goes into details.
143 The well noted in our verse. The text literally reads, and he sat down by the well. J.P.S. renders, and he sat down by a well.

144 That is, that Jacob alighted at Luz on the way to Haran. However, the previous verse reports that Jacob had arrived in Haran. I.E. explains that Scripture first tells us in a general way what happened. It then goes into details. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 28:10 and the notes thereto.
145 See I.E.’s comment on verse 18.

146 The Hebrew reads ve-khihanu li. If a kohen referred only to one who serves the Lord it would not be necessary to add the word li (unto me), as it would be understood that the reference is to priests of God. However, since one can also be a priest of idols the Bible adds the word li. The same is true with the priest of the Lord. If priests only referred to priests of the Lord there would be no reason for the Bible to add of the Lord.
147 I.E. never returned to this point. Cf. Weiser. This seems to indicate that he never edited his works.

148 Since them in and drove them away refers to females, a nun should have been suffixed to va-yegareshu (and drove away) and the word read va-yegareshun rather than va-yegareshum. For the mem is a masculine suffix and the nun a feminine suffix. I.E. thus notes that although va-yegareshum is ordinarily masculine, here it is feminine.

149 At times an extra nun (or a superfluous nun) is added to the plural imperfect. Thus in place of the usual yegareshu (they will drive away) we have yegareshun (they will drive away). Now if our word was written va-yegareshun we would not know whether the word was merely plural with a superfluous nun, meaning: and they drove away, or if it was a plural with a feminine suffix, meaning: and they drove them away. To avoid this problem Scripture employed the masculine form here.

150 The nun is a feminine third person plural pronoun meaning their. Since our text speaks of flocks belonging to females we would expect to find tzonan, which has a feminine suffix, and not tzonam, which has a masculine suffix. I.E. explains that tzonam is used in place of tzonan because it is hard to pronounce two nuns in succession.

151 According to our text Zipporah was the daughter of Reuel. However, Scripture always refers to Moses’ father-in-law by the name of Hobab or Jethro. Hence Zipporah must have been the daughter of Hobab/Jethro and not Reuel.

152 Verse 16 tells us, Now the priest of Midian had seven daughters, and they came and drew water. Thus it was the daughters of the priest of Midian and not Moses who drew the water. Moses helped them and watered the flock (v. 17); however, he did not draw water for them.

153 And Moses drew additional water for them. Hence they did not embellish upon what Moses had actually done. Scripture either did not report the event or alluded to it in and (Moses) watered the flock (v. 17).
154 Part of a prayer uttered by the patriarch Jacob. However, Jacob’s father was Isaac, not Abraham. We thus see that a grandfather is often called and considered as a father.
155 Daniel said this to Belshazzar who, according to I.E., was Nebuchadnezzar’s grandson.
156 Laban said this of Jacob’s children. However, in reality they were Laban’s grandchildren.
157 “His” refers to Nebuchadnezzar. The Bible thus refers to Nebuchadnezzar as the father of Belshazzar whereas in reality, according to I.E., he was Belshazzar’s grandfather.

158 Reuel told his daughters, Call him, that he may eat bread. The next verse opens, And Moses was content to dwell with the man. Scripture thus omits that Reuel’s daughters called Moses and invited him to eat bread.
159 The usual form for the feminine plural imperative of the root kof, resh, heh is kirenah. Thus kiren is irregular.
160 Hence Jethro is not mentioned in our incident.

162 A legendary history of Moses composed in the Middle Ages. Cf. Y.L. Zunz, Ha-Derashot Be-Yisrael, chap. 8. I.E. makes this point here because it is recorded in The History of Moses that Moses was a king in the land of Cush and that there he married a Cushite queen. The latter contradicts I.E.’s opinion that Zipporah and the Cushite are one and the same person.
163 That is, books not written by prophets or sages.
164 Two medieval works. See note 162, Zunz, op. cit., chap. 8.
165 The Pharaoh who sought to slay Moses died. Moses was thus able to return to Egypt. See I.E.’s note on verse 15. Also see Ex. 4:19.

167 I.E. apparently interprets and the children of Israel sighed by reason of the bondage as: Israel realized that they were being punished with bondage for worshipping idols. They then repented and cried out unto the Lord.
168 God, as it were, remembered that the time set aside for Israel’s enslavement was now over. See Gen. 15:13 and I.E.’s notes thereto.
169 Upon the children of Israel.
170 To the children of Israel.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 3
chapter.p: 1. THE MOUNTAIN OF GOD, UNTO HOREB. This is the manner in which Moses recorded it.1 The place is called Horeb because of its great heat and lack of rainfall.2 As Moses noted,3 it is located three days’ journey from Egypt. There is no moisture there and the dryness is overpowering because the Nile is far away.

2. APPEARED. Some interpret be-labbat esh to mean: in a flame of fire.4 However, it appears to me that its meaning is, in the heart5 of the fire, for we indeed find, How weak is thy heart (libbatekh) (Ezek. 16:30).6 However, Rabbi Adonim7 says that if this were so, then be-labbat would have been vocalized with a chirik beneath the lamed like the word ginnat (garden of) in I went down into the garden of nuts (Canticles 6:11).8 Now, Rabbi Adonim seems to have forgotten the word gannah (garden)9 in And as the garden causeth the things that are sown in it to spring forth (Is. 61:11).

THE BUSH. Saadiah Gaon says that seneh (bush) is a type of thorn bush. He further explains that the word seneh in And the good will of Him that dwelt (shokhni) in the bush (seneh) (Deut. 33:16) means heaven;10 that is, it refers to God the glorious.11 Rabbi Joshua,12 on the other hand, says that the verse refers to the glory that dwelt in the bush.13 However, Rabbi Joshua spoke incorrectly, for how can God be called “Him that dwelleth in the bush” when he dwelt there for but a moment.14 Furthermore, why is the word shokhni (dwelt) in the po’el form?15 The word oseh (makes) in Who makes (oseh) heaven and earth (Ps. 121:2) is different,16 as God is constantly making and causing heaven and earth to exist in the same manner as speech issues from the mouth of man.17 Additionally, after mentioning all the precious things (Deut. 33:13-16), Scripture concludes with the good will of God.18 Moreover, what reason is there to mention this angel?19 Furthermore, Scripture should have read, ba-seneh (in the bush)20 and thereby would have referred to the well-known bush.21

In my opinion seneh (bush) refers to only one thing,22 namely, a type of dry thorn bush. This is the case in Arabic.23 Mount Sinai is so named because this type of bush grew there.24 Similarly, its25 interpretation is: and the good will that he who lives in the place of the bush (seneh) seeks; that is, a person living in such a place entreats and prays that God do his will and wet the land that he lives in. He prays that God change it from a dry place, a place where the seneh grows, to an amply watered place so that it becomes like a wet and well-watered garden.

Scripture states that an angel of the Lord appeared out of the midst of the bush.26 The word seneh has the definite article the (heh) prefixed to it because these are Moses’ very own words in writing the Torah.27

The word bo’er (burned) is a transitive verb. The phrase a burning fire is similar to a devouring fire (Deut. 4:24). As the fire that burneth (tivar) the forest (Ps. 83:15) is proof of this.28 Now the fire that burned in the bush devoured all that was around it. Our verse is similar to They have set Thy sanctuary on fire (Ps. 74:7).29 While the mountain did burn with fire (Deut. 5:20) is also similar.30

[WAS NOT CONSUMED.] The word ukkal (consumed) is an adjective.31 It is similar to the pa’ul.32 The words lukkach (taken), which is vocalized with a kamatz in if thou see me when I am taken (II Kings 2:10), yullad (shall be born) in unto the child that shall be born (Jud. 13:8), yukashim (snared) in even so are the sons of man snared (Eccles. 9:12) are similar.33 Now since these verbs are transitive, the word mu’edet (unsteady) in and an unsteady leg (Prov. 25:19) cannot be classified among these words34 as these words are transitive.35 Mu’edet is similar to mo’edet, a po’elet, with the exception that a shuruk has been substituted for a cholam.36

3. AND MOSES SAID: I WILL TURN ASIDE (ASURAH) NOW. When a verb from the root samekh, vav, resh is followed by a mem it means: to distance from, as in suru mi-menni (turn aside from me) (Ps. 6:9) in which the speaker says, distance yourself from me. However, if the word el (to) which is vocalized with a segol follows it, then it has the opposite meaning, as in suru elai (turn in) (Jud. 4:18), the meaning of which is, turn from your place and come to me. Moses wanted to turn aside from where he was and to then draw near to the bush.37

AND SEE THIS GREAT SIGHT. This is the first sign recorded in the Torah that the Lord did via his prophet Moses. Scripture thus says, and this shall be the token (sign) unto thee that I have sent thee (v. 12).38 Yefet39 says that the interpretation of the sign is as follows: the enemy40 is compared to fire and Israel to a bush. Hence the bush was not burnt.

4. AND WHEN THE LORD SAW. These words were also written later by Moses.41 The angel was called by God’s revered name in the sense of, for My name is in him (Ex. 23:21).42 I will explain this when I comment on the latter verse. We find the same with the angel that appeared to Gideon. There it is written, And the Lord said unto him (Jud. 6:23).43 Or its meaning is that the Lord saw that Moses turned aside to see the great sight and He commanded an angel to call Moses.44 Hence the use of the term elohim (God) in our verse.45 The name Elohim is not a proper name but is, as I will explain, an adjective.46 It pertains to all holy beings that are incorporeal and are not forces in a body, as it is written, except the angels,47 whose dwelling is not with flesh (Dan. 2:11), that is, with a body.48 Thus elohim refers to the above-noted angel.49

5. AND HE SAID: DRAW NOT NIGH HITHER. Its meaning is, stand in your place and draw not nigh to the bush where the fire is.50 Is there yet a man come hither? (I Sam. 10:22) is similar.51 A nun is missing in the word shal (put off), as it is in the word ga (touch),52 for the word shal comes from the same root as ve-nashal (and shall cast out) in and shall cast out many nations (Deut. 7:1).

6. MOREOVER HE SAID: I AM THE LORD OF THY FATHER. After stating, I am the God of thy father, He explains that the reference is to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. He starts with Abraham because Abraham was the first to call upon the name of the Lord and he built an altar to the Lord,53 for his father and his brother worshipped idols. These three54 are mentioned while those closest to Moses, namely, Levi, Kehat, and Amram, are not noted55 because the former were prophets. Furthermore, they were fathers of all of Israel. Levi was not,56 whereas Moses stood for all of Israel.57 When God told Moses, I am the God of thy father, He was, as it were, speaking to all of Israel because Moses represented Israel.

AND MOSES HID HIS FACE. This is similar to for I have seen God face, to face, and my life is preserved (Gen. 32:31).58 The sensory perception of the eye59 is like the gate of heaven,60 for it can see in one moment images that are both far and near. However, this is not the case with the senses of the ears, nose, palate, and hand.61 Moses hid his face because he was greatly afraid.62
7. AND THE LORD SAID. The messenger speaks the same language as the one who sent him.63
[I HAVE SURELY SEEN.] Its meaning is: I have seen that which people do not see, namely, the violence that is done to them secretly.64
AND HAVE HEARD THEIR CRY. I have heard their cry which is heard by all and I know the pain which they bear in their hearts.65

8. AND I AM COME DOWN. Scripture says this because the heavens are more glorious than the earth.66 God’s glory fills everything.67 It is only because the decrees come down from heaven that Scripture employs the term And I am come down.68 Furthermore, the angel was a higher form69 and Moses was not able to go up to heaven.70 Hence Scripture reads, and I am come down to save my people.71

AND TO BRING THEM UP. This is in contrast to and I am come down.72 As I dwell in a high place73 so will I cause them to dwell in the most elevated place that is upon the earth.74 The aforementioned are the words of the angel.75 It is likewise written, He made him ride on the high places of the earth (Deut. 32:13).76 Behold, the Israelites went out of a land where they were afflicted to a good land.77 Scripture does not mention the Girgashites78 because they were the smallest of the seven.79 Now, it is fitting to raise the following question: Since six nations were descended from Canaan, why does Scripture mention the Canaanites?80 The answer is: The term Canaanites is an ethnic name and includes all the nations living in Canaan.81 Hence the entire land was called the land of Canaan. The Perizzite is to be identified with Sidon.82 The rest of the sons of Canaan mentioned in Scripture were few in number and are included in the term Canaanite.
9. AND NOW, BEHOLD. Its meaning is: And now, behold, the cry of the children of Israel who have repented83 is come unto Me.

[MOREOVER I HAVE SEEN THE OPPRESSION.] Its meaning is: Moreover I have seen the oppression with which they in their pride oppress them. Jethro similarly said, for that they dealt proudly against them (Ex. 18:11).
10. COME NOW THEREFORE. As My messenger to Pharaoh.84

11. AND MOSES SAID…WHO AM I. There is no difference between the words ani (I) and anokhi (I).85 The latter are similar to immi (with me) and immadi (with me). We have found that it is the way of the Hebrew tongue to derive the word ani (I) and the words attah (you in the singular) and attem (you in the plural), whose nuns have been swallowed,86 from the root of an (whither) in Whither went ye (I Sam. 10:14), as the place indicates the speaker.87 It is possible that the word anokhi is derived from the root of anakh (plumbline) (Amos 7:7)88 in a manner similar to the derivation of the word nechushtekh (thy bottom)89 (Ezek. 16:36).
Because the Lord told Moses, come now therefore, and I will send thee unto Pharaoh (v. 10), Moses responded, I am a shepherd and Pharaoh is a great king.90

Because God told Moses, that thou mayest bring forth My people the children of Israel out of Egypt (v. 10), Moses answered the Lord, Who am I that I am able to bring forth a great nation such as the children of Israel out of Egypt.91

[12.] AND HE SAID: CERTAINLY I WILL BE WITH THEE. Now go to Pharaoh and bring out the children of Israel and behold, I have given you a token92 that I have sent you. The reason they are being brought out of Egypt is that they should serve Me on this mountain where I have shown you this great wonder.93 It is thus written, (I am the Lord)…that brought you out of the land of Egypt, to be your God (Lev. 22:23). Moses similarly said to Pharaoh, We will go three days’ journey into the wilderness, and sacrifice to the Lord our God (Ex. 8:23)94 because the latter is the walking distance between eastern Egypt and Mount Sinai.95 However, when Israel left Egypt they did not go there via the land of the Philistines.96 Furthermore, Israel, as I will explain, dwelt in one place for many days.97 It is precisely this98 that Moses spoke of when he wrote, and (Moses) builded an altar under the mount…and…offered burnt offerings and sacrificed peace offerings (Ex. 24:4, 5). He then made a covenant with Israel that they be a people unto the Lord and that the Lord be their God.99

13. AND MOSES SAID. Moses now asked which of God’s names he should relate to Israel, for with the name of El Shaddai (God Almighty) he could not perform signs.100 The latter are only performed with God’s great and glorious name.101 Rabbi Joshua102 says that the Israelites had a tradition from their forefathers that Israel’s savior would reveal a new name of God to them, a name that they had never heard.103 Now when Rabbi Joshua heard that Scripture states, I am the Lord that brought thee out of Ur of the Chaldees (Gen. 15:7),104 he explained it by saying that these are the words of Moses.105 However, Rabbi Joshua is mistaken. In the Torah portion Bereshit at the beginning of the Pentateuch we find that Scripture does not employ the Tetragrammaton but uses the name Elohim (God) until the verse which concludes with the words in creating had made (Gen. 2:3).106 After the latter verse Scripture refers to God by the name Adonai Elohim (Lord God). After the birth of Cain, Scripture employs the term Adonai (Lord) for the Deity only by itself.107 We never find Moses using the name Elohim for God. Moses always refers to Him by His great and glorious name.108 He uses the term Elohim only in one place. He does this because Pharaoh said, Entreat the Lord, and let there be enough of God’s (Elohim)109 thunderings (Ex. 9:28). Upon hearing this, Moses responded, I know that ye will not fear the Lord (Adonai Elohim) (Ex. 9:30).110 However, there is no other similar case in Scripture.111

14. AND GOD SAID…I AM. Its meaning is, That I Am.112 Compare, And the house of David shall be as God, As the angel of the Lord before them (Zech. 12:8). Angel of the Lord, which follows God, explains the term God.113

15. AND GOD SAID MOREOVER…THE LORD. Another name meaning the same as the first one.114 However, one name (EHYH) is in the first person and this name (YHVH) is in the third person.115 It comes from the same root as yah (Lord). These three names are proper names.116 I will now go on to explain the meaning of the proper name of God, the meaning of its letters, part of the secret of God’s glorious name, and why it is not read as written.117

The words of Abraham the author: Behold, I now begin to elaborate because I need a firm foundation. Note that a proper name serves as a token and as a sign of the one being referred to by those who enunciate it and those who hear it.118 A proper name is distinguished from an adjective119 in four ways. The first is that an adjective is derived from an imperative, such as chakham (be wise)120 in My son, be wise (Prov. 27:11), or a perfect, as in My son, if your heart gets wisdom (chakham)121 (Prov. 23:15), or an imperfect, as in That thou mayest be wise (techkam) in thy latter end (Prov. 19:20).122 However, this is not the case with a proper noun such as Abraham, as no perfect or imperfect form can be derived from it.123 Now even though there are proper nouns that are derived from verbs, such as the name yitzchak (Isaac),124 we do not say yitzchakti (I was Isaaced) or itzchak (I will be Isaaced).125 A proper name is not used as an adjective.126 The second difference is that an adjective comes in the plural. For example, chakham (wise) becomes chakhamim (wise). However, we do not have a plural form for the proper name avraham (Abraham). Thus we do not say avrahamim (Abrahams). Neither is there a plural for the proper name yisra’el (Israel). Thus if there are two people named Israel in a place we do not say yisra’elim (Israels). We would only use the term yisra’elim if we wanted to relate each of them to the people of Israel, as the term Israel is the name of a group.127 The third difference is that a definite article is not prefixed to a proper noun as it is to an adjective. From the word chakham (wise) we get he-chakham (the wise man) (Eccles. 2:14).128 However, it is incorrect to say ha-avraham (the Abraham) or ha-yitzchak (the Isaac). The word ha-kohelet (Eccles. 12:8)129 cannot be used as an argument against the aforementioned because the term kohelet is not a proper name but an adjective describing the wisdom which was accumulated.130 Similarly, the word va-ha-adam (Gen. 2:8)131 is an adjective.132 It has a secret meaning to it, as it is the name of a genus.133 The name ha-menasheh (Deut. 3:13)134 has a definite article before it because it refers to genealogy.135 The fourth difference is that a proper noun has no construct form whereas an adjective does. For example, we find, chakham lev (wise of heart) (Job 9:4). However, it would be incorrect to say yitzchak ha-dor (Isaac of the generation), because a proper name stands by itself.136 The same is the case with the name Eheyeh (I am) and also with the glorious name of God, the Tetragrammaton, because both of these names are proper names.137 Now, we do find, Adonai tzeva’ot (the Lord of hosts) (Is. 1:9),138 and as a result many were forced to conclude that tzeva’ot is a proper name139 or that the Lord is outstanding among140 His host.141 However, this is incorrect, because Scripture reads, Elohe ha-tzeva’ot (the God of Hosts) (Amos 3:13).142 Tzeva’ot is never encountered by itself. It is always connected either to the word Elohim (God) or to God’s glorious name, Adonai (Elohim).143 Do not be bothered by the phrase Adonai Elohim tzeva’ot (O Lord God of hosts) (Ps. 59:6),144 as its meaning is similar to ve-ha-nevu’ah oded ha-navi (even the prophecy of Oded the prophet) (II Chron. 15:8).145

Now the Lord’s personal name is sometimes used in an adjectival sense because God alone exists forever and the existence of all things is contingent upon Him.146 God’s proper name is used here in the same way that the name moshe (Moses) is used in Then He remembered the days of old, when He drew (moshe) His people (Is. 63:11).147 The meaning of Adonai when used as an adjective is: the maintainer of existence. Hence in the phrase Adonai Elohim the holy angels are connected to God.148 Similarly, in the phrase Adonai tzeva’ot (Lord of hosts) tzeva’ot refers to the hosts of heaven.149 Pay no attention to Saadiah Gaon who says that God is called Adonai tzeva’ot because of Israel.150 Saadiah offers proof151 from and I will…bring forth My hosts (tzivotai), My people the children of Israel, out of the land of Egypt (Ex. 7:4). However, look at I saw the Lord sitting on His throne, and all the host of heaven standing by Him (I Kings 22:19).152

Now the name Elohim is an adjective, because it comes in both the plural and the singular.153 Compare, Is not God (Elo’a) in the height of heaven (Job 22:12).154 Furthermore, the word Elohim comes in the construct.155 Compare, Elohim Elohe yisra’el (God, the God of Israel) (Ps. 72:12).156 The word El (God) means mighty. The same is true of the term Shaddai (Almighty).157 Compare, Like the noise of great waters, like a mighty voice (Ezek. 1:24); and, and thy treasure shall be mighty (shaddai) (Job 22:25).158

Note that the number one is the secret and the foundation of all numbers,159 and that two is the first of the even numbers and three the first of the odd numbers. Now from one point of view there are only nine numbers.160 However, from another perspective there are ten numbers.161 If the numbers one to nine are written in a circle162 and the last number163 is multiplied by each of the other numbers,164 we find that the ones165 are on the left and the tens, which look like ones, are on the right.166 Now when we come to the number five which is in the middle, we find the reverse; i.e., the tens become ones and the ones become tens.167 However, looked upon from another perspective, there are ten numbers168 without any additions,169 for one cannot begin to count one without ten.170 The number ten is thus like the number one.171 It is a general term for all the ones, i.e., the numbers from one through ten.172 The number ten includes them because they are the first numbers. It is also similar to the ones because it is the first of the numbers,173 in the same way that the ones are, because when we reach the number twenty we have two tens paralleling the number two. Similarly, thirty is like three and all the tens till ninety are like the nine ones. When the number one hundred is reached we once again come upon a number which is similar to one. When we reach nine hundred we once again have nine numbers similar to the nine ones.174 This is so until we reach the number one thousand which consists of ten hundreds. Also, the number one thousand is similar to the number one, and likewise the following numbers correspond to the other nine numbers until nine thousand.175 When we reach ten thousand the sum is concluded because we now have one myriad. The same applies176 until we reach ten myriads. The beginning of all the numbers177 is similar to the number one. Hence mathematicians say that all of the numbers178 are either fractions of ten179 or multiples of ten,180 or the result of adding ten to the ones,181 or a combination of these two.182 Now the ten numbers are the same as the fingers on the hand,183 five corresponding to five.184 Similarly, there are nine spheres which are in a constant glorious state.185 The tenth sphere, which is holy, is so called186 because its power is manifest throughout the throne of glory.187 It is the most powerful sphere and circles all the bodies.188 There are two middle digits when we count from one to ten, namely, the numbers five and six.189 Now the numbers alef (1), heh (5), vav (6), and yod (10) are the most glorious numerals.190 Any squared number that ends in one will always have the number one in its root.191 The same is true with its counterpart.192 Similarly, the number five will be found in the square of five193 and the number six will be found in the square of six.194 These four numbers always maintain their identity when squared;195 therein lies their superiority over all other numbers that are squared. Additionally, every number is potentially present in the number one.196 Similarly, the number one is found in all the actual numbers.197 Furthermore, the number one accomplishes on one side what the other numbers accomplish in two sides.198 Now behold the power of the number one. If you add its square to the square of its double you get five,199 a number whose cube equals its squares, for if you add its square200 to the square of its double201 it will equal its cube.202 In all the numbers preceding five203 the relationship of the cube to the sum of the two squared numbers will be the same as the relationship of that number to five.204 The reverse is the case with the numbers above five.205 The number six206 is equal to its parts.207 There is no other number in the order of the integers that equals its parts aside from this number. When208 the square of one is added to the square of the first of the odd numbers209 we get ten.210 Now if we bisect a circle with a line that is ten units long211 and a line is drawn across the circle a third of the way up, a triangle two of whose sides are equal may be drawn.212 The number representing the area of this triangle will equal the circumference of the circle.213 Similarly the rectangle214 formed in the circle.215 Now up to ten216 the value of the triangle217 to the circumference will be the same as the diameter is to ten.218 The reverse will be the case in the numbers above ten.219

Now these four letters220 are very precious. They add up to twenty-two,221 the number of the letters in the Hebrew alphabet. Do not count the doubled letters twice,222 as they are the original letters with their horizontal bases straightened to form a line.223 The reason they have one name even though they are written differently is that they have one sound.224 The master of Hebrew grammar225 perceived that the letters have five sources.226 He classified half of the letters as root letters227 only, and half as root, prefix, or suffix letters.228 Now the second group of letters229 is more important than the first group.230 It is proper that a letter that is said often be one that is easy to pronounce.231 It is also fitting that the alef, heh, vav, and yod be easy to pronounce and have important meanings.232 These four letters are found in the vowels233 and are implied letters.234 These letters serve at times as consonants, at times as silent letters,235 and at times as paragogic letters.236 At times they drop out.237 At other times they are swallowed by a dagesh.238 Finally, at other times they interchange with each other.239

Now there are four gutturals. They start with the ayin, which is followed by the chet.240 Do not consider all the letters that make up the name of a guttural in your definition of a guttural, as the additional letters are not made by the throat.241 It is best to refer to them as sounded with a pattach.242 Now the ayin and chet are very hard to sound. A person who is not accustomed to pronouncing them in his youth will not be able to sound them properly. Thus the gentiles cannot sound them.243 Hence only the alef and heh were chosen from among the gutturals to serve as ministering letters.244 Ministering letters were also chosen from among the palatals, i.e., gimel, yod, kaf, kof, as the palate is next to the throat. The yod and kaf were chosen from the palatals to serve as ministering letters because they are the easiest palatals to pronounce. The gimel and kof are therefore only used as root letters.

The letters dalet, tet, lamed, nun, and tav are linguals. Two letters, the dalet and the tet, were chosen from the linguals to serve only as root letters. The others serve both as root letters and as ministering letters. The letters zayin, samekh, shin, resh, and tzadi are dentals. They are all hard to pronounce.245 The shin is the easiest of the dentals to sound. Hence it was chosen as a ministering letter while the others were left to serve only as root letters. Therefore three letters were chosen from among the labials, namely, the bet, vav, mem, and peh, to serve as ministering letters.246 The peh was left to serve only as a root letter.

It is only right that the alphabet begin with a guttural, because the throat is the first organ in the framework of the human body to produce a sound.247 It does so from bottom to top.248 The alef comes before the heh because it is the easiest guttural to pronounce. Hence the alef heads all the other letters of the alphabet and is equivalent to the number one. It is fitting that the heh be the fifth number equivalent to the glorious number five.249 These two letters are the easiest to enunciate. Now since the first letter of the alphabet is a guttural the second letter in the alphabet was chosen from among the five labials, which are produced by the last of the body’s five organs of speech.250 Hence the bet follows the alef, the vav also follows the heh, and the peh the ayin.251 Now it was necessary to put in two letters between the bet and the heh. A palatal, the gimel, was chosen as the third letter and a lingual, the dalet, as the fourth letter.252 Hence a dental, namely, the zayin, follows the vav.
