Why kill him when he went?66 Our case cannot be compared to that of Balaam.67 Similarly, the incident with Jacob is different.68 Should someone argue, where do we find a case where God’s anger did not cause harm,69 we will show him, And the anger of the Lord was kindled against them (Num. 12:9),70 yet no harm befell Aaron.71

Scripture refers to Aaron as the Levite, for this is the way the Levite prophet72 was known in Israel since there were others who bore this name.73 Now Aaron’s appointment as spokesman74 did not entail Moses’ demotion. On the contrary, Moses’ status was thereby elevated. Aaron was merely an instrument, similar to the mouth which brings forth the words of the invisible soul which, like the angels, cannot be seen because they are incorporeal. Moses’ station was thus similar to the station of an angel.75 This is the meaning of And thou shalt be to him in Elohim’s (God’s)76stead (v. 16). Now Elohim in Scripture does not refer to anything but God the glorious or His holy angels77 or the holy ones below who execute God’s justice in the world.78 Whenever Scripture refers to an idol by the term elohim79 it does so in keeping with the beliefs of its worshippers.80 It is similar to unto the prophet Hananiah81 (Jer. 28:5).

17. AND…THIS ROD. Scripture refers to the signs82 because the rod changed into a serpent before all of Israel and into a serpent before Pharaoh. The rod was also used to strike the Nile, to bring up frogs, to produce gnats, to bring down hail, to bring locusts, and to cause darkness.83

18. AND MOSES WENT…JETHER.84 Jether and Jethro are one and the same. Similarly, Geshem (Neh. 6:2) and Gashmu85 (Neh. 6:6) are one and the same, as are Salmah86 (Ruth 4:20) and Salmon (Ruth 4:21). Moses told Jethro that he was going to see his brethren. He did not reveal the secret to him.87

19. AND THE LORD SAID. The Torah is not88 in chronological order.89 The meaning of and the Lord said is, and the Lord had said.90 Similarly, And out of the ground made the Lord to grow91 (Gen. 2:9) and many other such instances. Now when Moses was handing over Jethro’s sheep to Jethro, God assured him that he could go to Egypt without trepidation because Pharaoh and his servants who knew about the incident of the Egyptian were dead. This is the meaning of that the king of Egypt died (Ex. 2:23); as long as Pharaoh lived it was improper for Moses to be a messenger to him.92

20. AND MOSES TOOK. We do not know whether Gershom was born at the time that Moses was a young man, when he fled to Midian, or during his old age. Do not rely on The History of Moses,93 as everything written in it is nonsense. Moses’ second son, namely, Eliezer, was born now, at the time that Moses started to prophesy. Moses planned to bring his wife and sons to Egypt so that they could leave Egypt together with all of Israel. However, this was not a good idea; he was going to bring the Israelites out of Egypt and they would see that he came with his wife and children to live there.94 Do not be surprised that a prophet should incorrectly assess practical events,95 for indeed we find that David asked Nathan the prophet whether is was proper for him to build a temple to the Lord.96 Nathan then answered him, All that is in thy heart do, for the Lord is with thee.97 However, in a prophetic vision of the night, Nathan was told to inform David that he should not build the temple.98

The elders99 were forced to translate upon an ass as upon the man carrier, because it is demeaning that the wife of the prophet and her two sons should ride on one ass.100 Yefet101 says that ass is used as a collective noun,102 as in And I have an ox and an ass (Gen. 32:6).103 However, Yefet is incorrect. This is not the place to use collective nouns.104 The term105 thus must be taken literally.106 Now the asses in Egypt are dearer and more precious than the mules.107 There is nothing to wonder about108 if his son Gershom rode behind his mother. Perhaps he was small109 and Eliezer was in her bosom for he was not yet circumcised.

[AND HE RETURNED TO THE LAND OF EGYPT.] Its meaning is that only Moses himself returned.110 When God met Moses (v. 24) Eliezer was circumcised (v. 25). When Eliezer was healed, Zipporah and her children returned to her father. Moses left them and went on to Egypt.

Scripture refers to the staff as the rod of God because of the sign that was performed with it.111 The rod of God is the same as the rod of Moses and the rod of Aaron. It was in his112 hand when he did the signs.113 Now that the rod of God is mentioned Scripture backtracks and relates that God told Moses114 all the wonders that he was destined to do in Egypt.115 He mentioned116 to Moses the sign that would bring Israel out of Egypt, namely, the plague of the first-born.117

[24. AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE WAY AT THE LODGING-PLACE.] This should have been connected to And Moses took his wife and his sons (v. 20).118 There are many such cases in the Pentateuch, an example being, he shall make restitution (Ex. 22:2). The latter is connected to he shall pay five oxen for an ox (Ex. 21:37).119

21. AND THE LORD SAID. This was told to Moses in Midian.120 God informed Moses that He would harden Pharaoh’s heart and that Pharaoh would not let them go despite all of the wonders, including the last one,121 that He would show them.122

22. AND THOU SHALT SAY. The meaning of Israel is My son, My first-born123 is: the ancestors of this nation were the first to serve Me. I therefore take pity on this nation as a father pities a son who serves him. You took him for a perpetual slave. I will therefore kill your first-born son.

23. AND I HAVE SAID UNTO THEE. Behold, I have told you time and time again to let My son go, that he may serve Me by offering sacrifices to Me, and thou hast refused to let him go. I will therefore punish thee.124 The ignorant say that these words are directed at Moses.125 The latter is sheer madness. Furthermore, Eliezer126 was not Moses’ first-born.127

24. AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE WAY. They had a tradition that a child should not be circumcised on the eighth day if he was sick, or while traveling when it was not possible for his guardian to tarry and circumcise him. Now because Moses could not tarry in carrying out God’s mission he concluded that he should not circumcise his son, because the child would be in danger if he were taken along.128 God therefore sent an angel129 to tell Moses to put his decision aside130 and to circumcise the lad. The child would then remain with his mother until healed and Moses would continue on by himself.

[THAT THE LORD MET HIM.] Its meaning is that God sent an illness upon Moses because it did not occur to him.131 This then is the meaning of and sought to slay him: God sought to slay Moses if he would not circumcise his son. Now because Moses was seized with trembling132 he could not circumcise his son. Zipporah circumcised him, for Moses revealed this secret to her.133 Do not be surprised that it is written, That the Lord met him;134 the reference is to an angel of the Lord. And the Lord went before them (Ex. 13:21) is similar, and there it is written, And the angel of God…removed (Ex. 14:19). However, Rabbi Samuel ben Hofni135 says: Perish the thought that God would seek to slay Moses who was on God’s mission to redeem His people. It was rather Eliezer whom the Lord sought to slay, and it is to Eliezer that the third person pronominal suffixes of va-yifgeshehu (met him) and hamito (slay him) refer. Scripture then goes on to explain that the reference is to Eliezer.136 Scripture therefore states, and cut off the foreskin of her son. He is not at first mentioned137 because he did not as yet have a name. And it came to pass, when she travailed, that one put out a hand (Gen. 38:28) is similar.138

25. THEN ZIPPORAH TOOK A FLINT. A sharp instrument.139 Compare, Make thee knives of flint140 (Josh. 5:2) which refers to sharp knives. Yea, thou turnest back the flint (tzur) of his sword141 (Ps. 89:44) is similar.

[AND CAST IT AT HIS FEET.] In my opinion the reference is to Moses’ feet. Our verse is like142 and when He seeth the blood upon the lintel, and upon the side-posts, the Lord…will not suffer the destroyer to come in unto your houses to destroy you (Ex. 12:23). Therefore143 He let him, that is, Moses, alone; his illness and shivering ceased. However, Rabbi Samuel144 says that his feet refers to Eliezer’s feet,145 and similarly He let him alone.146 This being the case we can refute him by asking, “If the illness befell Eliezer how could Zipporah circumcise him, thereby adding pain to his pain?”147
[A BRIDEGROOM OF BLOOD.] It is the custom of women to refer to a child as a bridegroom when he is circumcised.
[BLOOD.] Its meaning is, surely thou art a man of blood to me,148 for because of you my husband will die.

26. SO HE LET HIM ALONE. The word damim (blood) in Hebrew is used in two ways. One way is to indicate bloodshed, as in because thou art a man of blood to me (II Sam. 16:8).149 The person who says that damim refers to life150 is giving the word a meaning that it does not have. The second way151 is as a plural referring to actual blood,152 as in be-damayikh chayi (in thy blood live) (Ezek. 16:6). Now when Zipporah saw that the illness left Moses she exclaimed, you my son are not a bridegroom of blood, blood referring to death,153 but you are a bridegroom wallowing in the blood of circumcision. The word mulot (circumcision) is a noun. It is in the plural154 because of damim (blood).155

27. AND THE LORD SAID TO AARON. Aaron did not prophesy;156 there was no need for him to do so157 as Moses was the messenger sent to Pharaoh. However, prior to this Aaron had been sent as messenger to the male Israelites, and Miriam to the females. The prophet therefore says, And I sent before thee Moses, Aaron, and Miriam (Micah 6:4).
IN THE MOUNTAIN OF GOD. The reference is to Mount Horeb.
28. AND MOSES TOLD. God sent Moses to Israel first.158
AND ALL THE SIGNS WHEREWITH HE HAD CHARGED HIM. To first perform before Israel and then to perform other signs before Pharaoh.159
29. AND MOSES AND AARON WENT. The elders are the counselors in each generation,160 as Moses and Aaron could not possibly speak to six hundred thousand men. It was rather the elders who spoke to them.

30. AND AARON SPOKE. For he was Moses’ mouthpiece.161 Moses therefore never spoke to Israel except through Aaron. When Aaron died his son Eleazar took his place and similarly became Moses’ mouthpiece.
31. AND THE PEOPLE BELIEVED. After they heard that the Lord had remembered his people. The end of the time period that had been told to Abraham had come.162
THEIR AFFLICTION. Onyam comes from the same root as inuy (affliction).163

THEN THEY BOWED. Va-yikkedu (then they bowed) comes from a double root.164 It is like the word kodkod (skull).165 Va-yikkedu follows the paradigm of va-yittemu (were ended)166 in so the days of weeping in the mourning of Moses were ended (Deut. 34:8) and yiddemu (they are still)167 in they are as still as stone (Ex. 16:16). If only those who say that these words168 come from roots that begin with a nun169 would be as still as stone. In order to explain the paradigm170 they add roots that are nonexistent in the holy tongue.171 Can they not see that the word redu (get you down)172 (Gen. 42:2) follows the paradigm of benu (build ye)173 in Build ye (lakhem) houses (Jer. 29:5)174 although they are two different175 roots.176 The correct thing is to do everything in our power not to multiply roots because of paradigms.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Literally, told.
2 I.E. was bothered by the following: since God told Moses, And they shall hearken to thy voice (Ex. 3:18) why did Moses now say, But, behold, they will not believe me.

3 Thus God never actually told Moses that he would be believed. It should be noted that Nahmanides had a different reading of I.E. According to Nahmanides, I.E. offers two answers to the question raised (see note 2). God told Moses that the elders would believe. He did not tell him that the people would believe. And they shall hearken to thy voice only relates to behavior, not to inner belief.
4 The staff becoming a serpent.
5 The burning bush convinced Moses of the truth of his mission.
6 Moses was then 80 years old and walked with a staff (Krinsky).
7 Thus the staff in his hand was not a shepherd’s staff but the staff of an elder.
8 In Hebrew, chakhme ha-mechkar (philosophers professing materialistic principles) (Friedlander).
9 For a staff to be turned into a serpent by being cast upon the ground.
10 To conclude by their philosophic inquiries.
11 The dry wood of the staff became moist by coming into contact with the ground. It was then fit for life to enter it (Zarza). This explanation of course appears ridiculous to a modern person.
12 About Pharaoh. It explained Pharaoh’s nature.
13 By soft, I.E. means an object not inherently evil. Pharaoh at first did not oppress the Israelites.
14 Hebrew tannim. J.P.S. translates it as dragon. However, Yefet rendered it as serpent.
15 Like the serpent which turned back to a staff. Pharaoh the serpent of the Nile was defanged and broken like a dry stick.
16 Which became leprous. This raises a question: Leprosy is usually a sign of punishment. (Cf. Num. 12:10; II Chron. 26:20.) This being the case, why was Moses punished?

17 So too the sages of the Talmud and Midrash. Cf. Sabbath 57a; Shemot Rabba 3:12. Similarly Rashi. It is hard to understand why I.E. would quote a Karaite when he had traditional sources at his disposal that said the same thing.
18 That Moses was being punished.
19 First Moses should have been punished by having his hand turned leprous and then shown the sign of the staff turning into a serpent.
20 In other words, Moses was not being punished.
21 According to Saadiah Gaon ve-cheko means in his sleeve and ve-chekekha in your sleeve.
22 Moses did not know how many signs he would have to do before all the people would believe him.
23 See I.E. on Gen. 1:26.
24 Scripture refers to the second sign as the latter sign (ha’ot ha-acharon). However, in view of the fact that there were three signs, Scripture should have referred to it as the second sign.
25 The second sign was thus the latter sign at that moment.
26 It means please or pray.
27 I.E. explains avon (iniquity) to mean punishment. See his comments on Gen. 4:13 and 43:20. Thus bi ani adoni he-avon means upon me, my lord be, the punishment.
28 I.E.’s elaboration of the implication of bi ani adoni he-avon in the context in which it is used in this verse.

29 Our text reads, gam mi-temol gam mi-shilshom (neither heretofore), gam me-az dabberekha el avdekha (nor since Thou hast spoken unto Thy servant). Literally translated, it means: also from yesterday and also from the third day, also since Thou hast spoken unto Thy servant. The first “also” appears out of place hence I.E.’s comment. I.E. then goes on to explain what Scripture means by the third day.
30 This is the literal rendition of the verse. J.P.S. translates somewhat differently.
31 J.P.S. heretofore. See note 29.
32 J.P.S. heretofore. See note 29.

33 Hence shilshom (the third day) means three days ago. The point is that the Bible uses temol and shilshom back to back. Since temol means yesterday the word shilshom must mean three says ago, not the third day to come.
34 The masculine pronominal plural suffix.
35 That is, shilshom means their third day, i.e., today’s and yesterday’s third day (Weiser).
36 If the meaning of shilshom is their third day (shalosh she-lahem) the word should have read shilsham.
37 That is, the mem of shilshom is not the mem of the plural. It is a form (or superfluous) letter and has no meaning.
38 The mem in mishlosh has no meaning. See I.E. on Gen. 35:24.
39 The word az means then. Hence I.E.’s comment that me-az means from the time or since.
40 The reason that Moses said what is recorded in our verse.
41 By God when He revealed Himself to Moses.
42 This commentator explains that slowness of speech and tongue refers not to a speech impediment but rather to Moses’ inability to speak Egyptian. The latter interpretation is offered by Rashbam.
43 If the reference was merely to difficulty in speaking Egyptian, Moses would have limited himself to slowness of speech.
44 God appears to be addressing a complaint about a physical impediment rather than one dealing with a lack of knowledge.
45 Slowness of speech indicates a problem with labials, for the Hebrew word for speech is safah (lips). Slowness of tongue indicates a problem with linguals.
46 In our verse.
47 It comes from the root peh, kof, chet, which means to open. Thus pike’ach can refer to one who can either hear or see.
48 As our verse may be taken to imply.
49 See verse 12.
51 Hence shlach na (send, I pray) means send now.
52 Translated according to I.E. J.P.S. translates as, We pray thee.
53 Translated according to I.E. J.P.S. translation reads, Woe unto us; i.e., it does not translates na.

54 From the clause shelach na be-yad tishlach (send, I pray thee, by the hand of him whom Thou wilt send). Its literal meaning is: send, I pray Thee (or now) by the hand of Thou wilt send, hence I.E.’s comment that the word asher (whom, i.e., he whom) has to be added to the text. The word asher can mean which, that, who, or in order to.
55 Which means via the hand of him whom you were in the habit of sending, i.e., Aaron. Rashi interprets similarly.
56 The word asher has to be added to the clause which is to be read as if written, asher im levavam shalem (of them whose heart is whole).
57 Literally, Aaron his brother.
58 See Ezek. 20:5. I.E. identifies this prophet with Aaron.
59 Which shows that Aaron was a prophet, as God spoke to him.
60 Hence Moses suggested that God appoint Aaron to this task.
61 That is, Aaron is not angry that you, his younger brother, have been chosen as God’s messenger.
62 As God’s messenger, as a superficial reading of verses 10-14 implies.
63 In response to Moses’ reply, I am not a man of words.

64 Is not Aaron thy brother implies that Moses suggested that Aaron be chosen in his place. When he (Aaron) seeth thee, he will be glad in his heart implies that Aaron is not angry for not being chosen. He (Aaron) can speak well implies that Moses was concerned with not being able to speak before the king.
65 That is, God sought to slay Moses (v. 24) because he at first refused the Lord’s call to be His messenger. See Rashbam on verse 24.
66 Verse 24 describes what happened to Moses on his way to Egypt as God’s messenger.
67 Where God told Balaam that he may go to Balak (Num. 22:20) and then sent an angel with a drawn sword to stop him (Num. 22:22), for Balaam had evil intentions (Krinsky).

68 Gen. 32:25 tells us that an angel tried to kill Jacob. However, that incident too cannot be compared to that of Balaam, for that angel was not sent to punish Jacob. So Filwarg. For other interpretations see Krinsky and Weiser. However, their interpretations are forced.
69 That is, once the anger of the Lord was kindled against Moses punishment had to follow. The only punishment that conceivably followed was that the Lord sought to kill him.
70 Against Aaron and Miriam.
71 Thus punishment does not always follow the kindling of God’s anger.
72 That is, Aaron.
73 There were other people who bore the name Aaron. Hence people referred to the Aaron who was the prophet as Aaron the Levite.
74 Literally, this thing.
75 Moses was the “soul” of the words produced by Aaron. The soul is angelic; hence Moses was angelic.
76 That is, you will be as an angel to Aaron.
77 As in verse 16. Also see I.E. on Gen. 1:1.
78 Judges. See I.E. on Gen. 1:1.
79 Which seems to indicate that elohim also means an idol. However, I.E. has just stated that it refers only to God, angels, and judges.
80 Thus even when elohim refers to an idol it means a god.
81 Who was not a true prophet, yet was called one.
82 Scripture speaks of this rod, wherewith thou shalt do the signs. However, up to now Scripture speaks of only one sign that was to be done with the rod, i.e., its being changed into a serpent.
83 Many other signs were to be done with the rod in the future. Hence Scripture speaks of the signs.
84 This is the Hebrew reading. J.P.S. translates it as Jethro.
85 This is the Hebrew reading. J.P.S. translates it as Geshem.
86 This is the Hebrew reading. J.P.S. translates it as Salmon.
87 That he was going at God’s command to liberate them.
88 Always.

89 What is reported in verse 19 had to take place before what is recorded in verse 18. It is illogical for Moses to have told Jethro that he was going to Egypt before being informed by the Lord that Pharaoh was dead.
90 For the reasons noted in note 89 we must translate verse 19 as: and the Lord had said to Moses in Midian (i.e., before Moses had taken leave of Jethro), Go return into Egypt.
91 See I.E. on Gen. 2:9.
92 The same Pharaoh who knew of the incident of the Egyptian.
93 A medieval work dealing with the life of Moses.
94 Hence the Israelites would have reason to doubt whether they were really going to be brought out of Egypt.
95 That is, do not be surprised that a prophet can err as Moses did in wanting to bring his family to Egypt.
96 This is the import of II Sam. 7:2.
97 I.E.’s slight paraphrase of II Sam. 7:3.
99 Who translated the Pentateuch into Greek. See Megillah 9a.
100 For this implies that Moses was impoverished.
101 See notes and comments on Ex. 3:3.
102 Thus more than one ass was used by Moses’ family. Therefore the verse does not imply that Moses was impoverished.
103 The meaning of which is: And I have oxen and asses.
104 One uses the collective noun when one speaks of many of a kind. Here, at most two asses were involved and the use of the collective is out of place.
105 Ass.
106 It refers to one ass.
107 Hence Moses chose an ass rather than a mule for his family to ride upon.
108 Why Moses employed one ass for his family. His wife rode holding their infant son Eliezer and their other son rode behind her as children are wont to do.
109 Young. See the opening of I.E.’s comment. This would make the scenario more acceptable, and not be demeaning to Moses.
110 The verse reads, And Moses took his wife and his sons…and he returned to Egypt. Hence I.E’s comment.
112 Aaron’s (Weiser).
113 When Aaron performed signs he held the rod. Hence it is also referred to as the rod of Aaron.
114 In general terms.
115 Verse 21.
116 That is, he specifically mentioned.
117 Verse 23.

118 The sequence of events is: And Moses took his wife and his sons, and set them on an ass. And it came to pass on the way at the lodging place, etc. That which is between these verses is parenthetical.
119 And not that which immediately precedes it.
120 When God told Moses, Go return into Egypt (v. 19) (Krinsky).
121 The plague of the first-born. Even after this plague Pharaoh changed his mind and tried to re-enslave the Israelites.
122 Nahmanide’s version of I.E. had, “God informed Moses that he would harden Pharaoh’s heart and that Pharaoh would not let them go despite the wonders until He would show (them) the last wonder.”
123 And what follows, i.e., verse 23.
124 I.E.’s paraphrase of verse 23.
125 Moses refused to go to Egypt to liberate God’s first-born son (Israel). God therefore threatened to kill Moses’ son. This explains the sequence which follows in verse 24.
126 The son of Moses that God wanted to kill (v. 24).
127 If God wanted to kill Moses’ first-born because Moses did not have pity on His first-born, then Gershom should have been threatened.
128 After circumcising him.
129 This is the meaning of that the Lord met him.
130 Not to circumcise Eliezer.
131 To circumcise his son at that time. I.E. literally reads: Its meaning is, an illness came upon Moses from God that he did not think.
132 He was shivering due to the illness.
133 That he was ill because he did not circumcise his son.
134 I.E. explains that God sent an angel to tell Moses to desist from his decision. However, the verse implies that it was God Himself who met Moses.
135 The last Gaon of Sura. He died in 1034 C.E.
136 That is, to her son. The name Eliezer is not used in our passage.

137 Scripture refers to Eliezer by the term him. However, before referring to a person in the third person, one has to first identify him. I.E. thus explains that Scripture does not identify the object of va-yifgeshehu and hamito because he did not yet have a name.
138 Scripture does not identify the one that put out his hand because he was not yet named.
139 According to I.E. the word tsor (flint) is not to be translated as flint but as something sharp and hard as a flint, that is, a sharp instrument.
140 Hebrew, tzurim.
141 J.P.S. translates as edge of his sword.

142 That is, the placing of the bloody foreskin on Moses’ feet was similar to the placing of the blood on the side-posts and lintels of the Israelite homes; i.e., it prevented the destroyer from killing.
143 Because of what Zipporah did.
144 Rabbi Samuel ben Hofni.
145 Rabbi Samuel’s comment is in keeping with his interpretation that it was Eliezer rather than Moses who took ill.
146 The reference is again to Eliezer.
147 The idea is that it would be either dangerous or cruel.
148 Cf. II Sam. 16:8, because (surely) thou art a man of blood. Thus blood means bloody.
149 “To me” is not found in the verse quoted. I.E., under the influence of his comment on the word blood, added the words to me to II Sam. 16:8.

150 This commentary takes blood to mean life because a living person has blood flowing through him. According to this commentary, Surely a bridegroom of blood art thou to me means: Surely a live bridegroom are thou (Moses) to me; i.e., thou art alive because I circumcised Eliezer. Similarly the word blood in the next verse. It should be noted that in Ex. 22:2 Rashi explains dam (blood) as alive and I.E. takes issue with him there (Filwarg).
151 That the word damim is used.
152 The singular being dam.
153 That is, you are not a bloody bridegroom.
154 Prima facie, the singular should have been used.
155 Damim which precedes mulot is in the plural; i.e., the word mulot is in the plural because it follows damim.
156 God told Aaron, Go into the wilderness to meet Moses. He did not tell him to prophesy before Pharaoh (Weiser).
157 Henceforth.
158 Besides sending Moses to Pharaoh, God also told Moses to speak to Israel before speaking to Pharaoh, Hence Moses and Aaron went first to the children of Israel.
159 Hence Moses first performed signs before Israel (v. 30) and only later before Pharaoh (Ex. 7:10).

160 In other words, elders means counselors. In medieval Spain the Jews were ruled in part by a mo’etzah, a board of counselors. I.E. apparently assumes that each generation going back to Moses had a similar arrangement with the exception that in previous times they were referred to as zekenim (elders) rather than yo’atzim (counselors).
161 Melitz literally means interpreter.
162 That is, Know of a surety that thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs…four hundred years (Gen. 15:13).
163 Its root is ayin, nun, heh.
164 Its root is kof, dalet, dalet.
165 The root of which is kof, dalet, dalet.
166 From the root tav, mem, mem.
167 From the root dalet, mem, mem.
168 That is, va-yikkedu, va-yittemu, and yiddemu.
169 That is, that the root of yikkedu is nun, kof, dalet; of yittemu, nun, tav, mem; and of yiddemu, nun, dalet, mem.

170 The point is that the words yikkedu, yittemu, and yiddemu follow the paradigm of roots that begin with a nun. Compare, yippelu from the root nun, peh, lamed, and yittenu from the root nun, tet, nun. Hence they conclude that the former come from similar roots. See note 168.
171 For they make peh nuns out of double roots. See note 168.
172 From the root yod, resh, dalet.
173 From the root bet, nun, heh.

174 The word lakhem (ye) is not in Jeremiah. The reference might be Num. 32:24, which reads, Build you (lakhem) cities. In any case, if this is not a scribal error then I.E. quoted from memory and erred.
175 The literal reading is: and they are roots. “Two different” is not in our text, but it is in Vat. Ebr. 38. In any case, it has to be inserted in order to make sense.

176 We thus see that words from different root families can follow similar paradigms. Hence there is no reason to assume that yikkedu, yittemu, and yiddemu must be peh nuns because they follow a peh nun paradigm.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 5
chapter.p: 1. AND AFTERWARD. After Aaron did the signs1 the two of them came to Pharaoh and the two of them spoke.2 For the Lord had promised them, and I will be with thy mouth,3 and with his mouth4 (Ex. 4:15).

AND SAID…THUS SAITH THE LORD, THE GOD OF ISRAEL. Pharaoh had never before heard this name.5 Moses therefore added the God of Israel,6 the meaning of which is, the people of Israel and not only the patriarch Jacob.

THAT THEY MAY HOLD A FEAST (VE-YACHOGU) UNTO ME IN THE WILDERNESS. That they may sacrifice unto me.7 Compare, bind the offering (chag) to the horns of the altar with cords,8 and chaggim (offerings) in Let the offerings come round (Is. 29:1).9
2. AND PHARAOH SAID: WHO IS THE LORD, THAT I SHOULD HEARKEN UNTO HIS VOICE. He asked, “Who is the Lord that he is God?”10 We learn this from Moses’ answer to Pharaoh, which follows.11

3. AND THEY SAID. This name12 refers to the God of the Hebrews. The Hebrews were a group whom the Egyptians were familiar with.13 The term Hebrew refers to Abraham, who is called the Hebrew.14 It likewise refers to Abraham’s son Isaac and to Jacob and his sons,15 as I will explain when I comment on the verse if thou buy a Hebrew servant (Ex. 21:2).

AND THEY SAID. The word nikra (hath met) is similar to nikro nikreti (as I happened by chance)16 in As I happened by chance upon mount Gilboa (II Sam. 1:6). It means met. He explained to Pharaoh why they are obligated to offer sacrifices, i.e., lest a pestilence or sword come upon us.17
LEST HE FALL UPON US. Upon us includes us Israelites, also you, Pharaoh, and all the Egyptians.

When Pharaoh saw that swarms of animals came and devoured many Egyptians, as it is written, He sent among them swarms of animals, which devoured them18 (Ps. 78:45), he said, Go ye, sacrifice to your God in the land (Ex. 8:21).19 However, Moses answered him, it is not meet so to do in the land20 (Ps. 8:22). On the contrary, they would go a distance of three days’ journey into the wilderness (Ps. 8:23).21 The latter is the distance between Egypt and Mount Sinai for one who takes a straight path. It was there22 that the Israelites offered sacrifices, as it is written, ye shall serve God upon this mountain (Ex. 3:12).23 It is furthermore written, and Moses24 builded an altar under the mount (Ex. 24:4). Also, the altar that Moses built after Amalek was defeated25 was erected on Mount Sinai, as it is written, and (Israel) encamped in Rephidim26 (Ex. 17:1), and it is there written, Behold, I will stand before thee there upon the rock in Horeb27 (Ex. 17:6).

When the locusts came28 Pharaoh gave some of the Israelites permission to go and sacrifice (Ex. 10:11). After the plague of darkness Pharaoh gave them all permission to go, with the exception that their cattle were to remain (Ex. 11:24). Now when they saw that a plague came and struck their first-born, Moses’ words, lest he fall upon us with pestilence, became clear.29 They therefore said, We are all dead men (Ex. 12:33). The Egyptians then chased them out (Ex. 12:39) to go and sacrifice.30 They also let them have what they asked for (Ex. 12:36).

4. AND THE KING OF EGYPT SAID. The word tafri’u (ye cause to break loose) means ye cause to disrupt.31 Yifra (cast off restraint) in When there is no vision, the people cast off restraint (yifra)32 (Prov. 29:18) is similar. Pharaoh included Moses and Aaron in get you unto your burdens, for Moses and Aaron represented all of Israel.33 Your burdens does not mean your affairs.34 And will ye make them35 rest from their burdens (v. 5) proves the aforementioned.36

5. AND PHARAOH SAID. Yefet says that the meaning of the people of the land are now many is, we are not concerned if pestilence or sword befalls them, for those who toil37 are many.38 However, according to my opinion its meaning is, you are seeking to cause a great amount of work to cease.
6. AND THE SAME DAY PHARAOH COMMANDED. The taskmasters were Egyptian and the officers of the people were Israelites.
7. YE SHALL NO MORE GIVE. Tosifun (ye shall more)39 is spelled with an alef.40 However, it is usually spelled with a vav.41 Both of these letters42 interchange with the yod.
[STRAW.] It is customary for those who build with soil to mix it with straw or chaff so that it will last.

TO MAKE BRICK. Lilbon (to make brick) comes from the same root as levenah43 (brick). A brick structure is stronger than a stone structure,44 because a structure made out of soil45 will be damaged by water and a stone structure will be harmed by fire.46 It is similarly written, And they had brick for stone,47 and slime had they for mortar (Gen. 11:3).48 Note, there are nouns that are vocalized with a tzere, such as the word sefer (book),49 or a segol, i.e., tzedek (righteousness),50 whose status does not change51 at an etnach52 or at the end of a verse.53 The word teven (straw) falls into this category.54 We not know the reason for the this; however, such is the case.
AND GATHER. Ve-kosheshu (and gather) comes from the same root as kash (stubble).55 comes from a double root.56
8. AND THE TALE. Matkonet means tale. It refers to a specified amount.

9. LET HEAVIER WORK BE LAID. Saadiah Gaon says that al yishu (let them not regard) is like al yishanu (let them not rely)57 with the nun omitted, as it is in the word tet (to put)58 in I begin to put the dread of thee (Deut. 2:25).

Pay no attention nor listen to the dreamer who says that the root of tet is tat.59 Because he found Scripture employing the word tattah (you put) in My enemies you put to flight before me (II Sam. 22:41), he thought that tattah is like shattah (thou hast set)60 in Thou hast set our iniquities before Thee (Ps. 90:8). Now he cannot deny that the second tav in the word tattah indicates the second person61 and the tav of the root is swallowed in the dagesh,62 even though the tav63 should receive a dagesh like the tav in ve-hishbatti (and I will cause to cease) in and I will cause evil beasts to cease out of the land (Lev. 26:6). Since this is the case64 it is better for the nun to be swallowed65 as it is swallowed by the tav in the word va-amitto (and his truth) (Gen. 24:27), for the word amitto66 should have been written aminto and the word bat (daughter), benat and the word tet, tenet.67 The missing first nun of the word tattah in tattah li is similar to the missing yod in rad68 (spent) in the day was far spent (Jud. 19:11) and to the missing nun in the word ga (touch)69 in Touch the mountains, that they may smoke (Ps. 144:5).

However, in my opinion the word yishu (regard) means slack off, as Pharaoh said, for they are idle (nirpim) (v. 8).70 Yishu is similar to hasha (let go) in Let go of me (Ps. 39:14)71 and she’u (let go) in Let go of me (Is. 22:4),72 and to hasha (weaken) in And weaken73 their eyes (Is. 6:10), for when the eyes weaken they grow dim.74 Tishenah (shall be closed) in And the eyes of them that see shall be closed (Is. 32:3) is similar.
[LYING WORDS.] Its meaning is, because75 of the lying words that Moses and Aaron assure them with.76
10. WENT OUT. Of the king’s palace to the people who were working.77
11. GO YOURSELVES, GET YOU STRAW WHERE YE CAN FIND IT. Close by or far off.
FOR NOUGHT OF YOUR WORK SHALL BE DIMINISHED. Nigra (diminished) is a participle.78 It is therefore vocalized with a kamatz as is the rule.79
12. WERE SCATTERED. Va-yafetz (were scattered) is a transitive verb.80 Pharaoh, who caused them to scatter, is the subject.81
FOR STRAW. In place of straw.82 Compare, la-chomer (for mortar) in and slime had they for mortar (Gen. 11:3).83

13. AND THE TASKMASTERS WERE URGENT. Atzim (urgent) is a transitive verb.84 It is like the word shav (returned) and the word mash (moved), which is sometimes found transitive and at times intransitive.
[SAYING.] Its meaning is, saying to them.85.
DAILY. The phrase devar yom be-yomo (daily)86 is similar to And from one sabbath to another (Is. 66:23).87
14. AND THE OFFICERS…OVER THEM. Over the Israelites.

[BOTH YESTERDAY AND TO-DAY.] I have previously explained88 the use of the additional gam (both).89 Now, both yesterday refers to the day that Moses did the signs before the eyes of the people and they consequently were not occupied with their work. To-day refers to the day that Moses and Aaron came to Pharaoh.90 And thus it is written, And the same day91 Pharaoh commanded the taskmasters of the people (v. 6).92
15. WHEREFORE DEALEST THOU THUS WITH THY SERVANTS? It was never your practice to do this.93

[16. BUT THE FAULT IS IN THINE OWN PEOPLE.] The word ve-chatat (but the fault is)94 is a verb in the perfect.95 However, the vav changes it into an imperfect in accordance with the rules of grammar.96 The word is similar to ve-chate’ah.97 Now when the alef was silenced, as it is in the word chata,98 it was not possible to place a heh after the alef.99 They therefore substituted a tav for the heh.100 There is no need to place a dagesh101 in the tet.102 The word ve-karat (will befall)103 in and evil will befall you (Deut. 31:29) is similar.104 The word am (people) is here a feminine.105 Compare, ha-am (the people) in the people that were therein, how they dwelt106 in security (Jud. 18:7) and ha-am (the people) in Why is this people of Jerusalem slidden back107 (Jer. 8:5). Its meaning is,108 but the sin will be upon you. Moses out of respect alluded to Pharaoh by saying that the sin would be on his people.109 That I and my son Solomon shall be counted offenders (I Kings 1:21),110 And our enemies mock us as they please (Ps. 80:7),111 and Thus they exchanged their glory (Ps. 106:20)112 are similar.
17. BUT HE SAID. Your words did not avail, as Pharaoh was steadfast in the hardness of his heart.113
18. GO THEREFORE NOW, AND WORK. Pharaoh said this to the officers,114 as they too were obligated to work.

19. DID SEE. This verse is connected to the verses that follow it.115 They saw themselves in dire straits116 because Pharaoh had said to them, Ye shall not diminish aught from your bricks, your daily task.117 Then they met Moses and Aaron and complained to them.118 The word otam (they) means themselves,119 their very bodies.120 Otam (themselves) in But the shepherds fed themselves (Ezek. 34:8) and oto (himself)121 in and he122 buried himself in the valley (Deut. 34:6)123 are similar. Rabbi Moses ben Balaam124 says that oto (it)125 in he shall bring it (oto) unto the door of the tent of meeting (Num. 6:13)126 is also similar. However, in my opinion its meaning127 is that the priest shall command to bring him.128

20. AND THEY MET. The words “who were” are missing.129 Our text should be read as if written: who were standing.130 And Pharaoh dreams (Gen. 41:1)131 is similar. Its meaning is, and Pharaoh was dreaming. Similarly, and behold he was standing by the river (Ibid.).132 There are many other such instances in Scripture.133
21. AND THEY SAID UNTO THEM: THE LORD LOOK. At the violence done to us, the responsibility for which falls upon you.

[YE HAVE MADE OUR SAVOUR TO BE ABHORRED IN THE EYES OF PHARAOH.] Note that the five senses are perceived in one place located above the forehead.134 Hence one sense is substituted for another sense,135 as in And the light is sweet (Eccles. 11:7).136 However, Rabbi Merinus says that its meaning is, we are as disgusting and abhorrent in his eyes as a foul odor.137

22. AND MOSES RETURNED. Now a question: Why did Moses complain and say, Why is it that thou hast sent me? and Neither hast thou delivered Thy people at all after God told him, And I know that the king of Egypt will not give you leave to go (Ex. 3:19) until he performed all the signs that God commanded him? The answer is, Moses thought that Pharaoh would lighten Israel’s yoke as soon as he spoke to him. However, Pharaoh placed a heavier workload upon them.138

[WHEREFORE HAST THOU DEALT ILL WITH THIS PEOPLE?] Contrary to Your words, I have surely seen the affliction of My people (Ex. 3:7); And I am come down to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians (Ibid.).
[WHY IS IT THAT THOU HAST SENT ME] To harm Israel. Behold,139 I have not found an answer to give the officers.140
23. FOR SINCE. From the day that I spoke to Pharaoh he hardened his yoke over them, as it is written, And the same day Pharaoh commanded the taskmasters of the people (v. 6).
[NEITHER HAST THOU DELIVERED.] My very thought was that Pharaoh would begin to lighten their burden141 and You would begin to deliver them.
[HE HAS DEALT ILL WITH THIS PEOPLE.] The word hera (he has dealt ill) is a transitive verb.142 It is similar to here’u (they did worse)143 in they did worse than their fathers (Jer. 7:26).
chapter.ftnote: 1 Recorded in Ex. 4:30.
2 Unto Pharaoh, thus saith the Lord, God of Israel, etc.
3 Moses’ mouth.
4 Aaron’s mouth.
5 Pharaoh had never before heard the name YHVH (Lord).
6 So that Pharaoh would know to whom he was referring.
7 According to I.E. the word chag not only means a holiday, it also refers to the sacrifice that is offered on the holiday.
8 Translated according to I.E. New J.P.S. translation is similar.
9 Translated according to I.E.
10 Pharaoh was not denying God. He merely asked, “Who is this God YHVH (the Lord)?”
11 Moses answered Pharaoh that YHVH is the God of the Hebrews. We deduce from this that Pharaoh had asked, “Who is this God YHVH?”
12 The Tetragrammaton.
13 Hence Moses identified YHVH as the God of the Hebrews.
14 See Gen. 14:13.

15 It thus applies to the Israelites, hence the term, “the God of the Hebrews.” I.E. explains that the term Hebrew refers to Israelites because there were some commentators who believed that it applied to non-Israelite descendants of Abraham. See I.E. Ex. 21:2.

16 The Hebrew word for met comes from the root kof, resh, heh (karah). However, nikra (spelled with an alef) comes from the root kof, resh, alef. I.E. points out that the alef and the heh interchange. For nikro (spelled with an alef) comes from the root kof, resh, alef and means met, (happened by chance) while nikreti (I happened by chance), from the root kof, resh, heh (the heh changes to a yod in the perfect) has a similar meaning. We thus see that the word nikrah, whether spelled with an alef or a heh, means met.
17 I.E.’s paraphrase of lest He fall upon us with pestilence, or the sword.
18 Translated according to I.E.
19 In Egypt.
20 Of Egypt.
21 And offer sacrifices to the Lord.
22 At Mount Sinai.
23 Mount Sinai.
24 The word Moses is not in this part of the original verse. I.E. probably quoted from memory.
26 Amalek attacked Israel in Rephidim (Ex. 17:8).
27 Horeb is another name for Sinai. We thus see that Rephidim is very close to Sinai.
28 I.E. is not being precise. It was when the threat of locusts came that Pharaoh gave some of the Israelites permission to go and sacrifice. See Ex. 10:1-11.
29 They realized that they were included, as noted by I.E. earlier in his comment on us in verse 3.
30 To the Lord.
31 That is, ye cause the people to spoil their work schedule (Krinsky). Cf. Rashi, “You separate and remove (the people) from their work.”
32 According to I.E. the verse should be rendered: the people disrupt the order of society.
33 Hence Pharaoh’s words were directed at them.
34 Contra Rashi, who comments, “Go to your work which you have to do in your houses.”
35 The Israelites.
36 It is unlikely that the same term (burdens) would refer to Moses’ affairs in verse 4 and Israel’s toil in verse 5.
37 The Israelite slaves.
38 And we can afford to lose some of them to death.
39 From the root yod, samekh, peh.
40 Following the tav.
41 The yod changes into a vav in the hifil.
42 The vav and the alef.
43 Lilbon is a denominative of levenah.
44 Hence they used brick rather than stone.
45 Of mud.
46 Some stones burst when in a fire, but a structure made of brick “will not dissolve in water or fall apart when burned” (I.E. on Gen. 11:3).
47 That is, in place of stone (I.E. on Gen. 11:3).
48 That is, in place of mortar. “A building made from such material is very strong and will not dissolve in water or fall apart when burned” (I.E. on Gen. 11:3).
49 Vocalized tzere, segol.
50 Vocalized segol, segol.
51 That is, whose vowels do not change.
52 A sign indicating a pause. The etnach is placed under the accented syllable of the word which constitutes the most important logical pause within a sentence. It is similar to a colon or semicolon.

53 When a word is vocalized tzere, segol or segol, segol, the tzere and the segol change to a kamatz at an etnach or sof pasuk (the end of the verse). Compare, even / aven; shekel / shakel; lemech / lamech. However, this is not always the case.
54 Hence the end of verse 7 reads teven rather than taven.
55 In other words, ve-kosheshu is a denominative of kash.
56 A root whose second and third letters are the same. Its root is kof, shin, shin.
57 From the root shin, ayin, nun, meaning to rely upon, to lean upon. Cf. Is. 10:20, ve-nishan al Adonai (but shall lean on the Lord).
58 From the root nun, tet, nun, meaning to put or to give.
59 That is, tav, vav, tav, for tat is the third person perfect masculine of tav, vav, tav. Compare, kam from the root kof, vav, mem and shav from the root shin, vav, bet.
60 Shattah comes from the root shin, vav, tav. Tattah resembles shattah; hence this commentator concluded that tattah, like shattah, is an ayin vav.
61 It is not a root letter; it stands for attah (you) in you put.
62 There is a dagesh in the second tav of tattah. That dagesh is in place of a root letter, a tav.

63 This should be emended to read “for the tav.” I.E.’s point is that when a pronominal tav (see note 61) is connected to a root ending in a tav, the tav of the stem is dropped and is compensated for by a dagesh, as in the word ve-hishbatti (root shin, bet, tav). The reading “even though the tav” doesn’t seem to make sense, for it implies that there are grounds for the tav not to receive a dagesh. However, I.E. goes on to show the reverse (Filwarg).
64 That neither tav in tattah is a root letter.
65 That is, it is better to assume that the root of tattah is nun, tav, nun rather than tav, vav, tav, as the root nun, tav, nun is found in Scripture but the root tav, vav, tav as a verb is not.
66 From the root alef, mem, nun.
67 For its root is nun, tav, nun.
68 Words that begin with a yod drop their yod in certain circumstances. Similarly words that begin with a nun. The root of rad is yod, resh, dalet.
69 From the root nun, gimel, ayin.
70 According to I.E. al yishu (let them not regard) means let them not slack off.
71 Translated according to I.E. J.P.S. translates: Look away from me.
72 Translated according to I.E. J.P.S. translates: Look away from me.
73 J.P.S.: shut.
74 Hence the meaning of And weaken their eyes is, and dim or shut their eyes.
75 The Hebrew reads, be-divre shaker. I.E. explains that the bet here has the meaning of because; that is, the phrase means because of lying words.
76 That is, let them not slack off from their work because of the lying words of Moses and Aaron.
77 The text does not say from where they went out, hence I.E.’s comment.
78 The word can be mistaken for a perfect, hence I.E.’s comment.
79 If it were a perfect it would be vocalized with a pattach.
80 In the hifil, meaning he scattered.
81 According to I.E. the meaning of va-yafetz ha-am (so the people scattered) is, and he (Pharaoh) scattered the people.
82 In other words, the lamed prefixed to the word la-teven (for straw) means in place of. The more common meaning of such a lamed is, to, hence I.E.’s comment.
83 Here too the lamed prefixed to the word means in place of, as the meaning of la-chomer is, in place of mortar.
84 It means urging; i.e., the taskmasters were urging them on. The word atz is usually intransitive in the kal, hence I.E.’s comment.
85 To the Israelites.
86 Literally, the matter of a day in its day.
87 It refers to something which comes around in a fixed time (Weiser).
88 See I.E. on Ex. 4:10 and Gen. 43:8.
89 Our verse reads, gam temol gam ha-yom, literally, both (or also) yesterday and both (or also) today. The second gam appears to be redundant; indeed, J.P.S. omits it.
90 And told him for the first time, Let My people go (v. 1).
91 The very same day that Moses and Aaron came to Pharaoh.
92 Not to give the people straw for making bricks.
93 You never withheld straw from us.
94 From the root chet, tet, alef, meaning to sin.
95 According to I.E. ve-chatat ammekha (but the fault is in thine own people) is to be rendered, but thy people will sin.
96 The point is, chatat is a perfect, ve-chatat is an imperfect, for its vav is a conversive vav.
97 The usual form of this verb in the third person feminine is chate’ah in the perfect and ve-chate’ah in the imperfect. Chatat corresponds to chate’ah and ve-chatat to ve-chate’ah.
98 The third person masculine form of the verb fault or sin.
99 Literally, a silent letter after the alef. Two silent letters cannot be placed back to back.

100 A silent heh is the usual third person feminine suffix. However, if it were used here the alef could not be silent, as two silent letters cannot follow each other. Hence a tav was substituted for a heh.
101 A dagesh follows a pattach. If chatat was vocalized with a pattach (rather than a kamatz) beneath the chet, then chatat would be a noun rather than a verb,
102 Contra Rashi, who considers ve-chatat a noun. Cf. Rashi: “And this thing brings sin (chatat with a dagesh in the tet) upon your people.”
103 A third person feminine from the root kof, resh, ayin.

104 The usual third person form of this verb is kare’ah/ve-kare’ah in the feminine and kara/ve-kara in the masculine. The forms karat / ve-karat arose for the same reason that chatat / ve-chatat came into being.
105 Am is usually masculine. However, here the verb governing it, viz., ve-chatat, is feminine. Hence it too must be feminine.
106 Here too the verb yoshevet (dwelt), which governs am, is feminine.
107 The verb shovevah (slidden back), which governs am, is feminine.
108 The meaning of but the fault is in thine own people. See note 95.
109 In other words, rather than say, “but the sin (fault) will be upon you,” Moses said, but the sin will be in thine own people. However, he really meant the former.
110 According to I.E. its meaning is, you (David) shall be counted as an offender. However, Bathsheba did not want to say this directly to King David.
111 According to I.E. its meaning is, and our enemies mock You (God). Us was substituted for “You” out of respect for the Deity.
112 According to I.E. its meaning is they exchanged, Your glory. Their glory was substituted out of respect for God.
113 Hence he did not heed the words of Moses.
114 Who complained to Pharaoh (v. 15).
115 Verses 19, 20, and 21 should be understood as one unit. Contra Rashi, who thinks that verse 20 does not refer to the officers but to other Israelites.

116 I.E. renders va-yiru shotere vene yisra’el otam be-ra (and the officers of the children of Israel did see that they were set on mischief) as: and the officers of the children of Israel did see themselves in dire straits.
117 I.E.’s paraphrase of verse 19.
118 Verses 20 and 21. We thus see that verses 19-21 form one unit.
119 See note 121.
120 The word otam usually means them, hence I.E.’s comment.
121 Oto usually means him. However, here it means himself. Otam is the plural of oto, hence I.E.’s comment.
122 Moses. Cf. I.E. on Deut. 34:6.
123 Translated according to I.E. J.P.S. renders: And he was buried in the valley.
124 A Bible commentator and grammarian who lived in the 10th and 11th centuries. See Vol. 1, chap. 49, note 38.
125 He renders oto in Num. 6:13 as, himself.
126 According to Rabbi Moses this clause should be rendered: he shall bring himself unto the door of the tent of meeting.
127 The meaning of Num. 6:13.

128 That is, oto in Num. 6:13 has its usual meaning, him. According to I.E. the meaning of the verse is: he (the priest) shall bring him (via a command) unto the door of the tent of meeting. See I.E. on Num. 6:13.
129 Our verse literally reads: And they met Moses and Aaron standing. J.P.S. renders: And they met Moses and Aaron, who stood in the way.
130 Our verse should be read: And they met Moses and Aaron who were standing.
131 Translated according to I.E.
132 The Hebrew text literally reads: and behold he standing by the river; “was” has to be added.
133 Where words have been omitted from the text and have to be supplied by the reader.
134 Cf. I.E.’s comments on Gen. 42:1 and the notes thereto.

135 Scripture should have read: Ye have caused our savor to be abhorred in the nose of Pharaoh, for it is the nose that detects smell. However, since the senses are perceived in one place, Scripture interchanges them and employs sight in place of nose.
136 Light cannot be tasted. We thus see that Scripture interchanges the senses.
137 According to Rabbi Merinus the meaning of our clause is: Ye have made us to be abhorred by Pharaoh like a foul odor.
138 After Moses spoke to him.
139 That is, in view of the aforementioned.
140 Whose charges against Moses are recorded in verse 21.
141 As soon as I came to him and told him to free Israel.
142 It is a hifil from the root resh, ayin, ayin.
143 It too is a hifil from the root resh, ayin, ayin. However, whereas hera is a third person singular masculine perfect, here’u is a third person plural.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 6
chapter.p: 1. AND GOD SAID UNTO MOSES: NOW SHALT THOU SEE. When I bring the plagues upon Egypt things will start getting better for Israel, as I1 will yet explain.
God who is Almighty and also awe inspiring, placed before us the secret of the Torah.
I will now begin to explain the Torah portion called, And I Appeared.

2. AND GOD SPOKE. Scripture reads, And the people believed (Ex. 4:31). The latter implies that not all of the people believed. Everyone including Pharaoh, as I will yet explain,2 admitted to the existence of God.3 Scripture therefore says, And God spoke unto Moses, and said unto him: I am the Lord (v. 2); Wherefore say unto the children of Israel: I am the Lord (v. 6); and ye shall know that I am the Lord your God (v. 7).
3. AND I APPEARED. The patriarchs received their prophesies in visions of the night, hence the term And I appeared.4

[ALMIGHTY.] It is difficult to explain the word Shaddai (Almighty).5 Saadiah Gaon says that the shin of Shaddai is a preposition, like the shin prefixed to she-attah (that it is thou) in that it is thou that talkest with me (Jud. 6:17). The meaning of Shaddai is: Who said to the world, enough.6 However, I cannot see any meaning in this interpretation. How can God be called by the name “Who is enough?”7 Shaddai therefore can only be taken as an adjective, like the words tov (good) and sallach (ready to pardon) in good, and ready to pardon (Ps. 86:5) and davvai (faint)8 in My heart is faint within me (Jer. 8:18). Now Rabbi Samuel the Nagid explains Shaddai with the Arabic word al kahar, which means victorious and mighty. He further notes that the yod in Shaddai is in place of the double letter,9 like the yod in dalyu (hang limp)10 in The legs hang limp from the lame (Prov. 26:7) and the alef in baze’u (divide)11 in Whose land the rivers divide (Is. 18:2). Shaddai (mighty) in like a mighty voice (Ezek. 1:24)12 and Shaddai (mighty) in And mighty shall he thy silver (Job 22:25)13 are similar. The Nagid explained it well.14
[I MADE ME NOT KNOWN TO THEM.] The word nodati (I made Me known) is in the nifal.15 It is not like hodati (I made known)16 as Menachem maintains.17

[BUT BY MY NAME YHVH.] Rabbi Merinus says that u-shemi YHVH (But by my name YHVH)18 is an oath, as in Arabic there is a vav which indicates an oath.19 Rabbi Merinus explains the meaning of I made Me not known to them as: I made Me not known to them as I made Me known to you.20 However, we never find a vav with this meaning in Scripture.21 This then is its grammatical explanation.22 There are words that are to be read as if written twice.23 The same applies to letters.24 For example, the mem prefaced to me’el (From the God) in From the God of thy father, who shall help thee, and the (ve-et) Almighty, who shall bless thee (Gen. 49: 25)25 is also to be placed before ve-et (and the) and be read as if written u-me’et (and from the).26 Similarly the bet of be’el Shaddai (as God Almighty).27 Our phrase is thus to be read as if written: but by My name YHVH (u-vi-shemi) I made Me not known to them.28

Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that the word le-vado (only) has been omitted from the end of our clause. Our text should be read as if written: but I made Me not known to them only by My name YHVH.29 On the contrary, I at times appeared to them with the name El Shaddai (God Almighty) and at other times with the name YHVH. In my opinion, thy name shall not be called any more only Jacob, but Israel shall be used with it (Gen. 35:10)30 is similar.31 Really, there is no need for Saadiah Gaon’s reconstruction32 because we know that El Shaddai and the blessed and glorious Lord are one and the same,33 except that the term El Shaddai is an adjective and the glorious and revered name34 is, as I have explained,35 sometimes a noun and sometimes an adjective. Now we find it written with regard to Abraham, I am the Lord (YHVH) that brought thee out of Ur of the Chaldees, to give thee this land to inherit it (Gen. 15:7). We similarly find with regard to Jacob, I am the Lord (YHVH), the God of Abraham thy father (Gen. 28:13).36 Rabbi Joshua says that Abraham and Jacob did not know the name YHVH.37 Moses used it when writing the Torah.38 However, Rabbi Joshua is incorrect, for how would Moses dare to write a name that God did not utter.39 There is no doubt that the patriarchs knew the name YHVH as a proper name. However, they did not know it as an adjective.40

I will now reveal to you part of the secret meaning of the name El Shaddai. We know that God created the three worlds that I have previously noted.41 Everything in the lowest world receives power from the middle world according to the arrangements42 in the higher world. Due to the fact that man’s soul comes from above the middle world, if it is wise and recognizes the works of God, both those done without an intermediary43 and those done via an intermediary44 and if the soul forsakes the pleasures of this lowest world and separates itself from them to cleave to God the glorious, should there be at the time of the birth of such a person an arrangement of the stars indicating that evil will befall this man on a certain day, the God to whom this man cleaves will set the chain of events in such a way that this man is saved from the evil that was destined to befall him. Similarly, if it is in the arrangement of the stars that this man be sterile God will make him virile and he will sire children. Therefore our sages said that God told Abraham, “Leave your astrological calculations.”45 The statement “Israel has no star” is close in meaning to the latter.46 I will yet explain this in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.47 Therefore, before God said to Abraham, and I will multiply thy seed, he told him, I am God Almighty (El Shaddai) (Gen. 17:1), the meaning of which is: I overcome the upper arrangements. The aforementioned does not mean that the arrangements are destroyed. It rather means that the one who cleaves to God knows that God creates good things for him that are not in keeping with what the stars have determined for him.48 Jacob therefore said, the angel who hath redeemed me from all evil (Gen. 48:16), i.e., all evil that was destined49 to come upon me. This is, as I will explain, the secret of the whole Torah.50 Now the patriarchs did not reach the level where they were able to cleave unto God as Moses, whom the Lord knew face to face,51 did. Moses was therefore able to change the laws governing the lower world52 and produce signs and wonders53 that the patriarchs were incapable of. Now Moses said two things to the Lord. One, why is it that Thou hast sent me (Ex. 5:22)? Two, neither hast Thou delivered Thy people (Ex. 5:23). God answered the latter with, Now shalt thou see what I will do to Pharaoh (v. 1). He answered the former54 with, I am the Lord (v. 2).55 The meaning56 is that via the patriarchs My name El Shaddai57 was publicized, but through you My revered name YHVH58 will be known in the world. As God said, Wherefore say unto the children of Israel: I am the Lord (YHVH) (v. 6), the meaning of which is, behold, I have sent you to make this name known.
4. AND I HAVE ALSO ESTABLISHED. I have also sent you because I have established my covenant with the patriarchs to give the land of Canaan to them or to their children who are their equivalent.
5. AND MOREOVER. I have also sent you because the children of Israel have repented59 and have cried out unto me.
6. WHEREFORE. As I live so will my word live. I will redeem you with an arm stretched from the heaven to the earth.
7. AND I WILL TAKE YOU TO ME. When you receive the Torah on Mount Sinai.
[WHO BROUGHT YOU OUT.] Its meaning is that according to the great combination of the stars in heaven60 Israel was destined to remain in exile. This will be explained in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.
8. AND I WILL BRING YOU INTO THE LAND. For many of those who left Egypt entered Canaan.61 Additionally, their children are their equivalent.62

[WHICH I LIFTED UP MY HAND.] This is to be understood figuratively. God is compared to a man who lifts up his hand to heaven and swears. It is like For I lift up My hand to heaven (Deut. 32:40) and when he lifted up his right hand and his left hand unto heaven (Dan. 12:7).63
[I AM THE LORD.] Its meaning is, I will cause this to come about.

9. AND MOSES SPOKE. Israel did not hearken nor pay attention to the words of Moses, as their spirit was impatient because of the length of their exile and the hard labor which was recently put upon them.64
10. AND THE LORD SPOKE…SAYING. To Moses. Speak unto the children of Israel, and say unto them (Lev. 1:2) is similar.65
11. GO IN. To the king’s palace.

12. AND MOSES SPOKE BEFORE THE LORD, SAYING. Behold, the children of Israel who are thy people have not hearkened unto me; how then shall Pharaoh who is a king, and is not a member of your people hear me. Furthermore, it is a great handicap for me who am of uncircumcised lips to speak before him. Before I went to see Pharaoh for the first time You promised me that You would instruct my mouth not to pronounce a letter which is too difficult for me.66 However, now I may stumble in my words before him.67 Furthermore, You said that Aaron shall be the intermediary between me and Israel.68

13. AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES AND AARON. God now included all the details.69 Aaron was also going to be the intermediary between Moses and Pharaoh, as Scripture will go on to explain. God’s command was therefore directed to both of them.

AND GAVE THEM A CHARGE. To go unto the children of Israel, and unto Pharaoh king of Egypt. However, Rabbi Joshua says that and gave them a charge means, and gave them a charge not to be angry at the children of Israel if they did not hearken unto them.70 This interpretation is unnecessary.71

14. THESE ARE THE HEADS OF THEIR FATHER’S HOUSES. Moses and Aaron’s father, or it refers to the children of Israel who are mentioned above.72 The men mentioned73 were among those who descended to Egypt. Scripture starts with Reuben because the only honor left to him was to be listed first in the genealogy.74 These four sons of Reuben75 descended to Egypt.
15. AND THE SONS OF SIMEON. The family of Ohad was destroyed in Egypt or in the desert, as it is not mentioned in the Torah portion Phinehas.76
ZERAH. Zohar and Zerah are one and the same.77

16. THE SONS OF LEVI. These two tribes78 were mentioned first because they were older than Levi. Here Scripture is mainly concerned with Levi,79 as the Torah has no other intention now than to list the genealogy of Moses and Aaron. Gershon, Kohath, and Merari are mentioned in the order of their birth. They descended to Egypt.
[THESE ARE THAT AARON AND MOSES.] Aaron is mentioned first because of his age.80
Scripture mentions how long Levi lived but does not do so for the other tribal patriarchs out of respect for Moses and Aaron.81
17. THE SONS OF GERSHON. He had no sons but these two.
18. AND THE SONS OF KOHATH. Scripture mentions how long Kohath lived but does not do the same for Gershon and Merari out of respect for the messengers.82

19. AND THE SONS OF MERARI. His sons numbered two; there were no more. Scripture therefore says, These are the families of the Levites according to their generations,83 for those who descended to Egypt did not sire any children84 except for these sons of Jacob.85 Scripture also mentions how long Amram lived,86 out of respect for his sons.87
21. AND THE SONS OF IZHAR. They are mentioned because of Korah who quarreled with Moses.88
22. AND THE SONS OF UZZIEL. Uzziel is mentioned because of the honor given in the Torah to Mishael and Elzaphan.89 Scripture did not care to mention the sons of Hebron.90

23. AND AARON TOOK. Aaron’s wife is mentioned out of respect for Eleazar.91 Scripture notes that Elisheba was the sister of Nahshon because of the honor of the priesthood.92 The sons of Korah are mentioned because they were righteous, as it is written, Notwithstanding the sons of Korah died not (Num. 26:11). The prophet Samuel was a descendant of Korah.93

25. AND ELEAZAR. Eleazar’s wife is mentioned out of respect for Phinehas, as the priesthood was given to him eternally. Hence, logically speaking, Putiel was an Israelite.94 We do not know the meaning of Putiel as we do not know the meaning of Mishael and Aaron and all the other names that are mentioned. If what happened to Moses had not been recorded,95 we would not know why he was so called.96
26. THESE ARE THAT AARON AND MOSES. Scripture mentions Aaron before Moses97 because Aaron was older and also because he prophesied to Israel before the arrival of Moses.

27. THESE. Now from the time that they spoke to Pharaoh, Scripture mentions Moses before Aaron because of his great status. Indeed, God spoke to him face to face98 and he alone drew near unto the thick darkness where God was.99 This was not the case with Aaron. Scripture testifies with regard to Moses, My servant Moses is not so (Num. 12:7).100 Furthermore, Aaron said, oh my lord twice.101 You will therefore not find in the entire Pentateuch starting from this verse Moses not mentioned before Aaron. The same holds true for the Prophets and similarly for the Writings. There is no argument to the contrary from Now these are the generations of Aaron and Moses (Num. 3:1) or from, and she bore unto Amram Aaron and Moses (Num. 26:59), as Scripture lists them there in the order of their birth.102 The words generations and and she bore is proof of this.

28. AND IT CAME TO PASS. One may wonder why the arranger of the chapters103 did not104 connect this verse with what follows it105 when in fact it is dependent upon what comes next.106 Though we know no reason for the above,107 we do know that they are connected. On the day when the Lord spoke unto Moses in the land of Egypt (v. 28) what he told him was, I am the Lord; speak thou unto Pharaoh. (v. 29). Similarly, So, it came to pass, when all the men of war were consumed and dead from among the people (Deut. 2:16) is connected to that which follows it.108 Perhaps the one who arranged the places to stop knew why he did this,109 as his mind was much greater than ours.110
29. THAT THE LORD SPOKE. Scripture now goes back to the subject of And the Lord spoke unto Moses and unto Aaron (Ex. 6:13),111 namely, Go in, speak unto Pharaoh king of Egypt (Ex. 6:11).
chapter.ftnote: 1 That is, I.E.
3 As an impersonal power. However, they did not know Him as a personal God who is concerned with man, i.e, as the Lord.
4 Which implies, I appeared in a vision. The Hebrew word for vision (mareh) and the word for, and I appeared (va-era) come from the same root, resh, alef, heh.
5 Its meaning is not self-evident.

6 According to Saadiah Gaon, Shaddai is composed of two words, she-dai (who is enough). He further explained that she-dai is short for she-amar le’olam dai. Saadiah Gaon apparently interprets Shaddai as meaning the one who controls or sets a limit on nature. See Hagigah 12a, “What is the meaning of ani El Shaddai (Gen. 17:1)? Its meaning is: I am (ani) the God (El) who said to my world dai (enough). Resh Lakish said: When the Holy One created the sea, it went spreading on until the Holy One rebuked it and made it dry (i.e., said to it, enough).”
7 I.E. was bothered by having a proper name that opens with a prefix (the shin) (Krinsky).
8 In other words, the shin in Shaddai is not a prefix but an integral part of the word, like the dalet in davvai and the samekh in sallach.

9 According to the Nagid the root of Shaddai is shin, dalet, dalet. (Cf. I.E. on Gen. 17:1 and the notes thereto.) Shaddai is spelled shin, dalet, yod. Thus one dalet is missing. Rabbi Samuel says that the yod takes the place of the dalet.
10 The root of which is dalet, lamed, lamed. A lamed is missing in dalyu and is made up by the yod.
11 The root of baze’u is bet, zayin, zayin. A zayin is missing in baze’u and is made up by the alef.
12 Translated according to I.E.
13 Translated according to I.E. See I.E.’s commentary on Gen. 17:1 and note 2 thereto.
14 I.E. agrees with the Nagid that Shaddai means mighty or the Almighty.
15 Its literal meaning is, I was known.
16 Which is in the hifil. According to Menachem ben Saruk, a tenth-century Sephardic philologist, the meaning of our clause is: but My name YHVH I made not known to them. See note 18.

17 For if we take Menachem’s interpretation at face value, then Israel’s forefathers were not aware of the divine name YHVH. However, there are many verses that show that the patriarchs were aware of this divine name. Cf. Gen. 15:2; 22:14.

18 The literal meaning of the verse is: and/but My name YHVH I made Me not known to them. The latter is grammatically incorrect, as it lacks the preposition “by” before “My name,” and it presents a problem for it implies that the patriarchs were not aware of the name YHVH. However, it is clear from the book of Genesis that Abraham and Jacob were acquainted with this name. The commentaries which follow try each in his own way to solve this problem.
19 Thus u-shemi YHVH can be interpreted as an oath, its meaning being: I swear by My name YHVH.

20 This is the thrust of I made Me not known to them. The meaning of the entire verse is: I appeared unto Abraham, unto Isaac, and unto Jacob, as God Almighty, and I swear by My name YHVH that I made Me not known to them as I made Me known to you.
21 We never find a vav indicating an oath. Thus we can’t interpret u-shemi YHVH as: I swear by My name YHVH.
22 Of u-shemi YHVH.
23 See I.E. on Gen. 6:13 and the notes thereto.
24 See I.E. on Gen. 2:19 and the notes thereto.
25 Translated according to I.E.
26 The verse should thus be read as if written: From the God of thy father, who shall help thee, and from the Almighty, who shall bless thee. See I.E. on Gen. 49:25 and the notes thereto.
27 Also governs shemi.
28 Rather than the literal: but My name YHVH I made Me not known to them. I.E. will later elaborate on his explanation. See note 40.
29 That is, u-vi-shemi YHVH should be interpreted as if written, u-vi-shemi YHVH le-vado.
30 I.E.’s paraphrase of thy name shall not be called anymore Jacob, but Israel shall be thy name.
31 According to I.E., Gen. 35:10 proves Saadiah Gaon’s assertion that at times the word le-vado, although missing, is implied in the text.
32 Of our verse. That is, it is to be read as if written, u-vi-shemi YHVH le-vado.

33 In other words, there is no difference between the name YHVH and El Shaddai. So what sign of divine favor is there in God telling Moses that He appears to him only as YHVH while He appeared to the patriarchs sometimes as El Shaddai and sometimes as YHVH? As to the question raised by our verse, I.E. answers it at the end of his comment.
34 YHVH.
35 See I.E on Ex. 3:15 and the notes thereto.
36 Which shows that God appeared to the patriarchs with the name YHVH.
37 Rabbi Joshua interprets but by My name YHVH I made Me not known to them literally.

38 When Moses wrote the book of Genesis and recorded the history of the patriarchs he employed the name that God revealed to him. However, God himself never used that name when He revealed Himself to the patriarchs.

39 If in revealing himself to Abraham God said, “I am El Shaddai who brought thee out of Ur of the Chaldees,” would Moses deliberately dare to write, “I am YHVH that brought thee out of Ur of the Chaldees” (Gen. 15:7).

40 Thus but My name YHVH I made Me not known to them means, they did not know the adjectival meaning of YHVH; that is, they did not experience the adjectival meaning of My name YHVH, viz., My suspending the laws of nature (Krinsky).
41 See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 and the notes thereto.
42 The arrangement of the stars.
43 That is, sees the hand of God when He suspends natural law.
44 Sees the hand of God in the normal working of the world which ordinarily is under the influence of the heavenly constellations.

45 Cf. Sabbath 156a, “Abraham said before the Holy One Blessed Be He…I have searched my constellation and have found that I am incapable of having a son. Leave your astrological calculations, said the Lord to him, for Israel has no star.” Also see Nedarim 32a and Rashi on Gen. 15:5.
46 Israel’s fate is not determined by the stars, because Israel is under God’s direct influence. See I.E. on Deut. 4:19.
47 See I.E. on Ex. 33:22.
48 Literally, his arrangements.
49 By the arrangement of the stars.
50 The Torah teaches man to cleave to the Lord. The latter places man under the providence of God rather than that of the stars (Krinsky).
52 That is, to suspend natural law.
53 Changing a staff into a serpent, changing water into blood, splitting the sea, etc.

ftnote.italic: Why is it that Thou hast sent me?

chapter.ftnote: 55 That is, I have chosen you to make My name YHVH known in the world.
56 Of God’s response to Moses.
57 Which indicates that God rules the constellations and thus can change destiny.
58 Which indicates that God can suspend natural law.
59 See I.E. on Ex. 2:23.
60 Literally, the upper ministers.
61 Only those above the age of 20 died in the wilderness and did not enter Canaan. Thus the promise, And I will bring you into the land was fulfilled.
62 The children of the generation that left Egypt are equivalent to their parents. Hence it is as if all those who left Egypt entered Canaan.
63 Which are not to be taken literally.
64 The decree to produce bricks without being given straw.
65 In that Scripture repeats itself in the same verse by saying, “ speak to” and “say to.”
66 See I.E. on Ex. 4:12.
67 Since You did not repeat the promise this time.
68 But not between me and Pharaoh. Hence, I must address Pharaoh directly. However, this is too difficult for me since I am of uncircumcised lips.
69 Pertaining to Aaron’s role as an intermediary.
70 Shemot Rabba 7:3 and Rashi interpret similarly.

71 Since it requires that the verb va-yetzavvem (and gave them charge) apply to two different types of charges, one concerning Israel and one concerning Pharaoh. Cf. Rashi, “and gave them a charge unto the children of Israel to lead them gently and to be patient with them, and unto Pharaoh king of Egypt to verbally pay him respect.” Whereas according to I.E. the verb va-yetzavvem refers to one action, viz., to go.
72 Verse 13.
73 As heads.
74 This honor was left him when the birthright was taken away from him. See I.E. Gen. 49:4.
75 Mentioned in our verse.
76 Cf. Num. 26:12, 13 lists the families of Simeon. Ohad is not listed.

77 Zohar is not mentioned in Num. 26:12, 13 but is listed here. Zerah, on the other hand, is listed in Numbers but not here. Similarly, Rashi in Numbers identifies the two as one. He argues that both Zohar and Zarah connote shining.
78 Reuben and Simeon.
79 Thus there was no need to mention the tribes of Reuben and Simeon.
80 This note appears misplaced from verse 21. It is omitted in Vat. Ebr. 38.
81 Who descended from Levi.
82 Moses and Aaron, who descended from Kohath.
83 The reference is to the family of Levi who descended to Egypt.
84 Only the children of those who came down to Egypt are enumerated in verses 16-19 (Weiser). I.E. is vague.

85 All of those who descended into Egypt are considered sons of Jacob. Hence they and their children are listed as comprising the families of the Levites according to their generations. I.E. reads, ki lo holidu yorede mitzrayim rak eleh bene ya’akov, which literally reads, “for those who descended to Egypt did not sire any children. Only these are the sons of Jacob.” The commentaries offer various emendations and interpretations. See Weiser, Filwarg, Krinsky, and Motot.
86 In addition to mentioning how long Kohath lived, Scripture also mentions how long Amram lived.
87 Moses and Aaron.
88 Otherwise there is no reason to mention them, as neither they nor their fathers descended to Egypt.
89 They are respectfully referred to in Lev. 10:4.
90 There was no need to mention them here. See note 89.
91 Who succeeded to the priesthood after the death of his father Aaron.
92 The sons of Aaron not only had a good pedigree from their father’s side but also from their mother’s side, as their mother was the daughter of the prince of Judah.
93 See I Chron. 6:18-23.

94 Contra the Midrash, which derives the name Putiel from the words, pittem (fatten) and pittpet (conquered). The Midrash says that Eleazar’s wife was a descendant of Jethro, “who fattened calves for idols,” and Joseph, “who conquered his passions.” See Sotah 43a; Baba Batra 109b, Sanhedrin 82b and Shemot Rabba 67. I.E. disagrees, for he believes Putiel is mentioned to give respect to Phinehas, and it is no honor to have a pagan ancestor.
95 That Pharaoh’s daughter named him Moses because she drew him out of the water.
96 Without knowing the background behind the naming of Moses we could never guess why he was so called. Similarly, we cannot ascertain the meaning of Putiel.
97 Even though Moses is the more important of the two.
100 That is, Moses is unlike any other prophet. These words were addressed to Aaron and Miriam. We thus see that Moses was greater than Aaron.
101 I.E. is imprecise. What he means is that Aaron referred to Moses as “my lord” twice, viz., in Ex. 32:22 and in Num. 12:11. The phrase oh my lord is found only in the latter.
102 That is, Scripture indicates that it is listing them in the order of their birth.
103 I.E. does not believe that Moses arranged the chapters of the Torah. He apparently believes that the scribes did this.
104 So Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed editions omit “did not” (lo). However, it is obvious that is has to be inserted. Otherwise the comment makes no sense.
105 In the Hebrew edition of the Torah, verse 28 concludes a chapter.
106 That is, verse 30 continues the action of verse 29.
107 Why these verses were placed in different chapters.
108 Deut. 2:16 is connected to Deut. 2:17 although they are in different chapters in the Masoretic Bible.
109 A sarcastic statement. It implies that there is a chance that the one who arranged the portions of the Bible might have erred in setting up the chapters.
110 Hence we must give him the benefit of the doubt.
