111 Scripture now goes back to the account interrupted at verse 13. Rashi interprets similarly.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 7
chapter.p: I. AND THE LORD SAID. This was in response to, how then shall Pharaoh hear me, who am of uncircumcised lips (Ex. 6:12). God answered Moses, See I have set thee in God’s stead to Pharaoh.1

AND THE LORD SAID.2 Its meaning3 is: See, I have greatly elevated your status in that in Pharaoh’s eyes your stature is that of an angel. This is what God’s stead4 means. God5 speaks to the prophet and the prophet speaks to the men of his generation.6

[AND AARON THY BROTHER SHALL BE THY PROPHET.] Those who say that the word navi (prophet) comes from the root of niv in niv sefatayim (the fruit of the lips) (Is. 57:19) err.7 Niv comes from a two-letter root according to the French sages and from a hidden ayin root according to the Spanish sages.8 However, navi comes from a three-letter root.9 That its alef10 is a root letter can be seen from the words nevi’im (prophets) (Num. 11:29) and va-yitnabe’u (they prophesied).11 Furthermore, the word niv in niv sefatayim means fruit,12 for niv comes from the same root as tenuvah (fruitage) (Is. 27:6) and yenuvun (they shall bring forth fruit) in They shall still bring forth fruit in old age (Ps. 92:15). Ve-nivo nivzeh okhlo (and the fruit thereof, even the food thereof, is contemptible) (Malachi 1:12) is true proof of this. Additionally, what meaning is there to, restore the man’s wife; for he is a prophet (Gen. 20:7) if navi (prophet) means a speaker. Its only meaning13 is, he is a prophet to whom I reveal my secrets, as in But He revealeth His counsel unto His servants the prophets (Amos 3:7). He enjoys My presence therefore and he shall pray for thee, and thou shalt live (Gen. 20:7).
2. THOU SHALT SPEAK. To Aaron.
ALL THAT I COMMAND THEE; AND AARON THY BROTHER SHALL SPEAK UNTO PHARAOH. Even though Aaron is not mentioned every time14 that Moses came to Pharaoh, we know that they always came together.

3. AND I WILL HARDEN PHARAOH’S HEART. The question arises: “If God hardened Pharaoh’s heart what was his transgression and what was his sin?”15 The answer is: God granted wisdom to man and implanted in his heart the intelligence to receive power from on high to add to his good16 or to diminish his evil.17 I will explain this in the Torah portion Ki Tissa18 and when I comment on the verse Oh that they had such a heart as this alway (Deut. 5:26). Now the meaning of our verse is: I will harden his heart in order to multiply My signs and My wonders.19 Rabbi Joshua says that its meaning is: I will harden his heart so that he will be able to bear the plagues.20 However, he spoke incorrectly.21
4. AND I WILL LAY MY HAND. That is, my blow, for a blow is struck with the hand. Scripture speaks anthropomorphically.
[MY HOSTS.] Its meaning is: as the angels are the Lord’s hosts in heaven so are Israel22 upon the earth.

5. SHALL KNOW. Rabbi Judah, the first grammarian, has already noted the difference between ve-yade’u (shall know) and ve-yede’u (shall know). The word ve-yade’u, which is vocalized with a long kamatz, is a verb in the perfect. Compare, shame’u (they heard).23 The vav prefixed to yade’u changes it24 to an imperfect as per the grammatical rules.25 On the other hand, the yod of the word ve-yede’u, which is vocalized with a tzere,26 is a future prefix. Compare, ve-yishmeru (they shall keep).27 The silent yod between the yod and the dalet 28 is in place of the root yod. 29
Behold, God noted30 why He brought the plagues upon the Egyptians. He brought them so that His glorious name would be known in the world.31
6. AND MOSES AND AARON DID SO. Scripture now states generally that the signs32 were performed by Aaron and also by Moses. It then goes on to explain each one of the signs.

7. AND MOSES. The Pentateuch records the ages of Moses and Aaron. Aside from these two, we do not find in all of Scripture prophets concerning whom the Bible says that they prophesied in their old age.33 Their status was greater than that of all the other prophets, and to them alone did God speak in a pillar of cloud.34 Do not think that Samuel is to be included among them because it is written, He spoke unto them35in the pillar of cloud (Ps. 99:7), since I have already explained in its proper place that the Torah was given36 only to these two.37 Now, behold, through Moses and Aaron the righteous shall inherit the world to come, while all the other prophets are prophets who38 rebuke or predict the future.

8. AND THE LORD SAID UNTO MOSES AND UNTO AARON. God now began to direct His words to the two of them. God knew that at first Pharaoh would not ask for a sign but would merely say, I know not the Lord (Ex. 5:2). However, now Pharaoh would ask for a sign.39

9. TAKE THY ROD. The reference is to Moses’ rod which Moses had given to Aaron.40 Say unto Aaron: Take thy rod, and stretch out thy hand (v. 19); and he lifted up the rod (ba-matteh), and smote the waters (v. 20) is proof of this.41 Now by employing a bet that has a pattach beneath it42 Scripture is informing us that when He told him,43 Take thy rod, He was referring to the well-known rod. And thy rod, wherewith thou smotest the river, take in thy hand, and go (Ex. 17:5)44 is additional proof of the above.45

10. AND MOSES AND AARON WENT IN. This too, namely, that the rod became a tannin (serpent), was a wonder.46 It was not like the wonder that he did for Israel,47 as there it only changed into a nachash (serpent).48 However, Yefet says that nachash (serpent) and tannin (serpent) are one and the same.49
11. THEN PHARAOH ALSO CALLED FOR THE WISE MEN. Astrologers.
AND THE SORCERERS. Those who appear to change natural law.50

THE MAGICIANS. Those who know the secrets of nature. Chartumim (magicians)51 is a quadriliteral.52 It might be an Egyptian or Chaldean word, as we do not find this word used in Scripture except when dealing with them.53 Scripture indicates a difference between what Moses did and what the magicians did. Moses really changed the staff into a serpent. As for the magicians, Scripture reads, with their secret arts.54 Be-lahatehem (with their secret arts) comes from a triliteral root.55 It is derived from the same root as lahat (flame) in the flaming sword (Gen. 3:24) and lohatim (them that are aflame) in I do lie down among them that are aflame (Ps. 57:5) and lihat (ablaze) in And the day that cometh shall set them ablaze (Mal. 3:19). It56 refers to an illusion of lightning and passing fire.57

12. FOR THEY CAST DOWN. This, the swallowing of the magicians’ rods by Aaron’s staff and their consequent disappearance,58 was a second wonder.59 Scripture refers to the staff as Aaron’s rod60 for it was so at first. Rabbi Joshua says that Aaron’s rod swallowed the rods of the magicians after it returned to its original form.61 And this was a great wonder.
13. AND PHARAOH’S HEART WAS HARDENED. By itself.62 Pharaoh saw that the magicians were able to do what Aaron did.63

14. AND THE LORD SAID…PHARAOH’S HEART IS STUBBORN. Kaved (is stubborn) is a verb in the perfect.64 It is like the word zaken (was old) in when Isaac was old (Gen. 27:1), chafetz (were pleased) in If the Lord were pleased (Jud. 13:23), ahev (he loveth) in such as he loveth (Gen. 27:9).65 The mem of me’en (refuseth), which is a root letter,66 is vocalized with a tzere67 so that a dagesh is not placed in the alef68 which follows it.69 Cheref (jeoparded) in jeoparded their lives (Jud. 5:18) is similar.70

15. GET THEE UNTO PHARAOH IN THE MORNING. It is the custom of the king of Egypt until this very day to go out in the months of Tamuz and Ab to see how high the water has risen. This is the time the river increases. God commanded Moses to go in the morning and stand before the river and perform the sign of the striking of the river in the presence of Pharaoh. He commanded Moses to take and then give to Aaron the rod which he had turned into a serpent before coming unto Pharaoh (Ex. 4:3) and to wave it over the waters of Egypt so that Pharaoh would see with his very eyes the river turn into blood at the moment that Aaron struck it.
16. AND THOU SHALT SAY UNTO HIM. Say the following to him, because if he does not listen, this is the first plague. The rod which turned into a serpent (v. 10) was not a plague.

17. THUS SAITH THE LORD. The messenger speaks the word of the one who sent him.71 Moses was brief, for the term “His messenger” has been omitted. The statement should be understood thus: behold, I His messenger72 will smite with the rod that is in my hand.
[WITH THE ROD THAT IS IN MY HAND.] Moses said, that is in my hand, even though the rod was in Aaron’s hand because they were equals73 and both participated in the performance of the sign.
18. AND THE FISH. Fish is a general term for all things that swarm in the waters.
SHALL LOATHE. Ve-nil’u (shall loathe) is a nifal from the same root as the word la’ah (weary).74 Its meaning is, will be unable.75

19. AND THE LORD SAID. According to my opinion this is to be understood as follows. Aaron waved his hand and struck the Nile. He also waved his hand toward all the sides of Egypt to turn the waters of all the rivers in the land of Egypt, that is, in the kingdom of Egypt, into blood.76 The term the waters of Egypt is a general term. Over their rivers is one of its particulars. The term ye’or (stream)77 refers exclusively to the Nile. There are other rivers in Egypt,78 for the blood was over all of their country.79
OVER THEIR STREAMS. The plural ye’orehem (their streams)80 is employed81 because the Nile is found in many places.
THEIR POOLS. Pools of rainwater that form by themselves.
AND OVER THEIR PONDS OF WATER. This refers to fountains, wells, and cisterns.

Saadiah Gaon says that the word meyeme (water of),82 which is the word me (water of) doubled, refers to sweet water while the word me refers to bitter water, as in me ha-yam (waters of the sea). Scripture therefore reads, ha-kore le-me ha-yam (that calleth for the waters of the sea) (Amos 5:8). Now the Gaon forgot that Scripture states, me ha-yarden yikkaretun (the waters of the Jordan shall be cut off) (Josh. 3:13).83 The word me is always doubled when connected to a pronoun, as in the word memai (my water) (I Sam. 25:11) and in memekha (thy water) (Ezek. 12:18). This mode comes exclusively in the plural form,84 as it is incorrect to say memi (my water) and memah (her water).85 We find me86 used in the singular in because the water of (me) sprinkling was not dashed (Num. 19:13).87
[BOTH IN VESSELS OF WOOD AND IN VESSELS OF STONE.] That is, in water found in the homes in vessels made out of wood or basins made out of stone.
20. AND MOSES AND AARON DID. Scripture notes the smiting of the Nile. However, it does not bother to mention the waving of the hand over all the waters of Egypt.88

22. AND THE MAGICIANS OF EGYPT DID IN LIKE MANNER WITH THEIR SECRET ARTS. The word be-latehem (with their secret arts) comes from the same root as ba-lat (stealthily)89 in she approached him stealthily (Jud. 4:21).90 It means with secret things hidden from the eye. A heh has not been omitted from the word,91 for the heh is not an implied letter in the middle of a word.92

One may ask: If all the water in Egypt was turned into blood by Aaron, where did the magicians find the water to turn into blood? The answer is: Aaron turned only water that is found above ground into blood. He did not transform any water that was below ground.93 The magicians dug and brought forth water from beneath the ground and openly turned it into blood. Now, there is a great difference between what Aaron did and what the magicians brought about. Aaron transformed all of the Nile that was before him plus all the water that was in all the borders of Egypt, which he did not see.94 Furthermore, he changed water that was not standing still but was continually running, with other water taking its place, into blood. Additionally, the plague lasted for seven days. The magicians, on the other hand, were only able to transform a little water standing in a vessel, for a moment, until Pharaoh returned to his house.
23. AND PHARAOH TURNED. Scripture states even this95 because it first mentioned the sign of the rod which turned into a serpent and swallowed the other rods.96

24. DIGGED. Many say that the water was as red as blood in the hands of an Egyptian and became clear in the hands of an Israelite.97 If this is so then why doesn’t the Torah record this sign? I believe that the plagues of blood, frogs, and gnats98 included both Egyptians and Hebrews, for we shall follow Scripture.99 These three plagues caused little harm. However, God differentiated between the Egyptians and the Israelites with regard to the swarms,100 which was a very harmful plague. So too with regard to the plagues of murrain101 and hail102 because of their flocks.103 This was not the case with the boils and locusts,104 for they105 left106 Egypt.107 Now as the Egyptians digged,108 so did the Hebrews dig.109
25. WERE FULFILLED. Scripture notes this because unlike the other plagues, this plague lasted many days.
26. AND THE LORD SPOKE…GO IN UNTO PHARAOH. With your brother Aaron and inform him of the second plague if he does not let my people go.110

27. AND IF. The word ma’en (refuse) is a transitive111 participle.112 It is like the word ve-shabbe’ach (wherefore I praised)113 in Wherefore I praised the dead (Eccles. 4:2). The meaning of nogef (smite) is destroy. It is thus written, And frogs, which destroyed them (Ps. 78:45). The commentaries are divided as to the meaning of the word tzefarde’im (frogs). Many say that it is a type of fish called al-timsach114 in Arabic that is found in Egypt, that arises from the river and preys upon people. Others say that it is the well-known sound-producing creature which is found in the majority of rivers.115 This interpretation appears to me to be correct.
28. AND THE RIVER SHALL SWARM. Ve-sharatz (shall swarm) is a transitive116 verb. It is like yishretzu (swarm)117 in Let the waters swarm (Gen. 1:20).
[WHICH SHALL GO UP.] The reason Scripture states this is that the river is always lower than the city.

29. BOTH UPON THEE, AND UPON THY PEOPLE. Yefet says that Scripture reads, both upon thee, and upon thy people to hint that the frogs shall affect only Pharaoh and his people but not Israel. However, this is no proof.118 Since Scripture mentions that the frogs shall go up upon him and upon all of his people,119 there was no reason to mention Israel.120
chapter.ftnote: 1 Some of the printed editions of Ibn Ezra wrongly place this comment at the end of chapter 6.
2 In some manuscripts I.E.’s comments on chapter 7 start with this note, hence the repetition of the opening quote.
3 The clause to which I.E. refers to literally reads: See, I make thee a god (elohim) to Pharaoh.
4 Literally, a god. On elohim, meaning an angel; see I.E.’s comments on Gen. 1:1.
5 That is, the angel.
6 Similarly, Moses will speak to Aaron, and Aaron will speak to Pharaoh.
7 Cf. Rashi: “All forms of the term nevu’ah (prophecy) refer to one who calls and preaches words of rebuke to the people. It comes from the root of niv in niv sefatyim.”

8 According to Filwarg and others the Spanish and French sages differ only in terminology. Both hold that niv comes from the root nun, vav, bet. The French sages refer to such a root as a two-letter root because the vav is usually dropped. For the same reason the Spanish sages refer to it as a hidden ayin root. However, Krinsky argues that the French sages disagree as to what the root of niv is. The former hold that niv comes from a two-letter root; i.e., its root is nun, bet, while the Spanish sages believe it to come from the root nun, vav, bet. Contemporary works on grammar refer to the latter as an ayin vav.
9 Its root is nun, bet, alef.
10 The word navi is spelled nun, bet, yod, alef.
11 Both words are spelled with an alef. If the alef was not a root letter these words would not have an alef in them.
12 Rather than speech.
13 The meaning of navi (prophet) in Gen 20:7.
14 That Scripture records.

15 Prima facie, our verse states that God will harden Pharaoh’s heart and punish him for not mending his ways; i.e., I will harden Pharaoh’s heart and punish him for hardening his heart by multiplying “My signs and My wonders in the land of Egypt.”

16 If good things are destined to befall an individual he can increase the amount of good that will befall him by developing his intelligence. Individual Divine Providence is extended only to those who have developed their intellectual capacities. See Introduction to Vol. 1, p. XIII.
17 A person can decrease the evil that is destined to befall him by developing his intelligence. See preceding note.

19 God prevented Pharaoh from developing his intellectual capacities; God did this not to punish Pharaoh but so that He would have a pretext for multiplying His signs and wonders in the land of Egypt. I.E. apparently held that man has free will. However, God occasionally takes it away when it serves His purpose to do so. For other interpretations, see Weiser and Krinsky.

20 Hence there is no problem as to why Pharaoh was punished for being obstinate; Pharaoh was a free agent. God; granted him the physical strength to bear His plagues. He did not take away Pharaoh’s free will.

21 Rabbi Joshua is wrong. Heart in Scripture refers to an individual’s mental rather than physical capacity. And I will harden Pharaoh’s heart thus does not mean I will give Pharaoh a strong heart so that he can bear up under the pressure of the plagues, but rather that I will, so to speak, dull his brain so that he does not develop his intellectual capacity.
22 The Lord’s hosts, hence the term My hosts.
23 Yade’u and shame’u are third person perfect forms.
24 From a perfect.
25 For it is a conversive vav.
26 In Hebrew a kamatz katan which literally means a small kamatz.
27 The yod in ve-yishmeru (root, shin, mem, resh) is a future prefix. Similarly the yod of ve-yede’u.
28 The tzere has the yod sound in it.

29 Ve-yede’u comes from the root yod, dalet, ayin. Since the yod in ve-yede’u is a prefix the root yod is dropped. However, it is compensated by the tzere, which has the yod sound. Thus the word is sounded ve-yede’u, not ve-yide’u as it ordinarily would be. Compare, ve-yishmeru, ve-yishme’u, and ve-yikhtivu.
30 In this verse.
31 Not as a punishment for Pharaoh’s obstinacy. See I.E.’s comments on verse 3 and the notes thereto.
32 Some were done by Moses and others by Aaron. See I.E. on Ex. 8:12.

33 I.E., like Maimonides after him, apparently believed that a prophet has to be in perfect physical health in order to prophesy. “A person must satisfy the following conditions before he can become a prophet: The substance of the brain must…be in the most perfect condition…no part of his body must suffer from ill health” (Moses Maimonides, Guide for the Perplexed, Part II, chap. XXXVI, translated by M. Friedlander, 1904).
35 The previous verse speaks of Moses, Aaron, and Samuel. Thus prima facie, unto them refers to the latter three.
36 In a pillar of cloud. Cf. Ex. 24:18.
37 Moses and Aaron. Hence Ps. 99:7 does not apply to Samuel but only to Moses and Aaron. See I.E. on Gen. 20:17 and on Ps. 99:7.
38 Merely.
39 And both Moses and Aaron were involved in the bringing of miraculous signs.
40 For the purpose of striking the water. Hence Scripture refers to Moses’ rod as Aaron’s rod.
41 That thy rod (Aaron’s rod) in our verse refers to the rod which Moses gave to Aaron.

42 Verse 20 reads ba-matteh (the rod). Ba-matteh is short for be-ha-matteh. This heh ha-yedi’ah (the definite article) indicates a well-known object, in this case a well-known rod. Only Moses’ rod fits this description.
43 In verse 19.
44 God told this to Moses.
45 That the rod was really Moses’ rod, as Moses never struck the Nile. Aaron did. However, since it was used to strike the water, it was as if Moses himself struck the water.
46 A supernatural act, contra those who try to give this act some sort of natural explanation. See I.E. on Ex. 4:2.
48 In our verse the reptile into which the rod changed is called a tannin. In Ex. 4:3 the rod is described as changing into a nachash.
49 Hence the wonder done before Pharaoh and the one for Israel are more or less identical.
50 They do not actually suspend natural law; they only appear to do so via trickery.
51 Literally: this word.
52 Most Hebrew words come from a triliteral root, hence I.E.’s comment.
53 At the end of Genesis and here in Exodus in reference to the Egyptians and in the Book of Daniel with reference to the Chaldeans.
54 That is, via chicanery.

55 The printed editions read, ve-hamillah ha-shelishit. The heh should be dropped as it is the result of a scribal error. Indeed, Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, ve-hamillah shelishit. Its root is lamed, heh, tet.
56 Be-latehem.
57 The magicians made the rod appear to turn into a serpent in the same way that they have lightening and fire seem to appear.
58 The magicians’ rods disappeared permanently.
59 The first being the turning of Aaron’s rod into a serpent.
60 At the time that it swallowed up the magicians’ rods it was a serpent. Hence Scripture should have referred to it as Aaron’s serpent rather than as Aaron’s rod.
61 So too Rashi, hence the term Aaron’s rod.
62 God did not harden Pharaoh’s heart. Pharaoh hardened it himself.
63 Change their rods into serpents.
64 This form is also used for the participle form, hence I.E.’s comment.
65 All these words are perfects. However, their forms are also those of participles.
66 The root of me’en is mem, alef, nun.
67 Rather than a chirik.
68 An alef cannot take a dagesh.
69 Me’en is a pi’el. The middle root letters of words in the pi’el have a dagesh in them, and their first root letter is vocalized with a chirik in the perfect. Compare, dibber, shibber.
70 It too is a pi’el. Its chet is vocalized with a tzere in place of a chirik because its middle letter (a resh) cannot take a dagesh.
71 Moses said, In this thou shalt know that I am the Lord. However, as Moses is not the Lord, Moses should rather have said: In this thou shalt know that He is the Lord. Hence I.E.’s comment.
72 What Moses meant was: Thus saith the Lord, Behold, I am His messenger, in this thou shalt know, etc.
73 If they were not equals then the sign would have been attributed to the more important one even though both participated in the performance of the sign.
74 Its root is lamed, alef, heh.

75 Reading lo yukhelu as Vat. Ebr. 38 does. According to I.E. the word la’ah means unable. So too Rashbam. Rashi and others translate it as: were weary and tired. According to I.E. nil’u means were unable. The vav changes it to an imperfect; hence ve-nil’u means will be unable.

76 Our verse notes that Aaron was commanded to stretch his hand over the waters of Egypt. It does not state that the Nile was struck. However, the next verse states that Aaron struck the Nile but omits the fact that he stretched his hand over the waters of Egypt. I.E. held that the verses teach that Aaron was commanded to do two things: to strike the Nile (v. 20), and to stretch his hands over all the rivers of Egypt (Filwarg).
77 So J.P.S. However, the next verse renders ye’or as river. River is a better translation as it refers to the Nile.
78 Hence the Bible speaks of naharotam (their rivers).
79 While the Nile runs only through the middle of the country.
80 So J.P.S. According to I.E., their rivers.
81 There is only one Nile (ye’or) in Egypt. Why then is the plural ye’orehem employed?
82 I.E.’s comment pertains to the word meyemehem (of their water).
83 The Jordan’s waters are sweet. We thus see that me refers also to sweet water.
84 Even when it refers to the singular, the plural is used.
85 We rather say meyemai and meyemeha.
86 But never the double form meme.
87 The verb governing zorak (dashed) is singular. Hence me too is in the singular.
88 See note 77.
89 From the root lamed, vav, tet, meaning to envelop, to cover, i.e., to do something secretly. I.E.’s point is that be-latehem is not to be confused with be-lahatehem in verse 11.
90 New J.P.S. translation.
91 In which case its root would be lamed, heh, tet, for the heh would be implied in the pattach sound and be-lahtehem would thus be a variant of be-lahatehem in verse 11.
92 It is only an implied letter at the end of a word. For the meaning of an implied letter see the notes to I.E. on Ex. 3:15.
93 The Egyptians dug for water to drink. See verse 24.
94 Into blood. The point is that Aaron transformed both the water that he saw (the Nile) and the water which he did not see into blood.
95 Prima facie, even this seems out of place, for this was the first plague.
96 Which did not convince Pharaoh to set Israel free. Hence Scripture states, even this.

97 In other words, the plague of blood did not affect the Israelites. The very same water that was red in the hands of an Egyptian turned normal in the hands of an Israelite and vice versa. Cf. Shemot Rabba 9:9.
98 Or lice.
99 Rather than the aggadah. Since Scripture does not indicate that these plagues did not affect the Israelites, we do not assume the contrary.
100 Of wild beasts. This is explicitly stated in 8.18.
103 So that none of the flocks of Israel be diminished.
104 They too befell Israel.
105 The Israelites (Krinsky).
106 Soon left Egypt.
107 And left their fields behind. Hence they did not suffer any major losses from the plague of locusts. Neither did the boils, cause any permanent harm.
108 For water (v. 24).
109 For water. We must assume this, as the plague of blood struck them as well.
110 See I.E.’s comment on verse 2.
111 This form is also used for intransitive verbs, i.e., ayef (tired), hence I.E.’s comment.

112 Literally, a transitive adjective. I.E. refers to the present form as an adjective. I.E.’s point is that even though ma’en is ordinarily an infinitive, here it is used as an adjective. The normal participle form for this word in pi’el is me-ma’en.
113 Shabbe’ach is a participle even though this form of the word is ordinarily an infinitive. The normal participle form of this word in the pi’el is me-shabbe’ach.
114 The crocodile.
115 The frog.
116 This verb can be transitive or intransitive, hence I.E.’s comment.
117 Which is transitive. See I.E. on Gen. 1:20 and the notes thereto.
118 I.E. held that the plague of frogs also affected the Israelites. See his comments on verse 24.
119 Thy people means all of Pharaoh’s subjects. It doesn’t refer only to native Egyptians.
120 Israel is included in thy people.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 8
chapter.p: 1. AND THE LORD SAID…STRETCH FORTH THY HAND. Towards the four corners of heaven1 and the frogs will arise from the canals, from the rivers, and from the pools. However, they will not arise from all gatherings of water.2

2. AND AARON STRETCHED OUT HIS HAND. Behold, Aaron merely stretched forth his hand but did not strike the water as he did the first time.3 He merely indicated that the frogs could arise from the moment that he stretched out his hand.

3. AND THE MAGICIANS DID IN LIKE MANNER. In the little water.4 Pharaoh therefore saw that there was a difference between what Aaron did and what his magicians were able to do. He called Moses because he saw that his magicians could add to the plague5 but were unable to mitigate it.

4. THEN PHARAOH CALLED. Pharaoh employed the plural form for entreat (hatiru) out of respect for Moses and Aaron.6 This plague was worse than the first one, for we read, He sent among them…frogs, which destroyed them (Ps. 78:45).7
5. AND MOSES SAID UNTO PHARAOH: HAVE THOU THIS GLORY OVER ME. I will glorify you by entreating the Lord that He take away the plague on a day that you yourself shall designate.
[AND REMAIN IN THE RIVER ONLY.] The reason for mentioning the river is that this is where the frogs started from. Once Scripture notes the river there is no need to mention the canals and pools.8

6. AND HE SAID: AGAINST TOMORROW. Rabbi Samuel ben Hofni9 says that people usually pray that a plague be removed from them immediately.10 Pharaoh, however, thought that the plague of frogs resulted from an unpropitious conjunction of heavenly bodies which Moses knew about.11 He thought that the time for the removal of the frogs had now come.12 Therefore Pharaoh tested Moses by asking him to extend the plague and said, Against tomorrow.

7. AND THE FROGS SHALL DEPART. Ve-saru (shall depart) is ultimately accented, contrary to the rules of grammar.13 We find the same irregularity in the word samu (they put) in that they should put me into the dungeon (Gen. 40:15).

8. AND MOSES AND AARON WENT OUT. Moses cried unto the Lord because he trusted that the Lord would not put him to shame. Out of his own accord and without the permission of God, he had told Pharaoh, Be it according to thy word.
9. AND THE LORD DID ACCORDING TO THE WORD OF MOSES. Which he had spoken of his own accord.
10. AND THEY GATHERED. Va-yitzberu (and they gathered) is similar in meaning to the word va-yitzbor (laid up) in And Joseph laid up corn (Gen. 41:49).
HEAPS. Chomarim chomarim (heaps) is similar in meaning to chamor chamoratayim (heaps upon heaps) (Jud. 15:16).
11. BUT WHEN PHARAOH SAW THAT THERE WAS RESPITE. The word harevachah (respite) is similar in meaning to ve-ravach (relief) in so Saul found relief (Jud. 16:23).
HE HARDENED HIS HEART. Scripture employs an infinitive (hakhbed) in place of a perfect.14

12. AND THE LORD SAID. Note that the first three plagues and signs which Aaron brought about pertained to the lowest elements,15 as I have explained previously, since two were related to water and one to the dust of the earth. However, the plagues brought about by Moses with his rod related to a higher element. This was so because Moses was on a higher plane than Aaron. Thus the hail and the locusts were brought by the wind, and the darkness was in the air.16 Moses also brought about the plague of boils.17 However, three plagues came about without the use of the rod, namely, the swarms of beasts, murrain, and the death of the first-born.18 One plague, that of the boils, was brought about by Moses with Aaron’s minor participation and without the use of the rod.

[THAT IT MAY BECOME GNATS THROUGHOUT ALL THE LAND OF EGYPT.] This is similar in meaning to And it shall become small dust over all the land of Egypt (Ex. 9:9).19 The dust which Aaron struck gave birth, as it were, to gnats which went up over all the land of Egypt.20

13. AND THEY DID SO. And they did refers to Moses and Aaron. Moses is included because he told Aaron to smite the dust with the rod. Our verse is similar to and thy rod, wherewith thou smotest the river, take in thy hand (Ex. 17:5).

AND THERE WERE GNATS. Kinnam (gnats) is a generic name.21 The mem of kinnam is either superfluous or in place of a heh.22 In any case, it is not a root letter. The mem sometimes serves as the sign of the feminine plural, as in the word tzefardi’im (frogs). This term is a feminine, for when referring to the singular Scripture reads, va-ta’al ha-tzefarde’a (and the frog came up) (Ex. 8:2).23 The term kinnim is proof of the aforementioned.24 According to this interpretation the word ha-kinnam is irregular because of its superfluous mem.25 It is similar to the word rekam (empty) and chinnam (gratuitous).26 However, Yefet says that the mem of kinnam is a pronominal suffix relating to the Egyptians.27 He claims that the singular of kinnim (gnats) is kan, in the same way that the singular of pittim (morsels) is pat (morsel). He also says that the word ha-kinnam is similar to the word ha-oholi (my tent) (Josh. 7:21).28

Do not be amazed that Scripture records that after one spot was struck, all the dust of the earth became gnats throughout all the land of Egypt.29 Its meaning is that the plague then started.30 The same is true regarding the plagues of the water31 and the boils.32
14. AND THE MAGICIANS DID SO. They struck the dust of the earth.
TO BRING FORTH GNATS. To cause the earth to bring forth gnats as Aaron did. However, they could not do so.
[AND THERE WERE GNATS UPON MAN, AND UPON BEAST.] Scripture notes this a second time because the plague was also upon the magicians.

15. THEN THE MAGICIANS SAID. When the magicians saw that unlike the changing of the rod into a serpent and the plague of blood and frogs where they were able to duplicate Aaron’s actions they were now unable to imitate what Aaron had done, they said to Pharaoh that this plague did not come to liberate Israel but was a disaster sent by God in keeping with the arrangements of the stars dealing with Egypt’s fortune. I have previously explained that Pharaoh did not deny the existence of a Creator.33 He only denied the existence of the God which Moses revealed to him. Our verse is explained by, it is not His hand that smote us; it was a chance that happened to us (I Sam. 6:9) from heaven. Hence Pharaoh’s heart was hardened. Our interpretation is supported by the fact that the magicians said, This is the finger of God, and not, this is the finger of the Lord, meaning the God of Israel, as Pharaoh did when he exclaimed, Entreat the Lord, with regard to the plague of frogs and then similarly used this term for God in the latter plagues.34 Furthermore, Moses told Pharaoh that the Nile would be stricken before it was actually plagued, and he likewise informed him that the land would be inundated by frogs before they appeared. However, Moses did not inform Pharaoh that a plague of gnats was about to strike.35
16. AND THE LORD SAID. It is the custom of kings to go out to the river in the morning, for it is good for the eyes to see water.
17. I WILL SEND. The word mashli’ach (I will send) is in the hifil. It is irregular.36
[SWARMS OF FLIES.] The word arov (swarms of flies) refers to a mixture of evil beasts such as lions, wolves, bears, and leopards.37
[AND ALSO THE GROUND.] Uninhabited places.

18. AND I WILL SET APART. Some say that the word ve-hifleti (and I will set apart) is missing an alef.38 However, I believe that it comes from a root ending in a heh.39 The meaning of ve-hifleti is, and I will set apart. It is logical to assume that Pharaoh now started to lighten Israel’s burden. When he saw that the Lord put a division between Israel and Egypt he feared to harm them. He now saw the need to send them to offer sacrifices to the Lord, lest he fall upon us with pestilence (Ex. 5:3).40 Don’t you see that he now gave them permission to sacrifice to the Lord in the land of Egypt?41

[THAT I AM THE LORD IN THE MIDST OF THE EARTH.] This is a metaphor. It is the manner of kings to establish their residences in the middle of their kingdoms so as to be equidistant to their borders. The Lord similarly placed the heart, which is “king” over man’s body, in the center of the human corporeal frame. Man’s spirit too is located in the center of the body, as it is written, And (the Lord) formed the spirit of man in the midst of him (Zech. 12:1).42 There are many proofs from nature that this is so. Scripture states, Out of Zion, the perfection of beauty, God hath shined forth (Ps. 50:2) because Zion is in the center of the inhabited world and God’s presence is seen in the inhabited world.43
19. AND I WILL PUT A DIVISION. The meaning of pedut is a division. The word pidyon (redemption) is always similar in meaning.44
20. AND THE LORD DID SO. On the morrow, as Moses had spoken.45
[AND THERE CAME GRIEVOUS SWARMS.] By themselves.46 This plague was worse than any of the previous plagues.
21. AND PHARAOH CALLED. It was now clear to Pharaoh that the plagues came because the children of Israel did not offer sacrifices unto the Lord.
[IN THE LAND.] In his kingdom and not in any other place.

22. AND MOSES SAID. Rabbi Joshua says that the clause the abomination of the Egyptians was written to disparage idol worship. What Moses actually said to Pharaoh was, “the god of the Egyptians.” Rabbi Joshua further states that the god of Egypt was shaped like a lamb because the Egyptians believed that the constellation of the lamb ruled over their land. It is because of this that the Egyptians did not eat meat. However, if the reason for the Egyptians not eating meat was their worship of the lamb why did they also abstain from ox and goat meat?

I believe that the ancient Egyptians in the time of Moses had the same belief currently held by the people of India, who make up more than half of the world. All of them are descendants of Ham.47 They do not eat meat until this very day. These people also do not drink milk or blood or eat fish or eggs. In other words, they do not eat anything coming from a living creature. Furthermore, they abhor any person who eats any of the aforementioned. They consider shepherding to be an especially disgusting type of work. It is similarly written, for every shepherd is an abomination unto the Egyptians (Gen. 47:34).

They also do not allow any meat-eating person in their country. If any of them goes to a foreign country he will flee from any place where flesh is eaten. They will not eat anything which a meat-eater has handled. They consider his very garments unclean. It is thus written, because the Egyptians might not eat bread with the Hebrews (Gen. 43:32). Behold, Potiphar placed everything with the exception of the food which he ate under the care of Joseph, who was then living in his house. Potiphar would not permit him to touch his food because Joseph was a Hebrew. There is no reason to ask, “If this is so, then why did the Egyptians keep cattle?”48 We find the same to be the case in contemporary India. Horses, asses, and camels were used to carry burdens and for riding. Cattle served to pull the plow and sheep were kept for their wool. I will yet speak on this when I discuss the Passover observed in Egypt.49

Yefet says that an interrogative heh is missing in the phrase ve-lo yiskelunu,50 for its meaning is, will they not stone us.51 However, I believe that the word hen (lo) in hen nizbach (lo, we sacrifice)52 has the same meaning as the interrogative heh. The meaning of our verse thus is: if we sacrifice (hen nizbach) the abomination of the Egyptians before their eyes, will they not stone us? The word hen in hen hayetah ka-zot (if there hath been such a thing) (Jer. 2:10) is identical.53
23. WE WILL GO THREE DAYS’ JOURNEY INTO THE WILDERNESS. We must remove ourselves from the Egyptians.
[AS HE SHALL COMMAND US.] Regarding the type and number of animals to be selected as sacrificial victims.

24. AND PHARAOH SAID. The phrase entreat for me should have been placed at the beginning of the verse,54 as the verse means entreat for me that this plague will be removed and I will let you go to sacrifice in the wilderness as you asked. However, this is on the condition that you go no further than three days’ journey into the desert.

25. AND MOSES SAID…ONLY LET NOT PHARAOH DEAL DECEITFULLY. The word hetel (deal deceitfully) is irregular. A dagesh should have been placed in the tav, for its heh is a root letter. It should have been vocalized like the word dabber (speak) in behold, I cannot speak (Jer. 1:6).55 We find the same irregularity in hatel tehatellu vo (mock, will ye mock him) (Job 13:9).56 The correct vocalization of this word is found in the clause va-yehattel ba-hem eliyahu (that Elijah mocked them) (I Kings 18:27).57 Moses said, only let not Pharaoh deal deceitfully any more, because he had promised to let the people go during the plague of the frogs and then didn’t.

26. AND MOSES WENT OUT. There are words in Hebrew that have the same meaning in the kal and hifil. These words come in two forms with one meaning. Examples are: va-yetar (and entreated) in and entreated the Lord and ve-hatarti (and I will entreat) in and I will entreat the Lord (v. 25).58 Similarly moreh (shoot) and yarah (shot) in which I shoot and he shot an arrow (I Sam. 20:36).59 However, such words are rare.

27. AND THE LORD DID. The word va-yasar (and he removed) is grammatically irregular. Roots having a vav as their middle letter60 are vocalized with a kamatz beneath their first stem letter, i.e., va-yashav (and he returned)61 and va-yakam (and he got up).62 However, in cases where the last letter of the root cannot receive a dagesh, i.e., if it is a chet, ayin, or resh, then the first root letter is vocalized with a pattach,63 as in va-yanach (and rested)64 in and rested on the seventh day (Ex. 20:11); va-yana (was moved)65 in and his heart was moved (Is. 7:2); va-yasar (and he turned) in And he turned in unto her (Jud. 4:18). All of the aforementioned applies to words in the kal, because in the hifil roots having a vav as their middle letter are vocalized with a segol beneath their first stem letters in cases where their roots do not end in the letters mentioned above.66 An example of the aforementioned is va-yashev (and he brought back) in And he brought back all the goods (Gen. 14:16). Now and he removed is written va-yasar rather than va-yaser.67 It is like va-yasar (and he took off) in And he took off their chariot wheels (Ex. 14:25). However, it appears that va-yasar is a kal and that va-yasar he-arov (and He removed the swarms of flies) means: and the swarms of flies departed.68
28. AND PHARAOH HARDENED HIS HEART. He hardened his heart as he did at the plague of the frogs wherein it is written: he hardened his heart (v. 11).
chapter.ftnote: 1 The passage is to be interpreted, stretch forth thy rod with thy hand towards heaven so that a plague will descend upon the rivers, canals, and pools. I.E. interprets thus because he believed it unlikely that the Lord would ask Aaron to put forth his hand over every river, canal, and pool in the land of Egypt (Krinsky).
2 Unlike the plague of blood, which struck all gatherings of water (Ex. 7:19), the plague of frogs was limited to rivers, pools, and canals.
3 At the plague of blood. See Ex. 7:15.
4 Which they brought. The magicians could only bring forth frogs from the pans of water which they brought before Pharaoh, whereas Aaron caused frogs to swarm in all of the canals, pools, and rivers.
5 They could bring forth additional frogs from the water they brought but could not do anything to remove the frogs from the rivers, streams, and canals.
6 Pharaoh knew that it was Moses who would pray to God to have the frogs removed. He used the plural and thereby included Aaron in his plea, out of deference to Aaron.

7 Psalms does not say the same with regard to the plague of blood. It states, And turned their rivers into blood, So that they could not drink their streams (Ps. 78:44). It does not say that the plague of blood destroyed them.
8 The point of our verse is that the frogs remained in their natural habitat. The river is mentioned merely as an example of the aforementioned.
9 See chapter 4, note 135.
10 I.E. was troubled by Pharaoh requesting that the plague be removed on the next day, hence this comment.
11 And exploited for his benefit. Pharaoh did not believe that Moses had brought the plague. He thought that it was a natural occurrence.
12 On the day that he spoke to Moses.
13 According to the rules of Hebrew grammar it should have been penultimately accented.

14 In view of the fact that our verse deals with the past, Scripture should read hikhbid (he hardened) rather than hakhbed (to harden), as the former is a perfect and the latter an infinitive. I.E. points out that Scripture occasionally uses an infinitive with the meaning of a perfect. As to the question of free will, see I.E. on Ex. 7:3.
15 For the four elements, see Vol. 1, p. 74, note 53.
16 Air (wind) was believed to be a higher element.
17 It was Moses who threw the soot of the furnace heavenward and caused boils to break out upon man and beast. See Ex. 9:10. This plague entailed the element of air.

18 These three plagues did not entail any interaction with any of the elements. Thus Aaron brought three plagues via the rod, i.e., blood, frogs, and gnats. Moses similarly brought three plagues via the use of the rod, i.e., hail, locusts, and darkness. One plague was brought jointly by Moses and Aaron without the use of the rod, i.e., the plague of boils. Three other plagues came about without any action by Moses and Aaron, i.e., the swarms of beasts, (J.P.S. renders swarms of flies), murrain, and the death of the first-born.

19 The lamed prefixed to kinnim does not mean to, but for, i.e.; le-kinnim does not mean to gnats but for gnats, that is, so that gnats will result. Similarly, le-afar does not mean to dust but for dust, i.e., so that dust will result. I.E. comments thus because the lamed usually has the meaning of to.
20 Our verse does not teach that the dust literally turned into gnats. It only seemed so.
21 The word kinnam presents a problem. The Hebrew word for gnat is kinnah; for gnats, kinnim. Hence our verse should have read kinnim or kinnah if a collective noun were employed.

22 I.E. suggests that our verse employs a collective noun and that the word for gnat is ken (a variant of kinnah), the mem in kinnam being superfluous. He then suggests that the word for gnat is kinnah, with a mem substituted for a heh.

23 Va-ta’al (came up) is a feminine verb. Thus tzefarde’a (frog), the noun which it governs, must also be feminine. Hence tzefardi’im (frogs) is a feminine plural. I.E. makes note of this because a mem suffixed to a noun usually indicates that a word is a masculine plural.
24 That the mem of kinnam is not a root letter, for the plural of kinnah. is kinnim, not kinnamim
25 For the usual word for gnat is kinnah.
26 See Vol. 1, p. 306.
27 In other words, kinnam (gnats) means their gnats, for kinnam is a combination of the noun ken (gnat) and the pronoun she-lahem (their).

28 Words that result from the combination of a noun and a pronoun do not usually have the definite article (ha) prefixed to it. Thus prima facie, ha-kinnam cannot mean their gnats. Hence Yefet points out that we occasionally do find the definite article prefixed to a noun combined with a pronoun, as in the word ha-oholi.
29 I.E. assumes that this would strain some people’s credulity.
30 In other words, all the dust of the earth did not turn to gnats the moment Aaron struck the earth.
31 All the rivers, streams, pools, and ponds of Egypt did not turn into blood the moment Aaron smote the waters that were in the river (Ex. 7:20).
32 The boils did not break out upon all men and beasts the moment Moses threw the soot heavenward.
33 See I.E. on Ex. 5:2.

34 When Pharaoh finally acknowledged that the plagues were sent by the God of Israel, he used the term Lord (Adonai) rather than Elohim (God) for the Deity. Adonai is the Lord’s proper name. Elohim is a generic name and in the Bible often refers to idols.
35 Hence the magicians could argue that the gnats were not sent by the Lord.
36 The usual term for I will send, as used in our verse, is meshale’ach in the pi’el.
37 The word arov, translated by J.P.S. as swarms of flies, comes from the root ayin, resh, bet, meaning to mingle. According to I.E. it means a mixture of wild animals.
38 It comes from the root peh, lamed, alef. There is no alef in ve-hifleti, hence I.E.’s comment.
39 Its root is peh, lamed, heh. Hence there is no alef in ve-hifleti.
40 Lest he fall upon us with pestilence was first uttered by the Israelites. However, it also referred to Pharaoh. See I.E.’s comment on Ex. 5:3.
41 Which shows that Pharaoh now started to make concessions.
42 I.E. believed that man’s soul is located in the heart, which is in the center of the body. He held that Zech. 12:1 supports this contention.
43 See I.E. on Gen. 1:1.
44 To be redeemed means to be separated from ones enemies. Both pedut and pidyon come from the root peh, dalet, heh.
45 I.E. assumes that the swarms came the day after Moses had warned Pharaoh of their coming. They did not come immediately because God wanted to give Pharaoh a chance to repent (Krinsky).

46 Moses threatened a swarm of beasts (or flies). The Pentateuch tells us that a grievous swarm came. Hence I.E. notes that the grievous swarm came of itself; i.e., it was worse than what Moses threatened (Krinsky). That is, they were more numerous and/or more harmful.
47 As are the Egyptians.
48 The Pentateuch tells us that the Egyptians kept cattle. See Ex. 9:3 and many other verses in this chapter which relate the same.

50 Ve-lo yiskelunu (will they not stone us) literally means: and they will not stone us. For the clause to mean “(and) will they not stone us” it should read: ve-ha-lo yiskelunu; i e., an interrogative heh should be placed before the word lo.
51 The context implies that it is to be so translated.
52 Hence there is no need to place an interrogative heh before the word hen (lo). J.P.S. translates: lo, if we sacrifice.
53 There too hen is in place of the interrogative heh, for the meaning of hen hayetah is: if there had been, not lo, there had been. The word hen can mean lo, behold, or if.
54 Rather than at the end of the verse.
55 The word hetel is a pi’el. Hence it should follow the paradigm of dabber, which is a pi’el and should be vocalized hattel. Since the word is not so vocalized it is irregular.
56 I.E. has abridged the clause. Job 13:9 reads: Or as one mocketh a man, will ye mock Him? Cf. Krinsky.
57 The word is there vocalized in the usual pi’el form va-yehattel. Compare, va-yedabber.
58 The same root in a variant conjugation usually has a different though related meaning, hence I.E.’s comment. Va-yetar is a kal; ve-hatarti is a hifil.
59 Moreh is a hifil. Yarah is a kal.
60 The root of va-yasar is samekh, vav, resh.
61 The root of va-yashav is shin, vav, bet.
62 The root of va-yakam is kof, vav, mem.
63 Rather than a kamatz.
64 From the root nun, vav, chet.
65 Its root is nun, vav, ayin.
66 A chet, ayin, or resh.

67 Even though it is a hifil. It is so written because its final root letter is a resh. Thus the hifil and the kal of this root are spelled in the same way, hence the grammatical irregularity of this root.
68 If we take va-yasar to be a hifil its meaning is, and he removed. If we interpret it as a kal its meaning is, and he (it) departed.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 9
chapter.p: 1. GO IN UNTO PHARAOH. To his palace.

Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi says that two plagues were in the water: one, that it turned red and the fish died; two, that frogs arose from it.1 Two plagues were on the earth:2 one of gnats and the second the swarms, which were an assortment of wild animals. And it is written, Let the earth bring forth the living creature (Gen. 1:24).3 There were likewise two plagues in the air.4 Murrain5 is nothing but a change from the normal in the air’s heat or cold. This change causes an untold number to die in an instant, as the spirit of life which resides in the heart depends on the air.6 The second plague7 was the boils. Scripture refers to the firmament which is above their heads as the heaven.8 The seventh plague9 was a mixture of the sphere of the whirlwind10 and the sphere of fire.11 It is thus written, and fire flashing up amidst the hail (v. 24). The eighth was the plague of locusts which the wind brought from afar. The ninth was a wonderful plague in that the light from the two great luminaries and the stars was absent from above the land of Egypt.12 The tenth was the descent of the destroyer from the spheres of the glory13 to kill the first-born.14
2. AND WILL HOLD THEM STILL. The word hand or something similar15 has been omitted.16 One that holdeth17 a dog by the ears (Prov. 26:17) is similar.18

3. BEHOLD, THE HAND OF THE LORD IS UPON. Observe, we find that a yod interchanges with a vav,19 as elsewhere we read, and thou wouldest be (hoveh) their king (Neh. 6:6).20 The opposite is the case with the vav of kovai (that wait for me)21 in For they shall not be ashamed that wait for Me (Is. 49:23) which interchanges with a yod in the word ve-kove (but they that wait)22 in But they that wait for the Lord shall renew their strength (Is. 40:31).

The word dever (murrain) is a collective noun.23 Its verbal form24 is found employed only once, in va-tedabber (she destroyed) in she arose and destroyed all the seed royal of the house of Judah (II Chron. 22:10). The book of Kings25 reads, va-te’abed26 (and she destroyed) (II Kings 11:1). This interpretation is far-fetched.27 However, we know of no better one.28

4. AND THE LORD SHALL MAKE A DIVISION…NOTHING. The word davar (nothing)29 is used in reference to many words joined together, as in ha-davar (the word)30 in The word that the Lord spoke to Jeremiah (Jer. 46:13). It is also used in reference to a thing, as in our verse. Davar in thou hast not lacked a thing is similar (Deut. 2:7).
5. AND THE LORD APPOINTED. He set a fixed time for the sign to begin.31

6. AND THE LORD DID. The meaning of and all (kol) the cattle of Egypt died is, that most of the cattle of Egypt died. For behold, it is written,32 Now therefore send, hasten in thy cattle (v. 19).33 We find the same with regard to the plague of hail.34 Scripture reads, and the hail smote every herb of the field (v. 25). The plague of locusts concerning which it is written, and they shall eat the residue of that which is escaped, which remaineth unto you from the hail (Ex. 10:5) is proof of this.35

7. SO MUCH AS ONE. Ad echad36 means, as I will explain in the song of Moses,37 so much as one. The meaning of our verse is: even though Pharaoh sent agents and saw that God loves Israel and on their account smote his flocks,38 he was not so bothered by the death of the flocks during this plague as to let Israel go. Perhaps the plague did not last a long time.39
9. AND IT SHALL BECOME. This was miraculous, that this small amount of soot turned into dust all over the land of Egypt. This plague did not separate out the Israelites.40

BLAINS. The alef of avabu’ot (blains) is superfluous, as avabu’ot comes from the same root as tiveh (to boil)41 in And the fire causeth the waters to boil (Is. 64:1). The word is doubled42 like the words teshasha’u (shall be dandled)43 (Is. 66:12) and tesagsegi44 (thou didst make it to grow) (Is. 17:11).

10. AND THEY TOOK THE SOOT OF THE FURNACE. Each as earlier noted took handfuls of soot and Moses threw all of it heavenward.45 It is possible that the magicians were not smitten with the plague of frogs and swarms. Through their wisdom and their knowledge of natural law they searched for a way to gain a small respite.46 However, their knowledge now failed them, as Scripture tells us.47 Pharaoh did not ask Moses and Aaron to entreat the Lord48 because the plague did not last long. We cannot conclude from the plain meaning of the text that since the first plague lasted for seven days all the other plagues did so too. Additionally, we shall pursue the text of Scripture. It is known that the plague of murrain lasted for one hour49 and the plague of darkness for three days. There is no way to ascertain in which month Moses came and the plagues commenced.50 However, if our holy sages received this via tradition we accept and abide by it.51
12. AND THE LORD HARDENED THE HEART OF PHARAOH. He therefore did not request Moses to entreat the Lord.52
13. AND THE LORD SAID. Scripture does not here note that Pharaoh went out unto the water.53 Perhaps he had another reason for rising early.

14. FOR. Scripture reads, all My plagues because thunder, hail, rain, and fire combined in this plague. We do not find Pharaoh to be as afraid of all the passing plagues as he was of this one.54 He also said,55 the Lord is righteous (v. 27).
[THAT THERE IS NONE LIKE ME IN ALL THE EARTH.] This was said56 in accordance with Egyptian belief that their gods had the power to harm or to benefit.

15. AND SMITTEN. Va-akh (and smitten) is missing a nun. It is like the word ve-at (though I was offering) in Though I was offering them food (Hos. 11:4). They are both the same. Their roots are nun, tet, heh and nun, kaf, heh.

[PESTILENCE.] Scripture reads, ba-dever (with pestilence)57 because it refers to the well-known pestilence. It means: I would have killed all of you along with your cattle with the pestilence with which I smote them.

16. BUT IN VERY DEED FOR THIS CAUSE58 HAVE I MADE THEE TO STAND. Scripture goes on to explain the meaning of zot (this). It means to show thee My power.59 And out of the midst thereof as the color of electrum, out of the midst of the fire (Ezek. 1:4) is similar. However, Yefet says that its meaning is, for this plague,60 the reference being to the plague of hail.61

[AND THAT MY NAME MAY BE DECLARED THROUGHOUT ALL THE EARTH.] This does not refer to Pharaoh.62 On the contrary, the word sapper (be declared) is an infinitive like the word kabbed (promote)63 in for I will promote thee unto very great honor (Num. 22:17). Its meaning is not that Pharaoh will go all over the world to declare God’s glory, but rather that God’s name would be declared from generation to generation because of the signs which He performed.64

17. AS YET EXALTEST THOU THYSELF AGAINST MY PEOPLE. Mistolel (exaltest) means praises. It comes from the same root as the word salseleha (extol her) in Extol her, and she will exalt thee (Prov. 4:8). Now even though its first root letter is doubled65 it still belongs among the double roots.66 It67 is similar to the word solu (extol)68 in Extol him that rideth upon the skies (Ps. 68:5). Likewise ve-gilgaltikha (and roll thee down)69 (Jer. 51:25) is similar to mitgolel (wallowing) (II Sam. 20:12) and golu (roll). However, Rabbi Merinus says that the meaning of mistolel (exaltest) is strengthens and comes from the same root as mesillot in And the king made of the sandalwood pillars (mesillot)70 for the house of the Lord (II Chron. 9:11). Elsewhere it is written, And the king made of the sandalwood pillars (misad)71 for the house of the Lord (I Kings 10:12).

18. I WILL CAUSE IT TO RAIN. It is well known that even today neither rain nor hail comes down upon the land of Egypt. There is no need to explain why this is so.72 The same is still true of many other places. It was because of this that the Egyptians were greatly afraid, for with the exception of something resembling dew, nothing73 rains down there.
19. SEND HASTEN. The word ha-ez (hasten) means make to flee74 or gather.75 He-izu (flee) in The inhabitants of Gebim flee to cover (Is. 10:31) is similar.
20. HE THAT FEARED…MADE FLEE. On that very day.

21. AND HE THAT REGARDED NOT. There is a meaning in Arabic for the vav of va-ya’azov (left).76 However, it is not in our power to translate it into another language.77 Va-yissa (lifted up his eyes) in, On the third day Abraham lifted up his eyes (Gen. 22:4) is similar.78 There are many other similar instances.

22. AND THE LORD SAID. From a strictly logical point of view it appears that the stretching forth of his hand was with his rod.79 Behold, it is written afterwards, And Moses stretched forth his rod toward heaven,80 that is, in the air above. In the open firmament of heaven (Gen. 1:20) is similar.81
23. AND FIRE RAN DOWN. Va-tihalakh (ran down) is a kal form. It expresses going.
UNTO THE EARTH. Contrary to its nature, which is to go up.82
24. AND FIRE FLASHING UP AMIDST THE HAIL. A miracle within a miracle.83

25. AND THE HAIL SMOTE. This was a very strong plague, for it killed man and beast and broke every tree of the field. However, God pitied them84 and their cattle. Moses did not mention this to Pharaoh85 because he saw that Pharaoh sent agents and learned that there was not even one of the cattle of the Israelites dead, and yet did not take this to heart.86
27. AND CALLED. Pharaoh said, I have sinned, because he was greatly afraid that he, as was told to him, would be destroyed by the pestilence.87

28. ENTREAT THE LORD. Pharaoh made mention of the glorious name88 and referred to kolot Elohim (noises from God) because he, as I have already noted, admitted to the existence of a Deity.89 Moses combined the proper and adjectival names and said, “the Lord God” (YHVH / Adonai Elohim) because Pharaoh did not employ the term kolot YHVH / Adonai.90 The meaning of YHVH / Adonai Elohim is: the Lord alone is God. We never find Moses employing this phrase91 in the entire Torah. The term Adonai Elohim in O Lord God, Thou hast begun (Deut. 3:24) does not refute the aforementioned, as Adonai is written there with an alef, dalet. 92
29. AND MOSES SAID UNTO HIM: AS SOON AS I AM GONE OUT OF THE CITY. The commentaries say that Moses was unable to spread forth his hands in Egypt because it was filled with idols.93
THAT THE EARTH IS THE LORD’S. Not yours.

30. BUT AS FOR THEE. Rabbi Solomon94 says that the meaning of terem tire’un (ye will not yet fear) is: you do not fear.95 He interprets terem yishkavu (but before they lay down) (Gen. 19:4) similarly.96 However, the meaning of this word is not as he imagined, as the subject always follows.97 Following terem yishkavu (but before they lay down) Scripture reads, the men of the city, even the men of Sodom, compassed the house round: its meaning is, at the time when they lay down they compassed the house round. The word terem (before) in before they call, I will answer (Is. 65:24) and terem (before) in Yea before the fat was made to smoke (I Sam. 2:15) are similar. The same applies to all times the word terem is used. Thus terem never has the meaning of no.98

Rabbi Saadiah Gaon of blessed memory connected the whole subject.99 He explained it as follows. Moses said to Pharaoh, I shall pray for the hail to be removed.100 However, what it destroyed, it destroyed.101 The meaning of And the flax and the barley were smitten102 is, the flax and barley shall not return103 and I shall not pray for their recovery.104 Behold, its meaning is,105 before you fear God and confess and say the Lord is righteous,106 the barley and flax shall already be smitten. This vav,107 as I have noted, is correctly used according to the Arabic.108 However, in my opinion109 a word110 has been omitted,111 its interpretation being: before I spread my hands you will fear the Lord, viz., you and your servants. Moses was being polite. Its implication is, when the plague is removed you will rebel. Therefore Scripture notes afterwards, and (Pharaoh) hardened his heart, he and his servants. We do not find this in any other place.112

31. AND THE FLAX AND THE BARLEY. Scripture relates what happened.113 It is clear from the word nukkatah (were smitten) and also from the word nukku (were smitten) (v. 32)114 that the root of makkeh (smite) is nun, kaf, heh. It is similar to the words shuppu (corrode) and ru’u115 (unsightliness) in And his bones corrode to unsightliness (Job 33:21).
32. THEY RIPEN LATE. Afilot (ripen late) is an adjective. The word afel (darkness), as in, darkness, and not light, is close in meaning to it. It means that they were beneath the earth116 and unseen.

33. POURED. Nittakh (poured) is used in the same sense as ke-hittukh (as is melted) in117 As silver is melted in the midst of the furnace (Ezek. 22:22). It is a nifal118 like the word niggash (drew near) in but Moses drew near unto the thick darkness (Ex. 20:18).
34. AND WHEN PHARAOH SAW. Scripture now mentions, he sinned yet more,119 because Pharaoh confessed and said, I have sinned this time (v. 27).120
[AND HARDENED HIS HEART, HE AND HIS SERVANTS.] From this, Moses’ words, But as for thee and thy servants (v. 30), become clear.121
35. AND THE HEART OF PHARAOH WAS HARDENED. Though he feared this plague more than the earlier ones.122
chapter.ftnote: 1 The first two plagues came about through Egypt’s waters.
2 The next two plagues came about via the earth.
3 The plague of wild animals can thus be considered as a plague from the ground.
4 The next two plagues came about through the air.
5 Or pestilence. I.E. did not know that germs are the cause of pestilence.
6 See I.E. on Gen. 2:7.
7 To strike through the air.

8 When Scripture states, Take to you handfuls of soot…and let Moses throw it heavenward (Ex. 9:10) it means “and let Moses throw it up to the air,” as the air above is called the firmament. See I.E. on Gen. 1:6 where he writes, “The firmament is the air.”
9 The plague of hail.
10 A layer of wind surrounding the earth.

11 A layer of fire surrounding the earth. Medieval man believed in four elements: earth, water, air, and fire. I.E. explains that all the earthly elements plus some heavenly elements were involved in bringing about the plagues. That is, two blows came from the water, two from the earth, two from the air, one from a combination of air and fire, two more from the air (locusts and darkness), and one from the heavens. Earth is the heaviest element. We therefore would imagine that it would be the first element involved in the plague. However, I.E. notes in Gen. 1:6 that it is the nature of water to be below the earth. Hence the first plague came from the waters, and succeeding plagues moved upward to the heavens.
12 This too came about from the air, in that the air was clouded (Krinsky). See I.E on Ex. 10:22.
13 Hebrew, galgale ha-kavod. I.E. refers to a large shining star as a kavod (a glory). See Y. Klatzkin, Otzar Ha-Munachim Ha-Filosfim, Vol. II, Berlin, 1928, p. 62.
14 I.E. apparently believes that an evil conjugation of the stars caused the first-born to die.
15 Perhaps teeth (Weiser).

16 The word machazik (hold them) is a hifil, a causative. It literally means causes to hold. Hence, whenever this form is encountered, the word hand or something similar is implied although not always stated. Our phrase literally reads: and will still cause to hold them. I.E. interprets this to mean: and will still cause your hand (or something similar) to hold them (Filwarg).
17 Hebrew, machazik. J.P.S. translates as taketh.
18 This too should be read as: one that causeth his hand to hold a dog by the ears. It literally reads: one that causeth to hold a dog by the ears.
19 In our verse, in the word hoyah (is).
20 Hoveh is the usual form. Hence in hoyah a yod has been interchanged with a vav.
21 From the root kof, vav, heh.

22 The word kove is spelled kof, vav, yod. This comment presents a problem. Prima facie, no yod has been interchanged for a vav in kove, because this is the normal construct form of the word. Compare, love (lamed, vav, heh) and shave (shin, vav, heh). We must assume that I.E. read koye rather than kove (same vocalization but different spelling). See Rabbi David Kimchi and S. Kraus, Sefer Yeshayahu, edited by A. Kahanah, on Is. 40:31.
23 For pestilence. It does not refer to any particular disease (Weiser).
24 Hebrew nouns have verbal forms.
25 II Kings 11:1 and II Chron. 22:10 relate the same events in slightly different words.
26 Va-tedabber is parallel to va-te’abed. As va-te’abed means: and she destroyed, va-tedabber means: and she destroyed.
27 That is, that va- tedabber means and she destroyed. Perhaps it means she plotted against, or she waylaid, as in its Arabic cognate dabbra.
28 We must accept the reading of the parallel verse as its meaning, i.e., that va-tedabber means the same as va-te’abed.
29 Literally, a thing.
30 God spoke many words to Jeremiah. Thus Scripture should have read, ha-devarim, as in eleh ha-devarim (these are the words) (Deut. 1:1). Thus I.E. explains that davar can refer to many words.
31 So that the Egyptians would not think that the plague came about by accident (Krinsky).
32 With regard to the hail.
33 If all the cattle died from murrain, what cattle were left to be struck by the hail?
34 That Scripture uses the term kol (all or every) but means most.
35 If the hail destroyed every herb of the field, what was left for the locusts to eat?
36 Literally, until one.
37 Cf. I.E. on Ex. 14:28.
38 While none of theirs perished.

39 Once the plague quickly passed he was no longer afraid and hence did not let Israel go. Similarly, he did not ask Moses to intercede for him as he had done in the case of the plague of the frogs. See Ex. 8:4.
40 See I.E.’s comments on Ex. 7:24.
41 Its root is bet, ayin, heh.
42 The heh drops out and the bet and ayin are doubled, forming the apparently quadriliteral avabu’ot.
43 Its root is shin, ayin, heh. However, the heh drops out and the shin and ayin are doubled, forming the apparently quadriliteral teshasha’u.
44 Its original root is sin, gimel, heh. However, the heh drops out and the sin and gimel are doubled, forming the quadriliteral root sin, gimel, sin, gimel (Krinsky).
45 As clearly stated in verse 8. Even though Aaron took a handful of soot it was Moses who threw the soot toward heaven. See also I.E. on Ex. 8:12.
46 And hence were not smitten by the frogs and swarms.
47 The boils were upon the magicians (v. 11).
48 As he did in the case of the frogs (Ex. 8:4).
49 That is, a very short time, for death by pestilence is immediate.

50 According to the rabbis the plagues lasted for an entire year. See Eduyot 2:10, “the judgment of the Egyptians endured twelve months.” Similarly Seder Olam, 3. Also, according to the rabbis, since Israel was delivered in Nisan and the plagues lasted a year they had to commence in Iyar (Seder Olam 3). It is possible to further interpret the rabbinic statement that the judgment of the Egyptians lasted for one year to mean that it lasted for one year from the time that Moses first appeared before Pharaoh. If we assume the aforementioned then Moses first appeared before Israel and Pharaoh in the month of Iyar. Furthermore, if we accept the fact that the judgment of the Egyptians lasted for a year then each of the ten plagues struck a little over a month apart (Tiferet Israel on Eduyot 3:10). Cf. Shemot Rabba 9:12, “Rabbi Judah and Rabbi Nehemiah: One says Moses warned them for 24 days before (he plague struck and the plague ravaged them for seven days. The other one says he warned them for seven days and the plague ravaged them for 24 days.”
51 That is, that the plagues ravaged seven days, that a new one struck each month, that the plagues lasted for a year, and that Moses appeared in the month of Iyar. See note above.
52 As he did in the case of the frogs and swarms.
53 As it does in Ex. 7:15 with regard to the plague of blood and in Ex. 8:16 with regard to the swarms.
54 Because of the combination of thunder, hail, rain, and fire.
55 Due to his great fear of this plague.

56 There is none like Me in all the earth implies that there are other gods but that they are weaker than the Lord. Hence I.E. comments that the Lord spoke in accordance with Egyptian belief that there are other gods.
57 Rather than be-dever. Ba-dever is short for be-ha-dever (with the pestilence) and according to I.E. should be so translated, hence his comment.
58 The word cause is not in the Hebrew text. The Hebrew reads: But in very deed for this have I made thee to stand.
59 The verse is to be understood as follows: But in very deed for this, i.e., to show thee My power, and that My name my be declared throughout all the worlds have I allowed thee to exist.
60 This is short for this plague.
61 The verse is to be understood as follows: But for this plague have I made thee to stand, etc.

62 The form sapper is used both for the imperative and the infinitive. If it is taken as an imperative then it is Pharaoh who is being addressed, and our verse should be interpreted as follows: and that thou shalt declare My name throughout all the earth.
63 Kabbed, like sapper, is used for both the imperative and the infinitive.

64 I.E. takes issue with the Midrash and Targum Jonathan, which take sapper as an infinitive. Targum Jonathan translates, u-min bi-gelal de-tini shemi kadisha be-khol arah (and so that thou shall declare My holy name all over the earth). Also see the Mekhilta, Ex. 6, wherein we read:”…There remained not so much as one of them (Ex. 14:28)…Rabbi Nahman says, excluding Pharaoh, for concerning him it says, But in very deed for this cause, etc.” That is, that thou shalt declare My name all over the earth. Also Rashi on Ex. 12:29 interprets sapper as an imperative. Rashi comments, “Pharaoh too was a first-born but he remained alive out of all the first-born. Concerning him Scripture states, But in very deed for this cause, etc.”

65 The samekh, the first root letter, appears twice. Similarly the lamed, its second root letter. Thus the word appears to come from a quadriliteral root; i.e., its stem appears to be samekh, lamed, samekh, lamed, whereas the root of mistolel is samekh, lamed, lamed,
66 It basic root is samekh, lamed, lamed even though it appears to have a quadriliteral root. See I.E. on verse 9 and the notes thereto.
67 Salseleha. So I.E. on Prov. 4:8.
68 Which comes from the root samekh, lamed, lamed.
69 The root of ve-gilgaltikha appears to be gimel, lamed, gimel, lamed. However, its real root is gimel, lamed, lamed.
70 J.P.S. renders paths.
71 The point is that misad is parallel to mesillot. As misad means a support (from the root samekh, ayin, dalet) or something which gives strength, so does mesillot.
72 This is not the place to go into it.
73 Neither rain nor hail.
74 To a safe place.
75 Into a safe place.
76 Literally, and he left. Prima facie, this form is out of place. The proper form here is azav (left), hence I.E.’s comment.
77 Its meaning is identical to that of the Arabic fa. See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 and the notes thereto and Vol. 1, Foreword, p. xvi.
78 Here too the form va-yissa (literally, and he lifted up) is prima facie, out of place. The proper form is this case is nasa.
79 That is, when God told Moses, Stretch forth thy hand, he meant stretch forth thy rod with thy hand (Krinsky).
80 It is thus perfectly logically to assume that when God told him, Stretch forth thy hand toward heaven, He meant stretch forth thy rod with thy hand toward heaven.
81 Heaven here is short for or refers to the firmament of heaven, which refers to the air and not to heaven per se (Weiser). See I.E. on Gen. 1:6 and 1:20 and the notes thereto.
82 Fire rises upward.
83 For fire and water do not mix.

84 The reference appears to be to Israel. God pitied Israel and their cattle and none of them died (Krinsky, Netter). Weiser suggests that the reference is to Egypt. God pitied the Egyptians and warned them to gather in their cattle and stay indoors. However, the remainder of I.E.’s comment does not seem to bear out Weiser’s contention.
85 As he did in the case of the murrain. See verse 4.
86 Verse 7.
87 Verse 15.
88 YHVH, for Pharaoh said, Entreat YHVH (the Lord).
89 See I.E.’s comments on Ex. 6:2 and 8:15.

90 But rather used the term kolot Elohim. Since Pharaoh referred to YHVH / Adonai and to Elohim, he, being a pagan, might have referred to two deities. Hence Moses used the term YHVH / Adonai Elohim (the Lord God), which means YHVH alone is God.
91 YHVH / Adonai Elohim. Because Moses addressed Israelites, and they knew that YHVH / Adonai alone is God.
92 Rather than YHVH. Hence it does not mean YHVH alone is God but rather O Lord God.
93 See Mekhilta, Bo, chap. 1; Shemot Rabba 12:5, and Rashi.
94 Rashi.

95 According to Rashi terem means not yet. He renders terem tire’un as: you will not yet fear. However, I.E. quoted Rashi as saying that terem means no. Most of the commentaries avoid the issue. They apparently believe that I.E. was laconic in quoting Rashi. However, in his short commentary, I.E. quotes Rabbi Judah the grammarian as saying that terem means no. Weiser suggests that I.E. confused Rashi and Rabbi Judah in his long commentary. Since, as has been shown in Vol. 1 of this work, I.E. often quoted from memory and, as Birnbaum notes, did not always have time to edit his writings, it is quite possible that Weiser is right.
96 Rashi on our verse interprets it as meaning: they did not as yet lie down.

97 Not yet or no implies the end of a subject. However, terem is almost always followed by a subject. Hence I.E. interprets terem as meaning before. The problem with I.E.’s interpretation is that in our verse, unlike Gen. 19:4, the term seems to end the subject under conversation. It is to answer the latter that I.E. quotes Saadiah Gaon and then offers his own interpretation.
98 That is, of not yet.

99 According to Saadiah Gaon the meaning of terem is before. He connects verses 29-32. If he did not connect them, verse 30 would make no sense for it would end reading: I know before you fear the Lord God.
100 Verse 29.
101 Verse 31.
102 Verse 31.
103 For they have already been destroyed, and what is destroyed is destroyed.
104 However, I shall pray for the wheat and the spelt because they have not yet been smitten (v. 32).
105 The meaning of verse 30 and verse 31.
106 Verse 30.

107 Verse 31 starts with a vav. This seems to indicate that, contra Saadiah Gaon, the verse introduces a new topic and is not dependent on verse 30. If it were, it should read, ki terem tire’un mepene Adonai Elohim ha-pishtah ve-hase’orah nu-katah (but before you will fear the Lord God, the flax and the barley will be smitten). The fact that it opens with ve-ha-pishtah (and the barley) shows that verse 31 is an independent verse. The same applies to the vav that opens verse 32.
108 For the vav at the beginning of a verse does not always introduce an independent clause. See I.E. on verse 21 and the notes thereto.
109 I.E. agrees with Saadiah Gaon that terem means before. However, he does not see any need to connect and interpret the verses as Saadiah does.
110 Actually two words, efrosh (I spread) kapai (my hands).
111 Adding these two words eliminates the problem of no appropriate subject following terem.
112 That Moses politely alluded to the fact that Pharaoh would change his mind as soon as the plague disappeared (Weiser).

113 Contra Saadiah Gaon who believed that verse 31 is dependent on verse 30. I.E. holds that verse 31 is independent. He explains that it relates what happened next, not what Moses told Pharaoh about his limited fear of God. See I.E.’s comment on verse 30 and the notes thereto.
114 Nukkkatah and nukku are third person pu’als. Their root is nun, kaf, heh. In the verb makkeh, which is a hifil, the nun is missing.
115 Both are in the pu’al, as are nukku and nukkatah. Hence their nuns are not nifal form nuns but root letters (Krinsky).
116 Being beneath the earth is like being in a dark place.
117 Or turns liquid. Similarly, nittakh in our verse refers to liquid.
118 Hence it means was poured.
119 Which it never did before.
120 Scripture notes that he continued to sin even after he had confessed his transgression.
121 That Moses was justified in saying what he did (Weiser).
122 Even though the plague of hail scared him more than any of the previous plagues, as soon as it passed Pharaoh hardened his heart.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 10
chapter.p: God saved the seed of the whole-hearted man;1
He taught them a law by the hand of His servant.2
Behold the secret of the Torah portion
Go In Unto Pharaoh is the Commandment regarding, this month.3

1. GO IN UNTO PHARAOH. Go in unto him this time4 and do not be astonished that he has hardened his heart until now,5 For I have hardened his heart, and the heart of his servants. God mentioned the heart of his servants because their hearts6 would mellow with the coming of the plague of the locusts.7
[FOR I HAVE HARDENED HIS HEART.] Its meaning is: I have hardened his heart that I might show these My signs in the midst of them.

The Spanish scholars differ with regard to the word shiti (I might show).8 Some say that shiti is similar to binu9 (consider) (Deut. 32:7), simu (set)10 (Gen. 43:21), and other such words.11 The same is the case12 with yashit (he will put), yasim (he will place), yavin (he will understand), and comparable words13 in all of their14 forms.
