Others hold that shiti is a hifil minus the sign of the form,15 because they found the words yasum16 (maketh) and la-sus (rejoice)17 in who maketh a man dumb (Ex. 4:11) and for the Lord will again rejoice over thee for good, as He rejoiced over thy fathers (Deut. 30:9), all of which are kals. Others say that yasis is similar to yasus (he will rejoice)18 and shiti to sumi (set).19 They are all kals.

2. AND THAT THOU MAYEST TELL. God spoke to Moses, who is equivalent to all of Israel.20 Similarly, that ye may know that I am the Lord 21 means that all Israel shall know the aforementioned. The Torah speaks in human terms when it says, I have wrought, for it pictures God as acting as a human being who arranges events in order to avenge himself upon another.

3. AND MOSES AND AARON WENT IN. We know that Moses would not come in unto Pharaoh unless Aaron was with him,22 as Aaron was his spokesman.23 Scripture here mentions Moses and Aaron because now, unlike any of the other instances of the plagues, they were both returned to and finally expelled from the presence of Pharaoh.
TO HUMBLE. Le’anot (to humble) is a nifal.24 It comes from the same root as ani (humble).25

4. LOCUSTS. Arbeh (locusts) is the name of a type of locust.26 Perhaps it is so called because it is more numerous than other kinds of locusts.27 Scripture states, That which the palmer-worm (gazam)28 hath left hath the locust (arbeh) eaten (Joel 1:4).29 Concerning it, Scripture states, My great army which I sent among you (Joel 2:25). If this be the case then the alef of arbeh is superfluous.30
5. AND THEY SHALL COVER. Metaphorically speaking.
THAT ONE SHALL NOT BE ABLE TO SEE.31 The word ish (a man) has been omitted.32
Yefet says that many days passed between the plague of hail and the plague of locusts, for Scripture states: which groweth for you out of the field.33

6. SHALL BE FILLED. This word34 is irregularly used in the Hebrew language.35 The meaning of u-male’u (shall be filled) is that the houses were full of locusts.36 However, we also find mile’u (fill) in Fill four jars with water (I Kings 18:34) wherein mile’u is a transitive verb. It is as if it were vocalized with a pattach beneath the mem and a dagesh in the lamed37 and belonged to the conjugational form that receives a dagesh.38

[AND HE TURNED.] Rabbi Joshua says that va-yifen (and he turned) refers to Moses, who paid his respects to the throne by facing the king39 and walking out backwards.40 However, Yefet says that Moses finished his duties.41 So too u-fanita (and thou shalt turn)42 in and thou shalt turn in the morning (Deut. 16:7). However, what shall Yefet do with the word va-yifen (and he looked) in And he looked this way and that way (Ex. 2:12)?43 Va-yifen is to be explained as coming from the same root as panim (face).44 It has the same meaning as va-yar (and he saw). Now Moses left the presence of Pharaoh without his permission. Scripture notes this because Pharaoh asked that Moses and Aaron be brought back. After they were returned Pharaoh, in anger, commanded that they be driven out.45
7. AND PHARAOH’S SERVANTS SAID. The meaning of ha-terem46 teda (knowest thou not yet) is: do you first want it to become clear to you that Egypt is destroyed.

8. WERE BROUGHT AGAIN. The word et indicates the thing itself.47 Now whether one says ha-adam ohavi (the man loves me), in which the yod is a first person pronominal suffix, or he says ha-adam ohev oti (the man loves me),48 the reference being to my very self,49 the meaning is one and the same. Therefore, if someone says re’uven harag et shimon (Reuben killed Simeon) he is telling us that Simeon has been slain. However, the same is the case if he says, re’uven harag shimon (Reuben killed Simeon).50 Ve-rav ya’avod tza’ir (and the elder shall serve the younger) (Gen. 25:23)51 and asher bara Elohim adam (that God created man) (Deut. 4:32)52 are similar. Do not think that et indicates the direct object because it is often found to be so used.53 It is also found before the subject, as in u-va ha-ari ve-et ha-dov (and when there came a lion, or a bear) (I Sam. 17:34)54 and many other similar cases.

Rabbi Judah the grammarian says that Scripture reads, va-yushav (were brought again) rather than va-yushevu (were brought again)55 because of the word et.56 However, I believe that Scripture reads, va-yushav because Moses was the most important one. Scripture similarly reads, va-tedabber miriam ve-aharon57 (And Miriam and Aaron spoke) (Num. 12:1) because Miriam was the main speaker.
9. FOR WE MUST HOLD A FEAST UNTO THE LORD. All of us are obligated to sacrifice unto the Lord.58
10. SO BE THE LORD WITH YOU. Whom you say is with you.59

[SEE YE THAT EVIL IS BEFORE YOUR FACE.] The evil is close to you and is before your face. This meaning is also to be connected to for that is what ye desire (v. 11).60 Hence it is only right that I so act. At this point Pharaoh surmised that they wanted to flee.61

Note that our Master Moses did not go so far as to lie and say that Israel would return. He merely said that they would travel a three days’ journey (Ex. 9:23). However, the Egyptians thought that they would return. Hence they let them have what they asked.62 Moses had another reason for acting in this manner.63 Had Pharaoh given Israel permission to go64 and Israel did not return, Pharaoh would not have pursued them. However, God commanded Moses to act in this manner so that Pharaoh would chase after them and drown. Behold, this is clearly stated, that they turn back and encamp before Pi-hahiroth (Ex. 14:2).65 One should not question the acts of God,66 as He does everything with wisdom, though it be hidden from the eyes even of wise men. We find a similarity in the account of David, viz., And it shall be, when thou hearest the sound of marching in the tops of the mulberry-trees, that then thou shalt bestir thyself; for then is the Lord gone out before thee to smite the host of the Philistines (II Sam. 5:24).67
11. NOT SO; GO NOW YE THAT ARE MEN. The word gever (man), unlike the word adam (man),68 always refers to a man in Scripture.
FOR THAT IS WHAT YE DESIRE. The above-noted evil.69

12. FOR THE LOCUSTS. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that ba-arbeh (for the locusts) indicates that Moses placed a locust on the rod.70 However, this is incorrect. The correct interpretation of ba-arbeh is: so that the locusts would come.71

13. AN EAST WIND. Kadim (east) is an adjective, since kedemah mizrachah (the east side) is a noun.72 Kadim73 is so called because it is the first of the sides74 because the sun begins to shine there. Hence the west is termed achor (hinder side).75 Compare, Behold, I go forward (kedem), but He is not there, And backward (achor), but I cannot perceive Him (Job 23:8).
BROUGHT THE LOCUSTS. From its place and deposited them in all the kingdom of Egypt.
14. WENT UP. Neither after them shall be such was prophetically written.76
15. FOR THEY COVERED THE FACE OF THE WHOLE EARTH. The meaning of so the land was darkened is that the locusts intervened between the sun and the land. The land is always dark.77
16. THEN PHARAOH CALLED FOR MOSES AND AARON IN HASTE. Via his messengers.78 Pharaoh added, I have sinned, because he drove them away from his presence in disgrace.
17. NOW THEREFORE FORGIVE, I PRAY THEE. I will explain the term sa na (forgive, I pray thee) in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.79

[ONLY THIS ONCE.] Because I will not sin again by rebelling against the Lord. Pharaoh did not promise to free the people because Moses was angry.80 Moses went out of the city as was his wont81 and prayed.82

19. AND THE LORD TURNED AN EXCEEDING STRONG WEST WIND. West is termed yam83 in the holy tongue because the great sea84 which goes out from Spain and passes by the land of Egypt and goes on to the Land of Israel lies in the west. This sea is not to be identified with the Atlantic Ocean because Israel did not inherit that much territory.85 The Spanish Sea is called the great sea because it is three hundred Persian miles wide, whereas none of the seas in the Land of Israel such as the Sea of Reeds, the Kineret, and the Salt Sea is even thirty Persian miles wide.
20. BUT THE LORD HARDENED. This is to be understood à la the words of our sages of blessed memory who said, “The door is opened for one who comes to defile himself.”86
21. AND THE LORD SAID. We may logically assume although it is not so stated that Moses’ staff was in his hand.87

EVEN DARKNESS WHICH MAY BE FELT. Yefet says that ve-yamesh (which may be felt) is like ve-yamish (and it shall depart);88 its meaning is: that the darkness to which they have become accustomed shall depart and another type of darkness, thicker than it, shall come. Others say that ve-yamesh is missing an alef.89 Now the word emesh in the holy tongue refers to the previous night, like emesh (yesternight) in spoke unto me yesternight (Gen. 31:29). It is the same case with the Arabic ams, as the shin and samekh interchange in most of the words.90 Now their interpretation makes no sense.91 I believe that ve-yamesh comes from the same root as yemashesh (gropeth) (Deut. 28:29).92 One cannot argue that yemashesh comes from a double root93 because with regard to something very similar Scripture uses the term yemishun (handle)94 in They have hands but handle not (Ps. 115:7).95 Ve-yamesh refers to Egypt, Egypt being in the singular,96 as in so Egypt said I will flee97 (Ex. 14:25). Now the meaning of ve-yamesh choshekh (even darkness which may be felt) is that the Egyptians will feel the darkness with their hands,98 for the darkness shall be so thick that neither a candle nor a fire shall give off light. They saw not one another (v. 23) neither by the light of day nor by candlelight is proof of the aforementioned.99

22. AND MOSES STRETCHED FORTH. The Egyptians had no way of knowing that three days passed except through the Israelites, who had light. Now there are times when a thick darkness100 comes over the Atlantic Ocean during which time it is impossible for a person to distinguish between day and night. The aforementioned occasionally lasts for as long as five days. I myself have been there many times.
23. NEITHER ROSE ANY FROM HIS PLACE. From his house, as in abide ye every man in his place (Ex. 16:29). For where could they go without light?
24. AND PHARAOH CALLED. After three days when they saw light.

ONLY LET YOUR FLOCKS AND YOUR HERDS BE STAYED. Pharaoh wanted to know what was in Moses’ mind. He wanted to learn whether Moses planned to escape.101 Pharaoh said, let your little ones also go with you because Moses had earlier told him, We will go with our young and with our old (v. 9).
25. THOU MUST ALSO GIVE INTO OUR HAND SACRIFICES AND BURNT-OFFERINGS. You are obligated to give into our hands sacrifices and burnt offerings to be brought on the altar on your behalf.

26. THERE SHALL NOT A HOOF BE LEFT BEHIND. Of any kind that are among our cattle, as we do not know which kind we are to choose102 and how many of them we will sacrifice. This is the meaning of we know not with what we must serve.
27. BUT THE LORD HARDENED PHARAOH’S HEART. In a manner similar to for the Lord thy God hardened his spirit, and made his heart obstinate (Deut. 2:30).
28. THOU SHALT DIE. You will deserve to be put to death for rebelling against the king.
29. THOU HAST SPOKEN WELL. Ken (well) here has the same meaning as ken (right) in The daughters of Zelophehad speak right (Num. 27:6).103
I WILL SEE THY FACE AGAIN NO MORE. For I will never come to you again.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Jacob. Compare, ve-ya’akov ish tam (Gen. 25:27) which I.E. renders: and Jacob was a man of integrity, i.e., wholehearted. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 25:27 and the notes thereto.
2 Moses, who is called the servant of the Lord (Deut. 34:5).
3 Ex. 12, the chapter which deals with the Hebrew calendar. The laws pertaining to the establishment of the Hebrew calendar are referred to as sod ha-ibbur (the secret of intercalating the calendar).
4 This last time of your own accord; henceforth Pharaoh shall ask you to come to him (Weiser).
5 Do not be discouraged by the fact that he has not as yet let Israel go.
6 Unlike Pharaoh’s heart.
7 See verse 7, And Pharaoh’s servants said unto him…Let the men go, that they may serve the Lord their God.
8 Literally, I might put.
9 The root of which is bet, yod, nun.
10 The root of which is sin, yod, mem.
11 Words having a yod as their middle root letter. In other words, shiti is a kal from the root shin, yod, tav.
12 They are all kals having a yod as their middle root letter.
13 Words similarly vocalized.
14 Conjugational forms.
15 The heh. Because it is a hifil the word should read hashiti.

16 Yasum is a kal from the root sin, vav, mem. Now if shiti was a kal it should read yashut (like yasum), rather than yashit, in the third person imperfect form. Hence the form yashit must be a hifil. Similarly, if shiti were a kal it would read shuti. It should be noted that these grammarians assume that the root of shiti is shin, vav, tav (Weiser).

17 La-sus is a kal infinitive from the root sin, vav, sin. Here too we see that such roots are vocalized in the kal with a shuruk, not with a chirik as shiti is. Hence shiti cannot be a kal. The point of these grammarians is that when we come across forms such as yasis, yashit and the like, we are dealing with hifils having a vav as a middle root letter. When we come across forms such as yasus, yashut, we are dealing with kals having a vav as a middle root letter. Hence the word shiti must be a hifil (Weiser).

18 In other words, yasis is not a hifil; it is a kal. The reason it is pronounced yasis and not yasus is that yasis comes from the root sin, yod, sin, and yasus comes from the root yod, vav, sin (Weiser).

19 There are two roots for the word set. One comes from the root sin, yod, mem, and one from the root sin, vav, mem. Compare, som tasim (thou shalt in any wise set) (Deut. 17:15). Som comes from the root sin, vav, mem, and tasim from the root sin, yod, mem. Both som and tasim are kals. It is the same with the words for put/set. One word comes from the root shin, vav, vav, and the other from the root shin, yod, tav. Shiti comes from the latter root, hence its vocalization.

20 And that thy mayest tell doesn’t only refer to Moses, to whom God was speaking, but to all of Israel. The point is that Israel might tell their children and grandchildren all that God did to Egypt.
21 Which closes our verse.
22 Hence what need is there for Scripture to mention Aaron?
23 Therefore Moses would not go to Pharaoh without Aaron. See I.E. on Ex. 4:30 and 7:2.
24 Its meaning thus is, to be humbled.
25 From the root ayin, nun, heh.
26 Weiser.
27 It comes from the root resh, bet, heh, meaning numerous.
28 A type of locust.
29 Joel mentions four types of locusts: gazam, arbeh, yelek, and chasil. We thus see that arbeh is a type of locust.
30 It has no meaning.
31 Literally, that shall not be able to see, hence I.E.’s comment.
32 The verse should be understood as if read: that a man shall not be able to see.
33 Which indicates that the locusts ate new produce, as earlier the hail smote every herb of the field, and broke every tree of the land (Ex. 9:25).
34 Male’u (filled) is a third person kal perfect plural. The vav changes it into an imperfect.
35 I.E. goes on to point out that it is both transitive and intransitive in the kal.
36 In other words, here ma’le’u is intransitive. However, mile’u is transitive. Both are kal forms.
37 Malle’u.
38 As if it were a pi’el. Pi’el is always transitive.
39 According to Rabbi Joshua va-yifen means: and he faced. Compare, panim (face).
40 Rather than turn his back to Pharaoh and leave.
41 According to Yefet va-yifen means: and he was finished, i.e., finished his duties. Compare, panuy (unoccupied, disengaged).
42 According to Yefet u-fanita means: and you will be finished.
43 Here the word cannot be taken to mean he was disengaged, for what sense is there to a clause that reads: and he was finished this way and that way?

44 Its root is peh, nun, heh. It should be noted that the same applies to the above interpretations. However, I.E. means that the word means to turn the face and look. According to I.E. the meaning of our verse is: and he looked (va-yifen); i.e., he turned his face and went out from Pharaoh.
45 This time Pharaoh did not want to give Moses the chance to insult him by leaving on his own.
46 According to I.E. terem means before. See I.E. on Ex. 10:30 and the notes thereto.
47 It is used for emphasis. I.E. goes on to explain the meaning of et because our text reads, va-yushav et moshe ve-et aharon, (and Moses and Aaron were brought again).
48 Oti is a form of et.
49 Oti refers to the very persona.
50 In other words, the et does not make a difference. Re’uven harag et shimon means the same as re’uven harag shimon.
51 It has the same meaning as ve-rav ya’avod et ha-tza’ir.
52 It has the same meaning as asher bara Elohim et ha-adam.
53 It is so found most often in Scripture.
54 Here it emphasizes the subject rather than the object.
55 Va-yushav is in the singular. Its literal meaning is, was brought again. Since Scripture speaks of Moses and Aaron we would expect the plural, va-yushevu.
56 Since va-yushav is connected to the word et, which does not take on a different form before a plural, it too does not take on a plural form (Filwarg).
57 Va-tedabber is a feminine singular. Since Scripture speaks of Miriam and Aaron we would expect a plural masculine.
58 In other words, the term chag (feast) means a sacrifice, and our clause is to be translated: for we must sacrifice unto the Lord.
59 Pharaoh was not recognizing the Lord as God. What he was saying was: So be the Lord whom you claim as your God with you (Weiser).
60 For that is what ye desire refers to the evil mentioned in our verse; i.e., the clause is to be understood: for it is evil that you desire.
61 Hence he threatened them with evil.
62 Jewels of silver, and jewels of gold, and raiment (Ex. 12:35). They would not have given these objects to Israel if they had not believed that Israel would return.
63 Not telling Pharaoh that they would return.
64 That is, to leave Egypt permanently.
65 Scripture goes on to say, And Pharaoh will say of the children of Israel: They are entangled in the land…and he shall follow after them (Ex. 14:3, 4).

66 Why did God mislead Pharaoh into thinking that Israel was lost in the desert so that he would pursue them? He could have drowned Pharaoh and his army in the Red Sea without employing military strategy.

67 David too was told by God to use strategy in fighting the Philistines. David inquired of the Lord how to attack the Philistines. The Lord answered him, Thou shalt not go up; make a circuit behind them, and come upon them over against the mulberry-trees. And it shall be, when thou hearest the sound of marching in the tops of the mulberry-trees, that then thou shalt bestir thyself; for then is the Lord gone out before thee to smite the host of the Philistines (II Sam. 5:23, 24). Here too God instructed David to lead the Philistines into a trap so that God would destroy them. The Lord acted in this manner even though He could have destroyed them without employing this strategy.
68 Adam can refer to both a male or a female. Compare, Gen. 1:27.
69 Mentioned in verse 10.

70 Rabbi Moses takes the bet of ba-arbeh to mean with. Compare, the bet in be-tuppim u-vimcholot (with timbrels and with dances) (Jud. 11:34). Rabbi Moses interprets our verse as follows: Stretch out thy hand with the locust over the land of Egypt.
71 In other words, the bet has the meaning of because. Compare, ish be-chet’o (each because of his own sin) (Deut. 24:16).
72 In other words, kedemah is a noun and kadim an adjective.
73 Meaning be in front, before.
74 To see the sun.
75 It is the last side to see the sun.
76 The Torah prophesies that there will never be an exact duplication of this plague again.
77 The earth gets its light from the sun; hence without sunlight it is dark.
78 Pharaoh did not personally call them.
79 See Ex. 34:4, where I.E. explains that the phrase has two meanings, to forgive or to bear sin. Here it means to forgive.
80 And Pharaoh did not want to engage him any further in conversation (Weiser).
81 When he prayed.
82 Moses could not pray within the city because of the idols therein. See I.E. on Ex. 9:29.
83 Sea.
84 The Mediterranean. Scripture refers to the sea which borders the Land of Israel on the west as the “great sea.” Cf. Num. 34:6; Jos. 1:4; 9:1.
85 The Land of Israel was not that vast as to reach the Atlantic.
86 Sabbath 104a; Yoma 38b.
87 When he stretched out his hand towards heaven. See I.E. on Ex. 9:22.
88 From the root mem, vav, shin, meaning to depart or remove. Compare, lo yamish amud he-anan, (the pillar of cloud by day departed not) (Ex. 13:22).

89 Cf. Rashi. According to Rashi ve-yamesh, spelled vav, yod, mem, shin, is a form of emesh. According to him ve-yamesh choshekh (even darkness which may be felt) means: and the darkness of the night shall be even more dark (Cohen).
90 That are cognate to Hebrew and Arabic.
91 For emesh means yesternight. Thus ve-yamesh choshekh has to be translated: and yesterday shall be dark. This makes no sense.
92 From the root mem, shin, shin, meaning to feel, to grope.
93 While ve-yamesh, which has one shin, at first glance does not.
94 Or feel.

95 It too has only one shin, yet its meaning is to feel. As to the root of ve-yamesh and yemishun, they either come from the root mem, vav, shin, which is a variant of the root mem, shin, shin, or they come from the root mem, shin, shin and are conjugated with only one of the double letters. There are a number of other such words. Compare, asev (I will turn around) (root, samekh, bet, bet) and achel (I will begin) (root chet, lamed, lamed). Cf. Weiser.
96 Ve-yamesh is a singular. If ve-yamesh refers to Egypt the plural form should have been used, hence I.E.’s comment.
97 Anusah (I will flee) is in the singular.
98 According to I.E. ve-yamesh means: and he shall feel. Thus ve-yamesh choshekh means: and he (Egypt) shall feel the darkness.
99 I.E. takes literally, They saw not one another.
100 I.E. is obviously referring to a thick fog.
101 Hence he said, only let your flocks and your herds be stayed. If they intended to return they wouldn’t mind leaving the latter behind.
102 For offerings.
103 I.E. there explains ken as meaning true or correct. Our clause may thus be rendered: thou hast spoken truthfully; or, thou hast spoken correctly.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 11
chapter.p: 1. AND THE LORD SPOKE. The chapter opening with the words, Thus saith the Lord (v. 4)1 should have been connected to the previous verse.2 However, the chapter stating, Yet one plague more3 was inserted between them. The reason for this is that Scripture wanted to teach us when4 Thus saith the Lord5 was told to Moses.6 It was related to Moses while he was yet in Midian,7 viz., Behold, I will slay thy son, thy first-born (Ex. 4:23). Moses was commanded on Mount Sinai8 that when the time came for the plague of the first-born to arrive, every man should ask jewels of his neighbor.9 I have already explained why it is there written, but every woman shall ask of her neighbor (Ex. 3:22) and here it is written, and let them ask every man of his neighbor.10 Now the meaning of And the Lord said unto Moses: Yet one plague more will I bring is that the Lord had already told this to Moses.11 There are many such cases in Scripture.12 God said, he shall surely thrust you out, in keeping with His statement, and by a strong hand shall he drive them out of his land (Ex. 6:1).
2. SPEAK NOW. I have already explained that the word na means now.13
3. AND THE LORD GAVE. Scripture relates that the Lord kept his promise to Moses: of And I will give this people favor in the sight of the Egyptians (Ex. 3:21).
[MOREOVER THE MAN MOSES.] For many let them have what they asked out of respect for Moses.
AND IN THE SIGHT OF THE PEOPLE. The people of Egypt.

4. ABOUT MIDNIGHT. Some grammarians say that ka-chatzot (about midnight) is an infinitive.14 Its meaning is, when it shall be exactly one half of the night. They want to compare ka-chatzot ha-laylah (about midnight) to ba-chatzi ha-laylah (at midnight)15 in And it came to pass at midnight (Ex. 12:29). Now it is common knowledge that it is beyond the ken of a wise man to ascertain the exact moment of noon without great effort and the use of large copper instruments.16 It goes without saying that it is much harder to ascertain the more difficult time of midnight.17 I believe that there is no need for all of this since the meaning of ka-chatzot ha-laylah (about midnight) is, when the first half of the night has passed. The same is the case with ba-chatzi ha-laylah in And it came to pass at midnight (Ex. 12:29). It refers to the remaining half of the night.18 And it came to pass at midnight (ba-chatzi ha-laylah) (Ruth 3:8)19 and At midnight (chatzot laylah) I will rise to give thanks to thee (Ps. 119:62) are convincing proof of this.20
[WILL I GO OUT.] The reference is to the decree that goes out from the Lord.21

5. THE FIRST-BORN OF PHARAOH THAT SITTETH UPON HIS THRONE. Who is fit to sit upon Pharaoh’s throne after him.22 Moses mentioned the most honored of all the Egyptians, namely, the son of their lord whom all of them serve and also the meanest of them all, namely, the first-born of the maid-servant, who is himself a slave.23
[THAT IS BEHIND THE MILL.] Who grinds.24 Compare, And he did grind in the prison house (Jud. 16:21).

I have already explained that the prophets are not careful in preserving the exact wording but are rather concerned with reproducing meanings.25 The words hagmi’ini (give me to drink) (Gen. 24:17)26 and hashkini (give me to drink) (Gen. 29:45);27 zakhor (remember) (Ex. 20:8)28 and shamor (observe)29 (Deut. 5:12); sheker (false) (Ex. 20:13)30 and shav (false) (Deut. 5:17);31 lo tachmod (thou shalt not covet) (Ex. 20:14)32 and ve-lo titavveh (neither shalt thou covet) (Deut. 5:18)33 have one meaning. I will yet discuss this when I comment on the prayer of Moses (Ex. 32:9). Now, the first-born of the maid-servant34 means the same as the first-born of the captive (Ex. 12:29).35 The captive woman is a maid-servant who sleeps in the dungeon at night as prisoners do, as was noted by Joseph when he said, that they should put me into the dungeon (Gen. 40:15).

6. AND THERE SHALL BE A GREAT CRY. We do not find Scripture elsewhere stating anything like kamohu lo nihyatah ve-khamohu lo tosif (such as there hath been none like it, nor shall be like it anymore).36 The word al (over) has been omitted from our verse and the clause should be understood literally as follows: such as over it there hath been none like it, nor such over it shall be like it a cry anymore.37 Such as like it (kamohu) refers to havoc, calamity, death, and the like.38

7. SHALL NOT A DOG WHET HIS TONGUE. To frighten them. None whetted his tongue against any of the children of Israel (Josh. 10:21) is similar. Its meaning is that no dog shall bark at them or bite them. Now no dog shall whet his tongue at them or their cattle here on earth. How much more so when He sends a destroyer from heaven to smite their first-born?39
8. AND ALL THESE THY SERVANTS SHALL COME DOWN UNTO ME…SAYING. On your behalf.40

AND ALL THE PEOPLE THAT FOLLOW THEE. Be-raglekha (follow thee) means: who are under your dominion.41 For I will lead them to the place which I desire. And there went up ten thousand at his feet (be-raglav) (Jud. 4:10) is similar.42
Moses went out in hot anger because Pharaoh had told him, see my face no more (Ex. 10:28).
9. AND THE LORD SAID. According to the manner of the Hebrews and the rules of language this is to be rendered: and the Lord had already said.43 There are many other such instances.

10. AND MOSES. Even though Moses and Aaron did all these wonders which are mentioned in Scripture, Pharaoh’s heart did not soften and he did not let them go, because God hardened his heart. The chapter opening with the words, And it came to pass at midnight (Ex. 12:29)44 should by right have followed next so that the plagues would be described in order. However, the chapter dealing with, This is the ordinance of the Passover (chap. 12) was inserted in the middle to inform us how the first-born of Israel were saved when the destroyer came upon Egypt.45
chapter.ftnote: 1 Rather than our verse.

2 To Ex. 10:29. In other words, 11:4 should have followed 10:29, for in point of fact Moses told Pharaoh, Thus saith the Lord: about midnight will I go out into the midst of Egypt; and all the first-born in the land of Egypt shall die (11:4), after telling him, Thou hast spoken well; I will see thy face again no more (10:29).
3 Verses 1-3.
4 Reading matai, as in Vat. Ebr. 48, rather than u-matai, as in the printed editions.
5 Verse 4 and what follows.
6 According to I.E., And the Lord said (v. 1) means: and the Lord had already said, the reference being to what God told Moses in Midian (Ex. 4:23).
7 Contra Rashi, who believes that verses 1-3 contain a prophecy to Moses while in Pharaoh’s palace.
9 The point is that the command to ask for jewels and raiment was also not given at this point.
10 See I.E. on Ex. 3:22.
11 I.E. interprets va-yomer (and he said) as a pluperfect, meaning: and he had said.
12 Where Scripture employs the pluperfect.
13 See I.E. on Ex. 4:13.
14 A verbal noun meaning: when the night divides in half.
15 Which the Talmud (Berakhot 4a) takes to mean exactly at midnight.
16 I.E. apparently refers to a sundial.
17 Hence Scripture would not employ terms that are meaningless from a practical point of view.
18 Another way of saying after midnight.
19 That the man was startled, and turned himself; and, behold, a woman lay at his feet.

20 The exact moment of midnight is irrelevant to what is reported in Ruth 3:8, for what reason can there be to pinpoint the exact moment that the man was startled. Similarly, David had no way of determining the exact moment of midnight while he slept.
21 In other words, will I go out does not refer to the Lord Himself but to His decree.
22 Pharaoh’s first-born did not sit on the throne of Egypt, hence I.E.’s comment.
23 The point is that all first-born shall die, from the highest to the lowest.
24 Because grinding was the most menial work, it was reserved for slaves and prisoners.
25 I.E. on Gen. 5:29. Also see his commentary to Ex. 20:1 and the first chapter of the Sefer Ha-Yesod.
26 Spoken by Abraham’s servant to Rebekah when he asked her for water.
27 Used by Abraham’s servant when he quoted what he had said to Rebekah.
28 Which opens the fourth commandment quoted in Exodus.
29 Which opens the fourth commandment in Deuteronomy.
30 The term employed for false in the ninth commandment in Exodus.
31 The term employed for false in the ninth commandment in Deuteronomy.
32 Which opens the tenth commandment in Exodus.
33 Which opens the tenth commandment in Deuteronomy.
34 The term used by Moses in our verse.

35 The term used by God when he first told Moses that he would slay all the first-born in the land of Egypt. I.E.’s point is that Moses was not misquoting God, as “the prophets are not careful in preserving the exact wording.”
36 A comparable combination of masculine and feminine forms. Kamohu (like it) is masculine whereas nihyatah (hath been) and tosif (shall be) are feminine.

37 In other words, nihyatah and tosif refer to tze’akah (cry), a feminine noun mentioned in the first part of the verse. This eliminates the problem of having a masculine preposition/pronoun (kamohu) connected to feminine nouns (nihyatah, tosif).

38 Although they are not explicitly mentioned in our verse. The Hebrew form of these words is in the masculine. According to I.E. our verse is to be explained as follows: And there shall be a great cry throughout all the land of Egypt. Over such a calamity there hath been none like it (a cry), nor over such a calamity shall there ever be such (a cry).
39 If God will not allow even a dog to bark at the Israelites, He will certainly not permit His angel to harm them.
40 You will send them down to me with the following message.
41 Be-raglekha (follow thee) literally means at thy feet. Hence I.E.’s comment.
42 There too be-raglav means under his dominion.

43 Another way of saying that according to the rules of classical Hebrew, va-yomer can be either a perfect or a pluperfect. Here it must be a pluperfect, as God had already told what is reported in our verse to Moses in verse 1.
44 Which describes the death of the first-born.
45 They were saved by the blood of the paschal lamb which was put on the side-posts and on the lintels of the houses wherein the Passover sacrifice was eaten. See Ex. 12:7-13.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 12
chapter.p: 1. AND THE LORD SPOKE. Scripture now mentions the first of the commandments given via Moses and Aaron, as they alone were prophets of the law.1 After them, except for extenuating circumstances as in the case of Gideon2 and Elijah,3 no new precepts were revealed. Do not take the chanting of psalms in the house of God instituted by David4 to heart,5 as the latter was an enactment and an institution established by David and Solomon.6 Thus Scripture states, by their beliefs (II Chron. 9:22), and not by their prophecies. However, Saadiah Gaon says that they had a tradition going back to Moses that a king would arise and innovate musical compositions.7 Neither carry forth a burden out of your houses on the sabbath day (Jer. 17:22) is similar.8

2. THIS MONTH. Rabbi Judah Ha-Parsi9 says that the Israelites, like the uncircumcised,10 employed a solar calendar. He offers as proof, Thou shalt therefore keep this ordinance in its season (Ex. 13:10). But lunar years are not all equal, as the seasons of plowing and harvest are dependent solely on the movement of the sun as it travels to the north or the south.11 However, he did not speak correctly.

I will now explain.12 We know that it takes the moon, moving in its sphere13 in a given point facing the sphere of the zodiac, close to twenty-seven and a third days to return to this very point. Now let us assume a starting point wherein the moon is in conjunction with the sun at the beginning of Aries. In such a case the moon would not find the sun at the head of Aries when it returned there14 because the sun, traveling in its mean motion,15 would by then have journeyed twenty-seven degrees.16 This is because, contrary to the movement above,17 the sun and the moon move from west to east. The sun and the moon would next be in conjunction at the end of twenty-nine and a half days, two-thirds and seventy-three parts of an hour, according to the way Israelites divide the hour.18 Thus19 the moon would have traveled the very degrees that the sun journeyed,20 and the moon also would have had to travel two days and close to five hours in the parts in which the sun had moved.21

Actually, the year belongs only to the sun,22 as the sun gives birth to the four seasons of the year, cold, heat, summer, and winter. Now let us assume the sun to be at the beginning of Aries. It will then travel three hundred and sixty-five days plus close to a quarter of a day in its sphere until it returns a second time to where it started out. It is for this reason that a year is called a shanah.23 Now the moon has no year, as the sun has no month. Nothing new happens to the sun; only to the light of the moon does something new occur.24 It is because of this that a month is called a chodesh and also a yerach.25 It is so called26 because the light of the moon is renewed. We have conclusive proof that the moon has no light of its own, and that its light comes from the sun. The sun27 therefore does not darken except in the moment when it is in conjunction with the moon at the head or the tail of Aries.28 Similarly, the moon does not darken except when it is opposite the sun in the aforementioned places29 at night.30 Due to the fact that the year of the uncircumcised is close to a solar year31 and because they saw that the moon is renewed twelve times during a solar year, they divided the days of the year into twelve parts and called each part a month because it is close to the days of a lunar month. This arrangement of theirs is not in keeping with the laws of nature.32 Similarly the Moslems,33 because their festivals are contingent upon lunar months34 and a month starts from the night that the moon is first seen. They saw that there are twelve months in a solar year and they did not find a closer way of reckoning than this,35 as there is only a difference of eleven days between the two ways of numbering the year.36 They therefore made all of their years lunar. The time of their Passover37 recedes each year by eleven days until thirty-three solar years equal thirty-four lunar years.38 These things39 are not based on the laws of nature.

Now God commanded in His Torah that the festivals be kept in their seasons, for He said, Observe the month of spring and keep the passover unto the Lord thy God (Deut. 16:1). Now if spring is not found40 by half of the month41 then we make Passover in the month close to it.42 God similarly called the festival of Sha’vu’ot, the feast of harvest (Ex. 23:16)43 and the festival of Sukkot, the feast of ingathering (Ibid.).44 The harvest and the ingathering are dependent on spring.45 Furthermore, we see that God said that we should not observe the Passover on any day but the midpoint of a lunar month.46 The same applies to the festival of Sukkot.47 God thus commanded that we observe lunar months48 and that the seasons of the festivals be preserved.49 Moses did not mention in the Torah that we should count twelve or thirteen months.50 He said only51 that we should begin the count52 in the month that we find spring. That month is to be called the first month whether the year has twelve or thirteen months. It is thus written, in the second month (Num. 10:11) and In the third month (Ex. 19:1). All the other months are similarly written.53 Nisan, Iyyar, Sivan, and all the other names of the months are not Hebrew. They are Chaldean terms. We therefore do not encounter these terms in any book of Scripture except in the Scroll of Esther and in the prophecies of Zechariah, Daniel,54 and Ezra, who were in the Diaspora. This then is its55 meaning: in the first month, which is called Nisan in the Chaldean tongue.56 However, we find three months called by other names in Hebrew, viz., in the month Ziv (I Kings 6:1); in the month Ethanim (I Kings 8:2); in the month Bul (I Kings 6:7). If we pursue the literal meaning of the text the month of Ziv is not Nisan but Iyyar, for it is written, in the month Ziv, which is the second month (I Kings 6:1), that is, which is known as the second to the first of the months of Israel. The words of Solomon’s reign (Ibid.) are not connected to the word month but rather to the fourth year of Solomon’s reign (Ibid.),57 as we do not find the months related in the account of any king.58 Scripture only reports the year that the king started his reign. In the second day59 of the second month, in the fourth year of his reign60 recorded in Chronicles (II Chron. 3:2) is proof of this.

We can refute Judah Ha-Parsi61 with the argument that not all years are equal.62 The years differ,63 due to the effect of the planets, in that the rain increases or diminishes and the heat or cold increases or diminishes each month,64 making it different from the known norm. Spring is therefore not be found to have arrived when the sun returns to the spot that it was in at the beginning of the previous year although it was then spring. There is65 more than a year and two weeks66 between one spring67 and the next.68 The Israelites therefore relied on the spring found in their country in whatever month it occurred, as the time of the appearance of spring69 varies in all countries according to the distance of that land from the equator.

I will now give you a general rule. Although the Israelites in the time of the Holy Temple watched for the arrival of spring,70 the establishment of a leap year was not in their hands. It rather depended on the Bet Din which, as is related in the Mishnah,71 looked for other things besides spring.72 Now Moses did not explain to us in the Torah how we should establish years or months. Neither did he tell us what we should do if we do not find it to be spring. One can pose a difficult question from all this, namely, why did Moses explain the laws of the plagues of the leper, which fall upon one person and do not last forever,73 and leave out of the Torah the laws of the festivals74 that all of Israel is obligated to keep at all times? Furthermore, eating leaven on Passover and eating on the Day of Atonement are punished with excision. If Moses relied on the conjunction of the moon and sun he should have explained whether he meant according to the moon’s mean motion75 or its true conjunction,76 which takes place opposite the sphere of the constellations, because at times there are approximately fourteen hours between the calculated conjunction77 and the true conjunction. It is because of this that our holy fathers said, “At times it78 comes at longer intervals; at times it79 comes at shorter intervals.”80 Only one who knows his way in the science of astronomy can know this. Additionally, Moses should have explained from which part of the earth we reckon the conjunction. For behold, between Jerusalem and this city, whose name is Lucca, there is more than three hours.81 If Moses relied on the time the moon is first seen82 he should have explained the place of its sighting,83 as the Arc of Vision84 changes in each place according to the earth’s latitude and according to the latitude of the moon from the line of the constellations, in addition to changes in visibility due to longitude, latitude, atmospheric conditions, and the height of elevation or lack thereof. All of these things require lengthy exposition. Now if it is cloudy, shall we out of doubt observe the new moon for two days?85 This proves that the establishment of the new moon is contingent on the declaration of the Bet Din in each generation.86 They had a tradition that the Bet Din establish seven leap years every nineteen years, totaling two hundred and thirty-five months or six thousand, nine hundred and thirty-nine and two-thirds days, plus five hundred and ninety-five parts of an hour. The aforementioned are nineteen solar years without addition or subtraction. Do not concern yourself with the hour and four hundred and eighty-five parts of an hour87 according to “Samuel’s calendar.”88 We know that this was not hidden from him.89 Samuel only used a number which was close in his time to the men of his generation.90 Today there is a difference of close to nine days91 between the true circuit92 and Samuel’s circuit. Do not be amazed at this. For behold the Braita states93 that one who wants to know the place of the moon should calculate the year of the world and divide it into months and divide the months into twenty-nine and a half days and two-thirds of an hour, i.e., seven hundred and twenty parts of an hour.94 Now seventy-three parts are missing.95 They will add up to more than two-thirds of a day each cycle.96 There will thus be97 a difference of close to half a year between the calculation of the conjunctions from creation and our own calculation of the conjunction.98

It has thus been made clear to you that the sum of our years equals out every cycle of solar years, and our months are always lunar months.99 Blessed be the Lord who has guided me in the straight path.

I will now offer you proof from Scripture that the festivals are dependent upon the Bet Din. Scripture states, For the king100had taken counsel, and his princes, and all the congregation in Jerusalem, to keep the passover in the second month (II Chron. 30:2). Now if they had a tradition to look for spring,101 as those who argue with our rabbis of blessed memory claim, why did the king take counsel to establish the Passover in the second month?102 It will now be shown if their103 words are true. Hezekiah did three evils.104 First of all, he did not offer the Passover sacrifice in its time105 although he was ritually clean.106 Why did Hezekiah delay the observance of Passover because most of the congregation had not arrived?107 Such a thing is only found in the words of tradition,108 not in Scripture.109 Second, he ate and caused Israel to eat leaven in the first month.110 Third, on his own111 he decided to observe the festival of unleavened bread in the second month. Such a thing is not to be done. With the exception of eating the paschal lamb112 on one night,113 the Lord did not command the observance of the Passover in the second month, for all those who are unclean eat unleavened bread along with all of Israel in the first month. Far be it for Hezekiah to do such evil. Moreover, Scripture says of him that he did not turn aside to the right or left from the commandments of the Lord.114 Furthermore, Hezekiah himself said in his prayer, Remember now, O Lord, I beseech Thee, how I have walked before Thee…and have done that which is good in Thy sight (II Kings 20:3).

I will now explain.115 Know that Hezekiah took counsel with the entire congregation116 at the start of the first month that they should observe the Passover in the following month because most of the people had not arrived and the priests had not sanctified themselves in sufficient numbers.117 He thus added a month to the year, and the Passover that he observed was the actual Passover118 in its proper season. The fact that God plagued those who ate the paschal lamb in a manner contrary to what is written119 is proof of this. If the Passover observed by Hezekiah was not celebrated in its proper time and was therefore not acceptable to the Lord,120 why did He plague them?121 If Hezekiah sinned how is it that he prayed on their behalf122 and the Lord accepted his supplication and healed the people?123 The answer to one who would argue that the sages of blessed memory did not maintain124 that Hezekiah acted properly in adding another month during the month of Nisan125 is: they126 spoke the truth. It is the custom of every Bet Din to ascertain at the end of the month of Adar whether it is necessary127 to add another month to the year or not. Now Hezekiah did not do this; he committed a small error in adding another month to the year at the beginning of the month.128 Now since the additional month129 always comes before the first month,130 the latter is always the first of the months, and the festivals131 will fall in the seventh month from it.132 This is the meaning of it shall be the first month of the year to you (v. 2).133 We know that many commandments are in memory of the Exodus from Egypt. Behold, it is therefore fitting that the Exodus be the first reference point in Israel’s calculations. Thus it is written, And it came to pass in the four hundred and eightieth year after the children of Israel were come out of the land of Egypt, in the fourth year…in the month Ziv, which is the second month (I Kings 6:1).

The gentiles ask, if the year is made up of months and the month of spring is its foundation and beginning, why do you calculate your years from the seventh month and say that a new year begins on its first day?134 The answer is that our sages of blessed memory have already noted135 that there are four new year days.136 We clearly see that the sanctification of the jubilee year is on the tenth day of the seventh month (Lev. 25:9).137 Furthermore, God commanded that the Torah be read in the set time of the year of release, in the feast of tabernacles (Deut. 31:10)…that they may hear, and that they may learn (Deut. 31:12). Now if the beginning of the year of release is reckoned from Nisan, why didn’t God command that the Torah be read during the festival of unleavened bread? Now they were idle for half a year.138 Furthermore, Scripture states, and the feast of ingathering 139 at the turn of the year (Ex. 34:22). 140 Elsewhere it states,141 at the end of the year,142 when thou gatherest in thy labors out of the field (Ex. 23:16). Additionally, we can derive the aforementioned143 from the way the Torah speaks and from the way nature acts. The Torah first states,144 ye shall not sow and afterwards says, neither (shall ye) reap (Lev. 25:12). The season of sowing is close to Tishri,145 not Nisan. Furthermore, if we reckon the beginning of the year of release from Nisan he who sowed in the sixth year146 will not harvest in the seventh year, because the harvest falls after Nisan when the year of release has already started.147 He will also not sow in the year of release.148 We thus see that the words of our sages are correct.149

THE BEGINNING OF MONTHS. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen150 says that there is no need to use the term rosh chodesh (new moon). The term chodesh suffices,151 since the meaning of chodesh is the day that the light of the moon is renewed. Scripture thus states, chodesh ve-shabbat (New moon and sabbath) (Is. 1:13); chodshekhem u-mo’adekhem (your new moons and your appointed seasons) (Is. 1:14); mi-de chodesh be-chodsho (from one new moon to another) (Is. 66:23). Others argued with him and asked, if this be the case, then why does Scripture state, ba-chodesh hashe’vi’i be-echad la-chodesh (And in the seventh month, on the first day of the month) (Num. 29:1)?152 Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen answered, to remove doubt.153 They also quoted, u-ve-roshe chodshekhem (and in your new moons) (Num. 28:11) against him.154 He answered that Scripture speaks of the month of Nisan throughout the years,155 for only Nisan is the chief new moon.156 They then asked him, if so, then what sacrifices are we to offer on other new moons?157 He answered that Scripture states in the very same portion, This is the burnt-offering of every new moon throughout the months of the year (Num. 28:14).158 Scripture likewise states, Also in the day of your gladness, and in your appointed seasons, and in your new moons (u-ve-roshe chodshekhem),159 ye shall blow with the trumpets (Num. 10:10) because it is the beginning of the year.160 However, we161 will not set aside the words of our rabbis of blessed memory because of our own opinions. Our sages said that we sound the trumpets on the new moon of every month.162 It is correct to say chodesh or rosh chodesh.163 It is written, ad chodesh yamim (but a whole month) (Num. 11:20), the meaning of which is: until the days of the month are complete.164
3. SPEAK YE UNTO ALL THE CONGREGATION OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. For all those who are obligated to observe the commandments165 are required to do this.166

THEY SHALL TAKE. Whoever has cattle shall take from his cattle, as the Israelites had a lot of cattle. Or yikchu (they shall take) means they shall buy. Yefet says that they should start preparing the lamb on the tenth day and do so till the fourteenth day.167 However, we do not know168 whether this is a command for all generations or pertained only to the Passover observed in Egypt.169
A LAMB, ACCORDING TO THEIR FATHERS’ HOUSES. If they be few.170

A LAMB FOR A HOUSEHOLD. If they be many.171 After stating, a lamb, according to their fathers’ houses, Scripture says a lamb for each and every household.172 I have already explained the meaning of bayit (household) at the beginning of this book.173
4. AND IF THE HOUSEHOLD BE TOO LITTLE FOR A LAMB. Too little to eat a lamb because the members of the household are few. Then he and his neighbor shall take a lamb.

ACCORDING TO THE NUMBER OF THE SOULS. Mikhsat (number of) means a portion.174 The word mekhes (tribute) in And the Lord’s tribute (Num. 31:37) in which mekhes refers to the portion which each one shall take, is similar. So too the word kosi (portion) in O Lord, the share of mine inheritance and my portion (Ps. 16:5).175 This is also the meaning of takhosu (ye shall make your count).176 It comes from a double root.177 The doubled letter is missing in the word be-mikhsat178 and also in mekhes.179 Scripture follows the paradigm of memer (bitterness) in And bitterness to her that bore him (Prov. 17:25), which comes from a double root180 in its vocalization of mekhes.181

5. YOUR LAMB SHALL BE WITHOUT BLEMISH. It shall be without any deformity. The word seh (lamb) also applies to the two kinds182 taken in by the term tzon (flock).183 Sehkhevasim ve-seh izzim (the sheep and the goat) (Deut. 14:4) is similar.

Rabbi Moses ben Amram Ha-Parsi184 says that the obligation to offer a lamb only pertains to the Passover brought in Egypt. However, in the Land of Israel one could sacrifice a lamb or a bull. He offers as proof, And thou shalt sacrifice the passover-offering unto the Lord thy God, of the flock and the herd (Deut. 16:2), which applies to the Passover to be offered in all future generations. However, he did speak correctly. All future Passover offerings are in memory of the paschal lamb offered in Egypt, and one should not deviate from it. The meaning of the aforementioned verse can only be: And thou shalt sacrifice the passover-offering unto the Lord thy God of the flock as an obligation; and of the herd, bring peace offerings to be eaten cooked in water. Similarly, And thou shalt rejoice in thy feast, thou, and thy son, and thy daughter (Deut. 16:14) means thou art obligated;185 thy son and thy daughter are permitted to do so. Proof of the above is found in the book of Chronicles.186 We read there that on the fourteenth day187 they slaughtered lambs and bullocks.188 It is written there that the lambs were for Passover offerings189 and the bullocks which served as peace offerings were cooked in pots and caldrons.190 Only those sacrifices which came from the flock were roasted in the fire according to ordinance.191

Rabbi Joshua says that there is a difference between ben shanah (of the first year)192 and ben shenato (of the first year). A ben shanah193 has lived a year and ben shenato means exactly what Scripture says.194 Now with regard to the sacrifices offered by the princes it first states, keves echad ben shenato leolah (one he-lamb of the first year, for a burnt-offering) (Num. 7:15) and then states, kevasim bene shanah (he-lambs of the first year) (Num. 7:87).195
6. AND YE SHALL KEEP IT. Each one shall keep it in his house.

AT DUSK. Ben ha-arbayim (at dusk) is a difficult phrase. Rabbi Solomon196 says that it refers to the moment after midday that the sun moves to the west. He does not explain why arbayim is in the dual form.197 Now, Scripture states, And when Aaron lighteth the lamps at dusk (ben ha-arbayim) (Ex. 30:8), and there is no doubt that Aaron is to light the lamps when the sun sets.198 Now, when we researched this phrase we found that Scripture refers to the moment of ben ha-arbayim as erev (evening).199 For it is clearly written, At dusk (ben ha-arbayim) ye shall eat flesh (Ex. 16:12), and it is there stated, when the Lord shall give you in the evening (ba-erev) flesh to eat (Ex. 16:8). Likewise, concerning the lighting of the lamps it is written: Aaron and his sons shall set it in order, to burn from evening (erev) to morning before the Lord (Ex. 27:21).200 It is similarly written, even burnt-offerings mornings and evening (erev) (Ezra 3:3), and it is stated, The one lamb thou shalt offer in the morning; and the other lamb thou shalt offer at dusk (ben ha-arbayim) (Ex. 29:39). Now concerning the Passover sacrifice, about which the term ben ha-arbayim (at dusk) is employed, we find that Scripture states, there thou shalt sacrifice the passover-offering at even (erev), at the coming (bo)201 of the sun, at the season that thou earnest forth out of Egypt (Deut. 16:6). Rabbi Solomon202 explains that the reference is to the time that the sun comes to the west.203 However, this is not the meaning of bo. It refers to the opposite of the sun’s going forth upon the earth204 since it is written, the sun went out (yatza) upon the earth (Gen. 19:23),205 which means the time that the sun first begins to be seen on the earth. Similarly, And when the sun comes (ba) he shall be clean206 (Lev. 22:7) means when the sun shall no longer be seen upon the ground. Now it is written concerning a nocturnal seminal emission, But it shall be, when evening cometh on, he shall bathe himself in water; and when the sun comes (u-khe-vo ha-shemesh)207 he may come within the camp208 (Deut. 23:12). If this is not so, then let Rabbi Solomon explain what difference there is between “when the sun comes” with regard to Passover and “when the sun comes” with regard to a nocturnal seminal emission. It is the same with and when the sun comes he209 shall be clean (Lev. 22:7).210

The Sadducees211 say that there are three evenings.212 Their proof is from a verse which they found to read, ha-erev ha-shelishit (the third evening)213 (I Sam. 20:5). However, they do not recognize or understand the truth. It is written, Tomorrow is the new moon…And in the third day thou shalt hide thyself well (I Sam. 20:18, 19), the meaning of which is: when close to evening of the third day starting from today comes, you shall hide yourself well in the field where you are presently hidden. It is because of this that Jonathan said, until the third evening.214

I will now backtrack and explain.215 Know that the word arbayim is always vocalized according to the paradigm of the dual forms like ovnayim (birthstool) (Ex. 1:16). Luchotayim (planks) (Ezek. 27:5) is similar. So is derachayim (ways) (Prov. 28:18), as But he that is perverse in his ways (derachayim) shall fall in one of them (Ibid.) proves.216 The same is the case with the word shamayim (heaven), as the heavens consist of two poles217 which are like fastened nails upon which the sphere leans. I have already explained in The Book of God, the Glorious,218 that the word shamayim comes from the same root as the word sham (there) in There the upright might reason with Him (Job 23:7).219 The term shamayim alludes to these two places.220

We thus have two evenings: one when the sun sets, that is, the time when the sun descends beneath the earth; the second when its light disappears from the clouds.221 Now there is close to one and a third hours between them. It is at this time222 that one who experienced a seminal emission223 may enter the camp and Aaron kindles the lights.224

Rabbi Saadiah Gaon, of blessed memory, says that the altar of the burnt offering measured five cubits in length and five cubits in width. Such an area has room only for a small number of kohanim (priests), who are the ones that sprinkle the blood from the paschal lambs before it coagulates. Now in the days of Josiah,225 when the number of Israelites were few,226 the kohanim were not able to sprinkle the blood of the Passover offerings and the peace offerings that they slaughtered; i.e., they were not able to sprinkle them on the altar in one and a third hours.227 How much more unable to do so were they when all the tribes were in their country.228 There was thus a tradition that they begin to slaughter229 from the moment that it became clear to a person that the sun turned to the west.230 Scripture speaks of ben ha-arbayim (at dusk)231 because most of the paschal lambs were slaughtered then,232 and that marks its time limit;233 for one should not wait until the going down of the sun’s light.234
7. ON THE TWO SIDE-POSTS. Of the door of the house. Moses will go on to explain235 how they are to take the blood.

[LINTEL.] The word mashkof (lintel) means a window.236 Compare, va-yashkef (looked) (Gen. 26:8).237 This window was in the door.238 This is the custom in all Moslem countries. The practice of the uncircumcised239 differs from that of the Egyptians240 even regarding food,241 an example being, Thou shalt break it in pieces (Lev. 2:6).242 Similarly with regard to women’s jewelry such as the wearing of nose rings and earrings and all that the prophet Isaiah mentioned concerning the daughters of Zion (Is. 3:18-24).243 Likewise, all of their houses244 without exception are built in courtyards. One entrance is called the door to the house and the other the gate of the courtyard.

Many say that the purpose of placing the blood on the window and on the two side-posts was to demonstrate publicly that they slaughtered the abomination of Egypt,245 since by then the fear of the Israelites had fallen on the Egyptians, and the Israelites were not afraid of being stoned.246 Now if this was the case then the blood should have been placed on the entrance to the courtyard.247 However, the blood was placed in secret, for they closed the gate of the courtyard. Furthermore, they slaughtered the lamb at dusk, which is close to night, so that no one would see them. Moreover, no man left his house until the morning when each one went on his way and each one closed the gate to his courtyard. The Egyptians thought that the Israelites would return.248 The reason the blood was smeared on the window was to make atonement249 for all those eating in the house and to serve as a mark for the destroyer250 to see. It is to be understood in the same way as and set a mark on the foreheads of the men (Ezek. 9:4).251

[HOUSES.] The word battim (houses) is grammatically irregular, as it has a dagesh252 following a long kamatz.253 This is contrary to the rule254 whereby a dagesh is only placed after a short kamatz,255 as in ronnu (sing)256 in Sing, O ye heavens (Is. 44:23). Perhaps battim was vocalized with a kamatz 257 because of the missing yod in the word bayit.258 This form259 would thus not be confused with the form battim (baths) in ten baths are a homer (Ezek. 45:14) wherein battim, the plural of bat (bath) in The ephah and the bath (Ezek. 45:11), is vocalized with a pattach in the plural.260 The word battim (houses) in upon the houses is indicative,261 for unlike the rule it is penultimately accented.262

8. WITH BITTER HERBS THEY SHALL EAT IT. One of the Spanish wise men explained that it is well known that because of the Nile and the lack of rain, the humidity in Egypt is very high and the air is always moist. It was therefore their custom to eat all sorts of bitter herbs and mustards with their meals. An Egyptian always had bitters in which to dip his bread, even if he had but one loaf of bread, because the bitters are a cure for their climate.263 However, we will rely on the opinion of our ancients of blessed memory, who explained to us that the reason for the bitter herbs is to remind us that they made their lives bitter (Ex. 1:14).264

9. RAW. Some say that the meaning of na (raw) is: as it is now,265 i.e., when the meat is raw. However, we do not find the word na used in such a way elsewhere in Scripture.266 Others say267 that it comes from the same root as heni (breaks)268 in But if her father breaks her vow (Num. 30:6) and means broken.269 However, this is incorrect, as Scripture later states, neither shall ye break a bone thereof (v. 46).270 However, in my opinion the word na271 has no counterpart in Scripture. It means the opposite of cooked and is272 referred to as chai (raw). Compare, For he will not have sodden flesh of thee, but raw (chai) (I Sam. 2:15). I have previously noted that most of Arabic is similar to Hebrew.273 Now in Arabic raw meat is called nayy, and the alef heh, vav, and yod interchange in the tongue of the Arabs as it does in our tongue.274

NOR SODDEN. Bashel (sodden) is an adjective. Here its meaning is, that which is sodden with water.275 That which is roasted in fire is also called mevushal,276 for it is written, And thou shalt roast (u-vishalta)277 and eat it (Deut. 16:7) and, And they roasted (va-yevashelu)278 the passover with fire according to the ordinance (II Chron. 35:13). It is possible that nor sodden at all with water279 means nor cooked, that is, cooked in water, as a royal dish is sodden in liquids. They place a wide copper utensil on the fire and fill half of it with water. When the water boils they place the pot with the meat in cold water above the boiling water. Thus is the meat cooked.280 This dish is better than one prepared close to the fire.

I the writer281 add to the words of this scholar what I heard from his very own mouth.282 Bashel (sodden)283 is an adjective284 following the paradigm of kaved (heavy) and zaken (old). The term bashel 285 here is similar,286 as its bet 287 is vocalized with a kamatz and its shin288 has no dagesh. Bashel is not an infinitive289 like kabbed (promote) in for I will promote thee (Num. 22:17) or hakkeh (smite) in thou shalt surely smite (Deut. 13:16), as the infinitive is not joined to a word unless it is a perfect or an imperfect. Compare, dabber yedabber (speak well) (Ex. 4:14),290 and hakdesh hikdashti (I verily dedicate) (Jud. 17:3).291 However, the infinitive is never joined with the po’el or pa’ul. 292 Thus bashel (sodden) is similar to kaved (heavy).293 Its feminine form is beshelah, as in the shoulder…when it is sodden (beshelah) (Num. 6:19). Do not ask what need Scripture had to use the two terms bashel and mevushal.294 As the scholar295 pointed out,296 there are two soddenings, one of which is297 the placing of the utensil with the meat in the midst of the boiling water.

The plural of bashel mevushal is beshelim mevushalim. Compare, chakhamim mechukkamim (exceeding wise) in But they are exceeding wise (Prov. 30:24). The singular form is chakham mechukkam. Compare, barukh u-mevorakh (exceedingly blessed). There is a difference in nuance from a grammatical standpoint between chakham (a wise man) and mechukkam (one who has become wise).298 There is, as the scholar explained,299 a similar difference between bashel (sodden)300 and mevushal (sodden).301

ITS HEAD WITH ITS LEGS AND WITH THE INWARDS THEREOF. The word al has the meaning of with.302 The word al in And they came, both men and (al) women (Ex. 35:22) is similar. The head and the legs are to be washed in water303 as the ordinance requires.304

10. BUT THAT WHICH REMAINETH OF IT…BURN WITH FIRE. If one was unable to eat one’s portion due to circumstances beyond one’s control. Yefet says that the reference is to the bones. However, Scripture only speaks of what is normal.305

[11. AND THUS SHALL YE EAT IT.] The reference is only to the paschal lamb eaten in Egypt. However, those in Argalon306 do the same today in memory of the Exodus. These spiritual errants all leave their land on the fifteenth day in memory of the Exodus.
11. AND YOUR STAFF IN YOUR HAND. To lead the asses.307 Compare, and he smote the ass with his staff (Num. 22:27).308

[IN HASTE.] Israel was not to delay.309 They were to hurry and eat the paschal lamb before the moment of destruction arrived,310 when God would pass over their homes.311 God therefore commanded that the lamb be roasted in fire, because food that is roasted cooks quickly. The holy patriarchs312 similarly said the paschal lamb may be eaten only until midnight and it may only be eaten roasted.313
12. FOR I WILL GO THROUGH THE LAND OF EGYPT. God’s might and His power passed throughout the land. Hence it was as if God Himself went throughout the land.314

AND AGAINST ALL THE GODS OF EGYPT I WILL EXECUTE JUDGMENTS. In the manner of Dagon was fallen upon his face to the ground (I Sam. 5:4). It is similarly written, upon their gods also the Lord executed judgments (Num. 33:4).

[13. AND THE BLOOD SHALL BE TO YOU FOR A TOKEN.] This315 shall be for you a token so that your hearts will be strong and will not weaken as you hear the cries of the Egyptians when their first-born die via the destroyer.
[AND WHEN I SEE THE BLOOD.] I will pass over you and there will be no plague among you because I will see the blood. The blood will be a sign to the destroyer.316
14. AND THIS DAY SHALL BE UNTO YOU. It shall be a memorial for generations.

AND YE SHALL KEEP IT A FEAST. The reference is to the feast of Passover.317 Scripture says that it shall be kept a feast by an ordinance throughout your generations. However, it does not say that it is to be kept in all of your dwelling places, because this commandment is, as I will explain, contingent on dwelling in the Land of Israel.

15. SEVEN DAYS SHALL YE EAT UNLEAVENED BREAD. The reason for shall ye eat unleavened bread is to recall the matzot eaten when they left Egypt. They were not previously commanded to eat unleavened bread save for that which is to be eaten with the paschal lamb before midnight.318 However, God now commanded that they eat unleavened bread for seven days319 in memory of what happened to them when they left Egypt, as it is written there,320 for it was not leavened (Ex. 12:39). Had the Egyptians permitted them to tarry a bit, they would have leavened their dough. They ate unleavened bread for seven days until Pharaoh was drowned on the seventh day. The heavenly cloud led them day and night and they did not tarry very long even when they camped.321 It is similarly written when discussing the paschal lamb,322 seven days shalt thou eat unleavened bread therewith, even the bread of affliction (Deut. 16:3). Now according to its plain meaning, the text Seven days shall ye eat unleavened bread is stating an obligation.323 That thou mayest remember the day when thou camest forth out of the land of Egypt all the days of thy life (Deut. 16:3) is proof of this.324 It is because of this325 that Scripture states, Ye shall eat nothing leavened; in all your habitations shall ye eat unleavened bread (Ex. 12:20), as the latter326 is an obligation within the Land of Israel and outside of the Land of Israel.

[HOWBEIT THE FIRST DAY YE SHALL PUT AWAY LEAVEN OUT OF YOUR HOUSES.] Now since Israel had a tradition of commencing the slaughter of the paschal lamb when the sun started going down towards the west, and it is written, Thou shalt not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread (Ex. 34:25), the rabbis of blessed memory interpreted the word ach (howbeit) to mean a part of.327 Mark the fact that ceasing an act is not an act. The meaning of And on the seventh day God finished (Gen. 2:2) is: when the seventh day started God had already finished his work.328 Similarly, the meaning of the first day ye shall put away leaven out of your houses is: when the first day starts, all leaven shall already have been removed from the houses. Now the first day starts at the end of the fourteenth day at even, as it is written, from the first day until the seventh day. The meaning of the phrase329 then is that the seven full days330 are from the fourteenth day of the month at even, which is the end of the fourteenth day, until the twenty-first day at even. I will yet speak concerning this.
16. AND IN THE FIRST DAY. The day of the Exodus from Egypt.331 The seventh day is, as I will explain, the day that the Egyptians drowned.

NO MANNER OF WORK. We do not find the phrase kol melakhah (no manner of work) stated with regard to any of the festivals,332 with the exception of the Sabbath and the Day of Atonement.333 However, the phrase334 is employed with regard to Passover335 with the proviso that that which every man must eat is permitted.336 In all other places, be it Passover,337 Sha’vu’ot,338 the Day of Memorial,339 or the festival of Sukkot,340 Scripture employs the abridged form and states, ye shall do no manner of servile341 work.342 Only in one place343 with regard to Passover is it stated that you shall do no manner of work under the first stated conditions.344
17. AND YE SHALL OBSERVE. God here commanded that the matzot be watched345 from the time of the harvest.346

[HAVE I BROUGHT.] Scripture reads, have I brought your hosts out of the land of Egypt although they had not yet left Egypt. This prophecy took place at the beginning of the month.347 It meaning is: you will say this in all of your generations.348

18. IN THE FIRST. Scripture uses an abridged form since it had already stated, it shall be the first month of the year to you (v. 2). The meaning of in the first thus is, in the first month. In the tenth, on the first day of the month (Gen. 8:5)349 is similar.350
19. LEAVEN. Se’or (leaven) refers to something which induces leavening. The substance is well known.351 Scripture then goes on to say, for whosoever eateth anything which is leavened (machmetzet).352

Note that from the first day until the seventh day (v. 15) is not connected to what is adjacent, i.e., to shall be cut off353 but rather is connected to354 for whosoever eateth leavened bread.355 It is similar to of Solomon’s reign over Israel (I Kings 6:1).356

Yefet says that some letters refer both to the word in which they are placed and to a word previously written, as in odem pitdah u-vareket (carnelian, topaz, and smaragd) (Ex. 28:17), which is to be interpreted as if written, odem u-pitdah u-vareket (carnelian, and topaz, and smaragd).357 The same is true of mi-yom ha-rishon ad yom ha-shevi’i (from the first day until the seventh day).358

[WHETHER HE BE A SOJOURNER.] Scripture already noted that whosoever eateth leavened bread from among the Israelites incurs the penalty of excision.359 Scripture now adds a sojourner who is a sincere proselyte.360

20. NOTHING LEAVENED. Scripture first mentions the punishment361 and then the warning.362 In all your habitations shall ye eat unleavened bread is not optional as Six days shall work be done (Ex. 35:2) is. On the contrary, it is an obligation so that one will remember.363
21. AND MOSES CALLED FOR ALL THE ELDERS OF ISRAEL. So that they would tell the people.
AND TAKE YOU LAMBS. On the tenth day, as he was commanded by God.364

[AND KILL THE PASSOVER LAMB.] The grammarian365 says that ve-shachatu (and kill) in and kill the passover lamb is a pi’el.366 However, he spoke incorrectly. Ve-shachatu (shall kill it) in and the whole congregation of Israel shall kill it (v. 6) is a kal.367 It368 is properly vocalized with a kamatz beneath the shin because of the silent missing letter.369 However, ve-shachatu (and kill) in and kill the passover lamb is imperative in the kal. We do not find this root in the pi’el in any place in Scripture.370 The shin of ve-shachatu371 should have been vocalized with a chirik,372 as miskhu (draw)373 is. However, since the shin is followed by a guttural374 it was vocalized with a pattach, as is Hebrew practice. Compare, bacharu (choose) in choose you (Josh. 24:15).375 There are many other similar instances.376 The shin377 is therefore vocalized with a long pattach in the imperative. Both words378 are from the same conjugation.379
22. AND YE SHALL TAKE. Moses now explains the manner in which the blood is to be taken and placed on the lintel.380

[A BUNCH OF.] The word aguddat means a bunch (of). Compare, la-aggudah (band) in and became one band (II Sam. 2:25). Rabbi Merinus says that the alef in aguddah is appended,381 as aguddah comes from the same root as gedud (troop).382 Others say that the alef in aguddah is a root letter383 like the alef in afuddato (skillfully woven)384 in and the skillfully woven band (Ex 28:6).

[HYSSOP.] Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that azov (hyssop) is a plant known in Arabic as zatr and in the vernacular as oregano. It is an herb distinguished by various kinds of flavors. However, this interpretation is incorrect, for Scripture states, even unto the hyssop that springeth out of the wall (I Kings 5:13).385 I do not know the identity of the azov. However, logically speaking it is not a very mighty plant for it is the opposite of the cedar mentioned in Scripture.386

[BASIN.] Some say that they slaughtered the paschal lamb in the threshold of the gate,387 and they dipped the hyssop into it and then touched the side-posts with the blood. They say that the word saf (basin) is similar in meaning to the word saf (threshold) in and he measured the threshold (saf) of the gate (Ezek. 40:6)388 and to sippim (thresholds)389 in and the posts of the thresholds moved (Is. 6:4).390 Others say that saf (basin) is similar to sappot (basins) in brought beds, and basins (II Sam. 17:28) and that saf is a vessel over which they slaughtered the paschal lamb.
[UNTIL THE MORNING.] I will yet explain what this means.391

23. AND WILL NOT SUFFER. He will not suffer the destroyer. Yitten (will suffer)392 here is similar in meaning to netatikha (suffered I thee) in Therefore suffered I thee not (Gen. 20:6). Now, the destroyer is under God’s power. If God allows him to come into their homes it is as if He gave him permission to do so.

24. AND YE SHALL OBSERVE THIS THING. Many are of the opinion that the placing of the blood on the lintel and on the two side-posts is an obligation for all generations because this thing393 is connected to394 the taking of the hyssop and dipping it into the lamb’s blood. Furthermore, Scripture afterwards states, for that he passed over the houses of the children of Israel in Egypt (v. 27).395 This interpretation would be correct from a logical point of view were it not for the true tradition which states otherwise.396 The correct interpretation is that this thing397 refers to and kill the passover lamb.398 The meaning of the children’s question is,399 when your children will see their family in a group eating an entire lamb, whose bones one is prohibited to break, with its head, with its legs, and with the inwards thereof, unlike the custom on all other festivals, and from which a gentile, an uncircumcised one, a sojourner, and a hired servant may not eat, they will question you.400

25. AND IT SHALL COME TO PASS. Moses now explains that the slaughter of the paschal lamb is contingent upon dwelling in the Land of Israel. Do not be troubled by the Passover observed by Israelites at Mount Sinai.401 That was a commandment from on high.402 They did not observe another Passover in the desert. At Mount Sinai they were in an inhabited land and were thus able to find unleavened bread. However, when they were in a land that no man passed through403 they only had manna.
26. AND IT SHALL COME TO PASS…WHAT MEAN YE BY THIS SERVICE. The strange ritual that I noted.404

27. THAT YE SHALL SAY: IT IS THE SACRIFICE OF THE LORD’S PASSOVER. The word pesach (passover) is to be rendered pity, as we find, paso’ach ve-himlit (He will pity it and He will rescue it) (Is. 31:5).405 The lamb is termed pesach (passover), as in and kill the passover (pesach) (v. 21), because God had pity on the first-born of Israel because of the blood of the lamb. However, Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that the word pesach is derived from the word pi’se’ach (limp), since a lame person supports himself on his healthy leg.406 The destroyer acted in a similar manner. He exterminated the first-born in the Egyptian home and passed over407 the home of his Hebrew neighbor and did not destroy him. The term posechim (hopping) in How long will you keep hopping between two opinions (I Kings 18:20)408 is similar.
28. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL WENT AND DID SO. They took a lamb on the tenth day of the month. They did as the Lord had commanded Moses and Aaron: This is the ordinance of the passover (v. 43).
29. AND IT CAME TO PASS AT MIDNIGHT. The reference is to the second half of the night.409

[UNTO THE FIRST-BORN OF THE CAPTIVE THAT WAS IN THE DUNGEON.] Yefet says that the captives who grind the millstone in prison during the day are put at night into a pit whose opening is covered with the millstone.410 This is the meaning of behind the mill (Ex. 11:5).411
30. AND PHARAOH ROSE UP. He himself. But the Levites alone shall do the service (Num. 18:23), meaning the Levite himself, is similar.
FOR THERE WAS NOT A HOUSE WHERE THERE WAS NOT ONE DEAD. Scripture speaks of the majority of houses.412

31. AND HE CALLED. Logically speaking Moses and Aaron were not in the land of Rameses with the Israelites on the night of the fifteenth.
