On the contrary, they were in that part of Egypt in which was the royal seat where Pharaoh lived.413 Now Moses and Aaron left the doors of their homes at midnight414 in accordance with God’s dictate.415 After Pharaoh gave the Israelites permission to go and worship God, Moses went with the servants of Pharaoh to Rameses to bring Israel out of Egypt. It is common knowledge in our time that there are six Persian miles416 between ancient Egypt, where Joseph’s treasures are known to be until this very day, and Rameses. Now the Israelites began to leave Egypt in the morning,417 namely, at the break of dawn when the light of the sun is seen in the clouds. There is a full hour and a third between the moment that dawn breaks and sunrise. We find that it can be very dark and still be morning. Thus Scripture states, And she418 lay down at his feet419 till the morning (Ruth 3:14), and then adds, before one could discern another.420 Now some Israelites exited Egypt at the break of dawn when, from the Torah’s standpoint, it is still night until sunrise.421 This group was close to Egypt. Another group who were further from Egypt exited that very day.422 The Israelites constituted a very large congregation.423 It is more than eight Persian miles from one end of Rameses to another.424 Scripture therefore states in one place, the Lord thy God brought thee forth out of Egypt by night425 (Deut. 16:1), and elsewhere reads, This day ye go forth426 (Ex. 13:4). It is further stated, the children of Israel went out with a high hand in the sight of all the Egyptians (Num. 33:3),427 and it is there recorded, while the Egyptians were burying them that the Lord had smitten. Now the Egyptians buried their dead during the day. I have thus explained the meaning of morning.428
[31.] BOTH YE…AS YE HAVE SAID. Our cattle also shall go with us (Ex. 10:26).
32. [AND BLESS ME ALSO.] Pharaoh asked them to bless him and pray for him.429
[ALSO.] Scripture reads also because Pharaoh, as Moses had foretold,430 gave them sacrifices.
33. WERE URGENT. Va-techezak (were urgent) is in the feminine,431 because the state of Egypt includes everything.432
[WE ARE ALL DEAD.] I have explained its meaning in my comments on lest he fall upon us with pestilence (Ex. 5:3).

34. THEIR KNEADING-TROUGHS. Misheret (kneading-trough) is a wooden vessel. Compare, mishartekha (thy kneading-trough) in thy basket and thy kneading-trough (Deut. 28:5). Their asses were laden with garments which they asked of the Egyptians.433

35. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL DID. Each one asked in accordance with his status. Thus we find that only the princes donated precious stones, spices, and oil for the work of the tabernacle (Ex. 35:27, 28).434

36. AND THEY DESPOILED. We do not find the root nun, tzadi, lamed 435 in the kal. We find it only in the hifil and the pi’el. They436 are both transitive verbs because there is no difference in meaning between va-yenatzelu (and they despoiled)437 and va-yatzel (hath taken away)438 in Thus God hath taken away (Gen. 31:9) except that in the hifil the object439 is mentioned and in the pi’el it is omitted.440

37. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL JOURNEYED. The samekh in the word va-yisu (journeyed)441 should have received a dagesh to compensate for the missing nun,442 as the gimel in va-yiggeshu (and drew near)443 (Gen. 44:18) and the tav in va-yittenu (and they gave)444 (Gen. 35:4) do. It is possible that the dagesh was omitted to simplify enunciation.
FROM RAMESES. Rameses is vocalized with a pattach beneath the resh and a sheva beneath the ayin. It is not a city445 but rather the name of a district.446
TO SUCCOTH. Sukkotah means: to Succoth.447
[MEN.] Scripture mentions men. There was no need to mention the women because there were as many women as there were men, maybe even more.448
BESIDE CHILDREN. Taf (children) refers to those under the age of twenty.449
[38.] AND A MIXED MULTITUDE. Of Egyptians who intermingled with them. They are the asafsuf (mixed multitude) who joined them.450
39. AND THEY BAKED. The dough which they brought out of Egypt had leaven in it.451 They did not bake it452 until they camped in Succoth.453

40. NOW THE TIME THAT THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL DWELT IN EGYPT WAS FOUR HUNDRED AND THIRTY YEARS. There are many calculations454 in Scripture whose point of departure is unknown to us. I will now mention a few of them. And it came to pass at the end of forty years, that Absalom said unto the king (II Sam. 15:7). Now Absalom was not then forty years old.455 Furthermore, King David’s reign was not yet over.456 The commentaries tell us that the point of departure for this calculation is from the day that the ark abode in Kiriath-jearim (I Sam. 7:2).

It is stated, Now it came to pass in the thirtieth year (Ezek. 1:1). Some say that Ezekiel was thirty years old when he began to prophesy.457 Others say that the reference is to the thirtieth year of the jubilee.458 Other say that its point of departure is the finding of the Torah which was discovered by Hilkiah the priest.459 However, I am uncertain, for they are opinions without foundation or support.

It is written: And within threescore and five years shall Ephraim460 be broken, that it be not a people (Is. 7:8). The latter prophesy was uttered during the days of Ahaz, whose reign lasted for sixteen years. Samaria was exiled in the sixth year of his son Hezekiah’s reign.461 The commentaries were therefore forced to say that the sixty-five years start from the day that Amos prophesied, And Israel shall surely be led away captive out of his land (Amos 7:11). Others say that its point of departure is the earthquake.462

Now when we investigated the years starting with the time that Israel came to Egypt in the days of Joseph and his brothers we found that they do not come to the number of years spoken of in Scripture.463 There is no doubt that Kehat464 was among those who descended to Egypt.465 Let us imagine that Kehat466 begot his son Amram at the end of his life and that Amram467 similarly begot Moses at the end of his life. Now the years of Kehat and Amram’s lives come to two hundred and seventy. Moses was eighty years old when the Israelites went out of Egypt.468 It all thus comes to three hundred and fifty years. We are missing eighty years. It is for this reason that the elders469 added, “dwelt in Egypt and other countries.”470 The four hundred years in and shall serve them; and they shall afflict them four hundred years (Gen. 15:13) is not connected to and they shall afflict them471 but rather to thy seed shall be a stranger (Ibid.).472 There are many other such instances.473 We similarly find in our own chapter, from the first day until the seventh day (v. 15).474

Now we find it stated that God told Abraham at the covenant made “between the pieces,”475 that thy seed shall be a stranger…four hundred years. We know that the number of years that Israel dwelt in Egypt476 is contingent upon the “end,”477 which was told to Abraham.478 The author of the Seder Olam479 was compelled to say that after Abraham came to the land of Canaan he returned to Haran.480 The commentaries were forced to say that the prophecy I am the Lord that brought thee out of Ur of the Chaldees (Gen. 15:7) is not connected to the above-noted chapter481 but was said later.482 However, there is no need for all of this.483 Only the counting of the four hundred years is from the day that Isaac was born.484 The additional thirty years start from the day that Abraham left Ur of the Chaldees, the land of his nativity, and came with his father to Haran, as it is written, and they came unto Haran, and dwelt there (Gen. 11: 31). Abraham lived in Haran with his father for five years.485 He came to the land of Canaan at the age of seventy-five and never returned to Haran.

Now thirty years passed from the time that Abraham left Haran till the day Isaac was born. Abraham was the important one,486 and to him was the land of the Canaanite given. The verse I am the Lord that brought thee out of Ur of the Chaldees (Gen. 15:7) is connected to the entire chapter preceding487 and following it.488 The meaning of Now the time that the children of Israel dwelt in Egypt is to be explained: they were strangers there, also their fathers were strangers, as it is written, Yea, very few, and sojourners in it (Ps. 105:12); and as Abraham said, I am a stranger and a sojourner with you (Gen. 23:4).
FOUR HUNDRED AND THIRTY YEARS. From the day that their father Abraham left the land of his birth.

41. [AND IT CAME TO PASS AT THE END OF FOUR HUNDRED AND THIRTY YEARS.] Scripture states this so that it be known that they did not exit Egypt because of their cries to God until the time489 that the Lord had decreed for them had come.490

42. IT WAS A NIGHT OF WATCHING UNTO THE LORD. Since Scripture notes, it was a night of watching unto the Lord, and concludes by saying, this same night is a night of watching unto the Lord for all the children of Israel throughout their generations, the plain meaning of our verse appears to be: since God watched them and did not suffer the destroyer to come into their homes to plague them,491 the Lord commanded that this night be a night of watching492for all the children of Israel throughout their generations through the eating of the paschal lamb according to its ordinance and the ingesting of unleavened bread and bitter herbs on this night. Others say that watching here has the same meaning as the word watching in The watchers of the walls (Cant. 5:7); its meaning is that they should not sleep on this night but should praise God and relate the might that the Lord displayed when they went out of Egypt.493 Our sages hinted at the latter meaning when they said, The time for the reading of the morning shema has arrived.494

43. AND THE LORD SAID…THIS IS THE ORDINANCE OF THE PASSOVER. Since Scripture mentioned that it was a night of watching (v. 42), the reference being to the night of the fifteenth wherein the paschal lamb is to be eaten, the Torah completes its explanation of the laws of the Passover495 that is to be observed in future generations. Now Scripture does not mention the lintel and the side-post. Neither does it mention that the lamb is to be eaten with unleavened bread and bitter herbs,496 as they were previously mentioned with regard to the Passover observed in Egypt. Its meaning497 thus is: you shall eat the Passover offering in the future as you ate it in Egypt. Scripture then added other commandments.498 However, the commandments with regard to the lintel and the side-post have nothing to do with the eating of the paschal lamb.499 Do you not see that at the beginning of the chapter (i.e., v. 43) it states, there shall no alien eat thereof (bo)?500 The meaning of bo (thereof) is, of it.501 Its usage in this context is correct in Hebrew502 and also in Arabic.503 Ve-hanotar ba-basar u-va-lechem (and that which remaineth of the flesh and of the bread) (Lev. 8:32) is similar.504

44. BUT EVERY MAN’S SERVANT…WHEN THOU HAST CIRCUMCISED HIM. According to his wish, that he be converted to the law of Israel, if he is of the age when one is obligated to observe the commandments.505 The law dealing with someone that is bought for money and someone born in the house is the same.506 However, Scripture deals with that which is more prevalent.507
45. A SOJOURNER AND A HIRED SERVANT. Who are Israelites508 shall not eat of the paschal lamb if a portion of the lamb has not been assigned to them, as is the law for the entire congregation.

46. IN ONE HOUSE SHALL IT BE EATEN. As the paschal lamb eaten in Egypt was. Thou shalt not carry forth aught of the flesh abroad out of the house is proof of this.509 However, our sages of blessed memory said that in one house means in one company.510 The latter is the correct interpretation.

47. ALL THE CONGREGATION OF ISRAEL SHALL KEEP IT. All those of the age when one is obligated to observe the commandments are required to prepare a paschal lamb. When I researched the Torah, I found that the twenty-three times where karet (excision) is stated511 refer to negative precepts. However, I found only two dealing with positive precepts, namely, the paschal lamb512 and circumcision.513 Perhaps the reason for this is that there is an obligation to “remember” the Exodus from Egypt, and there is no greater manifestation of “remembering” than eating the paschal lamb in its proper time. And the beginning of the decalogue states, I am the Lord thy God, who brought thee out of the land of Egypt (Ex. 20:2).514
48. AND WHEN A STRANGER SHALL SOJOURN WITH THEE. The meaning of with thee is, with thee in the land of Egypt.515
[AND WILL KEEP THE PASSOVER.] Its meaning is, and he wants to keep the Passover. Then let him first be circumcised.
[BUT NO UNCIRCUMCISED PERSON SHALL EAT THERE-OF.] The reference is to uncircumcised Israelites516 such as those born on the way in the wilderness.517
49. ONE LAW. The stranger spoken of in this verse refers to a righteous proselyte, not to a stranger that dwells within the gates.518

50. [THUS DID ALL THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] Scripture has already mentioned this above.519 Perhaps the reason it is noted again is that it refers to the Passover offering brought in the wilderness of Sinai,520 at which time the strangers were circumcised.521 Do not be surprised that this is written in this place.522 Scripture states in the chapter dealing with the coming down of the manna that they should take a jar and put manna therein and place it before the Lord (Ex. 16:33). However, God had not yet commanded the making of the ark of the testimony.523 Have I brought your hosts out of the land of Egypt (v. 17) is similar.524

51. AND IT CAME TO PASS THE SELFSAME DAY. I believe that this verse is connected to the verse which follows,525 in which God told Moses to sanctify the first-born. The plague of the first-born took place at midnight, and when Israel went out of Egypt the next day God immediately commanded that the first-born of Israel and the first-born of their cattle be sanctified.526
chapter.ftnote: 1 Prophets who revealed commandments to Israel. See I.E. on Gen. 27: 13.
2 Who was commanded by an angel of God to build an altar and offer a burnt offering upon it. Cf. Jud. 6:26.
3 Who built an altar on Mount Carmel. See I Kings 18:31-38. I.E. assumes that Elijah was commanded by God to do so.
4 See I Chron. 6:16.
5 Do not assume that it was instituted by divine command.

6 Of their own accord. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, “established by David and Samuel.” This reading has the support of I Chron. 9:22. Indeed, Filwarg emends Solomon to Samuel. If we do not emend the text then we must interpret I.E. to mean that David established the practice of singing psalms in the house of God and Solomon reaffirmed it when he built the Temple. Cf. Weiser.
7 In other words, David did not institute the temple service on his own accord.
8 The prohibition against carrying a burden on the Sabbath was not instituted by Jeremiah; it was handed down from Moses.
