292 With the active or passive participle form. However, it is in bashel mevushal, as mevushal is a pu’al participle. Hence the term bashel in bashel mevushal cannot be an infinitive.
293 It is an adjective as kaved is.
294 See note 279.
295 Ibn Ezra.
296 Above.

297 Literally, the one is. If we do not interpret it to mean: one of which is, then along with Weiser we must assume that of one of the steps in the copyist’s description of the two-stage cooking process was lost.

298 The copyist comments thus because earlier he compared the plural form of bashel mevushal to the plural form of chakham mechukkam. Chakham means a wise man. Mechukkam means one who has been made wise (taught) by others. See I.E. on Prov. 30:24, “Mechukkamim: God gave them the wisdom to do this.”
299 I.E. in his opening comment on this verse.
300 Which means boiled (cooked).
301 Which means was cooked (boiled). Hence bashel, mevushal ba-mayim, boiled, boiled in water. The difference between bashel and mevushal is explained by I.E. in his opening comment on this verse.
302 Not on, its usual meaning. Hence rosho al kera’av ve’al kirbo means: its head with its legs and with the inwards thereof, not its head on its legs and on the inwards thereof.
303 Before roasting, although not stated here.
304 See Pesachim 74a.
305 When people eat some meat and not only bones remain uneaten.
306 The reference is unclear. Some identify it with a place in Algeria (Weiser).
307 They did not leave on foot, as they were setting out on a long journey. Hence the staffs in their hands were not for walking.
308 Balaam was then riding an ass. Thus the staff in his hand was not a walking stick but rather a rod with which to guide the ass.
309 Eating the paschal lamb.
310 When God would destroy the first-born of Egypt.
311 In other words, so that they could begin their departure from the land of Egypt immediately after being freed. They could not have done this if they had been busy eating the paschal lamb.
312 The rabbis of the Talmud.
313 Zevachim 56a.
314 In other words, I will go through the land is not to be taken literally. It means My might and power will go through the land.
315 Blood.
316 Literally, on or concerning the destroyer.
317 That is, the offering of the paschal lamb.
318 And they shall eat the flesh in that night, roast with fire, and unleavened bread; with bitter herbs…(v. 8).
319 Throughout the generations.
320 In the description of the Exodus.
321 They therefore had no time to bake leavened bread.
322 Which is to be eaten in all generations.
323 Contra the Talmudic opinion that the obligation to eat unleavened bread is limited to the first night of Passover. See Pesachim 120a. Also see Rashi on this verse.
324 Just as remembering the Exodus all the days is an obligation, so is eating matzot for seven days an obligation, since both are written in one verse.
325 It is because Scripture connected the obligation to eat unleavened bread with the paschal lamb, which is only offered in the Land of Israel.
326 Abstaining from leavened bread and eating unleavened bread.

327 Pesachim 5a. It is a general principle in Talmudic exegesis that ach and rak imply limitations. Thus ach divides the day, indicating that the putting away of the leaven is to take place in the middle of the day. According to the rabbis, ach ba-yom ha-rishon tashbitu se’or mi-batekhem (howbeit the first day ye shall put away leaven out of your houses) is to be rendered: At the middle of the day which is before the festival of unleavened bread ye shall put away leaven out of your houses.
328 See I.E. on Gen. 2:2.
329 Howbeit on the first day, etc.
330 Mentioned in the opening of our verse.
331 The 15th of Nisan.

332 In Lev. 23 and Num. 28 and 29 Scripture prohibits one from “working” on the festivals. The formula used is kol melekhet avodah lo ta’asu (ye shall do no manner of servile work). See Lev. 23:8, 21, 25, 35; 36. Also see Num. 28:18, 26, 29:1, 12, 35.
333 Wherein Scripture employs the term lo ta’aseh kol melakhah (ye shall do no manner of work). See Ex. 20:10; Lev. 23:3, 28. Also see Num. 29:7.
334 Kol melakhah.
335 Only in our verse and nowhere else is Passover mentioned.
336 To be done.
339 Rosh Ha-Shanah. See Lev. 23.25; Num. 29:1.

341 Scripture employs the term kol melekhet avodah (no manner of servile work) and not kol melakhah (no manner of work) with regard to the festivals. Our text follows Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed editions read, kol melakhah. This is obviously a scribal error.

342 Cf. Lev. 23:3. So Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed text read: No work shall be done. It is I.E.’s contention that ye shall do no manner of servile work is short for: ye shall do no manner of work save that which every man may eat, as okhel nefesh (that which every man must eat) is not considered melekhet avodah (servile work).
343 In our verse.
344 That is, if it is not for the purpose of preparing that which may be eaten.
345 That is, the grain that the matzah is made of.
346 Lest the grain be mixed with water and leaven.
347 See verse 1. Hence they had not yet left Egypt.
348 Scripture employs the perfect form because in the future people will speak of the past and say, on this selfsame day the Lord brought our hosts out of the land of Egypt.
349 Translated literally.
350 In the tenth is short for: in the tenth month.
351 I.E. could find no Hebrew synonym for se’or.

352 In other words, machmetzet refers to anything which is leavened. Scripture first prohibits keeping anything which induces leavening (se’or) in one’s home on Passover. It then prohibits eating on Passover anything which is leavened.

353 The second part of verse 15 literally reads: For whosoever eateth leavened bread that soul shall be cut off from Israel from the first day to the seventh day. I.E. argues that we should not read the verse in this manner; that is, from the first day, etc., does not follow shall be cut off.

354 I.E. explains that we are to connect For whosoever eateth leavened bread to from the first day, etc., and read verse 15 as if written: For whosoever eateth leavened bread from the first day until the seventh day, that soul shall be cut off from Israel.
355 Literally, to the eating of that which is leavened. There is either an error in the text (Weiser, Filwarg) or, more likely, I.E. paraphrased.
356 See I.E. on verse 2 and note 58.
357 In other words, the vav (and) placed in front of vareket also governs pitdah.

358 The heh placed before ha-rishon also governs the word yom that precedes it. So too the heh placed before ha-shevi’i governs the word yom that precedes it. The verse is thus to be understood as if written: me-ha-yom ha-rishon ad ha-yom ha-shevi’i. Yefet comments thus for it is Hebrew style to place a heh in front of the noun when there is one in front of the adjective. Compare, ha-har ha-tov (that goodly hill country) (Deut. 3:25) (Filwarg). See also Vol. 1, p. 47, note 168.
359 In verse 15.
360 Hence it is not being redundant in repeating the prohibition of eating leaven on Passover and the punishment for doing so.
361 For eating leaven on Passover in verse 19.
362 Not to do so in verse 20.
363 The Exodus.
364 Verse 3.
365 Jonah ibn Janach in his Sefer Ha-Shorashim.(Weiser).
366 A pi’el imperative. Compare, dabberu, hallelu
367 And so too in our verse.
368 Shachatu in verse 6.

369 That is because a kamatz (a silent missing letter) is always placed beneath the first letter in the kal perfect. I.E. refers to the kamatz as a silent missing letter because the kamatz vowel implies an alef. See I.E. on Ex. 2:4 and the notes thereto.
370 Hence shachatu in our verse cannot be a pi’el.
371 In our verse.
372 Because it is an imperative.
373 Kal plural imperatives are vocalized with a chirik beneath their first letters.
374 A chet.
375 Which is vocalized bachaeru, not bicharu because a guttural, a chet, follows the bet.
376 Compare, nahagu, sha’alu.
377 In shachatu.
378 Ve-shachatu (vocalized with a kamatz beneath the shin) in verse 6 and ve-shachatu (vocalized with a pattach beneath the shin) in our verse.
379 They are both in the kal. However, shachatu in verse 6 is a perfect and shachatu in our verse is in the imperative.
380 In verse 7 they were told to take the blood and place it on the lintel. Moses now explains the details of the ritual. Hence verse 22 is not redundant.
381 Or superfluous. It is not a root letter and has no meaning, as the word could read gudah and mean the same.
382 Gen. 49:19. Its root is gimel, dalet, dalet. Hence the alef is appended.
383 Its root being alef, gimel, dalet.
384 From the root alef, peh, dalet. Afuddato minus the pronominal suffix is afuddah. Thus aguddah follows the paradigm of afuddah.
385 The oregano plant does not grow out of walls.
386 I Kings 5:13 reads: And he spoke of trees, from the cedar that is in Lebanon even unto the hyssop that springeth out of the wall.
387 In a trench cut in the threshold (Krinsky). In other words, saf (basin) means a threshold.
388 New J.P.S. translation.
389 Sippim is the plural of saf.
390 Translated according to I.E.
391 See I.E.’s comments on verse 31.
392 The word yitten literally means, will give. At times it has the meaning of will give permission. Rashi similarly interprets, “He will not give him the power to come” into your homes.
393 That is, And ye shall observe this thing for an ordinance to thee and to thy sons for ever.
394 It immediately follows.

395 This is to be offered in response to the question, “What mean ye by this service? which will be asked by children in future generations (v. 26). Prima facie, the question pertains to the placing of the blood on the lintels and on the side-posts.
396 That the placing of the blood on the side-posts and lintels was only to be done in Egypt.
397 What mean ye by this service? See note 395.
398 In verse 21, and not to the taking of the hyssop and dipping it into the lamb’s blood.
399 Verse 26.
400 In other words, the children’s question does not pertain to the smearing of the blood on the lintel and side-posts but to the manner in which the Passover sacrifice is eaten.
401 Which was celebrated outside the boundaries of the Land of Israel. See Num. 9:1-5.
402 To observe that particular Passover outside of Israel (Num. 9:5). Otherwise Israel would not have offered the paschal sacrifice.

403 Jeremiah’s description of the wilderness in which Israel journeyed on the way to the promised land (Jer. 2:6). I.E. borrows Jeremiah’s description because he wants to emphasize that Israel had no one to buy wheat from to bake matzot. Hence the only Passover they could have celebrated was the one at Sinai.
404 See I.E.’s final comments on verse 24.
405 Translated according to I.E.
406 And hops or skips along. Hence a lame person is called a pise’ach, a hopper or skipper.
407 Or hopped or skipped over.
408 So J.P.S. new translation.
409 See I.E. on Ex. 11:4. This comment is not found in Vat. Ebr. 38.
410 That they ground with during the day. The literal meaning of bor (dungeon) is pit. Hence Yefet’s interpretation.
411 There is thus no contradiction between our verse and Ex. 11:5.
412 For there must have been many houses in which there was no first-born male (Weiser).
413 Awaiting Pharaoh’s permission to leave Egypt. Nahmanides interprets similarly.
414 Pharaoh called for them after the first-born had been slain.

415 Otherwise they would not have been permitted to leave their homes. See verse 22. Hence I. E. assumes that God told Moses and Aaron to leave their dwellings in response to Pharaoh’s call. I.E.’s interpretation is contra the Mekhilta, which pictures Moses and Aaron as staying in their homes until the morning and Pharaoh going around the land of Egypt asking, “Where does Moses dwell? Where does Aaron dwell?” According to the Mekhilta, when Pharaoh found Moses and Aaron he said to them, “Rise up, get you forth,” etc. Moses responded, “We are warned not to go out except in broad daylight as it is written, And none of you shall go out of the door of his house until the morning” (v. 22).
416 A Persian mile is, 8000 cubits, or approximately 2 1/2 miles.
417 They were not allowed to leave their homes till this time (v. 22).
418 Ruth.
419 Boaz’s feet.
420 We thus see that when morning begins people still cannot recognize each other because it is yet dark.
421 According to I.E. when the Torah speaks of day it means after sunrise.
422 That is, after sunrise.
423 That is why it took so long for all of them to leave.
424 Those Israelites who lived in that part of Rameses that was close to Egypt left at dawn and the others after sunrise.
425 The reference is to those who left at the break of dawn.
426 The reference is to those who left after sunrise.
427 This too refers to those who left after sunrise.
428 As he promised to do at the end of verse 22. I.E. literally reads, I have already explained.
429 So too Mekhilta, Onkelos, Rashi, and Nahmanides.
430 See Ex. 10:25. The meaning of our verse is: take your flocks and go but also pray for me over the sacrifices which I now give you.
431 However, mitzrayim (Egypt) is a masculine form. Scripture thus should have read, va-yechezak.
432 Mitzrayim is short for medinat mitzrayim (the state of Egypt). Medinah is feminine, hence the reading va-techezak (Krinsky).
433 Hence they had to carry their kneading-troughs on their shoulders.
434 The other Israelites did not have these precious items. They did not ask the Egyptians for these items because their status did not allow them to do so.
435 Which is the root of va-yenatzelu (and they despoiled). I.E. literally reads: we do not find the root of hatzalah in the kal.
436 Verbs formed from this root in the kal and the hifil.
437 A pi’el.
438 A hifil from the root nun, tzadi, lamed.
439 Which is being taken way is mentioned, as in Thus God has taken away (va-yatzel) the cattle.
440 As in our verse. Scripture states, And they despoiled (va-yenatzelu) the Egyptians. However, it does not say what they took.
441 From the root nun, samekh, ayin.
442 There is no nun in va-yisu. A missing first root letter is compensated for by placing a dagesh in the second stem letter.
443 From the root nun, gimel, shin. In va-yiggeshu the nun drops out and is compensated for by a dagesh in the gimel.
444 From the root nun, tav, nun.
445 That is the city of Raamses (Ex. 1:12) which the Israelites built. Both words have the same consonants. However, they differ in vocalization. See I.E. on Ex. 1:11 and Gen. 47:11.
446 That is, the name of the district where Israel dwelt. See I.E. on Ex. 1:11.
447 The heh at the end of the word is like a lamed at the beginning of a word; i.e., it means to.
448 Since some of the men had more than one wife.
449 As clearly implied in Num. 14:29, 31.
450 See Num. 11:4. I.E.’s point is that the asafsuf mentioned in Numbers is to be identified with the mixed multitude mentioned in our verse.

451 Scriptures implies that the bread did not leaven because there was no time for it to do so. The implication is that if there had been time for it to rise it would have done so. Hence we may assume that it had leaven (yeast) in it.
452 The matzot.
453 Their first stop after leaving Rameses (v. 37).
454 Of years.

455 David reigned for 40 years (I Kings 2:11). Absalom was born after David was crowned king in Hebron (II Sam. 3:2) and predeceased David (II Sam. 18:14). Thus Absalom’s entire life span was less than 40 years. Hence the number 40 cannot apply to the years that passed from Absalom’s birth.
456 David reigned for 40 years. However, since his reign was not yet over, the number 40 cannot apply to it.
457 In other words, the thirtieth year refers to the thirtieth year of Ezekiel’s life.
458 So Rashi and Kimchi.
459 See II Kings 22. This is the opinion of Seder Olam 26 and Targum Jonathan.
460 Another name for the kingdom of Samaria.

461 Thus at most 22 years could have passed between Isaiah’s prophecy and the exile of Ephraim/Samaria. What then did Isaiah mean by saying that at the end of 65 years Ephraim shall cease to be a people?
462 See Amos 1:1.
463 430 years.
464 Son of Levi.
465 Scripture explicitly says so. See Gen. 46:11.
466 Who lived 133 years. See Ex. 6:18.
467 Who lived 137 years. See Ex. 6:20.
469 The 70 elders who translated the Torah into Greek.
470 See Megillah 9a.
471 Israel was not enslaved for 400 years.
472 The verse should be understood as follows: Thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs for four hundred years, part of which time they shall serve them and afflict them.
473 When a clause is not connected to what immediately precedes it.
474 Which is not connected to what immediately precedes it. See I.E. on verse 19 and notes 353 and 354.
475 Hebrew, brit ben ha-betarim. See Gen. 15.
476 Mentioned in our verse.
477 The end of 400 years of being strangers.
479 Rabbi Jose bar Chalafta, a second-century Tanna.

480 In order to reconcile the number 430 given in our verse with the number 400 given in Genesis Seder Olam explains that the number 430 refers to the time that passed from the “covenant between the pieces” (Gen. 15), and the number 400 refers to the time from the birth of Isaac. The accounting is as follows: Abraham was 70 years old when God made the “covenant between the pieces” with him and told him that his children would be strangers for 400 years (Gen. 15:13). Abraham then went to Haran and spent five years there, as it is written, And Abraham was seventy and five years old when he departed out of Haran (Gen. 12:4). Now Isaac was born when Abraham was 100 years old (Gen. 21:5). Abraham thus lived in Canaan for 30 years without a son. Exodus, as noted above, starts the count from the “covenant between the pieces.” Genesis starts the count with the birth of Isaac 30 years later. However, it must be pointed out that the Seder Olam’s accounting is based on a number of assumptions: a) That the covenant between the pieces occurred when Abraham was 70 years old. Scripture nowhere says so. b) That Abraham returned to Haran. Scripture does not say this either. Hence I.E. did not want to accept the Seder Olam’s calculations. The question thus remains how to reconcile the number of years mentioned in Exodus with those given in Genesis.
481 Chapter 15, the “covenant between the pieces,” as Abraham was yet to leave the land.
482 After he returned to Canaan and permanently settled there. This too is not in keeping with the plain meaning of the text and is an argument against the Seder Olam.

483 a) To assume in contradiction to Gen. 15:5 that Abraham was 70 at the “covenant between the pieces”; b) to assume that Abraham returned to Haran; c) to assume that Gen. 15:7 is out of place and was not said at the “covenant between the pieces.”
484 As explained by the Seder Olam, for Scripture speaks there of thy seed.

485 If the 430 years start from the day that Abraham left Ur then Abraham had to be 70 years old when he left that city, for Isaac was born when Abraham was 100 years old and Israel was liberated 400 years later (see note 480). Now Scripture tells us that Abraham left Haran when he was 75 (Gen. 12:4). Therefore he spent five years in Haran. In his commentary on Genesis, I.E. implies that we cannot ascertain how many years Abraham spent in Haran. See I.E. on Gen. 12:1 and the notes thereto.
486 Hence the calculations in our verse begin with him.
487 Literally, above.
488 Literally, below. In other words, the words in the verse were said to Abraham at the “covenant of the pieces.”
489 430 years starting from the day that Abraham left Ur Chasdim.

490 Their crying reminded God that the period He ordained for their being strangers was over. Had they not cried out unto the Lord, the period of their servitude would not have ended, because according to the arrangement of the stars they were destined to remain in servitude for a much longer time. See I.E. on Ex. 2:23, 24 and 33:21 (Weiser).
491 I.E.’s paraphrase of It was a night of watching unto the Lord.

492 That is, observance. The Hebrew shamar means both watch and observe. Since God watched (shamar) Israel on this night, Israel must observe (li-shemor) God’s special laws this night. Hence lel shimurim (a night of watching) means a night of observance.
493 According to this interpretation lel shimurim means a watch night.
494 This implies that the sages stayed up all night on the night of the seder. See Passover Haggadah. Also see Tosefta Pesachim 10.
495 In verses 43-50.
496 In verses 43-50.
497 The meaning of This is the ordinance of the passover.
498 The purpose of this chapter was to give additional rules concerning the Passover.
499 Hence unlike the eating of unleavened bread and bitter herbs it does not have to be observed in future Passovers.
500 Which is a law not previously mentioned. We thus see that the purpose of this chapter was to give additional rules concerning the Passover.
501 The word bo usually means in him or in it.
502 It is proper Hebrew to say, lo yokhal bo (he shall not eat of it), although from a very literal point of view it means he shall not eat in it.
503 A similar term is used in Arabic.
504 Here too the bet means “of.” Ba-basar literally means in the meat and ba-lechem in the bread. However, in Lev. 8:32 ba-basar u-va-lechem are to be rendered of the flesh and of the bread.
505 The age of thirteen.
506 The two are usually coupled together. See Gen. 17:12, 13; Lev. 22:11.
507 Hence only someone that is bought for money is mentioned here
508 Contra the rabbis who interpreted the verse as applying to non-Jews. Cf. Mekhilta 15, Rashi, and Nahmanides.
509 Carry forth aught implies that house is to be taken literally (Krinsky).
510 See Mekhilta 15, Onkelos, and Rashi.
511 It should be noted that according to the Mishnah in Kritot 1:1, the Torah prescribes excision for 36 transgressions. The discrepancy is explained by Krinsky.
512 The question thus arises, why is such a harsh penalty inflicted upon one who violates the positive commandment of offering a paschal lamb?
514 Hence remembering the Exodus is a very important commandment, and by not offering the paschal lamb one is in effect denying the Exodus.
515 As a mixed multitude joined Israel.
516 Not to sinners.
517 Who because of the danger involved could not be circumcised. See Josh. 5:5, 7.

518 And does not accept Judaism. Such a stranger who is uncircumcised cannot eat of the paschal lamb, and the statement in verse 49 (one law, etc.) which deals with the eating of the Passover offering cannot apply to him.
519 Verse 28.

521 In other words, thus did all the children of Israel does not repeat what is stated in verse 28, but refers to the circumcision of the strangers (gerim). It was a convenient place to circumcise those strangers who were not circumcised in Egypt.
522 When it happened a year later.
523 Recorded in Ex. 25:10-14. Thus Ex. 16:33 is chronologically out of place.
524 It is chronologically out of place because when this was said Israel was still in Egypt. See I.E. on verse 17.

526 Ex. 12:51 and what comes next should be understood as follows: And it came to pass the selfsame day that the Lord did bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their hosts, that the Lord spoke unto Moses saying: Sanctify unto Me all the first-born, etc.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 13
chapter.p: 1. AND THE LORD SPOKE. Scripture employs a short form,1 for Moses stands in place of Israel.2 However, Yefet says that Moses was commanded to verbally sanctify all first-born.3 The aforementioned is the reverse of then the priest shall defile him (Lev. 13:8);4 the priest, being holy, defiles an individual by declaration.5

2. OPENETH. Peter (openeth) means the opening of. Peter is similar to peture (open) in and open flowers (I Kings 6:18). Its meaning is, the son who first opens the womb.6 The word rechem (womb) is irregular, as according to the rules of Hebrew grammar the letter preceding a guttural is vocalized with a pattach.7
3. AND MOSES SAID. Remember this day was said by Moses on the fifteenth day.8 It means the same as And this day shall be unto you for a memorial (Ex. 12:14).

[OUT OF THE HOUSE OF BONDAGE.] This indicates that the Egyptians forced them to work as if they were their slaves.9 Elsewhere Scripture reads, out of the iron furnace (Deut. 4:20), for the Egyptians overpowered them.10 However, the Lord brought them out by strength of hand from the mighty.

4. THIS DAY. Moses first mentions, there shall be no leavened bread eaten, its meaning being, do in future generations what you did on the day that you left Egypt.11 As you left Egypt at the time when the first ears (aviv) are found,12 so shall you do yearly in the future in the Land of Israel when the first ears come. The first ears refers to the first ears of barley. The word aviv (Abib) means the first that ripens.13 Aviv comes from the same root as av (father), which means first to the one whom one begets, or sage14 to the student whom one teaches.15 Furthermore, it is written, for the barley was in the ear (aviv) (Ex. 9:31).16 Even of the first-fruits (bikkure) of wheat harvest (Ex. 34:22),17 which is written with regard to the festival of weeks,18 is proof of the above.19
5. AND IT SHALL BE. Scripture does not list all of the seven Canaanite nations because they have already been mentioned elsewhere.20
6. THE SEVEN DAYS. This is the service.21

7. UNLEAVENED BREAD. Now the stranger that is within the gate was exhorted by God to observe the Sabbath,22 as it is only on the condition that he do no work before the Lord on the Sabbath that he may dwell within the gates. Similarly on the Day of Atonement, for it is so written.23 The same applies to Passover, as a stranger is not permitted to eat leaven even on his own property. This is the meaning of in all thy borders.

8. IT IS BECAUSE OF THAT. Rabbi Merinus says that ba’avur zeh (it is because of that) should have been written, zeh ba’avur; i.e., this is because of what the Lord did for me.24 He cited what in his opinion are many other such instances.25 However, I do not think that he was right in even one instance. For how can we invert the words of the living God? The meaning of the verse is just the opposite of what he understands it to be, because we do not eat unleavened bread “because of this.”26 Its meaning rather is: it is because of this, i.e., it is because of this service, namely, the eating of unleavened bread and the abstention from leavened bread, which are the first of the precepts that God commanded us, that the Lord did signs for us and brought us out of Egypt.27 Its meaning thus is: God took us out of Egypt only to serve Him, as it is written, when thou hast brought forth the people out of Egypt, ye shall serve God upon this mountain (Ex. 20:12). It is furthermore stated, I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, to be your God:28 I am the Lord your God (Num. 15:41).

9. AND IT SHALL BE A SIGN UNTO THEE. There are those who oppose our holy patriarchs29 and say30 that for a sign…and for a memorial is to be understood in the manner of For they shall be a chaplet of grace unto thy head, And chains about thy head (Prov. 1:9).31 They also say that And thou shalt bind them for a sign upon thy hand (Deut. 5:8) is like Bind them continually upon thy heart, Tie them upon thy neck (Prov. 6:21)32 and also that And thou shalt write them upon the door-posts of thy house (Deut. 6:9) is like Write them upon the table of thy heart (Prov. 3:3). They furthermore say that it shall be for a sign…and for a memorial means for with a strong hand hath the Lord brought thee out of Egypt shall drop from your lips.33 However, this is incorrect, for at the beginning of the book of Proverbs it is stated, The Proverbs of Solomon. Thus whatever Solomon henceforth mentions is by way of parable. However, it is not, heaven forbid, written in the Torah that it is metaphoric. Hence it is to be taken only at face value. We thus will not interpret it except literally. It does not contradict reason if explained according to its plain meaning, like Circumcise therefore the foreskin of your heart (Deut. 10:16), which has to be interpreted according to the requirements of reason.34

[UPON THY HAND.] Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that the term yad (hand) in most of Scripture refers to the left hand,35 as in Yea, My hand (yadi) hath laid the foundation of the earth, And My right hand hath spread out the heavens (Is. 48:13); and Her hand (yadah) she put to the tent-pin, And her right hand to the workmen’s hammer (Jud. 5:26). However, the teachings of tradition are firmly established and do not require any support.36

10. FROM YEAR TO YEAR. Mi-yamim yamimah (from year to year) is similar to yamim tiheyeh ge’ullato (for a full year shall he have the right of redemption (Lev. 25:29). The meaning of mi-yamim yamimah is, from year to year. The year begins when the Bet Din announces its commencement.37
11. AND IT SHALL BE. Moses mentions only the Canaanite, because he was the father of them all.38
[AS HE SWORE UNTO THEE.] Its meaning is similar to for unto thee, and unto thy seed, I will give this land (Gen. 26:3).39
12. THAT THOU SHALT SET APART. Thou shalt set it apart unto the Lord so that it does not get mixed up with another.
Now these two precepts40 were commanded on the fifteenth day.

COMING OF. Sheger41 (coming of) follows the paradigm of eretz (land of) whose vocalization does not change in the construct. However, a number of irregular cases42 are found. They are: shegar (the increase of)43 in the increase of thy kine (Deut. 7:13), chadar (chamber of)44 in and in the chamber of thy bed (Ex. 7:28), havel (vanity of)45 in Vanity of vanities (Eccles. 1:1), hamatekha (thy venom)46 in That puttest thy venom thereto (Hab. 2:15), and delatekha (thy doors)47 in and shut the doors (Is. 26:20). I have not found any additional instances.
13. AND EVERY FIRSTLING OF AN ASS. Which is unclean, thou shalt redeem with a lamb.

THOU SHALT BREAK ITS NECK. Some say that va-arafto (thou shalt break its neck) means thou shalt write the word holy on its neck.48 However, I say that anyone who says this is himself a stiff-necked ass. For behold it is written, He will break down (ya’arof) their altars (Hos. 10:2),49 and ve-arefu sham et ha-eglah ba-nachal (and shall break the heifer’s neck there in the valley) (Deut. 21:4), in which the meaning of ve-arefu is, as explained by the transmitters of the law, to cut off the neck.50 All firstlings that are not brought up on the altar or are not redeemed are required to be killed, as all the first-born of Egypt both man and beast perished. God did not save them51 from the decree which he had issued on the first-born of the Egyptians except that they should be prepared for His service.
The Israelites had no unclean animals except for asses. Therefore no other52 first-born53 is to be redeemed.
14. AND IT SHALL BE. Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi of blessed memory says that the word machar (in time to come)54 is missing an alef, its meaning being that which comes after today.55

15. AND IT CAME TO PASS. Moses begins by saying, By strength of hand the Lord brought us out from Egypt (v. 14) and backtracks and explains that what the strength of hand refers to is the plague of the first-born. It was because of this plague, and not because of the first plagues, that Israel went out of Egypt. The poet similarly says, To Him that smote Egypt in their first-born, For His mercy endureth for ever (Ps. 136:10).56 Moses wrote elliptically. When Moses said, that the Lord slew all the first-born in the land of Egypt, both the first-born of man, and the first-born of beasts, it was known57 that God saved our first-born and the first-born of our cattle. It is to the latter,58 not to the slaying of the first-born, that therefore I sacrifice to the Lord all that openeth the womb is connected.
ALL THAT OPENETH THE WOMB, BEING MALES. From a kind fit to be sacrificed to the Lord.59

16. AND IT SHALL BE FOR A SIGN. Scripture mentions, And it shall be for a sign upon thy hand with regard to two commandments.60 That which the sages of blessed memory transmitted, namely, that the chapters61 are to be written,62 is true.

AND FOR FRONTLETS. Totafot (frontlets) means a memorial.63 Others say64 that the tet of totafot65 is doubled,66 its meaning being to speak. They say that it comes from the same root as ve-hettef (and preach) in and preach toward the south (Ezek. 21:2). However, in my opinion this is far-fetched.67
Can a fool who rebels against his maker succeed?
When at peace his liver an arrow shall split.
Note and take heed, O recusant;
All that the portion Be-Shallach records concerning Pharaoh.
17. AND IT CAME TO PASS WHEN PHARAOH HAD LET THE PEOPLE GO. The vav in ve-lo nacham (led them not) is like an unaspirated fa in the Arabic tongue.68

It is known that the distance between Egypt and Jerusalem by way of the land of the Philistines is not very great. It is about a ten-day journey by straight road. If this was not so, how did the tribes69 come as far as Egypt upon their asses?70 If the distance was very great how much would have been necessary for them and their asses to eat?71 Furthermore, upon returning they brought back food for their households.72

ALTHOUGH THAT WAS NEAR. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that ki karov hu means although that was near.73 In my opinion, ki am keshe oref hu (for it is a stiff-necked people) (Ex. 34:9); refa’ah nafshi ki chatati lakh (Heal my soul; for I have sinned against Thee) (Ps. 41:5); and ki rekhev barzel lo (though they have chariots of iron) (Josh. 17:18) are similar.74 However, I see no need for this interpretation,75 for its meaning is: the reason God did not lead them by way of the land of the Philistines was that it was close.76 God thus led them via a distant way so that they would not witness any war and say, Let us make a captain, and let us return to Egypt (Num. 14:4).

[LEST PERADVENTURE.] We know for certain that the Lord knows the future.77 God knew that the people would repent if He led them by the way of the land of the Philistines. Scripture reads, Lest peradventure the people repent because the Torah employed human terminology so that those who study78 will understand.79

18. LED THE PEOPLE ABOUT. Va-yassev (led about)80 is a verb81 that comes from a double root. Its stem is samekh, bet, bet. Va-yassev also has an alternative vocalization.82 Compare, va-yasekh (shut up) in Or who shut up (Job 38:8)83 and va-yagel (and rolled) in and rolled the stone (Gen. 29:10).84 Pay no heed to those who say that the root of va- yassev is nun, samekh, bet.

[THE WILDERNESS.] The word ha-midbar (the wilderness) is to be read as if written twice.85 The clause is to be understood as if written, by the way of the wilderness, wilderness of the Red Sea. Similarly, ha-aron ha-bebrit (the ark of the covenant) (Josh. 3:14) is to be understood as if written, the ark, ark of the covenant,86 and, ve-etz ha-da’at tov va-ra (the tree of the knowledge of good and evil) (Gen. 2:9) as if written, and the tree of the knowledge, knowledge of good and evil.87 Likewise the terms ha-sefer ha-miknah (the deed of the purchase)88 (Jer. 32:12) and ha-yayin ha-chemah (the wine of fury) (Jer. 25:15).89 There are many other similar instances.

RED SEA. Suf (Red) is the name of a place. Others say that suf comes from the same root as sof (the end)90 in The end of the matter (Eccles. 12:13). It is so called because it lies at the end of the world. The reference is to the Atlantic, which I have already mentioned.91 However, this is a major blunder, because the yam suf (Red Sea) lies in the east, opposite Egypt.92 The Spanish Sea93 is larger than it.94

ARMED. Some say that chamushim (armed) means full of wealth, possessing all that they need. Now Scripture states, neither had they prepared for themselves any victual (Ex. 12:39).95 Furthermore, what reason is there to mention this now?96 The only meaning of chamushim is, girded with weapons for war. Compare, chalutzim ta’avoru (ye shall pass over armed) (Deut. 3:18), the meaning of which is: ye shall pass over with girded loins.97 The fact that Scripture in one place reads, ve-attem ta’averu chamushim (but ye shall pass over before your brethren armed) (Josh. 1:14) and in another place refers to the Israelites as chalutzim (Deut. 3:18) is true witness to the aforementioned.98 What reason was there for them to carry food before their brethren?99 The reason Scripture at this point notes that the children of Israel went up armed is that it is previously stated, Lest peradventure the people repent when they see war, and they return to Egypt (v. 17).100 For101 the Israelites went out with a high hand (Ex. 14:8), with weapons of war and not like fleeing slaves.

19. AND MOSES TOOK THE BONES OF JOSEPH. Scripture mentions above that the children of Israel who were alive in that generation went up out of the land of Egypt. Scripture now notes that the children of Israel also brought up with them the most honored one of them, the one through whom they came down to Egypt. The latter had made them swear before his death that they would tell their children, and their children would instruct their children about this.102 Now Moses busied himself with fulfilling the oath so that no guilt would fall upon Israel. For we see that the princes of Israel swore an oath to the Gibeonites.103 Now they only took this oath on condition that the Gibeonites came from a distant place as they claimed.104 After it was found that the Gibeonites came from close by105 it was fitting that they not keep their oath so that they and all Israel not violate the injunction, thou shalt save alive nothing (Deut. 20:16). However, they kept their oath out of regard for God’s glory so that they not desecrate it.106 Many years later God punished the children of Israel107 because Saul permitted the Gibeonites who were in Nob, the city of the priests, to be put to death.108
[THE BONES OF JOSEPH.] Scripture mentions the bones of109 for all of the flesh and skin breeds worms and putrefies, and after a few years only the bones remain.110
20. AND THEY TOOK THEIR JOURNEY…ETHAM. Etham is, as I will explain,111 the wilderness of Shur.

21. AND THE LORD WENT BEFORE THEM BY DAY. We know that the Lord inhabiteth eternity and His name is Holy (Is. 57:15), and that He is enthroned of old. Selah (Ps. 55:20).112 Scripture speaks in the language of men. It reads so because God’s power went with Israel, as in That caused His glorious arm to go at the right hand of Moses (Is. 63:12).

[IN A PILLAR OF CLOUD.] Scripture reads, in a pillar of cloud because it was not shaped like other clouds but was in the form of a pillar stretching from the sky upon the earth. A pillar is called an ammud113 in Hebrew because the base (ma’amad)114 of the house is on it.115

[THAT THEY MIGHT GO BY DAY AND BY NIGHT.] Scripture reads, that they might go by day and by night because the camp was large and they could only journey a short distance.116 They therefore journeyed part of the day117 and also part of the night.118 These two pillars were, as I shall explain,119 before the Israelites until they came to the sea.
22. DEPARTED NOT. Yamish (departed) is a transitive verb.120 For God mentioned above121 did not cause the pillars to depart from before the people.

[BY DAY.] The word yomam (by day) is not found employed in Scripture except for the time when the sun shines upon the earth. The word yom (day) found in the Torah, the Prophets, and the Writings refers also to nighttime, for it is written, on the day (yom) that I smote all the first-born in the land of Egypt (Num. 8:17). Now the slaying of the first-born took place at night.122 It is also written, this day (ha-yom) is a day (yom) of good tidings (II Kings 7:9). Now it was then night, for we read there, if we tarry till the morning light (Ibid.). Scripture also reads, The day (yom) I cry in the night before Thee (Ps. 88:2).123
chapter.ftnote: 1 Scripture should have followed up our verse with: speak unto the children of Israel and say unto them as in Num. 6:1,2. As things stand, it is nowhere stated in our chapter that Moses told or was commanded to relate the contents of verse 1 to the Israelites.
2 Hence And the Lord spoke unto Moses is the same as saying, the Lord spoke unto Israel; i.e., the contents of this chapter pertained to Israel.
3 According to Yefet this command was only for Moses. Moses personally was to declare all first-born holy.

4 Translated literally. J.P.S. renders, then the priest shall pronounce him unclean. Both Moses and the priests perform their actions verbally. What I.E. means by the term “reverse” is that one makes someone unclean while the other makes one holy.
5 And not in any other way. The verse can be taken to mean that the priest shall place an unclean object upon the subject in order to make him unclean, hence I.E.’s comment.
6 Peter kol rechem literally means the opening of the womb, hence I.E.’s comment.

7 Rather than a segol in penultimately accented nouns. Compare, nachal (river), lahav (flame), and na’ar (youth) (Weiser). Hence our word should have been vocalized racham rather than rechem. Cf. Jud. 5:30.

8 Of Nisan, the day that they actually left Egypt. The Hebrew literally reads: on the day (ba-yom) of the 15th day (yom) he said remember. Filwarg correctly points out that the second yom is a scribal error and should be deleted.

9 Hence Scripture speaks of the place/house of bondage. However, the Israelites were not true slaves. They were a separate nation. They lived in their own houses, not in the homes of their masters; they had a family life and a culture. I.E. apparently comments thus so that people would not think of the ancient Israelites in the same way that they thought of contemporary slaves, i.e., as mean people. Cf. Aristotle’s Politics, 1:5, “From the hour of their birth, some are marked out for subjection, others for rule…Clearly there are some who are by nature free, others are by nature slaves, and for the latter their condition of servitude is both advantageous and just.”
10 And forced them to work as if they were the slaves, of the Egyptians.
11 Eat no leaven on that day.
12 Verse 4 reads, ha-yom attem yotze’im be-chodesh ha-aviv (This day ye go forth in the month Abib). I.E. interprets this verse to mean: This day ye go forth in the month of fresh ears.
13 The barley ripens first.
14 A sage is called an av. Cf. Jud. 17:10, Dwell with me, and be unto me a father (av) and a priest; and Pirke Avot (Ethics of the Fathers/Sages).
15 In this case av means first in wisdom.
16 Which shows that aviv refers to ears of barley.
17 The Torah refers to the first ears of the wheat harvest as bikkurim, not avivim, for aviv refers to the first barley ears, which ripen about two months before the wheat does.
18 Which falls seven weeks after Passover.
19 That aviv means first.
20 They are listed in Gen. 15:19-21 and there is no need to repeat all of them here.
21 Spoken of in verse 5.
23 The Day of Atonement is called a sabbath of solemn rest (Lev. 23:32).

24 Our verse literally reads: And thou shalt tell thy son in that day saying, because of this (ba’avur zeh) the Lord did for me when I came forth out of Egypt. Rabbi Merinus could find no sense in this. Prima facie, “because of this” refers to the eating of matzah. What meaning is there in: because of the eating of the matzah, the Lord did for me when I came forth out of Egypt? He thus interprets our verse to mean: It is because of that (zeh ba’avur) which the Lord did for me when I came out of Egypt that I eat matzah and abstain from leaven.
25 Where the word order has to be inverted. See Sefer Ha-Rikmah, chap. 28.
26 In other words, ba’avur zeh is not to be interpreted as a reason for the eating of the matzah and abstaining from leaven.

27 Our verse is to be understood thus: And thou shalt tell thy son in that day saying: It is because we should observe this (and other) precept(s) the Lord did signs for me when I went out of Egypt. So too Rashi.
28 That is, so that you will serve me.
29 Who interpret our verse literally and say that for a sign unto thee upon thy hand, and for a memorial between thy eyes refers to the phylacteries placed upon the hand and head.
30 Those who oppose the rabbis. I.E. reads, she-amar. This is obviously a scribal error. The correct reading is, she-ameru.

31 Which is not to be taken literally, for it refers to the teachings of one’s father and mother (Prov. 1:8). Similarly with our verse (see note 20). It is worthy of note that this interpretation is found in Rashbam, who notes that from a literal point of view our verse is to be taken metaphorically: that is, a person should recall the Exodus as if it were written upon his hand and adorned his head as a jewel.
32 Which is not to be taken literally.
33 Its knowledge shall be second nature, so that you can recall it and speak of it at the drop of a hat.
34 See I.E.’s third approach to Biblical interpretation, Vol. 1, pp. 10 and 11.
35 According to the rabbis the hand phylactery is placed on the left hand.
36 I.E. disagrees that yad usually refers to the left hand.
37 As explained by I.E. in his comments on Ex. 12:2.
38 Gen. 10:15-18. Hence the term Canaanite includes all the inhabitants of Canaan. Also see I.E. on Gen. 15:20

39 As He swore unto thee and to thy fathers means as He swore unto your fathers to give this land to you their seed (Krinsky), as we do not find God taking this oath to the generation enslaved in Egypt.
40 The sanctification of the first-born (v. 2) and the eating of unleavened bread (v. 3 and 6).
41 Vocalized segol, segol.
42 Nouns vocalized segol, segol whose vowels change to sheva, pattach in the construct.
43 Rather than sheger, as in our verse.
44 The absolute form of which is cheder.
45 The absolute form of which is hevel.
46 The absolute form of which is chemet.
47 The absolute form of which is delet.
48 The word oref means a neck. Hence va-arafto literally means: and you shall neck it. Hence the possibility of this interpretation.
49 We thus see that the verb derived from oref means to break.
50 Apparently no one disputes the rabbinic interpretation. Otherwise I.E. would be guilty of circular reasoning.
51 The first-born of Israel, both man and beast.
52 Unclean.
53 Animal.
54 Literally, tomorrow.

55 In other words machar is short for me’acher (after). Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi interprets this way because “And it shall come to pass when thy son asketh thee tomorrow (machar),” etc., makes no sense in our context, whereas And it shall come to pass when thy son asketh thee in time to come (machar) does. Also see Rashi, “There are instances when machar means after some time.”

56 Which is followed by And brought out Israel from among them (Ps. 136:11). None of the other plagues are recalled in Ps. 136. Only this plague is mentioned, because it was the one that caused Pharaoh to permit Israel to leave Egypt.
57 At that time.
58 Although it is not stated in the text.
59 In other words, “all” is not to be taken literally because it does not include unclean animals.
60 The eating of unleavened bread (v. 9) and the sanctification of the first-born (v. 16).
61 Ex. 13:1-10 and Ex. 13:11-16, which contain these commandments.
62 In the phylacteries.
63 Our verse is similar to verse 9, which has zikaron (memorial) in place of totafot (frontlets).
64 Menachem ben Saruk (c. 910-970 C.E.). See Rashi.
65 Which is spelled with two tafs.
66 From the root tet, peh. Menachem believed that Hebrew words come from a two-letter root
67 Because ve-hettef comes from the root nun, tet, peh whereas totafot comes from the root tet, tet, peh (Krinsky).
68 In other words, a vav prefixed to a word does not always mean and. Hence ve-lo nacham does not mean: and led them not, but may mean: that God led them not, or something similar.
69 Jacob’s sons.
70 To buy food. See Gen. 42-44.
71 In other words, if the distance between Egypt and Canaan had been very great they would not have been able to carry enough food with them for the journey.
72 If the distance was very great they would have had to carry a vast amount of food for the journey plus an additional amount for their households.

73 In other words, the word ki, which usually means “for” or “because,” has the meaning of “although” here. Rabbi Moses interprets thus, for prima facie, the word, “because” is out of place here, as God should have led them by the way of the Philistines because it was close.

74 The word ki in these verses is to be translated as although. Hence Ex. 34:9 is to be translated, although it is a stiff-necked people; and Ps. 41:5, Heal my soul; although I have sinned against Thee.
75 For interpreting ki here as although.
76 In other words, ki karov hu is to be rendered, because it was close.
77 Lest peradventure implies that God was uncertain about the future. This contradicts the concept that the Lord is omniscient, hence I.E.’s comments.
78 The Torah.
79 What the Torah is trying to convey. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26.
80 Vocalized with a pattach beneath the yod, a tzere beneath the samekh, and a dagesh in the samekh.
81 In the hifil.

82 It may be vocalized va-yasev, with a kamatz beneath the yod and a segol beneath the samekh. For a double root in the hifil imperfect may be vocalized pattach tzere, as in yassev, or kamatz segol, as in yasekh, yagel, yasev.
83 Vocalized kamatz, segol.
84 Vocalized kamatz, segol.

85 The Hebrew reads, ha-midbar yam suf. Now a definite article cannot be prefixed to a word in the construct. Hence I. E. argues that ha-midbar yam suf is short for ha-midbar, midbar yam suf. See Vol. 1, Foreword, p. XV, and I.E. on Gen. 2:9.
86 See Vol. 1, p. 54, note 36.
87 See Vol. 1, p. 54.
88 The phraseha-sefer ha-miknah, is short for ha-sefer, sefer ha-miknah (the deed, deed of the purchase).
89 Ha-yayin ha-chemah is short for ha-yayin, yen ha-chemah (the wine, wine of fury).
90 In other words, yam suf (Red Sea) is a variant of yam sof and means the Sea of the End, that is, the sea which lies at the end of the world.
91 Ex. 10:19. Literally, as I have already mentioned.
92 Whereas the Atlantic does not.
93 The Mediterranean.
94 The Red Sea. How much more so the Atlantic, which is greater than the Mediterranean. Hence the Red Sea cannot be identified with the Atlantic.
95 Which shows that they did not have everything they needed.
96 That they had provisions. It adds nothing to the account here. Its proper place is in Ex. 12:39.
97 The word chalatz means loins. Therefore, chalutzim ta’avoru literally means: ye shall pass over with loins, i.e., with loins girded with weapons.
98 That chamushim means armed.

99 If chamushim means stocked with food then Josh. 1:14 tells us that the tribes of Dan and Reuben and half the tribe of Manasseh passed over the Jordan before the rest of Israel, carrying food. Now what conceivable reason was there for this? Food carriers or baggage follow behind troops. They do not precede them.
100 Hence we might assume that they were unarmed.
101 Contrary to what verse 17 might imply.
102 To bring his bones up with them.
103 That they would not harm them. See Josh. 9.
104 See Josh. 9:9.
105 That is, from the land of Canaan.
106 As they swore upon God’s name.
107 See II Sam. 21:1.
108 See Rashi and Kimchi on II Sam. 21:1.
109 Rather than the body of.
110 I.E. was apparently unaware of the process of mummification.
112 In other words, God is incorporeal, for if He had a body He could not be eternal. This being the case, why does Scripture read, And the Lord went?
113 From the root ayin, mem, dalet.
114 From the root ayin, mem, dalet.

115 An alternative translation is: because the existence (ma’amad) of the house depends on it. See the word ammud in Kimchi’s Sefer Ha-Shorashim. Be that as it may, I.E.’s point is that the passive form ammud (it was stood up), rather than the active omed (stands) is used for a pillar because the house is stood up, i.e., stands/exists (ammud) because of it.
116 At a time.
117 That is, a little by day (Cohen).
118 That is, a little by night.

120 Meaning he caused to depart, the reference being to the Lord mentioned in verse 21. Thus lo yamish ammud he-anan (the pillar of cloud departed not) means: God did not cause the pillar of cloud to depart.
121 In verse 21.
123 Translated literally.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 14
chapter.p: 1. AND THE LORD SPOKE. It is truly not proper for an intelligent person to scrutinize God’s actions and ask, why did the Lord act thus?1 For all of God’s actions are done wisely. Man’s wisdom is as nothing before God.2 I mention this because you will read in this Torah portion that God3 guilefully commanded the Israelites to turn back4 so that Pharaoh would go out and pursue them, and drown in the sea.5 God’s thoughts are very deep.6
2. PI-HAHIROTH. Pi-hahiroth is elsewhere called Pene-hahiroth (Num. 33:8). It is so called7 because the mouth (peh) is on the face (panim).8 It is the name of a place.

BEFORE BAAL-ZEPHON. Some say that the Egyptian magicians made bronze images which drew power from the stars, and that Baal-zephon was a statue that no slave fleeing Egypt was able to pass by.9 It is because of this that Scripture reads, that the people were fled (v. 5).10 However, in my opinion because Moses said to Pharaoh, We will go three days’ journey into the wilderness (Ex. 8:23), it appeared to Pharaoh from these words that Moses knew the road that they would take to the place where they intended to sacrifice. Thus when Pharaoh heard that the Israelites started to go by way of the wilderness,11 and when they had traveled some distance12 backtracked to go in another way, Pharaoh surmised that everything that Moses had told him was said in guile, that he did not intend to sacrifice but to flee. For one who flees becomes confused on the way and does not know which road to take.

OVER AGAINST IT. The word nikhcho (over against it) is vocalized with a chirik.13 It is similar to the word niflo (was fallen)14 in after that he was fallen (II Sam. 1:10). There are many other such instances.15
3. AND PHARAOH WILL SAY OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. This is similar to say of me (Gen. 20:13).16

ENTANGLED. Nevukhim (entangled) is vocalized with a shuruk in place of a cholam.17 It is similar to the word ta’avuri (pass)18 in neither pass from hence (Ruth 2:8), for nevukhim is a nifal as the word nekhonim (ready) (Ex. 19:11) is.19 Now navokhu (perplexed) (Joel 1:18) and also navokhah (perplexed) in but the city of Shushan was perplexed (Est. 3:15) are like nakhonah (established)20 in And the kingdom was established (I Kings 2:46). Its meaning is, they are like a person who cannot find anyone to advise him and does not know what to do.21
The nun in nivkhe (depths of) in the depths of the sea (Job 38:16)22 is a root letter.23 The meaning of nivkhe yam (the springs of the sea) is the depths of the sea. Nivkhe has no place here.24
THE WILDERNESS HATH SHUT THEM IN. The ways of the wilderness are closed to them, and like fugitives they do not know where to go.
4. AND I WILL HARDEN PHARAOH’S HEART. As if he forgot the plagues25 with which the Egyptians were smitten because of Israel.
AND I WILL GET ME HONOR UPON PHARAOH. My glory shall be manifest in the world when I drown Pharaoh and his army.26
AND THE EGYPTIANS SHALL KNOW. The remnants27 and those who drowned prior to their death shall know that I am the Lord.
AND THEY DID SO. Scripture’s short way of saying that they turned backwards.28
5. AND IT WAS TOLD THE KING OF EGYPT. That they are not going for any purpose but to flee.
6. AND HE MADE READY HIS CHARIOT. By command.29 It is like So Solomon built the house (I Kings 14:4).30
7. AND HE TOOK SIX HUNDRED CHOSEN CHARIOTS. The chosen chariots of all the chariots that he had.31

AND CAPTAINS. Note that the king is like the number one. Therefore the one who is next to him in rank is called the mishneh (the second), which is derived from the same root as shenayim (two). The third in rank is called the shelishi. 32
8. WITH A HIGH HAND. They had all the weapons of war and so did not go out like fugitives.

9. AND THE EGYPTIANS PURSUED AFTER THEM. This is in keeping with linguistical style.33 It is similar to and the people saw,34 and they trembled and stood far off35 (Ex. 20:15), the meaning of which is, when they saw this,36 they trembled and stood far off. The meaning of and the Egyptians pursued after them thus is: when the Egyptians pursued them,37 they overtook them as they were encamping by the sea.
[ALL THE HORSES.] Scripture notes this38 to inform us that they did not come upon them scattered.39
AND HIS HORSEMEN. Parashav means his horsemen.
AND HIS ARMY. Chelo (his army) means his foot soldiers.
10. AND WHEN PHARAOH DREW NEAR. When Pharaoh caused his camp to draw near.40 The verb hikriv (drew near) is always transitive in Scripture.41

11. AND THEY SAID. We find that the holy tongue employs two words with one meaning back to back when one would suffice. Now the phrase ha-mibbeli en kevarim (because there were no graves)42 is similar to ha-rak akh be-mosheh (only with Moses?) (Num. 12:2).43
TO BRING US FORTH. Le-hotzi’anu (to bring us forth) is vocalized with a long kamatz in place of a tzere.44 It is similar to ro’ani (seeth me)45 in Thou hast said:46 None seeth me (Is. 47:10).

12. IS THIS NOT THE WORD. This is not stated.47 However, we know that this was the case, for how could they say to his face something that was not true? This remark was included in but they hearkened not unto Moses (Ex. 6:9).48
13. STAND STILL, AND SEE THE SALVATION OF THE LORD. For you will not wage war but you shall see the salvation which the Lord will work for you this day.

One may ask: How is it that a large camp comprising six hundred thousand armed men were afraid of those who pursued them? Why did they not stand and fight for their own and their children’s lives? The answer is: The Egyptians were masters over Israel. The generation that left Egypt were trained from their youth to bear the yoke of the Egyptians. They were of humble spirit. How then could they now wage war against their masters? The Israelites were lazy and not learned in war. Can you not see that were it not for the prayers of Moses, the Amalekites, who came49 with a small number of men, would have defeated Israel.

God alone, Who doeth great things (Job 5:9); And by Him actions are weighed (I Sam. 2:3), so arranged events that all Israelite males50 who left Egypt died out,51 for they had no spirit to fight the Canaanites; and a new generation with a noble spirit, who had never tasted exile, arose after the generation of the wilderness.52 I have noted the aforementioned in the account of Moses recorded in the Torah portion Ve-Eleh Shemot.53

14. THE LORD WILL FIGHT FOR YOU. Lakhem means for you.54 Similarly, whenever the word war (milchamah) is followed by a lamed it indicates aid. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen therefore explains li (me) in For there are many that fight (lochamim) me (li) on high55 (Ps. 56:3) to mean for me.56 The meaning of on high is, a war on high, as is the case with all that sit.57
AND YE SHALL HOLD YOUR PEACE. In contrast to and the children of Israel cried out (v. 10).

15. WHEREFORE CRIEST THOU UNTO ME. Some say that Moses was crying out unto the Lord.58 However, this is incorrect, for God had already told Moses, and I will get Me honor upon Pharaoh (v. 4).59 On the contrary, this was told to Moses who stood in Israel’s stead60 because the children of Israel cried out to the Lord.
THAT THEY GO FORWARD. Little by little until they reach the edge of the sea.

16. AND LIFT THOU UP. God told Moses to lift up his rod and divide the sea before the children of Israel went forward. The Lord did not tell Moses to strike the sea.61 He told him to stretch out his hand toward the sea62 in the manner63 of And Moses stretched forth his rod toward heaven 64 (Ex. 9:23). We know that the rod did not divide the sea but that from the moment that Moses stretched his hand toward the sea God caused the sea to go back by a strong east wind and the waters then65 split. For it is so written.66

17. AND I. We know that the Red Sea is not situated between Egypt and the Land of Israel. There was no reason for them to enter the sea.67 However, God commanded them to do so, so that the Egyptians would enter behind them and drown. The children of Israel, as I will explain,68 entered the sea from the wilderness of Etham and exited the sea to the wilderness of Etham.
18. AND THE EGYPTIANS SHALL KNOW. Those that remained.69
WHEN I HAVE GOTTEN ME HONOR UPON PHARAOH. Who will drown along with his chariots and horsemen.

19. AND THE ANGEL OF GOD. This took place before speak unto the children of Israel, that they should go forward (v. 15).70 It’s meaning thus is, and the angel of God had already removed.71 I have already showed you many such instances.72

Now because these three verses73 are connected to each other and each one has seventy-two letters we find in them, as stated in the books,74 the sign of the secret of God’s explicit name. However, in my opinion it is so written75 because, as I will explain in the Torah portion Ki Tissa,76 the numerical value of God’s glorious name comes to seventy-two.

The Book of Raziel77 states that one who wants to query the heavenly powers in a dream should read the verse, Now it came to pass in the thirtieth year, etc. (Ezek. 1:1), for it contains seventy-two letters.78

THE ANGEL OF GOD. The reference is to the great prince79 who goes in the cloud, concerning whom it is written, And the Lord went before them by day (Ex. 13:21). When this angel, who went before the camp of Israel, moved and went behind them, the pillar of cloud moved with him. Let the one who identifies the angel of God with the cloud show us where we find the pillar of cloud called the angel of God. Furthermore, if the angel and the pillar are one and the same, why is and the pillar of cloud removed from before them repeated? If he should answer that Scripture repeats the same idea in different words,80 then we respond that it is not the manner of Scripture to repeat itself except in prophecy81 or reproof.82 Moreover, it is unfit to repeat oneself when reporting how something happened.83
20. AND IT CAME. And the angel came.84
AND THERE WAS THE CLOUD AND THE DARKNESS HERE. Between the camps.
AND IT LIT UP THE NIGHT.85 As was the manner on all the nights, so that Israel could cross the sea. They crossed it at night.

Rabbi Merinus says that the meaning of va-ya’er (he lit up) is, he darkened. And the night shall be light about me (Ps. 139: 11)86 is similar. Furthermore, we find, On the light of the fourteenth day87 in rabbinic literature. However, the one who interprets thus turns darkness into light and light into darkness, for it is impossible in any language for a word to mean both a thing and its opposite unless it is euphemistically used, as in Naboth did bless God and the king (I Kings 21:13).88 The word light in shall be light about me refers to the light itself, as I have explained.89 Similarly, the sages said90 that On the light of the fourteenth is a refined language,91 which is similar to a euphemism. Furthermore, what reason was there for Scripture to say, and he darkened the night? It is dark every night. The only meaning of va-ya’er et ha-laylah is that he92 lit up the night93 as he did from the day that Israel went out of Egypt, for the pillar of fire was seen every night. Now if Israel had no light how did they cross the sea?94 For behold, by the time Pharaoh came into the sea and the Lord looked forth upon him in the morning watch, most of the Israelites had already crossed.95
21. AND MOSES STRETCHED OUT HIS HAND…ALL THE NIGHT. Even while Israel was crossing, the wind did not cease.

22. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL WENT INTO THE MIDST OF THE SEA. Do not think that because Scripture reads, in the midst96 of the sea that the Israelites reached the middle of the Red Sea. On the contrary, even if they entered the sea for even half of a Persian mile one may say that they came in the midst of the sea.97 It is like And the mixed multitude that was in the midst of them98 (Num. 11:4), for the mixed multitude was not in the middle of the camp. The meaning of the midst of the sea is, the place where there was water at the beginning of the night.99

AND THE WATERS WERE A WALL UNTO THEM. The waters froze.100 It is also written, The floods stood upright as a heap (Ex. 15:8).101 After most of Israel crossed, the waters which formed a wall for them melted. This is the meaning of that the waters may come back upon the Egyptians (v. 26). These waters102 separated between the Egyptians and the dry land.103 It therefore states, and the Egyptians fled against it (v. 27), as the Egyptians thought that they would go out onto dry land.104 But the walls of water melted and separated them and dry land. There is no doubt that those who pursued Israel saw the light by which Israel crossed.105
24. AND IT CAME TO PASS IN THE MORNING WATCH. The alef of ashmoret106 (watch) is a superfluous letter.107

THAT THE LORD LOOKED FORTH. The reference is to the angel of the Lord mentioned earlier.108 The same is the case with Gideon,109 where the messenger is called by the name of the sender. Since the sender commands his agent to commit an act, it is as if the sender himself had executed it.
THROUGH THE PILLAR OF FIRE AND OF CLOUD. Between these two pillars.110

AND DISCOMFITED. Possibly because of this the poet says, The voice of Thy thunder was in the whirlwind (Ps. 77:19).111 Similarly And He shot forth lightnings, and discomfited them112 (Ps. 18:15). Elsewhere it is written, And He sent…Lightning, and discomfited them113 (II Sam. 22:15).
25. AND HE TOOK OFF. Va-yasar (and He took off) is a hifil.114 It should have been vocalized va-yaser with a segol beneath the samekh. I have already noted its grammatical explanation.115

[AND HE TOOK OFF THEIR CHARIOT WHEELS.]116 Some say its meaning is that they117 untied the knot of the wheel118 from the horses119 so that, being lighter,120 they could flee more easily. However, the above-mentioned divine discomfit fell upon them and their horses, and they could only drive them with great difficulty.121 Others say that va-yasar comes from the root of sorer (rebellious) (Deut. 21:18).122 He who went before them wanted to turn the chariot around.123

FOR THE LORD FIGHTETH FOR THEM AGAINST THE EGYPTIANS. Lahem124 means for them.125 It now becomes clear that God’s word, and the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord (v. 4), which He spoke earlier meant: and the Egyptians shall know before their deaths.
26. THAT THE WATERS MAY COME BACK. The waters which served as walls for them should return to their previous state.
27. WHEN THE MORNING APPEARED. Lifnot boker (when the morning appeared) means toward morning.
TO ITS STRENGTH. Le-etano means to its strength. It is a noun,126 like etan in mighty rivers (Ps. 74:15).127
FLED AGAINST IT. I have already explained128 that the Egyptians in fleeing thought that they were returning to dry land when in actuality they were going toward the sea.

May the bones of Chivi129 the dog130 be crushed. Chivi said that Moses knew the time of low tide, when the level of the sea goes down, and the time of high tide, when the sea comes in and its level rises, and so brought his people across the sea when the tide was normally low. However, Pharaoh did not know the manner of the sea and therefore drowned. This interpretation is sheer madness, as the sea is not normally dry in any place when its level goes down. However, all was dry.131 Neither do walls of water remain on the right or the left.132 Furthermore, the end of low tide and the beginning of high tide do not become clear until some hours have passed.133 Moreover, the Israelites had not yet finished crossing before Pharaoh and his army drowned.134

AND THE LORD OVERTHREW. Va-yena’er (overthrew) is a pi’el. Na’arti (I shook) in Also I shook out my lap (Neh. 5:13) is similar to it.135 Va-yena’er is to be understood in the manner of hath He thrown into the sea (Ex. 15: 1).136
28. AND THE WATERS RETURNED. The waters that were walls returned.

SO MUCH AS ONE OF THEM. Even one of them did not escape.137 Similarly ad echad in and, behold, there was not so much as one (ad echad) of the cattle of the Israelites dead (Ex. 9:7). Indeed, the poet says, There was not one of them (echad me-hem) left (Ps. 106: 11).138

29. BUT THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. The reason this is noted a second time139 is that there remained some Israelites who were still crossing the sea while Pharaoh was drowning. This was a miracle within a miracle, for in the place where the Israelites were crossing the sea there was a strong east wind drying140 and where Pharaoh and his host were, God brought another wind to melt the waters that were frozen and formed walls. There were thus two winds in two places in the sea close to one another.141 True proof that this interpretation is correct is offered by the statement in the Song of Moses, And with the blast of Thy nostrils the waters were piled up (Ex. 15:8), which speaks of the wind that blew for Israel; and the statement, Thou didst blow with Thy wind, the sea covered them (Ex. 15:10), which speaks of the wind that caused the Egyptians to drown. It is because of this that the end of the song reads, and the Lord brought back the waters of the sea upon them; but the children of Israel walked on dry land in the midst of the sea (Ex. 15:19).

Do not ask, how could all of Israel cross in one night? Did not the six hundred thousand men on foot142 make up only a quarter of the camp?143 Perhaps they passed over some other way.144 Or perhaps the sea split into twelve parts, as the sages of blessed memory say.145 Now the Israelites did not cross the width of the sea.146 On the contrary, they moved along its length and came out in the wilderness of Shur from wherein, as I will explain, they entered the sea.147

30. THUS THE LORD SAVED. Now the Israelites were saved from the hand of the Egyptians. Until now the fear of Pharaoh was upon them.148 Scripture tells us that the Egyptians drowned in the sea. The sea did not cast their bodies out upon the dry land,149 for it is clearly written, The earth swallowed them (Ex. 15:12).150 The meaning of and Israel saw the Egyptians dead upon the sea-shore151 therefore is: when the Egyptians drowned, the Israelites, who were on the shore, saw their dead bodies.152
31. FEARED. When Israel saw this great blow they feared God, as in And David was afraid of the Lord that day when Uzzah who put forth his hand to the ark of God died (II Sam. 6:9).
AND THEY BELIEVED IN THE LORD. They believed that the Lord is truth153 and that Moses is His servant and will do only that which the Lord commands him to do.

The verse thus states: For there are many that fight for me on high as is the case with all important people. 74 Post-talmudic works such as Lekach Tov on Ex. 14; Responsa of R. Hai Gaon. Also see Ozer Ha-Geonim, Hagigah, p. 23. The Talmud speaks of the 72-letter name of God. See Sukkah 45a. Those who see the 72-letter name of God in these verses do so in one of the following two ways. They arrange the three verses on top of each other and arrive at God’s name by reading down, i.e., vav, vav, vav; yod, yod, yod; samekh, bet, tet, etc. Or they invert verse 20 and arrange the three verses as above and read down, i.e., vav, heh, vav; yod, lamed, yod; samekh, alef, tet, and so on. The reason they invert the middle verse is that it states, and the one did not come near the other all the night; i.e., one is not to combine the letters of this verse in their normal fashion but they are to be read backwards as the word ha-laylah (the night) is. For ha-laylah reads the same whether from left to right or right to left (Krinsky).

75 These three verses. In other words, verses 19-21 consist of 72 letters each, not because a combination of their letters spells out a secret name of God, but rather they allude to God (YHVH) whose might delivered Israel.

76 I.E. insists that when the Talmud speaks of the 72-letter name of God it refers to the tetragrammaton (YHVH),which when calculated as follows, Y (10) YH (15) YHV (21) YHVH (26), comes to 72. Cf. I.E.’s Sefer Ha-Shem 5.
