147 See I.E. on Ex. 15:22.
148 The Israelites dreaded Pharaoh until they saw the Egyptian corpses.
149 Contra Rashi and Mekhilta on this verse, and Pesachim 118b.
150 That is, the sea bed swallowed them (Krinsky).
151 Which implies that the sea cast them out.
152 Before they sank.

153 Unchanging and Ultimate Being. Cf. Mishneh Torah, Mada 1:3,4: “The Truth of His being is incomparable to the truth of any other individual being…He alone is the Truth, and no other being possesses a truth similar to His Truth.”

chapter.title: CHAPTER 15
chapter.p: 1. THEN SANG MOSES. It is Hebrew style to employ an imperfect preceded by the word az (then) in place of a perfect.1 Compare, Az yivneh shelomoh (then did Solomon build) (I Kings 11:7);2 az yedabber yehoshu’a (then spoke Joshua) (Josh. 10:12);3 az yavdil mosheh (then Moses separated) (Deut. 4:41).4 The same is true in Arabic.

Moses composed the song by himself. He then taught it to all of Israel, each one of whom then sang and said, I will sing unto the Lord.5 And Moses and the elders of Israel commanded the people (Deut. 27:1) is similar. The commandment was first spoken only by Moses. The elders of Israel then repeated it to everyone.6
AND SPOKE, SAYING.7 Each one of the Israelites was to say the following, or the following was to be said in every generation.

FOR HE IS HIGHLY EXALTED. He demonstrated His exaltation by casting both the mighty rider and his exalted and powerful steed into the sea as one casts an arrow. The meaning of ramah (thrown) in ramah va-yam (hath He thrown into the sea) is similar to the word rome (throws) in armed with that which a bow throws (Ps. 78:9).8

2. THE LORD IS MY STRENGTH AND SONG. Rabbi Solomon9 of blessed memory says that there is a difference between ozzi (my strength), which is vocalized with a furtive kamatz, and uzzi, which is vocalized with a kubbutz. He therefore says that the yod in ozzi (my strength) in the Lord is my strength and song is superfluous.10 However, Rabbi Solomon does not offer another such instance.11 Rabbi Solomon goes on to say that ve-zimrat (and song) is in the construct with Yah (the Lord). He interprets our verse as if it read: The strength and vengeance12 of the Lord became my salvation.13 Rabbi Solomon thought that our verse is similar to va-yehi ba-yom ha-shelishi va-yissa avraham et enav (on the third day Abraham lifted up his eyes) (Gen. 22:4).14 However, one who knows Arabic knows the difference between the two verses.15 It is neither correct Hebrew nor Arabic form to say ozzi ve-zimrat Yah va-yehi li li-shu’ah.16 There is no difference between ozzi vocalized with a furtive kamatz and the same word vocalized with a kubbutz.17 For while Scripture reads, chukki (mine allotted)18 in Feed me with mine allotted bread (Prov. 30:8) it elsewhere reads, chokkha19 ve-chok ba-nekha (thy due, and thy son’s due) (Lev. 10:13). Now we find the word ve-ozzekha (in Thy strength) (v. 13) vocalized with a furtive kamatz, later on in this song and similarly in O Lord, in Thy strength (be-ozzekha) the king re-joiceth (Ps. 21:2).20 The yod of ozzi is thus a first person suffix.

Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that the meaning of ve-zimrat Yah is, the Lord is my song,21 for the resh of ve-zimrat (and song) is vocalized with a kamatz.22 Similarly,23 the meaning of shenat in I will not give sleep (shenat) to mine eyes (Ps. 132:4) is, my sleep,24 as shenat is vocalized with a kamatz.25 Likewise, the meaning of nachalat, which is vocalized with a kamatz26 in Yea, I have a goodly heritage (nachalat) (Ps. 16:6) is my heritage.27 Similarly,28 the meaning of menat, which is vocalized with a kamatz29 in, O Lord, the portion (menat) of mine inheritance and of my cup (Ps. 16:5), is my portion.30 However, what will Rabbi Moses do with the word menat (portion) in the king’s portion (II Chron. 31:3) in which menat is vocalized with a kamatz and is in the construct. It is the same case with the word yam (sea) in the salt sea (Num. 34:3) and in the sea (yam) of Chinnereth (Num. 34:11). Should one respond that the latter are irregular, we would tell him to place ozzi ve-zimrat Yah among them.31

I believe that the word ozzi (my strength) is, as is the style of the Hebrew language, to be read as if written twice.32 Our clause is to be read as if written, ozzi, ve-zimrat ozzi33 Yah (The Lord is my strength and the song of my strength).34 The reason behind this verse is that Moses earlier mentioned, The horse and his rider hath He thrown into the sea (v. 4). Moses now states that this was not through his own majesty and strength. On the contrary, he confesses, my strength and the glory of my strength35 is Yah alone who is the Lord.

Yah is, as I have explained,36 one of the three proper names of God. All three37 come from one root.38 Since the word eheyeh39 is frequently employed in speech it was necessary to substitute a vav for a yod in God’s glorious name.40 The word Yah41 is likewise known.42 Its yod was vocalized with a pattach because of the guttural43 and the silent yod44 was dropped45 because it has another secret numerical meaning.46 We find Yah combined with God’s glorious name in ki ozzi ve-zimrat Yah YHVH (for God the Lord is my strength and song) (Is. 12:2). I have already explained that the name YHVH is at times a proper name and at times an adjective.47
THIS IS MY GOD. My power.48
AND I WILL GLORIFY HIM. I will place Him in a building.49

[THIS.] The word zeh (this) is to be read as if written twice. The last clause of our verse is to be read as if written: And this is my father’s God, the reference being to the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.50
AND I WILL EXALT HIM. For I will recount His might.
3. THE LORD IS A MAN OF WAR. The Lord supports those who love Him and cleave unto Him and He is a man of war to their enemies.

[MAN.] The word ish (man) means a being.51 Scripture thus states in reference to the stars, ish lo nedar (not one faileth) (Is. 40:26); and in reference to the living creatures, ish el ever panav yelekhu (they went every one straight forward) (Ezek. 1:9); and in reference to the angels, ve-ha-ish gavriel (the man Gabriel) (Dan. 9:21). The meaning of ish milchamah (a man of war) thus is, a being who wages war. It is similar to the term ish emunim (a faithful man) (Prov. 20:6), the meaning of which is, a being52 imbued with faith.

THE LORD IS HIS NAME. His name will now be known. Compare, That calleth for the waters of the sea, And poureth them out upon the face of the earth; The Lord is His name (Amos 5:8). He alone can do such a thing.53
4. PHARAOH’S CHARIOTS. God, as it were, cast Pharaoh’s heavy chariots and their hosts as if they were a light arrow.
[AND HIS CHOSEN CAPTAINS.] Moses made mention of his chosen captains “who were over all them”54 because he had previously spoken of Pharaoh’s hosts.

[THE RED SEA.] Yefet55 says that suf in yam suf (the Red Sea) has the same meaning as the word suf (flags) in The reeds and flags shall wither (Is. 19:6) and the word suf in and laid it in the flags (Ex. 2:3). For reeds and rushes grow around the yam suf,56 and not around other seas.57 However, Rabbi Joshua says that suf is the name of a city.58 It is like yam kinneret (the sea of Chinnereth) (Josh. 13:27).59
5. THE DEEPS. The deeps of the earth.60 Compare, The earth swallowed them (v. 11).
[COVER THEM.] A shuruk has been substituted for a cholam in yekhasyumu (cover them).61 Compare, ta’avuri (pass) in neither pass from hence (Ruth 2:8).62
THE DEPTHS. Metzolot (the depths) means the deep waters. Similarly va-tashlikheni metuzlah, (for thou did cast me into the deep waters) (Jonah 2:4).63
6. GLORIOUS. The yod of nedari (glorious) is superfluous.64 It is like the yod of akhzari (cruel).65

[THY RIGHT HAND.] The repetition of the phrase Thy right hand, O Lord indicates the same as the repetition of For, lo, Thine enemies, O Lord (Ps. 92:10)66 and The floods have lifted up (Ps. 93:3).67 It indicates time and time again. Its meaning is: your right hand dashes the enemy in pieces times without number.
[GLORIOUS IN POWER.] Glorious in power refers to God.68 However, there are those who say that it refers to the Lord’s right hand.69

7. AND IN THE GREATNESS OF THY EXCELLENCE. Which is superior to all who exalt themselves. You are able to shatter (overthrow) those that rise up against You. You need no iron weapons to shatter them. All You have to do is send forth Your wrath and it consumeth them as stubble, for God’s wrath is as hot as fire.
8. AND WITH THE BLAST OF THY NOSTRILS. You rebuke the waters and they congeal. Compare, By the breath of God they perish (Job 4:9).
THE WATERS WERE PILED UP. The word ne’ermu (were piled up) is similar to the word aremat (a heap of) in a heap of wheat (Cant. 7:3).
THE FLOODS STOOD UPRIGHT AS A HEAP. The waters, whose nature is to flow and descend, turned into a heap (ned), as in And rose up in one heap (ned) (Josh. 4:16).70 The meaning of ned (heap) is a wall.
THE DEEPS WERE CONGEALED. Kafe’u means were congealed. Compare, ve-kippa’on (frost) (Zech. 14:6).71
IN THE HEART OF THE SEA. The heart lies in the middle of the body from the point of view of the body’s width.72
9. THE ENEMY SAID. The reference is to Pharaoh.

[SHALL BE SATISFIED UPON THEM.] The word timla’emo (shall be satisfied upon them) is difficult.73 Rabbi Merinus explains that timla’emo nafshi (my lust shall be satisfied upon them) means: my person74 shall be full of them;75 i.e., I will take all of their wealth. The term timla’emo is to be understood like the term yetza’uni (gone forth of me)76 in My children are gone forth of me (Jer. 10:20). Its meaning77 is connected to I will divide the spoil.78 Others say that timla’emo is used in the same sense as the word me’lo’o (presume)79 in that durst presume in his heart (Esth. 7:5).80
[MY HAND SHALL DESTROY THEM.] After doing the latter81 I shall destroy them.
MY HAND SHALL DESTROY THEM. Torishemo means shall destroy them.82 Similarly the word torishu (you will destroy) in But if you will not destroy (Num. 34:55).83

10. THOU DIDST BLOW WITH THY WIND. Nashafta (Thou didst blow) comes from the same root as neshef (night). The meaning of nashafta ve-ruchakha (Thou didst blow with Thy wind) is: You brought a wind at night that drowned them.84
THEY SANK. Tzalelu (they sank) comes from the same root as metzolot (depths). Compare, My lips quivered (tzalelu) at the voice (Hab. 3:16).85
IN THE MIGHTY WATERS. This is connected to they sank. Our verse is to be read as if written: they sank86 as lead in the mighty waters.

AS LEAD. Oferet (lead) comes from the same root as afar (dust).87 If one puts any of the six kinds of metal88 in the ground each will lose one of its familiar elements in a given number of years.89 However, lead will always maintain itself.

11. WHO IS LIKE UNTO THEE, O LORD, AMONG THE MIGHTY. Elim (the mighty) refers to the holy angels in the celestial heights. The sons of the mighty (bene elim)90 refers to the stars. I will explain this further in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.
GLORIOUS IN HOLINESS. The reference is to the Throne of Glory.

[FEARFUL IN PRAISES, DOING WONDERS.] For all who want to acclaim God are afraid to praise His name because who can recite all of His praises. However, they are obligated to praise Him because He alone does wonders.

12. THOU STRETCHEDST OUT THY RIGHT HAND. Your wonders91 were manifest when You stretched forth Your hand from the highest realm of the celestial heights where Your name is exalted, and the ground which is beneath all earthly creatures swallowed up the enemy of Israel. Your right hand, which is above the heaven of heavens, reached, as it were, in a moment to the bottom of the sea.92
[THY RIGHT HAND.] Its meaning is, Thy strength.
13. THOU IN THY LOVE HAST LED. Moses used the perfect nachita (led) in place of the imperfect,93 as is the style in prophecy.94
[IN THY LOVE.] The reference is to the pillars of cloud and fire, for God led them.95 On the other hand, it might allude to the fact that God led them up till now.96
THOU HAST LED. Nehalta (thou hast led) is similar to etnahalah (I will journey) in I will lead on97 gently (Gen. 33:14).98
IN THY STRENGTH. Not by their strength.
TO THY HOLY HABITATION. The reference is to Mount Sinai where God’s Glory dwelt. It is similarly written, and brought you unto Myself (Ex. 19:4).
14. THE PEOPLES HAVE HEARD. The reference is to the peoples round about them and also to the peoples whom they would pass by.99
PANGS HAVE TAKEN HOLD ON THE INHABITANTS OF PHILISTIA. The inhabitants of the land of Philistia.100 The word inhabitants indicates this.101
15. THE MIGHTY MEN. Ele (mighty men) spelled with a yod102 means sheep,103 for the sheep have leaders.104

[THEN WERE THE CHIEFS OF EDOM AFFRIGHTED…THE MIGHTY MEN OF MOAB, TREMBLING TAKETH HOLD UPON THEM.] The Philistines, the Edomites, and the Moabites did not wage war with the Israelites in the wilderness.105

ALL THE INHABITANTS OF CANAAN ARE MELTED AWAY. Because of the reports which they received, as in And as soon as we heard it, our hearts did melt (Josh. 2:11). The inhabitants of Canaan is also106 to be interpreted as the inhabitants of the land of Canaan.107

16. TERROR AND DREAD FALLETH UPON THEM. This refers to Edom and Moab even though Canaan is mentioned above.108 He spoke unto them in a pillar of cloud (Ps. 99:79) is, as I have explained, similar.109 Likewise, and shed the blood of war in peace (I Kings 2:5) only refers to Abner.110 So too, and God healed Abimelech, and his wife, and his maid-servants; and they bore children refers to Abimelech’s wife and handmaids.111 All of this112 because Scripture reads, Till thy people pass over, O Lord.113 For Israel passed them114 before they came to the land of Canaan. Moses repeated Till Thy people pass because they circled Mount Seir for many days.115
[THOU HAST GOTTEN.] Its meaning is: they were slaves in Egypt and Thou hast gotten them to be Your servants.

17. THOU BRINGEST THEM IN, AND PLANTEST THEM IN THE MOUNTAIN OF THINE INHERITANCE. A prayer that Israel remain long in the land and not be exiled from it.116 Our verse is like in the mountain of the height of Israel will I plant it (Ezek. 17:23).

IN THE MOUNTAIN. The goodly hill country and Lebanon (Deut. 3:25)117 is similar. Or it alludes to Mount Moriah.118 It is therefore followed by The place, O Lord, which Thou hast made for Thee to dwell in.

[WHICH THOU HAST MADE.] Its meaning is: which Thou hast prepared as a place for a sanctuary for Thyself.119 The place mentioned lies opposite the glorious celestial place,120 for the places on earth vary in accordance with the star that is over them.121 Those who are versed in the science that deals with the constellations will understand this.122

[THE SANCTUARY.] The word mikkedash (sanctuary)123 has the same meaning as mikdash (sanctuary).124 The word mittoharo (his brightness) in Thou hast made his brightness to cease (Ps. 89:45) is similar, as the dagesh in the tet is superfluous, like the dagesh in the kof of mikkedash.125 The dalet126 does not receive a dagesh127 because the kof128 is vocalized with a mobile sheva.129 With the exception of the form shetayim we do not find it to be the way of Scripture to place a dagesh in a word which follows a mobile sheva. I have already noted its grammatical uniqueness.130
WHICH THY HANDS HAVE ESTABLISHED. Its meaning is similar to thou hast made,131 for Scripture repeats itself.
18. THE LORD SHALL REIGN. God’s Kingship will be seen when the Holy Temple132 which will be dedicated to His name shall be built.

[FOR EVER AND EVER.] Le-olam va-ed (for ever and ever)133 is an abridgment. The full form is le-olam ve-ad134 olam (for ever and until ever). Do not be amazed that the word ed135 is not in the construct,136 for we find, shokhen ad137ve-kadosh shemo (That inhabiteth eternity, whose name is Holy) (Is. 57:15). It is the custom of Hebrew to vocalize a vav with a pattach138 when the syllable which follows it is accented.139 Compare, va-ez (or goat) in of ox, or sheep, or goat (Lev. 7:23). It is for this reason that va-ed is vocalized with a pattach.140 Now Scripture reads, va-okhal141 mi-kol (I have eaten of all) (Gen. 27:33). However, at the end of a verse it reads, ha-nachash hishi’ani va-okhel142 (the serpent beguiled me, and I did eat) (Gen. 3:13). Hence the statement, le-olam va-ed.143
19. FOR THE HORSES OF PHARAOH. This verse is, in my opinion, part of the song.144 Its purpose is to recall the wonder within the wonder,145 which I have noted.146

[UPON THEM.] Upon them refers to the horses of Pharaoh…his chariots and his horsemen. It also includes Pharaoh.147 For Scripture clearly states, The enemy (Pharaoh) said (v. 9) and then goes on to say, The earth swallowed them148 (v. 12). Furthermore, it is explicitly written, But (God) overthrew Pharaoh and his host in the Red Sea (Ps. 136:15).

22. AND MOSES LED. I believe that the pillar of cloud, and likewise the pillar of fire, that went before the people when they left Egypt was to ensure that Israel was able to go by day and by night (Ex. 13:21). After Pharaoh and his hosts drowned, Israel was no longer frightened and did not travel at night.149 Indeed, we do not find it recorded in the Torah portion Be-Halotekha150 that Israel journeyed at night. Behold, Moses now led the people according to God’s command.151

There are only six journeys from the Red Sea until Mount Sinai152 lasting less than forty days.153 The air154 is then good. It is neither humid nor cold. He who does not have a tent can live outdoors155 without harm. When Israel came to the wilderness of Sinai they all erected booths,156 as they camped there for about year. Moses informed them that they would tarry there until they constructed the Tabernacle. It was for this reason that, as I will explain,157 Israel brought out acacia wood from Egypt. The festival of booths was established in commemoration of the booths that Israel made there, for Scripture states, that your generations may know that I made the children of Israel to dwell in booths when I brought them out of the land of Egypt (Lev. 23:43). How can one maintain that Israel dwelt in clouds?158 For the booths do not resemble clouds.159 I will yet explain why the festival of Sukkot is observed in the seventh month.160 When the Tabernacle was erected God descended upon it in a pillar of cloud, as it is clearly written, and there was fire therein by night (Ex. 40:38). When the cloud journeyed the children of Israel went onward (Ex. 40:36). It is because of this that Scripture reads, and thou goest before them, in a pillar of cloud by day (Num. 14:14). There were thus two interchanging pillars161 over the Tabernacle. If the statement to the effect that there were seven interchanging pillars over the Tabernacle162 is based on tradition, then we will rely on tradition and set aside our own opinions.

INTO THE WILDERNESS OF SHUR. This is the very wilderness of Etham.163 Perhaps there were two cities in the wilderness that were so called.164 Or the wilderness had two names.165 And they went three days in the wilderness, the reference being to the wilderness of Shur, is proof of this.166 Therefore to indicate this167 the bet of ba-midbar (in the wilderness), which precedes and found no water, was vocalized for emphasis with a pattach.168

[23.] AND WHEN THEY CAME TO MARAH. It is elsewhere written, And they journeyed from the Red Sea (Num. 33:11). The latter is similar to And Moses led Israel onward from the Red Sea,169 (and they went out into the wilderness of Shur and came to Marah) (v. 22). We similarly find, and they went three days’ journey in the wilderness of Etham, and pitched in Marah (Num. 33:8).170
23. THEREFORE THE NAME OF IT WAS CALLED MARAH.171 Someone called it Marah.172 Who was born unto Levi in Egypt (Num. 26:29)173 is similar.

24. AND THE PEOPLE MURMURED. Va-yillonu (murmured) is a nifal. It is similar to ve-yikkonu (shall be established)174 in And thy thoughts shall be established (Prov. 16:3), which comes from the same root as nakhonu (prepared) (Prov. 19:29).175 It comes from a double root176 or from a root in which the middle letter is missing.177 If it came from a root which begins with a nun178 it would have followed the paradigm of va-yiggashu (came near) (Gen. 45:4).179

25. AND HE CRIED UNTO THE LORD; AND THE LORD SHOWED HIM A TREE. We do not know what type of tree this was.180 What happened can only be described as a miracle. If the waters were stationary181 then we would say that they were medicinally sweetened.182 What the sages said is correct.183
THERE HE MADE FOR THEM. God184 for Israel.
A STATUTE AND AN ORDINANCE. To discipline them and to instruct them.

[AND THERE HE PROVED THEM.] This is to be understood in the manner of for the Lord your God putteth you to proof, to know whether ye do love the Lord your God with all you heart and with all your soul (Deut. 13:4). Scripture similarly states, And He afflicted thee,185 and suffered thee to hunger (Deut. 8:3); and that He might prove thee, to do thee good at thy latter end (Deut. 8:16),186 that is, to do good to those who did not murmur against Moses.187

26. AND HE SAID: IF THOU WILT DILIGENTLY HEARKEN. I have already noted that when the word shema (hearken) is followed by a lamed188 or a bet it does not mean to hear the words being spoken but rather to understand the subject which is being verbalized. Shema in our verse thus means to understand what the Lord commands us to do.
AND WILT DO THAT WHICH IS RIGHT IN HIS EYES. This refers to the positive commandments.
AND WILT GIVE EAR TO HIS COMMANDMENTS. To understand what the negative commandments consist of.
AND KEEP ALL HIS STATUTES. Not to violate them. Compare, And ye shall not walk in the statutes189 of the nation (Lev. 20:23). It is God’s statute not to imitate the practices of the nations.190

[NONE OF THE DISEASES.] Its meaning is, the diseases you should remember. For you saw with your own eyes the diseases, the strokes, and the plagues which I put upon the Egyptians because they rebelled against Me. Now if you will hearken to My statutes you will be saved from these plagues, for I will not do to you what I did to them. Additionally, you have no need of a physician for I am the Lord that healeth thee from all disease which I have decreed to be upon the earth. I will heal you as I healed the bitter waters which no physician has the ability to heal. Behold, what happened at Marah was the opposite of what occurred when the first plague struck, for the waters of the Nile were sweet but the Egyptians could not drink from them.191 However, here192 the bitter waters turned sweet. You should therefore love the Lord and keep yourself from rebelling against Him, for He will do good for you.

27. AND THEY CAME TO ELIM. Saadiah Gaon says there were seventy species of palm trees there.193 Others added, for each and every tribe.194 Others said, for each and every person.195 However, there is no need for these interpretations, for the springs of water, of which there were twelve, and the seventy palm trees did not come into being now because of Israel.196 Additionally, this was not the time for the ripening of palms.197

I believe that Israel tarried in Marah for only one day198 and that they stayed in Elim for about twenty days.199 Scripture therefore says, and they encamped there by the waters.200 The next verse therefore informs us that Israel journeyed from Elim on the fifteenth day of the second month.201 Now Israel camped in the following four places202 in fifteen days:203 the wilderness of Sinai,204 Dophkah, Alush, and Rephidim, for they came to the desert of Sinai at the beginning of the third month.205 Scripture mentions the palm trees to let us know that contrary to the waters of Marah the waters here were sweet, for palm trees cannot flourish in a land of bitter waters.206
chapter.ftnote: 1 Az yashir mosheh (then sang Moses) literally means: then Moses will sing. I.E. points out that an imperfect preceded by the word az occasionally has the meaning of a perfect. Similarly, in the next three verses cited by I.E. verbs that are in the imperfect are to be translated as perfects, for the imperfects are preceded by the word az.
2 Yivneh is an imperfect that means will build. Thus az yivneh shelomoh literally means: then will Solomon build.
3 Yedabber is an imperfect that means will speak. Therefore az yedabber yehoshu’a literally means: then will Joshua speak.
4 Yavdil is an imperfect that means will separate. Thus az yavdil mosheh means: then Moses will separate.

5 Hence the song is in the singular even though the verb which introduces it reads, va-yomeru (and spoke), which literally means: and they spoke. Then sang Moses and the children of Israel this song may be interpreted to mean that Moses and Israel simultaneously broke into song. However, this interpretation is untenable, as it is impossible for a whole nation to know the contents of a song without first being taught its words. Hence I.E.’s comment.
6 For Moses and the elders did not simultaneously command the people.
7 In Hebrew, lemor (saying). Lemor is used when a statement is directed to someone. However, what follows is a hymn, hence I.E.’s comment. Cf. Filwarg.
8 Translated according to I.E.
9 Rashi.
10 According to Rashi the yod of ozzi is not a first person pronominal suffix. The word ozzi has the same meaning as the word oz. It means strength. Cf. Rashi’s comment on this verse.

11 Actually Rashi does. He offers ha-yoshevi (enthroned) and shokheni (dwelt), the yods of both of which are superfluous. Cf. Filwarg. If this is what I.E. meant then he must have quoted Rashi from memory and erred. However, it is possible that what I.E. means is that Rashi offered no other instance of two words ending in a yod coming from the same root, one word vocalized with a kubbutz, the other with a kamatz, with the yod of one superfluous and the yod of the other a first person pronominal suffix.
12 According to Rashi ve-zimrat (and song) is to be rendered, and vengeance. Rashi connects ve-zimrat to zamar, which means to prune or cut. God, as it were, pruned Israel’s enemies.

13 Rashi reads our verse as one clause. The problem with this reading is that the second part of the sentence starts with va-yehi (and he is become), which usually opens a new clause. Hence Rashi points out that va-yehi at times has the meaning of hayah, which continues a thought rather than starting a new clause.
14 Wherein va-yissa (lifted up), which is grammatically similar to va-yehi, does not begin a new clause but rather continues a thought.
15 Knows when an inverted imperfect such as va-yehi or va-yissa can be used with the meaning of hayah or nasa and when it cannot, for Hebrew and Arabic are sister languages.
16 That is, to connect part a and b of the line and read it as one clause. Hence va-yehi li li-shu’ah cannot mean: became my salvation, but rather, And He is become my salvation.
17 In other words, contra Rashi, ozzi and uzzi mean the same.
18 With a kubbutz.
19 Vocalized with a furtive kamatz.

20 Ozzekha is the word oz plus the second person pronominal suffix. Similarly, ozzi is the word oz plus the first person pronominal suffix. This contra Rashi, who maintains that the yod of ozzi is superfluous.
21 In other words, ve-zimrat (and song) is short for ve-zimrati (and my song).
22 Hence ve-zimrat cannot be in the construct with Yah, for if ve-zimrat were in the construct with Yah it would be vocalized with a pattach rather than with a kamatz.
23 According to Rabbi Moses.
24 For shenat is short for shenati (my sleep).
25 Rather than with a pattach. If shenat were vocalized with a pattach it would be in the construct.
26 Rather than with a pattach.
27 For nachalat is short for nachalati (my heritage).
28 According to Rabbi Moses.
29 Rather than with a pattach.
30 For menat is short for menati (my portion).

31 Once it is established that a word ending in kamatz tav is occasionally in the construct it is possible to interpret ve-zimrat as being in the construct with Yah. Hence there is no need for the novel interpretation that ve-zimrat is short for ve-zimrati.
32 I.E. makes this point throughout his commentary.
33 Ve-zimrat is in the construct with ozzi, which is carried over from the first part of the verse.
34 Literally, my strength, and the song of my strength is the Lord.
35 I.E. interprets the song of my strength to mean: the glory of my strength.
36 Cf. I.E. on Ex. 3:15.
39 Which means I will be, and is also one of the names of God. See Ex. 3:14.

40 The point is, since God’s name comes from the root heh, yod, heh, the form YHVH was used for God’s name rather than YHYH, which means he will be, and is frequently employed in speech. Filwarg suggests emending our textto read: since the word yihyeh is frequently employed in speech it was necessary for a vav to be substituted for a yod in God’s glorious name.
41 Short for YHVH. What I.E. means by Yah are the letters yod heh.
42 It is known that Yah is short for yehi (let there be) (Filwarg). Filwarg suggests emending to: The word yehi is likewise frequently employed.
43 Because it precedes a heh.

44 Since Yah is short for YHVH, its shortened form should be YHY (yehi), as YHVH is really YHYH (which stands for yehiyeh), the vav being substituted for a heh. Hence I.E.’s comment. For I.E.’s explanation of the divine name see I.E. on Ex. 3:15.
45 And a vav was not substituted for it as in the full name of God (Filwarg).

46 If the letters of the name Yah are spelled out and then computed they come to 26. The latter is the same as the numerical equivalent of the letters making up the divine name YHVH. Yah is spelled yod heh. Yod heh spelled out = 26. That is, yod spelled out comes to 20: yod (10), vav (6), dalet (4). Heh, which is spelled heh (5), alef (1), comes to 6. The full name of God, Y (10) H (5) V (6) H (5), comes to 26. Thus Yah = YHVH.
47 See I.E. on Ex. 3:15.
48 El (God) means power. Hence Eli (my God) means my power. See I.E. on Ex. 3:15.
49 I will erect for Him a temple. I.E. connects ve-anvehu (and I will glorify Him) to naveh (habitation), hence his translation. See Onkelos and Rashi.
50 In other words, “my father” refers to the patriarchs.
51 Or an entity. I.E. makes a similar point in his comments on Gen 15:10. Translating ish as a being obviously eliminates an anthropomorphism.
52 Cf. Krinsky and Weiser.
53 After God does a wondrous thing people speak of it and His name thus becomes known.
55 See notes on I.E. Ex. 3:3.
56 Hence the meaning of yam suf is the Sea of Flags or the Sea of Reeds.
57 This is Yefet’s assumption.
58 Hence the meaning of yam suf is the Sea of Suf.

59 Chinnereth was the name of a city. See Jud. 19:35. The area around the city was called the land of Chinnereth (I Kings 15:20). The sea adjacent to this area was called the Sea of Chinnereth. Similarly, the Talmud refers to it as the Sea of Tiberias (Megillah 6a) because the city of Tiberias is situated on it shores.
60 The bottom of the ocean floor.
61 According to the rules of grammar the word should have read yekhasyumo. Compare, timla’emo, torishemo (v. 9).
62 Wherein a shuruk has been substituted for a cholam, for the word should have read ta’avori.
63 Translated according to I.E.
64 It has no meaning. Scripture could have employed nedar as it does i n verse 11.
65 Which is superfluous. The word akhzari is found in Is. 13:9; Jer. 6:23; Prov. 11:17; and elsewhere in Scripture. Scripture uses the term akhzar in Deut. 32:33; Job 30:21; 41:2; and Lam. 4:3.
66 The line repeats itself in Ps. 92:10.
67 The line repeats itself in Ps. 93:3.
68 The verse should be interpreted, Thy right hand, O Lord who art glorious in power.
69 They claim that the verse should be interpreted, Thy right hand, O Lord, which is glorious.
70 The reference is to the waters of the Jordan that split so that Israel could enter Canaan.
71 Translated according to I.E.
72 In the heart of the sea thus means in the midst of the sea.

73 Here. For the suffix mo in timla’emo means them. Hence our verse literally reads, My soul will fill them (or satisfy them). However, this was not Pharaoh’s intention. Pharaoh’s intention was to be full of their wealth. Hence our text should have read: My soul will be full of them; i.e., I will be full of their wealth.
74 Nafshi (my lust) may also be translated as, my person or my soul.
75 In other words, even though the suffix mo means them we can interpret it to mean from them or of them. We can thus interpret timla’emo to mean full of them rather than will fill them.

76 The suffix ni means me. Thus yetza’uni literally means: gone forth me. However, this is not the meaning of the word in the context of the verse. Its meaning is, gone forth of me. We thus see that Scripture sometimes employs a direct object suffix with the meaning of an indirect object. The same is true of timla’emo.
78 In other words, I will be full of them means: I will be full of their spoils.
79 The root mem, lamed, alef doesn’t only mean to fill. It also means to presume. In our verse it is used in the latter sense.
80 Thus timla’emo means: will carry out my intentions. Hence timla’emo nafshi means: I will carry out my intentions upon them or, according to J.P.S., my lust shall be satisfied upon them.
81 Satisfying his lust upon them.
82 The root of torishemo is yod, resh, shin. This root also has the meaning of to inherit, hence I.E.’s comment.
83 Translated according to I.E.
84 Thus nashafta ve-ruchakha literally means: you “nighted” with a wind.

85 This comment presents a problem. If tzalelu is the verbal form of metzolot (depths) then its meaning is, they sank. This being the case, what connection is there between tzalelu in our verse and tzalelu in Hab. 3:16, which means quivered? Krinsky suggests reading metzilot (bells, cymbals) (Zech. 14:20) rather than metzolot (depths). Indeed, I.E. connects tzalelu in Hab. 3:16 to metziltayim (cymbals). According to Krinsky we should read, “Tzalelu (they sank) comes from the same root as metzilot (bells, cymbals).” In other words, tzalelu means they tingled, and the meaning of our verse is, they tingled like lead in the mighty waters; i.e., they cried and shrieked as they drowned as if they were lead cymbals. The point is, they did not die quietly.
86 If we accept Krinsky’s emendation then we should render, they tingled.
87 Its root being ayin, peh, resh.
88 For the six other metals see I.E. on Ex. 3:15 and the notes thereto.
89 They decompose in the ground.
90 Spoken of elsewhere in Scripture. See Ps. 29:1.
91 Spoken of in the previous verse. Literally, what is the wonder?
92 I.E.’s description of the fate of the Egyptians.
93 The verse speaks of God bringing Israel to His holy habitation. It thus deals with the future. I.E. interprets Thou in thy love hast led as: Thou in thy love will lead.
94 For the prophet speaks of the future as if it already has come to pass. See I.E. on Gen. 48:22.
95 God, out of love for His people, caused the pillar of cloud and the pillar of fire to lead Israel.

96 This refers to I.E.’s opening comment that Scripture uses a perfect in place of an imperfect. I.E. now suggests that the Pentateuch uses a perfect because it speaks of the past; i.e., up to this point God lovingly led Israel i n their march to His holy habitation.
97 J.P.S. renders journey.
98 In other words, the root nun, heh, lamed means to lead.
99 On their journey to the promised land.
100 In other words, Philistia is short for the land of Philistia. Peleshet (Philistia) is the name of a nation, hence I.E.’s comment that here it refers to their country (Krinsky).
101 It indicates that Scripture speaks of a country.
102 As it is in our verse.
103 Or rams. Thus ele mo’av (the mighty men of Moab) literally means the rams of Moab.
104 The rams lead the sheep.
105 See I.E.’s comment on verse 14.
106 Like the inhabitants of Philistia. See I.E.’s comments on verse 14 and the notes thereto.
107 For Canaan is short for the land of Canaan.
108 Canaan is the last mentioned in verse 15.
109 For He spoke unto them refers only to Moses and Aaron even though Samuel is also mentioned in the verse. See I.E. on Gen. 20:17 and Ex. 7:7.
110 Not to Amasa, although both are mentioned in the verse.
111 Not to Abimelech. See I.E. on Gen. 20:17.

112 I.E. had to take the trouble to say all of this, i.e., that the verse does not refer to the Canaanites even though they are the last nation mentioned in the previous verse, and then he had to offer other similar instances.
113 Which implies that the verse speaks of the march to and not the conquest of Canaan.
114 Edom and Moab.
116 As a tree takes root in the ground and remains there permanently, hence the use of the term titta’emo (plantest them).
117 Literally, the goodly mountain and Lebanon. In the mountain thus refers to the land of Canaan, which is mountainous.
118 The mountain in Jerusalem upon which the Holy Temple was built.
119 The verse literally reads, a place for a dwelling Thou hast made. I.E. thus explains that the word order has to be rearranged. He then interprets the rearranged word order.
120 See Mekhilta Ex. 10, “The Sanctuary below is directly opposite the Throne above.” Also see Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:5 and Rashi.
121 I.E.’s interpretation of the rabbinic text quoted in the previous note. According to I.E. the greater the star, the more important the place under it (Krinsky).

122 The greater the star over a place, the greater the importance of the place (Weiser). I.E. believed that the Temple was under the influence of the sphere wherein all the stars are embedded. Hence its site was the most important place on earth (Krinsky).
123 In our verse, which has a dagesh in the kof.
124 Which does not have a dagesh in the kof but has one in the dalet. Mikdash is the form for sanctuary used throughout Scripture. The form mikkedash is found only here.

125 The mem in mittoharo, like the mem of mikkedash, is a form mem and not a prepositional mem. Hence the dagesh following it, like the dagesh which follows the mem in mikdash, is superfluous. If the mem of mittoharo or mikkedash was a preposition then the dagesh following it would not be superfluous, for it would be in place of a nun. For the prepositional mem is in place of the word min (from).
126 In mikkedash.
127 A dagesh kal, as does the dalet of mikdash.
128 Of mikkedash.

129 Because of its dagesh. A dagesh kal follows a sheva nach (quiescent sheva). It does not follow a mobile sheva (sheva na). Hence mikdash, which is vocalized with a quiescent sheva, has a dagesh in its dalet whereas mikkedash, which is vocalized with a mobile sheva, does not.
130 In his commentary on the letter nun, in the Sefer Ha-Tzachot, I.E. notes that shetayim is the only word in Hebrew in which a sheva na is followed by a word with a dagesh.
131 The meaning of The sanctuary, O Lord, which Thy hands have established is the same as The place, O Lord, which Thou hast made for Thee to dwell in.
132 Mentioned in the previous verse.
133 Literally, forever and until.
134 Va-ed is a variant of ve-ad.
135 In le-olam va-ed.
136 With another word. For the word is a preposition and it seems strange to end a phrase with it.
137 Here too ad, a variant of ed, is not in the construct.
138 That is, a kamatz. I.E. occasionally refers to the kamatz as a pattach (Krinsky).
139 Hence the word reads va-ed rather than ve-ed.
140 That is, a kamatz.
141 Vocalized with a pattach.
142 Vocalized with a tzere. In other words, the pattach changes to a tzere at the end of a sentence. Similarly, the word ad is vocalized ed at the end of a sentence.
143 Rather than le-olam va-ad.
144 Even though it is in prose. It was for the latter reason that Nahmanides does not interpret it as part of the song. See Nahmanides and Shadal on this verse.
145 Namely, that Israel was crossing the Red Sea at the same time that the Egyptians were drowning.
146 See I.E. on Ex. 14:29.
147 Contrary to the Midrashic opinion that Pharaoh survived.
148 Scripture thus clearly states that Pharaoh drowned.
149 Hence they no longer needed the pillars.
150 In which we find a description of Israel’s journey. See Num. 8:15-22.

151 In other words, Moses rather than the pillars now guided Israel. It is I.E.’s opinion that the pillars led Israel from the time they left Egypt till they came to the Red Sea, and that from the Red Sea to Sinai Moses led Israel. When the Tabernacle was erected the pillars of cloud and fire descended upon it, and the pillar of cloud once again led Israel. See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 13:21.
152 Listed in Num. 33:14,15.
153 Israel journeyed from Sinai on the 21st of Nisan until the first of Sivan when they came to the desert of Sinai.
154 At that time of year in the wilderness.
155 At this time of year.
156 As I.E. goes on to explain, they were informed by Moses that they would spend the fall and winter at Sinai.
157 See I.E. on Ex. 25:5.
158 According to Rabbi Ishmael the booths spoken of in Lev. 23:43 refer to the “clouds of glory.” Cf. Sukkah 34:4. I.E. disagrees.
159 For an explanation of Rabbi Ishmael’s opinion see Nahmanides on Lev. 24:43.
160 See I.E. on Lev. 23:43.
161 A pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night.
162 Mekhilta, Be-Shallach 1.

163 See I.E. on Ex. 13:20. I.E. insists that the wilderness of Shur is to be identified with the wilderness of Etham because he wants to harmonize verses 22 and 23 with Num. 33:8. For the latter states, and (Israel) passed through the midst of the sea into the wilderness; and they went three days’ journey in the wilderness of Etham, and pitched in Marah. See I.E.’s comments on verse 23.
164 One named Shur and the other Etham. The wilderness was named after these cities. At times it is called after one, at other times after the other.
165 Shur and Etham.

166 That the desert had two names, Shur and Etham. For, the line and they went three days in the wilderness (of Shur) is parallel to and they went three days’ journey in the wilderness of Etham (Num. 33:8).
167 That the desert spoken of is Shur.
168 Which indicates the subject, i.e., the wilderness mentioned earlier in the verse, namely, the wilderness of Shur. Cf. Vat. Ebr. 38.
169 In other words, Num. 33:11 and Ex. 15:22 refer to the same event.
170 Thus the wilderness of Shur is to be identified with the wilderness of Etham.
171 Literally, Therefore he called the name of it Marah. The question is who? Hence I.E.’s comment.
172 The verse is abridged.
173 Literally: whom she bore unto Levi. Here too the subject is missing and the verse should be interpreted as whom someone bore unto Levi.
174 Which is a nifal and is similarly vocalized.
175 The root of which is kaf, vav, nun. Similarly, the root of va-yillonu is lamed, vav, nun.
176 A two-letter root. That is, its root is lamed, vav, nun. However, the vav is usually dropped in the conjugation. Hence it appears to have only two letters (Weiser, Krinsky).
177 That is, its root may be described as a double root or as a root in which the middle letter is dropped.

178 Nun, lamed, nun. I.E. makes this point because there is a dagesh in the lamed. Now one might argue that the dagesh in the lamed is not the dagesh of the nifal conjugation but rather a dagesh that compensates for a missing nun, as in va-yippelu from the root nun, peh, lamed.
179 That is, it would have been conjugated as a root whose first letter is a nun. However, it is not. Hence it has to be taken as an ayin vav in the nifal.
180 Contrary to the rabbis in the Midrash who identify the tree as a willow, olive, pomegranate, or date tree. See Mekhilta, Be-Shallach 1; Yalkut Shimoni on Ex. 15:25.
181 If we knew for a fact that Scripture deals with water gathered in a pool or the like.

182 However, it is equally possible that our text deals with running water. In the latter case we can’t maintain that the waters were medicinally sweetened because what was healed moved on and new bitter water replaced it.
183 That it was a miracle. See Yalkut Shimoni on Ex. 15:25.
184 He might be taken to refer to Moses, hence I.E.’s comment.
185 This refers to the lack of water which the Israelites suffered.
186 Which is preceded by that He might afflict thee.
187 To those who showed their love for God by not murmuring against Moses.
188 As in our verse where the word le-kol (to the voice of) follows shamo’a tishma (diligently hearken).
189 J.P.S. renders customs.
190 In other words, the meaning of and keep all his statutes is: and you will not imitate the practices of the nations.
191 After the first plague struck.
192 At Marah.
193 Seventy palm trees would not suffice for a such a large population. Hence Saadiah Gaon says that there were 70 species of palm trees there, each species consisting of numerous trees.
194 There were 70 types of palm trees for every tribe.
195 There were 70 palm trees per person.
196 There is thus no reason to assume that Israel found a forest of palm trees in the wilderness vast enough to feed a large nation.
197 In other words, there are no dates on the palm trees in the month of Iyyar. Thus Scripture does not imply that Israel ate from the palm trees. Hence there is no reason to exaggerate their number.

198 I.E. offers no proof for this. He may base his opinion on the fact that Scripture does not note here that Israel camped in Marah. (However, Scripture does so in Num. 33:8). It rather mentions Marah as a place that Israel passed by on the way to Elim.

199 Israel journeyed from Elim on the 15th of Iyyar (16:1). There are 24 days from the 21st of Nisan, when Israel crossed the Red Sea, to the 15th of Iyyar. Israel journeyed for three days without water (v. 22) and spent one day at Marah. Hence they spent about 20 days at Elim.
200 To emphasize that their main camp at this time was at Elim.
201 That is, where they spent the longest period of time from the crossing of the Red Sea up to this point.
202 Listed in Num. 8:12-16.
203 There are 15 days from the 15th of Iyyar until the first of Sivan, when Israel came to Sinai.
204 This should be emended to read Sin, Israel’s first stop on the way to Sinai. If it is not emended then I.E. lists Israel final destination first.
205 See I.E. on Ex. 19:1.
206 I.e., contrary to the opinion of the commentaries quoted earlier, Scripture does not mention the palm trees to inform us that Israel ate of them.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 16
chapter.p: 1. AND THEY TOOK THEIR JOURNEY. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that the reason Scripture mentions the fifteenth day of the second month is to inform us that Israel left Egypt on the fifth day of the week.1 Now, the first day of Nisan fell on a Thursday2 and Iyyar on a Friday and on a Sabbath.3 Israel came to the wilderness of Sin4 on a Sabbath5 and complained6 upon camping. Moses then told them that they would eat meat at even7 and that manna would come down in the morning.8 Now it is logical to assume that the manna first came down on a Sunday because Scripture states, And it shall come to pass on the sixth day (v. 5), the reference being to the sixth day of the week and the sixth day from the day on which the manna began to descend.9 We will accept that which the Gaon says because of tradition,10 not because of his explanation, for who told the Gaon that the manna came down on the morning following the coming of the Israelites to the wilderness of Sin?11 The Israelites may have camped there for four or more days12 but the manna started to come down on Sunday. The latter is so because we start the count13 from the day that the manna began to fall,14 for all the nations rely on Israel with regard to this numeration.15 Observe, the Christians named the days of the week after the stars.16 However, they did not do the same with the Sabbath day. The first five days of the week in Arabic are numbered. The sixth day is called al juma17 because it is the most honored day of the week for the Arabs and they congregate on this day. The Arabs refer to the day of shabbat as sabbat because the shin and samekh interchange in their script. They learned this18 from the Israelites. Behold, the natives of India, who do not have the belief of six days of creation, begin the week on Wednesday because the sun is the star of that day and according to their beliefs it rules over them.

2. AND THE WHOLE CONGREGATION OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL MURMURED. The Israelites murmured only against Moses at the waters of Marah (Ex. 15:23)19 because it was he alone who led Israel onward.20 Only a part of Israel and not the whole nation complained.21 Scripture therefore reads, And the people22 murmured against Moses (Ex. 15:24). However, in the wilderness of Sin we find that Scripture states, And the whole congregation of the children of Israel murmured against Moses and against Aaron because both of them had brought them out of the land of Egypt. In Marah they complained because of the water. However, they now complained about a lack of bread and meat because they had already consumed most of their cattle, for thirty days had passed since they left Egypt. A congregation as large as Israel could only buy food at very great expense.23
4. BEHOLD, I WILL CAUSE TO RAIN BREAD FROM HEAVEN. The bread will come down like rain from the sky.

[BREAD.] The word lechem (bread) means food. It is found used for bread itself and also for meat, as in lechem isheh (food of the offering made by fire) (Lev. 3:11). It is also used for fruit, as in Let us destroy the tree with the fruit thereof (be-lachmo) (Jer. 11:19).
[THAT I MAY PROVE THEM.] For they will daily need Me.
5. [TWICE.] The meaning of mishneh (twice) is two omers per person, for it is so written.24

6. AND MOSES AND AARON SAID. Moses and Aaron said, then shall ye know that the Lord hath brought you out from the land of Egypt because the Israelites charged, for ye have brought us forth into this wilderness (v. 3). They answered, “Observe, we will perform two signs for you, one at the evening of this very day25 and one on the morning of the morrow26 so that you will know that the Lord hath brought you out from the land of Egypt.” Scripture should have read: at even and in the morning ye shall know27 because and in the morning28 is not connected to then ye shall see the glory of the Lord.29 For as Scripture goes on to say,30 Israel saw God’s glory on that very day.
7. AND IN THE MORNING. I have already explained this.31
FOR THAT HE HATH HEARD YOUR MURMURINGS. This is connected to then ye shall see the glory of the Lord.32
AND WHAT ARE WE. What can we do? We only did what we were commanded to do. The word ve-nachnu (and we) is missing an alef.33
8. AND MOSES SAID. Moses now told them what the two signs34 would consist of.
9. COME NEAR BEFORE THE LORD. Turn35 to the wilderness.36
10. AND IT CAME TO PASS. It became clear to them that when Aaron spoke to them, they came near before the Lord. The cloud came immediately and God’s glory was seen in it.
11. AND THE LORD SPOKE. The Israelites saw that Moses went to the glory of the Lord and spoke to God.

12. I HAVE HEARD. The word telunnot is irregular in that its nun has a dagesh.37 This prophecy38 is repeated.39 Scripture had already noted,40 the Lord shall give you in the evening flesh to eat, and in the morning bread to the full. It was only repeated41 so that Israel would see the glory of the Lord.42

[AT DUSK.] The term ben ha-arbayim means, as I have already explained, at dusk.43 This verse proves my interpretation of and in the morning, then ye shall see the glory of God. (v. 7).44 For the verse states, At dusk ye shall eat flesh, and in the morning ye shall be filled with bread.45
13. AND IT CAME TO PASS AT EVEN. At the end of that very day.
THAT THE QUAILS CAME UP. Possibly from the direction of the sea.46

A LAYER OF DEW. Shikhvat (a layer) is similar to yashkiv (bring down) in Or who can bring down (yashkiv) the bottles of heaven (Job 38:37).47 It means a descent.48 Scripture elsewhere writes, u-veredet ha-tal (And when the dew descended)49 (Num. 11:9).

May the name of Chivi50 rot for saying that the manna is to be identified with what is known in the Persian tongue as tarnagbin, in Arabic as man, and in the vernacular as manna. There are many questions raised against him. First of all, no manna falls today in the wilderness of Sinai,51 for we know the location of the mountain.52 Now I have seen that which resembles manna in the kingdom of Al tzakir,53 and it only comes down in Nisan and Iyyar and in no other months.54 Additionally, if you place it in the sun it does not melt.55 Furthermore, it does not rot in the evening.56 Moreover, it is not very hard and one does not have to grind it in a pestle57 if one wants to make cakes out of it. Furthermore, it melts when placed upon the tongue.58 In addition, it does not satisfy59 because it does not produce good blood. It is only used as a medical ingredient.60 Furthermore, a double portion of manna came down on Friday.61 Moreover, the manna did not come down on the Sabbath. Furthermore, the manna came down wherever Israel camped.62 In addition, the manna crossed over the Jordan with the Israelites and did not cease to descend, according to the plain meaning of Scripture, until half the month of Nisan,63 had passed.

14. AND WHEN THE LAYER OF DEW WAS GONE UP. The meaning of va-ta’al (was gone up)64 is ceased.65 It is similar to alah (went up) in Then defiledst thou it — my couch went up (alah) (Gen. 49:4).66 The meaning of the latter verse is: from the time that you defiled my couch it was removed from me and ceased to function.67 Ta’aleni (take me away)68 in O my God, take me not away in the midst of my days (Ps. 102:25) is similar.

The dew came down first to clean the earth. When the dew was gone the manna descended. The latter69 is clearly written,70 viz., And when the dew fell upon the camp in the night, the manna fell upon it (Num. 11:9).

A FINE, SCALE-LIKE THING. Mechuspas (scale-like thing) means round shaped. It has no cognate.71 The one who says72 that mechuspas is similar to machsof (uncovering) (Gen. 30:37),73 which is spelled with a sin,74 is incorrect. For it is the manner of Hebrew to double the first and second root letters,75 as in the word yafyafita (thou art fairer)76 (Ps. 45:3), or to double the second and third stem letters, as in the word yerakrak (greenish)77 (Lev. 13:49), or to double only the third stem letter, as in sagrir (a very rainy day)78 (Prov. 27:15). However, we never find the second root letter79 doubled80 except for instances when the heh81 is silent, as in hagigi (my meditation)82 (Ps. 5:2) in which the gimel appears to be a third root letter after the heh is dropped.83 Hence it was doubled. However, we do not find the middle root letters to be doubled in words where all root letters are sounded.84

AND WHEN THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL SAW IT. Rabbi Solomon85 says that the meaning of man hu (what is it) in Arabic is, what is it? However, someone misinformed him, because the Arabic phrase for “what is it” is mah huwi, as the term man is used in Arabic exclusively in reference to people. The way to explain man is to note that it comes from the same root as minnah (appointed) in who hath appointed your food and your drink (Dan. 1:10).86

[AND MOSES SAID UNTO THEM.] Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that we know that the Torah is not written in chronological order. Thus the meaning of And Moses said unto them is: and Moses had previously said unto them.87 There are many similar instances.88 Indeed, we find that Scripture states in this very portion, and it bred worms and rotted, the meaning of which is: and it bred worms and had previously rotted.89 Indeed, Scripture states, and it did not rot, neither was there any worm in it (v. 24).90 Scripture delayed reporting the words of Moses91 because it had to elaborate and go on to say, This is the thing which the Lord hath commanded, etc. (v. 16).92
[GATHER YE OF IT EVERY MAN ACCORDING TO HIS EATING.] This was to be done by logical estimate.93 An omer for a head was for someone fully grown, for minors gather according to how much they consume.94

17. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL DID SO. According to the plain meaning of the text some gathered more and some less according to the number of people in their tents. However, our sages said that our verse speaks of a miracle.95
18. AND WHEN THEY DID METE IT WITH AN OMER. Each one found that he had the amount that he had estimated.96

19. AND MOSES SAID UNTO THEM: LET NO MAN LEAVE OF IT TILL THE MORNING. Its meaning is, do not leave some of the manna over to eat on the next morning. Rather, trust in the Lord that it will descend on the following day. There was no command to eat the entire omer.97 However, that which a person did not consume was to be thrown outside of his tent.
20. NOTWITHSTANDING THEY HEARKENED NOT UNTO MOSES. The word anashim (some of them) is connected to Notwithstanding they hearkened not unto Moses.98 They were few in number.99
Rabbi Merinus100 says that va-yarum (and it bred worms) comes from the same root as rimmah (worms).101
21. AND THEY GATHERED IT MORNING BY MORNING. The meaning of ve-cham ha-shemesh (and as the sun waxed hot) is: and when the day waxed hot. For the sun does not wax hot.
IT MELTED. Namas (melted) comes from a double root102 and is in the nifal.

22. AND IT CAME TO PASS. More than the usual amount of manna descended on this day, as Scripture goes on to note. Israel gathered twice as much food on this day because Moses had commanded them to do so.103 However, they did not know why.104 Also,105 Scripture states, they gathered, not they found.106

The rulers of the congregation came and told Moses that Israel did as he commanded them. They then asked Moses: What should be done with the extra portion? Why did he command them to gather twice as much food?107 How could they consume such a large amount of food?

23. AND HE SAID UNTO THEM. God has already told me that you are obligated to rest tomorrow and not do any work including the preparation of food,108 for tomorrow is a Sabbath day unto the Lord. This is God’s day109 because He rested from all His work on the seventh day. We find the same with regard to the Sabbatical year, viz., then shall the land keep a sabbath unto the Lord (Lev. 25:2).

[SABBATH.] The word shabbat is grammatically difficult. It does not belong in the paradigm of gannav (thief)110 because the tav of shabbat is a feminine suffix,111 as is proven by the phrase shabbat hi la-Adonai (it is a sabbath unto the Lord) (Lev. 23:3).112 The word shabbat113 is a noun meaning cessation.114 The following is its grammatical explanation. The word should have been spelled and vocalized shabbetet115 according to the paradigm of dalleket (inflammation) (Deut. 28:22). When one of the tavs116 was dropped the bet was vocalized with a kamatz117 to indicate that the word is feminine. It is the same, as I will explain, with the word achat (one).118
[BAKE.] The word efu (bake) is irregular. It should have followed the paradigm of asu (do).119 Behold, Moses told the rulers of the congregation120 what they should do.121

BAKE THAT WHICH YE WILL BAKE. Bake as you normally do so that you will have what to eat on this day. And see the that which ye will seethe has a similar meaning.122 Behold, prepare and cook all this according to your heart’s desire from one omer and eat as much as you need.123

AND ALL THAT REMAINETH. Lay it up till the morning and I will tell you what to do.124 Now Moses did not inform them that no manna would descend on the Sabbath day. It was only in the morning that he revealed this secret to them

25. AND MOSES SAID. Many lacking in faith erred because of this verse and said that a person is obligated to keep the Sabbath day plus the night which follows it,125 because Moses said, for to-day and not the night before is a sabbath unto the Lord. Additionally, Moses said, Tomorrow is a solemn rest (v. 23).126 They interpreted, in accordance with their view, And there was evening and there was morning one day (Gen. 1:5) to mean that the first day was not finished until the morning of the second day.127 However, they spoke incorrectly. As I have already made mention to you, Moses spoke to Israel only in accordance with their practice. Now the manner of the land of the uncircumcised128 with regard to their food, their dress, their buildings, and affairs is not the same as that of the Land of Israel. It is the practice in the Land of Israel that no one bakes, cooks, or does any other work, both in summer or winter, at any time but during the day.129 Hence Moses said, Tomorrow is a solemn rest.130

Now pay close attention to understand the stupidity of those who explain and there was evening and there was morning in the manner which I noted above. For Scripture says, And God called the light day (Gen. 1:8), the reference being from the time that the sun rises until the time that it sets; and to the darkness He called night, the reference being from the time that the sun sets until the time that it rises. The night is thus the opposite of day, as the darkness is the opposite of the light. This being the case, how can Scripture refer to the evening, which commences at the time that the sun sets and lasts until the morning, as “day” when it is then night? Behold, concerning such people Scripture states, They change the night into day (Job 17:12).

Now note that the word day is used in Hebrew in two ways. I have already mentioned one of them, viz., as long as the light of the sun is over any place on the earth. Therefore Scripture states, three days, night and day (Esth. 4:16) and, and night and day (Gen. 8:22). Now if the measure of the day includes the night in it, why mention night?131 It is also incorrect from the point of view of the science of linguistics132 for a noun to refer to two things which are the opposite of each other.133

The word day is used secondarily in the sense of close or far-off time, as in on the day that I smote all the first-born in the land of Egypt (Num. 3:13); thou art to pass over the Jordan this day (Deut. 9:1); and cast them into another land, as it is this day (Deut. 29:27); And it shall come to pass in that day (Is. 7:21). There are many other similar instances.

Now let us leave all these things aside and seek, as I have said, only after the day of the Torah,134 for our years are not established according to the movement of the sun and moon but rather according to what the Bet Din decrees.135 Now we find that Scripture states, Seven days shall ye eat unleavened bread (Ex. 12:15). Scripture then goes on to explain that this number136 begins on the evening of the fourteenth of the first month (Ex. 12:18). Scripture also states, from even unto even, shall ye keep your sabbath (Lev. 23:32).137 Furthermore, a man who has a seminal emission during the night or day, for it is so written, viz., that which chanceth him by night (Deut. 23:11), does not become “clean” until sunset, which is the end of the first day.138 Now if it were so,139 namely, that the first day ends on the morning of the next day,140 then it is only fit for the one who experienced an emission to immerse himself in the morning.141 For if we say that the day and the night which follows it make up one day then the one who experienced an emission142 will be “unclean” for half a day143 and clean for half a day.144 And one who experienced an emission at the beginning of the night will be unclean for half of a day that passed145 and also for half of the coming day.146 This is the opinion of those who err.147 I have already explained to you the meaning of and there was evening and there was morning (Gen. 1:5) in its place.148

AND MOSES SAID. Moses now explained to them what they should do with the additional manna which was laid up, and he revealed to them its secret, that they would not find it this day because it did not come down.
26. SIX DAYS SHALL YE GATHER IT. It shall always be as it is now for as long as you are in the wilderness; that is, ye shall gather it for six days but on the seventh no manna shall come down.
[IN IT THERE SHALL BE NONE.] The word bo (in it) is added for additional clarification. It is similar to but of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not eat of it (Gen. 2:17).149
27. AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE SEVENTH DAY. Of the manna’s appearance.150
THAT THERE WENT OUT…TO GATHER. To see whether Moses’ words would stand up.
28. AND THE LORD SAID UNTO MOSES. Moses was Israel’s representative.151 The meaning of our verse is: the Lord said unto Moses, tell the following to the Israelites.
[MY COMMANDMENTS.] This was said in reference to the people who left some of the manna over until the morning.152
[MY LAWS.]153 For God taught them the reason for the Sabbath.154 They therefore gathered twice as much bread on the sixth day.

There is a reason why Scripture employs the plural, namely, My commandments and My laws.155 All the commandments and laws are, beyond any doubt, to be taken literally. However, they have secret meanings pertaining to the soul that only the enlightened can understand. Thus every commandment has two meanings.156

29. SEE. Its meaning is: see the wonder that the Lord will perform for you so that it shall become clear to you that God commanded you to rest as He rested when He made all things in the beginning. God is therefore permitting twice as much manna to come down today as normally comes down every day.
ABIDE YE EVERY MAN IN HIS PLACE. In one’s tent.
[LET NO MAN GO OUT OF HIS PLACE.] It meaning is: let no man go out of his place on the seventh day to gather manna as the men who went out to gather did.157
[30.] SO THE PEOPLE RESTED. Scripture tells us that from that day on, no man went out on the Sabbath to gather.158
31. AND THE HOUSE OF ISRAEL CALLED THE NAME THEREOF MANNA. Behold, Scripture previously noted the miracles associated with the manna.159 It now turns to relate its praises.

[AND IT WAS LIKE CORIANDER SEED, WHITE.] Some say that gad (coriander) refers to kosbarta, in Arabic, kusbar. Others say that it means mustard. However, I do not know, as it is not found in any other context save in reference to the manna. The same is the case with the word tzappichat (wafers), which Saadiah Gaon says means an unleavened wafer. Now when the manna was eaten as it was when it came down, it had the taste of a wafer made with honey. However, when cooked it had the taste of a cake baked in oil (Num. 11:8). Scripture mentions these two delicacies.160

32. AND MOSES SAID. This chapter should have followed the account of the construction of the Tabernacle.161 It was placed here to relate the miracle of the manna162 lasting for generations.163 Now Moses told this to Israel.164 He therefore said, wherewith I fed you.165
33. A JAR. A clay or copper utensil. The word is not found elsewhere.
[BEFORE THE LORD.] Its meaning is, before the divine glory which is upon the cherubim.

34. AS THE LORD COMMANDED MOSES. Scripture here explains that before the Lord means: before the Testimony, the reference being to the ark. The ark is referred to as the Ark of the Testimony because of the tablets of the covenant166 that were in it.

35. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. This miracle167 was greater than all the other miracles that were done via Moses, for many miracles were connected with the manna. These miracles, unlike all other wonders, lasted for forty years.

[UNTIL THEY CAME TO A LAND INHABITED.] Scripture says this for they were in the wilderness, in a land that no man passed through (Jer. 2:6).168 Now once Israel crossed the Jordan they ate the grain that they found there.169 The reason Scripture found it necessary to say, they did eat the manna, until they came unto the borders of the land of Canaan is that the manna accompanied them until they came to Gilgal,170 which lies on the border of the land of Canaan. The manna then ceased to fall, for now they had new grain.
36. NOW AN OMER IS THE TENTH PART OF AN EPHAH. Scripture mentions this measurement because one omer per person was sufficient for satiation.
