chapter.title: CHAPTER 17
chapter.p: 1. JOURNEYED. Scripture is being brief in saying by their stages. For from the wilderness of Sin Israel journeyed to Dophkah; from there to Alush, and from Alush they went to Rephidim.1
[ACCORDING TO THE COMMANDMENT OF THE LORD.] Its meaning is, as I have already noted,2 via the hand of Moses.3

2. WHEREFORE THE PEOPLE STROVE. Scripture mentions the people, not all of the people as it does with regard to the manna,4 for there were two parties. One had no water to drink. This is the group5 that strove with Moses. The second group had water which they brought from Alush. This group,6 as Scripture goes on to say,7 wanted to test God and see if He would provide water.
GIVE US WATER. They spoke to Moses and Aaron.8 There was no need to mention Aaron,9 for I have already explained that Moses spoke to Israel only through Aaron.10
[WHY STRIVE YE WITH ME?] Moses answered them,11 Why strive ye with me? Let us all cry out unto the Lord.12 He said, wherefore do ye try the Lord? to those who wanted to test God.13
3. AND THE PEOPLE THIRSTED. When the thirst overpowered them they raged against Moses and accused him of doing them evil in bringing them out of Egypt.14

4. AND THE PEOPLE CRIED…THEY ARE ALMOST READY TO STONE ME. Scripture speaks metaphorically.15 Its meaning is: they have striven with me and they rage against me. If they had the power they would stone me.

5. AND THE LORD SAID. Some say that because Moses said, they are almost ready to stone me, God told him, Pass on before the people who strive with you and inform them that you will now give them water.16
AND TAKE WITH THEE OF THE ELDERS OF ISRAEL; AND THY ROD, WHEREWITH THOU SMOTEST THE RIVER. By command.17
6. BEHOLD, I WILL STAND BEFORE THEE THERE UPON THE ROCK IN HOREB. Its meaning is, you will find Me there, the idea being you will encounter My strength and power on Horeb.18
AND THOU SHALT STRIKE THE ROCK. Which contains no water.19
[AND MOSES DID SO.] Scripture is being brief, for it does not mention, and the congregation drank, and their cattle (Num. 20:11).20
7. CALLED. Moses or someone.21
MASSAH AND MERIBAH. Because of the two reasons noted.22

It is the style of the Hebrew language to begin its comments with the second of two items when two particulars are listed,23 as the second item is at hand. Compare, And I gave unto Isaac Jacob and Esau (Josh. 24:4), which is followed by and I gave unto Esau (Ibid.). Scripture similarly first mentions Massah and then Meribah and turns to explain that the name of the place was called Meribah because of the striving of the children of Israel with Moses. It then explains that the place was called Massah because they tried the Lord. Now “trial” refers to Israel’s asking, Is the Lord among us to provide for all of our needs? This second party angered God more than the first.24 Scripture therefore says, Ye shall not try the Lord your God, as ye tried Him in Massah (Deut. 6:16).25
8. THEN CAME AMALEK. The reference is to the nation of Amalek, which dwelleth in the land of the South (Num. 13:29).26

9. AND MOSES SAID UNTO JOSHUA. Joshua was the grandson27 of Prince Elishama ben Ammihud, the possessor of the banner of the tribe of Ephraim.28 Scripture refers to him here as Joshua,29 which is the name by which Moses called him in the account of the spies.30
CHOOSE US OUT. It is Hebrew style to speak in this manner.31 Compare, choose thee (II Sam. 24:12); Tarry ye here for us (Ex. 24:14).
MEN. Renowned, powerful men and men of war, as in all of them men (Num. 13:3).
AND GO OUT, FIGHT WITH AMALEK. Go out from the camp of Israel to fight against Amalek.
I WILL STAND ON TOP OF THE HILL. Horeb, which is the same as Mount Sinai.
WITH THE ROD OF GOD IN MY HAND. With which I will lift my hand to pray.
10. SO JOSHUA DID. Aaron and Hur are mentioned because of the need to explain (they) stayed up his hands (v. 12).32

11. AND IT CAME TO PASS. Some say that Moses held his hand33 up in a manner similar to one holding up a banner in war.34 However, if this was the case then Aaron or Hur would have lifted the rod up or they would have placed it on a high place on the mountain so that the people would see it standing. The correct interpretation is the one offered by the ancient sages.35

12. BUT MOSES’ HANDS WERE HEAVY. We know that a human being does not have the strength to hold his hands up for an entire day. One cannot even hold them up for a few hours, certainly not until the going down of the sun.36 Now Scripture notes that Moses’ hands were heavier than the hands of other old people.37 Moses thus could not continually hold his hands up.
[AND PUT IT.] Its meaning is, they strengthened his place38 because he was not able to stand up.39
AND AARON AND HUR. Stood.

Scripture employs the masculine kevedim (heavy)40 and similarly reads, mi-zeh echad u-mi-zeh echad (the one on the one side, and the other on the other side).41 Ve-hinneh yad sheluchah elai, ve-hinneh vo megillat sefer (behold, a hand was put forth unto me; and, lo, a roll of a book was therein) is similar (Ezek. 2:9).42

AND HIS HANDS WERE STEADY. Each one of his hands.43 The phrase is grammatically similar to Its branches run over the wall (Gen. 49:22)44 and But the righteous45 are secure as a young lion (Prov. 28:1).

STEADY. Emunah (steady) is a noun meaning something lasting and permanent.46 Others say that emunah comes from the same root as the word omen (brought up)47 in And he brought up Hadassah (Esth. 2:7). Aaron and Hur were like nursemaids who lifted up his hands.48

13. AND JOSHUA DISCOMFITED AMALEK. There is no difference between va-yachalosh49 (discomfited or weakened) and va-yechelash50 (weakened) (Job 14:10).51 Likewise, the word yitrof52 (tear) (Ps. 7:3) means the same as yitraf53 (tears) (Gen. 49:27).54 The same is the case with the words tiddor (voweth)55 in voweth a vow (Num. 30:4) and va-yiddar (vowed),56 which is vocalized with a pattach in and Jacob vowed a vow (Gen. 28:20). However, this root,57 like the word shav (returned), is sometimes transitive and sometimes intransitive.58 Or,59 va-yechelash (weakened) in a man (gever) dieth, and is weakened (Job 14:10) means he was already weakened,60 like the word va-yivash (and rotted)61 in and it bred worms, and rotted (Ex. 16:20). Scripture therefore employs the term gever (man), which indicates a mighty man.62

14. WRITE THIS FOR A MEMORIAL IN THE BOOK. This chapter63 was said in the fortieth year.64 The fact that Scripture reads ba-sefer (in the book) with a pattach beneath the bet65 is proof of the aforementioned. For ba-sefer refers to the well-known book, that is, the book of the Torah.66 It is also possible that they had another book67 known as The Book of the Wars of the Lord68 which was lost to us, as were the Sefer Ha-Yashar69 and the Midrash of Iddo70 and the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel71 and the works of Solomon.72
[IN THE EARS OF JOSHUA.] For God knew that Joshua was destined to wage war with the kings of Canaan.73

[FOR I WILL UTTERLY BLOT OUT THE REMEMBRANCE OF AMALEK.] Because Amalek angered God. For the chiefs of Edom and similarly those of Moab and of Philistia feared and trembled before God because of the signs which the Lord displayed in Egypt and at the sea.74 Now this very Amalek heard of the might that God displayed on behalf of His people Israel. Behold, he came from a distant place to wage war against Israel. He did not fear God. Indeed, Scripture explicitly states, and he (Amalek) feared not God (Deut. 25:18).75 Some say that Amalek was the name of a king.76 They say this because Scripture reads, Amalek and his people. On the other hand, it is possible that another nation joined Amalek.77
15. AND MOSES BUILT AN ALTAR. On Horeb. The word mizbe’ach (altar) is to be read as if written twice. Our verse is to be read as if written, mizbach Adonai (the altar of the Lord).78

16. THE HAND UPON THE THRONE OF THE LORD. It is as if God put His hand upon His throne. This was the taking of an oath.79 It is similar to For I lift up My hand to heaven (Deut. 32:40).80 Rabbi Joshua says that its81 meaning is that the first one to sit upon the throne of Israel, the reference being to Saul,82 will have a mighty hand.83 We similarly find it said concerning Solomon: Then Solomon sat on the throne of the Lord (I Chron. 29:23).
chapter.ftnote: 1 See Num. 33:12-14. In other words, by their stages alludes to all the places that Israel stopped between Sin and Rephidim.
2 See I.E. on Ex. 15:22.
3 Moses alone, rather than the pillars of cloud and fire, now led the people.
4 See Ex. 16:2.
5 The people mentioned in our verse.
6 The second group did not strive with Moses.
7 In the last part of our verse.
8 The Hebrew reads, tenu (give). Tenu is in the plural, hence I.E.’s comment.
9 In our verse even though the people’s words were also directed at him. Aaron is not mentioned in our verse, hence I.E.’s comment.
10 See I.E. on Ex. 4:30.
11 The first party.
12 This, according to I.E., is implied in Why strive ye with me?
13 The second party.
14 Hence and the people murmured follows and the people thirsted.
15 Moses was not in actual danger of being stoned.
16 In this interpretation, pass on before the people is short for: pass on before the people who strive with you, etc.
17 Moses did not personally smite the river. He told Aaron to do so. See Ex. 7:19 and I.E. on Ex. 17:25.
18 Our verse is not to be taken literally. It should be understood as: you will find My strength and power upon the rock in Horeb.
19 At present.
20 As it does in recording a similar account in the wilderness of Sin.
21 Our verse literally reads, And he called the name of the place Massah and Meribah. The subject is omitted, hence I.E.’s comment.
22 In our verse Massah means trying and Meribah strife.
23 Scripture first mentions Massah and then Meribah. It then goes on to first explain Meribah and then Massah.
24 For the first complained because they were overpowered by thirst.
25 The first party is not mentioned at all in this verse.
26 And not to any other nation or person by that name. See I.E.’s comment on verse 20.

27 Reading nin, as in Vat. Ebr. 38 and in some of the printed editions. Some editions have nun. The latter is probably a scribal error. However, Filwarg believes it to be correct and tries to justify it. It is also possible that I.E. was playing on the words nin and nun, the former meaning grandson and the latter being the name of Joshua’s father.
29 His birth name was Hoshe’a. See Num. 13:16.
30 See Num. 13:16.
31 To employ the possessive pronoun, lakh (for thee) or lanu (for us) for purposes of emphasis.
32 Since Scripture goes on to note that Aaron and Hur held up Moses’ hands it first had to tell us that they went up the hill with Moses.
33 Which grasped the rod of the Lord.
34 Cf. Rashbam.

35 Moses’ raised hands served to direct the heart of Israel towards heaven. Cf. Rosh Ha-Shanah 3:8: “Now do the hands of Moses promote or hinder the battle! It is rather to teach you that when the Israelites directed their thoughts on high and subjected their hearts to their Father in heaven, they prevailed; and if not they were defeated.”
36 Therefore what purpose does Scripture have in telling us but Moses’ hands were heavy?
37 Ibn Ezra does not indicate why Moses’ hands were heavier than those of other people his age.
38 By placing a stone beneath him (Krinsky).
39 Not only were Moses’ hands tired but Moses himself was unable to stand.
40 Rather than the feminine kevedot. Yad (hand) is a feminine, hence I.E.’s comment.

41 I.E. interprets our text as meaning: one was supporting this hand and one was supporting the other hand. In other words, mi-zeh refers to the hands. However, since yad is feminine Scripture should have read mi-zot echad u-mi-zot echad.
42 Vo (therein) is masculine. However, yad is feminine. We thus see that Scripture occasionally combines feminine nouns with masculine pronouns or adjectives.

43 Yadav (his hands) is plural; emunah (steady) is singular. Hence va-yehi yadav emunah (and his hands were steady) means: and his hands was steady. I.E. holds that when a verb or an adjective in the plural governs or modifies a noun in the singular, the verb or adjective refers to each one within the plural. Hence, “and his hands was steady” means: and each one of his hands was steady. See Vol. 1, Foreword, p. xvii.

44 Banot (its branches) is plural; tza’adah (run) is singular. According to I.E., Gen. 49:22 should be translated: each one of its branches runs over the wall. See I.E. on Gen. 49:22 and the notes thereto.
45 Tzadikim (righteous) is plural; kefir (young lion) is singular. According to I.E., Prov. 28:1 should be translated: but each one of the righteous is secure as a young lion.

46 Literally, standing and everlasting. Moses’ hands turned into something firm and steadfast (Shadal), for he did not lower his hands but held them up steadily. The image is of something pillar-like.
47 The noun omen means a person who raises a child. Cf. Num. 11:12; II Kings 10:1; Is. 49:2.

48 Netter. The idea being that Aaron and Hur lifted up Moses’ hands the way a nursemaid carries a child. Thus va-yehi yadav emunah (and his hands were steady) means: and his hands were nursed by nursemaids. For other interpretations and possible translations see Weiser and Krinsky.
49 Which is an efol.
50 Which is an efal. Both words come from the root chet, lamed, shin, and may be used interchangeably.
51 Translated literally.
52 An efol.
53 An efal.
54 Translated literally. J.P.S. renders, raveneth.
55 An efol.
56 An efal.
57 Chalash, unlike taraf (tore) and nadar (vowed).
58 In our verse it is transitive. In Job 14:20 it is intransitive.

59 That is, va-yachalosh in Job 14:20 is not only intransitive but also a pluperfect. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: “Or va-yechelash means he weakened others… Scripture therefore employs gever, which indicates a mighty man.” Thus “or” introduces a new interpretation of the word va-yechelash. Whereas the previous interpretation believed it to be intransitive, this one believes it to be transitive.

60 Reading u-devar chalash acherim as Vat. Ebr. 38 does. The printed texts read: u-khvar chalash acherim (he has already weakened others). See above note. The point is va-yechelash is a pluperfect. Translated according to I.E., our verse should be interpreted: the mighty man (gever) who killed others dieth. Or, the mighty man weakened and dieth.
61 Which is a pluperfect. See I.E. on Ex. 16:20 and the notes thereto.
62 For purposes of contrast. Mighty man is in contrast to dieth.
63 Verses 14-16.
64 Of Israel’s sojourn in the wilderness rather than immediately after the battle with Amalek.
65 Rather than be-sefer (in a book).
66 Which Moses completed shortly before his death.
67 And the reference is to that book rather than to the Torah. In this case it is possible for this chapter to have been written shortly after the Exodus.
68 See Num. 21:14.
69 See Josh. 10:13; II Sam. 1:18.
70 Cf. II Chron. 13:22.
71 See I Kings 14:19, 29.
72 Which were not preserved in Scripture. See I Kings 5:12.
73 And Amalek dwelt in the southern part of Canaan. See I.E. on verse 1.
75 Hence God decreed this punishment for him.
76 Not that of a nation. Hence the command to blot out Amalek (Deut. 25:19) applies only to the king and his descendants.
77 In other words, Amalek and his people means the nation of Amalek and its allies.

78 Our verse reads: And Moses built an altar, and called the name of it Adonai-nissi (the Lord is my banner). I.E. suggests that we read the verse as follows: And Moses built an altar, and called the name of it the altar of the Lord who is my banner.
79 Placing His hand upon the throne is equivalent to saying: I swear (Krinsky).
80 Raising the hand to heaven and making a statement is equivalent to swearing.

ftnote.italic: The hand upon the throne of the Lord.

chapter.ftnote: 82 Who waged war against and defeated Amalek. See I Sam. 15.
83 The meaning of our verse being: the first king that will sit on the Lord’s throne will have a mighty hand and defeat Amalek.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 18
chapter.p: The word of Abram,1 the prisoner of hope;
Who loosened his bowstring (yitro).2
Half of his courage is forever gone;
And the rest3 (yitro) was dissipated by his tortuous wanderings.
This4 is a comment5 upon the chapter
Which opens with the word Yitro (Jethro).

1. NOW JETHRO HEARD. Scripture notes above6 the incident of Amalek because Amalek came to Rephidim.7 Now the chapter that opens with the words In the third month (Ex. 19:1) should have followed the incident of Amalek,8 for Scripture states there, And when they were departed from Rephidim, and were come to the wilderness of Sinai (Ex. 19:2).9 This being the case, why was the account of Jethro inserted between these two chapters?10 Saadiah Gaon says that Jethro came to the wilderness of Sinai before the giving of the Torah.11 However, I believe that Jethro came to Sinai in the second year,12 after the erection of the tabernacle.13 For the chapter14 speaks of a burnt-offering and sacrifices for God (v. 12),15 and it does not mention that he built a new altar.16 Furthermore, Scripture writes, and I make them know the statutes of God, and His laws (v. 16).17 Now this18 took place after the giving of the Torah.19 True proof that my words are correct is the fact that Scripture clearly states, where he20 was encamped, at the mount of God (v. 5).21

Now Moses spoke to Hobab,22 the latter being Jethro as I explained in the Torah portion These Are The Names.23 For Moses’ father-in-law24 does not refer to Reuel, which precedes the term father-in-law,25 but refers to Hobab.26 Scripture clearly states, from the children of Hobab the father-in-law of Moses (Jud. 4:11). Moses told Hobab, [Leave us not, I pray thee] forasmuch as thou knowest how we are to encamp in the wilderness (Num. 10:31). Now we know that Israel camped around Sinai for about a year. Lo and behold, Moses’ very words prove this to be so. For Moses is quoted in the Torah portion, These are the words as saying, The Lord our God spoke unto us in Horeb, saying: …turn you, and take your journey (Deut. 1:6,7).27 Now this was said close to their time of journey.28 Moses continued, And I spoke unto you at that time saying: I am not able to bear you myself alone (Deut. 1:9); for the Lord your God hath multiplied you, and, behold, ye are this day as the stars of heaven for multitude (Deut. 1:10). The reason Moses mentioned this to them was that God told Jacob, Behold, I will make thee fruitful, and multiply thee, and I will make of thee a company of peoples; and will give this land to thy seed after thee for an everlasting possession (Gen. 48:4). Now the meaning of the latter is: when your seed increase I will give them the land. Moses therefore said, the Lord your God hath multiplied you and the time for you to inherit the land has come. However, since you are so numerous I was not able to carry you alone,29 and I had to place over you captains of thousands and captains of hundreds.30 Now this31 was the advice given to Moses by Jethro on the morrow following his coming to the wilderness of Sinai.32 Moses therefore said to Hobab, who, as we explained, is to be identified with Jethro, We are journeying (Num. 10:29).33 Hobab responded, I will not go; but I will depart to mine own land, and to my kindred (Num. 10:30). This is what And Moses let his father-in-law depart; and he went his way into his own land (v. 27) refers to.

I will now explain why the chapter dealing with Jethro was inserted here. It was placed here because Scripture had just mentioned the evil that Amalek did to Israel. The Torah wants to contrast it with the good that Jethro rendered Israel. Scripture notes, And Jethro rejoiced for all the goodness which the Lord had done to Israel (v. 9) and that he gave proper and correct counsel to Moses and Israel. Moses told Jethro, and thou shalt be to us instead of eyes (Num. 10:31), meaning that he enlightened their eyes.34 King Saul similarly said,35 for ye showed kindness to all the children of Israel (I Sam. 15:6).36

Now because Scripture states in the preceding chapter, the Lord will have war with Amalek from generation to generation (Ex. 17:16), namely, that when God gives Israel rest they are obligated to wage war against Amalek, the Torah mentions the account of Jethro. For the descendants of Jethro lived in proximity to the nation of Amalek,37 and the Torah wants Israel to remember the kindness that Jethro demonstrated so that they do not harm his seed. Thus we find the Rechabites, who were descended from Jethro, living among the children of Israel in Jerusalem. We find Jonadab the son of Rechab38 in the time of Jeremiah (Jer. 35:19).39 There is another chapter similar to the one above.40
ALL THAT GOD (ELOHIM) HAD DONE. Scripture employs the name of God41 that was known in the world before the appearance of Moses, for all admitted that God existed.42

AND FOR ISRAEL HIS PEOPLE. God’s people, or the people of Moses.43 It is possible that the lamed44 should be translated as “because,” that is, because of Moses and Israel, the reference being to the plagues and the drowning of Pharaoh.
HOW THAT THE LORD (YHVH) HAD BROUGHT. Scripture employs the divine name revealed to Moses, since it was through the miracles45 that Israel went out of Egypt.
2. AND JETHRO TOOK. Scripture reads, Moses’ wife, and not Jethro’s daughter, because Moses was more important than her father’s house.46

AFTER HE HAD SENT HER AWAY. Some say that Moses gave her permission to return to her father’s house, at the lodging place, prior to his returning alone to Egypt.47 Other say she sent gifts to Moses.48 Compare, shilluchim (gifts) in gifts unto his daughter (I Kings 9:16).49

3. AND. Note that those who speak the holy tongue preserve the verbal forms in all conjugations.50 However, they are not careful to do so with proper nouns.51 Therefore do not be amazed that Moses called his son Gershom because he lived (gar) there (sham).52 For look, kayin (Cain) was so called because Eve said, kaniti (I have gotten) (Gen. 4:1). However, this is grammatically incorrect.53 The name Noah, which Scripture derives from yenachamenu (shall comfort us) (Gen. 5:28),54 is even more difficult.55 Scripture at times inverts a name. Thus Hushim (Gen. 46:23) and Shuham (Num. 26:42) are one and the same. Yabetz (Jabez)56 was so called because his mother bore him in pain (otzev).57 Sometimes a letter is dropped in a name, as in the case of Maacah58 which is a variant of Micah.59 The reverse is true of Yov (Iob) (Gen. 46:13), which is the same as Yashuv60 (Jashub) (Num. 26:24). Many say it is the same61 with Shemu’el (Samuel), which62 is derived from she’iltihu (I have asked him) (I Sam. 1:20).63 However, in my opinion a shuruk has been substituted here64 for a cholam, as in the case of Tohu65 (I Sam. 1:1) and Toah66 (I Chron. 6:19); Zuph67 (I Sam. 1:1) and Zophai68 (I Chron. 6:11); Nun69 (Ex. 33:11) and Non70 (I Chron. 7:26). Now Shemu’el (Samuel) comes from sehmo el (his name is God).71 Samuel’s mother called him by God’s name because the Lord answered her request.72 Do not be amazed that a human being should be called by God’s name, for, observe, we find this to be the case with the name Zurishaddai73 (Num. 7:36). There are many other similar instances.74 In my opinion the altar which Moses built was similarly called Adonai-nissi (the Lord is my banner) (Ex. 17:15).75 Likewise, the name of the Messiah will be called Adonai-tzidkenu (the Lord is our righteousness) (Jer. 23:6). However, Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that God’s name is connected to the word yikre’o (shall call him) and the name of the Messiah will be tzidkenu (our righteousness).76 Now its correct interpretation is in keeping with the opinion of the master of the cantillical notes,77 who placed a tircha78 in the word yikre’o.79 For there is a great difference between va-yikra be-shem Adonai (and called upon the name of the Lord) (Gen. 12:8), written in connection with Abraham with a tircha beneath the word va-yikra,80 and vayikra ve-shem Adonai (and proclaimed the name of the Lord) (Ex. 34:5)81 which is written in the Book of Moses82 as I will explain in its place.83

4. AND THE NAME OF THE OTHER84 WAS. It is the custom in Hebrew to say, “This is how the second one was called.”85 At other times it uses the term “the one,” as in86 and the name of one was Bozez, and the name of the other was Seneh (I Sam. 14:4).87

[FOR THE GOD OF MY FATHER WAS MY HELP.] The word amar (he said), which should have followed the word ki (for), has been omitted in for the God of my father. Scripture does not read, “for he said the God of my father was my help” because the phrase refers to for he said: I have been a stranger (v. 3), which is written above.88 It is similar to for God hath made me fruitful (Gen. 41:52).89 I have already explained why Moses named his younger son Eliezer.90
5. AND CAME. Scripture notes that Jethro followed etiquette when he came to Moses. Jethro went first, the sons of Moses went behind him, and after them Moses’ wife, as is the custom.
WHERE HE WAS ENCAMPED. He encamped there for many days.91

6. AND HE SAID UNTO MOSES. He had already said92 unto Moses prior to his coming,93 via an agent94 or by a written message: I thy father-in-law Jethro am coming unto thee, and also thy wife, who is uppermost in importance, and her two sons who are coming with her.

7. AND MOSES WENT OUT TO MEET HIS FATHER-IN-LAW. Out of regard for Jethro and his wisdom, but not out of regard for his95 wife and children, for it is not customary for a respected person to go out to meet his wife or children.

AND BOWED DOWN. Va-yishtachu (and bowed down) is grammatically difficult.96 We know that it comes from a root ending in a heh.97 The vav in va-yishtachu98 is in place of a heh,99 like the vav of shalev (at ease)100 in I was at ease (Job 16:12), from whose root we get the word shalavti (at ease) in I was not at ease (Job 3:26). Now the term va-yishtachaveh101 should have been employed in the singular,102 rather than va-yishtachu, for the tav103 is a sign of the hitpa’el conjugation. It is like the tav in mishta’eh (steadfastly)104 in And the man looked steadfastly on her (Gen. 24:21). For the rule relating to the dentals105 states that if the first letter of a root before which the tav of the hitpa’el conjugation is placed106 is a dental, then107 [the tav is placed after the first root letter].108 Now because the heh has been changed into a vav in va-yishtachu Hebrew allows the first vav,109 which is not a plural suffix, to remain in place of the root heh110 and silences the vav.111 Hence the word reads va-yishtachu.112 Now a vav at the end of a word is the sign of the plural suffix when silent as in titra’u (look one upon the other) in Why do ye look one upon the other (Gen. 42:1). Thus the word va-yishtachu, ending in a silent vav, would appear to be in the plural. Va-yishtachu was therefore penultimately accented113 to differentiate between it and the customary way of vocalizing plurals.114
[AND BOWED DOWN.] Logically speaking, the one who goes out is the one who bows to his counterpart.115
[EACH OTHER.] Scripture refers to Jethro as Moses’ friend because of his greatness in wisdom.116
AND THEY CAME INTO THE TENT. Which was known as Moses’ tent.
8. AND MOSES TOLD. This verse indicates that the meaning of for Moses, and for Israel (v. 1) is: because of them.117

THE TRAVAIL. Tela’ah (travail) comes from the same root as ve-nilu (shall loathe)118 in and the Egyptians shall loathe (Ex. 7:18). The tav is superfluous.119 Its meaning is, an affliction which a person is unable to bear or verbalize. It refers to Egypt’s pursuit of Israel at the sea, the war with Amalek, and the thirst and hunger which the congregation suffered. God delivered them from all of these.

9. AND JETHRO REJOICED. Va-yichad (rejoiced) comes from the same root as the word chedvah (rejoicing).120 It should have been vocalized like the word va-yift (enticed) in And my heart hath been secretly enticed (Job 31:27) and va-yishb (and took captive) in and took some of them captive (Num. 21:1).121 However, the chet was vocalized with a pattach122 because it is a guttural, and the dagesh123 remains in the dalet124 as it was. I am not aware of a letter having a dagesh at the end of a word in all of Scripture except in the case of a bet, gimel, dalet, kaf, peh, tav at the end of a word when two sheva’im come together,125 as in the word va-yishb (and took captive)126 in and took some of them captive (Num. 21:1) and va-yesht (and he drank)127 in And he drank of the wine (Gen. 9:21). However, we never find a dagesh at the end of a word when preceded by a vowel128 except in the case of a pattach. In the latter case we find two such words namely, va-yichad (rejoiced) in And Jethro rejoiced and yichad (rejoice) in Let it not rejoice among the days of the year (Job 3:6).

10. AND JETHRO SAID: BLESSED BE THE LORD. Give your attention to the grammatical explanation of the word barukh (blessed). Note that the pa’ul129 can only be formed from transitive verbs. If you find a verb following the pa’ul form, look around; if you find it has a transitive po’el130 form, then the word is a real pa’ul. However, if you do not find it to be so,131 then the word132 is an adjective.133 Similarly, if a word is in the po’el form and its root does not come in the pa’ul in the same conjugation, then the word is also not a po’el but an adjective. For example, the po’el and pa’ul forms of shamar (kept) are shomer (keeps) and shamur (kept).134 Compare, shamur in riches kept by the owner thereof to his hurt (Eccles. 5:12). Now we encounter holekh (goes), omed (stands), yotze (goes out). All these words appear to be verbs in the po’el, for they follow the form of shomer. However, since these roots form intransitive verbs, for one cannot say halukh (wented), amud (stooded up), yatzu (wented out), these words do not come in the pa’ul. Therefore when Scripture uses the term holekh (went) in because he went (Num. 22:21), it employs an adjective, not a verb.

We find [Scripture using] the word atzum (mighty). The word appears to be a pa’ul because it follows the paradigm of shamur (kept). However, when we investigated this root we found the word va-ya’atzmu (waxed mighty), in and multiplied, and waxed exceedingly mighty (Ex. 1:7), to be among the intransitive verbs. For its transitive form comes in the hifil135 as in va-ya’atzimehu (and made them too mighty) in and made them too mighty for their adversaries (Ps. 105:24). Now we cannot say that otzem (strengthens) following the paradigm of shomer (keeps) means strength,136 for in this case it has a different meaning, as in otzem (shutteth) in And shutteth his eyes from looking upon evil (Is. 33:15).

Now we find the word barukh, which follows the paradigm of shamur (kept). We searched all of Scripture and we did not see this root137 used with this meaning138 in all of the kal conjugation.139 We found it used140 only with another meaning, namely, to kneel, as in va-yivrakh (kneeled) in and kneeled down upon his knees (I Chron. 6:13), which141 is also intransitive and does not have a pa’ul142 form. The word barukh (blessed) is thus like the word atzum (might), a kal adjective.

Rabbi Merinus143 says that barukh (blessed) is an adjective in the pi’el. Its resh should have received a dagesh like all other such roots,144 such as berekh (curse)145 in Naboth did curse (I Kings 21:13). Barukh follows the paradigm of shakkul (bereaved)146 in as a bear that is bereaved of her whelps (Hos. 13:8). However, Rabbi Merinus spoke incorrectly, for all adjectives such as shakkul (bereaved), gibbor (warrior), shikkor (drunk)147 do not undergo any change by having the vowel that precedes the dagesh change in the singular construct or in the plural.148 Compare, gibbor (mighty man)149 in And Zichri, a mighty man of Ephraim (II Chron. 28:7), and gibborim150 (mighty) in Woe unto them that are mighty (Is. 5:22). Now the word berukh (blessed of),151 in Come in, thou blessed of the Lord (Gen. 24:31) and berukhim (blessed) in, Blessed be ye of the Lord (Ps. 115:15), argue against Rabbi Merinus.152

WHO HATH DELIVERED YOU. He said this153 to Moses and Aaron, who were God’s messengers and through whom the plagues came upon Pharaoh and Egypt. Jethro therefore said, out of the hand of the Egyptians, and out of the hand of Pharaoh. After this154 he blessed the Lord, who hath delivered the people from under the hand of the Egyptians in Egypt and at the splitting of the Red Sea.155
11. NOW I KNOW. I have explained the meaning of now I know in the Torah portion Shemot, in the verse and they shall say to me: What is His name? (Ex. 3:13).156

[YEA, FOR THAT.] Because of the fact that the Egyptians dealt willfully with Israel.157 Jethro similarly, noted above, I know that the Lord is greater than all gods in that he punished the Egyptians because they made Israel work with rigor. It is similarly written, Thou knewest that they dealt proudly (hezidu) against them (Neh. 9:11) that is, they158 behaved like a person who does whatever he wants to.159 Scripture already stated, for I know their pains; and I am come down to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians160 (Ex. 3:7,8).
12. AND JETHRO, MOSES’ FATHER-IN-LAW, TOOK A BURNT-OFFERING AND SACRIFICES. The latter refers to peace-offerings.161
[FOR GOD.] The meaning of for God is that henceforth the revered Lord shall be his God.
AND AARON CAME, AND ALL THE ELDERS OF ISRAEL. There is no need to mention Moses, as they were in Moses’ tent.
TO EAT BREAD. Peaceofferings.
[BEFORE GOD.] Scripture reads thus because Moses’ tent was on the east side of the tabernacle.162
13. AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE MORROW. Of Jethro’s coming.
THAT MOSES SAT. As was his custom.

FROM THE MORNING UNTO THE EVENING. Note that true morning163 begins with sunrise. The term morning is, as I have previously noted,164 also applied to the breaking of dawn, when light begins to be seen in the clouds. In the latter instance the term is artificially used. Similarly, true evening begins when the sun sets. The term is also artificially applied up to the time that the light sets.165 David similarly said, The sun ariseth, they166 slink away (Ps. 104:22). Scripture then states, Man goeth forth unto his work, And to his labor until the evening (Ps. 104:23).167 It is therefore fitting to interpret from even unto even, shall ye keep your sabbath (Lev. 23:32) to mean: from the true evening to the true evening.168 However, our sages of blessed memory “added from the weekday to the holy day”169 and said that the Sabbath does not end until the stars come out.170 It is thus fitting from the Torah’s point of view to start the Sabbath at sunset. All scientists and astronomers admit that the day’s boundary is171 the moment when the circle of the sun faces all over the area of the earth. This starts at sunrise and ends at sunset.

14. AND…SAW ALL THAT HE DID TO THE PEOPLE. That he caused them to stand from morning to evening. Rabbi Solomon172 says that Jethro reacted in this manner because Moses alone sat and Israel stood, the latter being improper.173 There can be no doubt that Moses’ station was too great for Jethro to say this.174 For behold, Aaron, who was a great man in the eyes of Israel and was older than Moses, said to Moses, Oh my lord (Num. 12:11). Moses acted in the proper manner, for the judge sits and the litigants stand. We thus read, then both the men, between whom the controversy is, shall stand (Deut. 19:17). Jethro said, why175 to Moses for no reason other than that Moses was sitting alone and had no other judges to assist him.

[WHY.] Rabbi Merinus says that the word maddu’a (why) is similar to mallakhem (what mean ye) (Is. 3:15) and to mazzeh (what is that) in what is that in thy hand (Ex. 4:2), each of which is a compound of two words.176 The same is true of maddu’a, which means: what is in your mind that you do this?177

15. AND MOSES SAID. Moses answered, I do two things. One, Because the people come unto me to inquire of God, that is, to inquire of God’s law.178 The other, when they have a matter, it cometh unto me (v. 16). Moses explained the second task first, namely, and I judge between a man and his neighbor (ibid.); and, he then said,179 to one who inquires, I make them know the statutes of God.

17. AND…SAID…THE THING THAT THOU DOEST IS NOT GOOD. In my eyes. Jethro then explained himself, Thou wilt surely wear away. Navol tibbol (thou shalt surely wear away) comes from the same root as yibbol (wither)180 in And whose leaf doth not wither (Ps. 1:3) and novelet (fadeth)181 in For ye shall be as a terebinth whose leaf fadeth (Is. 1:30). Its meaning is, you shall, as it were, drop like a withered leaf. The word gam (both)182 is to be prefaced also to for the thing is too heavy for thee.183

18. TO PERFORM IT. Asohu (to perform it) is grammatically inconsistent.184 It follows the form of lishmerehu185 (to preserve him),186 for we do not find the heh to be visible in the root ayin, sin, heh.187
19. HEARKEN NOW UNTO MY VOICE, I WILL GIVE THEE COUNCIL. I’atzekha, means I will give you council.

[GOD.] Note that the term Elohim (God) is, as I have noted, an adjective.188 It is only because the word is used often that this adjective is considered as if it were a proper noun. Examples of the latter are: Elohim (God) in God will let me gaze upon my adversaries (Ps. 59:11); In the beginning God (Elohim)created the heaven and the earth (Gen. 1:1), and many other instances. It is for this reason that our sages of blessed memory placed Elohim among the names that are not erasable.189

[AND GOD BE WITH THEE.] Its meaning is, God will help you if you act in this manner. At the close of his words, Jethro told Moses to ask permission of God to act in accordance with Jethro’s counsel. This is what Jethro meant by and God command thee so (v. 23). There is no doubt that Moses did so.190
[BE THOU FOR THE PEOPLE.] The meaning of la-am191 is, for the people.
BEFORE GOD. From God’s side.192

AND BRING THOU THE CAUSES UNTO GOD. If they be difficult. These are the things that Moses mentioned at first,193 viz., when they have a matter, it cometh unto me (v. 16). Jethro then explained this194 to him,195 viz., the hard causes they shall bring unto thee.

20. AND THOU SHALT TEACH THEM. As to the second thing you spoke of,196 you are obligated to teach and instruct them only those things that they are uncertain of. For it takes great effort to teach all, the work that they must do. Now as to the meaning of ve-hizharta (and thou shalt teach): ve-hizharta comes from the same root as nizhar in and took not warning (Ezek. 33:5). Nizhar means took warning.197
THEM. Ethem (them) is a compound of two words.198

[AND THOU SHALT TEACH THEM.] You shall warn them199 to observe the positive and negative commandments that are tied to the heart,200 such as, to love God,201 to cleave unto God,202 to fear God,203 to walk after God,204 to circumcise the foreskin of the heart,205 not to hate one’s brother,206 not to take revenge,207 and not to bear a grudge.208 They are the most important commandments. Moses similarly said, [But the word is very nigh unto thee] in thy mouth, and in thy heart, that thou mayest do it (Deut. 30:14).209 There many such precepts.
THEY MUST WALK. Yelekhu bah means wherein they must walk.

AND THE WORK THAT THEY MUST DO. The reference is to positive precepts which are observed by action. Most of them are not positive commandments that stand by themselves210 but serve as a reminder, such as the Sabbath,211 the Festivals,212 the redemption of the first-born,213 loving the stranger,214 the fringes,215 the tefillin,216 the mezuzah,217 and also the prohibition against mixing linen and wool,218 and many others.219 I will explain them in their place.

21. MOREOVER THOU SHALT PROVIDE. I have already informed you that the speakers of Hebrew do not preserve exact wording. They only preserve meanings.220 Hence, as I will yet explain, we will not pay attention to whether the text is full or deficient.221 Now when Moses recounted this incident,222 in place of able men223 he said, Get you…men (Deut. 1:13).224 Men in the latter verse has the same meaning as men in Choose us out men (Ex. 17:9) and in all of them men (Num. 13:3).225
Jethro said appoint men.

SUCH AS FEAR GOD. Who do not fear men but fear only God. It was to them that Moses was referring when he said,226 wise…and understanding (Deut. 1:13).227 For it is not possible for one to be a fearer of heaven unless one be wise.
Jethro continued:
MEN OF TRUTH. Who do not lie.
HATING UNJUST GAIN (betza). Money.228 People who appear so, and are known as such by the community. It was in reference to these that Moses said, and known (Deut. 1:3).229

RULERS OF THOUSANDS. One may wonder: If the meaning of the term rulers is here to be taken literally, then their number comes to more that seventy-nine thousand.230 Now, it is extremely far-fetched for there to have been so many rulers. Indeed, Scripture states, For the transgression of a land many are the princes thereof (Prov. 28:2).231 Furthermore, how is it possible for an eighth of the camp to be heads of the tribes? For this is what Moses said, that is, So I took the heads of your tribes232 (Deut. 1:15). Additionally, how is it possible that all of the above-mentioned virtues233 were found in these people who came out of Egypt and learned their ways? Indeed, Scripture states, After the doings of the land of Egypt, wherein ye dwelt, shall ye not do (Lev. 18:3).234 Now the desert generation, who were taught by Moses for forty years, did not have to work, for their bread was freely given and their water faithfully delivered. The manna, which they were not in the habit of eating in Egypt, in contrast to the types of food which they desired,235 instilled wisdom. Nevertheless, Moses told this generation at the end of forty years, but the Lord hath not given you a heart to know, and eyes to see, and ears to hear, unto this day (Deut. 29:3). We are thus amazed as to how it was possible to find the above-noted number236 of wise and understanding men.237

It appears to me that the rulers of thousands were men who had under them a thousand people, namely, slaves, young men, or hired hands. It is possible that these were the heads of the tribes and that they numbered twelve. The rulers of hundreds were many. The rulers of fifties were so called after the manner of and fifty men to run before him (II Sam. 15:1).238
22. AND LET THEM JUDGE THE PEOPLE. When the people have a matter. What they do not know how to judge you will judge. If you do not know it, then bring thou the causes unto God (v. 19).

[23. THEN THOU SHALT BE ABLE.] The vav of ve-yakholta (then thou shalt be able)239 is like the Arabic fah.240 If you do this thing, and God grants you permission to do it, then you will be able to endure. Now the word amod (endure) is an infinitive. It is like the word amod (stand)241 in Stand in the door of the tent (Jud. 4:20). Peshotah (strip you) ve-orah (and make you bare), va-chagorah (and gird) in Strip you, and make you bare, and gird sackcloth upon your lions (Is. 32:11) are also infinitives.

[AND ALL THIS PEOPLE ALSO SHALL GO TO THEIR PLACE IN PEACE.] Its meaning is, when some the disputants who were standing before Moses were not able to present their cases before him242 for adjudication, their conflict intensified when they returned to their tents. However, now243 each one would return to his place, that is, his tent, in peace.

24. [SO MOSES HEARKENED.] Scripture mentions Jethro’s council but does not mention Moses’ council.244 Moses added to Jethro’s council: that is, Moses placed officers over the tribes to enforce the decrees of the judges. Scripture thus reads, and officers, tribe by tribe (Deut. 1:15), and Judges and officers shalt thou make thee in all thy gates (Deut. 16:18).

25. AND MOSES CHOSE ABLE MEN. This thing was ascertainable. Such as fear God245 is not mentioned, for only God knows what is in a person’s heart. Moses said that he chose wise men for us, for he was able to ascertain this. However, there are wise men who are not God-fearing. Moses mentioned246 men who are known (Deut. 1:13),247 that is, men whom people recognize. He did not mention them here because he was being brief.

26. THEY JUDGED THEMSELVES. Yishputu (judged) means the same as yishpotu (judged).248 A shuruk has been substituted for a cholam in yishputu. It is similar to lo ta’avuri (neither pass) in neither pass from hence (Ruth 2:5), which has the same meaning as ve-lo ta’avori (and neither pass).249 However, Rabbi Solomon250 wanted to distinguish between them251 but was unable to do so.252

Now from a grammatical standpoint the following may be said. We find the terms chadelu (ceased)253 and chadellu (ceased) with a dagesh in the lamed because it is marked with an etnach254 in The rulers ceased (chadelu) in Israel, they ceased (chadellu) (Jud. 5:7). We similarly find the word nazollu255 (quake) at the end of a verse in That the mountains may quake (Is. 63:19). Scripture likewise reads, tehatellu256 vo (will ye mock him) (Job 13:9) since tehatellu is considered257 to be the last word in the sentence because it is connected to the word vo, which has only one vowel. Similarly, yishpetu hem is like yishputu (hem),258 for one can say259 that the etnach260 does not have the same power that the end of the verse has. Observe the word yippelu (fall) in The peoples fall under thee (Ps. 45:6); yeminekha (thy right hand) in The Lord at thy right hand (Ps. 110:5); avdekha (thy servant) in Thou hast dealt well with Thy servant (Ps. 119:65)261 and many other such instances. We do not find this to be the case at the close of a verse.262
27. AND MOSES LET HIS FATHER-IN-LAW DEPART. With respect,263 as in and Abraham went with them to bring them on the way (Gen. 18:16).264

chapter.ftnote: 34 I.E. takes ve-hayita (and thou shalt be) as a perfect. He renders Num. 10:31 as: and you were to us instead of eyes; i.e., you enlightened us with your council. See I.E. on Num. 10:31 where he quotes this interpretation and prefaces it with the phrase, “many say.”

I.E. suggests that the lamed here has the meaning of because. Thus our verse should be rendered: because of Moses and because of Israel His (or his) people. See note 43.

54 From the root nun, chet, mem.
55 For Noah (no’ach) comes from the root nun, vav, chet. If Noah were derived from yenachamenu, then he should have been called Menachem. See I.E. on 5:29.

76 Jer. 23:6 reads, ve-zah shemo asher yikre’o Adonai-tzidkenu. I.E. renders this clause: and this is the name whereby he shall be called: Adonai-tzidkenu (The Lord is our righteousness). Saadiah disagrees. He places a comma after the word Adonai, and translates: and this is the name whereby he shall be called by the Lord: Tzidkenu (Our Righteousness).

85 As in Num. 11:26, which literally reads, the name of the one was Eldad, and the name of the second was Medad.

89 There too the word amar is missing. See I.E. on Gen. 41:52.
