91 The participle choneh (encamped) indicates a lasting action.
92 In other words, va-yomer (and he said) is a pluperfect.
93 What point would there be for Jethro to say upon coming to Moses, I thy father-in-law…am coming unto thee.
94 So too Rashi.
95 His own.

96 Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: “Va-yishtachu (he bowed) and also estachaveh (I will bow) are grammatically difficult.” That is, the entire paradigm is difficult, for its root is shin, chet, heh and it is spelled with a vav. Va-yishtachu is especially difficult in that the heh drops out and it is irregularly vocalized.
97 Its root is shin, chet, heh.
98 That is, the final vav.
99 The root heh.
100 The root of which is shin, lamed, heh. However, a vav has been substituted for a heh.

101 There appears to be an error in the text, for va-yishtachaveh ends vav, heh, while I.E.’s point is that the word should really have no vav at all. See note 96. Filwarg suggests two possible emendations: one, va-yishtacheh, the other, va-yishtachev. In the former, I.E. is explaining that if a vav had not been substituted for a heh, the word would have been va-yishtacheh. For the latter is the way third person hitpa’el’s are vocalized. If we emend to va-yishtachev, then I.E. is merely explaining why the word is vocalized va-yishtachu when, as noted above, according to Hebrew grammar the word should have been vocalized va-yishtachev. The error in transcription probably arose from the fact that the normally used word for “and he bowed” is va-yishtachaveh. See Filwarg and Krinsky.
102 That is, the third person singular perfect.
103 In va-yishtachu.
104 Which is not a root letter but is the tav of the hitpa’el conjugation.
105 A shin, samekh, tzadi, or zayin.
106 The tav of the hitpa’el conjugation precedes the root. Compare hitkatev, hityashev, etc.
107 In the Hebrew text the sentence ends here. There is either a scribal error or I. E. did not finish his thought.
108 Rather than before it. Thus in va-yishtachu the tav follows rather than precedes the shin.
109 In the third person plural form, va-yishtachavu (and they bowed) (Filwarg).
110 In the third person.
111 That is, they vocalized the word with a shuruk. I.E. refers to the shuruk as a silent vav.
112 This should be emended to va-yishtachavu. For other interpretations see Krinsky and Weiser.
113 Rather than ultimately accented as is the usual case with words in the third person perfect.
114 Which is to accent them ultimately. In other words, va-yishtachu is penultimately accented to indicate that it is not a plural.
115 Thus it was Moses who did the bowing.
116 See I.E. on Ex. 3:15.
117 Because of Moses and because of Israel, for Scripture reads: for Israel’s sake. See I.E. on Ex. 18:1
118 Its root is lamed, alef, heh. According to I.E. ve-nilu means unable. See I.E. on Ex. 7:18.
119 It is neither a root letter nor a prefix.
120 Its root is chet, dalet, heh The meaning of va-yichad thus is, and he rejoiced.

121 The root of va-yift is peh, tav, heh, and that of va-yishb is shin, bet, heh. Va-yift is short for va-yifteh and va-yishb for va-yishbeh; that is, in words ending in a heh, the heh may be dropped in the imperfect. The latter is referred to as an abbreviated root. Now since the root of va-yichad is chet, dalet heh, va-yichad should have been vocalized va-yichd.
122 Rather than a sheva.
123 Which is placed in the dalet in the long form, viz., yechedeh.
124 In the short form. Va-yichad has a dagesh in it. Prima facie, there is no reason for this dagesh. Hence I.E.’s comment.
125 That is, when the last two letters in the word are vocalized with a sheva.
126 Which has a sheva beneath each of the last two letters, the shin and the bet.
127 Which has a sheva beneath each of the last two letters, the shin and the tav.
128 A sheva is not considered a vowel.
129 The passive kal participle form.
130 Po’el is the active kal participle form.
131 If the word does not have an active form.
132 In the pa’ul.
133 According to I.E. all intransitive verbs in the participle form, whether active or passive, are adjectives, for they describe a state.
134 Thus shomer and shamur are true po’el and pa’ul forms.
135 Whereas va-ya’atzmu is in the kal.
136 Even though the word atzam in the kal means waxed mighty, its po’el form does not mean waxes mighty but closes. In other words, the word atzam meaning strength has no po’el form.
138 That is, meaning blessing.
139 I.E.’s point is that the root bet, resh, kaf in the kal means to kneel. It is only used with regard to a blessing in the pa’ul form.
140 In the kal.
141 Like the above-noted words.
142 There is no kal pa’ul form for kneeled because barukh means blessed.
143 Rabbi Jonah ibn Janach.
144 Words in the pi’el receive a dagesh in their middle stem letters. When the middle root letter cannot receive a dagesh, the preceding letter is vocalized with a tzere in place of a chirik.
145 Which is vocalized with a tzere rather than a chirik because the resh cannot receive a dagesh. In other words, the word for blessed should have been vocalized berukh rather than barukh.

146 Which is a pi’el. It should be noted that shakkul is vocalized with a pattach, and barukh with a kamatz. The reason for the latter is that since the resh of barukh cannot receive a dagesh, the pattach preceding it is changed to a kamatz.
147 That is, all pi’el adjectives.
148 In other words, the vowel beneath the first letter of a word in the pi’el does not change in the singular construct or in the plural. However, they do in the kal.
149 Which is a singular construct.

150 Which is a plural absolute. The point is, the chirik preceding the bet with the dagesh in it does not change in gibbor, which is in the construct. Neither does it change in gibborim, which is the plural of gibbor. However, it does change in the kal; viz., davar becomes devar in the construct and devarim in the plural.
151 The construct of barukh.

152 The singular of which is barukh. We thus see that in the case of these two words the kamatz changes to a sheva. However, as noted above, this does not occur in the pi’el form. Hence barukh cannot be a pi’el. It has to be a kal.
153 In other words, And Jethro said means: and Jethro said to Moses and Aaron.
154 After blessing God.
155 In other words, after blessing God for delivering Moses and Aaron, he blessed God for saving Israel.
156 See I.E. on Ex. 3:13.
157 In other words, ki va-davar (yea, for that) means: because of the fact, viz., the bet prefixed to davar means because. The bet usually means in. Hence I.E.’s comment.
158 The Egyptians.
159 In other words, the words hezidu and zadu mean dealt willfully.
160 The hand of the Egyptians indicates that the Egyptians did what they wanted with Israel.
161 Zevachim (sacrifices) usually refers to peaceofferings (Weiser).

162 The tabernacle faced east. Hence Moses’ tent was in front of God’s tabernacle. It will be recalled that according to I.E., Jethro arrived in the second year following the Exodus, after the erection of the tabernacle.
163 Hebrew, boker.
164 See I.E. on Gen. 12:31.
165 That is, from sunset till the disappearance of the light.
166 The nocturnal creatures. We thus see that morning begins at sunrise.
167 Erev. The psalm seems to describes man’s working hours from sunrise to sunset, for erev is antithetical to sunrise. We thus see that evening begins at sunset.
168 That is, from sunset to sunset.
169 That is, the sages extended the holy day.
170 See Sabbath 34b.
171 That is, day begins.
172 Rashi.

173 Cf. Rashi, “[Moses] sat like a king and all of the people stood. Jethro was troubled by this. For Moses did not show respect for Israel. He chastised Moses for this and said, What is this thing that thou doest to the people?”
174 To rebuke Moses for sitting in judgment while the litigants stood.
175 Sittest thou alone, etc.
176 Mazzeh being a compound of mah (what) and zeh (this) and mallakhem being a compound of mah (what) and lakhem (to you).

177 In other words, maddu’a is a compound of ma (what) and du’a (opinion), i.e., what is your opinion? Du’a is spelled dalet, vav, ayin, and is a variation of the root yod, dalet, ayin, meaning knowledge.
178 That is, to inquire of God is short for, to inquire of God’s law.
179 Explaining verse 16.
180 The root, of which is nun, bet, lamed. Navol is an infinitive and tibbol an imperfect. The literal translation of navol tibbol is: wither you will wither; that is, you will collapse.
181 Or withers.
182 Literally, also. Verse 18 reads: also thou, also this people.

183 That is, for the thing is too heavy for thee is not a reason for what precedes it but an additional reason why Moses should not judge the people all by himself. For an alternate interpretation see Filwarg.
184 The root of asohu is ayin, sin, heh. When roots that end in a heh are combined with a pronoun, the heh changes to a tav. Hence our word should read asoto rather than asohu.
185 Which, unlike the root of asohu, is a “whole,” i.e., a root that does not drop a letter.
186 Cf. yishmeruhu (preserve him) in Ps. 41:8.

187 The heh in this root is dropped when conjugated. Compare, asiti, asita, etc. Thus there is no reason why the root should follow the paradigm of a “whole” root when combined with a pronoun. Hence the grammatical inconsistency of asohu.
188 See I.E. on Ex. 3:4,15.
189 One is forbidden to erase any of God’s name. Elohim is included among the latter. See chapter 4 of Tractate Soferim.
190 Even though this is not stated in the text.
191 Literally, to the people. Hence I.E.’s comment.

192 Hebrew, mi-pe’at Elohim. The Biblical text reads, mul ha-Elohim; literally, before of God. I.E. apparently interprets it as: you will face the people from the same side as God faces them: that is, you will serve as God’s messenger to the people (Weiser). It is interesting to note that Peshita interprets similarly. It reads, “teaching the people from God.” However, the mem in I.E. often has the meaning of a lamed. Thus mi-pe’at Elohim might be interpreted as li-fe’at Elohim; that is, you will be the intermediary between the people and God (Krinsky). See Rashi. In this case, mul ha-Elohim means before God.
193 In response to Jethro’s question, why do you sit and the people stand around you from morning till evening (v. 14). Also see I.E. on verse 15.
194 That the people should bring before Moses only the difficult causes.
195 In verse 22.
196 That you are busy instructing the people.
197 Hence ve-hizharta (and thou shalt teach) means: and thou shalt warn.
198 It is made up of et and hem.
199 See note 205.
200 That one observe with one’s heart. Bachya ibn Pekuda (c. 1050-1120) referred to them as chovat ha-levavot (duties of the heart) and wrote a work by that name.
204 Deut. 26:17; 28:9. To imitate God’s attributes of mercy, that is, to be kind, charitable, loving, etc.
209 Which according to I.E. means that the commandments observed with the heart are the most important commandments. See I.E. on Deut. 30:14.
210 That is, that the act itself is of inherent worth, such as belief in God, tzedaka, acts of loving kindness.
211 Which bears testimony that God created heaven and earth. See Ex. 20:11.

212 Each of which serves as a reminder of a historical or theological proof. For example, Passover commemorates the Exodus from Egypt, Sukkot the booths in which the Israelites dwelt during the sojourn in (he wilderness, and so on.
213 Which remind us that God spared the first-born of Israel when he slew the first born of Egypt. See Ex. 13:15.

214 This reminds us that we were strangers in Egypt. See Deut. 10:19. It is note-worthy that I.E. did not consider the love of the stranger as an inherently worthy act. A different reading of Scripture was that of Hermann Cohen, who wrote, “[The] law of shielding the alien from all wrong is of vital significance in the history of religion. With it alone, true religion begins. The alien was to be protected, not because he was a member of one’s family, clan, religious community, or people; but because he was a human being. In the alien, therefore, man discovered the idea of humanity.” The Pentateuch and the Haftorahs, ed. by J.H. Hertz, Soncino Press, London, 1967, p. 313.
215 Which recall God’s commandments. See Num. 15:39.
216 Which reminds the worshipper of God and one’s duties to God and the Exodus. See Ex. 13:9,16; Deut. 6:4-8; 13:13-19.
217 Which serves the same purpose as the tefillin. See Deut. 6:4-8; 13:13-19.
218 Which serves as a reminder not to combine what God has set apart. See I.E. on Lev. 19:19.
219 There are many other commandments which serve as reminders of theological truths and historical events.
220 See I.E. on Ex. 11:5 and Gen. 5:29.

221 That is, whether two texts that relate the same event match each other exactly. I.E. makes this point here because, as he goes on to note, there are discrepancies between our chapter and the first chapter of Deuteronomy with regard to the description of the quality of the judges chosen by Moses.
222 The appointment of judges.
223 Hebrew, anshe chayil. Literally, valiant men, mighty men.
224 Rather than get you able men, as in our verse.

225 The meaning of men in both of these verses is, men of valor, for both verses deal with tasks requiring such men. Thus anashim in Deut. 1:13 means the same as anshe chayil in Ex. 18:21 even though the wording is different.
226 To Israel.
227 That is, bring forth wise and understanding men and I will appoint them as judges.
228 That is, betza (unjust gain) means money. So too Rashi.
229 Translated according to I.E.

230 The Israelites numbered six hundred thousand and three thousand and five hundred and fifty men (Ex. 38:26). The number of rulers over thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens of such a group comes to 79,650 (Krinsky).
231 Translated according to I.E. A surfeit of rulers is a punishment for a people. Why then would Moses appoint so many rulers over Israel?
232 The verse continues: And made them heads over you, captains of thousands, and captains of hundreds, and captains of fifties, and captains of tens.
233 Able men, God-fearing men, truthful men, etc.
234 Which implies that Israelites followed Egyptian practice. Otherwise why tell them not to do so?
235 See Num. 11:5.
237 So soon after the Exodus when, as noted in Deut. 29:3, forty years later such men were a rarity.

238 That is, they each had fifty servants. Thus ruler over thousands, hundreds, etc., does not refer to judges in charge of a thousand Israelites, a hundred Israelites, etc., but to the amount of wealth possessed by the people from whom the judges were chosen.
239 Va-yakholta can be taken to mean: and thou shalt be able. Hence I.E.’s comment that it means: then thou shalt be able.
240 It does not necessarily mean “and.” See I.E. on Gen. 1:2 and the notes thereto.
241 Which is an infinitive.
242 Literally, before you. For Jethro addressed Moses.
243 If Jethro’s advice were followed.

244 Scripture in our chapter notes that Jethro advised Moses to appoint judges and that Moses followed his advice. However, it omits telling us that Moses decided not only to appoint judges but to appoint officers as well.
245 See verse 21.
246 That is, he appointed.
247 Translated according to I.E.
248 This is the more common form.
249 Ta’avori is the more common form.
250 Rashi.
251 Between yishputu and yishpotu. Rashi implies that yishpotu is an imperative and yishputu a participle. See Rashi on verse 26.
252 As they mean the same thing.
253 The usual form.
254 What is commonly referred to as an etnachtah.
255 Rather than nazelu, the usual form.
256 Rather than tehatelu the usual form.
257 Literally, “they” considered tehatellu to be the last word, etc.
258 That is, they mean the same but are vocalized differently because one (yishpetu) comes in the middle of a sentence and the other (yishputu) at the end of a sentence.
259 Thus who would dispute this point by saying that the etnachtah and the sof pasuk equally change the word’s vocalization. Hence yishpetu and yishputu should be vocalized in the same way.
260 Placed beneath yishpetu.
261 All of these words have an etnachtah beneath them and maintain their normal vowels. Similarly yishpetu.
262 The vowels in these words change at the end of a verse. So too yishputu.
263 Va-yeshellach (let depart) can be translated: and he sent away.
264 There too le-shallecham (to bring them on the way) is not to be rendered: to send them away, but rather to escort them. See I.E. on Gen. 18:16 and the notes thereto.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 19
chapter.p: 1. IN THE THIRD MONTH. We do not know the meaning of the same day (ba-yom ha-zeh)1 unless the interpretation of Rabbi Moses2 to the effect that it3 refers to the new moon is correct.4 It is like Tomorrow is the new moon (I Sam 20:18).5 Scripture notes this6 because the Torah was given a few days after Israel camped.7 Perhaps Moses went up to God8 on day one9 and then came down and spoke to Israel.10 Then on the third day of the month he went up again to report the words of the people to God.11 It was then told to Moses that the giving of the Torah would take place on the third day.12 All of this is by way of logical exegesis because we accept the tradition13 that the Torah was given on the sixth day of Sivan.14
According to the rules of the calendar, if15 a day was not added to the month of Iyyar,16 then the Torah was given on a Friday.17
It is possible that Scripture reads, the same day because the distance18 from Rephidim and Mount Sinai was greater than the distance between each journey.19
2. AND WHEN THEY WERE DEPARTED FROM REPHIDIM.20 Its meaning is, they had already departed from Rephidim.21 I have pointed out to you many other such instances.22
THEY ENCAMPED IN THE WILDERNESS. The previously mentioned wilderness of Sinai.

[AND THERE ISRAEL ENCAMPED.] Scripture reads, and there Israel encamped, after stating, they encamped in the wilderness, because the heads of the tribes and the elders camped before the mountain due to their respected positions.23 As I will explain,24 Israel stood around the mountain, in accordance with their status, on the day the Torah was given. Scripture uses the singular form va-yichan (encamped) because they25 were few in number. Rabbi Solomon26 says that before (mi-neged) the mount means on the eastern side of the mountain. However, Scripture states, a good way off (mineged) shall they pitch, round about27 the tent of meeting (Num. 2:2), namely, on all sides of the tent of meeting. For28 as the standards journeyed,29 so did they camp.30
3. AND MOSES WENT UP UNTO GOD. Scripture above reads, before the mount (v. 2). Its meaning thus is: and Moses went up to the mount of God.31
[AND THE LORD CALLED UNTO HIM.] Its meaning is,32 and the Lord had already called him.33 For Moses would not have ascended without permission.

[OUT OF THE MOUNTAIN.] Scripture says this34 becauce Moses did not ascend above the mountain.35 For the Lord spoke to Moses on the mountain. Do not be bothered by the fact that Scripture afterwards states, And the Lord came down upon mount Sinai (v. 20),36 for the Torah says this from the point of view of Israel when they beheld the cloud and fire. Scripture explicitly states, and thou didst hear His words out of the midst of the fire (Deut. 4:36).37

[SAYING.]38 Its meaning is that the Lord39 called Moses to tell him: Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob). The meaning is, say something relating to all of40 the house of Jacob, to those alive today and to their children after them.

[AND TELL THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] The reference is to the elders. The elders will then tell all of the people.41 We thus read, And Moses came and called for the elders of the people (v. 7),42 and it is then written, And all the people answered together (v. 8).
[HOUSE.] I have previously explained the meaning of the word house (Ex. 1:1).

4. YE HAVE SEEN. The vengeance that I executed upon the Egyptians on your behalf, and that I bore you out of Egypt as if you were carried on the wings of eagles. For an eagle flies higher in the air than any other bird. All birds are afraid of him and he fears no bird.

[I BORE YOU ON EAGLES’ WINGS.] Moses employed a similar metaphor later on when he said, As an eagle that stirreth up her nest (Deut. 32:11),43 that is, it slowly leads its young.44 Moses similarly referred to the clouds45 when he said, Spreadeth abroad her wings (Ibid.).

AND BROUGHT YOU UNTO MYSELF. In that God’s glory came down upon this mountain. This is the holy mountain referred to by Moses.46 Now Moses said,47 ye shall serve God upon this mountain (Ex. 3:12). The latter is the same as Thy holy habitation (Ex. 15:13).48

5. NOW THEREFORE, IF YE WILL HEARKEN UNTO MY VOICE. To observe my commandments and keep the covenant which I will make with you. The reference, as I will explain with irrefutable proofs in the proper place,49 is to the covenant made by Moses with Israel after the giving of the Torah, when he built the altar.50
[TREASURE.] The word segullah (treasure) means something precious, lovely, and unique.

[FOR ALL THE EARTH IS MINE.] This is connected to all peoples.51 The clause is to be interpreted: for all the peoples of the earth are mine. This is what Scripture means by and [I] set you apart from the peoples, that ye should be Mine (Lev. 20:26).52

Rabbi Merinus says that ki li kol ha-aretz (for all the earth is mine) means: even though all the earth is mine.53 I believe that this is the case with ki am keseh oref attah (it is a stiffnecked people) (Ex. 32:9)54 and refah nafshi ki chatati lakh (Heal my soul; for I have sinned against Thee) (Ps. 41:5).55
7. AND MOSES CAME. To the camp of Israel.56 There is no need to mention that Moses descended.57

AND SET BEFORE THEM. As in And this is the law which Moses set before the children of Israel (Deut. 4:44).58 However, the Gaon says that the word set is used here in the same way as the word set in set59 it in their mouths (Deut. 31:19). The reference60 is to the oral law which explains the written law.61
8. TOGETHER. The word yachdav (together) is grammatically unique62 in Scripture because of the added vav.63 Yefet explains it to mean alone, by oneself, without anybody else there.64
[REPORTED.] Scripture mentions, and Moses reported, but has no need to mention that Moses went up65 because Scripture is being brief.

9. AND THE LORD SAID. What reason is there for saying, And Moses told the words of the people unto the Lord (v. 9) after having said,66 And Moses reported the words of the people unto the Lord? Note that there are many verses in the Torah that should have come earlier.67 Their meaning is that such and such already took place.68 For example, the meaning of va-yitzar (formed) in, Then the Lord God formed69 (Gen. 2:7) is, He70 had already formed;71 the meaning of va-yatzmach (made to grow) in And out of the ground made the Lord God to grow (Gen. 2:9) is, He had already made to grow;72 the meaning of va-yomer (and said) in and said: Whose daughter art thou? (Gen. 24:23) is, and he73 had already said.74 Indeed, Scripture explicitly states,75 And I asked her, and said (Gen. 24:47),76 and then,77 I put the ring upon her nose (Ibid.). Similarly, the meaning of And she78 said unto the servant (Gen. 24:65) is, and she had already said unto the servant,79 and then, she alighted from the camel (Gen. 24:64).80 There is no need to elaborate.81 Now the meaning of And Moses told here82 is, and Moses had already told. Scripture does not mention what Moses told.83 The word higid (told) always refers to something new that has not previously been mentioned. It is thus not connected to and Moses reported.84 From God’s answer to Moses, “Lo, I come unto thee in a thick cloud” (v. 9), we learn what Moses told.85 Furthermore, as I will explain,86 we find this clearly stated in Moses’ very words.

Note that the Egyptians and the Indians are from the children of Ham. Each one relies on the other.87 The people of India do not eat meat. The Egyptians used to do the same. They changed their practice only because the kingdom of Ishmael88 overpowered them and they accepted the religion of the Ishmaelites. The Indian sages offer proofs in accordance with their thinking that it is impossible for God to talk to a person and for that person to live. Now the Israelites were in Egypt.89 There were among them people who followed this belief.90 They were in doubt about Moses’ prophecy. And they believed in the Lord, and in His servant Moses (Ex. 14:31) does not dispute this.91 For Scripture reads, And Israel saw (Ibid.). It does not say: and all Israel saw.92 Even if it read, all of Israel,93 it would speak of the majority as is the style of the language,94 as in and all the cattle of Egypt died (Ex. 9:6),95 which is followed by Now therefore send, hasten in thy cattle (Ex. 9:19).96
[LO, I COME UNTO THEE.] This is to be understood as an answer to Moses, who told this97 to God.98
[IN A THICK CLOUD.] When God will descend upon the mountain.
WHEN I SPEAK WITH THEE. The Decalogue. They will then believe that God in truth speaks with a person and he lives.

[AND MAY ALSO BELIEVE THEE.] That you are a prophet. All doubt will be removed from their minds. It is explicitly written, we have seen this day that God doth speak with man, and he liveth (Deut. 5:21). It is also written there, For who is there of all flesh, that hath heard the voice of the living God speaking out of the midst of the fire, as we have, and lived? (Deut. 5:23). And it is there written, Go thou near, and hear (Deut. 5:24).99 This is what Scripture means by and may also believe thee for ever.
10. AND THE LORD SAID…SANCTIFY THEM TO-DAY AND TOMORROW. Observe, God enlarged the time allotted for Israel’s sanctification by giving them the rest of this day and the morrow.100

[AND SANCTIFY THEM.] By washing in water. This is indicated by and let them wash their garments.101 Our verse is to be interpreted after the manner of But if he wash them not, nor bathe his flesh (Lev. 17:16). Moses therefore said, starting from now, come not near a woman (v. 15) so that they would be sanctified and not be unclean. One who drew near to a women should sanctify himself,102 as in for she was purified103 from her uncleanliness (II Sam. 11:4).
11. AND BE READY. Its meaning might be that no person among them should sleep during the night, after the manner of the high priest on Yom Kippur,104 as Israel would hear God’s voice in the morning.

12. AND THOU SHALT SET BOUNDS. Place a border on the mount.105 Set bounds about the mount, and sanctify it (v. 23) is therefore similar.106 I dwell on this because the crazy one107 who inverted the words of the living God in his book108 said that Moses intended to say,109 set bounds about the people,110 but what came out of his mouth was “the mount” rather than “the people.”
WHOSOEVER TOUCHETH THE MOUNT. With his body.111

13. NO HAND SHALL TOUCH HIM. The word bo (him) refers to the person who touches the mount.112 It means that no one shall enter after him113 to grab him. On the contrary, those who see him shall immediately stone him from where they are standing or shall shoot him through with arrows if he be distant.

[SHOT THROUGH.] The word yiyareh (shot through) differs from its counterparts.114 For the rule pertaining to roots that have a yod as their first letter is that the yod changes to a vav in the nifal imperfect, as in the word yivvada (be known)115 in and the plenty shall not be known (Gen. 41:31) and va-ivvaser (and I was chastised)116 in Thou hast chastised me, and I was chastised (Jer. 31:18). Perhaps they117 did this so that this root118 not be confused with the root of tivvare (thou mayest be feared)119 in That Thou mayest be feared (Ps. 130:4).120 For the alef and the heh are silent at the end of the word and there is no difference in pronunciation between them.121
WHETHER IT BE BEAST OR MAN, IT SHALL NOT LIVE. Not so a bird as it cannot be taken, for it immediately flies away.

WHEN THE RAM’S HORN SOUNDETH LONG. Yovel (ram) is a lamb.122 Jubilee (yovel) is so called because Scripture states, Then shalt thou make proclamation with the blast of a shofar123 (Lev. 25:9), and the shofar is made from the horns of a lamb.124 It is similarly written, And it shall be, that when they make a long blast with the horn of the yovel,125 and when ye hear the sound of the shofar126 (Josh. 6:5).

One must wonder at those who say that And when the voice of the horn waxed louder and louder, Moses spoke (v. 19) refers to when the ram’s horn127 soundeth long.128 For the voice of the horn129 was a great wonder;130 there was no greater wonder at that assembly around Mount Sinai. For sounds of thunder, lightning, and a thick cloud are also visible in the world. However, the voice of the horn131 was unheard of until the day of the Decalogue.132 Behold, the sound133 was not from the horn of a lamb.134

[WHEN THE RAM’S HORN SOUNDETH LONG, THEY SHALL COME UP TO THE MOUNT.] The Gaon135 says136 that when Moses sounds the horn it will give them permission to ascend.137 This took place after Moses descended138 on the Day of Atonement and commanded that the tabernacle be constructed

THEY SHALL COME UP TO THE MOUNT. Rabbi Samuel ben Hofni says that “they” refers to Aaron, Aaron’s sons, and the seventy elders concerning whom it is written, And unto Moses He said: Come up unto the Lord, thou, and Aaron, Nadab, and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel (Ex. 24:1).139 However, Moses did not give permission to the rest of the people to ascend Mount Sinai. He therefore said “they” and not others. His words appear good in my sight. For the glory was continually on Sinai until the tabernacle was erected, as it is written, and the glory of the Lord filled the tabernacle (Ex. 4:34). God then spoke with Moses in the tent of meeting. Perhaps Moses then sounded the horn140 and now that the glory was gone,141 God gave him142 permission to ascend.143
14. AND MOSES WENT DOWN…AND SANCTIFIED THE PEOPLE. As I have already explained.144

15. BE READY AGAINST THE THIRD DAY. The meaning of li-sheloshet yamim is, for the third day. According to the plain meaning of the text, Moses did not add a day by himself.145 I will bring two faithful witnesses,146 both of which are found in this book. Now it is written, And he put them all together into ward three days (sheloset yamim) (Gen. 42:17). It is then written, And Joseph said unto them the third day (yom ha-shelishi) (Gen. 42:18). Scripture also states, within yet three days (sheloshet yamim) shall Pharaoh lift up thy head from off thee (Gen. 40:19). It is then written, And it came to pass the third day (ba-yom ha-shelishi) (Gen. 40:20).147 Similarly here, heyu nekhnim li-sheloshet yamim [means be ready for the third day].
16. AND A THICK CLOUD UPON THE MOUNT. Upon the mount alone. The same applies to the thunder and lightning.148
[EXCEEDING LOUD.] Its meaning is, louder than the voice of any shofar (horn) that they ever heard.
AND ALL THE PEOPLE THAT WERE IN THE CAMP TREMBLED. Because of the sound of the shofar (horn).
17. AND MOSES BROUGHT FORTH. Its meaning is: and Moses brought forth the people out of their tents149 to meet God and to accept the Lord who came down on Mount Sinai as their God.150

AND THEY STOOD AT THE NETHER PART OF THE MOUNT. Outside of the boundary that Moses set for them. Now they stood at Mount Sinai in a manner similar to that in which Moses made their children stand at the end of forty years151 when he made a covenant with them.152 The first-born153 that [came] near the Lord were first, after them the heads of the tribes,154 namely, the princes, after them the elders, after them the officers, after them all the men of Israel;155 after them came the little ones,156 after them the women,157 and after them the proselytes.158 Moses and Aaron passed over the boundary and were on the mount close to the priests. This was so159 even though Scripture does not explicitly say so, as Scripture was brief. We know that they160 did not rebel against the word of God for, behold, it is written, Go, get thee down, and thou shalt come up,161 thou, and Aaron with thee (v. 24). Moses similarly said, I stood between the Lord and you (Deut. 5:5).162

18. NOW MOUNT SINAI WAS ALTOGETHER ON SMOKE. The shin of ashan (smoke) is vocalized with a long pattach because it is a verb in the perfect.163 Do not be surprised at the word for smoke164 since Scripture reads, ke-eshen165 ha-kivshan (as the smoke of the furnace) after saying, va-ya’al ashano166 (and the smoke thereof ascended). Note that ashano follows the form of shelalo (his spoil)167 and zehavo168 (his gold),169 for nouns come in various forms each of which has a different name.170 Thus Scripture reads, shegar171 alafekha (the increase of thy kine) (Deut. 7:13), but elsewhere it reads, ve-khol peter sheger172 be-hemah (every firstling that is male) (Ex. 13:12). Scripture reads, ve-et ha-bosem173 ve-et ha-shemen (and the spice, and the oil) (Ex. 35:28). However, we also find, ve-kinneman besem174 (and of cinnamon spice)175 (Ex. 30:23). Furthermore, Scripture reads, ariti mori im besami (I have gathered my myrrh with my spice) (Cant. 5:1). Now, if besami (my spice) was derived from bosem,176 the word should have been vocalized with a chataf kamatz and be pronounced bosmi like the word kodshi (my holy object), which is derived from kodesh (holy).177 Similarly, if besami was derived from besem (sweet)178 in and of cinnamon spice (Ex. 30:23), then besami should have been vocalized with a pattach like the word shamni (my oil),179 which is derived from shemen (oil), or with a chirik like the word tzidki (my righteousness),180 which is derived from tzedek (righteous). The word besami minus the yod181 is thus vocalized with two kematzim and pronounced basam (spice),182 like the word shalal (spoil) and the word zahav (gold).
AND THE WHOLE MOUNT QUAKED GREATLY. The reverse of the usual, for mountains do not move. It is only by way of parable that Scripture states, And the hills did tremble (Is. 5:25).

19. AND WHEN THE VOICE OF THE HORN WAXED LOUDER AND LOUDER. The normal thing is for the sound of the shofar to be stronger when first sounded.183 However, the reverse was the case here.184 Perhaps God made it sound weaker at the beginning so that Israel would not lose heart out of fright.

MOSES SPOKE. According to Saadiah Gaon, God periodically stopped the sound of the shofar, at which time Moses spoke185 with a loud voice. God then answered Moses with a voice, as in then he [Moses] heard the Voice speaking unto him (Num. 7:89). It is concerning this that Scripture states, that the people may hear when I speak with thee (v. 9). However, I have already told you186 that in my opinion, when I speak with thee refers to the Decalogue.187 Moses spoke is to be explained by connecting it to the voice of the horn (shofar). Moses’ soul cleaved unto God.188 Moses spoke with God from the foot of the mountain and asked something of God. However, Scripture does not reveal what Moses asked. God answered Moses with a voice audible to Moses.189 The sound of the shofar, although very loud, did not prevent Moses from hearing the voice. Because of this,190 Scripture states afterwards, and the Lord called Moses with the sound of a voice and told him to ascend the mountain where the glory of God was.

20. AND THE LORD CAME DOWN. I will now convey a general principle that will satisfy you191 until, with God’s help, I will come to the Torah portion Ki Tissa, where I will explain extremely deep things to you very clearly. Know that man’s soul is extolled and glorious. It comes from the middle world.192 However, man’s body comes from the inferior world. The only one in this inferior world who has the ability to speak is man. Likewise the hearer, that is, the person to whom the speaker wants to convey what is in the speaker’s heart.193 An intelligent person cannot invent speech.194 He must employ the language that is known and used. All languages are built upon the arrangement of the human form,195 which is made up of an incorporeal soul and a body made out of four elements.196 Now when a person speaks to a fellow human being in a language that the latter knows, he understands the speaker’s words and their forms in their arrangements. If one wants to speak of things that are on a lower level than human beings, he has to raise their level and give them human form so that anyone who hears him will understand his words. Hence they197 attributed a head to the earth, as in The head of the dust of the world (Prov. 8:26),198 a mouth to the earth, as in And the earth opened her mouth (Num. 16:32), and a side, as in from the sides of the earth (Jer. 6:22).199 We similarly find, the head of the Jordan (Num. 13:29)200 and in the heart of the sea (Ex. 15:8). There are many such instances. Now they are all metaphoric, for the sea has no heart. Furthermore, they picture one part of the body as if it had the form of the entire body. Thus Scripture says, Death and life are in the hand of the tongue (Prov. 18:21).201 There are many such cases.

Similarly, when a person wants to speak of things more important than he, namely, of things from the upper world, he brings them down to his level and anthropomorphizes them, speaking of them as if they had human form. All this is done so that the hearer can be understood. Scripture thus reads, the man Gabriel (Dan. 9:21).202 Scripture similarly speaks of his203 arms and his feet (Dan. 10:6) and tells us, and the voice of his204 words [was] like the voice of a multitude (Ibid.). They [the writers of Scripture] took hold of this style of speech when describing the Most High. Scripture thus states, And a helmet of salvation upon His205 head (Is. 59:17); For the mouth of the Lord hath spoken (Is. 1:20); The eyes of the Lord are toward the righteous, And His ears are open unto their cry; The face of the Lord is against them that do evil (Ps. 34:16,17); and and there was under His feet (Ex. 24:10). This is the way to understand And the Lord came down (Gen. 11:5) and, and God went up (Gen. 17:22), for everything is full of His glory.206 I will present a parable in the Torah portion Ki Tissa through which you will be able to understand what Scripture means by God ascending and descending.207

[AND THE LORD CALLED MOSES TO THE TOP OF THE MOUNT.] The reason the Lord called Moses208 was so that Israel would see Moses’ greatly elevated state, namely, that he reached the top of the mountain where there was the glory of God, whose words the people would hear from the fire that was there.

21. GO DOWN, CHARGE THE PEOPLE, LEST THEY BREAK THROUGH. Each one from the place209 where he stands, thinking that they are rendering Me honor because of their great desire to gaze at My glory. Moses therefore said, to gaze.210
[THE PEOPLE.] The term ba-am (the people)211 is to be read as if written twice. Our verse is to be read as if written: and shall fall from them, many people.212

22. AND LET THE PRIESTS ALSO. The reference is to the first-born.213 Though the first-born are holy, as it is written, sanctify unto Me all the first-born (Ex. 13:2) nevertheless, let them add to their holiness by sanctifying themselves through their thoughts.

[THAT COME NEAR THE LORD.] Who are at the beginning of the boundary.214 Or its meaning is,215 who offered burnt offerings upon the altar that Moses built after Amalek was vanquished,216 and who also will offer sacrifices on the altar of the covenant that Moses built and fixed beneath the mountain where Israel stood to hear the voice of God.217

23. AND MOSES SAID UNTO THE LORD: THE PEOPLE CANNOT COME UP TO MOUNT SINAI. Saadiah says that he contemplated this verse for many years and could not understand its meaning218 until he came across a book dealing with the customs of the Persian kings in which it is stated that a king’s messenger does not have permission to tell the king that he has accomplished his mission until the king commands him to do another task. Only then may he tell the king.219 However, I believe that because God220 told Moses, lest they break through unto the Lord to gaze, Moses did not know whether he had to warn the people not to gaze.221 He had already warned them222 that they were not to pass the boundary.223 God then told Moses, Go, get thee down and charge them as I commanded you.224 For Israel needed to be charged a second time.225

24. AND THOU SHALT COME UP, THOU, AND AARON WITH THEE. A little above the boundary so as not to be too far from Israel, because after God finishes speaking the Decalogue, Israel will say to you, Speak thou with us, and we will hear (Ex. 20:16).

I will now give the Gaon the answer to his question.226 God did not tell Moses to charge Israel not to gaze upon Him.227 He told Moses228 to charge the people229 not to pass over the boundary. For it was necessary to charge them at the very time of God’s revelation to listen and guard their lives.
25. SO MOSES WENT DOWN UNTO THE PEOPLE, AND TOLD THEM. When Moses finished telling the people,230 he and Aaron went up the mountain beyond the border whereupon God immediately began to speak.
