chapter.title: CHAPTER 20
chapter.p: 1. AND GOD SPOKE. There are some very difficult questions to be raised in this chapter. Many say that God only uttered the first two statements.1 As proof they offer the fact that the first statement reads, I am the Lord thy God (v. 2), and the second, for I the Lord thy God am a jealous God (v. 5).2 However, the third statement reads, Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain (v. 7) and does not say “My” name; the fourth reads, for in six days the Lord made heaven and earth, the sea, and all that in them is, and rested on the seventh day; wherefore the Lord blessed the sabbath day, and hallowed it (v. 11); the fifth reads, that thy days may be long upon the land which the Lord thy God giveth thee. (v. 12). One may ask, how can I am the Lord be counted among the Ten Statements,3 as God is the one who commands?4 Clearly, I am the Lord is neither a positive nor a negative commandment.

The following questions are even more difficult than the above-noted ones. When we read this chapter, namely, the Torah portion Va-Yishma Yitro (And Jethro heard)5 first, and then read the Torah portion Va-Etchannan (And I besought) (Deut. 3:23; 7:11), we notice that from I am the Lord (v. 2) through the Lord will not hold him guiltless that taketh His name in vain (v. 7) there is no difference in the two portions.6 However, starting from Remember (v. 8) to the conclusion of the Ten Statements, there are differences in every place.

Yitro7 reads, Remember (v. 5), while Va-Etchannan8 has, Observe (Deut. 5:12). The latter also ends with the addition, as the Lord thy God commanded thee. Yitro states, nor thy cattle (v. 10); Va-Etchannan adds, nor thine ox, nor thine ass (Deut. 5:14).

More difficult than all of these is that the reason given for the Sabbath in Yitro is, for in six days the Lord made heaven and earth (v. 12). The verse then goes on to say, wherefore the Lord blessed the sabbath day and hallowed it (v. 12). Now these verses are not quoted in Va-Etchannan, which offers a totally different reason for the Sabbath. It states, And thou shalt remember that thou wast a servant in the land of Egypt (Deut. 5:15). The latter concludes with, therefore the Lord thy God commanded thee to keep the sabbath day.

Scripture tells us in Yitro and in Va-Etchannan that the reward for honoring one’s father and mother is that thy days may be long.9 However, Va-Etchannan adds, and that it may go well with thee (Deut. 5:16). It also adds, as the Lord thy God commanded thee (Ibid.) to the commandment dealing with honoring one’s father and mother.

Yitro reads, Thou shalt not murder. Thou shalt not commit adultery. Thou shalt not steal. Thou shalt not bear false witness (v. 13). Va-Etchannan reads: Thou shalt not murder. Neither shalt thou commit adultery. Neither shalt thou steal. Neither shalt thou bear false witness (Deut. 5:17). Yitro reads, ed sheker (false witness) (v. 13). Va-Etchannan reads, ed shav (false witness) (Deut. 5:17). Yitro reads, Thou shalt not covet (lo tachmod) thy neighbor’s house; thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s wife (v. 14).

Va-Etchannan has, Neither shalt thou covet thy neighbor’s wife: neither shalt thou desire (ve-lo titaweh) thy neighbor’s house (Deut. 5:18). It also has, his field. “His field” is missing in Yitro. In Yitro, his man-servant, nor his maid-servant precede his ox, nor his ass (v. 14). However, in Va-Etchannan (Deut. 5:18) his ox, or his ass precede his man-servant, or his maid-servant. 10
Yitro states: And God spoke all these words, saying (v. 1). However, Va-Etchannan reads: These words the Lord spoke unto all your assembly (Deut. 5:19).

When we searched the words of our sages to see what they said concerning this, we found that they said, “Remember (v. 8) and Observe (Deut. 5:12) were uttered simultaneously.”11 Now this statement is, as I will explain, more difficult than all the other questions which we raised. Heaven forbid that I say the sages spoke incorrectly, for our minds are insignificant in comparison to theirs. The problem is that our contemporaries take the words of our sages at face value. However, this is not so, as I will explain after I finish noting all of the questions this chapter raises. I will then explain the proper way to remove all problems and questions pertaining to this chapter.

Observe and Remember could have been uttered simultaneously only miraculously. Now even if we admit that a miracle did occur there is still room to ask why Scripture did not write Remember and Observe in Yitro and also in Va-Etchannan? Furthermore, what shall we do with the other verses that come in two versions? If we assume that they were simultaneously uttered, like Observe and Remember, why didn’t our sages of blessed memory mention it, as this is an even greater miracle? For even if we assume that two different words with one meaning can be uttered simultaneously, one can still ask, how is it possible for many verses with different meanings to be stated at the same time? Additionally, why would God say, as the Lord thy God commanded thee (Deut. 5:12)?12 Furthermore, when before the assembly around Mount Sinai did the Lord command one to honor his father and mother?13

Yitro does not have, that it may be well with thee (Deut. 5:16).14 Hence God said this, or He did not say it.15 Furthermore, how could God say, Neither shalt thou commit adultery (Deut. 5:17)?16 Also, how could God say, thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s house (v. 14) and in Va-Etchannan say, Neither shalt thou covet thy neighbor’s wife (Deut. 5:18)?17 Additionally, how could God say, his man-servant, or his maid-servant18 and then his ox, or his ass, and at the same time say the opposite?19 It is impossible to rationally accept such things.

Even more difficult than all of the things that I have mentioned above is that all the wonders which Moses performed have some parallel [in the world of our experience].20 This will be understood by the intelligent. Now, God’s saying Remember and Observe simultaneously is a wonder of wonders.21 Such a wonder should have been clearly recorded in the Torah more than all the signs and wonders that are noted therein. Even if we maintain that God’s speech is unlike human speech,22 how did Israel understand what God was saying? For if a person hears, Remember, and Observe simultaneously, he understands neither the one nor the other. Even in the case of one word, namely, the word zakhor (remember),23 if one does not hear the zayin enunciated before the kaf and the resh he will not understand what the speaker is saying.

We clearly know that the eye perceives much better than the ear does, for we have indisputable proof that thunder sounds at the very moment that the lightning is seen. Now the eye perceives the lightning from a distance.24 However, the sound is brought to the ear by the air. The sound travels slowly and does not reach the ear until a moment has passed. Now the forms of the letters that one enunciates are “written” in the air after the manner of the five organs which produce them.25 They are not written in the manner of script, which is produced by the human hand.26 Now the entire letter zayin enters the ear before the kaf, the vav, and the resh.27 Even if we assume that Remember and Observe were miraculously uttered simultaneously, how was Israel able to understand what was being said? If we assume that the ear, which does not normally have the ability to hear two words at the time, was at that time miraculously able to hear two words at the same time, why didn’t the sages of blessed memory mention this? For this is a greater miracle than God’s uttering two words simultaneously.28 Aside from this, what shall we do with the remaining questions relating to variant verses which, unlike Observe and Remember, do not have the same meaning? What are we to do with statements that appear in Va-Etchannan29 and do not appear in Yitro?30 Also, how are we to harmonize Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s house (v. 14) with Neither shalt thou covet they neighbor’s house (Deut. 5:18)?31 How are we to explain the reversals?32

I cannot explain the above to you33 until I first make clear to you the rules of the Hebrew tongue.34 Now God is my witness, He knows the deepest recesses of my mind. God knows that I would have remained silent if I did not have to explain the above difficulties.35 However, before I begin, I will explain the words of our sages of blessed memory.36

Abraham the author declares: It is the style of those who speak Hebrew to express their thoughts very clearly at times. However, at other times it is their style to say what they must in as few words as is necessary for a person to understand their meaning. Note that words are like bodies and their meanings are like souls. The body is, at it were, a vessel for the soul. Hence all the wise men of all nations37 are in the habit of preserving the ideas conveyed by a word38 and are not concerned with changes in wording when the meaning remains one and the same. I will now offer you a number of examples.39

God told Cain: And now cursed art thou from the ground, which hath opened her mouth to receive thy brother’s blood from the ground… When thou tillest the ground, it shall not henceforth yield unto thee her strength; a fugitive and a wanderer shalt thou be in the earth (Gen. 4:11,12). Cain replied: Behold, Thou hast driven me out this day from the face of the land (Gen. 4:14). Now who is so simple as to think40 that the latter verse does not convey what the former verse does because of the change in words.

Look, Eliezer said, Give me to drink (hagmi’ini), I pray thee (Gen. 24:17). However, he quoted himself as saying, Let me drink (hashkini), I pray thee (Gen. 24:45). Moses said, the firstborn of the captive that was in the dungeon (Ex. 12:29). However, it is earlier written, the first-born of the maid-servant that is behind the mill (Ex. 11:5). In Deuteronomy, Moses quoted the prayer which he offered on behalf of Israel because of the golden calf (Deut. 9:26-29). Now to the unintelligent, this prayer appears totally different from the one recorded in the Torah portion Ki Tissa (Ex. 32:11-14). The general rule is, one will find the same meaning in different words whenever anything is repeated in Scripture, such as the dreams of Pharaoh41 and Nebuchadnezzar,42 and many other things.

Now Scripture, as I noted, sometimes abridges and other times elaborates. It does the same with prefixes.43 At times it adds them. At other times it leaves them out. However, the meaning remains the same. Thus God said, and blue,44 and purple (Ex. 25:4). However, Moses said, blue,45 and purple (Ex. 28:6). God said, onyx stones46 (Ex. 25:7). However, Moses said, and onyx stones47 (Ex. 35:9). There are many such instances. Either way is correct, as the verse which leaves out the vav is employing a concise style. There is no harm in it.48 Similarly, the verse which has a vav in it does no harm because it adds clarity.

Now one does not search for a reason that a vav, which is enunciated by the mouth,49 is sometimes left out, sometimes written, and sometimes added.50 For any of the aforementioned51 is correct. We do not look for the reason why an enunciated vav was written.52 This being the case, why should we look for reasons regarding53 the silent vav which is not enunciated? For example, we should not ask why the word le-olam (forever)54 is written with or without a vav.55 Now people want reasons for full and also for deficient spellings. I would have kept silent if they wanted reasons for each one of them,56 or if there was only one way to spell these words.57 I will give you an example. Suppose someone tells me, “Write the following to my friend: I so and so love you forever;” and I spelled ploni (so and so) without a vav, and also ohevekha (I love you) without a vav and le-olam (forever) deficiently.58 Then Reuben came to me and asked me why I wrote deficiently. Now my concern is to write what I was told to write. I am not concerned with full or deficient spellings.59 Perhaps Levi will come along and teach me how to write.60 I do not want to dwell on this. However, the intelligent will understand what I mean.61

I will now explain the above-noted difficulties.62 Note that this chapter preserves the wording of the Ten Statements exactly as uttered by God, for Scripture states, And God spoke all these words, saying (v. 1). The statements open with I am the Lord thy God, and close with nor any thing that is thy neighbor’s (v. 14). Moses also noted, These words the Lord spoke unto all your assembly in the mount out of the midst of the fire (Deut. 5:19) when he mentioned the Ten Statements a second time. The Ten Statements have no break in them.63 Furthermore, the Lord uttered all of them exactly as they were written by the finger of God. One can refute the evidence64 from the third, fourth, and fifth statements, which are not in the first person,65 as follows: now that you have accepted the Lord as your God,66 Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain (v. 7).67 Similarly for in six days the Lord made heaven and earth (v. 11).68 It should also be noted that it is the style of those who speak Hebrew to speak in this manner.69 Thus Scripture states, neither shall the fat of My feast remain all night until the morning (Ex. 23:18). This is then followed by into the house of the Lord thy God (Ex. 23:19). There are many such examples.

Those who say that the first statement70 is not part of the Ten Statements differ in the following. Some say that Thou shalt have no other gods before Me (v. 3) is the first statement, and Thou shalt not make unto thee a graven image (v. 4) the second. However, this is incorrect, as both statements deal with one and the same thing.71 One (v. 3) deals with accepting another god in secret and the other (v. 4) openly.72 One (v. 3) deals with belief and the other (v. 4) with action. Now in the statement Remember the sabbath day, to keep it holy…thou, thy son…thy daughter, openly or secretly is all in the one commandment (v. 8).73

Others say that Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s house (v. 14) is the ninth statement, and thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s wife (Ibid.) is the tenth.74 They offer as proof the fact that God said, Thou shalt not covet twice, for there are two types of coveting. One is active, like an act of thievery, as in neither shall any man covet thy land (Ex. 34:24).75 Now if the latter dealt with coveting in one’s heart, then the Land of Israel would be a bad place.76 The second type of coveting is with one’s heart. Hence Moses had to explain77 that its meaning is,78 thou shalt not desire.79 However, this too80 is nonsense. Why would God mention thievery only with regard to a house and not mention other things along with it?81

I will offer you proof from the very words of Moses that these commentators explained incorrectly. Look, God said, Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s house (v. 14). However, Moses said, Neither shalt thou covet thy neighbor’s wife (Deut. 5:18). In their opinion, the second Thou shalt not covet written in our chapter refers to coveting with one’s heart, and the first one deals with the theft of a house. If this is the case, then Moses82 inverted the matter, for he used, Neither shalt thou desire with thy neighbor’s house, and Thou shalt not covet, which means thou shalt not steal, with thy neighbor’s wife. Their definitions are thus destroyed. The truth of the matter is that I am the Lord thy God is, as I will explain in its place, the first statement.

I will now comment on Remember and Observe. Note that the meaning, not the wording, is preserved.83 Thus our father Isaac said to Esau, that my soul may bless thee before I die (Gen. 27:4). However, Rebekah told Jacob that she heard Isaac say, and bless thee before the Lord before my death (Gen. 27:7). Now lifne moti (before I die) (Ibid.) means the same as betrem amut (before I die).84 This being the case,85 why did Rebekah add, before the Lord?86 The answer is that Rebekah knew that Isaac was a prophet of the Lord and that the blessing which he would pronounce would be prophetically uttered. Hence she said, before the Lord to Jacob.87 She was, as it were, explaining the meaning of the blessing.88 Moses acted in a similar fashion. The Ten Statements recorded in this chapter are God’s very words without any additions or subtractions, and they alone were inscribed on the tablets of the covenant. It is not as Saadiah says that Remember was on one side and Observe was on the second side.89

The Ten Statements recorded in the Torah portion Va-Etchannan are the words of Moses. The fact that the second version twice reads, as the Lord thy God commanded thee90 is positive proof that this is so.91

Note that memory is stored in the back of brain, which is in the head. The forms are there preserved. Now memory includes observance.92 The meaning of Remember is that one should keep in mind every day of the week what day that happens to be.93 The reason for all of this is that one will observe the seventh day and do no work on it. The reason for remembering is for observance.94 Thus when God said, Remember, all the people understood that its meaning was, Observe. Hence Remember and Observe were, as it were, said simultaneously.

Moses [similarly] had no need to mention for in six days the Lord made heaven and earth (v. 11) in the second version95 because he had at first stated, as the Lord thy God commanded thee (Deut. 5:13). The latter clause is to be understood as if it read, as the Lord thy God commended thee in “your Torah,”96 in the commandment opening with Remember (v. 8) and closing with and hallowed it (v. 11).

Now God commanded that man- and maid-servants rest on the Sabbath.97 The Lord, however, did not give a reason for this.98 Moses therefore explained the reason. Moses said the reason God commanded that servants should rest on the Sabbath is that a person should remember that, like the servant, he too was a slave in Egypt, and God redeemed him from there.
Note that eight of the statements are entirely negative commandments and that Honor thy father and thy mother99 is a positive commandment.

The rational wisdom which God has implanted in man’s heart teaches us that we are obligated to repay with good the good that a person has done for us. Now a child comes into the world only because of his parents. They nurse him, they care for him, they raise him, they give him to drink, they feed him, and they dress him. One has to honor one’s parents because they are the cause of his living upon the face of the earth. Hence the reward for honoring one’s parents is that thy days may be long upon the land (v. 12). God commanded a person to honor his parents because God breathed a soul into him100 through his parents who prepared the body, for he who honors them honors God. Now Moses said, Honor thy father and thy mother (Deut. 5:16) and then added by way of explanation, as the Lord thy God commanded thee (Ibid.).101 As I will explain in my comments on the verse that opens with the words Thou shalt not eat it (Deut. 12:25), reward is given for the observance of the positive commandments and punishment is meted out for the violation of negative commandments. Moses thus said that one is obligated to honor one’s parents that thy days may be long (Deut. 5:16). The obligation to honor one’s parents is dictated by reason. In addition, one who honor’s his parents will receive a good reward, namely, thy days will be long because one listened to the voice of God who commanded us to honor them. Thus what was noted in the explanation of Rebekah’s words102 also applies to what Moses said.

I have already noted that the terms onyx stones and and onyx stones mean the same thing. Thou shalt not commit adultery (v. 13) and Neither shalt thou commit adultery (Deut. 5:17), and ed sheker (false witness) (v. 13) and ed shav (false witness) (Deut. 5:17), are similarly “children of one father.”103 Thou shalt not covet (v. 14) and neither shalt thou desire (Deut. 5:18) likewise come out of one womb.104 God said, Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s house (v. 14) because intelligent people first acquire a house and then a wife, next a man-servant and a maid-servant, and then an ox and an ass to plow their fields. Our chapter lists these items in this order. However, Moses105 listed them in another order, for young men first desire a woman, then a house. Now since Moses spoke of the house and the field, he next took note of the ox and the ass106 because they are used in plowing one’s field. Moses next mentioned the man-servant and the maid-servant. At the very end Moses, like God, generalized and said, or any thing that is thy neighbor’s (Deut. 5:18).
Scripture reads, These words the Lord spoke (Deut. 5:19), and not all these words (v. 1) as is first written, because God’s words are intermingled with Moses’ words.
THE FIRST STATEMENT: I AM THE LORD.

Note that all of the commandments fall into one of the following two categories. One category consists of rational laws which God implanted into the minds of all intelligent human beings. There are many such commandments. The only one of the Ten Statements which does not fall into this category is the command to observe the Sabbath. Hence every intelligent human being of every nation and of every tongue assents to them, for they are implanted in the human mind by reason. There is nothing to add to them or to subtract from them. Abraham observed them along with additional precepts.107 God gave the Torah only to rational human beings. He who is without reason has no Torah.

The second category that the precepts fall into is that of “hidden commandments,” that is, commandments for which that the Torah does not reveal any reason. Far be it, far be it for one to even think that any of these commandments contradict reason. We must in all instances observe everything that God has commanded us, whether their secret has or has not been revealed to us. If we find that one of the commandments contradicts reason, then we should not take it at face value but must search for its meaning in the books of our wise men, of blessed memory, to find out whether it is a parable. If we do not find this recorded,108 then we must investigate and try to understand it with all of our strength. Perhaps we can explain it. If we cannot, then we must leave it as it is and admit that we do not know its meaning.109 Circumcise therefore the foreskin of your heart (Deut. 10:16) is an example of the aforementioned. Now did God command us to sadistically murder people?110 We know of a certainty that each one of the commandments that are not placed upon us by reason has a secret meaning to it, though it be hidden from us. The fact that in some instances Scripture gives the reason why they were commanded is proof of this. Thus Scripture tells us that the Sabbath is in memory of God’s creation of the world; and the festival of unleavened bread, that thou mayest remember the day when thou earnest forth out of the land of Egypt (Deut. 16:3). Scripture states, Love ye therefore the stranger; for ye were strangers in the land of Egypt (Deut. 10:19).111 Sowing with two kinds of seeds is prohibited, lest the fullness of the seed…be forfeited (Deut. 22:9). Scripture states, Only he112 shall not multiply horses so that he does not cause the people to return to Egypt (Deut. 17:16).113 It similarly gives the reason why Neither shall he114 multiply wives to himself (Deut. 17:17), namely, that his heart turn not away (Ibid.). The latter is not an independent commandment as Rabbi Simeon ben Kayyara115 states.116 Scripture similarly tells us the reason for and he117 shall read therein118 (Deut. 17:19), namely, that his heart be not lifted up above his brethren (Deut. 17:20). We similarly find in the chapter dealing with the assembly,119 and that they may learn120 (Deut. 31:12). This is the case with many commandments.121 Hence122 every intelligent human being whose eyes have been opened by God can learn from the Torah the secret of all the commandments.

There are three types of commandments, namely, commandments observed with one’s heart, commandments observed by speech, and commandments observed by acts. The commandments observed with the heart are of two sorts, namely, positive and negative commandments. The positive commandments include: Therefore thou shalt love the Lord thy God (Deut. 11:1); and to cleave unto him (Deut. 11:22); that thou mayest fear this glorious and awful Name (Deut. 28:58); but thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself (Lev. 19:18). The negative commandments include: Thou shalt not hate thy brother in thy heart (Lev. 19:17.); Thou shalt not take vengeance, nor bear any grudge (Lev. 19:18).

The commandments observed by speech also consist of positive and negative commandments. Among the positive commandments are: reading the shema, saying grace after meals, uttering the priestly benedictions, and making a confession [declaration] when one brings tithes.123 There are many such commandments. Among the negative precepts124 we find: Thou shalt not bear false witness (v. 13); Thou shalt not revile God (Ex. 22:27), and Thou shalt not curse the deaf (Lev. 19:14).
The positive commandments and negative commandments observed through actions are legion. There is no reason to mention them.

The commandments incumbent on the heart are the most important and the most prominent of the commandments.125 Many people think that with the exception of idol worship there are no sins connected to thought.126 The truth of the matter is that idol worship is worse than all the other mental sins put together. Can they127 not see that Scripture writes, There are six things which the Lord hateth (Prov. 6:16), and then goes on to say, A heart that deviseth wicked thoughts (Prov. 6:18). Scripture furthermore states: thou didst well that was in thy heart (II Chron. 6:8); Do good, O Lord, unto the good, And to them that are upright in their hearts (Ps. 125:4); Let your heart therefore be whole with the Lord our God (I Kings 8:61): I the Lord search the heart (Jer. 17:10); but the Lord looketh on the heart (I Sam. 16:7).

Now the first statement128 is the basis of the nine that follow it. Its place is among the precepts of the heart.129 The first statement teaches that one should believe with an unwavering faith that this glorious God, whose name is written but not pronounced,130 is one’s only God.

Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi, who rests in glory, once asked me why God said, I am the Lord thy God, who brought thee out of the land of Egypt rather than, I am the Lord thy God who made heaven and earth and created you? I answered the following. Know that people who believe in God the glorious are not on the same level of faith. Many believe what they have heard; that is, they believe because their masters have told them so. Above them are those who believe because of what they have read in the Torah, which God gave to Moses. Now they would place their hands upon their mouths131 if a heretic were to come along and argue that God does not exist, for they do not possess the means to answer. Now a person whose heart has moved him132 to study the sciences, which are the steps that lead to the place of his desire,133 will see God’s work in the metals, in the plants and living creatures, and in the human body itself. He will know the makeup of each organ according to the scientific explanations of how each organ functions. He will similarly know the reason for each organ’s form. His heart will then aspire to learn the science of the spheres that are the Lord’s works in the middle world,134 which is everlasting. He will learn when the sun or moon is eclipsed. He will know how the moon causes the sun to be eclipsed. He will know why the moon is eclipsed and what causes its eclipses. He will know these things and be able to prove them beyond a shadow of a doubt.

The intelligent person will come to know God by learning the ways of God.135 Moses similarly stated, show me now Thy ways, that I may know Thee (Ex. 33:13). Now God the revered proclaimed, I am the Lord thy God in His first statement.136 Only one who is of great intellect can understand this.137 I have already explained in the Torah portion, Ve-Eleh Shemot that God alone is everlasting without any change and that there is none aside from Him that exists forever, and none aside from Him is enthroned of old, Selah, (Ps. 55:20).

God alone maintains the uppermost world138 by His power. The middle world is maintained by God’s power and by His holy angels, who are of the uppermost world. Ours, the lowest of the worlds, is maintained by God’s power plus the power of the two higher worlds. Now the statement I am the Lord is sufficient for the intelligent of any nation.139 But only Israel140 believes that the sky and earth were made close to five thousand years ago. The nations of the world do not deny that God alone made sky and earth. They differ only in that they maintain that God continuously creates without beginning or end.141

Now the Lord performed signs and wonders in Egypt until Moses brought them out of there so that He would be their God. Moses similarly said, Or hath God assayed to go and take Him a nation from the midst of another nation (Deut. 4:34). The meaning of the latter is that God did for Israel what He did not do for any other nation. God created the middle world.142 He rules over the lowest of the worlds.143 Good or bad befalls every nation according to the arrangement of its star, for this is what God has apportioned to them. Now Israel was destined to continue in slavery according to the stars of its constellation. However, because of God’s love of the patriarchs, the Lord used His power to bring forth signs in the lowest world which were not decreed by the powers of the middle world. God removed Israel from the rule of the constellations and made them the people of His very own inheritance. It is because of this that the ancients say, “Israel has no star.”144 I will yet explain this via parables in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.

It was because of the signs that God performed in Egypt that Moses said, Unto thee it was shown, that thou mightest know that the Lord, He is God; there is none else beside Him (Deut. 4:35). Everyone, learnèd and nonlearnèd, adults and children, witnessed this. When recounting the events at the assembly at Sinai,145 Moses added that Israel heard God’s voice. Thus, following the latter, Moses said, Out of heaven He made thee to hear His voice, that He might instruct thee (Deut. 4:36). At the very end146 Moses said that ultimate knowledge consists in the development of one’s mind to the point where one is able to prove to himself that the Lord alone is God.147 Scripture therefore states, know this day, and lay it to thy heart, that the Lord, He is God in heaven above and upon the earth beneath; there is none else (Deut. 4:39). David similarly said, And thou, Solomon my son, know thou the God of thy father, and serve Him (I Chron. 28:9). Knowledge is in the heart.148 It does not refer to confession with one’s lips.149

Now it is for the intelligent that God said, I am the Lord.150 He added, who brought thee out of the land of Egypt (v. 2) so that the intelligent and the non-intelligent151 would understand. God added, thy God, meaning, you are obligated to serve me, that is, to be My servant and to be My people, and I will be your God, because I…brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage (Ibid.). The aforementioned was explained by Moses in the chapter that opens with the words When thy son asketh (Deut. 6:20.152 The meaning of the question153 is: why are we, more than any other nation, obligated to observe God’s commandments? Have we not all one creator?154

Moses gave three answers.155 The first one is, We were Pharaoh’s bondmen in Egypt (Deut. 6:21) and God did all these good things156 for us. We are therefore obligated, even if we do not know the reason for His commandments, to observe everything that God commands us to do. The second one is, God did not decree the commandments to us because of His own needs but rather for our good always (Deut. 6:24). The third is, And it shall be righteousness unto us; that is, we will be righteous people and thus merit the world to come if we observe to do all this commandment before the Lord our God, as He hath commanded us (Deut. 6:25).

The philosophers have discovered that there are ten aspects relating to that which is corporeal.157 They are primary categories. There is nothing above them. The first pertains to a thing’s essence. It is everlasting. The other nine are accidents. They depend on the first, are joined to it, and result from it. The first is like the number one in the number ten, for the entire sum158 came out of number one and all sums are found in it.159 One is the foundation.160

Now the first statement uttered by God the glorious includes all precepts directed at the heart, tongue, and human deeds. For one who does not believe in his heart that God exists has no commandments upon him. A person is obligated to mention God’s name every moment, to honor Him. Everything a person does,161 he must do only for the glory of God. A person should162 not keep from violating a negative precept except out of regard for God’s glory. For example, a man who gives charity to the poor should not give it out of respect for the collector, nor so that people should praise him. For if this is the case, then a human being’s status is more important in his eyes than the glory of God, who gave him wealth and abundance of money from which he can give charity and receive a reward from God.

The same applies to one who trespasses in secret so that163 his sin will not become known to the king, or people see him and come to consider him a shameful person. One who thinks thus164 is insane, for it is written, He that planted the ear, shall He not hear (Ps. 94:9). Now God sees the hidden things. He sees what people cannot openly see. God knows each one’s thoughts and his secrets. Now a person is afraid of the king165 who will die on the next day and not punish him, and does not fear the True King in whose hands is his soul in this world and in the next world.
The Gaon, Rabbi Saadiah composed azharot.166 He encompassed all the commandments167 in these Ten Statements.168

We find169 God’s name170 in the first five statements.171 I have already explained that the first statement is the foundation upon which all the commandments rest. It is followed by Thou shalt have no other gods. The sin of the one who does not believe in God is greater than the sin of the one who worships idols. For there are many who believe in the Lord and offer sacrifices to idols, like those who offered to the queen of heaven, because they think that it can help them. As the verse says, But since we let off to offer to the queen of heaven, and to pour out drink-offerings unto her, we have wanted all things (Jer. 44:18). Scripture also reads, They feared the Lord, and served their own gods (II Kings 17:33). We find the same with Naaman who said, when I prostrate myself in the house of Rimmon,172 the Lord pardon thy servant in this thing (II Kings 5:18). Now all of the above-mentioned believe in the Lord. However, they join another with Him. It is for this reason that the name of the revered God is written in this statement.173

God’s name is also written in the third statement, for swearing falsely is less of a sin than idolatry.174 Nevertheless, one who does this publicly shames the Lord. It is possible that the violator acts in this manner out of anger or need, for he believes in his heart in God and does not worship any deity along with the Lord.175

The fourth statement tells us that the Lord176 rested on the seventh day. Thus he who does work on the Sabbath denies that God created the world. Now this sin is less severe than taking the name of the Lord in vain.
The Lord’s name is written in the fifth statement because parents are God’s partners in the creation of a human being. If a person does not honor his parents, it is as if he is not honoring God.

The five remaining statements deal with sins against a fellow human being.177 The first one is the most heinous, namely, causing the soul to separate from the body. This is followed by the rape of the body.178 Next comes, Thou shalt not steal money. Afterwards comes stealing with the tongue. Next comes coveting with one’s heart.

3. THOU SHALT HAVE NO OTHER GODS. Scripture speaks from the point of view of the idol worshipper.179 It is similar to Then Hananiah the prophet180 took (Jer. 28:10); and, And the men pursued after them181 (Josh. 2:7). Samuel’s statement, Why hast thou disquieted me (I Sam. 28:15) is similar, for Scripture speaks from Saul’s point of view.182 This is not the place to explain it.183

[BEFORE ME.]184 Its meaning is like that of And Haran died before the face of his father185 Terah (Gen. 11:28), which means that Terah was with Haran and saw him die. Similarly, and Eleazar and Ithamar ministered in the priest’s office before the face of Aaron their father 186 (Num. 3:4). The meaning of our verse thus is, it is unseemly for you to worship any other god along with Me since I am your God and am always with you and see what you do. One of the wise men once said, “Do not anger your master when he sees you.” Now this commandment, namely, Thou shalt have no other gods is directed to the heart and to the mouth, for aside from this precept there is no other negative commandment in the Torah directed to the heart.187 If a man says in the presence of witnesses that he intends to murder or commit adultery, he will not be executed for what he said as long as he does not commit any act. However, Scripture states concerning anyone who says, Let us go and serve other gods (Deut. 13:7), but thou shalt surely kill him (Deut. 13:10). On the other hand, the statement Thou shalt not make unto thee a graven image (v. 4) deals with an act. It prohibits the making of a graven image out of wood or stone. It prohibits making any manner of likeness of anything that is in the heavens by any sort of means.

Scripture uses the term above because the heavens are above the earth on all sides. There are no likenesses in the heavens except for the forty-eight forms.188 Those who are wise about the forms do things that are wrong.189 What they do is very close to idolatry.

4. OR THAT IS THE EARTH BENEATH. There are many likenesses in the earth which is beneath the heavens190 and also in the water, as is explained in the Torah portion Ve-Etchannan.191 Scripture reads, the water under the earth because the sea and the earth are part of one globe.
5. THOU SHALT NOT BOW DOWN UNTO THEM. As do the masters of the forms,192 who think that they can cause upper powers to descend for the needs of a given person.

NOR SERVE THEM. Thou shalt have no other gods before Me includes sacrificing and offering to the gods. It also includes the prohibition and make no mention of the name of other gods, neither let it be heard out of thy mouth (Ex. 23:13) and the book of Joshua’s statement nor cause193 to swear by them (Josh. 23:7).
[A JEALOUS GOD.] What God demands is only logical,194 for how can you give the honor due to the Lord who created you and sustains your life to another who can neither harm nor aid.195

Scripture employs the term el (god) to inform us that the Lord is mighty and can exact vengeance at any moment from the idol worshipper without the sinner being able to save himself. Jeremiah said, every man that eateth the sour grapes, his teeth shall be set on edge (Jer. 31:30). The book of Ezekiel clearly states that God the revered swore that the son shall not bear the iniquity of the father (Ezek. 18:20). This being the case, what does Scripture mean by visiting the iniquities of the father upon the children? The answer is that which Ezekiel clearly states. If a father was wicked and his son did not follow in his footsteps, then the son does not bear the iniquity of the father.196 For visiting the iniquities197 is, as I have noted, connected to God’s enemies.198

Poked (visiting) has the same meaning as zokher (remembering).199 Compare, And the Lord visited (pakad) Sarah (Gen. 21:1).200 which is another way of saying, and the Lord remembered (va-yizkor) Sarah. God is patient with the wicked because it is possible that he will repent and bear a son who is better than he. Now if the son walks in the footsteps of his father and so do the third and fourth generations, then God will not be patient and withhold his anger from the fourth generation. If all of them until four generations are enemies of God, then they will all perish in the fourth generation. For God will remember what the father did, what the son did, and what the grandson did. Hence he will not keep his anger in check when it comes to the fourth generation.
Grandchildren are considered as children.201 Hence Scripture employed a shortened form. One can understand this202 from the terms the third and fourth generation.203

6. AND SHOWING MERCY UNTO THE THOUSANDTH GENERATION.204 Scripture elsewhere reads, to a thousand generations (Deut. 7:9). Some people think this represents a problem.205 However, it does not, for Scripture reads as follows: if you will observe My commandments then God will keep the covenant and the mercy which He swore unto your ancestors, that is, to the three patriarchs.206 This is the meaning of who keepeth covenant and mercy with them that love Him and keep His commandments to a thousand generations (Deut. 7:9). However this chapter deals with another matter. Scripture here states, and showing mercy to thousands.207 Its meaning is, without end, namely, forever. This can be explained in two ways. One, God shows mercy to those who love Him by granting everlasting existence to their souls so that they remain alive for thousands upon thousands of years. Two, that God will eternally show mercy to their offspring who are like them. David similarly said, But the mercy of the Lord is from everlasting to everlasting upon them that fear Him, And His righteousness unto children’s children (Ps. 103:17).

Now there is no doubt that God’s mercy is eternally upon those who fear Him.208 It is only because Scripture mentions the children’s children,209 in keeping with And His righteousness endureth for ever (Ps. 111:3), that Scripture has to explain that this only applies if the children are good. Scripture therefore says that this is so only in regard to those who keep God’s covenant. When I comment upon the Torah portion Ki Tissa, I will explain to you why the attribute of visiting the sins of the fathers is to be counted among the attributes of mercy.210
[THEM THAT LOVE ME.] The reference is to the pious.211
[AND KEEP MY COMMANDS.] The reference is to the righteous.212

7. THOU SHALT NOT TAKE THE NAME OF THE LORD THY GOD IN VAIN. The word shem (name) has the same meaning as the word zekher (memory). It serves as a sign of the one who is so called.213 However, the term zekher is employed in Hebrew at times when someone is recalled in memory, and at times when someone is recalled in speech, whereas names are only used with reference to the latter. We thus find David saying, Nor take their names upon my lips (Ps. 16:4). Now when a person mentions God’s name214 he is saying, as God is True so is what I will say true. Thus if he does not keep his word, he is, as it were, denying God. It is still the custom in Egypt for one to incur the death penalty if he swears by the head of the king and does not keep his word. The culprit is not spared even if he gives his ransom in gold because he publicly insulted the king. If this is the case with regard to a king of flesh and blood, how many thousands of times more does one have to be careful that one’s mouth does not cause his tongue to stumble and bring his flesh into guilt by mentioning God’s name in vain.215

Now Scripture tells us that Israel publicly took an oath because of the incident involving the concubine at Gibeah. We find that those who violated the oath were put to death.216 It should be noted that Phineas the priest was there.217 Similarly with the people of Jabesh-gilead, men, women, and children.218 Even those who desecrate the Sabbath are not dealt with in this manner.219 We also read that Saul wanted to kill his son Jonathan for desecrating an oath that Jonathan was not even aware of.220 Scripture also tells us221 that God brought a famine upon the land because Saul and his house violated the oath taken by the leaders of Israel which they swore unto the Gibeonites.222 We are told that when the house of blood was put to death, God was entreated for the land.223 Solomon similarly said to Shimei, Did I not make thee to swear by the Lord (I Kings 2:42).224

The sum of the matter is that with the exception of honoring one’s parents,225 we do not find the reward for observing a commandment clearly spelled out in any of the Ten Statements. We similarly do not find the punishment for violating a commandment226 spelled out except for idolatry and taking God’s name in vain. Many think that a person who takes the name of the Lord in vain does not commit a great sin. I will show that in reality it is more severe than any of the other prohibitions which follow. For a murderer cannot commit murder, nor an adulterer adultery, both of which are major sins, whenever they want to because they are afraid of being caught. However, the person who is the habit of swearing falsely will daily utter innumerable vows. Such a person is so accustomed to committing this sin that he is not even aware that he is taking an oath. Should someone chide him and say to him, “Why are you swearing?” he responds by swearing that he did not swear, because he is so habituated to swearing. For he prefaces anything he says by saying, “I swear.” They227 think that this is an elegant way to speak.228

If Israel was guilty only of this sin it would be cause enough to prolong the exile and add blows to our blows. I will now demonstrate their madness. For a murderer who kills his enemy satisfies his impulses by exacting vengeance. Similarly the adulterer for the moment. Likewise the thief who finds pleasures for his needs, and the false witness who does so to gain favor or revenge. Now the one who is constantly swearing, although there is no need for him to do so publicly, desecrates the name of God without deriving any benefit from his act.

8. REMEMBER THE SABBATH DAY TO KEEP IT HOLY. The meaning of to keep it holy is explained by what follows, namely, Six days shalt thou labor. Scripture similarly explains the meaning of and hallowed it (v. 11) by going on to say that God rested on the seventh day from all of His work. The reason the sanctification of the Sabbath is here connected to the Lord blessed [the sabbath day], as it is in the chapter opening with the words were finished (Gen. 2:1), is that God sanctified this day and prepared it so that the souls229 would receive an infusion of wisdom above that of the other days. That is why Scripture states the Lord blessed [the sabbath day].230 I have already explained this in my comments on A Psalm, a Song. For the sabbath day.231

We have seen232 that the sabbatical year is similar to the Sabbath.233 It too is a seventh, that is, it falls every seven years. God commanded that the Torah be read at the beginning of the year234 in the presence of the men, women, and little ones. The reason for this is that they may hear, and that they may learn…and observe to do all the words of this law (Deut. 31:12). Now the Sabbath was given235 for understanding the works of God and the study of His Torah. Scripture thus states,236 For Thou, Lord, hast me glad through Thy work (Ps. 92:5).237 A person is occupied with his needs all the days of the week. However, it is only right that he separate himself on the Sabbath and rest for the sake of God’s glory. He should not occupy himself with vanity by spending his time seeking advice, even if it concerns his past needs. He should similarly not seek counsel about what he should do in the future. The prophet similarly said, Nor pursuing thy business,238 nor speaking thereof (Is. 58:13).

It was customary for the Israelites to travel before the onset of the Sabbath to where the prophets lived, as indicated in Wherefore wilt thou go to him to-day? it is neither new moon nor sabbath (II Kings 4:23).
I have239 already noted that whosoever does any work on the Sabbath is in essence denying creation. However, such an individual does not deny the existence of God the revered.240

There can be no doubt that the word thou includes all those who are obligated to observe the commandments. Hence nor thy son, nor thy daughter (v. 10) refers to small children for whose rest their father is responsible. Scripture tells us that we are obligated to guard them241 lest they do anything on the Sabbath that we are prohibited from doing. The same applies to nor thy man-servant, nor thy maid-servant who is in our power. We our obligated to guard him and not allow him to do any work for another party; otherwise, we violate a negative commandment,242 so that thy man-servant and thy maid-servant may rest as well as thou (Deut. 5:14). This was explained by Moses our master in the way we have noted.243 It is only on this condition that the stranger may dwell in our gates, namely, that the stranger does not do any work on the Sabbath and on Yom Kippur.244 Hence the stranger is also mentioned in the second version.245 It is the same case with the sexual prohibitions.246 The stranger may dwell among us only if he observes the sexual prohibitions. Likewise with regard to eating blood.247

When reading the Book of Jeremiah we noticed that the prophet was very strict about the Sabbath.248 The prophet explicitly stated that if Israel returns to Sabbath observance and keeps the Sabbath as they were commanded to, then even though the decree that Jerusalem be destroyed was issued, they would not be exiled from their place, and the thrones of the Davidic dynasty would remain standing in Jerusalem.249

12. HONOR THY FATHER AND THY MOTHER, AS THE LORD THY GOD COMMANDED THEE. I have already noted that the Lord’s name is mentioned in the first five statements. In all of these statements we find the form, the Lord thy God.

[THAT THY DAYS MAY BE LONG.] The word ya’arikhun (may be long) is a transitive verb. Its meaning is that one’s parents will be the cause of one’s days being long.250 The term ta’arikhu (ye may prolong) in and that ye may prolong your days (Deut. 11:9) and ve-ha’arakhta (that thou mayest prolong) in and that thou mayest prolong thy days (Deut. 22:7) are proof of this.251 You will find that because of the commandment which you observe, you lengthen your days.252

[UPON THE LAND.] Scripture reads, upon the land because if Israel observes this commandment they will not be exiled from the land. The prophet Ezekiel similarly states, In thee253 have they made light of father and mother (Ezek. 22:7). The commandment Honor thy father and thy mother means that we should not do the opposite; that is, we should not curse or make light of our parents. Now one who curses his parents incurs the death penalty because people hear the curse come out of his mouth.254 However, this penalty does not apply to one who disrespects his parents, for one can do so in secret. Therefore the one who is disrespectful to his parents falls under a curse like all those who are listed as cursed,255 for their deeds were done in secret.

13. THOU SHALT NOT MURDER. With your hand or your tongue, that is, by giving false testimony which results in having someone executed, or by tale bearing,256 or by wickedly giving someone counsel which you know will result in his death, or by not revealing a secret which you are aware of, to someone who would be saved if he knew what you know. If you do not reveal the secret you are a murderer.

THOU SHALT NOT COMMIT ADULTERY. Many think that the term ni’uf (adultery) only applies to adultery257 because they found Scripture stating, asher yinaf et eshet re’ehu (even he that committeth adultery with his neighbor’s wife) (Lev. 20:10). What reason is there to state this, having just said, asher yinaf eshet ish (that committeth adultery with another man’s wife)?258 However, its meaning is not as they think.259

Now the previous verse reads, For whatsoever man there be that curseth his father or his mother shall surely be put to death; he hath cursed his father or his mother; his blood shall be upon him (Lev. 20:9). Its meaning is,260 he committed a great sin in cursing his parents who bore him. The same is true even of he that committeth adultery with his neighbor’s wife, whom261 he is obligated to love as himself. The word ni’uf refers to an illicit sexual act. Behold, we find that Scripture states, va-tinaf et ha-even ve-et ha-etz (and she committed adultery with stones and with stocks) (Jer. 3:9).262 However, it is unfit to discuss this abomination publicly.263

Saadiah Gaon says that there are many levels of illicit sexual acts. The least illicit level is sleeping with a virgin or widow.264 Next comes sleeping with one’s wife during her menstrual cycle, for she will be permitted to him in a few days. Then comes sleeping with someone else’s wife, for it is possible that her husband will die and she will be permitted to him. Next comes sleeping with a Canaanite woman,265 who does not follow Israelite law, without giving her seed, for it is possible that she will convert and he can then marry her. However, if he gives her seed then it is as if he himself is worshipping idols. Next comes sleeping with a male, which can never be permitted. Next comes bestiality, that is, intercourse with a nonhuman. The Gaon knew how to classify the various types of illicit intercourse,266 for Scripture decrees the penalty of karet267 for all of the illicit sexual acts listed in the Torah portion Achare Mot.268 Saadiah omitted intercourse with one’s mother, sister, and daughter from his list of different levels of illicit sexual acts.269

THOU SHALT NOT STEAL. Stealing implies taking money secretly. There are thieves who incur the death penalty, namely, those who kidnap an Israelite, be he a child or one who cannot speak clearly.270 The prohibition to steal money applies both to when the owner is present and to when he is not present. It also applies to cheating in number, measure, and weight. The term stealing also applies to what Absalom did,271 that is, it prohibits deceiving another person.

THOU SHALT NOT BEAR FALSE WITNESS. For many years I asked myself why Scripture employs the phrase ed sheker (false witness) and not edut sheker (false testimony). I now believe that Scripture is addressing the false witness, and our verse is to be interpreted as if it read, “Thou shalt not give testimony if thou art a false witness.” The implication of this clause is the same as that of neither shall ye deal falsely, nor lie one to another (Lev. 19:11). We find that a bet follows the word for testimony in and hath testified (anah) falsely against his brother (be-achiv) (Deut. 19:18). We also find this verb employed without a bet following it in yishma El ve-ya’anem (God shall hear, and testify against them) (Ps. 55:20).272 Now ve-ya’anem is a compound of ve-ya’aneh (and shall testify) and bam (against them).273 The phrase lo nega’anukha (not touched thee) in as we have not touched thee (Gen. 26:29) is similar, as the meaning of lo nega’anukha is lo naganu bakh (we have not touched thee).274
There is a type of false witness who incurs the death penalty, namely, the one concerning whom it is written, then shall ye do unto him, as he had purposed to do unto his brother (Deut. 19:19).275

14. THOU SHALT NOT COVET. Many people are amazed at this commandment. They ask, how is it possible for a person not to covet in his heart all beautiful things that appear desirable to him? I will now give you a parable.276 Note, a peasant of sound mind who sees a beautiful princess will not entertain any covetous thoughts about sleeping with her, for he knows that this is an impossibility. This peasant will not think like the insane who desire to sprout wings and fly to the sky, for it is impossible to do so. Now just as a man does not desire to sleep with his mother, although she be beautiful, because he has been trained from his childhood to know that she is prohibited to him, so must every intelligent person know that a person does not acquire a beautiful woman or money because of his intelligence or wisdom, but only in accordance with what God has apportioned to him. Indeed, Koheleth states, yet to a man that hath not labored therein shall he leave it for his portion (Eccles. 2:21). Furthermore, our sages taught, children, life, and sustenance are not dependent upon a person’s merits but upon the stars.277 The intelligent person will therefore neither desire nor covet. Once he knows that God has prohibited his neighbor’s wife to him she will be more exalted in his eyes than the princess is in the eyes of the peasant. He will therefore be happy with his lot and will not allow his heart to covet and desire anything which is not his. For he knows that that which God did not want to give him, he cannot acquire by his own strength, thoughts, or schemes. He will therefore trust in his creator, that is, that his creator will sustain him and do what is right in His sight.
Observe, we have completed explaining the Ten Statements.
One of the wise men of this generation said: We know that nine spheres278 correspond to the nine numbers279 that are the basis of all numbers.280 It is the same with these nine statements.281
Now the first statement, which corresponds to the glory of God the revered who speaks, is not included among the nine statements, for it is the first of the ten in number.282

Now the second statement, which is Thou shalt have no…etc. (v. 3), corresponds to the highest sphere, which moves west to east and propels the other spheres to make a twenty-four hour east-to-west circuit in contrast to its own motion.283 It is in reference to this sphere that Scripture states, other gods. It says this to let us know that the spheres run by the power of God. Many considered this sphere to be the creator because it is incorporeal.

The third statement, namely, Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain (v. 7), corresponds to the sphere of the constellations wherein are all the hosts of heaven, with the exception of the seven moving stars.284 Now this important sphere encompasses all the forty-eight bodies285 and their forms.286 God’s power is there revealed to the eye.287 There are places in this sphere which contain many stars. There are other places in it which have no stars. It is impossible for a man to know this secret. Many of those deficient in wisdom think that these forms in their arrangement were created in vain.288

The fourth statement, the statement about the Sabbath, corresponds to the sphere of Saturn. The astrologers289 tell us that each one of the moving stars has a certain day in the week in which its power is manifest.290 The star is the dominant power the first hour of the day.291 The same is true concerning the star which is the dominant power in the first hour of the night.292 They say that Saturn and Mars are harmful stars. Hence harm befalls anyone who begins any work or sets out on a journey when one or the other dominates. The sages therefore said that permission was given for harming293 on Wednesday night294 and on the eve of the Sabbath. Now we do not find these two “demons”295 ruling night and day, back to back, on any other day of the week except for Saturday.296 It is therefore unfit for one to occupy himself on Saturday with everyday matters. On the contrary, one should devote himself on this day to the fear of God.

The fifth statement, namely, Honor thy father and thy mother, corresponds to the sphere of Jupiter,297 which indicates peace, righteousness, mercy, and the obligation to reward and honor those to whom we owe a debt of gratitude.
The sixth statement, Thou shalt not murder, corresponds to the sphere of Mars, which points to bloodshed and wounding.

There is a difference of opinion among the astrologers about whether Venus is above or below298 the sun. The wise men of India brought proof that Venus is above.299 Now the seventh statement, namely, Thou shalt not commit adultery, corresponds to the sphere of Venus, the nature of which points to all acts of intercourse and harlotry.

The eighth statement, namely, Thou shalt not steal, corresponds to the sphere of the sun and indicates force. It removes the power of any planet300 that is in conjunction with it so that its light is not seen.
Now the ninth statement, namely, Thou shalt not bear false witness, corresponds to the sphere of Mercury, which indicates language.301
The tenth statement, namely, Thou shalt not covet, clearly corresponds to the sphere of the moon, which is the lowest of the spheres. It indicates desire.

15. AND ALL THE PEOPLE PERCEIVED THE THUNDERINGS.302 I have already explained the meaning of “saw the thunderings.”303 Scripture says the aforementioned because all the senses are perceived in one place.304 Now the meaning of our verse is: when Israel saw these wonders, that is, when the people perceived the thunderings and the lightning, which people normally fear, and the voice of the horn, a sound such as had never been heard of before, and the mountain smoking, they trembled. The meaning of va-yanu’u (and they trembled) is, and they moved; that is, each one of them turned from where he was standing and went backwards. Va-yanu’u is similar to the word na (a fugitive) in a fugitive and a wanderer (Gen. 4:12). The word va-yanu’u (were moved) in And the posts (amot) of the door (ha-sippim) were moved (Is. 6:4) is similar. The meaning of amot (posts) in the aforementioned verse is cubits, for the thresholds305 moved a number of cubits from their place.306 The prophet was not able to estimate, in his vision, how many cubits they moved. It is impossible to maintain that va-yanu’u means: and they trembled. For if Israel did not remove themselves from their place, how did they stand far off?

16. AND THEY SAID. The reference is to the priests and the heads of the tribes who were close to Moses. They spoke to Moses after the Ten Statements were completed because they were very anxious, for they feared that God would continue to speak to them and that they would consequently die. That is why Moses told them, Fear not (v. 17).

17. AND MOSES SAID. The lamed in the word le-va’avor (for) is superfluous.307 It is like the lamed in the word le-mabbarishonah (at the first) (I Chron. 15:13) and the lamed of le-avshalom (Absalom) in Absalom the son of Maacah (I Chron. 3:2).
[TO PROVE YOU.] To prove you is similar in meaning to and that He might prove thee, to do thee good at thy latter end (Deut. 8:16).
AND THAT HIS FEAR MAY BE BEFORE YOU. As it is written, the day that thou stoodest before the Lord thy God in Horeb (Deut. 4:10).308
18. AND THE PEOPLE STOOD AFAR OFF. Scripture mentions this a second time because Moses did the opposite. They stood from afar; however, Moses drew near the thick darkness.

19. AND THE LORD SAID. Many err because they found Scripture stating, and thou didst hear His words out of the midst of the fire (Deut. 4:36) that God was on Mount Sinai, for it is written, And the Lord came down upon mount Sinai (Ex. 19:20). However, Scripture here states, I have talked with you from heaven.

Now he who is intelligent will understand its meaning from my comments on the Torah portion Ki Tissa.309 What I will now do is offer a parable. Perhaps this will help the unintelligent understand. Imagine the form of a person standing with his feet on Mount Sinai and his head in heaven. This is the meaning of And the Lord came down (Ex. 19:20) and of God’s speaking from heaven. It is similar to And His feet shall stand in that day upon the mount of Olives (Zech. 14:4), for we know that God’s glory fills heaven and earth.310

20. YE SHALL NOT MAKE WITH ME. Its meaning is: Look, I who dwell in heaven spoke to you without any intermediary.311 Indeed, Scripture explicitly states, The Lord spoke with you face to face (Deut. 5:4).

Do not be perplexed because Scripture repeats, ye shall not make.312 Scripture is following elegant Hebrew style. It is similar to Thou shalt not covet (v. 14).313 It all has one meaning,314 to be read as follows: “Ye shall not make with Me gods of silver, or gods of gold.” It is like Thou shalt not make unto thee a graven image (v. 4). Its meaning is: do not make forms that receive powers from above and think that you make them for My glory, in that they will serve as an intermediary between Me and you, like the golden calf which Israel made. As I will explain in its place, Aaron made the golden calf for God’s glory.315 God warned Israel at the beginning316 not to make gods of gold because He knew that Israel would make the golden calf. The meaning of with Me thus is: I have no need for intermediaries to be with Me. Scripture therefore states afterwards, I will come unto thee and bless thee. Its meaning is, through My glory I will come unto thee.

21. AN ALTAR OF STONE.317 Some say that the reason318 is that they not make images on the altar. Scripture therefore commanded that the altar be constructed from unhewn stones. Perhaps these commentators can explain why the entire tabernacle was adorned with cherubim and why cherubim of gold were placed over the arkcover. Furthermore, the entire temple constructed by Solomon was decorated with cherubim, images,319 and open flowers (I Kings 6:32). These places were more important than the place of the altar.320 I will speak on this in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.

Some say that the meaning of An altar of earth is that the altar shall not be constructed on a high place. However, this is not what the words imply. The fact that Scripture goes on to state next, And if thou make Me an altar of stone is proof of this.321

Our sages said that An altar of earth means that the bronze altar322 is to be filled with earth. They spoke the truth, for that is what they did. However, this verse serves only as a reminder323 and as a support.324 This325 is not its literal meaning. The earth that was placed in the altar was not essential,326 and the altar327 was known only as the bronze altar. It was so named because it was made out of bronze. The altar of incense328 was also called the gold altar because it was covered with gold.329 Furthermore, if the implication of An altar of earth is an altar filled with earth, then the meaning of an altar of stone is an altar filled with stones. However, we cannot say that the altar330 was not constructed of stones, for Scripture explicitly tells us that it was made out of stones.331 The reference332 is to the altar made on Mount Ebal.

I will now explain. Saadiah Gaon says that there is a difference of opinion concerning the altar that Moses built beneath Mount Sinai.333 Some say that he built the altar before the giving of the Torah. Others maintain that he built it afterwards. The Gaon agrees with the first opinion. He says that what Scripture records in this chapter, namely, the chapter which contains the words All that the Lord hath spoken we will do (Ex. 19:8), is repeated in the second chapter, that is, in the chapter that reads, All that the Lord hath spoken will we do, and obey (Ex. 24:7).334

I will prove to you conclusively that Moses built the altar after the giving of the Torah. This chapter clearly states that God told Moses, when he went up to the mountain of God prior to the giving of the Torah, Ye have seen what I did unto the Egyptians…Now therefore, if ye will hearken unto My voice (Ex. 19:4, 5). God started by saying, Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob (Ex. 19:3). Now Moses did not relate335 any commandments, statutes, or ordinances to Israel. He merely wanted to hear from their very lips whether they wanted to listen to God’s voice and do what He commanded them. Israel replied by saying, we will do (Ex. 19:8). Scripture then goes on to report, And Moses told the words of the people unto the Lord (Ex. 19:9). Moses then sanctified Israel so that they would be fit to hear God’s word, which consisted of the Ten Statements. He now336 started to instruct the people in God’s commandments.

When Moses approached the thick darkness God told him everything stated in the section that begins, Ye shall not make with Me (v. 20)337 and the entire chapter of Now these are the ordinances (Ex. 21:1) up to, for they will be a snare unto thee (Ex. 23:33). Scripture then tells us, And Moses came (Ex. 24:3); that is, he came down from the mountain. Scripture then goes on to state, and [Moses] told the people all the words of the Lord and all the ordinances (Ibid.). The words of the Lord refers to the positive and negative commandments, starting with Ye shall not make with Me—gods of silver (v. 20); the account of the altar and all the positive and negative commandments found in the chapter that begins, And these are the Ordinances, such as thou shalt surely bring it back to him again (Ex. 23:4); thou shalt restore it unto him by that the sun goeth down (Ex. 22:25), and Thou shalt not revile God (Ex. 22:27). The ordinances refer to the laws dealing with slavery, assault, fights, goring, arson, theft, oaths. It is concerning these that Scripture there writes, and all the ordinances (Ex. 24:3). It is concerning these laws that our forefathers said, will we do, and obey (Ex. 24:7). The meaning of will we do is, we will observe the positive and the negative commandments. The meaning of and obey is: we will obey the ordinances. The Israelites therefore added and obey, something which they at first338 did not say339 following the giving of the Torah.

The meaning of An altar of earth clearly is, as the phrase implies, an altar made out of earth. This is what Scripture refers to when it writes later, and builded an altar under the mount (Ex. 24:4). Scripture here writes, and shalt sacrifice thereon thy burnt-offerings, and thy peace-offerings (v. 21), and it is there written, [and they] offered burnt-offerings, and sacrificed peace-offerings (Ex. 24:5).340

There is no doubt that the section beginning, An altar of earth and also Ye shall not make with Me (v. 20) were stated because of the blood of the covenant which Moses dashed on the altar (Ex. 24:6) and because the people pledged that the Lord alone would be their God and that they would observe His commandments and ordinances (Ex. 24:7).
Scripture mentions, thy sheep, and thine oxen (v. 21) because both of them are kinds of animals from which burnt offerings and peace offerings may be brought.341

I saw a heretic, may his bones be crushed, arguing against the sages of the Talmud for saying, Which was the place appointed for the sacrifices (Zevachim 5:1).342 The heretic claimed that he never found the Torah using the term sacrifice (zevach) except for a peace offering.343 We thus find Scripture speaking of a burnt offering and sacrifices (zevachim). The burnt offering is an entity unto itself, and sacrifices refer only to peace offerings, as in [and they] offered burnt-offerings, and sacrificed peace-offerings of oxen unto the Lord (Ex. 24:5). We344 find this to be the case all over. Now I showed this heretic that what he said was incorrect. Scripture here states, and shalt sacrifice345 thereon thy burnt-offerings, and thy peace-offerings. He then admitted that he sinned in contradicting people eminently greater than any who lived in all the generations that came after them.

[IN EVERY PLACE WHERE I CAUSE MY NAME TO BE MENTIONED.] Its meaning and interpretation is, in every place where I will set a memorial for My name, that is, in every place where My glory dwells such as Shilo and Nob where the ark stood. If you come to the aforementioned place for the sake of My name to visit Me, I too will come unto you and bless you.

[I WILL COME UNTO THEE.] This is an anthropomorphism. Its meaning is: you will find Me in the place upon which I cause My name to be mentioned, which is the place of My glory.346 I, as it were, came to you because I knew that you would come and it is because of you that I came. Furthermore, because you came to pay Me homage, I will come unto thee and bless thee. You will have no need to seek anyone else, for you will find Me as long as My glory is there.
22. AND IF THOU MAKE ME AN ALTAR OF STONE. The altar that Moses built to make a covenant with Israel with the blood of the covenant347 [was made out of earth].348

God commanded349 that Israel build an altar of stone on the other side of the Jordan before they would inherit the land and that they write the entire Torah upon the stones, because many of the commandments are contingent upon the Land of Israel.350 We similarly find that God required their children351 to build such an altar when they entered the land352 because of the commandments contingent upon the Land of Israel.353 They sacrificed and ate peace offerings there354 as their fathers did.355

According to the above, the meaning of And if thou make an altar of stone is, now build an altar of earth. However, if you are worthy to enter the Land of Israel, then you will make Me an altar of stone.
IT.356 The reference is to the stones.

HEWN STONES. Its meaning is similar to that of but his minister Joshua, the son of Nun, a young man (Ex. 33:11).357 Similarly here, lo tivneh ethem gazit (do not build a hewn structure out of them).358

The word gazit (hewn stones) comes from the same root as gozeze (shearers) in and went up unto his sheep-shearers (Gen. 38:12) and gaz (cut) in, For it is speedily cut, and we fly away (Ps. 90:10).359 It is the same case with nagozu (cut) in Even so shall they be cut down, and he shall pass away (Nahum 1:12). Its meaning360 is, cut.361 Only unhewn stones, that is, stones as God created them, [were to be used].

FOR IF THOU LIFTED UP THY TOOL UPON IT. The word cherev (tool) refers to an iron instrument made for cutting.362 It is possible that the instrument is called a cherev because it destroys (mecharevet). Scripture elsewhere states, thou shalt lift up no iron tool upon them (Deut. 27:5),363 that is, upon the altar of stones that Israel built.364

We should not look for explanations for the commandments. However, from a rational point of view it is possible that the prohibition against hewn stones is similar to the law governing “a vile thing.”365 It is unseemly for that which is left over from a sacrifice which was brought upon the altar to become vile, for if what remains of a sacrifice becomes vile then the sacrifice, which was sanctified, is defiled. The same is true of the prohibition against hewn stones. It is possible that the chips that result from the stone-cutting be profaned by being dedicated to idolatrous use if the builders cut stones in order to build an altar. The latter would be disrespectful. Now Scripture states366 that the priest atones upon the altar.367

23. NEITHER SHALT THOU GO UP BY STEPS UNTO MINE ALTAR. Ben Zuta says that be-ma’alot (by steps) comes from the same root as ma’al (trespass).368 However, he did not open his eyes and see that the mem in ma’al is a root letter, as u-ma’alah vo ma’al (and act unfaithfully against him) (Num. 5:12) proves.369 Now ma’al follows the paradigm of na’al.370 Its plural absolute form is ne’alot (shoes). Compare, and worn shoes (ne’alot) and clouted upon their feet, and worn garments (Josh. 9:5). Thus be-ma’alot should have been vocalized bi-me’alot, that is, with a chirik beneath the bet371 and a kamatz beneath the ayin.372 Be-ma’alot373 can only have the meaning of ma’alot374 in And there were seven steps (ma’alot) to go up to it (Ezek. 40:26).

Ben Zuta clearly intended to ascend the ladder of wisdom with his follies. However, his nakedness was uncovered thereon. This is what happens to every heretic who does not believe in the words of our ancient sages.
The law prohibiting the use of steps to go up to the altar takes in all altars of earth, stones, or copper. The phrase Mine altar implies all altars made for the Lord.

274 In other words, the kaf suffix stands for the word bakh. Thus in both cases the suffix stands for a bet.
275 If the false testimony would have resulted in an innocent person’s execution, then the false witness is put to death.
276 Which will aid you in understanding the commandment that prohibits coveting.
277 Mo’ed Katan 28a.
278 See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 and the notes thereto.
279 From 2 to 10.

281 Of the Decalogue.
282 It is the basis of all that follows. Similarly, the number one is not included among the ten numbers.
283 Which moves west to east.
284 Each of which has its own sphere. Literally, the seven ministers.
