287 God’s power is seen in the arrangement of the stars.
288 Hence the third statement reads, Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain.
289 Literally, the experimenters.
290 In other words, Saturn dominates on the Sabbath. Indeed, the name Saturday means Saturn’s day.
291 On which it is dominant.
292 The star which is dominant during the first hour of the night dominates that night.
293 Which I.E. interprets to mean for Mars and Saturn to have an evil influence.
294 Saturn dominates Wednesday night (Weiser).
295 Mars and Saturn.
296 Literally, this day Mars rules Friday eve and Saturn on Saturday (Weiser).
297 Hebrew, tzdek. Literally, righteousness.
298 An allusion to sexual intercourse.
299 This has no bearing on I.E.’s comment. He inserted it as an aside on his comments on the verse.
300 The moon included.
301 Literally, the tongue. According to the Talmud anyone born when Mercury dominates will be wise. See Sabbath 156a.
302 Literally, and all the people saw the thunderings, hence I.E. comments.
303 See I.E. on Ex. 5:21.
304 See I.E. on Ex. 5:21.
305 I.E. renders sippim (doors) as thresholds.
306 According to I.E., Is. 6:4 should be rendered: and the thresholds moved some cubits.
307 It has no meaning, for le-va’avor (for) means the same thing as ba-avur.
308 The verse goes on to say, that they may learn to fear Me all the days that they live upon the earth.
309 See I.E. on Ex. 33:21.
310 There is thus no need for Him to go up or come down (Weiser). God is all over.
311 That is why Ye shall not make with Me—gods of silver, or gods of gold. (v. 20).
312 The phrase Ye shall not make appears twice in our verse.
313 Which is found twice in verse 14 even though once would suffice.
314 Whether repeated or not.
315 See I.E. on Ex. 31:18.
316 Concerning the laws, after revelation of the Ten Statements.
317 The Bible reads, an altar of earth. That is what I.E. comments upon.
318 The prohibition to use hewn stones in constructing the altar.
319 Hebrew, temunot. However, I Kings 6:32 reads, timmorot (palm trees). It is possible that temunot is a scribal error and that we should read timmorot.
320 Why then would God prohibit similar images on the altar?
321 That “earth” is to be taken literally, for if it is not to be taken literally then neither is “stone.”
323 That the bronze altar was filled with earth.
324 For the tradition that the bronze altar was to be filled with earth.
325 The interpretation that an altar of earth means that the bronze altar is to be filled with earth.
326 It was not an actual part of the bronze altar. Indeed when Israel journeyed from place to place the earth was left behind. Hence it would not be referred to as an altar of earth
327 Described in Ex. 27:1-8.
329 The point is the altar of incense had two names. However, unlike the earth placed in the bronze altar, the gold was an essential part of the altar.
330 Referred to in Scripture as an altar of stone.
332 In Deut. 27:5.
334 We thus see that they refer to the same event.
335 At that time.
336 After the Ten Statements were revealed.
337 That is, verses 20-23.

340 We thus see that the altar mentioned here and the altar mentioned in Ex. 24:5 were built for the same purpose. This supports I.E.’s contention that the reference is to the same altar.
341 These were the offerings brought by Moses after God’s revelation to Israel.
342 Chapter 5 of tractate Zevachim deals with the place set aside for the various sacrifices. The term used by the Mishnah for various sacrifices is zevachim.
343 Whereas the rabbis in tractate Zevachim apply it to all sorts of sacrificial offerings.
344 So argued the heretic.
345 Hebrew, ve-zavachta. We thus see that the term zavach also applies to peace offerings. Similarly with the noun zevach/zevachim.
346 That is, the place where God’s glory dwells.
348 The words in brackets are not in the text, but they have to be added to make sense of I.E.’s comment. See Weiser.
349 God now also commanded (Filwarg).
350 See Deut. 27:1-8. I.E. claims that Deut. 27:1-8 refers to the command given now.
351 The children of those who stood at Mount Sinai.
353 That is, because of the many commandments contingent upon living in the Land of Israel.
354 At Mount Ebel.
355 At Mount Sinai.
356 Literally, them. Hence I.E.’s comment.
357 Which, according to I.E., is short for: but his minister Joshua, the son of Nun, did the ministry of a young man. See I.E. on Ex. 33:11.
358 In other words, lo tivneh ethem gazit (literally, you shall not build them hewn stones) is short for lo tivneh ethem binyan gazit.
359 Translated according to I.E.
360 The meaning of gazit.

362 The word cherev usually means a sword. Hence I.E.’s comment.
363 The word barzel (iron tool) rather than cherev is used in this parallel verse. We thus see that cherev refers to an iron tool used for cutting.
364 Upon crossing the Jordan.

369 Ma’alah is a third person kal whole root form. Therefore, the root of u-ma’alah has to be mem, ayin, lamed. Ma’al is the noun form of ma’alah.
370 It is vocalized pattach, pattach.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 21
chapter.p: One who pays attention to meanings,
Both general and particular;
Will understand why a vav
Precedes Eleh Ha-Mishpatim.1

1. NOW THESE ARE THE ORDINANCES. After the children of Israel told Moses, Speak thou with us, etc. (Ex. 20:16), God told Moses, when Moses drew near to the thick darkness,2 Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel, etc. (Ex. 20:19). God began to warn them against making golden gods.3 He told Moses that upon Moses’ descent from Mount Sinai, He would make a covenant with Israel to the effect that the Lord alone would be their God.4 God taught Moses the ordinances and commandments5 so that Moses would tell Israel, if you accept these ordinances and commandments then God will make a covenant with you. At the end of these conditions,6 God told Moses the portion of Behold, I send an angel before thee (Ex. 23:20). The most important part of the latter chapter is the elimination of idol worship from their country when they entered it. Moses explained this to Israel before he made the covenant,7 for Moses concluded with, neither shalt thou serve their gods (Deut. 7:16).8 Now the portion opens with the prohibition against making other gods alongside the Lord9 and concludes with the commandment to uproot the memory of idols and molten gods which were made in the land of Canaan.10

2. IF THOU BUY. Before I begin to explain11 let me give you a general rule. Each ordinance or commandment12 is an independent unit. If we are able to find a reason that two ordinances or commandments are connected to each other, then we will expend all of our efforts to connect them. If we are not able to do so, we will conclude that the reason this cannot be done is our intellectual deficiency.13

There is nothing in the world more difficult for a human being to bear than to be under the control of another person like himself. Scripture therefore began14 with the law of the Hebrew servant. Our sages said that the Hebrew servant15 is an Israelite. The same applies to And if a man sell his daughter to be a maid-servant (v. 7).16 However, our sages maintain that And if a man smite the eye of his bondmen (v. 26) refers to a Canaanite.17 Similarly, If the ox gore a bondman (v. 32).18 And they said that then he shall be sold for his theft (Ex. 22:2) refers to an Israelite.

Those who dispute with our sages say that the Hebrew slave19 is not an Israelite but rather someone of Abraham’s family.20 The same is true of the daughter sold into slavery21 and of all the slaves mentioned afterwards. They are to be understood in the same way.22 Their proof is from the wife and her children (v. 4),23 for they say that family identity is established by the father.24 They offer additional proof from and he shall serve him for ever (v. 6), for they say that the latter means all of the slave’s life.25 It was difficult for them to accept that an Israelite would have his ear pierced.26

Let us now seek the plain meaning of the words.27 If the Hebrew slave is not an Israelite, then why did Scripture state, If thy brother, a Hebrew man…be sold unto thee28 (Deut. 15:12)? Do we not know that brother in Thou shalt not hate thy brother in thy heart (Lev. 19:17) means an Israelite? It is the same case with between a man and his brother, and the stranger that is with him (Deut. 1:16).29 There are many such cases.

Now there is no doubt that the meaning of Abram the Hebrew (Gen. 14:13) is: Abram of the children of Eber, about whom Scripture says avi kol bene ever, (the father of all the children of Eber) (Gen. 10:21),30 in contrast to and Ham is the father of Canaan (Gen. 9:18). On the other hand, it is possible that Abram was called the Hebrew because he came from beyond the river,31 although in this case the term used should have been ivri nahari 32 rather than ivri. Let us assume that Scripture was being brief,33 because we find that the Bible states, And I took your father Abraham from beyond the River (me-ever ha-nahar) (Josh. 24:3).34

The Hebrews are also called Israelites, for we see that Moses told Pharaoh, Thus saith the Lord, the God of Israel (Ex. 5:1). However, when Pharaoh asked Moses, “Who is this God?”35 Moses answered him, The God of the Hebrews (Ibid.). The God of the Hebrews thus means the same as the God of Israel. Now if the Israelites are called Hebrews because they are related to Eber, then the children of Ishmael and the children of Keturah36 and the children of Esau should be joined to us. However, we do not find Scripture referring to any people as our brothers except for Edom,37 who shared one womb with Jacob.38 We also do not find Scripture referring to Esau39 as our brother in commandments.40 We find him referred to as a brother only in the account of the messengers.41 The same applies to Thou shalt not abhor an Edomite, for he is thy brother (Deut. 23:8)42 wherein Scripture mentions he is thy brother after first mentioning the term Edomite.43 The same is true of Because he44 did pursue his brother45 with the sword (Amos 1:11).46

Now we do not find in all of Scripture the word Hebrew employed except in regard to the children of Jacob. Scripture thus states: And there was with us there a young man, a Hebrew (Gen. 41:12); because the Egyptians might not eat bread with the Hebrews (Gen. 43:32); an Egyptian smiting a Hebrew (Ex. 2:11); two men of the Hebrews were striving together (Ex. 2:13). Jonah said, I am a Hebrew (Jonah 1:9) because he was asked, and of what people art thou (Jonah v. 1:8). If the term Hebrew had referred to many nations, Jonah would not yet have told them of what people he was.47 Scripture also states, that ye be not servants unto the Hebrews (I Sam. 4:9);48 Now the Hebrews49 that were with the Philistines (I Sam. 14:21). The book of Jeremiah states: that every man should let his man-servant, and every man his maid-servant, being a Hebrew man or a Hebrew woman, go free (Jer. 34:9). The latter closes by explaining, that none should make bondmen of them, even of a Jew his brother (Ibid.). Now it is known that an Edomite is not called a Jew.50

Those who disagree with our sages say, look, it is written: And many from among the peoples of the land became Jews (mityahadim) (Esther 8:17)51 in reference to those who were not Jews. This is blindness. For according to their opinion, whether the meaning of the word mityahadim (became Jews) is that they claimed to be Jews or that mityahadim means they accepted Judaism,52 Scripture should have read, “even of one of his brothers who became Jewish.”53 Furthermore, the word mitabber (becoming a Hebrew)54 should be formed from the word ivri according to this interpretation.55 One who says this, meddleth (mitabber) with strife not his own (Prov. 26:17).56

It has thus been clearly shown that the words of our sages are correct. We will rely upon them with regard to all of the commandments in accordance with their tradition, which they received from their fathers. Furthermore, how can one think that an Ishmaelite and an Edomite shall serve for six years57 and an Israelite until the year of jubilee.58

SIX YEARS HE SHALL SERVE. And no longer. It is like Six years thou shalt sow thy field (Lev. 25:3).59 At the start of the seventh year of his being sold he shall go free no matter what year it be.60 Do not be amazed that Jeremiah writes, At the end of seven years (Jer. 34:14),61 because everything has two ends and sometimes the end is found at the beginning and sometimes it is at the end.62

Our verse deals with a servant whom the law courts have sold, namely, an individual concerning whom it is written, then he shall be sold for his theft (Ex. 22:2). However, And if thy brother be waxen poor with thee, and was sold unto you (Lev. 25:39)63 or to a stranger (Lev. 25:47) refers to a slave who sells himself according to the years remaining to the year of jubilee, for such a servant goes out when the Jubilee comes. Israel has a tradition that males but not females are sold because they stole. I will finish the matter in the chapter which follows.

Rabbi Merinus says that the yod of the word la-chofshi (tree) is superfluous.64 It is like the yod of le-mishi (for cleansing) (Ezek. 16:4) and the yod of akhzari (cruel) (Prov. 11:17). However, Rabbi Judah the grammarian says the lamed of la-chofshi (free) is superfluous because its meaning is similar to chofshi (free) in And when thou lettest him go free (Deut. 15:13).65 Its yod is, as it were, the yod of relationship, like the yod of ha-kadmoni (of the east gate) (Ezek. 19:19). The lamed of la-chofshi is like the lamed of la-avshalom (Absalom)66 in the third, Absalom the son of Maacah (I Chron. 3:2). However, in my opinion the lamed and the yod in la-chofshi are both prepositions, even though one would have sufficed.67 Chofshi is similar to ha-oholi (of my tent) (Josh. 7:21) in in the midst of my tent.68 Chofshi (free) is an adjective.

[FOR NOTHING.] The word chinnam (for nothing) comes from the same root as channunu (grant)69 in grant them (Jud. 21:22). It means a gift.70 We do not know why chinnam has a mem.71 Its mem is like the mem of rekam (empty) (Gen. 31:42).72

3. IF HE COME IN BY HIMSELF. Some say that the word be-gappo (by himself) has the same meaning as be-gufo (with his body). Now we find the phrase gufat sha’ul (the body of Saul) (I Chron. 10:12) in Scripture.73 However, the forms of nouns change.74 Others say75 that gappo (himself) has the meaning of wing. Wings are referred to as gappin in Aramaic. It is as if Scripture read, if he came in bondage possessing only the wing of his garment.76 However, this is out of context, for the context requires us to explain be-gappo as meaning that he carries no other body on his back. Gappo is like gabbi (my back) in The plowers plowed upon my back (Ps. 129:3).77

Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that Scripture had to say, If he come in by himself, he shall go out by himself78 while saying79 he shall go out free80 because of his wife,81 that is, the Torah had to say, if he be married.82

Now if an Israelite women is not sold by a law court for theft, why does Scripture say, then his wife shall go out with him? It states this to teach us that the one who acquires a Hebrew slave is obligated to support his [the slave’s] wife. She is with him until they go out together.

4. IF HIS MASTER GIVE HIM A WIFE. We find that those who employ the holy tongue render honor with various nouns83 but not with verbs. They use the terms adon (lord) and also adonim (lords).84 They employ the latter as a singular in a cruel lord (adonim) (Is. 19:4). They employ the term adonav (his lord)85 in the construct.86 They do not use the term adono (his lord),87 for we do not find the word adono in Scripture. However, Adoni (my lord),88 as in My lord asked (Gen. 44:19), is employed in the first person. It is prohibited to use the plural form89 so that it not be confused with God’s glorious name.90 It is similarly unfit to use the singular declensional form adoni (my lord) in My lord asked (Ibid.) when God is spoken of.91 The same applies to the term Elo’ah (God).92 Rabbi Merinus says that eloho (their god),93 rather than elohav (their god),94 in their might unto their god (Hab. 1:11) is used in a disparaging manner.95

IF HIS MASTER GIVE HIM A WIFE. A Canaanite woman according to our sages.96 It is possible that the meaning of a Canaanite women is in keeping with Moreover of the children of the strangers that do sojourn among you (Lev. 25:45) conceming whom it is written, of them shall ye buy bondmen and bondmaids (Lev. 25:44).97 The same applies to all Canaanite slaves,98 for Scripture states, thou shalt save alive nothing that breatheth (Deut. 20:16) with regard to the seven nations.99 Scripture states with regard to Solomon, of the nations concerning which the Lord said unto the children of Israel: They shall not come among you, neither shall you go among them (I Kings 11:2).100 Now this is written101 with regard to Zidonians and Hittites,102 not Moabites and Ammonites.103

5. BUT IF THE SERVANT SHALL PLAINLY SAY. Our sages have already explained104 that his ear is not pierced unless all these conditions,105 including because he loveth thee and thy house (Deut. 15:16), have been fulfilled.106

6. THEN HIS MASTER SHALL BRING HIM UNTO GOD. The term Elohim (God) means those who establish God’s laws in the land.107 It is customary for the judges to sit in the gate of a city that has doors and a bolt. To the door or the door-post means that what Scripture deals with in this verse is to be performed before those who sit in the gate.

AND HE SHALL SERVE HIM FOR EVER. We know that the word le-olam (for ever) in Hebrew refers to time, as in it hath been already, in the ages (le-olamim) which were before us (Eccles. 1:10), wherein olamim means ages.108 Similarly, ve-yashav sham ad olam (and there abide for ever) (I Sam. 1:22) means: and he will there abide until he grows up. Va-avado le-olam (and he shall serve him for ever) likewise means: and he will serve him until the year of jubilee,109 for there is no season of Israel that is longer than it.110 Going free is comparable to a renewal of the world.111 It is also possible that its meaning is that he should be as he was in former times.112
7. AND IF A MAN SELL HIS DAUGHTER TO BE A MAID-SERVANT. Scripture speaks of a minor who is under her father’s control, like the daughter whose oaths a father may annul.113
The phrase unto a foreign people (v. 8) is connected to this verse.114 For unto a foreign people speaks of the father.115

8. TO SELL HER UNTO A FOREIGN PEOPLE HE SHALL HAVE NO POWER, SEEING THAT HE HATH DEALT DECEITFULLY WITH HER. Bi-vigdo (that he hath dealt deceitfully) is similar to the word nivgad (we deal treacherously) in Why do we deal treacherously every man against his brother (Mal. 2:10). It is true and correct that the master has no right to sell her to an Israelite.116 We know this from tradition.117 The sages used this verse as a peg and as a support.118 Do not be surprised at the distance between unto a foreign people and the verse to which it is connected,119 for as I will explain, it is the same case with he shall make restitution120 (Ex. 22:2).

Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that unto a foreign people means to a stranger. The same is true of wilt Thou slay even a righteous nation121 (Gen. 20:4). However, it is impossible that Scripture would refer to an individual by one of these terms. It is correct for Scripture to say, “and Israel said,” because Israel is a collective noun, like Egypt in and Egypt said (Ex. 14:25).122 However, it is impossible for a noun which refers to a group, such as the terms people, nation, company, and congregation, to be used for an individual. The meaning of wilt Thou slay even a righteous nation is explained by that thou hast brought on me and on my kingdom a great sin (Gen. 20:9).

[SHE SHALL NOT GO OUT AS MEN-SERVANTS DO.] Its meaning is, she shall not go out as men-servants who always go out after six years. The maid-servant also goes out after six years of servitude, as Scripture states, If thy brother, a Hebrew man, or a Hebrew women, be sold unto thee, he shall serve thee six years (Deut. 15:12). However, the maid-servant goes out if she reaches the onset of puberty before six years pass.

IF SHE PLEASE NOT HER MASTER. If she does not find favor in the eyes of her master after he bought her in order to take her for a wife. This is the meaning of who hath espoused her to himself; he espoused her to be his wife123 or he espoused her to be the wife of his son.124

Note that the word lo (himself) is spelled125 lamed alef in the text126 and is read127 as if written with a vav and so spelled in the margin.128 The Gaon says that the word lo has two meanings.129 It is similar to It is He that hath made us, and we are His (lo) (Ps. 100:3).130 One meaning is, we have not made ourselves.131 The second meaning is, we are His.132 However, in my opinion only the second is the correct meaning.133 The same applies to all of them.134

Rabbi Judah the grammarian says that we cannot distinguish in pronunciation between lo spelled with an alef and lo spelled with a vav or a heh, as in is it not (ha-loh)135 in Rabbah of the children of Ammon (Deut. 3:11). All cases where the text has an alef and the margin a vav136 are to be interpreted the way they are read.137

Note that the word ve-hefdah (then shall he let her to be redeemed) is a transitive verb. It is similar to ve-happodekha (and redeemed thee) (Deut. 13:6); padah (redeemed) in who hath redeemed my soul (II Sam. 4:9); peditem (redeemed them) in For I have redeemed them (Zech. 10:8).138 Now vehefdah is a hifil. It is like ha-matzmi’ach (maketh to spring) in Who maketh the mountains to spring with grass (Ps. 147:8)139 or like the word he’ekhil (fed)140 in saying Reuben fed (he’ekhil) Simeon bread. The meaning of ve-hefdah thus is,141 he shall seek her redemption and accept it whether she redeems herself, or her father or one of her relatives redeems her. If she is close to the end of her years of servitude, they shall compute how many years she has served and how many remain till the seventh year or to the time that she reaches the onset of puberty. The redemption money will be in accordance with the aforementioned computation.142

UNTO A FOREIGN PEOPLE. I have already explained it.143 Note that the term nokhri (foreign) applies to all people who are not Israelites. The word nokhri does not have the same meaning as the word zar (stranger), as the term zar refers to one who is not of the same tribal family.144

Now if we say that the Israelites are called Hebrews because145 of Eber, who worshipped God, then whoever is descended from Eber and follows Eber’s faith is called a Hebrew.146 However, if we say that one is called a Hebrew because of Abraham,147 then Scripture states, for in Isaac shall seed be called to thee (Gen. 21:12).148 Now even though Scripture writes with regard to Ishmael, because he is thy seed (Gen. 21:13),149 the land150 was given only to Isaac.151 Jacob and Esau were sons of Isaac. However, Scripture states with regard to Isaac, for unto thee, and thy seed, I will give all these lands (Gen. 26:3). Now Isaac’s seed was “called” only in Jacob, to whom the land was given. Thus the children of the concubines152 along with the children of Esau are considered foreigners.
9. AND IF HE ESPOUSE HER UNTO HIS SON. Yi’adennah (espouse her)153 follows the paradigm of yirashennah.154 The word mo’ed (season)155 is similar to156 the word moked (altar).157
[AFTER THE MANNER OF THE DAUGHTERS.] The reference is to virgin daughters who were not sold.
HE SHALL DEAL WITH HER. The son, and also the father if he took her.
10. IF HE TAKE HIM ANOTHER WIFE. Be she a daughter of Israel who was sold, or be she a daughter of Israel that was not sold.
HER FOOD. She’erah refers to her food. He must sustain her flesh, which is what she’erah means.

AND HER CONJUGAL RIGHTS. Some say that ve-onatah (and her conjugal rights) means: and the place of her dwelling.158 According to them, the word ve-anah (shall howl) in and jackals shall howl (Is. 13:22) and ve-anetah (and she shall respond) in and she shall respond there (Hos. 2:17) have a similar meaning.159 However, I believe that ve-anah iyyim (and jackals shall howl) is to be taken as it implies.160 Ve-anah is similar to ve-anita (and thou shalt speak) in and thou shalt speak and say (Deut. 26:5). Ve-anah is used metaphorically, for Scripture there metaphorically states, and the satyr shall cry to his fellow (Is. 34:14).161 Similarly, ve-anetah in and she shall there respond means she shall make music. Ve-anetah is similar to enu (sing) in Sing unto the Lord with thanksgiving (Ps. 147:7).

Onatah refers to sexual activity, also known as the time of lovemaking.162 The word et (time) is missing a nun.163 It is similar to the word emet (truth).164 Hence the tav of ittekh (thy time) in and, behold, thy time (Ezek. 16:8) receives a dagesh.165 Likewise,166 itto (his time) is similar to amitto (his truth). The word attah (now) is also similar.167 Note, onatah comes from the same root as et. The word attah (now) means this time.168

11. AND IF. Scripture employed an abridged form in saying shelosh eleh (these three). It is similar to shelosh se’im (three measures) (Gen. 18:6),169 for Scripture should have read, ha-shelosh ha-eleh.170

Many think that these three refers to her food, her raiment, and her conjugal rights. However, this is impossible. After Scripture stated, he shall deal with her after the manner of daughters (v. 9), and one is obligated to give these three things to all daughters there is no need to mention this here. Furthermore, Scripture writes concerning the beautiful woman171 who is a foreigner, but thou shalt not sell her at all for money (Deut. 21:14). How much more so is this maid-servant not to be sold for money.172 Its correct interpretation thus is: and if he does not do one of these three things, namely, if he does not marry her, or espouse her to his son, or redeem her, she shall go out for nothing when she has the onset of puberty.173 If any that is unclean by a dead body touch all of these, which means one of these, shall it be unclean174 (Hag. 2:13) is similar. There are many other similar instances.175

The Gaon asks, what reason was there for Scripture to say, without money after stating for nothing? He answers: If she took ill in her master’s house and he spent money on medicine,176 then she did not have to pay him back anything. However, in my opinion there is no need for all of this, for Scripture offers additional explanation, such as for thou shalt die, and not live (II Kings 20:1).177

12. HE THAT SMITETH A MAN. The reason this follows the laws dealing with the man- and maid-servant is that Scripture wanted to go on and explain how to deal with one who strikes his man- and maid-servants.178
[A MAN.] The reference is to an Israelite.
HE SHALL SURELY BE PUT TO DEATH. By a court of law. This is the case whenever the term mot yumat (he shall surely be put to death) is employed. The one exception to this will be shown shortly.

13. AND IF A MAN LIE NOT IN WAIT. Tzadah (lie in wait) is similar to the word bi-tzediyyah (lying in wait) (Num. 35:20) and tzodeh (layest wait) in though thou layest wait for my soul to take it (I Sam. 24:12). Observe, it involves laying in wait and acting presumptuously.179

BUT GOD CAUSE IT TO COME TO HAND. Innah (cause it to come) is similar to mitanneh (seeketh an occasion) in he seeketh an occasion against me (II Kings 5:7), the meaning of which is, he looks for reasons and excuses.180 The meaning of our clause is that God caused and arranged things so that this person would die at this individual’s hand even though he had never intended to kill him. God caused this to happen to him so that he would be exiled from his place because of some other sin which he committed. Scripture explicitly states, There shall no mischief befall the righteous (Prov. 12:21).

14. AND IF A MAN COME PRESUMPTUOUSLY. To slay him181 is to be understood as if written, and slew him with guile.182 Similarly If she profane by playing the harlot (Lev. 21:9),183 the meaning of which is, if she profane herself by playing the harlot and therefore she profaneth her father (Ibid.).184

It is known that the term chillul (profanation) and the word techillah (beginning) come from a double root.185 However, they differ in meaning. It was therefore necessary to differentiate between them. Scripture therefore reads, techel li-zenot (profane by playing the harlot) (Lev. 21:9), for if it had the meaning of beginning, it would read tachel (thou shalt begin), as in tachel lispor (shalt thou begin to number) (Num. 16:9).186

FROM MINE ALTAR. This is the reverse of the previous verse. It is there stated, then I will appoint thee a place [whither he may flee], the reference being to the cities of refuge. However, he who presumptuously kills and flees, even if he seeks refuge at the altar as Joab did,187 shall be put to death. Our sages said even a priest188 who wants to perform the service at the altar shall be put to death.189

15. AND HE THAT SMITETH HIS FATHER. Since Scripture had previously mentioned, He that smiteth a man, so that he dieth, shall surely be put to death (v. 12), Scripture had to explain that there is an instance where one is put to death for smiting someone even when the one who is struck does not die. This is the case when one hits one’s father.

The word u-makkeh (and he that smiteth) is to be read as if written twice.190 It was out of regard for the parents’ honor that Scripture found it necessary to state191 that even when one does not strike one’s parents but curses them, he is to be put to death.

16. AND HE THAT STEALETH A MAN. Saadiah Gaon asks: Why was this verse inserted between He that smiteth his father (v. 15) and And he that curseth his father (v. 17)? He answers that Scripture speaks only of the commonplace. Those stolen were young children. They were brought up in a strange country and did not recognize their parents. It is thus possible for them to strike and curse their parents. The punishment for this will fall upon the kidnapper.
OR IF HE BE FOUND IN HIS HAND. In the market before he sells him,192 then he shall be put to death.
17. AND HE THAT CURSETH. We find a curse that invokes the name of God, as in and cursed them in the name of the Lord (II Kings 2:24). We also find curses that do not invoke the name of God.

18. AND IF MEN CONTEND. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that be-egrof (with his fist) is similar to egrofin (strong) in “strong men.”193 The reference194 is to something strong and hard. Rabbi Merinus says that the alef of egrof is superfluous. It is like the alef of ezro’i (my shoulder) (Job 31:22).195 It comes from the same root as ge-rafam (swept them away) (Jud. 5:21).196 The reference is to something that one drags in one’s hand.197 The same is true in Arabic.
19. IF HE RISE AGAIN. We will rely on our sages of blessed memory who said that al mishanto (upon his staff) means that he supports himself and does not lean on others as sick people do.198
THEN SHALL HE THAT SMOTE HIM BE QUIT. They shall release him from prison.

[LOSS OF HIS TIME.] Shivto (loss of his time) comes from the same root as shevitah (rest),199 for his work stopped.200 This interpretation is correct.201 Shivto follows the paradigm of shivro (his corn money) (Gen. 44:2), for the tav is a root letter. It is possible that shivto comes from the same root as shivtah (tarried) in save that she tarried a little in the house (Ruth 2:7). Shivtah comes from the same root as the word yashav (sat).202 Shivto refers to the time that the one who was struck sat at home resting, without work. What proves that this interpretation is correct is that it is the reverse of and walk abroad.203

AND SHALL CAUSE HIM TO BE THOROUGHLY HEALED. This is a sign that permission has been granted to physicians to heal blows and wounds that are visible on the surface.204 However, it is in God’s hand to heal any illness which strikes inside of the body. It is thus written, For He maketh sore, and bindeth up (Job 5:18). Furthermore, Scripture tells us concerning King Asa, yet in his disease he sought not to the Lord, but to the physicians (II Chron. 16:12).205 Now Scripture distinguished between them.206 It does not state, verafo yirpe (and he shall surely heal), which is in the kal.207 It rather reads, ve-rappo yerappe (and shall cause him to be thoroughly healed). The latter is in the pi’el.208 I will explain this very well later on in this portion.209

The rabbis received a tradition concerning other payments210 in addition to the two211 mentioned in our verse. They similarly received a tradition to include spices which are not stated in the Torah among the incense spices.212

20. AND IF A MAN SMITE HIS BONDMAN. There is no doubt that according to Israelite jurisprudence the same ordinances that apply to a free man apply to a person sold into bondage. Hence it is impossible for the bondman213 to be a Hebrew servant.214 Furthermore, Scripture states at the end,215 for he is his money.216 Now the bondman and bondwoman217 are the ones concerning whom Scripture writes, of them shall ye buy bondmen and bondmaids (Lev. 25:44).
The bet of ba-shevet (with a rod) is vocalized with a pattach. 218 The reference is to the rod219 which the master was in the habit of using to beat his servants.

Now all those who dispute the words of our sages220 are forced to agree with them with regard to the phrase nakom yinnakem (he shall surely be avenged),221 for vengeance takes many forms.222 Now logic will not help them in this case.223 The fathers have received the tradition that nakem yenakem (he shall surely be avenged) is similar to a sword that shall avenge (nokemet) the vengeance of the covenant (nekam berit) (Lev. 26:25).224
21. NOTWITHSTANDING. Observe that the word yukkam (be punished),225 which is a hofal, has the same meaning as yinnakem (be punished),226 which is a nifal.

The heretics227 say that the meaning of nakom yinnakem (he shall surely be avenged) is that great vengeance shall be exacted, namely, that the master shall be beaten. However, if the bondman lives for a day, less vengeance shall be exacted. If he lives for two days no vengeance shall be taken. They argue228 that we do not find the term vengeance used with reference to the death penalty inflicted by a law court. They also say, that there is no positive proof that a sword that shall avenge (Lev. 26:25) refers to being put to death.229 Furthermore, what need is there to say “two days” after saying “a day”?230 However, their231 real difficulty lies in accepting the idea that the master would be executed because of the death of a bondman. I will now answer them.

Why didn’t Scripture specify what greater or lesser vengeance is to be exacted?232 Let us now pursue what is written in Scripture. Scripture states, nekom nikmat bene yisrael (avenge the children of Israel) (Num. 31:2). It then goes on to tell us that all the Midianites were killed. Note that Samson said, ki im nikkamti ba-khem (surely I will be avenged of you) (Jud. 15:7). It then states, And he smote them hip [and thigh with a great slaughter] (Jud. 15:8). Samson said, ve-innakemah nekam achat (that I may be this once avenged) (Jud. 16:28) and they died in the house.233 Scripture states, And a two-edged sword in their hand (Ps. 149:6). It then goes on to say, To execute vengeance (nikamah) upon the nations (Ps. 149:7).

The Bible states, For he doth avenge (yikkom) the blood of his servants (Deut. 32:43). Now blood indicates slaughter.234 This is the way the term235 is always used. The reason Scripture here refers to execution by vengeance is that a master seeks excuses to fall upon his bondman because he is in his power,236 as he cannot smite a fellow Israelite.237

Now let us turn to Scripture’s statement a day or two. Observe that the latter is like At the mouth of two witnesses [or three witnesses] (Deut. 17:6).238 They239 said that they do not know its meaning.240 Let them put our verse along with it.241 Our sages of blessed memory said that the meaning of a day or two is that the hours shall add up to the twenty-four of a day.242

Now when we examined the verse we found that Scripture says, “with the rod,”243 the reference being to the disciplining rod, as in Thou beatest him with the rod244 (Prov. 23:14). It is thus clear that the master wanted to punish the bondman. Scripture did not mention what the laws are regarding a master who kills his bondman,245 because a master normally takes pity on the bondman, whom he owns, and refrains from killing him even as he takes pity upon his cattle. Now God commanded that a master shall not act sadistically when he punishes his bondman. When he sees the bondman dying under his rod the master shall let him be. If he does not leave the bondman alone then he will be put to death on the bondman’s account, for God’s mercy is upon all of His creatures. Indeed, concerning David we read, Thou hast shed blood abundantly (I Chron. 22:8).246 The reference was to non-Israelite blood.247
22. AND IF MEN STRIVE248 TOGETHER. The reference is to Hebrew men249 who strive together and hit each other. Scripture similarly reads, Wherefore smitest thou thy fellow? (Ex. 2:13)250

AND HURT. Both are included.251 Sometimes its meaning is one or the other.252 Thus the meaning of they shall be burnt with fire, both he and they (Lev. 20:14) is, either this one or that one.253 If both254 are Israelites one law applies to them. The woman spoken of in this verse is an Israelite woman.
YET NO HARM FOLLOW. To the woman.
HE SHALL BE SURELY FINED. Because of the children who were aborted and died.

ACCORDING AS THE WOMAN’S HUSBAND SHALL LAY UPON HIM. If the one who hurt the woman wants to do according to the will of the father of the children.255 Otherwise he shall pay in accordance to the ruling of the law court. Bi-fililim (as the judges determine) is similar to the word u-fillelo (shall judge him).256

23. BUT IF ANY HARM FOLLOW. To the woman. We find a difference of opinion.257 Some say that the one who caused the women’s death is put to death because he intended to kill a fellow Israelite. They offer as proof the fact that Scripture states, he shall surely be fined (v. 22) with regard to the children, but it states with regard to the woman, then thou shalt give life for life. Now if the reference is to a fine,258 then in what way is the woman’s death worse than that of the children? On the other hand, if we say that one is to be punished with death for killing the children, why did Scripture alter its style259 and read, life for life?

The opposing opinion maintains that one who intends to kill one individual and kills another is not put to death, and the reason the Torah altered its language and stated life for life is that the fine for killing a person is much greater than that for killing an embryo. They offer as proof the fact that the Torah afterwards reads, eye for eye, tooth for tooth (v. 24). The latter is not to be taken literally. On the contrary, it refers to ransom.260
This portion261 was written because of the clause eye for eye, tooth for tooth.262 Scripture afterwards codifies the law dealing with the eye and tooth of a bondman.263

24. EYE. Rabbi Saadiah says that we cannot interpret this verse according to its plain meaning. For if a man struck his neighbor’s eye and the eye lost a third of its sight, how is it possible to punish the culprit with an equivalent blow, that is, with a blow which is neither greater nor lesser?264 There is a possibility that the culprit will lose his entire eyesight. Burns, wounds, and stripes present even greater difficulties, for if they were inflicted on a dangerous area it is possible for the culprit to die. The mind cannot accept this.265

Ben Zuta266 said to Saadiah Gaon: Does not Scripture elsewhere state, as he hath maimed a man, so shall it be rendered unto him (Lev. 24:20)? Rabbi Saadiah answered him: We have a bet taking the place of the word al (on).267 Its meaning is, so shall a fine be placed upon him.268 However, Ben Zuta responded, as he hath done, so shall it be done to him (Lev. 24:19).269 The Gaon retorted: Observe, Samson said, As they did unto me, so have I done unto them270 (Jud. 15:11). Now Samson did not take their wives and hand them over to others.271 He only repaid them for their dastardly acts. Ben Zuta responded: If the culprit272 is a poor man what shall his punishment be? The Gaon answered: If a blind person shall blind one who can see, what shall be done to him, for it is possible for a poor person to become wealthy and pay. However, it is eternally impossible for the blind to pay.273

The general rule is that we cannot fully explain any commandment written in the Torah unless we rely on the words of our sages of blessed memory. Just as we received the Torah274 from the sages,275 so did we receive the Oral Law.276 There is no difference between them. Now the interpretation of eye for eye is, it is fitting for the culprit to give his eye in place of his victim’s eye if he does not pay ransom for it.277

[TOOTH FOR TOOTH, HAND FOR HAND, FOOT FOR FOOT.] Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says: In some cases the payment for taking out a tooth is very small.278 This is the case when a youth is struck, because if his tooth is uprooted another will take its place.279 Scripture mentions the hand because one does work with it.280 Scripture mentions the foot because the loss of a foot is worse than the loss of a hand, as a person cannot walk on one foot.281

However, I believe that Scripture mentions these organs because they are the ones that are usually harmed. When a man strikes his neighbor he strikes him in the eye which faces him, or the mouth which faces him and thus breaks his teeth, or in the hand that his neighbor fights with or protects his face with, or his foot when he runs away from him.
25. BURN. Keviyyah (bum) is to be taken at face value; that is, it refers to a burn caused by fire.

Some say that petza (wound) refers to a bleeding wound and chabburah (stripe) to a blow that does not draw blood. However, the Gaon says that petza refers to breaking a bone and chabburah to a bleeding wound.

26. AND IF A MAN SMITE. God commanded that a bondman should go free because of his eye or tooth to prevent masters from cruelly striking their servants with terrible blows. Thus if the master destroys his bondman’s eye or even his tooth, then the bondman will pass from his control free of charge and the master will forfeit his property.
27. AND IF HE SMITE OUT HIS BONDMAN’S TOOTH. Scripture, as I have noted, speaks about the most usual. According to tradition a bondman similarly goes free if any of his major organs282 are destroyed.

28. AND IF AN OX GORE A MAN. This portion283 is mentioned because of if the ox gore a bondman or a bondwoman (v. 32).284 The man and the woman referred to in our verse are Israelites. Our verse reads, or a woman. Scripture does not mention a woman in He that smiteth a man, so that he dieth (v. 12) because it is the manner of Scripture to mention the more important, namely, the male. Nevertheless, the same law applies to a female.285 Scripture now mentions a woman286 so that the owner of the ox does not protest and argue that the woman did not follow the normal practice. For there are places where it is not the custom for women to go out of the city to a field where oxen are found. It is because of this that Scripture afterwards states, Whether it have gored a son, or gored a daughter (v. 31). The law concerning one that smiteth a man applies equally whether the victim is an adult or a minor. Scripture mentions son or a daughter so that the owner of the ox does not protest against the parents and say that the parents should have watched their children.

THE OX SHALL BE SURELY STONED. The meaning of and its flesh shall not be eaten is that its flesh shall not be eaten as the flesh of an animal that dies of itself, which the stranger in the gate or the foreigner may eat.287 Our sages said that every time Scripture states, it shall not he eaten, it means that it is prohibited to derive any pleasure from it.
BUT THE OWNER OF THE OX SHALL BE QUIT. Of punishment.

29. BUT IF THE OX WAS WONT TO GORE. There is no doubt that there is no ransom for those who are to be executed by a court of law.288 The transmitters of tradition therefore said that shall also be put to death refers to death at the hands of heaven. Now I believe that here [the term shall be put to death] is similar to eye for eye. Its meaning is, the owner shall be put to death if he does not give a redemption for his life. All of this because Scripture reads, yumat (shall be put to death); not yamut (he will die).289

30. IF THERE BE LAID ON HIM A RANSOM. This does not contradict Moreover ye shall take no ransom for the life of a murderer (Num. 35:31), for Scripture speaks there of a real murderer. However, the person spoken of in our verse did not commit murder. He is only punished because he did not restrain the ox by tying it up. Or, if he tied the ox up, he did not do so properly so that the ox was able to free itself. Or, the ox did not find the door290 closed291 and it went out and caused damage.
LAID UPON HIM. By the decree of the judges.

31. WHETHER IT HAVE GORED A SON, OR HAVE GORED A DAUGHTER. Both of whom are Israelites, for Scripture afterwards reads, If the ox gore a bondman (v. 32). God decreed that the owner of the ox292 be punished because it is hard for God to see an animal kill a person who is created in the image of God. Because of this, the ox is also stoned.

33. AND IF A MAN SHALL OPEN A PIT. Which was dug.293 Scripture mentions this because God does not want an animal to die in vain, that is, if its death does not serve human needs. Furthermore, he294 injures the owner of the beast.

34. THE OWNER OF THE PIT. The one who opened it or the one who dug it. This is the law even though the pit is on public property.295 He made it for his use; therefore he is called the owner of the pit.
HE SHALL GIVE MONEY. He shall pay what the fallen animal was worth when alive after deducting the value of the carcass.

35. AND IF ONE MAN’S OX HURT ANOTHER’S. Ben Zuta says that re’ehu (another’s)296 is an adjective describing the ox.297 However, Ben Zuta did not notice that the word shor (ox) is in the construct with ish (man’s).298 This is also the case with the word shor (ox) and re’ehu (another’s).299 However, an ox has no neighbor except for Ben Zuta.300 The owner of a tame ox pays half of the damage.

36. OR IF IT BE KNOWN. On the other hand, if the ox was a gorer he shall pay the entire damage. Scripture mentions the laws dealing with the ox up to If a man steal an ox (v. 37).301 All of this302 because of the bondman who is sold303 because of his theft. This is the way our Torah portion opened, namely, If thou buy a Hebrew servant (v. 2).304

37. IF A MAN STEAL. Rabbi Joshua says that God was stricter with an ox than with a sheep because the thief cannot hide an ox as he can a sheep.305 One cannot steal it unless one is experienced in the art of theft.306 However, Saadiah Gaon says that the theft of an ox is more severely punished because the owner of the ox suffers more than that of a sheep because the ox is used for plowing.

Now if the term Hebrew does not refer to an Israelite, why does Scripture use the term brother? Brother refers only to an Israelite. If Deut. 15:12 referred to a non-Israelite it should have read, “If a Hebrew man be sold unto thee.” We thus see that our verse refers to an Israelite.

45 Israel.

47 By saying I am a Hebrew, he might be saying I am an Edomite, or a Moabite, or the like.
48 The reference there is clearly to that of an Israelite.
49 The reference is to Israelites.
50 Hence the term Hebrew in Jer. 34:9 cannot apply to him. I.E. notes this because he had earlier noted that Scripture refers to the Edomites as brothers.

51 We thus see that the term Jew can be applied to someone who is not born a Jew. Hence the term Jew in Jer. 34:9 may also apply to a non-Jew, that is, to a non-Jewish slave who observes some of the commandments (Filwarg).
52 According to I.E., mityahadim means: praised the Jews.

53 Jer. 34:9 refers to the man-servant as a yehudi, a Jew. If the reference was to those not born Jewish, i.e., slaves who belong to Jews and practice Judaism, then the term used should have been mityahed, acting Jewish.

68 Ha-oholi has an emphatic heh prefix and a first person pronoun yod suffix. According to Hebrew grammar, the emphatic heh is not suffixed to a declined noun. Josh. 7:21 thus should have read, ha-ohel, or oholi. We thus see that Scripture sometimes combines two forms.

70 Something freely or graciously given.

76 In other words, gappo refers to the wing (corner) of his garment.
77 In other words, gappo is a variant of gabbo (his back), for the bet and peh sometimes interchange because they are similarly sounded labials.
78 In other words, why repeat that the slave goes out free after having stated the same in verse 2?
79 That is, immediately after saying (Filwarg). For other interpretations see Krinsky.

81 That is, because it wanted to go on and explain the law dealing with the slave’s wife, and it is the style of Scripture to repeat itself when it introduces a new law.

96 Mekhilta, Mishpatim 1.

100 I.E. quoted from memory and erred. The Book of Kings reads, of the nations concerning which the Lord said unto the children of Israel: Ye shall not go among them, neither shall they come among you.
101 That Solomon loved women of the nations concerning which the Lord said unto the children of Israel: Ye shall not go among them, neither shall they come among you.

106 That is, the servant’s ear is not pierced unless all the conditions listed in verse 5 and in Deut. 15:16 have been fulfilled.
107 That is, elohim means judges.

109 This is the opinion of the sages of the Talmud. See Mekhilta on third verse.

The word le-olam literally means to a world. Hence I.E.’s comment. This interpretation appears to differ slightly from the preceding one, which took the word olam to mean time.

120 Which, according to I.E., is connected to Ex. 21:37.

122 Translated according to I.E.

A twenty-four hour period.” Also see Rashi: “A day which is made up of a part of two separate days, i.e. twenty-four hours calculated from any moment” (Rashi, paraphrased by Cohen).

For doing so, he and one of the women are executed; i.e., if he is married to a woman and sleeps with her daughter, then it is the daughter who is executed; if he is married to the daughter and sleeps with the mother, it is the mother who is executed. See I.E. on Lev. 20:14.

It is with life that he must pay for life…Rabbi says: Then thou shalt give life for life. This means monetary compensation.” Also see San. 79a.

268 Lev. 24:40 reads: ken yinaten bo (so shall it be rendered unto him). According to Saadiah Gaon, ken yinaten bo should be interpreted as if written, ken yinaten alav (so shall it be placed upon him); i.e., he is to be fined accordingly.
