chapter.title: CHAPTER 22
chapter.p: 1. IF A THIEF BE FOUND BREAKING IN. At night, as the thief would not break in during the day. If the sun he risen upon him in the verse which follows proves this.

[THERE SHALL BE NO BLOODGUILTINESS FOR HIM.] That is, the one who kills the thief is not guilty of bloodshed.1 One has to be amazed at those who interpret damim (bloodguiltiness) as life.2 If this is so, what is the meaning of because thou art a man of blood (damim) (II Sam. 16:8) and his blood (damav) shall be upon him (Lev. 20:9).

2. IF THE SUN BE RISEN UPON HIM…HE SHALL MAKE RESTITUTION. This3 refers to he shall pay five oxen for an ox, etc. (Ex. 21:37), which is written above.4 It is like unto a foreign people (Ex. 21:8)5 and And also unto thy bondwoman thou shalt do likewise (Deut. 15:17), which refers to thou shalt furnish him liberally (Deut. 15:14), which is written above it.
HE SHALL BE SOLD FOR HIS THEFT. Because of his theft.6

3. IF THE THEFT BE FOUND IN HIS HAND. This verse refers to all beasts.7 Our sages8 received a tradition that Scripture decrees9 that the law concerning the payment of “four and five” applies only to oxen and sheep.10

4. IF A MAN CAUSE A FIELD OR A VINEYARD TO BE EATEN. This too is connected to what is written above11 wherein the damage cause by an ox is mentioned. Scripture reads, ki yaver (if…cause…to be eaten). The word yaver (cause to be eaten) comes from the same root as be’irenu (our cattle) in we and our cattle (Num. 22:4).12 It13 is a pi’el.14
[AND IT FEED IN ANOTHER MAN’S FIELD.] Bi-sedeh acker15 means in another man’s field.16 Ye that have eaten up the vineyard (Is. 3:4)17 is similar.
5. IF FIRE BREAK OUT. This too is connected to what is written above, for it speaks of damage caused to a field.

[HE THAT KINDLED.] The word ha-mavir (he that kindled) does not have the same meaning as the word yaver (cause to be eaten) in if a man cause…to be eaten (v. 4) even though they both come from the same conjugation.18 For the word fire indicates what ha-mavir means.19 It is considered beautiful Hebrew style to employ the same word with two meanings,20 as in With the jawbone of an ass (ha-chamor), heaps upon heaps (chamor chamorotayim) (Jud. 15:16), and in that rode on thirty ass colts (ayarim), and they had thirty cities (u-sheloshim ayarim lahem) (Jud. 10:4). Now in the latter verse the second ayarim means cities, as which are called Havvoth-jair (Ibid.) proves.21
6. IF A MAN DELIVERS. This is also connected to what is written above.22 Scripture speaks of theft so as to complete the ordinances concerning theft.23

7. WHETHER HE HAVE NOT PUT HIS HAND UNTO HIS NEIGHBOR’S GOODS. This indicates that then the master of the house shall come near unto God refers to an oath sworn before judges.24 Hence, For every matter of trespass (v. 8) follows. This means that the one who swore sinned.25

Rabbi Joshua says that pesha (trespass) means that it went out of the owner’s possession, as in “Then did Edom revolt from under the hand of Judah.”26 (II Kings 8:22). For every matter of trespass (v. 8) includes everything that follows27 and everything28 that passes out of the owner’s possession,29 whether stolen30 or lost,31 with the finder denying and not admitting that he found it.
8. WHEREOF ONE SAITH. The witness saith, This is it.
THIS IS IT…HE WHOM GOD SHALL CONDEMN. If God32 shall condemn the keeper, because he himself stole it, or one who found an object and denied finding it, and thus became a thief because of it.
9. IF A MAN DELIVER. Our verse speaks of a paid bailee.33
10. UNTO HIS NEIGHBOR’S GOODS. According to the pace of the cattle (Gen. 33:14.) is similar.34 The owner takes nothing from the keeper except for the oath.
12. IF IT BE TORN IN PIECES. He was paid for this.35
LET HIM BRING IT FOR WITNESS. Let him bring a piece of the carcass as proof. This is in line with As a shepherd rescueth out of the mouth of the lion, Two legs, or a piece of an ear (Amos 3:12).
13. AND IF A MAN BORROW AUGHT. According to the plain meaning of the text, the owner thereof not being with it means that the owner can claim that the borrower overworked his animal.
14. IF THE OWNER THEREOF BE WITH IT. If the owner himself saw how the animal was hurt or died.36 The same law applies to a hired animal accompanied on the way by its lessee and lessor.37
Scripture concludes its dealing with theft of property and proceeds to discuss theft of confidence namely, seduction, for we often find men seducing young women of immature mind.38
15. THAT IS NOT BETROTHED. For a betrothed woman is considered to be married39 even though she has not slept with her husband.40

[HE SHALL SURELY PAY A DOWRY FOR HER.] Mahor yimharennah (he shall surely pay a dowry for her) is similar to the word mohar used in the sense of attachment, as in acher maharu (that attach themselves unto another)41 (Ps. 16:4). The root mem, heh, resh having the meaning of quickly (meherah) is only found in the pi’el in all of Scripture.42
15. HE SHALL PAY MONEY. For seducing her.

17. A SORCERESS. Scripture mentions the law of the sorceress after the law dealing with a seduced virgin because those who lust desire to satisfy their cravings through magic.43 Scripture speaks of a sorceress because women practice sorcery more than men.44

18. WHOSOEVER LIETH WITH A BEAST. Scripture first mentions the laws dealing with the seduction of an immature young woman. It also mentions intercourse with an animal that, unlike a woman, cannot cry for help. It then mentions45 the law concerning a woman who can cry for help.46

19. HE THAT SACRIFICETH UNTO THE GODS. According to the plain meaning of the text the verse does not speak of an Israelite, for Scripture already warned against this in the second statement.47 It is only mentioned because of the stranger who is mentioned in the next verse. It is because of the stranger48 that Scripture reads, Whosoever lieth with a beast (v. 18), for this is the manner of the foreign nations. Now a stranger may live in the Land of Israel on the following conditions: that he does not lie with a beast and that he does not sacrifice unto idols. Scripture reads, la-elohim (unto the gods) because the reference is to the gods that the stranger was previously accustomed to worship.49 The term la-elohim (the gods) also takes in the angels.50
UNTO THE LORD ONLY. Only unto the glorious name51 which is a common noun not used for any other being.52
20. AND A STRANGER. When a stranger commits himself not to worship idols you shall not wrong him in your country because you are more powerful than he is. Remember that you were strangers like him.

When Scripture makes mention of the stranger who is powerless, it similarly takes note of the orphan and widow who are powerless Israelites. After saying lo te’annun (ye shall not afflict) (v. 21) which is in the plural, Scripture says im te’anneh (if thou afflict) (v. 22)53 because whoever sees a person afflicting the orphan and the widow and does not aid them, is also considered an afflicter.

22. IF THOU AFFLICT THEM. Note the punishment.54 If a person afflicts an orphan or a widow and no one comes to their aid, all are punished. The next verse therefore reads, My wrath shall wax hot, and I will kill you, that is, all of you.

Scripture says, “for if he cry at all unto me”55 in regard to the orphan. The same applies to a widow. However, it is possible that the orphan is very young and cannot articulate his pain like the widow.56
24. IF THOU LEND MONEY. If the Lord gave you enough wealth so that you are able to lend to the poor.57

This section58 is mentioned here because the poor are like the stranger, the orphan, and the widow.59 God calls the poor My people because the pious do not seek to acquire wealth in this world, as can be seen from Elijah’s behavior.60 Elisha, who did not want to accept Naaman’s gift (II Kings 5:16), also proves this point.61 So does Samuel from Ramah.62
[WITH THEE.] Its meaning is, in the place where you dwell.

THOU SHALT NOT BE TO HIM AS A CREDITOR. In that he favors you because of your kindness. Scripture reads, tesimun (shall ye lay) because the lender, the scribe, and the witnesses all violate the law.63

25. IF THOU AT ALL TAKE THY NEIGHBOR’S GARMENT TO PLEDGE. After saying salmat re’ekha (thy neighbor’s garment), which is the feminine,64 and similarly, after saying, ki hi kesuto levaddah (for that is his only covering) (v. 26).65 Scripture says, teshivennu (thou shalt restore it).66 Scripture reads teshivennu because it refers to the pledge.67

Saadiah Gaon asks, what reason is there to take the pledge during the day and to return it at night? He answers, because the lender fears that the borrower might secure an additional loan from someone else and give him the pledge as security for the loan.
[26. FOR THAT IS HIS ONLY COVERING.] Its meaning is, you should pity him.

[FOR I AM GRACIOUS.] According to the Gaon the term chanun (gracious) is similar in meaning to channuni channuni (Have pity upon me, have pity on me) (Job 19:21).68 Its meaning is, I will give him money and take away your money. I believe that this is not the meaning of chaninah (graciousness). What did David seek in saying, Be gracious unto me, O God. according to Thy mercy (Ps. 51:3)?69 Chanun rather has the same meaning as the word rachum (merciful) although there is a difference between them,70 as I will note in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.

Now the phrase that I will hear which follows and it shall come to pass, when He crieth unto Me is similar to for if they cry at all unto Me, I will surely hear their cry — My wrath shall wax hot (v. 22,23).71 How shall you know that I will surely hear their cry? You will know it from My wrath which follows.72
27. THOU SHALT NOT REVILE73 GOD. The reference is to the judges,74 namely, the priests, the sons of Levi, who have the Torah with them.
NOR CURSE75 A RULER OF THY PEOPLE. In secret or in public. The Geonim differentiated between revile and curse.76 The ruler spoken of in our verse is the king noted in Deuteronomy.

When we examined all the verses that come one after the other until And in all things that I have said unto you take ye heed (Ex. 23:13), we discovered that most of them deal with the poor. They appear to be connected to the section If thou lend money…to the poor (v. 24).

Yefet says the reason Scripture mentions Thou shalt not revile God is that if the lender should violate the law and not return the pledge,77 the poor man, while in pain during the night, might revile the judge who ruled that the lender should take the pledge.

28. THE FULNESS OF THY HARVEST, AND OF THE OUTFLOW OF THY PRESSES. Mele’atekha (the fulness of thy harvest) is another name for wine and dimakha (the outflow)78 another name for oil. However, Saadiah Gaon says that mele’atekha refers to both the fullness of the seed and the fullness of the winepress. He says that dimakha alludes to oil, because when an olive is pressed the oil drips like a tear (dema). Now this verse is explained elsewhere, namely, The first-fruits of thy corn, of thy wine, and of thine oil, and the first of the fleece of thy sheep (Deut. 18:4).79 Scripture therefore couples The first-born of thy sons shalt thou give unto Me with it.80 For the first-born are the first of one’s strength.81

Ben Zuta says that mele’atekha (the fulness of thy harvest) refers to pregnancy and dimakha (the outflow of the press) is another term for sperm, which is a drop. He also says that Thou shalt not delay means that one should not delay taking a wife. Hence, The first-born of thy sons shalt thou give unto Me follows it. However, this is sheer insanity. Why did Scripture mention mele’atekha before dimakha? According to Ben Zuta, dimakha refers to the ejaculation of semen into a woman, which is then followed by pregnancy. Furthermore, pregnancy is not in the hand of man. It depends only upon God.82
Yefet says that this verse is mentioned so that the poor person does not delay to give that which he is obligated to give.83
[29. SHALT THOU DO WITH THINE OXEN, AND WITH THY SHEEP.] Likewise thou shalt give the first-born84 to the priest.

30. AND YE SHALL BE HOLY MEN UNTO ME. Since Scripture mentions thine oxen and thy sheep, which are permitted to be eaten, it warns one not to eat meat which is torn, for it is possible that a poor person might eat torn meat because of his poverty.85
[IN THE FIELD.] Scripture speaks of what is most common. The same law applies if the animal was torn in the midst of a city. That chanceth him by night (Deut. 23:11)86 is similar.87

[TO THE DOGS.]88 The lamed prefaced to kelev (dogs) was vocalized with a pattach89 because the reference is to the dog who guards the oxen and the flock.90 Torn meat is not fit for anyone, only for a dog

Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that torn meat is unhealthier than meat from an animal that dies of natural causes. There is something poison-like in torn meat that is harmful to the health of a human being. Hence Scripture does not permit one to give torn meat unto the stranger that is within thy gates (Deut. 14:21) or to sell it unto a foreigner (Ibid.) as it does to meat from an animal that dies of natural causes (Ibid.).
chapter.ftnote: 1 In other words, damim (literally, blood) means bloodshed. Hence en lo damim (there shall be no bloodguiltiness in him) means he is not guilty of bloodshed.

2 The reference is to Rashi. Rashi interprets en lo damim (there shall be no bloodguiltiness in him): “This is not murder. He is considered as dead to begin with.” Also see Rashi on verse 2. “Damim lo (there shall be bloodguiltiness for him): He is considered as a living person, and the owner of the house commits murder if he kills him.”
3 He shall make restitution.
4 For the first part of our verse does not deal with what a thief steals. It deals rather with the circumstances under which an owner may kill a thief (Krinsky).
5 Which is connected to the first part of verse 8. See I.E. on Ex. 21:7,8.
6 I.E.’s point is that the bet prefaced to genevato (his theft) means because. Thus bi-genevato means because of his theft. The bet prefaced to a word usually means in. Hence I.E.’s comment.
7 Not only to an ox, ass, or sheep.
8 Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: however, our sages, etc.
9 Hebrew, gezerat ha-katuv.
10 See Baba Kama 67b.
12 Thus ki yaver ish means if a man sends his beast, i.e., he sends his beast to pasture. Indeed, this is how I.E. renders yaver in his short commentary. Similarly Rashi on verse 4.
13 The reference is apparently to yaver (Krinsky, Weiser). However, see next note.

14 Yaver, as I.E. points out in his short commentary, is a hifil. Some believe that our text is corrupt and that we should emend it accordingly. See Krinsky and Weiser. However, according to Filwarg, I.E.’s comment refers to bi’er (feed), which is the pi’el.
15 Literally, in another field. Hence I.E.’s comment.
16 In another field is short for in another man’s field.
17 Ye that have eaten up the vineyard means ye have eaten up the vineyard which belongs to another.
18 Mavir and yaver are both hifils.
19 Our verse opens with If fire break out. It then goes on to say that the “mavir” shall surely make restitution. It is thus clear that ha-mavir means he that kindled [the fire].
20 In one verse or passage.

21 Jud. 10:4 reads: And he had thirty sons that rode on thirty ass colts (ayarim), and they had thirty cities (ayarim), which are called Havvoth-jair (the villages of Jair) unto this day. It is highly unlikely that which are called Havvoth-jair refers to ass colts.
22 The above verses 1-3 dealing with theft.
23 Begun in the earlier verse.

24 Whether he have not put his hand unto his neighbor’s goods indicates an oath; i.e., then the master of the house shall come near unto God…[and shall swear] whether he have not put his hand unto his neighbor’s goods. So too Rashi.
25 That is, swore falsely (see Rashi). Since the previous verse deals with an oath taken by the bailee, the verse that follows deals with instances where the bailee commits perjury.
26 There is no such verse. II Kings 8:22 literally reads: “Yet Edom revolted from under the hand of Judah…Then did Libnah revolt at the same time.” I.E. probably quoted from memory and erred.
27 That is, oxen, asses, sheep, or raiment.
28 Else.
29 I.E.’s paraphrase, For every manner of trespass.
30 This is implied in every manner of trespass.
31 Explicitly mentioned in our verse.
32 That is, the judge.
33 A bailee, or keeper, who is paid for his services. This bailee is obligated to pay if what is placed in his charge is stolen or torn. See verse 11.

34 Melekhet (goods) is similar to the word melakhah (cattle) in According to the pace of the cattle. The word melakhah literally means work. Hence I.E.’s comment that it sometimes connotes goods, property, or anything that is one’s “work.” See I.E. on Gen. 33:14.
35 He was paid to make sure this did not happen.
36 The bailee does not have to pay for the animal, for the owner would not have permitted the bailee to overwork his animal.

37 I.E.’s interpretion of im sachir hu ba bi-secharo (if it be a hireling he loseth his hire) as: if a hired animal, while being accompanied by its lessee and lessor, was hurt or died, the lessee is not obligated to pay. See Weiser. See also Rashi who interprets differently.
38 Hence Scripture deals with this vice.
39 And the one who sleeps with her is punished by death. See Deut. 22:24.

40 According to Rabbinic tradition there are two stages to marriage, erusin (betrothal) and kiddushin (sanctification). In the first stage the woman lives with her parents and is prohibited from having intercourse with her husband. In the second stage the women leaves her parent’s home and takes up her domicile with her husband. In contemporary times the erusin and kiddushin take place at the same time. A woman who is an arusah is considered to be married even though she still lives with her parents. Thus a “betrothed woman” in Scripture does not refer to an engaged woman; it refers to a married woman.
41 Translated according to I.E. According to I.E., mahor yimharennah (he shall surely pay a dowry for her) is to be rendered: he shall surely attach himself to her; that is, he must marry her.
42 Whereas mahor yimharennah is in the kal.
43 By bewitching in one way or another the objects of their desire.
44 The same law applies to a sorcerer. However, Scripture speaks of what is most usual.
46 If raped.
47 Of the Decalogue, viz., Thou shalt have no other gods before Me (Ex. 20:3).
48 Some texts read, for it is on account.
49 The kamatz beneath the lamed indicates the definite article, namely, the gods that the stranger was accustomed to worship.
50 For the term elohim also refers to angels.
51 YHVH.
52 May one offer sacrifices.
53 Which is the singular.
54 For afflicting a widow or orphan.
55 Translated literally.
56 That is, he can only cry out.

57 If thou lend implies that lending money to the poor is not an obligation. However, it is clear from Deut. 15:7-11 that one is obligated to lend money to the poor. Hence I.E. points out that one is obligated to lend money only if one has money to lend.
58 Verses 21-23.
59 In that they are defenseless.

60 Scripture tells us that Elijah was girt with a girdle of leather about his loins (II Kings 1:8) and fed by ravens (I Kings 17:6). This, and the general description of Elijah’s life in Scripture, led I.E. to conclude that Elijah was poor.
61 For money was not important to Elisha.
62 Who did not use his position to gather wealth. See I Sam. 12:3.

63 Tesimun is a plural. Hence I.E.’s comment. According to the Talmud the borrower also violates the law. See Baba Metzia 75b. I.E. apparently held that according to the plain meaning of Scripture the borrower is not included, for tisimun cannot apply to him.
64 That is, salmat is in the feminine.
65 Kesuto (his covering) is in the feminine. Actually, ki hi kesuto levaddah follows teshivennu.
66 Teshivennu is masculine. Scripture should have used teshevennah since both salmat and kesut are feminine nouns.

67 Chavul (pledge) is masculine. Teshivennu (thou shalt restore it) does not mean thou shalt return the garment but rather thou shalt return the pledge (see previous note). It should be noted that the noun chavul is not explicitly stated in the verse but is implied in the verbs chavol tachbol (take to pledge).
68 According to Saadiah the word chanun means gracious. Thus Job 19:21 should be rendered: be gracious to me, be gracious to me.
69 The context makes it clear that David was not seeking a monetary gift from God.
70 In nuance.

71 Scripture tells us that when the orphan shall cry unto God, the Lord will hear his cry. It does not state what will happen next. I.E. thus points out that what follows I will surely hear their cry in verse 22 also applies here, viz., My wrath shall wax hot, and I will kill you with the sword; and your wives shall be widows, and your children fatherless (v. 23).
72 In verse 23.
73 Hebrew, tekalel.
74 Elohim (God) means judges. Thus, Thou shalt not revile God, means thou shalt not revile a judge or judges.
75 Hebrew, ta’or.
76 See notes 73 and 75. Kelalah refers to an insult, me’erah (curse) refers to a defect in a person’s body or fortune (Weiser).
77 At night.
78 Literally, weeping, or trickling.
79 Deut. 18:4 is parallel to our verse and indicates that our verse deals with the first fruits.
80 That is, it follows the law dealing with the first fruits of the fullness of the harvest and the outflow of the presses.
81 They are thus similar to the first fruits.

82 According to Ben Zuta our verse commands a man to marry and have children, viz., The first-born of thy sons shalt thou give unto Me. I.E. claims that there cannot be a command to have children, for while a man can marry and attempt to have children, there is no guarantee that he will. See I.E. on Gen. 1:22 and the notes thereto.
83 In other words, this verse is addressed to the poor. Yefet comments thus because most of our verses deal with the poor. See I.E.’s notes on the previous verse.
84 Of thine oxen and thy sheep.
85 I.E. comments thus because most of our verse deals with the poor. See I.E.’s note on verse 27.
86 The reference is to a seminal emission.
87 Scripture speaks of a nocturnal emission because that is when most involuntary emissions take place. However, the same law applies to an emission that occurs during the day.
88 Literally, to the dog.
89 Rather than with a sheva.
90 The pattach beneath the lamed indicates the definite article.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 23
chapter.p: 1. THOU SHALT NOT UTTER A FALSE REPORT. One should not invent fantasies in order to spread lies.
[PUT NOT THY HAND WITH THE WICKED.] Its meaning is, do not join a wicked person1 in testifying falsely to harm the innocent. A poor person might do this because of his poverty.2
2. THOU SHALT NOT FOLLOW A MULTITUDE TO DO EVIL. If you see many people testifying concerning something that you know nothing of, do not say to yourself all of these people cannot be lying.3

Saadiah Gaon says that there are two commandments in this verse. One is a negative commandment,4 the other a positive commandment.5 The Gaon says that6 we are obligated to follow the majority,7 for Saadiah thought that the word le-hattot (to pervert) has the same meaning as li-netot (to turn).8 However, this is not the case. Le-hattot is a pi’el.9 It is similar to the word matteh (perverteth) in Cursed be he that perverteth the justice due to the stranger, fatherless, and widow (Deut. 27:19). This form10 is also found without the word justice following it. See u-matteh11 ger (and pervert the stranger)12 (Mal. 3:5).

Our rabbis of blessed memory derived the law that the halakha follows the majority opinion from this verse.13 They transmitted the truth to us, for after Scripture states, Thou shalt not follow a multitude to do evil, we learn that we are commanded to follow a multitude that wants to do good.14
NEITHER SHALT THOU BEAR WITNESS. This commandment falls upon all of Israel. How much more so is a judge, before whom a dispute comes, obligated to help his neighbor.15

3. NEITHER SHALT THOU FAVOR A POOR MAN. This too is connected [to If thou lend money to any of My people even to the poor],16 as you might think that you are doing good in helping the poor.17 Scripture elsewhere states, nor favor the person of the mighty (Lev. 19:15).18

4. THINE ENEMY’S OX. Oyivkha (thine enemy’s) is spelled with a chirik beneath the yod.19 Oyivkha is a verb,20 for the word ve-ayavti 21 (then I will be an enemy) (v. 22) is a transitive verb.22 Its meaning is, even though you know that he is your enemy.23 The same is true of the word sona’akha (him that hateth thee) (v. 5).24 Scripture uses the term oyivkha25 because it is proper usage.26 This is also the case with sona’akha.27

It is possible that this section28 was written because if the ox and the ass belong to a poor person, then the reward for returning them is very great. One observes God’s law and one also acts kindly with the poor.

5. THOU SHALT FORBEAR. Ve-chadalta (thou shalt forbear) is similar to chadal (forbear) (II Chron. 25:16), the meaning of which is, forbear from doing this thing.29 Ve-shamarta (and thou shalt observe) (Deut. 17:10) is similar.30 The meaning of ve-chadalta ma’azov lo (thou shalt forbear to pass by him) is, forbear from leaving the matter31 to him alone. On the contrary, assist him in opening the knots32 and leave the burden as it is,33 and it will fall down on both sides of the donkey.34 The beast will then rise.35 Some say36 that its meaning37 is similar to va-ya’azevu (and they restored) in and they restored Jerusalem (Neh. 3:8), its meaning being, thou shalt surely load the burden. However, this is far-fetched.

6. THOU SHALT NOT WREST THE JUDGMENT OF THY POOR. This is directed to judges.38 Thou shalt eat it39 before the Lord thy God (Deut. 15:20) similarly refers to the one who is fit to eat it.40 Scripture, as it were, separates the kohen from the Israelites and addresses him.41 The person who says42 that the reference43 is to the first-born of the flock44 speaks nonsense.
7. KEEP THEE FAR FROM A FALSE MATTER. This45 is directed to judges. They are not to judge falsely.46 Justice, justice shalt thou follow (Deut. 16:20) is similar.47

AND THE INNOCENT AND RIGHTEOUS SLAY THOU NOT. Those who are innocent and righteous in this case. If you know, that the defendant is wicked in some other matter do not say, because he committed some other horrible act, let me kill him and remove him from society.48 I will exact punishment from him and he will not escape My hand.49
8. AND THOU SHALT TAKE NO GIFT. This verse is also mentioned because the wealthy give bribes to the judges to divert justice from the poor.50
AND PERVERTETH THE WORDS OF THE RIGHTEOUS. Saadiah Gaon says that the word tzaddikim (righteous) modifies divre (words of).51 However, this is not possible, for divre is in the construct.52
[RIGHTEOUS.] Righteous refers to righteous in the matter before the judges, not righteous with regard to the observance of the commandments.
10. AND SIX YEARS. This too53 is mentioned because of that the poor of thy people may eat (v. 11).54
11. BUT THE SEVENTH YEAR THOU SHALT LET IT REST. This is the year that the Lord’s release is proclaimed. One is then prohibited from exacting a debt from his needy neighbor.55
AND LIE FALLOW. U-netashta (and lie fallow)56 means it shall not be sown. And we would forego (ve-nittosh)57 the seventh year (Neh. 10:32) is similar.58
12. SIX DAYS. Scripture also mentions that the son of thy handmaid, and the stranger, who is in your gate, who is poor, and [who] hires himself out to you, may be refreshed.59

13. AND IN ALL THINGS THAT I HAVE SAID UNTO YOU TAKE YE HEED. Scripture now mentions idolatry. And in all things that I have said unto you refers to God’s commandments and ordinances. Observe them, not the ordinances of other gods. Scripture says, and make no mention of the name of other gods ; that is, do not mention their names in any oath or cause their adherents to swear by their names. The precise meaning of neither let it be heard out of thy mouth is: you shall not cause others to swear by their names; that is, do not tell an idolater, “Swear to me by your god.”

14. [THREE TIMES.] The meaning of regalim60 is times. You shall serve only Me. You shall serve Me three times a year by coming before Me like a servant who comes before his master to bring him a gift. Scripture therefore afterwards reads, el61 pene ha-adon Adonai (v. 17),62 the meaning of which is, before the Lord63 God (v. 17). And none shall appear before Me empty (v. 15) is similar.64 Scripture mentions this because pagans go to worship their vanities on specific days.65 Scripture therefore reads, thou shalt keep a feast unto Me, the meaning of which is, only unto Me.
[THOU SHALT KEEP A FEAST.] The word tachog (thou shalt keep a feast) means thou shalt sacrifice. It is similar to the word chag (sacrifice) in tie the sacrifice with ropes (Ps. 118:27).66
TIMES. The word regalim comes from the same root as regel (foot), for most of the people come on foot.67

15. THE FEAST OF UNLEAVENED BREAD. Scripture starts with the festival of unleavened bread68 because it falls in the first month of the year.69 Now Scripture states, seven days thou shalt eat unleavened bread. This is similar to Thou shalt keep the feast of tabernacles seven days (Deut. 16:13). It is thus an obligation.70 However, Six days thou shalt do thy work (v. 12) differs.71 For Scripture immediately states that one has to rest on the seventh day (Ibid.).72 Seven days thou shalt eat unleavened bread differs from it.73 Furthermore, why doesn’t Scripture read, seven days you shall not eat leavened bread?74
IN THE MONTH ABIB. I have already explained this.

[AND NONE SHALL APPEAR BEFORE ME EMPTY.] Many think that ve-lo yera’u fanai rekam (and none shall appear before Me empty) is like u-fanai lo yera’u (but My face shall not be seen) (Ex. 33:23).75 However, this is incorrect, for those who come to the house of the Lord are there seen.76 Venireh et pene Adonai (That he may appear before the Lord) (I Sam. 1:22) is proof of this.77 The phrase et pene Adonai in yera’eh khol zekhurekha et pene Adonai (shall all thy males appear before the Lord thy God) (Deut. 16:16) means before the Lord.78

16. AND THE FEAST OF HARVEST. The harvest of the first of the wheat. Now the barley crop which is what Abib refers to79 is always there when the festival of unleavened bread arrives. There are seven weeks from the arrival of the first barley to the arrival of the first wheat. Compare, Seven weeks shalt thou number unto thee (Deut. 16:9).
AND THE FEAST OF INGATHERING, AT THE END OF THE YEAR. And a new year commences. Sowing begins in the month of Marcheshvan.80

17. THREE TIMES. These three times, concerning which I said, None shall appear before Me empty (v. 15), was said only with regard to males who are of the age when they are obligated to observe the commandments. Those who are ill and cannot come are exempt.
18. THE BLOOD OF MY SACRIFICE. The reference is to the sacrifice of the paschal offering, which is eaten with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.

THE FAT OF MY FEAST. The reference is to the unblemished lamb81 which one is obligated to offer. It is similarly written, in offering the portions that were to be burnt and the fat till the morning (II Chron. 35:14).82

19. THE CHOICEST FIRST-FRUITS OF THY LAND. This is what And if thou bring a meal-offering of first-fruits unto the Lord (Lev. 2:14) refers to. As I will explain in its place, the verse83 is directed to the individual.84 Scripture mentions this law after Thou shalt not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread (v. 18), for the first fruits begin then.85

[THOU SHALT NOT SEETHE A KID IN ITS MOTHER’S MILK.] The fools86 say that the word gedi (a kid) comes from the same root as meged (precious fruit).87 However, this is impossible, for the mem of meged is a root letter. The word megadim (precious fruit) in with precious fruit (Cant. 4:13) is definite proof of this.88 We do not find such a thing in the Hebrew language.89 Furthermore, how are we to explain lo tivashel (thou shalt not seethe)?90 A person cannot ripen the precious fruit. Indeed, Scripture states, And for the precious things (u-mi-meged) of the fruits of the sun91 (Deut. 33:14). Additionally, what reason is there to say in…milk?92 Where do we find such an expression?93 Additionally, what is the meaning of its mother’s? Where else is the tree called the mother of the precious fruit? The fools came to this conclusion because they found this commandment coupled with The choicest first-fruits of thy land. 94 Elsewhere we find this commandment95 coupled with Ye shall not eat of any thing that dieth of itself (Deut. 14:21). The latter is its proper place. However, it96 was only mentioned together with the first-fruits because the kids increase and grow then.97

There is another commentator who says that the meaning of Thou shalt not seethe is, thou shalt not prolong; that is, a kid shall not be with its mother more than seven days.98 Now if this is the case, why does Scripture mention this law again?99 Furthermore, their proof is in the phrase bashel katzir (the harvest is ripe) (Joel 4:13).100 However, the term bashel means to seethe,101 for the sun seethes like fire.102 It is the same case with hivshilu (ripe)103 in and the clusters thereof brought forth ripe grapes (Gen. 40:10).

Rabbi Solomon104 says that gedi (a kid) means young and tender. He says it applies to young oxen and young lambs. He claims that the phrase gedi izzim (a kid of the goats) (Gen. 38:17) proves this, since there is no reason to connect them.105 However, this is not so. The term gedi applies only to a goat. Thus in Arabic106 the term gedi means a goat. It is never used for any other kind. However, there is a difference between a gedi and a gedi izzim. A gedi is larger than a gedi izzim. A gedi izzim still needs to be with other goats. The same applies to the terms sa’ir (a he-goat) and se’ir izzim.107 Our sages have received the tradition that an Israelite is not permitted to eat meat and milk.108

I will now explain.109 Note that it is the Torah’s custom to speak of that which is most prevalent. For example, the Torah refers to the ostrich as a bat ha-ya’anah (Lev. 11:16).110 Now why does the Torah do something here which it does not do in any other place? For in no other place does the Torah refer to an entire species by the term “daughter of” (bat). Note that the flesh of the ya’anah is as dry as wood. It is not customary for people to eat it, as it contains no moisture. The only flesh of this species that is eaten is that of the “daughter” (bat), whose flesh has a little moisture in it because it is a young female.111 However, young ostrich males have no moisture in them.

Similarly, people do not eat meat and milk, for it is not pleasant to do so. Meat takes long to cook, but milk boils quickly.112 It is not the custom even today in the land of the Ishmaelites for a person to eat a lamb cooked in milk because the lamb is very moist and so is milk. It is thus harmful.113 Hence it is not eaten. On the other hand, the flesh of the kid contains no moisture. When a goat is small it is hot.114 Therefore they [inhabitants of Ishmaelite lands] cook the kid with milk.

Do not be surprised that the people of the surrounding areas are not in the habit of eating a kid of the goats.115 All the physicians admit that there is no comparable meat, and they even permit the sick to eat it. They similarly eat it in Spain, Africa, the Land of Israel, Persia, and Babylonia. It was similarly the custom of the ancients to eat it. We thus read: two good kids of the goats (Gen. 27:9); that we may make ready a kid for thee (Jud. 13:15). We also find that the kohen eats the kid of the goats that is brought as a sin offering (Lev. 6:19; 23:19,20).
It is because it is not the custom for a person to eat raw meat that the Torah prohibited a person from cooking a kid in its mother’s milk.116

Some say that bishul (seething) only applies to meat roasted over a fire.117 However, is it not written, u-vasel mevushal bamayim (sodden…with water) (Ex. 12:9)? We similarly find that the Book of Chronicles states bi-shelu ba-sirot (sod they in pots) (II Chron. 35:13).

There is no need for us to search for the reason it is prohibited.118 The reason is hidden from the eyes of the intelligent. It is possible that it is prohibited to seethe a kid in its mother’s milk because to do so is very cruel. The idea behind this law is like the idea behind And whether it be cow or ewe, ye shall not kill it and its young both in one day (Lev. 22:28), and thou shalt not take the dam with the young (Deut. 22:6).

It is the practice of most people that do not have a flock to buy milk in the market.119 In such a case the milk usually consists of a mixture coming from many goats. It is possible for the buyer of a kid not to know where the mother is.120 Now if the one who has bought a kid later buys milk, it is possible that some of this milk contains milk from the mother of the kid which he previously purchased. He will then violate the law.121 We must be strict when in doubt regarding a Biblical law.122
The Ishmaelites also admit that if one cooks a kid in its mother’s milk the resulting dish tastes better because the mother and the kid are similar in nature. Scripture speaks of what is most usual.

The ancients of blessed memory were strict in order to remove all doubt.123 They thus prohibited meat and milk.124 God who gave them wisdom will fully reward them. I will further explain in each of their respective places why Scripture noted this law a second125 and a third time.126

20. BEHOLD, I SEND AN ANGEL BEFORE THEE. God told Moses that he should also127 tell Israel that if they accept all the laws128 and ordinances, starting from Ye yourselves have seen (Ex. 20:19),129 then God would bring them into the land.

[AN ANGEL.] Many err concerning the angel. Some say that the angel refers to the Book of the Torah, for Scripture says, for My name is in him (v. 21).130 Others say that the reference is to the ark of the covenant.131 They interpret and hearken unto his voice (v. 21) as: and hearken to what is written in it.132 They also say that for he will not pardon your transgression (Ibid.) means: for God will not pardon your transgressions. Now all of this is nonsense, as this theme133 is found throughout Scripture. We thus read: He will send His angel before thee (Gen. 24:7); the angel who hath redeemed me from all evil (Gen. 48:16). Moses similarly said, and sent an angel, and brought us forth out of Egypt (Num. 20:16). We likewise read, And the angel of His presence saved them (Is. 63:9); And the angel of the Lord went forth (Is. 37:36); and said to the angel that destroyed the people (II Sam. 24:16); My God hath sent His angel (Dan. 6:23); and the appearance of the fourth is like that of an angel (Dan. 3:25).134 There are many similar instances.

We read in the book of Daniel, The prince of Persia…the prince of Greece (Dan 10:20); except Michael your prince (Dan. 10:21).135 Michael is the angel referred to as the great prince, for he is exalted above many others. Scripture also states regarding Michael, one of the first princes, came to help me (Dan. 10:13).136 The meaning of first is, first in rank. It is like and sat first in the kingdom (Esther 1:14). The angel referred to137 is Michael.
TO KEEP THEE BY THE WAY. So that nothing evil happens to you.
WHICH I HAVE PREPARED. For you. Our verse follows the idea When the Most High gave to the nations their inheritance (Deut. 32:8),138 which I will discuss later.

21. TAKE HEED OF HIM. Every angel follows God’s command. The angel does not add or subtract from what God has commanded him.139 The same applies to Satan, who tormented Job.140 He was an angel. It was the same case with the angel who went out to hinder Balaam. Now, whoever hearkens to the voice of the angel is hearkening to the voice of God the glorious.

[BE NOT REBELLIOUS AGAINST HIM.] The word tammer (rebellious) is difficult. Its meaning appears to be similar to va-yamru (rebelled)141 in but they rebelled against Me (Ezek. 20:8). However, in this case our word should have read tamreh.142 The Spanish scholars were therefore forced to say that tammer comes from a double root.143 It is like vayassev (led about)144 in But the Lord led the people about (Ex. 13:18), for the entire form145 comes from a double root.146 Venasevah (wound about) in were broader as they wound about (Ezek. 41:7) is a nifal.147 It148 is like ve-navela (confound)149 in and there confound (Gen. 11:7), which comes from the same root as balal (mixed).150 It is also similar to ve-navekah (empty)151 in And the spirit of Egypt shall be made empty (Is. 19:3), which comes from the same root as bokek152 (empty) (Is. 24:1). Do not be surprised that we have two roots153 with one meaning. For we find this to be the case with the words sorer (bear rule)154 and sarita (striven)155 in that every man shall bear rule (sorer) in his own house (Esther 1:22) and in for thou hast striven (sarita) with God (Gen. 32:29). The same is true of tammer (rebellious) in be not rebellious against him156 and memer (rebellious) in And rebellious to her that bore him (Prov. 17:25).157 Memer follows the paradigm of mekhes (tribute) (Num. 31:28), which comes from the same root as takhossu (ye shall make your count) in ye shall make your count for the lamb (Ex. 12:4). It comes from a double root.158

[FOR MY NAME IS IN HIM.] Note that for My name is in him is connected to Take heed of him, and hearken unto his voice (v. 21).159 It is like And also unto thy bondwoman thou shalt do likewise (Deut. 15:17).160
I have already explained that God’s glorious name161 is a proper name, as it refers only to the Lord. It is also found as an adjective.162 For God is all, and all comes from Him.163

[IN HIM.] God is said to be in him in the same sense that the center of a circle is equally distant to all points on the circumference of the circle.164 It is only in this sense that Scripture tells us that God’s glory is in the midst of the camp,165 and that the Lord’s glory journeys in the camps.166 It is thus written, that Thou Lord art in the midst of this people (Num. 14:14). Scripture likewise reads, And formed the spirit of man within him (Zech. 12:1).167

Do not be astonished that Scripture first reads, But if thou shalt indeed hearken unto his voice (Ex. v. 22) and then goes on to say, and do all that I speak (Ibid.).168 I will give you an example by which you can understand the above. All the scientists who study astronomy have proven beyond a shadow of a doubt that the moon is a body which receives its light from the sun, for the moon has no light.169 It is for this reason that the sun grows dark when the moon joins it170 during the day.171 The sun and the moon are both embedded in spheres that are similar to the spheres of the constellations.172 The darkness results only from the fact that the moon, which like the sun is circular, passes beneath the sun.173 Now the side of the moon which faces the sun is totally illuminated. However, the side which is above it is dark. It is not illuminated. Observe that the moon thereby blocks the light of the sun. The moon is also left without light even in the middle of a lunar month174 if the shadow of the earth comes between it and the sun.175 Look! We know that the light of the moon at night illuminates the air. Now if Reuben calls the light of the moon moonlight, he speaks the truth. If Simeon refers to the light of the moon as sunlight, he too speaks the truth.176

22. [AN ADVERSARY.] The wise men of Spain found the word evah (enmity)177 spelled with a silent yod (Gen. 3:15). However, our verse reads, ve-ayavti178 et oyevekha (I will be an enemy unto thine enemies).179 They also found Scripture reading tzed180 chayyah (in hunting any beast) (Lev. 17:13) and tzayyadim181 (hunters) (Jer. 16:16). They also found the word din (the cause) in They plead not the cause of the poor (Jer. 5:28)182 and dayyan183 (judge) in The Lord therefore be judge (I Sam. 24:16). They therefore said that a verb has no less than three letters.184 Hence evah185 comes from a root whose middle letter is silent.186

23. FOR. God commanded Israel to remove all idols immediately upon coming to the Land of Israel. He mentioned six nations and did not bother to mention the smallest among them.187 It is concerning the latter that God said, and I will [immediately] cut him off.188 As to the others, By little and little I will drive them out (v. 29). It is also possible that and I will cut him off means: and I will cut off each one of them. It is like Its branches run over the wall (Gen. 49:22).189

24. THOU SHALT NOT BOW DOWN TO THEIR GODS. This is what I referred to earlier when I said that the Book of the Covenant190 opens and closes with a warning against idol worship. For Ye yourselves have seen (Ex. 20:19), which opens the Book of the Covenant, is a warning against idolatry, as is for they will be a snare unto thee (v. 33), which closes the book. However, there is a difference between the two. At the beginning of the book God commanded [Israel] not to make a god of silver alongside the Lord. At the end of the book He commanded Israel to uproot from the land of Canaan all the idols that its inhabitants had made. For whoever worships idols violates, as it were, all the negative commandments of the Torah. Furthermore, all of the positive commandments which he observes are of no avail to him in this world or in the next world.

25. AND YE SHALL SERVE THE LORD…HE WILL BLESS THY BREAD AND THY WATER. Its meaning is, you shall serve only the Lord who took you out of the house of bondage and brought you to the land of nations which served other gods who were not able to save them from your hands. Serving God is defined as doing all that the Lord has commanded, namely, to love the Lord, to cleave unto Him, to swear by His name, to pray to Him, to sacrifice the daily and the additional offerings unto Him and to honor Him by giving tithes. One who does the above has his reward with him.191 The latter consists of the following four things192 which he will receive in this world. One, And He (God) will bless thy bread and thy water. Two, I (God) will take sickness away from the midst of thee. Three, None shall miscarry, nor be barren, in thy land (v. 26). Four, The number of thy days I (God) will fulfill (Ibid.). Now all of these rewards pertain to the body. In addition, God will do the reverse of these blessings to your enemies; namely, I will send
My terror before thee (v. 27); And I will send the hornet before thee (v. 28).

Abraham the author writes: There are some great scholars who are very learned in the two laws193 but have not studied the sciences. I therefore cannot begin to explain the abovementioned blessings without first mentioning a bit of the sciences.194 Man’s body comes from the lowest world. However, man’s soul (neshamah), which is tied to the body,195 comes from on high. There are two powers that are intermediate between the body and the soul. These two powers are referred to in the main in Hebrew as ru’ach (spirit) and nefesh (life force, appetite, desire), for the soul (neshamah) is the rational part of man and its place is in the brain of man. From it comes the power of all emotions and the desire to move.196

The ru’ach (spirit) is situated in the heart. Life depends on the ru’ach. The ru’ach desires to dominate; that is, it seeks to overcome all opposition. It is the source of anger. Solomon similarly said, Be not hasty in thy spirit (ruchakha) to be angry (Eccles. 7:9), and A fool spendeth all his spirit (rucho) (Prov. 29:11). The seat of the nefesh (life force, appetite, desire) is in the liver. It is the nefesh that desires to eat. It is thus written, because thy soul (nafshekha) desires (Deut. 12:20). The nefesh is the source of sexual desire. Now some people are created in such a way that these three souls are strong. In others they are weak. In other instances one soul is strong, another weak, or neither weak nor strong. Now, people fall into twenty-seven categories.197

God gave the Torah to strengthen, to intensify, and to increase the power of man’s supernal soul. When this happens the body does not rule over it. However, if the Torah is not observed, then the body overpowers the neshamah. I will explain198 with the following parable. We know from the teachings of the sciences that any person whose constitution is overcome by red bile will be angry, for this is the nature of fire199 and red bile is like fire. Now when the neshamah is unintelligent it pursues the wants of the body because it cannot overcome its desires. Additionally, let us consider a person who is not by nature hot. If another person comes along and curses him to the point where he becomes angry, he begets heat in his body which was not there before he became angry.

God the exalted, in his kindness, chose Israel and taught them His Torah. If Israel observes the Torah they become wise. Their wisdom guides them in a straight path to all things that will not harm them. The general rule is: the body must be subservient to the dictates of the soul (neshamah) rather than the soul being subservient to the dictates of the body. When the soul (neshamah) is strong, then the heavenly power known as nature, which preserves the body, grows in might.

Now our verse tells us that God’s blessing shall be upon all our food and drink. For there is a curse that adversely effects the power of nature, as in Thou shalt eat, but not be satisfied (Micah 6:14). Observe that all illnesses come from the food that enters the body. Now a person who observes the Torah will not fear them. This is the meaning of and He will bless thy bread. There are other diseases that come from outside the body due to a change in the air caused by a shift in the arrangement of the planets. It is concerning this that our verse states, and I will take sickness away from the midst of thee. Look, a person who observes the Torah has no need for a physician along with God the Revered. Scripture thus writes, yet in his disease he sought not to the Lord, but to the physicians (II Chron. 16:12).

I have thus spoken on the science of medicine. I will now speak on the science dealing with the heavenly bodies. Note that what befalls human beings depends on the alignment of the planets and what their arrangement indicates at the time of a person’s birth. The aforementioned is extremely difficult to understand. If a woman is born under an arrangement that decrees she will not be able to carry her children to term, then it will be the nature of her womb to abort the children in it. The same is true if the woman is born under an arrangement that decrees that she be barren and not have children.

Now if a person who is born under an arrangement of the planets that determines that he will have a physical makeup that is unable to beget children cleaves to God, then if he truly cleaves to God, the revered God will strengthen the power of this man’s kidneys and see to it that his sperm functions properly so that he will be able to have children. God therefore told Abraham, I am God Almighty; walk before Me, and be thou whole-hearted (Gen. 17:1). This is what the rabbis meant by “Cease thy planet gazing.”200 God told Abraham, “If you make a treaty to serve Me, I will greatly multiply you, as I will overcome what nature has decreed for you.”201 This is not a victory over the arrangements of the stars,202 for they were not created to do good or ill to the lowest world. On the contrary, they always go and do the service of God, as that is what they need to do. The inhabitants of the lowest world receive a thing and its opposite203 from them in accordance with their desire. Thus if we observe the Torah we will not receive evil from the heavenly bodies.204 I will yet speak on this in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.205 The third blessing206 is a blessing to the effect that all of Israel have children and that none of their children die in the lifetime of their parents.
26. [BARREN.] The reference is both to one’s wife and to his cattle.
[THE NUMBER OF THY DAYS I WILL FULFILL.] This, the fourth blessing, is a blessing for long life.

We know that there is a fixed and established time to every person’s life in accordance with the heat and moisture which are the natural components of the human body. One’s life is not fixed in accordance with the foreign fire207 and foreign moisture which are unnatural components of the body.208 The person who cleaves to God strengthens his body’s heat and moisture through the power of his soul. Such a person will live longer than his allotted life span. We thus read, The fear of the Lord prolongeth days (Prov. 10:27). It is also stated, In the midst of his days he shall leave them (Jer. 17:11).209 We further read, but the Lord shall smite him; or his day shall come to die (I Sam. 26:10). Now a person who dies in war or in a plague does not die on the day set aside for his death in accordance with the nature of the heat and moisture in his body. He dies because of outside events. Now if a person cleaves to God, the Lord will save him from all of these things.

We find that the Torah states, lest he die in battle (Deut. 20:5). We also read, why shouldest thou die before thy time (Eccles. 7:17). This does not contradict the science of astrology. For a star’s decree is dependent upon many things, as I will explain in commenting on so that we are distinguished, I and Thy people (Ex. 33:16). Scripture therefore states, behold, I will add unto thy days (Is. 38:5). Why should I continue to go on and on?210

27. I WILL SEND MY TERROR. The reference is to a fear in the soul. The body immediately weakens.211 This is what and I will make all thine enemies’ necks towards thee212 refers to. Its meaning is: your enemies will turn their necks to you; that is, they will flee from you when you look at them.
28. AND I WILL SEND THE HORNET. The reference is to a plague in the body which saps its strength. The word tzirah (hornet) comes from the same root as tzara’at (leprosy).213

Scripture mentions three of the seven Canaanite nations. However, the same applies to all of the other Canaanite nations. It is also possible that this plague ravaged these three nations more than it did the others.214

29. I WILL NOT. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that this215 will serve as a sign. When Israel will see that they have become fruitful and multiplied, then the seven nations will be uprooted.216 However, there is no need for this interpretation, for Scripture217 mentions the reason that God will not drive out the Canaanites in one year, namely, lest the land become desolate. The borders of the Land of Israel will be too large for those who left Egypt to be able to settle all of it.218 Pen (lest) in lest the land is like pen (lest) in lest the fulness of the seed….be forfeited (Deut. 22:9).219
30. BY LITTLE AND LITTLE. Until you increase and are able to inhabit the entire land. Scripture now goes on to describe the length and breadth of the land.
31. AND I WILL SET THY BORDER. This is what May he have dominion also from sea to sea, And from the River unto the ends of the earth (Ps. 72:8) refers to. The River220 refers to the Euphrates.
[32. THOU SHALT MAKE NO COVENANT WITH THEM.] Do not make a covenant with them in any case.221
[NOR WITH THEIR GODS.] Its meaning is, you shall destroy their gods.222
33. THEY SHALL NOT DWELL IN THY LAND. When you increase, you shall destroy and annihilate all the seven nations.
The Book of the Covenant ends here.
