182 I.E. took of the poor from Jer. 22:16. It does not appear in Jer. 5:28.
183 The yod is silent in the word din but sounded in dayyan. Both din and dayyan come from the same root.

184 The yod, as we have seen, is not sounded in tzed and din. This would seem to indicate that these words come from a two-letter stem and that the yod serves as a vowel letter. However, in view of the fact that the yod is sounded in tzayyad and dayyan, it is clear that these words have a threeletter root, and that the yod in tzed and din is a root letter.
185 Like tzed, and din.
186 Its root is alef, yod, bet.
187 The Girgashite. See Gen. 10:16. The Girgashite was one of the seven nations inhabiting Canaan.

188 Translated literally. J.P.S. reads; I will cut them off. In Hebrew the Girgashites are referred to as “him” (“it” in English) in the singular because they were separated from the other Canaanite nations and immediately destroyed (Weiser).

189 The meaning of which is that each one of its branches runs over the wall. According to I.E. when Scripture refers to the many by the singular, it may mean each one of the many. See I.E. on Gen. 49:22 and the notes thereto.

190 Ex. 24:7 speaks of the Book of the Covenant. According to I.E. the Book of the Covenant consists of Ex. 20:19 through Ex. 23:33. When Moses later wrote the entire Pentateuch he incorporated it into the Torah.
191 Is assured of his reward.
192 Mentioned in our verse.
193 The written Torah and the oral Torah.
194 I.E. held that a person cannot fully comprehend the Torah if he or she is ignorant of the sciences.
195 During a person’s lifetime.
196 That is, the desire to move the body (Krinsky).
197 There are 27 possible combinations of the three souls, or powers, in their three possible states: strong, weak, and intermediary. See Krinsky and Filwarg.
198 How the soul can or cannot overcome the body’s desires.
199 It is the nature of fire to consume. So too with anger, which takes over the body.

200 See Sabbath 156a (Soncino): “How do we know that Israel is immune from planetary influence? Because it is said, And He brought him (Abraham) forth from abroad (Gen. 15:5). Abraham pleaded before the Holy One, blessed be He, ‘Sovereign of the Universe! one born in mine house is mine heir’ (Gen. 15:3). ‘Not so’, He replied, ‘but he that shall come forth out of thine own bowels’ (Gen. 15:4). ‘Sovereign of the Universe!’ cried he, ‘I have looked at my constellation and find that I am not fated to beget child.’ Go forth from [i.e., cease] thy planet (gazing), for Israel is free from planetary influence.”
201 Ibn Ezra’s explanation of the Rabbinic reconstruction of Gen. 25.
202 I.E. seems to indicate that God does not change the laws of nature. Maimonides had a similar notion. According to Maimonides miracles were built into nature.
203 That is, good or bad.
204 This is how God set up the laws of astrology.
206 None shall miscarry, nor be barren (v. 26).
207 Possibly a reference to fever.
208 In other words, illness can cut short a person’s normal life span.
209 Which indicates that doing evil will lead to the shortening of one’s life.
210 When I have adequately made my point already.
211 When fear seizes the soul.
212 Translated literally. J.P.S. reads, and I will make all thine enemies turn their backs unto thee.
213 According to I.E., And I will send the hornet should be rendered, and I will send the plague.
214 Hence Scripture mentions only these three.
215 The reference is to verse 30.
216 Saadiah’s paraphrase of verse 30.
217 In our verse.
218 I.E.’s interpretation of verse 30. If God expelled its inhabitants in one year the land would become desolate.
219 In other words, the term pen means lest.
220 In our verse and in Psalms. See I.E. on Ps. 72:8.
221 Regardless of the size of your borders.
222 Thou shalt make no covenant with them means you shall destroy their gods.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 24
chapter.p: 1. AND UNTO MOSES HE SAID. All that God mentioned from above1 until now2 consisted of the conditions that Moses was to place before Israel. God then told Moses, after you make the covenant with Israel you, Aaron, Aaron’s sons, and seventy of the elders of Israel, namely, the holy first-born, shall come up unto Me.

2. AND MOSES ALONE SHALL COME NEAR. Do not be amazed that God first said, Come up3 unto the Lord (v. 1) and then, And Moses alone shall come near unto the Lord,4 rather than, and you will come near unto the Lord,5 for this is Hebrew style.6 We thus read, Then the Lord caused to rain upon Sodom and upon Gomorrah brimstone and fire from the Lord out of heaven (Gen. 19:24), the meaning of which is, from Him.7 However, Samuel said, And the Lord sent Jerubbaal, and Bedan, and Jephthah, and Samuel (I Sam. 12:11). Samuel did not say, and me.8 There are many such instances.

3. AND MOSES CAME. Scripture does not mention that Moses came down from the mountain9 because there was no need to do so.10 The meaning of And Moses came and told the people all the words of the Lord is, and Moses came in the midst of the camp of Israel and told the people all the positive and negative commandments that are codified between ye your-selves have seen (Ex. 20:19) and for they will be a snare unto thee (Ex. 23:33).11
AND ALL THE ORDINANCES. Which he placed before them. They are mentioned in this portion.12
AND ALL THE PEOPLE ANSWERED. As if they were one person.13
4. AND MOSES WROTE. After Moses related all the words of God, the commandments, and the ordinances, he wrote them down. This is what the Book of the Covenant consists of.

AND BUILDED AN ALTAR UNDER THE MOUNT. At the place where Israel stood at the time that the Torah was given. The word va-yiven (and builded) is to be read as if written twice. Our verse is to be read as if written: and he builded twelve pillars.14
5. AND HE SENT THE YOUNG MEN OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. The reference is to the young men who were the sons of the chosen15 elders who were to go up on the mountain with Moses.
WHO OFFERED BURNT-OFFERINGS. This is what and shalt sacrifice thereon (Ex. 20:21) refers to.
Scripture mentions that oxen were offered as peaceofferings because many people partook of the peaceofferings.16
6. AND MOSES TOOK HALF OF THE BLOOD. Of the burnt and peaceofferings.
[BASINS.] The word agganot (basins) refers to round vessels. Compare, aggan ha-sahar (round goblets) (Cant. 7:3). It is ajan in Arabic.

AND HALF OF THE BLOOD. Of the burnt and peaceofferings he dashed against the altar for God. Observe, the word agganot is to be read as if written twice. Moses placed half of the blood in basins, and he also placed the other half of the blood in basins.17

7. AND HE TOOK. When Moses read the Book of the Covenant to the elders and they accepted it upon themselves, he then took the remaining half of blood18 and sprinkled it upon the people, that is, the elders, for they stood for all of Israel.19 We similarly find the same regarding the bullock offered for an error made by the congregation. We read there, And the elders of the congregation, who were representing all of Israel, shall lay their hands upon the head of the bullock (Lev. 4:15).
[AND SPRINKLED IT UPON THE PEOPLE.] This sprinkling20 is like and sprinkled it upon Aaron, and upon his garments (Lev. 8:30).
[BEHOLD THE BLOOD OF THE COVENANT.] Moses called it the blood of the covenant.
9. THEN WENT UP MOSES. Scripture does not mention the mountain because there was no need to do so.21
10. AND THEY SAW THE GOD OF ISRAEL. In a prophetic vision. It is similar to I saw the Lord sitting on His throne (I Kings 22:19; II Chron. 18:18).

[A PAVED WORK OF SAPPHIRE STONE.] Saadiah Gaon says that the sappir (sapphire) is white.22 He offers the phrase livnat ha-sappir as proof.23 However, this is not the case. The sappir comes in no color but red.24 The fact that it is the style of Scripture to repeat itself in different words proves this. Now it is written, Her princes were purer than snow, They were whiter than milk (Lam. 4:7). We thus see that Scripture repeats itself in different words. The verse continues, They were more ruddy in body than rubies, Their polishing was as of sapphire (sappir) (Ibid.). The term sappir thus has the same connotation as rubies.25 Furthermore, if livnat ha-sappir means like the whiteness of sapphire what reason is there for Scripture to say, like a work?26 It should have read, like the appearance of.27 Actually, the word livnat is etymologically related to the word levanah (brick). It is like the word cheshkat (darkness of)28 in Darkness of waters (Ps. 18:12), which is etymologically related to the word chashekhah (darkness) (Gen. 15:12). Now the paved work of sapphire stone (livnat ha-sappir) was similar to the vision of the sapphire stone which had the form of a throne29 seen by Ezekiel in his prophetic vision (Ezek. 1:26; 10:1).

AND THE LIKE OF THE VERY HEAVEN FOR CLEARNESS. Its meaning is, beneath the paved work of sapphire stone there was the likeness of the very heaven. The latter refers to the ice-like firmament that was stretched over the heads of the beasts Ezekiel saw in his vision (Ezek. 1:22). Now our verse reads, and they saw the God of Israel. However, in Ezekiel Scripture reads, This is the living creature that I saw under the God of Israel (Ezek. 10:20).30 Scripture was being brief.31 The creature was under the firmament, and the firmament was under the throne of glory. All of this was under God the revered.32
11. AND UPON THE NOBLES. The word atzile (nobles of) is similar to the word u-me’atzilehah (from its nobles).33 The term elders34 is not used because the term nobles include Nadab and Abihu.35
[HE LAID NOT HIS HAND.] Its meaning is: that they saw God and did not die, as I will explain in my comments on the verse for man shall not see Me and live (Ex. 33:20).
[AND DID EAT AND DRINK.] They came down from the mountain happy.
AND DID EAT. The peaceofferings which their young people sacrificed.

AND DRINK. In happiness. Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi says that the meaning of and did eat is, they had to eat even though they enjoyed the splendor of God’s presence. Scripture mentions this because Moses lived for forty days and forty nights without eating and drinking, as is noted in the next section.36
12. AND THE LORD SAID UNTO MOSES: COME UP TO ME INTO THE MOUNT. And be there until I give you [the tables of stone, and the law, etc.].37
A Spanish sage38 said that the first tablets which were the work of God,39 which means were finished by God, were created the same size as the ark.40 The second tablets also were

The work of God, who is the One who created everything.41 However, Moses finished the second tablets.42 A finished product is called a work. We thus read, va-yemaher la’asot43oto (and he hastened to dress it) (Gen. 18:7). The sage said this because Scripture reads, tables of stone44 and does not employ the term stones as it does in reference to the second tablets.45 Now I pointed out to the above sage that Scripture states,46 When I was gone up into the mount to receive the tables of stone (avanim)47 (Deut. 9:9). Furthermore, Scripture there48 employs the phrase luchot avanim (tables of stone) three times.49 The meaning of luchot even (tables of stone) therefore50 is tables made of stone and not of wood.51

The Gaon says that which I have written is connected to tablets of stone and not to the law and the commandment,52 for God only wrote the Ten Statements.53 He explains that the meaning of the law is the written law and that of the commandment is the oral law, as all the commandments were given to Moses on Sinai during the days that Moses was on the mountain. It is similarly written, But as for thee, stand thou here by Me (Deut. 5:28).54 However, I believe that the law refers to the first and fifth statements of the Decalogue,55 and and the commandment refers to the other eight statements.56

13. AND MOSES ROSE UP. We may logically conclude that Joshua left the camp of Israel with Moses and stayed beneath the mountain until Moses came down. Observe, Joshua knew nothing about the making of the golden calf.57 There is no reason to ask, what did Joshua eat?58 Joshua gathered the manna which was around the camp and ate it daily.
14. AND UNTO THE ELDERS. The known elders, namely, the elders who saw God the revered.

AND, BEHOLD AARON. Aaron59 was also a first-born.60 It is possible that Hur was a first-born too and he was one of the seventy. Both of them were to judge in place of Moses until Moses came back. I have already explained61 that Jethro only came in the second year.62
15. AND MOSES WENT UP…AND THE CLOUD COVERED. The cloud had already covered the mountain on the sixth day of the month.63

16. AND THE GLORY OF THE LORD ABODE. This means that the glory of God had already abode, for Scripture clearly states, And the Lord came down upon mount Sinai. (Ex. 19:20).64 Furthermore, Scripture states, but Moses drew near unto the thick darkness where God was (Ex. 20:18).65
AND THE CLOUD COVERED IT.66 The cloud covered Moses and no one was able to see him.

AND THE SEVENTH DAY HE CALLED UNTO MOSES. There is no reason for the Gaon’s question, “Why didn’t Moses go up to the top of the mountain when he went up at first?”67 Moses was not able to go up68 without permission.69
17. AND THE APPEARANCE. Now the mountain was entirely covered by a cloud. God’s glory was on top of the mountain. God the revered was seen there in the form of burning fire.
18. AND MOSES ENTERED…AND WENT UP INTO THE MOUNT. Its meaning is, and Moses went up to the top of the mount where God’s glory was.

AND MOSES WAS IN THE MOUNT. He did not come down. Scripture writes concerning these forty days, I did neither eat bread nor drink water (Deut. 9:9). This is a great wonder. There never was such a miracle before.
chapter.ftnote: 1 From Ex. 20:19.
3 Aleh (come up) is in the second person.
4 This is in the third person.
5 In other words, why does Scripture switch from the second to the third person?
6 Not to be grammatically consistent.

7 From the Lord is another way of saying from Him, as Scripture is referring to the Lord in the third person. I.E.’s point is that Gen. 19:24 is grammatically consistent, for the entire verse is in the third person.

8 To be consistent, Samuel should have employed a pronoun, for Samuel is the speaker. Thus I Sam. 12:11 is not grammatically consistent. We thus see that not all verses in Scripture are grammatically consistent.

9 Ex. 20:18 tells us that Moses went up to Mount Sinai. Scripture never tells us that he came down. However, now God tells Moses to go up to Mount Sinai. Thus Moses, at some point after Ex. 23:33, must have come down from the mountain.

10 For if we find God telling Moses to come up, it is obvious that Moses had previously come down from the mountain. According to I.E., Moses came down from the mountain after he received the Book of the Covenant.
11 That is, all the commandments contained in the Book of the Covenant.
12 The Torah portion Mishpatim.
13 Va-ya’an (answered) is in the singular. It literally means, and he answered. Hence I.E.’s comment.
14 Our verse is to be read as follows: and builded an altar under the mount, and builded twelve pillars, according to the twelve tribes of Israel.
15 Our texts have ha-bachurim (the chosen). Vat. Ebr. 38 has ha-bekhorim (the first-born). See I.E. on verse 1.

16 Peace offerings were eaten by the celebrants. Since many celebrants (see previous note) partook of the offerings, oxen, which provide a substantial amount of meat, were sacrificed. Sheep and goats may also be brought as peaceofferings. However, they do not provide the same amount of meat as oxen. Hence I.E.’s comment.
17 According to I.E. our verse should be read as if written: and Moses took half the blood and put it in basins; and the other half he put in other basins and dashed the blood against the altar.
18 The half that had not been dashed on the altar.
19 It would have been impossible for Moses to sprinkle the blood upon all of the people. Hence I.E.’s comment.
20 Moses sprinkled the blood upon their garments (Krinsky).
21 It is clear from the context that Moses and those who accompanied him went up on Mount Sinai.
22 That is, sapphire stones have a white color.
23 According to Saadiah Gaon the word livnat (paved of) means whiteness of. Compare, lavan (white). Thus according to the Gaon the meaning of livnat ha-sappir is the whiteness of sapphire.

24 The usual color of sapphires is blue. However, white and yellow sapphires are also quite common. They never come naturally in red. I.E. either did not identify the sappir stone with sapphires, or he did not know what a sapphire was.
25 They both allude to the color red.
26 Scripture reads, ki-ma’aseh livnat ha-sappir, which according to Saadiah Gaon means like a work of the whiteness of stone.
27 The whiteness of sapphire. In other words, Scripture should have read, kimareh livnat ha-sappir rather than ki-ma’aseh livnat ha-sappir.
28 Both words are in the construct and are similarly vocalized.

29 See Ezek. 10:1: Then I looked, and, behold, upon the firmament that was over the head of the cherubim, there appeared above them as it were a sapphire stone, as the appearance of the likeness of a throne.
30 I.E.’s point is that in Ezekiel, God is described as sitting on a throne which was upon a platform held up by four beasts. However, here the throne and the creatures are omitted.
31 Here. In other words, we must transpose elements of Ezekiel’s vision to complete the account of the vision described in our verse.
32 That Moses and the elders saw God sitting upon a throne. God’s throne was upon an icy firmament held up by four creatures.
33 Translated according to I.E. See I.E. on Is. 41:9.
34 Verse 1 tells us that the elders accompanied Moses. Hence I.E.’s comment.
35 Who also accompanied Moses. Nadab and Abihu were nobles, not elders. See Rashi and Ramban.
36 Verse 18. Actually verse 18 only tells us that Moses was on Mount Sinai for 40 days. However, Deut. 9:9 tells us that Moses did not eat or drink during those forty days.
37 In other words, we should interpret our verse as if the term “until” was in the text.
38 I.E. does not identify him, nor can we.
39 Ex. 32:15 tells us that the tablets were the work of (ma’aseh) God.
40 Which was their final form. According to this sage, work of God means put into their final form by God. For the size of the ark, see Ex. 25:10.
41 That is, He created both sets of tablets.
42 See Ex. 34:1. Hence the second tablets are not referred to as God’s work.
43 The word la’assot come from the same root as the word ma’aseh (work).
44 In our verse and in Ex. 31:18.

45 Ex. 34:4. Scripture refers to the second tablets as luchot avanim, which literally means tables of stones. It refers to the first tablets as luchot even (tables of stone). The Spanish sage assumed that the phrase luchot even refers to a perfectly created stone, whereas luchot avanim refers to stones which require additional work (Filwarg).
46 With regard to the first tablets.
47 Literally, stones.
49 All of which are in reference to the first tablets.
50 That is, in view of the fact that Scripture refers to both tablets as luchot avanim, and the distinction that the sage made between them is untenable.
51 It other words, it does not mean perfectly created stones.
52 Which immediately precedes which I have written.
53 Which He inscribed on the tablets of stone.
54 The verse continues, and I will speak unto thee all the commandments, and the statutes, and the ordinances, which thou shalt teach them.
55 The only two positive commandments in the Decalogue.

56 Which are negative commandments. Hence Scripture refers to them by two different terms. Thus the entire verse deals with the Decalogue. Furthermore, we can now connect which I have written to that which immediately precedes it.
57 Hence he could not have been in the camp.
58 Since he was outside of the camp.
59 Aaron, like the 70 elders, was a first-born. See I.E.’s comment on verse 1.
60 This contradicts the Rabbinic opinion that Miriam was the eldest (Shemot Rabba 1:13). See Krinsky and Filwarg.
61 See I.E. on Ex. 18:1.

62 In other words, this occurred before Moses appointed judges over Israel. If judges had been appointed over Israel, Moses would not have found it necessary to appoint Aaron and Hur as judges in his place.

63 The cloud did not now cover the mountain. It covered the mountain on the sixth day of the third month, the day that God revealed the Decalogue. Moses ascended the mountain seven days later. Va-yekhas (covered) is to be taken as a pluperfect, meaning: had already covered.
64 Which shows that God’s glory was previously on the mountain. According to I.E., va-yishkon (abode) is a pluperfect.
65 Also this verse shows that God’s glory was previously on the mountain.
66 Literally, and the cloud covered him. There is no neutral form in Hebrew. Thus “him” can refer either to the mountain or to Moses. Hence I.E.’s comment.

67 Verse 13 tells us that Moses went up the mountain. Our verse tells us that God called unto Moses to come up, i.e., to come up to the top (see I.E. on verse 18). The question thus arises, why didn’t Moses immediately go up to the top of the mountain?
68 To the top of the mountain.
69 Without a specific call to go up to the top of the mountain.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 25
chapter.p: God who gave a perfect Torah to his children;
The Lord who brings to light all hidden things;
Will explain to us the words of wisdom inscribed
In the Torah portion That They Take For Me An Offering.

1. AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES. When Moses went up to the top of the mountain1 God spoke to him regarding the tabernacle. God told Moses that Israel should construct a sanctuary dedicated to God the revered. The Lord would dwell in this tabernacle and speak therein with Moses. Moses would no longer come up on the mountain.2

2. [THAT THEY TAKE FOR ME.] The words ve-yikchu li (that they take for Me)3 is similar to the form surah elai4 (turn in to me) (Jud. 4:18). Surah elai means turn from your place and come to me.5 Ve-yikchu li has a similar connotation. It means let him6 take from what he owns and give it to me.7 The same is true of Fetch me (kechi li), I pray thee, a little water (I Kings 17:10).8

3. AND THIS IS THE OFFERING. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that we do not find silver mentioned in connection with the tabernacle except for the silver of those who were counted.9 This being the case, how could Scripture state that the silver was an offering?10 The Gaon answers that other silver was donated for use in the construction of a silver table,11 since it is highly unlikely that there was no table for preparing things,12 for cutting, for washing, or for the trumpets and basins.13 However, I believe that there is no need for the Gaon’s interpretation. Scripture did not bother to exclude one of the sixteen materials,14 as fifteen were donated.15 It is the same with These are the sons of Jacob, that were born to him in Paddanaram (Gen. 35:26).16 However, Benjamin was born in the land of Canaan. He was not born elsewhere.17 Furthermore, Scripture states, Thy fathers went down into Egypt with threescore and ten persons (Deut. 10:22). However, the sons of Joseph did not go down to Egypt, for they were born in Egypt.18

Scripture begins with a precious gift, namely, gold. It concludes with a precious gift, onyx stones, and stones to be set,19 which only the princes possessed. However, this was not the case with gold, as most of the people had gold. Now, no iron was used in the construction of the tabernacle.20 Scripture tells us regarding the first temple, and there was neither hammer nor axe nor any tool of iron heard in the house, while it was in building (I Kings 6:7).21

4. AND BLUE. Yefet22 says that tekhelet (blue) is a blacklike color. Black is the final23 color, as all colors turn black,24 and no human hands can change black.25 However, we will rely on the sages of the Talmud who said that tekhelet is green wool.26
AND PURPLE. Argaman (purple) is a red-like color. It is referred to as argevan in the Book of Chronicles (II Chron. 2:6) and as arju’an in Arabic. This color is only found in wool or silk.27

AND SCARLET. However, Scripture elsewhere reads, sheni ha-tola’at28 (and the scarlet) (Lev. 14:6). We find the same with mi-tzur ha-challamish (out of the rock of flint) (Deut. 8:15) and chelmish tzur (out of the flinty rock) (Deut. 32:13). Saadiah Gaon rendered tola’at shani as krimez (red).29 Although tola’at shani is also red, it is not the same color that argaman is.30 Many people identify tola’at shani with silk31 because of the word tola’at.32

AND FINE LINEN. Shesh refers to linen, which is a type of flax that is found only in Egypt. It comes only in white and is not dyed. We thus read, Of fine linen (shesh) and richly woven work33 from Egypt (Ezek. 27:7).34 The Gaon translated shesh as osher in Arabic. This material is in existence until this very day.
AND GOATS’ HAIR. Izzim is to be rendered as goats’ hair.35
5. AND RAMS’ SKINS. Skins from large rams. Such skins are prepared in the land of Al Gudmas36 and are referred to as gudmasi.

AND SEALSKINS. Techashim (seals) refers to a type of animal that was known then,37 as it is written, va-ena’alekh tachash (and shod thee with sealskin) (Ezek. 27:7). It is thus clear that it was already known.38

AND ACACIA-WOOD. Some of our ancient sages said39 that the patriarch Jacob planted acacia trees in Egypt, and Israel, upon the command of Moses, brought them out. And every man, with whom was found40 acacia-wood…brought it (Ex. 35:24) is proof of this.41 They possessed acacia as they possessed the blue and the purple.42

However, one wonders, why does Scripture say, with whom was found, which means it was used for personal needs.43 Now, if we so interpret it,44 then we must ask, why did the Israelites take acacia wood out of Egypt? What need did they have for acacia wood?45 Furthermore, it is clear that the Egyptians thought that the Israelites were going to offer sacrifices and then return to Egypt. That is why the Egyptians lent the Israelites [gold and silver jewels plus raiment].46 How could the Israelites take out many boards, each one of which was ten cubits?47 The boards were also accompanied by bars.48 In Egypt they passed by the seat of the king. What was their answer to those who asked them why they were carrying acacia wood when they were going on a three-day journey to offer sacrifices?

Now we do not know whether our ancestors had a tradition that the Israelites took the acacia wood out of Egypt. If they did, then we will accept their tradition. However, if their statement is based on reasoning, then we must seek another explanation. We suggest that there was a forest of acacia trees next to Mount Sinai. When Israel came to Sinai, Moses told them that they would be spending a long time there. I have already explained49 that there was no cloud over them at this time.50 Each one of them then made a booth. The princes made court-like structures, each one in accordance with his status. They cut the entire forest down, for they were a large nation. They made booths.51 Moses did not speak to them regarding the tabernacle until after the Day of Atonement.52 This is the meaning of with whom was found (Ex. 35:24).53
6. OIL FOR THE LIGHT. Oil needed for the light in accordance with the requirements of the law.54

The wise men of this generation say that ve-liktoret ha-sammim (and for the sweet incense)55 has to be inverted in order to be understood.56 Its meaning is, and the perfumes for the incense.57 Now if this is the case, then why didn’t Scripture say, for the anointing oil spices (ve-le-shemen ha-mischah besamim)?58 Furthermore, Scripture reads, and the spice, and the oil, for the light (ve’et ha-shamen le-ma’or), and for the anointing oil, and for the sweet incense (ve-liktoret hasammim)59 (Ex. 35:28).60 I believe that the word spices (besamim)61 takes in the spices needed for anointing oil and the spices that were mixed with the incense perfumes.62 This is also the true tradition.63
7. ONYX STONES. This includes all the stones of the ephod and the one of the breastplate.64
TO BE SET. I will explain later the meaning of me-lu’im (to be set).65
8. AND LET THEM MAKE ME A SANCTUARY. The tabemacle is called a mikdash (a sanctuary)66 because it is the tabernacle67 of God the holy.68

9. I SHOW THEE. You will see it with your eye. Unlike the visions of Ezekiel,69 which were in prophetic dreams. Scripture adds the emphatic heh and reads ha-mishkan (the tabernacle) after it mentions the term sanctuary.70

[EVEN SO SHALL YE MAKE IT.] A vav is placed in front of the word ken (even so) in the phrase ve-khen ta’asu71 (even so shall ye make it)72 regarding the vessels, for Scripture earlier states, ve-asu li mikdash (And let them make Me a sanctuary) (v. 8).73
10. AND THEY SHALL MAKE. Scripture begins by saying, And they shall make an ark because it had at first said, And let them make Me a sanctuary (v. 8).74

[TWO CUBITS AND A HALF SHALL BE THE LENGTH THEREOF, AND A CUBIT AND A HALF THE BREADTH THEREOF, AND A CUBIT AND A HALF THE HEIGHT THEREOF.] We do not know if these measurements refer to the outside or to the inside of the ark. Now if the reference is to the outside of the ark,75 then the width of the two sides of the ark,76 each of which was covered by gold on the inside and the outside, added up to half a cubit,77 making the size of the tablets a cubit in width and a cubit in length.78 Now if we say that the height of the ark79 was also half a cubit thick, then each tablet was extremely heavy.80 Perhaps81 God gave strength to the hands of Moses, which were “heavy”82 to begin with, so that he was able to bring down a tablet of stone in one hand.83 Now Scripture states, tables that were written on both their sides (Ex. 32:15).84 Perhaps it was so,85 for a tablet is a cube having six sides.86 We similarly find it written87 that there were three arks.88

Its weight raises questions.89 Furthermore, the width of the ark cover90 was a handbreadth91 Additionally, we read in Scripture that the gold which was donated92 came to less than one thousand and four hundred parts of the gold which king David left.93 Observe, the cherubim were made of olive wood.94 The incense altar was also not completely made of gold.95

If we look at it logically, then it appears that the ark was covered with gold for appearance sake96 and that very little gold actually went into the covering.97 Were not the boards, the bars, the table, and the incense altar all covered with gold? Nothing except for the menorah was made entirely of gold. Now once they made an ark out of gold, what need was there for wood?98 The fact that Solomon covered the porch and the house with gold demonstrates how the covering was actually done.99
11. A CROWN OF GOLD. The word zer (crown) comes from the same root as the word zareta (you crowned) in, You crowned my going about and my lying down (Ps. 139:3).100

12. THE FOUR FEET THEREOF. I searched all of Scripture and did not find the word pa’am (foot) used in the sense of corner.101 It is always employed in the sense of a foot. We thus read: Even the feet of the poor, and the steps (pa’ame) of the needy (Is. 26:6); And shall make His footsteps (pe’amav) a way (Ps. 85:14); How beautiful are thy steps (fe’amayikh) (Cant. 7:2). There are many other instances.

I was therefore forced to explain that the ark had feet,102 for it would be disrespectful for the ark to sit on the ground.103 Furthermore, what reason is there for Scripture to place a connective vav before the word u-shete (and two) when dealing with the two rings of gold (v. 12)? If the reference was to the rings already mentioned,104 then Scripture should have read, shete taba’ot (two rings), as that is the proper syntax if the Torah wants to indicate that it is dealing with the four gold rings previously noted.105

One of the wise men of our generation understood this.106 He says that the staves were placed in the ark in the rings that were on its feet. He further says that they would remove the staves from the lower rings and place them in the upper rings when it was necessary to carry the ark. It is similarly written, and shall set the staves thereof (Num. 4:6).107 However, I believe that the staves were never removed once they were placed in the upper rings, for Scripture states, they shall not be taken from it (v. 15). As to And shall set the staves thereof (Num. 4:6), it means that the priests shall place the staves upon the shoulders of the Kohathites.108

When the ark was placed in the Holy of Holies109 it was necessary to place it near the wall110 so that the cherubim111 would cover the ark and its staves.112 The end of each one of the staves therefore113 extended.114 This is what Scripture refers to when it states, And the staves were so long (I Kings 8:8).115 The four lower rings116 thus117 served, as is the case with chests,118 for beauty and elegance.119
15. IN THE RINGS OF THE ARK. In the rings that are on the sides of the ark.120

16. AND THOU SHALT PUT. The tablets and the testimony121 are one and the same.122 They were, as it were, a marriage contract.123 They were the tablets of testimony.124 And he took and put the testimony into the ark (Ex. 40:20) is perfect proof of this.125 Furthermore, Moses did not write the scroll of the Torah.126 The scroll of the Torah was placed by the priests next to the outer side of the ark of the covenant.127 It is additionally written, There was nothing in the ark save the two tables of stone (I Kings 8:9). There is a difference of opinion concerning this.128

One may raise the following question. Scripture reports that God told Moses (v. 16), And thou shalt put into the ark the tables129 which I shall give thee. The Torah then tells us, And He gave unto Moses, when He had made an end of speaking with him…the two tables of the testimony (Ex. 31:18). Now Moses broke these tablets. Moses thus did not fulfill the command of God.130 It is possible to give the following answer. Perhaps this is the reason why our sages said that the broken tablets were placed in the ark.131 Scripture132 does not contradict their words, for both the first and the second tablets were tablets of the covenant.133 It is also possible to answer that Scripture (v. 16) speaks only about the second tablets. The statement which I shall give thee does not contradict this.134 For Scripture also says concerning the second tablets, And the Lord gave them unto me (Deut. 10:4). Furthermore, note that we do not find that God told Moses that he should make an ark and place the first set of tablets there. For God knew that Moses would break them.135 It was only concerning the tablets that Moses hewed136 that God said, and make thee an ark of wood (Deut. 10:1).

Now our sages said that and make thee an ark of wood does not refer to the ark made by Bezalel.137 This is correct. However, if we follow the plain meaning of the text, then it does not appear to me to be far-fetched to interpret the text138 as referring to the ark which Bezalel constructed. Scripture similarly reads, And they shall make an ark of acacia-wood (v. 10).139

There is no reason to ask, where were these tablets placed before the tabernacle was constructed?140 For there is no need to mention this.141 What forced me to offer this explanation142 was the fact that Moses says, and [I] put the tables in the ark which I had made (Deut. 10:5). Now if we assume that Moses relates the account as it happened,143 even though we do not know the reason why he should mention this,144 what shall we do with what follows, namely, as the Lord commanded me (Deut. 10:5).145 This is proof that Scripture speaks of the tablets which Moses placed in the ark of the covenant.146 [Moses tells us that] these tablets are there147 until this very day (Ibid.).148 This is the meaning of and there they are unto this very day (I Kings 8:8).149

This150 is also a sign and a witness that there was no Torah scroll in the ark, for Moses first put the tablets in the ark.151 He then placed the ark cover with the cherubim over the ark. Now God’s glory dwelled upon the cherubim. Scripture explicitly reads, Thou art enthroned upon the cherubim (Ps. 80:2). This being the case, how could Moses place a Torah scroll inside the ark in the fortieth year without first removing the ark cover with the cherubim from on top of the ark?152 There is no need for all of this.153

17. AND THOU SHALT MAKE AN ARK-COVER. The word kapporet means a cover. Yefet says that the word le-khapper (to make atonement) in to make atonement for him (Lev. 1:4) is similar. Its meaning is similar to whose sin is covered154 (Ps. 32:1).155 However, I believe that the word le-khapper (to make atonement for him) (Lev. 1:4) is similar in meaning to the form kofer (ransom). Now this is clearly stated,156 for Scripture states, then shall they give every man a ransom (kofer) for his soul unto the Lord (Ex. 30:12). Scripture then goes on to say, le-khapper al nafshotekhem157 (to make atonement for your souls) (Ex. 30:15).158
Scripture does not mention the thickness of the ark cover.159

18. AND THOU SHALT MAKE TWO CHERUBIM. Our sages said that the cherubim looked like two youths. They said that the kaf in keruvim is a preposition and the word keruvim (cherubim) means the same as the Aramaic word ke-ravia (like youths).160 Now if they had a tradition that the cherubim were youth-like images, then what they said was true. They interpreted the word in a manner that would recall the tradition.161 They did the same with the word chanukkah.162 The kaf in the word keruv (cherub) is a root letter,163 as the word hakeruvim (the cherubim) in And the cherubim shall (v. 20) proves.164 The heh of ha-keruvim indicates the definite article. It is not an interrogative heh165 like the heh in ha-kemakkat (or is he slain) in Or is he slain according to the slaughter of them that were slain by Him (Is. 27:7).166

Now when I searched for the meaning of the word keruvim (cherubim) I found that it refers to various forms. Compare, Thou wast the far-covering cherub (keruv) (Ezek. 28:14).167 Ezekiel said that each one of the beasts which he beheld168 had four faces (Ezek. 1:6). One of these faces was the face of an ox (Ezek. 1:10). However, elsewhere he describes this very creature as having the face of a cherub in place of the face of an ox (Ezek. 10:14). Its meaning169 is that the creature had the image that Ezekiel had mentioned earlier.170 At the end Ezekiel says, This is the living creature that I saw under the God of Israel by the river Chebar; and I knew that they were cherubim (Ezek. 10:20). Ezekiel thus called the four creatures cherubim. The kaf in the word keruvim thus is a root letter.

OF BEATEN WORK. Mikshah (of beaten work) means equal. The word mikshah (the same size) in And instead of hair trimmed to the same size (ma’aseh mikshah) baldness171 (Is. 3:24)is similar. Ma’aseh (trimmed)172 has the same meaning as asah (trimmed) in nor trimmed his beard (II Sam. 19:25).173 Its meaning174 is that each cherub was equally distant from the edge of the ark cover.

19. CHERUB. Observe! The cherubs were positioned175 on the long side of the ark.176 The staves were therefore placed to the width of the ark.177 There is someone who disagrees and says that side refers only to the long side.178 He offers proof from and for the second side of the tabernacle (Ex. 26:20).179 However, and five bars for the boards of the side of the tabernacle (Ex. 26:27), which is right next to the verse that he quotes, destroys his proof.180
The cherubim which were upon the two edges of the ark were made out of the ark cover itself

20. AND THE CHERUBIM SHALL. Yefet says that the meaning of toward the ark-cover shall the faces of the cherubim be means that the cherubim shall face the center of the ark cover. However, I believe that the faces of the cherubim did not stand erect,181 but rather inclined a bit towards the ark cover.182
21. AND IN THE ARK. This is in keeping with Hebrew syntax.183 Moses had already put the testimonies into the ark.184 He was told: afterwards185 place the ark cover [over the ark].186

22. AND THERE I WILL MEET WITH THEE. I do not understand in what way this verse contradicts And the Lord called unto Moses, and spoke unto him out of the tent of meeting, saying (Lev. 1:1).187 For the phrase tent of meeting takes in the tabernacle and everything in it.188 There is no need for a clarifying189 verse.190

[OF ALL THINGS WHICH I WILL GIVE THEE IN COMMANDMENT UNTO THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] The word et191 in and (ve-et) of all things which I will give thee in commandment has a vav placed before it192 for the following reason.193 The word ve-dibbarti (and I will speak) is to be read as if written twice.194 Our verse is to be read as if written: and I will speak with thee from above the ark cover, from between the two cherubim. Scripture does not mention what will be spoken.195 Its meaning is, I will speak with you in order to inform you of My secret and to answer your questions.196 And I will speak to you of all the things which I will give thee in commandment unto the children of Israel.197

We have reason to ask, why did God mention the ark first198 when Scripture reads, the pattern of the tabernacle, and the pattern of all the furniture thereof (v. 9).199 The answer is that it is linguistic style to explain the last item with which one has closed.200 Compare, And I gave unto Isaac Jacob and Esau; and I gave unto Esau mount Seir (Josh. 24:4).201 God therefore began with an explanation of the tabernacle’s furniture.202 God started with the most important piece of furniture203 and then went on to the explain the table and the menorah. After this, God said, Moreover thou shalt make the tabernacle (Ex. 26:1).
Now when Moses gathered the congregation he spoke to them about the tabernacle and the tent first.204 Then he told them about the ark.
There was no need for anyone to teach Moses.205

There is reason to wonder why God didn’t mention the altar of incense.206 The answer by way of parable is:207 God’s glory did not depart [from the tabernacle].208 The ark was therefore in the form of a throne.209 Observe, a menorah and a prepared table [were placed in the sanctuary].210 God did not mention the altar of incense until He first mentioned the altar of the burnt offering, because God wanted to issue the command, You shall offer no…burnt-offering, nor meal-offering; and ye shall pour no drink-offering thereon (Ex. 30:9).211
Moses mentioned the incense altar to the children of Israel following the menorah.212 The incense altar was similarly constructed after the menorah.213
23. AND THOU SHALT MAKE. There is no doubt that the dimensions mentioned in our verse refer to the thickness of the table214 plus the height of its legs.215
25. AND THOU SHALT MAKE. The border was on top216 as is the case with tables.
AND THOU SHALT MAKE A GOLDEN CROWN. Scripture now explains that the crown which was mentioned earlier should be around the borders.
26. AND THOU SHALT MAKE…FOUR RINGS…AND PUT THE RINGS IN THE FOUR CORNERS. East, west, north, and south.217
27. CLOSE BY THE BORDER. Scripture mentions the place where the rings were to be placed.

28. THAT THE TABLE MAY BE BORNE WITH THEM. Venissa (may be borne) is a nifal. Ve-nissa is similar to ve-nikkah (be quit) in then shall he that smote him be quit (Ex. 21:19). For nissa218 and nikkah219 have a dagesh in them to make up for the dropped first root letter.220
29. AND THOU SHALT MAKE. What the rabbis said is known.221

[WHEREWITH TO POUR OUT.] The phrase wherewith to pour out refers to the jars thereof (kesotav).222 It does not relate to and the bowls thereof, which immediately precedes it.223 The following is similar: Moses and Aaron among His priests, And Samuel among them (Ps. 99:6). Scripture then goes on to say, He spoke unto them in the pillar of cloud (Ps. 99:7). The latter refers to Moses and Aaron, not to Samuel.224 The fact that Scripture says with regard to the making of the vessels, the jars thereof (ha-kesot) wherewith to pour out (Ex. 37:16) proves that wherewith to pour out225 refers to the jars thereof. So does and the jars (kesot) wherewith to pour out (Num. 4:7).

The word nasakh (pour) has many meanings. We thus read, They shall not pour out wine-offerings (nesekh) to the Lord (Hos. 9:4);226 The image perchance, which the craftsman hath melted (nasakh) (Is. 40:19); and Truly it is I that have established (nasakhti) My king (Ps. 2:6).227

Rabbi Nathan,228 the author of the Arukh,229 says that kesavot (jars) are rods,230 as that is how they are referred to in Arabic.231 However, the one who told this to him did not know the Arabic language and spoke it laughably. Rods in Arabic are referred to as katzab, which is spelled with a tzadi and a bet.232

There is an error233 in the Book of Chronicles.234 Chronicles mentions basins in place of dishes, bowls in place of pans. It mentions jars as Scripture does here. In place of the bowls it mentions forks.235 They were all made of gold for use at the table. It is possible that David commanded that other utensils be placed upon the tables which Solomon would make.236 However, the table placed in the tabernacle differed.237

30. AND THOU SHALT SET UP UPON THE TABLE SHOWBREAD. According to the plain meaning of the text, the bread was called showbread238 because of the explanation which follows it.239 That which the sages said is also true,240 as the ka’arot (dishes) were molds.241

31. AND THOU SHALT MAKE A CANDLESTICK. I have seen copies of Scripture which the wise men of Tiberias have examined. Behold, I found the word te’aseh (be made) spelled with a yod.242 Fifteen of their wise men243 swore that they checked every word, vowel, full and deficient spelling, three times. I did not find this to be the case with the books of Scripture in Spain, France, and on the other side of the sea.244 Our sages said that the additional yod in te’aseh alludes to the ten245 candlesticks which Solomon would make. Let me generalize. If there is a yod in te’aseh, then te’aseh is irregular.246

The Midrash tells us that the menorah made itself.247 The meaning of this midrash is that all who saw the menorah marveled and asked, “How could a human being make it?”248 Look! Scripture states, and he249 made candlesticks250 and so he made the candlestick (Num. 8:4).251 Behold, Scripture writes, On a griddle it shall be made (te’aseh) with oil;252 when it is soaked, thou shalt bring it in (Lev. 6:14).
Observe, the word miksheh (of beaten work) here has the same meaning as the word miksheh which is written in connection with the cherubim.253
EVEN ITS BASE AND ITS SHAFT. This is the body of the menorah.
32. AND THERE SHALL BE SIX BRANCHES. Kanim (branches)254 refers to a round, long, and hollow object.255

33. THREE CUPS. The Gaon says that meshukkadim (almond blossoms) means in the shape of almonds. However, the word meshukkadim really is related to the word li-shekod (attached)256 in Attached daily at my gates (Prov. 8:34).257
38. PURE GOLD. Refined gold without any impurities.
40. AND SEE. The making of the menorah required wisdom. One had to have intellectual perception258 to know how to make all these utensils259 out of one talent of gold.

[WHICH IS BEING SHOWN.] The word moreh (being shown)260 is irregular.261 It is not employed in the same way that the word mushlakh (be thrown) (II Sam. 20:21) is,262 for the verb ra’ah (saw) does not come in the pa’ul.263 Only the term nireh (seen)264 is employed.265 This is so because one who sees is not acting on anything. He merely perceives an image. Those who are versed in the sciences will understand this.266
I wish to lay down a fundamental principle to you before I speak on the tabernacle, which also267 was made out of curtains [decorated] with cherubim.268

Abraham the author says: All that exists, exists in one of the following two ways. One, it exists as a body that has length, width, and depth. The aforementioned results in six sides. From the length of an object comes front and back, from its width right and left, and from its height269 up and down. There are also incorporeal beings, namely, God’s holy angels and man’s soul.

These two types of beings270 were created by God alone. It is not in the power of any created being to create a corporeal being. It is certainly beyond the power of any being to create an incorporeal being, for incorporeal beings are more important than corporeal beings.271 It is also beyond the power of any created being to totally annihilate another being 272
There is something which comes very close to existence and is tied to existence but does not exist independently.273 This thing is called form.274 Form also comes in two ways.

One type of form is permanent and does not pass away, namely, the form of the holy angels and the wisdom which is in the soul.275 Form is also found in corporeal elements. The heat of fire and the wetness of water are examples.
The accidents276 are the second way in which form manifests itself. The accidents are not permanent. They come and go. They change. They turn and disappear. Man is able to produce accidents.277

It is impossible for the glorious God to have a permanent or unchanging278 image or picture because God created the essence of all things.279 Now, all forms are either permanent or accidents.280 Let me give you one example.281 The moon is eclipsed282 when the earth’s shadow enters between the moon and the sun at the head or tail of the dragon.283 I will give you another example.284 We know that the power of the soul is all over the body. However, there are places in the human body such as the eyes or the nose that are more sensitive than others because of the nerves that go out from the brain. The bones and liver are devoid of sensation. Now the heart is more receptive to the power of the soul than are all other organs of the body. Many organs therefore serve it. Similarly with the glorious God. We know that God’s glory fills the world. However, there are places where God’s power is more manifest than in other places. This is so for the following two reasons.

Divine manifestation varies in accordance with the natural makeup of the recipient and in accordance with the upper power that is above the receiver.285 Therefore, the place of the holy temple [Mount Moriah] was chosen.286

If God will give you wisdom, then you will understand the secret of the ark, the ark covering, and the cherubim which spread their wings.287 You will also understand the secret of the objects which were placed outside of the curtain,288 namely, the menorah, the incense altar, and the table.289 You will also comprehend the secret of the objects placed outside of the opening of the tabernacle, namely, the altar of the burnt offering and its utensils and the basin and its base. These objects served to honor God.

I gave you these hints because there are many people in our generations who think they are wise. Perhaps they will mock my words. He who knows the secret of his soul and the makeup of his body is able to understand the workings of the upper world. This is so because man is a microcosm. Man was the last thing created by God when he created the earth. Let this serve as a sign: He began with the largest290 and finished with the youngest291 (Gen. 44:12).292
Saadiah Gaon notes that there are eighteen objects in the tabernacle which serves as the intermediary world.293 The same number of objects is found in the upper word294 and also in the microcosm.295
Here is a general rule. Each cherub was made to receive power from above. It was also made so that the intelligent will learn.296 There is no need to go on.

31 Which is produced by a worm.
32 Which means a worm.
33 Ezekiel reads, with richly woven work. If not a scribal error, then I.E. quoted from memory and erred.
34 We thus see that shesh comes from Egypt.
35 Izzim literally means goats. Hence I.E.’s comment.
36 Located in Libya (Weiser).
37 In Biblical times. However, we can no longer identify it.

38 That is, the identity of the tachash was known in Ezekiel’s days; otherwise Ezekiel would not have referred to it. I.E. takes issue with the Rabbinic interpretation that the tachash existed only during the time that the tabernacle was constructed. If this was the case, why would Ezekiel refer to it? See Talmud Sabbath 28a. Also see Rashi.
39 See Tanchuma 1:9 and Bereshit Rabba 94:4. Also see Rashi.
40 See note 43.
41 That Israel had acacia wood in their possession. They could have had this wood in their possession only if they had brought it out of Egypt.
42 Which they also brought out of Egypt. See verse 4.

43 According to the rabbis the meaning of with whom was found is, whoever brought out wood for the purpose of erecting the tabernacle. However, if this was its meaning, then Scripture should have read, whoever brought out (acacia wood) (Krinsky). Hence we must interpret with whom was found according to its plain meaning, i.e., whoever happened to have had acacia wood for his personal needs.
44 If we interpret the verse with whom was found as meaning that the acacia wood was used by each individual who brought it out of Egypt for that person’s own use.
45 I.E. assumes that the Israelites had no need for acacia wood. This being the case, why did the Israelites take it out of Egypt with them?

54 In other words, pure olive oil beaten for the light (Ex. 27:20) (Filwarg).

57 In other words, ve-liktoret ha-sammim should be interpreted as if written ve-sammim li-ketoret.

58 Rather than besamim le-shemen ha-mishchah (spices for the anointing oil.) The point is that since ve-liktoret ha-sammim (and for the sweat incense) is out of order, why isn’t the preceding phrase also out of order?
59 Literally, and for the incense of the perfume.
60 Here too oil for the light is in order, and incense of the perfume is not.
61 In the phrase spices for the anointing oil.

62 In other words, our text is to be understood as if written: be-sammim le-shemen ha-mischah u-ve-sammim li-ketoret ha-sammim (spices for the anointing oil and spices for the incense of sweet incense).
63 Received by the sages of the Talmud. According to the rabbis the sweet incense contained spices. See Keritot 6a.
64 The ephod had two onyx stones (Ex. 28:9) and the breastplate one (Ex. 28:20).

65 He never did in his long commentary. However, in his comments on our verse in his short commentary, I.E. quotes three interpretations of the term melu’im, one of them to the effect that the stones covered the front of the choshen.
66 In our verse.
67 Or dwelling place.
68 Scripture tells Moses to construct a mikdash. However, he later refers to the structure as a mishkan. Hence I.E.’s comment.

70 The term ha-mishkan (the tabernacle) refers to the above-noted sanctuary. I.E.’s point is that Scripture does not command the making of a mishkan. It commands the making of a mikdash. Hence I.E. explains why the term ha-mishkan is used.

71 Literally, and so shall ye make. “The expression and so shall ye make it thus refers only to the pattern of all the furniture (mentioned right above), but does not refer to the pattern of the tabernacle, since the term ‘making’ was already stated with reference to it, namely, and let them make me a sanctuary” (Chavel).
72 The context requires “so shall ye do,” that is, ken ta’asu. Our verse adds an extra vav. The vav indicates that the verse is connected to what comes before.
73 In other words, the meaning of ve-khen ta’asu is, and you should similarly make the vessels (Weiser). See Rashi and Nahmanides, who offer different interpretations.

74 Literally, And they shall make Me a sanctuary. In other words, Scripture employs the same term ve-asu for the ark as it did for the sanctuary. It does so because it is the first vessel to be named. With regard to the making of the other articles of furniture, Scripture states, And thou shalt make (see Ex. 25:23,31; Ex. 26:1,31; Ex. 27:1,9. Hence I.E.’s comment. See Shemot Rabbah 33:3.
75 Both the length and width.
76 That is, the two sides making up the width of the ark and the two sides making up the length of the ark.
77 In other words, the half a cubit spoken of in our verse refers to the combined width of any two facing sides of the ark.

78 If the combined width of any two facing sides of the ark came to half a cubit, then the inside of the ark measured one cubit in width and two in length. Each one of the two tablets which filled the inside of the ark was thus a cubit long and a cubit wide.

79 That is, that the combined thickness of the top cover and the bottom of the ark was also a half cubit. I.E. comments thus, for it is possible to interpret and a cubit and a half shall be its height as referring to the ark plus its legs. Indeed, this is the way I.E. interprets this clause in chapter 9 of his Yesod Morah. See note 80.
80 A stone measuring a cubed cubit is very heavy.

81 I.E. uses the term “perhaps” because it is possible that the tablets were not a cubed cubit. See chapter 9 of the Yesod Morah where I.E. says that we do not know the height of the tablets or of the ark. He argues that the height for the ark given in our Torah portion does not relate only to the ark but to the ark plus the legs which he assumes the ark had. I.E. argues thus because he believed that it would be impossible for Moses to hold in his hands tablets of stones which measured a cubed cubit.
82 Tired. See Ex. 17:12 and I.E.’s comment on it.
83 That is, in each one of his hands.
84 I.E. now states his true position, that is, that the tablets were very thin. See note 81.
85 It is possible that the tablets were engraved on only two sides.
86 Hence Scripture points out that the Decalogue was written on only two of its sides.
87 In the Talmud.

88 Yoma 72b. “Bezalel made three arks, two of gold, and one of wood…He placed the ark of wood inside the ark of gold, and the ark of gold inside the ark of wood. He covered its upper rim with gold. It was consequently overlaid within and without with gold.”
89 According to the Bible the ark was carried by four men. I.E. questions the ability of four men to carry a piece of furniture constructed of three arks, two of which were made of solid gold.
90 That is, the ark’s covering.
91 According to Rabbinic opinion. See Sukkah 5a. This too would add to the ark’s weight.

92 By the Israelites for the construction of the tabernacle. See Ex. 38:24: All the gold that was used for the work in all the work of the sanctuary, even the gold of the offering, was twenty and nine talents, and seven hundred and thirty shekels.

93 For Solomon to use in constructing the temple. See I Chron. 22:14: Now, behold…I [David] have prepared for the house of the Lord a hundred thousand talents of gold. I.E. questions whether Moses had enough gold available to construct two arks of gold of the size described in our chapter.

94 The reference is to the cherubim made by Solomon. See I Kings 6:23-28. The point is that Solomon had much more gold available than Moses did. Nevertheless, he made the cherubim out of olive wood overlaid with gold.
95 It was made of wood overlaid with gold. See Ex. 30:1-5. Hence it is possible that the ark was also constructed in this fashion.
96 So that it would look as if it was completely made of gold.
97 Hence the ark was not overly heavy. It should be noted that with the tablets inside, it still was of considerable weight.
98 The wooden ark.

99 So Filwarg. The point is, Solomon could not have thickly covered the walls of the temple with a thick layer of gold. He must have covered it with a very thin layer. We thus see that when one covers wood with gold, one does so very lightly.
100 Translated according to I.E. See I.E. on Ps. 139:3.
101 Onkelos renders, pa’amotav (feet thereof) zivyateh (its corners). So do Rashi and many others. Hence I.E.’s comment.
102 For the meaning of pa’amotav is, its feet.
103 Hence it rested on feet.
104 In the first half of the verse.

105 Verse 12 reads: And thou shalt cast four rings of gold for it, and put them in the four feet thereof (pa’amotov); and two rings (u-shete ta’abotav) shall be on one side of it, and two rings on the other side of it. I.E. argues that and two rings shall be on one side of it, and two rings on the other side of it does not refer to the four rings mentioned in the first part of the clause. If it did, our verse would read: And thou shalt cast four rings of gold for it, and put them in the four feet thereof (pa’amotav): two rings shall be on one side of it, and two rings on the other side of it. There were thus eight rings on the ark. See Nahmonides who quotes I.E.’s interpretation and strongly disagreees with him.
106 That the second part of verse 12 does not elaborate upon the first part.

107 According to this scholar, and shall set the staves thereof indicates that the staves were moved from time to time; i.e., they were placed in the top rings when the ark was about to be carried and were removed from the top rings and placed on the lower rings when the ark rested.
108 Not that the staves were at times placed in the upper rings and at other times in the lower rings. See note 105.
109 Hebrew, devir.
110 Right against the western wall of the sanctuary built by King Solomon (Meijler).
111 That is, the wings of the cherubim.
112 See I Kings 8:7.
113 Since the ark was right against the wall, the staves which normally protruded at that end were pushed out toward the opposite end.
114 Eastward from the ark. Nevertheless, they were not removed from the ark even though they no longer served any purpose.

115 That is, once the ark was placed against the wall, the staves extended for a greater distance than they had before (Meijler). I.E. comments on the staves in Solomon’s temple to show that the staves were never removed from the ark.
116 Which were placed on the feet of the chest.
117 I.E. explained earlier that once the staves were put in the upper rings, they were not removed from them. Hence he now explains that the lower rings only had an ornamental purpose.
118 Expensive chests have ornaments on them.
119 They did not serve as holders for the staves. They served as ornaments.
120 See verse 13. In other words, in the rings of the ark is short for: in the rings that are on the sides of the ark.
121 Hebrew, edut.

122 I.E. comments thus because some identify the testimony with the Torah. See Rashi, “The Testimony refers to the Torah, which is a testimony between Me and you that I have commanded you the commandments that are written in it.”
123 A marriage contract serves as a testimony that a marriage took place.

124 That is why Scripture refers to the tablets as tablets of the covenant. See Deut. 9:9-11. It does so because the tablets recall God’s covenant with Israel. A marriage contract similarly recalls the covenant of marriage.
125 For it was the tablets that were placed in the ark.
126 That is, Moses had not yet written the book of the Torah. He wrote it shortly before his death. Hence the term testimony cannot refer to the Torah.
127 See Deut. 31:26.

128 The tablets placed in the ark. Some rabbis believe that only the second pair of tablets was placed in the ark. Others believe that the first pair of tablets, which Moses broke, was also placed in the ark. See Baba Batra 14b. Also see Rashi on Deut. 31:26.
129 Verse 16 has testimony in place of tablets. I.E. is paraphrasing.
130 The question arises: How could Moses, the servant of God, disobey His command?
131 See Baba Batra 14b.
132 Verse 16 seems to speak of only one set of tablets.
133 Thus verse 16 also refers to the first tablets.
134 For prima facie, this appears to apply only to the first set of tablets.
135 Hence God, who is omniscient, could not have been speaking of the first tablets in verse 16.
136 That is, the second tablets.

137 See Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 8:3; Shekalim 6:5. Also see Rashi on Deut. 10:1. The rabbis took literally and make thee an ark of wood. That is, the ark was to be made only from wood. Hence it could not refer to the ark made by Bezalel, which was overlaid with gold. Bezalel’s ark is the ark dealt with in our chapter.
139 We thus see that Bezalel’s ark is also referred to as a wooden ark.
140 If the ark spoken of in our chapter is identified with the wooden ark spoken of in Deut. 10:1.

141 This information has no consequence. There is no reason for Scripture to explain where the tablets were kept until the tabernacle and its furniture were constructed. We can assume that the tablets were placed in a proper container in a suitable place.
142 That the ark spoken of in Deut 10:1 is to be identified with the ark made by Bezalel.
143 That is, that we interpret Deut. 10:1,5 as meaning that Moses himself made an ark for the tablets and that this ark is not the one that Bezalel made (Krinsky).
144 That Moses made a wooden ark to temporarily store the tablets.
145 The only ark which we find God commanding Moses to make was the ark Bezalel made. Hence the reference must be to Bezalel’s ark.
146 That is, that Scripture speaks of the ark of the covenant made by Bezalel. See note 112.
147 In the ark.
148 That is, they were permanently placed in the ark. The reference can only be to the ark made by Bezalel.
149 That the tablets are in the very first ark in which Moses placed them.
150 And [I] put the tables in the ark which I had made (Deut. 10:5).
152 I.E. assumed that once the ark was closed, Moses would not open it because God’s glory was upon it.
153 If we reject the opinion that a Torah was in the ark.
154 In other words, le-khapper means to cover, i.e., to cover someone’s sins.
155 Translated literally.
156 That le-khapper in le-khapper alav (to make atonement for him) is similar to kofer (ransom).
157 Le-khapper alav is similar to le-khapper al nafshotekhem because both speak of people.
158 According to I.E. this should be rendered, to offer a ransom for your souls.
159 See I.E.’s comment on verse 10 and the notes thereto.
160 Sukkah 55b; Hagigah 13b. See I.E. on Gen. 3:22 and the notes thereto.
161 The point is that the word keruvim does not really mean like youths. However, the sages interpreted the word that way in order to recall their tradition.

162 The rabbis said that the word chanukkah is made up of the words chanu kaf heh [they rested on the 25th (of Kislev)]. This is obviously not the real meaning of the word chanukkah. The rabbis interpreted it that way so that people do not forget that Chanukkah falls on the 25th of Kislev.
163 Not a preposition meaning like.
164 If the kaf of keruvim was a preposition then Scripture would not read ha-keruvim, for the definite article is not prefixed to a preposition.
165 The meaning of ha-keruvim is, the cherubim.

166 I.E. comments thus because it is possible to place an interrogative heh before a prepositional kaf. Thus if the heh of ha-keruvim was an interrogative heh, there would be no proof that the kaf of keruvim is a root letter.
167 That is, a bird with large wings. We thus see that a cherub can refer to a bird-like image.
168 When he saw the vision of the chariot.
169 The meaning of Ezek. 10:14.

170 The face of an ox. In other words, By the face of the cherub (Ezek. 10:14), Ezekiel means it had the already mentioned image, namely, the image mentioned in Ezek. 1:6; i.e., it had the face of an ox. We thus see that the term cherub refers to an image.
171 Translated according to I.E.
173 The word ma’aseh usually means work of. Hence I.E.’s comment.
174 The meaning of mikshah ta’aseh otam (of beaten work shalt thou make them).
175 In their face-to-face position.
176 Scripture tells us that the cherubim were placed at the two ends of the ark cover. According to I.E. the term end implies the long end (Meijler).

177 The Book of Kings tells us, And the staves were so long that the ends of the staves were seen from the holy place, even before the Sanctuary (I Kings 8:8). This could only have happened if the staves were placed along the width of the ark. For the long side of the ark was placed in a north-south direction in the sanctuary (so that both cherubim would face the Holy of Holies) while the curtain that separated the temple proper from the sanctuary was on the eastern wall of the sanctuary (Meijler).
178 Scripture tells us that the staves were on the side of the ark (v. 12). Hence according to this scholar the staves, contra I.E., could not have been placed along the width of the ark.
179 The verse speaks of the length of the tabernacle.
180 For this verse speaks of the width of the tabernacle.
181 Prima facie, With their faces one to another implies that the cherubim directly faced each other.

182 In other words, toward the ark-cover shall the faces of the cherubim be does not mean that the cherubim shall face straight down to the ark cover as Yefet says. It means that the faces of the cherubim shall incline toward the ark cover.
183 To list first what comes last, for the tablets were placed in the ark before the cover was put on it. However, our verse tells of the latter before it tells of the former.
184 Before he put the ark cover over the ark.
185 After you place the testimonies in the ark.
186 In other words, our verse is to be understood as follows: And thou shalt put the ark cover over the ark; but before this, in the ark thou shalt put the testimonies which I shall give you.

187 According to Rashi our verse contradicts Lev. 1:1. See Rashi on verse 22: “[Scripture states] And I will speak with thee from above the ark-cover (Ex. 25:22). However, another verse reads, and spoke unto him out of the tent of meeting, (that is, the tabernacle outside of the curtain) saying (Lev. 1:1). We thus find two verses contradicting each other. A third verse comes and reconciles them; viz., And when Moses went into the tent of meeting…then he heard the Voice speaking unto him from above the ark-cover (Num. 7:29). Moses entered the tabernacle and when he came to the entrance a Voice descended from heaven toward (the place) between the cherubim, and from thence it went forth and was heard by Moses in the tent of meeting.”
188 Hence it also refers to the Holy of Holies where the ark was.
189 Or reconciling.
190 See note 184.
191 The word et has no translatable meaning. It serves to connect a verb with the direct object. In this case, it connects ve-dibbarti (and I will speak) with what follows et.
192 Our versions of the Torah do not have a vav before the word et. We might also note that Rashi’s Torah scrolls also read ve-et. Rashi considered this vav superfluous.

193 Without the vav our verse reads: and I will speak with thee from above the ark-cover, from between the two cherubim which are upon the ark of the testimony, of all things which I will give thee in commandment unto the children of Israel. With the vav, our verse reads: and I will speak with thee from above the ark-cover, from between the two cherubim which are upon the ark of testimony, and of all things which I will give thee in commandment unto the children of Israel. Hence I.E.’s comment.

194 I.E.’s point is that our verse is to be read as follows: and I will speak with thee from above the ark-cover, from between the two cherubim which are upon the ark of testimony, and I will further speak to you of all things which I will give thee in commandment unto the children of Israel.

195 In other words, part 2 of the verse does not tell us what part 1 of the verse refers to. This would not be the case if the word et did not have a vav before it. In the latter case, part 2 of the verse would go on to explain what God spoke to Moses about.
196 In other words, part 1 deals with a private dialogue between God and Moses.
197 In other words, part 1 deals with a private dialogue between God and Moses. Part 2 deals with the commandment which Moses was to transmit to Israel. Hence the connective vav.
198 That is, why is the ark the first sacred item which Moses was commanded to make?
199 The tabernacle is mentioned first. Thus God should have told Moses to first construct a tabernacle and then to make the furniture which was to be placed therein.
200 A sentence.

201 Scripture mentions Jacob before Esau. We would thus expect for Scripture to deal with Jacob before Esau. However, it goes on to deal with Esau. We thus see that Scripture elaborates first on what it dealt with last.
202 Because that is what is mentioned last in verse 9.
203 The ark.
205 As to how to construct the tabernacle. Krinsky claims that the reference is to the Midrash, which says that Bezalel took issue with Moses over what order to follow in constructing the tabernacle.
206 In our Torah portion. It is mentioned in Ex. 35:15. However, it should also have been mentioned here along with the other furniture that was placed inside the tabernacle.

207 I.E.’s point is that the tabernacle may be compared to a king’s palace. Indeed, Scripture states that the tabernacle served as a dwelling place for God, let them make Me a sanctuary, that I may dwell among them (v. 8). Hence it had to be suitably furnished.
208 In other words, the tabernacle served, as it were, as God’s dwelling place.
209 For God, who dwelt there.

210 They served to furnish God’s house. A table and a lamp were the typical furnishings of a house. See II Kings 4:10, “Let us make…a little chamber on the roof; and let us set…there…a table…and a candlestick.”.

211 He couldn’t issue this command without first dealing with burnt offerings, meal offerings, or drink offerings. These offerings were brought to the altar which stood in the courtyard of the tabernacle. Hence Scripture delayed the command to make an incense altar.

212 When he relayed God’s command to Israel regarding the construction of the tabernacle. For the incense altar was stationed in the same section of the tabernacle as the menorah, namely, in the Holy of Holies. See Ex. 35:15.
214 That is, the table top.
215 The cubit and a half given as the height of the table included the legs as well as the table itself.
216 On the table top.
217 That is, on the east, west, north, and south corners of the table.
218 The root of which is nun, sin, alef.
219 The root of which is nun, kof, heh.
220 For the nuns in nissa and nikkah are nuns of the nifal conjugation.

221 The rabbis (Menachot 97a) said that “ke’arotav (its dishes) are the molds; kapotav (its pans) are dishes (of frankincense); kesotav (its jars) the props; menakki’otav (its bowls) the rods; asher yussakh ba-hen (wherewith to pour) wherewith the bread was covered.” Also see Rashi. Contra to what Krinsky, Meijler, and others write, it appears that I.E. does not accept the Rabbinic interpretation. In fact, in the short commentary he renders kesotav as cups (kosot).
222 According to I.E., kesavot are jars used in pouring.
223 For they were not used for pouring.
224 For God did not speak to Samuel in the pillar of cloud. We thus see that a clause does not always refer to what immediately precedes it.
225 In our verse.
226 The Hebrew text literally reads: They shall not pour out wine (yayyin) to the Lord. I.E. either paraphrased or quoted from memory and erred.

227 I.E. comments thus because of the word yussakh (pour out) in our verse. Yussakh is the pu’al form of nasakh. It is noteworthy that none of the meanings that I.E. quotes for this word fit in with the Rabbinic interpretation of yussakh. As it will be recalled, the rabbis interpreted yussakh to mean was covered. See note 221.
228 Rabbi Ben Yehiel of Rome (c. 1035-1106). This comment is not found in our editions of the Arukh.
229 A dictionary of the Talmud and Midrashim.

230 See Rashi. According to Rashi the kesavot (jars) were “semitubular-shaped rods placed three in a row upon each of the twelve loaves of showbread, so as to separate one from the other and allow air to pass through them to save them from becoming moldy” (Cohen).
231 Similarly Rashi: “In the Arabic language anything hollow is called kaso.”
232 Whereas kasvah, the singular of kesavot, is spelled kof, sin, vav, heh.

233 Many commentaries were bothered by the use of the term shibbush (error). Filwarg would like to emend to shinu (a difference). However, he has no manuscript evidence to back up his emendation. S.Y. Rapaport does not believe that I.E. would have uttered such a word. In keeping with his theory that the long commentary was composed by students of I.E. from notes taken at their master’s lectures, he claims that the students misunderstood what I.E. said (See Toledot Rabbenu Natan, S.Y. Rapaport, p. 30). Unlike Filwarg and Rapaport, Nahmanides had no doubts that I.E. uttered these words. He comments, “Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote: ‘There is an error in Chronicles…’ The error, however, is in Rabbi Abraham’s words (not in the Book of Chronicles)” (Chavel translation). Nahmanides goes on to say that I Chron 28:17 does not speak only of the utensils made for the table but also of other utensils made for the altar. It should be noted that I.E. goes on to reconcile I Chron. 28:17 and our verse. However, Nahmanides did not accept his interpretation.
234 The list of utensils made for the table as recorded in I Chron. 28:17 does not match the list in our verse.
235 I Chron. 28:17 reads, “And the fleshhooks (forks), and the basins, and the jars of pure gold and…the golden bowls.”
236 The Book of Chronicles tells us that Solomon made 10 tables (II Chron. 4:8). I.E. suggests that these tables had different utensils than the table made by Moses.

237 It had different utensils. It is also possible that I.E. was of the opinion that the construction of the table placed in the tabernacle differed from the ones made by Solomon. Hence, its utensils differed.
238 Lekhem ha-panim.

239 Scripture goes on to say that the showbread (lekhem ha-panim) before Me alway. According to I.E. this indicates that lekhem ha-panim means bread that is placed before [God]. In other words, according to I.E., the word panim is similar to the word li-fene.

240 According to the sages the bread was called lekhem ha-panim (literally, bread of faces) because it was baked in a mold with the two sides open. Hence the bread was said to have two faces or surfaces directed to the two sides of the sanctuary (Cohen). See Menachot 94b and Soncino’s notes there. Also see Rashi on verses 29 and 30.
241 In which the showbread was made. See note 195. Also see Menachot 94a and Rashi on verse 29.
242 In the Tiberian copies of the Torah. It is also so spelled in our versions.

243 Tiberian scholars. The scholars of Tiberias were known for their work in preserving the text of Scripture (massorah). The Ben Asher and Ben Naphtali families were active there. In fact, Maimonides recommended the Torah Scroll written by Aaron ben Asher in 930 C.E. as a model for all Torah scrolls.
244 England (Weiser).
245 Yod is numerically equivalent to 10.
246 For the word te’aseh is normally spelled without a yod.
247 Tanchuma, Shemini 8; Be-halotekha 3. Also see Rashi.
248 In other words, people said that a work of art like the menorah had to be a supernatural creation.
249 Bezalel.
250 The reference is probably to Ex. 37:17. However, there the reading is: And he made the candlestick. Either I.E. misquoted from memory or we have a scribal error.
251 We thus see that the menorah was made by Moses.
252 We thus see that te’aseh does not imply made by itself. No one can interpret Lev. 6:14 as meaning that the meal offering made itself.
253 See I.E. on verse 18.
254 Literally, reeds. Hence I.E.’s comments.
255 That is, a tube.
256 Cohen. The three cups were attached to each other.
257 Translated according to I.E.
258 Hence the phrase And see.
259 The menorah and its accoutrements.
260 Moreh is a hofal.
