261 It is not employed in the way that a hofal normally is, for nothing happens to the person to whom an object is shown. Hence Scripture should have read ro’eh ba-har, rather than morah ba-har. This is Krinsky’s interpretation. For another interpretation see Weiser.
262 II Sam. 20:21 reads, Behold, his head (rosho) shall be thrown (mushlakh) to thee over the wall. In this verse mushlakh refers to the object being thrown, viz., his head.
263 The pa’ul is the passive kal form. All kal transitive verbs come in the pa’ul, i.e., katav/katuv, akhal/akhul, shavar/shavur. However, ra’ah does not have a pa’ul form.
264 The nifal participle form. According to I.E. the word nireh does not imply that anything is happening to the object being seen, whereas the pa’ul form does.
265 However, the pa’ul is not employed.
266 That the eye is merely a receptor.
267 In addition to the ark.
268 See Ex. 26:1. I.E.’s point is that the tabernacle, like the ark, was adorned with cherubim.
269 Referred to earlier by I.E.
270 Corporeal and incorporeal beings.
271 Hence if it is beyond the power of any created being to create a corporeal being, it is certainly beyond its power to create an incorporeal being.
272 One can destroy a physical object but one cannot annihilate the matter out of which it is made.

273 According to medieval philosophy, ideas and concepts have a life of their own. Thus wet, hot, hard, soft exist as entities in themselves even though in the physical world they are never found isolated from some corporeal element.

274 “The intelligible structure, characters constituting a substance or species of substances, as distinguished from the matter in which these characters are embodied” (Dictionary of Philosophy, ed. by Dagobert D. Runes, Littlefield, Adams and Co., 1959).
275 As noted above, medieval philosophy taught that ideas have a disembodied existence.

276 Accident “has no independent and self-sufficient existence, but exists only in another being, a substance or another accident. Accidents may change, disappear or be added, while substance remains the same” D. Runes, (Dictionary of Philosophy).

277 To create and to do things which are “accidents.” For example, wood is a substance. Man cannot create wood. However, man can make a table. A table is an accident. The form of the wood is the wood’s essence, that is, the properties that make wood.
278 As those who believe in God’s corporeality conceive him.
279 It is thus illogical to assume that God has the form of any of his creatures (Weiser).
280 Hence God cannot have any form.
281 By which we can understand the significance of the tabernacle. For other interpretations see Krinsky and Netter.

282 The moon receives its light from the sun. However, there are places where it does not receive the sun’s light. There are similarly places on earth where God’s power is more manifest than in others.
283 The point at which the orbit of the sun and moon intersect (Meijler).
284 The role of the tabernacle. See note 281.

285 Some people and some places on earth are created in such a way that they are more open to God’s revelation than other people or places are. See I.E. on Gen. 28:16. This is also the opinion of Rabbi Judah ha-Levi. See Book II of the Kuzari.
286 Because it is under God’s special presence and open to it.

287 The ark and the cherubim which were placed in the Holy of Holies represent God’s throne (Meijler). It is also possible that I.E. believed that the ark was constructed in such a way that it drew power from above and thus served to channel God’s word to Moses. See I.E. on Ex. 31:18.
288 In the tabernacle proper.

289 They served, as it were, as furniture in God’s house (Meijler). It is also possible that I.E. held that in some mystical way they provided the physical conditions which made divine manifestation possible. See end of I.E.’s comment.
290 The macrocosm.
291 The microcosm. God first created the universe. He created man last of all. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 and the notes thereto.
292 Translated according to I.E.
293 The world of the spheres. This world mediates between man and the upper world. This is precisely what the tabernacle did. See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 and the notes thereto.
294 The world of the angels. See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 and the notes thereto.
295 In man.
296 Man can develop his soul and receive intellectual power from on high (Krinsky).

chapter.title: CHAPTER 26
chapter.p: 1. MOREOVER THOU SHALT MAKE THE TABERNACLE. As you were first told, namely, the pattern of the tabernacle (Ex. 25:9).1

THE WORK OF THE SKILLFUL WORKMAN. Our sages said that ma’aseh choshev (the work of the skillful workman) refers to two faces, and [ma’aseh] rokem (the work of the weaver) (v. 36)2 to one image. What they said is correct. However, according to the plain meaning of the text, ma’aseh choshev is neither needle-work nor weaving.3 It refers rather to a process employed today in making silk garments. The image that arises in the heart comes from insight and thought.4 The artist draws it upon a tablet. He then places two threads upon the image which he thought up in order to draw it from a distance.5

2. THE LENGTH. The uninformed say that the curtains were twenty-eight cubits in length because of the twenty-eight stages6 of the moon. However, actually there were ten curtains over the tabernacle to correspond with Who stretchest out the heavens like a curtain (Ps. 104:2).7 The place of the Holy of Holies therefore was a cube in measure.8

3. COUPLED. Choverot (coupled) is an adjective.9 On the other hand, it might be a verb10 meaning that this curtain coupled the other curtain. Ephraim is joined (chavur) to idols (Hos. 4:17), wherein chavur is a pu’al,11 is proof of the aforementioned.12

4. LOOPS. Some say that the word u-ve-lullim (and by winding stairs) in and they went up by winding stairs into the middle row (I Kings 6:8) is similar to the word lule’ot (loops),13 for the bet in u-ve-lullim is a preposition.14
THAT IS OUTMOST. The word ha-kitzonah (that is outmost) is an adjective like the word ha-elyonah15 (that is uppermost).
5. FIFTY. Scripture now mentions the number of loops.

[OPPOSITE.] The word makbilot (opposite) means this one was opposite the other.16 There are those who say that the word koval (before)17 in and smote him before the people (II Kings 15:10) and kavolo (opposite it) in and shall strike that which is opposite it (Ezek. 26:9)18 are similar.
[ONE.] The word ishah (one)19 means the very thing.20 The same is true with the word ish (man). Scripture therefore reads, ve-ha-ish gavri’el (the man Gabriel) (Dan. 9:21).21
6. AND THOU SHALT MAKE FIFTY CLASPS22 OF GOLD. The word kores (stoopeth) in Bel boweth down, Nebo stoopeth (Is. 46:1) is similar.23

[THAT THE TABERNACLE MAY BE ONE WHOLE.] Look, the term tabernacle refers to the ten curtains. The tabernacle is called one, and it encompass all ten [curtains] for all physical entities are made of various elements. Similarly God the revered, who is One. God includes everything and is called One.24 The same is true with the microcosm25 and the macrocosm.26
7. AND THOU SHALT MAKE CURTAINS OF GOATS’ HAIR FOR A TENT. Le-ohel (for a tent)27 means to serve as a tent.
[THEM.] The word otam (them) is there for purposes of additional explanation,28 as it refers to the curtains of goats’ hair.29

8. THE LENGTH OF EACH CURTAIN. The word achat (each) is irregular. The word should have read achedet,30 for the dalet is not a letter that serves as a prefix or a suffix.31 However, the dalet was dropped because it is very hard to sound a dalet and a tav, both of which are dentals, back to back. It32 was dropped for the same reason that the tav in meshasrat33 (ministered) in ministered unto the king (II Kings 1:15) was dropped.
9. FIVE. The word chamesh (five) is vocalized with a sheva34 and a pattach.35 It is an abridged form,36 like the word shelosh37 (three) in shelosh se’im (three measures) (Gen. 18:6).38

[AND SHALT DOUBLE OVER THE SIXTH CURTAIN IN THE FOREFRONT OF THE TENT.] Observe, when the sixth curtain was doubled,39 half of a curtain40 was left at the end.41 Hence Scripture states, the half curtain that remaineth over (v. 12). There is no need42 to mention that the length of the curtains was placed over the width of the tabernacle. Now the width of the tabernacle was ten cubits, and the height of its two sides was nine cubits.43 Scripture therefore states, And the cubit on the one side (v. 13) to cover the tabernacle.44

10. AND THOU SHALT MAKE FIFTY LOOPS. The number of loops on the curtains of the tent45 was the same as the number of loops of the tabernacle.46 The same applies to the clasps.47 However, the loops and the clasps of the tent48 were not opposite the loops and the clasps of the tabernacle.49 On the contrary, they were two cubits behind them towards the west.50

11. AND THOU SHALT MAKE. The clasps of the curtains which made up the tabernacle51 were made of gold because they were used for the most important curtains. The tent served as a cover over the tabernacle. Its clasps were therefore made of brass.52 The brass clasps were not visible because there were two covers over the tent.53

12. AND AS FOR THE OVERHANGING PART…THE HALF CURTAIN. The term half is sometimes used in the sense of close to a half, as in and the half-tribe of Manasseh (Josh. 22:9). When we come to the description of the boards you will understand that which requires explanation.54
13. AND THE CUBIT…WHICH REMAINETH OVER. The word ba-odef55 (which remaineth over) is like the word oved (perishing). It is an adjective,56 as the cantillical note is placed on the last syllable.57
14. AND THOU SHALT MAKE A COVERING. Over the covering58 because of the rain.59

15. AND THOU SHALT MAKE THE BOARDS FOR THE TABERNACLE. The term tabernacle only applies to the curtains60 and the boards.61 As God informed Moses of the tabernacle,62 so did He inform him of the boards.63

[STANDING UP.] The word omedim means standing up as it grew on the tree,64 for the length of the wood65 is its height.66 The same applies to a person when he stands. The opposite is the case when he lies down.67 On the other hand, the word omedim might mean standing straight up.68

16. TEN CUBITS. We do not know whether the cubits of the tabernacle were measured from the armpits69 like Ezekiel’s cubits.70 Logically, the cubits of the first temple were of such cubits,71 as we find that the Book Of Chronicles72 speaks of the earlier73 measure.74
17. TWO TENONS. The word yadot (tenons) comes from the same root as yad (hands).
JOINED. The word meshullavot (joined) has no cognate except for the word ha-shelabbim (the stays) (I Kings 7:29).

18. AND THOU SHALT MAKE. Observe! Scripture does not record the thickness of the boards. The ancients75 said that each board was a cubit thick. If this is the case76 then the southern wall, which was thirty cubits, [was a cubit thick]. This was also the case with the northern wall.77 Thus a space measuring eight cubits in width78 was left for the western wall.79 However, eight boards80 had to be placed there.81

It is possible that the ancients were compelled to say that the boards were a cubit thick. They were compelled to say that the boards were a cubit thick because of the middle bar82 which was inserted into the boards.83

According to Rabbi Solomon84 the bar could only lay there by a miracle.85 According to the plain meaning of the text there were three middle bars.86 Scripture similarly writes, from end to end (v. 28).87 It does not state88 from end89 to the ends.90

Now if the sages received a tradition that the boards were a cubit in thickness, then we will accept their tradition. However, if they arrived at this measurement by reasoning, then we can explain it differently. The two bars, namely, the upper two bars, and likewise the two lower bars,91 reached half of the wall.92 The middle bar that was placed in the midst (be-tokh) of the boards (v. 28) passed through from end to end.93 To work it in the midst (be-tokh) of the blue, and in the midst of the purple94 (Ex. 39:3) is similar,95 as is and put the bells in the midst (be-tokh) of the pomegranates96 (Ex. 39:25). The middle bars would not have been covered with gold97 if they were not placed on the surface of the boards.98

If we admit that we do not know the thickness of each board, then we can explain the structure of the western wall. Now, they first set up the western wall. For two boards were set aside to serve as corners99 of the tabernacle,100 as the meaning of mekutzot101 is corners. The same was true of half of the corners of the courtyard,102 for the courtyard103 was in the form of a parallelogram.

We thus have two corners. Now these two corner boards were not the same size as the other boards mentioned in Scripture.104 Scripture therefore separates these boards105 and says, thus shall it be for them both (v. 24), that is, only for them and not for any of the other boards. The tabernacle was erected by utilizing these two boards. The remaining six boards106 were placed in the middle.107 The width of the tabernacle was thus ten cubits.108
We do not know if the corner boards were square or round,109 for we have only one remaining cubit.110
According to Rabbi Solomon’s explanation, these boards did not stand in a straight line111 because half a cubit was inside the tabernacle.112 We are dealing with boards, not with garments.113

They then114 set up the boards on the northern and southern sides. Now an amount equivalent to the thickness of the boards115 protruded116 from the tabernacle.117 The pillar118 of the opening of the tabernacle was therefore opposite it.119 The half a curtain of goatskin120 fixed it.121

30. AND THOU SHALT REAR UP THE TABERNACLE. Moses should tell this to the wise-hearted.122 Or, Scripture states, And thou shalt rear up the tabernacle because Moses reared it up first.123 However, there were others with him,124 for many people were required to rear up the tabernacle.

31. AND THOU SHALT MAKE A VEIL. We find that Solomon acted similarly with regard to the opening of the Holy of Holies.125 The wall126 was possibly made out of wood.127 Scripture notes that the entire house128 measured sixty cubits,129 and Rashi,130 of blessed memory, explains the Holy measured forty cubits and the Holy of Holies twenty cubits.131
The sockets132 were made of silver133 out of respect for the ark.

The Holy of Holies in the temple was double that of the one in the tabernacle in length, width, and height.134 Do not be astonished that Scripture writes135 that the temple was thirty cubits in height and the Holy of Holies took up a third of the temple.136 For there were upper stories directly above the ark cover that is over the Holy of Holies.137 The Book of Chronicles tells us, And he overlaid the upper chambers with gold (II Chron. 3:9).

33. AND THE VEIL SHALL DIVIDE UNTO YOU. The word ve-hivdilah (shall divide) is irregular in that it is ultimately accented.138 The same is true of the word ve-hikkita (and thou shalt smite) in and thou shalt smite the rock (Ex. 17:6).139
36. AND THOU SHALT MAKE A SCREEN…THE WORK OF THE WEAVER. Ma’aseh rokem (the work of the weaver)140 is inferior to ma’aseh chosev (the work of the skillful workman).141
The pillars142 were covered with gold and the hooks were likewise covered with gold of respect for God. The sockets of the pillars were made out of brass because the screen was in between.143
chapter.ftnote: 1 Moses was told to make the tabernacle according to the pattern which he had been shown earlier. I.E. comments thus because Scripture reads, ha-mishkan (the tabernacle), i.e., the earlier-noted tabernacle, rather than tabernacle (Krinsky).

2 See Yoma 72:b: “It was taught in the name of Rabbi Nehemiah rokem (weaving) is needlework, therefore it has only one face. Choshev is weaving work, therefore it has two faces.” According to Rashi, one face means the same image on both sides of the curtain. Two faces means a different image on each side of the curtain, e.g., “a lion on one side, and an eagle on the other side.” Also see Rashi on Yoma 72b.
3 According to I.E. needlework or weaving did not entail artistic skill. Hence it could not be considered ma’aseh choshev, which literally means the work of an artist.
4 Literally, and its thought. Hebrew, machashvtah (and its thought). Meijler suggests emending to machashavah.

5 It isn’t clear what I.E. had in mind. Meijler suggests that some words might be missing from our texts. Rabbi Isaac Sarim (Be’er Yitzchak, Israel, 1991) comments, “I was not worthy to understand his (I.E.’s) holy words. One has to be an expert silk worker to understand his words.” According to Weiser, I.E. is describing the transfer of an image from a wooden tablet to silk. This is done by holding the tablet over the silk by two threads (or chords) and then dropping it, thus imprinting it upon the screen.

6 Literally, camps. The moon has a slightly different appearance each night of the month. According to Meijler, I.E. rejected this opinion because the curtains were 28 cubits in length merely in order to cover the width of the tabernacle and its sideboards down to the sockets.
7 In other words, the ten curtains of the tabernacle corresponded to the heavens which contain the ten spheres. The tabernacle was, as it were, God’s dwelling place. See I.E. on Ex. 25:40.
8 The Holy of Holies was 10 cubits wide, 10 cubits in length, and 10 cubits height. These measurements corresponded to the ten spheres.
9 Literally, is in the form of an adjective. If choverot is an adjective, then our verse reads: five curtains coupled together, one to another.
10 Literally, it has the form of a verb. If choverot is a verb, then our verse should be translated: five curtains coupling one another.
11 The third person perfect passive form of chover.
12 That choveret is a verb. If a verb is found in the passive, it must have an active counterpart. It should be noted that choveret is the feminine form of chover.
13 In our verse.
14 Thus the basic word in Kings is lullim. Lullim is masculine plural. Lule’ot is its feminine counterpart.
15 II Kings 18:17; Is. 7:3.
16 So Weiser and Krinsky. However, Filwarg renders: each loop was ready to receive (le-kabbel) the other loop.
17 Or opposite.
18 Translated literally. The reference is to a battering ram.
19 Literally, a women. Hence I.E.’s comment.
20 For an explanation of this comment see I.E. on Gen. 15:10 and the notes thereto. Also see I.E. on Ex. 15:3.
21 The meaning of which, according to I.E., is the being Gabriel, as Gabriel is not a man.
22 Hebrew, karse.
23 Its meaning is: Nebo shall be bent like a clasp (Filwarg).
24 This is a very difficult comment: it borders on pantheism. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 and the notes thereto. Cohen paraphrases, “God is One but comprehends all.”
25 Man. We speak of one man. However, a man is made up of many parts.
26 We speak of one vast world. However, the world is made up of various parts.
27 Literally, to tent. Hence I.E.’s comment.
28 The word them in eleven curtains shalt thou make them appears to be unnecessary.
29 Scripture tells us that the eleven curtains mentioned in the second part of the verse refer to the curtains of goat’s hair mentioned in the first part of the verse.
30 The Hebrew word for one is echad. The feminine form thus should be achedet.
31 Which drops out when not needed. On the contrary, it is a root letter. Hence it should not fall out.
32 The dalet in achedet.
33 According to the rules of Hebrew grammar the Bible should have used the word mesharetet.
34 That is, with a chataf pattach.
35 That is, a tzere. I.E.’s point is that the word chamesh is in the construct.

36 Our verse should have read, chamesh ha-yeri’ot, (vocalized with a kamatz beneath the chet), rather than chamesh (vocalized with a chataf pattach beneath the chet) ha-yeri’ot, for the construct indicates possession. Thus chayyat ha-sadeh (animals of the field) is short for chayyot shel hasadeh (animals of the field). However, since a number cannot be possessed, it is incorrect to say chamesh shel ha-yeri’ot. Thus chamesh ha-yeriyot is not short for chamesh shel ha-yeri’ot. Hence is not a true construct form. It is merely a quicker way of saying chamesh (vocalized with a kamatz beneath the chet) ha-yeri’ot.
37 Shelosh is in the construct with se’im.

38 Here too, for the reason given in note 37, the text should have read, shelosh (vocalized with a kamatz beneath the shin) ha-se’im rather than shelosh (vocalized with a sheva beneath the shin) se’im.
39 Over the front of the tabernacle.
40 Literally, half of it. The reference obviously cannot be to the front curtain. It must be to the last curtain.

41 Of the tabernacle. There were 11 curtains. Each curtain was 4 cubits in width, making a total of 44 cubits when the curtains were joined. The tabernacle was 30 cubits in length. Its back (the western side of the tabernacle) was 10 cubits in height. When the joined curtain was placed over the length of the tabernacle, 10 cubits covered the back of the tabernacle, 20 covered the top of the tabernacle, and 2 cubits extended over the front of the tabernacle. There were thus 2 cubits remaining. These trailed behind the back of the tabernacle.
42 For Scripture.

43 The curtains were 28 cubits long. The width of the tabernacle was 10 cubits. The side boards of the tabernacle were 10 cubits in height. However, only 9 cubits were exposed because one cubit was covered by the sockets. It stands to reason that the length of curtains was placed over the width of the tabernacle to cover its sides and top.
44 A curtain made of goats’ hair was placed over the first set of curtains. This curtain was 30 cubits long. Verse 13 tells us that the 2 extra cubits served to cover the exposed sockets.
45 That is, the curtains made of goats’ hair. These curtains served as a tent over the tabernacle. See verse 12.
46 The first set of curtains made from woven fabric. According to I.E. the term tabernacle (mishkan) refers to these curtains. See I.E. on verses 6 and 15.
47 There was an equal number of clasps on the curtains made of fabric (the tabernacle) and on the curtain made from goats’ hair.
48 The curtain made of goats’ hair.
49 That is, the fabric curtains.
50 For there were 11 curtains of goats’ hair and ten of woven fabric.
51 See I.E.’s comment on verse 6.
52 For the tent was inferior to the tabernacle.
53 See verse 14.
54 Namely, the meaning of the half curtain that remaineth over shall hang over the back of the tabernacle.
55 That is, odef, for the bet in ba-odef, is a preposition.
56 With the noun which it describes implied; that is, ba-odef should be understood as if written, ba-odef ha-yeri’ah (in the remaining curtain).
57 If odef were a noun, the accent would be on the first syllable and the dalet would be vocalized with a segol.
58 Of the curtains made of goats’ hair.
59 To protect the lower curtains from the rain.
60 The woven curtains. See above verse 6.
61 Hence when God said, the pattern of the tabernacle (Ex. 25:9), the boards were included.
63 Hence Scripture reads, ha-kerashim (the boards), that is, the boards previously alluded to in the word mishkan.

64 The wood is to be in the same position as it was when it grew as part of a tree. In other words, it is to be placed in a vertical position. Cf. Rashi, “The length of their boards shall stand vertically in the walls of the tabernacle. You shall not make the walls out of lying boards so that the width of the boards constitutes the height of the walls.”
65 Spoken of in the next verse.
66 Hence Scripture states, shall stand up.

67 When a person lies down, his length is not in a vertical position. The same applies to a board. I.E.’s point is that omedim (standing) means that the long side of the board is to be placed in a vertical position.
68 Standing perfectly straight up (Sarim).

69 Hebrew, atzilah (where the arm joins the shoulder) (Krinsky). An alternate interpretation is: we do not know whether the cubits of the tabernacle’s “noble cubits” are like Ezekiel’s cubits. A “noble cubit” is a cubit that is larger then the ordinary cubit (Krinsky).
70 Ezek. 41:8. The cubits mentioned in Ezek. 41:8 measured from the armpit to the finger tips (Krinsky). Ordinary cubits measure from the elbow to the fingertips.

71 Prima facie, it appears that I.E. means that they were the same type of cubits as those spoken of by Ezekiel. However, this cannot be so because I.E. goes on to quote II Chron. 3:3 to the effect that the earlier cubits, i.e., the smaller cubits, were employed in the temple. We must thus interpret “of such cubits” as referring to the cubits of the tabernacle. See Sarim. For alternate interpretations see Meijler and Krinsky.
72 II Chron. 3:3.

73 So Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed editions have middah acharonah (the later measure). This appears to be an error, for II Chron. 3:3 explicitly reads, ba-middah ha-risonah (the earlier or the ancient measure). The earlier measure refers to the measure employed in the tabernacle. It is possible that the reading of the later measure occurred because of the problem pointed out in note 70. On the other hand, it is possible that I.E. quoted from memory and erred, and that the printed texts rather than Vat. Ebr. 38 preserve the original reading. In this case, “were of such cubits” refers to Ezekiel’s cubits.
74 When it describes the first temple.
75 The rabbis of the Talmud. See Sabbath 98b.

76 Krinsky quotes an opinion which suggests this emendation: “If this is the case, the southern wall was a cubit thick. This was also the case with the northern wall. Thus only the width of 8 cubits was left for the western wall.”
77 The southern and northern walls of the tabernacle consisted of 20 boards, each of which was 1 1/2 cubits in width.

78 The tabernacle was 10 cubits in width. This can be ascertained from the size of the fabric and goats’ hair curtains which covered the tabernacle. These curtains were 28 and 30 cubits long. Ten cubits of the former covered the width of the tabernacle down to the sockets; 10 cubits of the latter covered the width of the tabernacle as well as its sideboards and sockets.
79 For the northern and southern walls each took up a cubit. I.E. believed that the tabernacle was 10 cubits in width and 30 in length only as measured from the outside.
80 See verses 22 and 23.

81 Each of which was 1 1/2 cubits wide. The question thus arises, how do we fit these boards into a space of 8 cubits? The width of each board was thus obviously not a cubit. I.E. will later explain that the space on the west measured about 10 cubits and that only six of the eight boards measured 1 1/2 cubits.
82 See verse 28. According to the Talmud this middle bar was inserted into the boards themselves.

83 There are those who would emend to: It is possible they were compelled to say that the boards were a cubit thick because of the middle bar which was inserted into the boards (Krinsky). It should be noted that the text of this chapter appears to be especially corrupt due to the difficulty of understanding I.E.’s comments.
84 Rashi.

85 According to the Talmud Sabbath 98b, “It (the middle bar) lay there by miracle” (Soncino translation). Rashi in his comments on the Talmud explains that one long middle bar was placed into one of the boards and it miraculously snaked around all three sides of the tabernacle. This comment is not in our editions of Rashi on the Pentateuch. In our editions, Rashi merely notes that a separate middle bar was inserted into each of the three sides of the tabernacle. I.E. probably quoted Rashi from memory and attributed to him here what he wrote in his commentary on the Talmud.
86 That is, each had its own separate middle bar.
87 The middle bar reached from end to end.
88 Which it would if one middle bar encircled all the sides of the tabernacle.
89 That is, from one end.
90 To all the other ends.
91 Each wall of the tabernacle had five bars (v. 27). I.E. explains that there were two top bars, two bottom bars, and one middle bar.

92 One of the top bars was placed along half the length of the walls of the tabernacle starting from one direction. Another was placed in the same position starting from the other side. They met in the center. The bottom bars were similarly placed. A middle bar which extended from one end to the other end was placed between the upper and lower bars.
93 In other words, the middle bar was not inserted into the boards. It was placed on the outside of the boards, as explained in note 91.
94 Translated literally.

95 According to I.E. the word be-tokh (in the midst) does not always literally mean in the midst of an object’s very body. It can be taken to mean midpoint or between. Thus in Ex. 39:3, be-tokh (in the midst) means among. Similarly, in verse 28 be-tokh ha-kerahsim does not mean in the very midst of the board’s body but rather at the midpoint of the board’s outer surface.
96 The meaning of which is, put the bells between the pomegranates.
97 See verse 29.
98 What purpose is there to gold plating a bar that is inserted into a board.
99 On the northwest and southwest corners of the tabernacle. For the corner boards see verse 23.
100 These two corner boards were set up first.
101 In verse 23.
102 The tabernacle courtyard had four corner poles. Two of them were set up first.
103 Like the tabernacle.
104 All the boards of the tabernacle were 1 1/2 cubits in width. These two boards were a little more than half a cubit. See note 108.
105 Scripture discusses these boards apart from the other boards.
106 Western boards.
107 Between the two corner boards.

108 The six boards came to 9 cubits. Each one of the corner boards came to a little more than half a cubit. A half cubit of open space and a little more to cover the width of the boards made up the northern and southern walls of the tabernacle.
109 Since these boards were not the same size as the other boards, it is possible that they were likewise not shaped like them. In fact, being corner boards they might have been round.
110 To cover. See note 108.

111 It is hard to ascertain what I.E. means by this. According to Rashi the corner boards did stand in a straight line with the other six boards. Filwarg writes, “I cannot explain this.” Sarim similarly comments, “I did not find any scholar or commentary that explains I.E.’s language.” Meijler suggests that what I.E. means by “these boards did not stand in a straight line” is that the corner boards did not serve the same purpose as the other six boards. For the other six boards served to cover the inside of the tabernacle while most of the surface of the corner boards served to cover the northern and southern boards.

112 That is, because only half a cubit was inside of the tabernacle. According to Rashi, who accepts the Talmudic tradition that the boards were a cubit in thickness, the two outer boards like all the other boards were 1 1/2 cubits in width. One half a cubit of each one of the corner boards filled the remaining open spaces left over after the six boards were placed on the western side of the tabernacle (see note 108). See Rashi on verse 23.
113 In other words, there is no way that a board measuring 1 1/2 cubits can be squeezed into a space measuring half a cubit.
114 After setting up the western wall of the tabernacle.
115 Of the western wall (Filwarg).
116 On the eastern side of the tabernacle.

117 That is, from underneath the fabric curtain which is referred to as the tabernacle. See I.E. on verse 15 and the notes thereto. I.E.’s point is that when the fabric curtains, which measured 44 by 28 cubits, were sewn together and placed over the tabernacle, which measured 30 by 10 cubits, 10 of the 44 cubits covered the back of the tabernacle, an undetermined amount covered the thickness of the boards of the western wall, and what remained covered the top of the tabernacle. An amount of space equivalent to the thickness of the western wall was thus left uncovered on the eastern side of the tabernacle.
118 That is, each one of the five pillars that served as supports for the screen of the door for the Tent. See verse 36.
119 That is, under it, i.e., under the exposed area. For the pillars for the screen for the door of the Tent stood at the very entrance to the tent.
120 Which hung over the front of the tent. See verse 9.
121 That is, covered the exposed area.

122 In other words, And thou shalt rear up the tabernacle means: and thou shalt command the wise-hearted to rear up the tabernacle. I.E. comments thus because it was impossible for Moses himself to rear up the tabernacle. Concerning who the wise-hearted are see Ex. 36:1.
123 And the others then joined in.
124 In other words, And thou shalt rear up the tabernacle means, and thou shalt begin to rear up the tabernacle.
125 See II Chron. 3:14, And he (Solomon) made the veil of blue, and purple, etc.
126 Separating the Holy from the Holy of Holies. The veil was hung over an opening in this wall.
127 And was not very wide. It thus did not take up much space.
128 The temple.
129 I Kings 6:2.
130 See Rashi on I Kings 6:2.
131 Had the wall separating the Holy from the Holy of Holies been made out of stone, it would have diminished the space of the Holy.
132 Of the pillars holding up the veil.
133 See verse 32.
134 The Holy of Holies in the temple measured 20 by 20 by 20. The Holy of Holies in the tabernacle measured 10 by 10 by 10.
135 In I Kings 6:3.
136 The Temple measured 60 by 20 by 30. The Holy of Holies thus measured 20 by 20 by 30.
137 Twenty cubits were taken up by the Holy, the remainder by the upper chambers. However, the entire measure came to 30 cubits.
138 Whereas a third person hifil is penultimately accented even when it has a conversive vav prefixed to it.
139 Ve-hikkita in Ex. 17:6 is penultimately accented. Hence it has been suggested that the reference is to ve-hikkita in Deut. 20:13, in which ve-hikkita is ultimately accented.
140 See I.E. on verse 1.
141 See I.E. on.verse 1.
142 Which held up the screen of the door of the Tent.

143 It was between the veil of the Holy of Holies and the screen of the gate of the courtyard (Ex. 27:16). Hence the pillars supporting the veil were covered with gold and their sockets were made out of silver; the pillars supporting the screen of the door of the Tent were covered with gold and their sockets were made of brass, while the pillars supporting the screen of the temple courtyard were unplated although their sockets were made of brass (Filwarg).

chapter.title: CHAPTER 27
chapter.p: 1. AND THOU SHALT MAKE. Any shape whose length is the same size as its width is called a square. The latter is a true1 square, as quadrilaterals2 come in five shapes.3

[AND THE HEIGHT THEREOF SHALL BE THREE CUBITS.] Look, if contrary to the opinion of our sages,4 we say that there was no need for a ramp5 because the altar was three cubits high,6 what then will the opponents of the sages7 do with the altar which Solomon made? That altar was ten cubits high8 whereas the height of a person is only four cubits.
[FOUR-SQUARE.] Scripture describes the altar as being ravu’a (four-square) because the length of the altar was the same as its width.9
2. CORNERS. The word pinnot means corners.

3. [TO TAKE AWAY ITS ASHES.] The meaning of ledasheno is, to take away its ashes. The meaning of yedasheneh (accept the fat) in And accept the fat of thy burnt-sacrifice; Selah (Ps. 20:4) is, he shall make ashes out of it.10 Its meaning is that the sacrifice will be burnt on the altar and accepted.11 Observe the word tedashen (make fat) in maketh the bones fat (Prov. 15:30). They all belong to the same12 conjugational form,13 namely, the pi’el. The meaning of tedashen is to fatten, as in As for Asher, his bread shall be fat (Gen. 49:20).14
AND ITS SHOVELS. The word ve-ya’av (and its shovels) is similar to the word ve-ya’ah (shall sweep away) in And the hail shall sweep away (Is. 28:17).15

[ALL THE VESSELS THEREOF.] The lamed in le-khol (all)16 in le-khol kelav (all the vessels thereof) is superfluous.17 It is like the lamed in le-min (from)18 in from the day that the foundation of the Lord’s temple was laid (Haggai 2:18).19
4. A GRATING. The word mikhbar (a grating) is similar in meaning to the word kevarah (sieve) (Amos 9:9).
BRASS. The word brass (nechoshet) is connected [to the word grating].20 The text should be interpreted as if it read, a grating of brass, constructed like a net.21
5. [LEDGE.] The word karkov (ledge) does not appear in any other place.

8. [HOLLOW WITH PLANKS.] Nevuv luchot (hollow with planks) is to be explained in accordance with the Aramaic translation.22 The phrase ve-ish nevuv yillavav (But an empty man will get understanding) (Job 11:12) is similar, for ish nevuv means an empty person, that is, a person lacking intelligence. The verse is similar to the aphorism, a head without a brain.

The laver23 is not mentioned24 because it25 was not made from the gifts which were donated by all of Israel. It was made only from the gifts of the women.26 Hence the basin was mentioned with the chapter dealing with the spices,27 for the spices were also not donated by all of Israel. The spices were given only by the princes.28

9. AND THOU SHALT MAKE. We find that Scripture says, kedemah mizrachah (on the east side eastward) (v. 13).29 We know that there are three “heads” to the east.30 The first is opposite the point of the head of Capricorn,31 which is the furthermost southern position of the sun. The second32 is opposite the celestial equator, which is the head of Aries and Libra.33 The third is opposite the head of Cancer, which is the sun’s furthermost northern position.34 The same applies to the phrase negbah temanah (south…southward)35 in the south.36
SOUTHWARD. The word temanah (southward)37 comes from the same root as yamin (south). Compare, The north and the south (yamin), Thou hast created them (Ps. 89:13).

10. [AND THEIR FILLETS.] The meaning of chashukehem (their fillets) is their attachments, the hooks being attached to the pillars.38 Va-tidbak nafsho (and his soul did cleave) (Gen. 34:3) means the same as chashekah nafsho (his soul longeth) (Gen. 34:8).39
12. AND FOR THE BREADTH…FIFTY CUBITS. The width of the courtyard was thus half of its length.40

The commentaries tell us that the tabernacle was placed fifty cubits westward.41 Now its width was fifty cubits. This is what and the breadth fifty every where (v. 18) means. However, I believe that the meaning of the breadth fifty every where is that the courtyard was a right-angled parallelogram,42 and its width was fifty cubits on all sides.43 There is no necessity to explain the breadth fifty every where as referring to the side of the courtyard,44 as Scripture does not repeat the dimensions length by width as it normally does.45

19. ALL. The meaning of All the instruments of the tabernacle is, all the instruments that were for the use of the tabernacle. The pins of the tent46 and the pins of the court were of brass. So were the hammers.47
If your heart desires to know the truth
Look at the body,
And consider the most glorious thing in it.48
I will secretly reveal the mystery of the Urim and Thummim
In the Torah portion entitled, And Thou Shalt Command.

20. AND THOU SHALT COMMAND. I will first note the reason for the position of this Torah portion.49 After God finished enumerating all the holy utensils, the veil, the tabernacle, the tent, the cover, the altar of the burnt offering, the courtyard, and the screen,50 He commenced51 to deal with those who ministered in the tabernacle.52 He explained the service which they alone were to perform. No stranger was permitted to perform the service alongside them. God opened53 with the command that they54 cause a lamp to burn using pure olive oil. They were not to employ any other oil. It is only fitting that those who ministered in the tabernacle were to be distinguished and set apart, both in family and in dress.55 Scripture lists the garments one after the other.56

Scripture then mentions that those who served in the tabernacle were obligated to learn the service during the seven days of consecration. Moses was to teach and train them. After this, the priests would serve in the tabernacle. They would offer the daily burnt offering on the altar of the burnt offering. They were not to offer it upon the golden altar. The priests were to offer only incense upon the golden altar and to make atonement upon its horns once a year.57

And thou shalt command 58 means that there is an eternal command upon the congregation to continually provide olive oil to kindle a perpetual light. Do not be troubled by the oil which the princes59 brought.60 It was anointing oil.61 The congregation, on the other hand, was obligated to bring oil for the light.

There is a practice in countries where olives grow to choose pure olives, that is, olives that do not have any rot on them or olives that have not been partially eaten. These olives are then used to make oil for the king’s food. This is the reason that Scripture mentions pure62 before beaten.
FOR THE LIGHT. For the light needed during the night.63
TO CAUSE A LAMP TO BURN. To kindle the lamps.64 Scripture states, that they should burn65according to the ordinance (II Chron. 4:20) concerning Solomon’s candelabra.66

[CONTINUALLY.] The meaning of tamid (continually) is nightly.67 There is a more difficult usage of the term tamid,68 namely, and it shall be always (tamid) upon his forehead (Ex. 28:38).69 The meaning of the latter is that the holy plate shall always be upon the miter whenever the miter is placed upon the head of the high priest.70
21. WHICH IS BEFORE THE TESTIMONY. The testimony is short for the ark of testimony.

Yefet says that ya’arokh (shall set)71 is similar in meaning to ke-erkekha (as thou valuest it)72 in as thou the priest valuest it (Lev. 27:12). It means that the priest shall estimate the amount of oil that will be sufficient for the lamps to give light from evening till morning.73 The same applies to the phrase nerot ha-ma’arakha (even the lamps to be set in order) (Ex. 39:37).74
Ya’arokh may also be properly interpreted as meaning shall set, for the lamps were set in a semicircle.75 I will yet speak on this.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Reading be-emet, as in Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed texts contain ba-amah. If we read ba-amah, then the meaning of the sentence is: it was square by cubits; that is, it was 5 cubits long and 5 cubits wide. Many of the commentaries suggest emending the text to be-emet.
2 Literally, for squares come in five shapes. I.E. refers to quadrilaterals as squares.
3 Squares, rectangles, parallelograms, rhombuses, and trapezoids.
4 According to sages of the Talmud the altar was ascended via a ramp. See Mishnah Middot 5:2. Also see Mekhilta, Yitro 11.
5 To ascend the altar.

6 A priest does not have to ascend in order to perform the service on a threecubit high altar. The priest can stand next to the altar and offer the sacrifices. As I.E. points out, the height of an average person is 4 cubits. It should be noted that according to the Talmudic sage Rabbi Judah, the altar was 3 cubits high above the ledge which went all around the altar, and the entire altar was 10 cubits in height. See Zevachim 59b. Also see Rashi.
7 Who maintain that the altar had no ramp. It should be noted that the Pentateuch does not mention that the altar had a ramp.
8 See II Chron. 4:1.

9 The altar was 3 cubits in height. Hence I.E. comments that the altar was only square with regard to its length and width. This comment is found in Vat. Ebr. 38, in Weiser, and in some other editions. It is omitted by most mikra’ot gedolot editions.
10 According to I.E., Ps. 20:4 should be rendered: and make ashes out of your burnt offerings.
11 By God.

12 Our texts read, to a different form. However, this reading is impossible, as le-dasheno, yedasheneh, and tedashen are all pi’els. Hence the commentaries suggest emending acher (different) to echad (one or same). See Filwarg, Krinsky, and Weiser. It should be noted that the Margoli’ot Tuvah edition of I.E. reads echad rather than acher.
13 Although their meaning differs. I.E. points out that the root dalet, shin, nun in the pi’el form can have a number of meanings: to take away ashes, to turn into ashes, and to fatten.

14 Gen. 49:20 is not a proof text, as the word deshen does not appear in it. I.E. merely uses it in order to define the word tedasheno. I.E. literally reads: tedashen has the same meaning as, As for Asher, his bread shall be fat.
15 According to I.E., ve-ya’av literally means: and its sweepers. He probably rendered ve-ya’av as: and its brushes, or, and its scrapers. See Krinsky.
16 Literally, to all. Hence I.E.’s comment.
17 It has no meaning. It is not to be translated.
18 For le-min is to be translated as if written min (from).
19 Translated literally.

20 Not to reshet (network), which precedes it, for reshet (network) is connected to ma’aseh, not to nechoshet. Our verse, which reads, mikhbar ma’aseh reshet nechoshet (a grating of network of brass) is to be interpreted as if written: mikhbar nechoshet ma’aseh reshet (a grating of brass, of network).
21 So too Rashi.
22 That is, Onkelos. Onkelos renders nevuv luchot as chalil luche (hollow with planks).
24 In this Torah portion. However, prima facie, it should have been mentioned, as it was made right after the altar. See Ex. 38:1-8 (Krinsky).
25 Unlike the objects mentioned in our Torah portion.
27 Ex. 30:22-28. The chapter dealing with the laver precedes the chapter dealing with the spices.

29 In speaking of the east, Scripture in verse 13 uses the phrase kedemah mizrachah. Now since both kedem and mizrach mean east, Scripture should have read kedemah or mizrachah. The question thus arises, why did Scripture employ the phrase kedemah mizrachah? I.E. brings up this issue here since Scripture uses the phrase negev temanah (south…southwards). Here too the question arises, why employ the phrase negev temanah when both negev and teman mean south?
30 The eastern sky is divided into three sections. Each section is called a “head.” The sun rises at various places in the eastern sky at different times of the year.

31 The eastern sky consists of the constellations Aries, Taurus, and Gemini. The northern sky consists of Cancer, Leo, and Virgo. The western sky consists of Libra, Scorpio, and Sagittarius. The southern sky consists of Capricorn, Aquarius, and Pisces. Capricorn is located in the southwestern section of the heavens. Aries lies in the southeastern part of the sky. The first “head” of the east begins at a point in the southeastern sky directly opposite the constellation of Capricorn.
32 Head of the east.
33 The celestial equator extends from Aries to Libra.

34 The term kedemah mizrachah refers to the middle portion of the eastern sky. So Krinsky. I.E. comments thus because in his opinion the tabernacle corresponded to the heavens. Thus kedemah mizrachah corresponded to a certain portion of the heavens. Weiser claims that kedemah mizrachah refers to the entire eastern side.
35 Which our verse employs. Actually our verse reads, negev temanah. I.E. used the term negbah temanah because verse 18 reads kedemah mizrachah.
36 The southern part of the sky also has three “heads.” The phrase negbah temanah refers to the middle portion of the southern sky. So Krinsky. For other interpretations see Weiser.
37 That is, the word teman (south).
38 The fillets, like the hooks, were attached to the pillars. See Rashi: “The pillars were encompassed by threads of silver round about.”

39 The Bible first says va-tidbak nafsho. It then repeats the same account. However, in the latter it employs chashekah nafsho in place of va-tidbak nafsho. We thus see that davak and chashak have the same meaning.
40 The courtyard was 100 cubits long.

41 From the eastern wall of the courtyard. See Eruvin 23b. “He placed the tabernacle (which measured 30 by 20 cubits) at the edge of fifty cubits (i.e., 50 cubits inwards) so that there was fifty cubits in front of the tabernacle and twenty cubits around the sides.”

42 Hebrew, me-rov orekh zavyotav nitzavot. Literally, because of its many long right angles. In other words, the courtyard was a parallelogram that measured 50 cubits in width. Such a structure is 50 cubits in breadth every where, i.e., all along its width. Meijler suggests emending me-rov orekh zavyotav nitzavot (because of the length of its many angles) to meruva orekh zavyotav nitzavot (a right-angled parallelogram). Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: merchav arokh zeviyot, which means a right-angled parallelogram. This reading seems to be the most correct. Be that as it may, according to I.E. the import of our verse is that the tabernacle courtyard was not tapered but measured 100 by 50 cubits.
43 For the meaning of the breadth fifty every where is that its width did not vary.

44 That is, the eastern side of the courtyard (Filwarg). I.E. takes issue with the rabbis who held that the courtyard on the east side of the tabernacle was a 50 by 50-cubit square, as the tabernacle was placed 50 cubits inwards from the eastern wall of the courtyard. See note 41. See I.E.’s short commentary. Also see Rashi.
45 Verse 18 reads, chamishim ba-chamishim (fifty every where). If Scripture were speaking of a square it would read, chamishim al chamishim (fifty by fifty) (Filwarg). Also see Weiser.
46 In other words, and all the pins thereof refers to the pins of the tent.

47 Which were used to bang the pins in the ground (Weiser). The hammers are not mentioned in the text. However, they are implied in All the instruments of the tabernacle. Its meaning is, all the instruments that were for the use of the tabernacle.
48 The soul (Krinsky). In other words, develop your soul and you will learn the truth.
49 Why the Torah portion Tetzavveh follows the Torah portion Terumah.
50 All of the aforementioned are enumerated in Terumah.
51 In Tetzavveh.
52 That is, the kohanim, the priests.
53 Our Torah portion.
54 The priests.
55 From the rest of the nation.
56 Krinsky.
58 The children of Israel, that they bring unto thee pure olive oil beaten for the light.
60 This indicates that the oil is brought by the individual rather than by the congregation.

61 Rather than oil for the light. However, Scripture explicitly states that the princes brought oil for the light, and for the anointing oil (Ex. 35:28). Krinsky explains that only the princes had pure olive oil in the desert (see I.E. on Ex. 35:27). Hence after the princes donated the oil to be used for anointing oil, some of it was utilized for the light.
62 Pure refers to the olives, not to the oil. According to I.E. our verse should be interpreted as follows: that they bring unto thee olive oil, from pure olives beaten for the light.
63 I.E. interprets la-ma’or (for the light) as: needed for the light. He then elaborates: needed for the light at night.
64 Le-ha’alot ner (to cause a lamp to burn) literally means to cause a lamp to go up.
65 Hebrew, le-va’aram.
66 In other words, the use of the term le-va’aram with regard to Solomon’s candelabra shows that le-ha’alot used in connection with Moses’ menorah means to kindle.
67 For the menorah did not burn continually. The word tamid means continually. Hence I.E.’s comment.
68 That is, a use of the term which presents us with greater problems than the one in our verse.
69 For the Bible explicitly states that the holy plate shall always be on the high priest’s head. However, in our verse the phrase ner tamid is merely descriptive.
70 In other words, always means whenever the miter is worn by the high priest.
71 From the root ayin, resh, kaf. This root can mean to estimate or to arrange. Hence the two interpretations of ya’arokh (shall set).
72 In other words, as you estimate its value.
73 In other words, ya’arokh (shall set) means shall estimate.
74 Yefet interprets nerot ha-ma’arakha (even the lamps to be set in order) as: the lamps to be estimated; that is, the lamps whose oil has to be estimated.
75 The branches of the menorah formed a semicircle. See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 25:37.

chapter.title: Chapter 28
chapter.p: 1. AND BRING THOU. Scripture says, And bring thou near unto thee [Aaron thy brother, and his sons…that they may minister unto me] because at first Moses was the high priest.1 I have already hinted2 at why Aaron3 was chosen to be sanctified to the Lord so that the priests4 would make atonement for Israel. Aaron was chosen because of the importance of Nahshon’s family.5

We cannot find fault with Moses,6 our master, as Moses was a fugitive.7 Who would have given him a Hebrew woman?8 Furthermore, the burden of all of Israel was upon Moses.9 Moses had to teach Israel the commandments. He also had to judge all difficult cases.10

[THAT THEY MAY MINISTER UNTO ME.] The vav in lekhahano (that they minister) in that they may minister unto me is superfluous.11 It is like the vav in chayeto (beast)12 in every beast of the field (Ps. 104:11) and beno (son of)13 in the son of Beor (Num. 24:3).

Our verse lists the sons of Aaron. It is possible that Aaron had other sons besides these.14 There is no doubt that Aaron’s family increased greatly in the wilderness. Hence they were given the many cities enumerated in the Book of Joshua.15

2. AND THOU SHALT MAKE HOLY GARMENTS. They are called holy garments because they were worn during the sanctuary service. On the other hand, it is possible that they were called holy garments in accordance with that they sanctify not the people with their garments (Ezek. 44:19).16
The garments of Aaron referred to in our verse are the ones which Scripture later enumerates.17
FOR SPLENDOUR AND FOR BEAUTY. They shall glorify18 themselves with these garments, for no other Israelite shall wear similar garments.
3. AND THOU SHALT. The vav in milletiv (I have filled)19 refers to lev 20 (hearted).21

4. AND THESE ARE THE GARMENTS. Scripture first mentions the breastplate, which was worn over the ephod, which was worn over the robe.22 It then mentions the tunic and the girdle23 which went around it24 after the mitre was placed on Aaron’s head. This is what happened25 when Aaron washed26 and put on linen breeches.27 However, there was no reason to mention the breeches here nor in the description of the actual investiture of Aaron,28 for it is the manner of all men to wear breeches. Now Moses put the tunic upon Aaron.29 He then placed the mitre upon Aaron’s head,30 and He placed “the plate of the holy crown”31 upon the mitre.32

Our verse, which enumerates the priestly garments, does not mention “the plate of the holy crown” because “the plate of the holy crown” was not a garment. However, our sages mentioned the holy plate among the priestly garments33 because most of the objects worn by the high priest were garments. Hence the sages speak of the eight garments worn by the high priest. The Urim and Thummim34 were not garments.35 Neither were the stones,36 nor the cards.37

After this38 Moses encircled Aaron with the girdle. Moses then placed the robe upon Aaron. He then placed the ephod upon the robe and put the ephod upon him, and he girded him with the skilfully woven band of the ephod and bound it unto him therewith (Lev. 8:7).39 The skillfully woven band was part of the ephod.40 The ephod was so called because of the skillfully woven band.41 Moses dressed Aaron according to the order described in our verse.

Do not be bothered by the fact that Scripture later states, regarding the actual investiture of Aaron, And he set the mitre upon his head (Lev. 8:9).42 Its meaning is, he had already placed the mitre with the golden plate on Aaron’s head when he dressed him in the tunic.43 The meaning of and clothed him with garments (Zech. 3:5) is similar; i.e., they had already clothed him. For Scripture previously states, So they set a fair mitre upon his head (Ibid.).44
5. AND THEY SHALL TAKE THE GOLD. The wise-hearted who made the priestly garments were trustworthy.45

[6. AND THEY SHALL MAKE THE EPHOD.] Scripture starts with the ephod46 because it was larger than the breastplate. The Torah tells us that the breastplate be not loosed from the skilfully woven band of the ephod (v. 28).47

There are some very difficult questions relating to the ephod and the breastplate. Moses only made one ephod.48 However, Scripture states, that he49 came down with an ephod in his hand (I Sam. 23:6). The latter does not refer to the ephod made by Moses,50 for Scripture does not read “the ephod,”51 the meaning of which is, the well-known ephod,52 as it does when it states, “Bring hither the ephod” (I Sam. 23:9).53 Furthermore, why does Scripture state, he came down, but it does not say he brought down? It thus appears that the ephod was accidentally among his possessions.54 Additionally, Scripture there states, fourscore persons55 that did wear a linen (bad) ephod (I Sam. 22:18).56

Many commentaries explain this verse as meaning that the persons57 were fit to wear the ephod.58 However, they did not bother to learn the truth.59 A bad (linen) ephod is an ephod made from a type of flax. However, the ephod made by Moses was not made of bad (linen).60 It was made of gold, blue wool, purple wool, and scarlet, with shesh (linen)61 intertwined with all of the aforementioned.62

They only inquired of the breastplate of judgment which had the Urim and Thummim upon it.63 Scripture similarly writes, by the judgment of the Urim before the Lord (Num. 27:21). Bring hither the ephod (I Sam. 23:9)64 does not present a counterargument65 because the breastplate was connected to it. The Urim66 went along with the breastplate.67 We similarly read, till there stood up a priest with Urim and Thummim (Neh. 7:65). Scripture likewise states, Thy Thummim and Thy Urim (Deut. 33:8).

Now, Scripture tells us68 that God answered David through Abiathar’s ephod.69 However, we also read that when Saul went to war he inquired of the Urim (I Sam. 28:6). These were the very Urim that were placed in the breastplate of judgment which was with the ephod70 and the ark.71 However, David inquired of Abiathar’s ephod in Ziklag. Abiathar’s ephod was thus not Moses’ ephod.72

The following problem is even more difficult.73 It is clear that the Urim do not refer to the stones of the breastplate,74 as Scripture openly states, And thou shalt set in it settings of stones (v. 17). The setting of the stones was the work of a stonecutter and not the work of Moses. God then told Moses,75 And thou shalt put in the breastplate of judgment the Urim and the Thummim (v. 30).76

Scripture, in describing the making of the breastplate,77 tells us, And they set in it four rows of stones (Ex. 39:10). Scripture then describes the four rows of stones.78 Scripture tells us that Moses placed the breastplate upon Aaron and in the breastplate he put the Urim and the Thummim (Lev. 8:8). Now according to the plain meaning of the text the stones were not the objects that enlightened or fulfilled,79 because inquiries were made of the Urim and Thummim.

We do not know what they were. The explanation that the names of the tribes80 and the patriarchs81 were inscribed on the breastplate is of no help,82 for the breastplate of judgment was so called only because of the Urim that were on it.83

There is an additional question: we cannot identify the Urim with the Thummim,84 for Scripture states, with Urim and Thummim (Neh. 7:65). Furthermore, the words with Urim and Thummim are in the plural. They thus consisted of many objects.85
Rabbi Solomon says that the Urim and Thummim consisted of an inscription of God’s explicit name.86 However, he would not have said this had he seen the responsa of Rabbi Hai Gaon.87

There is a very deep secret behind the ephod and the breastplate. I will allude only to a part of this secret. Perhaps he who knows the mind of the Most High will understand it. The following are the keys to the secret of the ephod.88 The two wreathen chains on the two rings [represent the head of Aries and Libra].89 The band of the ephod represents the celestial equator.90 Hence six names were inscribed on the stone which was on the other shoulder.91

Now these things92 can only be grasped by the mind. Hence six names were inscribed on one stone93 in accordance with the number, names, and order of birth of the tribes of the children of Israel.94 Six names were similarly inscribed on the second stone.95 On the other hand, the names on the breastplate were not divided in the same manner as they are grasped by the mind.96 They were divided in a way that could be perceived by the eye.97

Scripture states, And they shall bind the breastplate by the rings thereof unto the rings of the ephod with a thread of blue (v. 28) to prevent the breastplate from moving to the side.98 The breastplate was folded, for the Urim and Thummim were kept there until such time as they were needed. They were then placed outside of the breastplate.99

Note, the stones of the ephod were like each other.100 They were of one color.101 This was not the case with the stones of the breastplate,102 for the sapphire stones103 served as a memorial,104 while the judgment of the children of Israel was upon the stones of the breastplate.105

The word Urim is related to the word ur (fire) in I am warm, I have seen the fire (Is. 44:16).106 The Thummim are so called because they are whole.107 The Urim were of gold and silver. This was not the case with the Thummim.108
The [importance of the] number [twelve] has been established by irrefutable proof from the upper and lower worlds.109 The intelligent will understand what I say.110

Now the priests had many ephodim. They all had bands. However, they lacked the breastplate and the Urim. A priest who was an expert in using the Urim and Thummim was able to respond to an inquirer because the ephod at hand resembled [the ephod made by Moses].111 However, the priest did not always get an answer.112

Now if I wanted to even begin to reveal this secret113 it would take up more space than the entire commentary which I have composed on this book. For only an individual who has studied works on geometry and the secret of the way the sky works can understand the secret of the ephod. There is no need to expand on the form of the ephod, the breastplate, and the rings.
[9.] ONYX STONES. The avne shoham (onyx stones) were white. They are called burla in Aramaic and balor in Arabic.

We have no way to positively identify the stones that were set in the breastplate. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon translated them114 as he saw fit, as he had no tradition to rely upon.115 We read the Gaon’s translation and noticed that he rendered sappir (sapphire) as white.116 However, this is not the case. Sappir is red.117 The fact that the first stone118 mentioned by the Torah was a carnelian119 does not refute this,120 for there are five visible colors: white, lightning,121 red, green, and black. Now since red is the middle color122 it comes in various shades.

Saadiah Gaon renders nofekh (carbuncle) as black on the basis of and she painted (ba-pukh)123 her eyes (II Kings 9:30).124 However, the nun in nofekh is undoubtedly a root letter,125 for nofekh follows the paradigm of odem (carnelian).126

A great Sephardic scholar said that yahalom (emerald) is a diamond.127 This stone has the ability to break up all other stones and to bore through bdellium. Yahalom is related to the word holem (smiteth) in smiteth the anvil (Is. 41:7). The yod of yahalom is not a root letter.128 It is like the yod of yitzhar (oil).129

Also achlamah (amethyst) is to be identified with the dream stone.130 This is a stone that always induces dreams in the person who wears it.131 One should not be surprised at this,132 as every stone has a specific power placed in it by nature. Thus there is a stone that attracts iron.133 There is likewise a stone that stops bleeding. Another stone is repelled by vinegar. There is also a stone whose pieces always form a triangle when broken.

[14. CHAINS.] The middle root letter has been doubled in sharsherot (chains).134 However, the word has the same meaning when the middle root letter is not doubled. Compare, sharshot135 gavlut (plaited chains) (v. 22).

It is very difficult to explain the meaning of gavlut (plaited) in Hebrew.136 The same applies to many of the words employed by Scripture that refer to the making of the breastplate as well as to the word choshen (breastplate) itself.
28. AND THEY SHALL BIND. Ve-yirkesu is related to the word me-rukhse (from the plottings) in from the plottings of man (Ps. 31:21). It means twisted.137
30. AND THOU SHALT PUT IN THE BREASTPLATE OF JUDGMENT. Judgment refers to the laws of God and his decrees concerning the future. It is these things that people inquire of the Urim and Thummim.138

31. AND THOU SHALT MAKE. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon translates the word me’il (robe) by the Arabic memtar, which is a cloak-like139 garment except that its opening was in the midst of the robe.140 Our sages said that the pomegranates (v. 33) were placed all around the robe. A bell was placed between every two pomegranates.141 However, others say that the bells were not visible. They were placed inside the pomegranates, where they rang.142

36. AND THOU SHALT MAKE A PLATE. The Gaon renders tzitz (plate) atzabah. It143 was placed on the mitre. It was not shaped like a crown, as the plate144 was placed only on the forehead.145 According to the plain meaning of the text, the migba’ot (head-tires) (Lev. 8:13)146 were not shaped like the mitre (mitznefet). The head-tires are similar to the high hats which men in this and surrounding countries place upon their heads as a head covering.

[37.] THE MITRE. The mitre147 is made from long thin material which is twisted only around the head.148 The turbans worn by women in these areas are somewhat similar. In Spain, Africa, Egypt, Babylonia, and Baghdad and in the land of the Ishmaelites, only men of respect, not the women, wear turbans on their heads.149 The important officials place a golden plate on the turban over the forehead. I have already noted that the ornaments in the Land of Israel and the customs practiced there differ from those in these areas.

Rabbi Solomon150 found it necessary to harmonize Scripture151 by explaining that three blue threads were attached to the plate.152 However, according to the plain meaning of the text only one blue thread153 was necessary to keep the plate, which was on the face of the mitre on the forehead, in place.

37. AND THOU SHALT PUT IT ON A THREAD OF BLUE. The meaning of al petil techelt (on a thread of blue) is, with154 a thread of blue,155 as the thread was tied to the plate on two sides.156 There is no doubt that the front of the mitre was placed over the forehead.157 It158 was not placed over the head. Scripture elsewhere states, And they tied unto it a thread of blue, to fasten it upon the mitre (Ex. 39:31), that is, upon the forehead.159

Do not be surprised that Scripture uses the term al.160 We find the same161 in the following, And they came, both men with (al) women (Ex. 35:22);162And the priest shall wave them with (al) the bread of the first-fruits for a wave-offering before the Lord (Lev. 23:20); with (al) the two lambs (Ibid.); the fat with (al) the breast (Lev. 7:30). There are many similar instances in Scripture.
Now you will never find [the mitre and the head-tires interchanging].163 For the mitre was set aside only for Aaron, and the head-tires for his children.

Some say that the word migba’ot (head-tires) is related to the word givot (hills) (Gen. 49:26).164 The mitre165 surrounded and wrapped the head.166 We similarly read, He will violently roll (tzanof) and toss thee Like a ball (yitznofkha tzenefah) (Is. 22:18); Yea, He will wind thee round and round (ve-otekha ato) (Is. 22:17).

The one who knows how the mitre is wrapped knows the meaning of [The mitre shall be removed…] this shall be no more the same: that which is low shall be exalted, and that which is high abased (Ezek. 21:31).167 It takes a special skill to wind a mitre around the head.

Now Scripture states, And thou shalt set the mitre upon his head, and put the holy crown upon the mitre (Ex. 29:6). The tzitz (plate) (v. 36) is thus called a nezer (crown).168 But upon himself shall his crown (nizro) shine (yatzitz) is similar (Ps. 132:18).169 Perhaps they all170 are used in the sense of tzitz, meaning something seen. The same is true with the word metzitz (peereth) in He peereth through the lattice (Cant. 2:9).

Note that the five senses come together in the two cavities which are in that part of the brain which is behind the forehead. This is where the imaginative power is located. Furthermore, all thoughts begin there. It is for this reason that Scripture writes, regarding the plate, that Aaron shall bear the iniquity committed in the holy things (v. 38). It is possible that those who hallowed holy things unto the Lord did so while thinking improper thoughts.171

[39. AND THOU SHALT WEAVE THE TUNIC IN CHEQUER WORK.] When Scripture first mentions Aaron’s tunic it says, a tunic of chequer work (v. 4). Only Aaron’s tunic was chequered. His sons’ tunics were not. The tunic was chequered to dignify Aaron. Scripture similar reads, And he put upon him the tunic (Lev. 8:7) when it describes Aaron’s investiture. It reads, the tunic,172 the reference being to the chequered tunic. However, concerning Aaron’s children we read, and clothed them with tunics (Lev. 8:13).173 The latter is similar to And for Aaron’s sons thou shalt make tunics (v. 40).174
Rabbi Saadiah Gaon translated ve-shibatzta (and thou shalt weave…in chequer work) as: you shall weave eye-like [designs].175 It is a coin-like design, that is, a square within a circle.176

41. AND THOU SHALT PUT THEM UPON AARON THY BROTHER. The word otam (them) takes in the chequered tunic, the mitre, and the girdle which are Aaron’s garments. It also takes in the unchequered tunics, the girdles, and the head-tires which are the garments of Aaron’s sons.177
AND CONSECRATE THEM. By word of mouth.178 It is similar to the priest shall make him unclean179 (Lev. 13:44).
42. LINEN BREECHES. The linen breeches were short so that the priest would not trip over them.
43. WHEN THEY GO IN. To offer incense or to kindle the lamps.180
chapter.ftnote: 1 I.E. assumes that only a high priest could appoint Aaron and his sons as priests.
2 See I.E. on Ex. 6:23 and the notes thereto.
3 Not Moses.
4 Aaron and his descendants.

5 Aaron was chosen because he married a woman belonging to the respected family of Nahshon. Aaron’s wife was Elisheba, the daughter of Amminadab, the sister of Nahshon (Ex. 6:23), prince of the tribe of Judah.
6 For marrying a Midianite women. I.E. comments thus because he has just noted that Aaron married the sister of Nahshon and was rewarded with the priesthood.
7 When he married Zipporah.
8 Moses had no opportunity to marry a Hebrew woman.
9 Hence he was not appointed high priest.
10 See Ex. 18:20-26. The point is that Moses was not punished for not marrying a Hebrew woman by having the priesthood taken away from him.
11 In other words, the vav in le-khahano is not a pronominal suffix, and le-khahano has the same meaning as le-khahen.
12 Chayeto has the same meaning as chayat. The vav in chayeto is not a pronominal suffix.
13 Beno has the same meaning as ben, for the vav in beno is not a pronominal suffix.

14 However, they were not fit to be priests (Krinsky). Hence they are not listed. I.E. comments thus because if all of Aaron’s sons had been fit to be priests, there would have been no need to list these four. It would have sufficed to state Aaron and his sons.
15 According to Josh. 20:19, 13 cities were set aside for the priests.
16 In other words, the garments had the power to sanctify those whom they touched; the garments per se were holy.
17 In verse 4.
18 Or beautify.
19 Which is in the singular.
20 Which is in the singular.

21 The phrase chakhme lev (wise-hearted) precedes milletiv (I have filled it). Since chakhme is plural, Scripture should have read milletim. Hence I.E.’s comment that milletiv refers to lev, which is singular.
22 In other words, Scripture first describes the priestly garments in the order in which they were removed when the high priest undressed.
23 Scripture next describes the garments in the order in which Aaron donned them, namely, tunic, mitre, and girdle (Filwarg).
24 The order is tunic, mitre, and girdle. I.E. connects the tunic and the girdle because the girdle was wound around the tunic.

25 This is the way Aaron put on his priestly garments. See Lev. 8:7, where Scripture describes the investiture of Aaron. It begins with the tunic, girdle, and robe, viz., And he put upon him the tunic, and girded him with the girdle, and clothed him with the robe, etc.
26 And first put on the priestly garments. See Lev. 8:6,7.
28 That is, in Lev. 8:7.
31 Hebrew, tzitz nezer ha-kodesh.
33 See Yoma 71b.
34 See verse 30.
35 Hence they are not included among the eight garments
36 Worn on the ephod and the tunic.
37 Cards containing the Divine Name.
38 After placing the mitre upon Aaron’s head and the plate over Aaron’s forehead.
39 That is, with the band of the ephod.
40 Hence the end of the verse, Moses bound it [the ephod] unto him [Aaron] therewith.
41 The word ephod means to girdle (Krinsky).
42 This verse concludes the account of Aaron’s donning his vestments. It clearly implies that the mitre was placed on Aaron last, rather than after the tunic.
43 In other words, va-yasem (and he set) has a pluperfect meaning: and he had set. See Vol. 1, p. xvi, item 4.

44 Zech. 3:4,5 reads: Take the filthy garments from off him…And I will clothe thee with robes. And I said: Let them set a fair mitre upon his head. The aforementioned shows that the mitre was donned following the robes. However, when Scripture describes what actually happened it says, So they seta fair mitre upon his head, and clothed him with garments (Zech. 3:5). The latter implies that the mitre was put on before the garments. Hence I.E.’s interpretation that and clothed him with garments (Ibid.) means, and they had already clothed him.
45 Hence the materials for the sacred garments were not measured out to the “wise hearted-men.” On the contrary, on their own they took the gold, the blue, etc. (Filwarg).
46 Even though in verse 4 it mentioned the breastplate first.
47 This shows that the breastplate was smaller than the ephod, for the smaller object is normally attached to a larger one.
48 In other words, the Torah implies that there was only one ephod, the one made by Moses. I.E. was especially bothered by the problem of the many ephods cited in Scripture.
49 Abiathar.
50 This verse implies that other ephods were employed in ancient Israel.
51 I Sam 23:6 reads “an ephod,” not “the ephod in his hand.”
52 That is, the ephod made by Moses. According to I.E. ephod means an ephod. The ephod, with the definite article prefixed to it, is the ephod made by Moses. See I.E. on Gen. 31:19, note 30.
53 The reference being to the ephod made by Moses.

54 According to I.E., that he came down with an ephod in his hand implies that Abiathar happened to have an ephod which he brought down, whereas if Scripture had read: that he brought down the ephod in his hand, it would have implied that Abiathar deliberately brought down the ephod. In the latter case, the reference would be to the ephod made by Moses.
55 The Biblical text has fourscore and five. If it is not a scribal error, then I.E. quoted from memory and erred.
56 We thus see that there were 80 ephods.
57 Spoken of in I Sam. 22:18.

58 Fourscore and five persons that did wear a linen ephod means fourscore and five persons who were fit to wear a linen ephod. In other words, they did not actually wear an ephod but were worthy of wearing the ephod made by Moses.
59 Their interpretation does not solve the problem of there being more than one ephod.
60 Hence I Sam. 22:18 cannot be interpreted as meaning that the priests were worthy of wearing the ephod made by Moses.
61 Shesh is a high quality linen.
62 In other words, even though our verse states that the ephod made by Moses contained linen it was not made wholly out of linen. It was made out of all the material enumerated in our verse (Weiser).

63 This introduces another problem connected with the ephod. Namely, it is clear from most places in Scripture that questions concerning future actions were directed to the Urim and Thummim, which were placed in the breastplate of judgment, which was placed on the ephod. However, David inquired of Abiathar’s ephod in Ziklag. Now as I.E. later shows, Abiathar’s ephod is not to be identified with Moses’ ephod. Thus in addition to the problem of a multiplicity of ephods, the question arises as to how these other ephods worked, as these ephods did not have the Urim and Thummim attached to them.
64 Spoken by David who asked: will the men of Keilah deliver me up into his [Saul’s] hand? will Saul come down, as thy servant hath heard? (I Sam. 23:11).
65 Prima facie, this verse implies that the ephod itself served as the instrument by which God’s will was divined.
66 And Thummim. See next note.
67 Thus it was the Urim and Thummim which served to reveal God’s will.
69 In Ziklag. This ephod did not have the Urim and Thummim with it. The problem described above in note 61 now follows.
70 It was attached to the ephod.
71 It was worn by the priest who accompanied the ark.
72 Moses’ ephod was with Saul. We thus see that other ephods served to divine God’s will.
73 Than the above-raised question relating to a multiplicity of ephods and how they worked.

74 “Urim [means] they made their words enlightening [and Thummim] because they fulfill their words” (Soncino, Yoma 73b). Rashi explains that the stones on the breastplate of judgment served as the instrument of divination by lighting up. See Rashi on verse 30. Also see note 88. However, Rashi does not identify the stones on the breastplate with the Urim and Thummim. Other commentaries taking the Talmud at face value did. It is with these commentaries that I.E. takes issue.
75 After describing how the stones were to be arranged on the breastplate.
76 It is thus clear that the Urim and Thummim are not to be identified with the stones on the breastplate of judgment.

77 The printed texts have ephod. This is an obvious error. The word ephod does not appear in Vat. Ebr. 38. The latter reads: “Scripture in describing its making,” the reference being to the making of the previously mentioned breastplate.
78 We thus see that the stones are part of the breastplate and are not to be identified with the Urim and Thummim.
79 In other words, the stones on the breastplate are not to be identified with the Urim and Thummim. See note 73.

80 As noted above, the Talmud explains that the letters on the stones lit up. It then says, “But the tzadi was not inscribed on any of the stones.” For none of the tribes has a tzadi in their names. The Talmud responds, “Rabbi Samuel ben Isaac says, ‘The names of Abraham, Isaac (Hebrew, yod, tzadi. chet, kof), and Jacob were also inscribed upon the stones’” (Yoma 73b).
81 See note 80. The Talmud says, “But the tet was not inscribed on the stones.” The words shivte yeshurun (the tribes of Jeshurun) were similarly inscribed on the stones” (Yoma 72b).
82 It does not help us to understand what the Urim and Thummim were.
83 And as we have seen, the Urim cannot be identical with the stones which were upon the breastplate.
84 In other words, we do not know what the Thummim were.
85 And we do not know what these objects were.
