86 See Rashi on verse 30: “The Urim and Thummim consisted of an inscription of God’s explicit name [upon some unknown material] which was placed inside the folds of the breastplate by means of which it [the breastplate] shed light upon its words and fulfilled its words.” That is, made its statements clear and its promises true.
87 According to Rabbi Hai Gaon, inscriptions of God’s explicit name cannot be used to divine the future. Nor do they assure success in any endeavor (Rabbi Samuel Zarza, Mekor Chayyim).

88 According to I.E. the ephod was an astrological instrument which corresponded to the arrangement of the heavens. It drew power from above and, when properly used, had the ability to predict the future. Nahmanides sided with Rashi’s interpretation of the ephod and took strong issue with I.E. See Nahmanides on verse 30, “Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra thought to display wisdom in the matter of the Urim and the Thummim, by saying that they were made by a craftsman from gold and silver, and he continued his discussion of them in this vein, for he thought that they were akin to the forms which the astrologers make in order to know the thoughts of the one who comes to ask of them [about the future]. But what [Ibn Ezra] said is of no import. Rather, the Urim and Thummim are as Rashi has written: this was an inscription of the Proper Name of G-d which was placed between the folds of the breast-plate” (Chavel translation).

89 So Zarza. I.E. does not explain what the two wreathen chains on the two rings stand for. Sarim suggests that a line is missing. However, it is possible that I.E. believed that, from what follows, it is obvious what the two wreathen chains on the two rings stand for.
90 The celestial equator extends from Aries to Libra. It divides the 12 constellations into two parts.

91 They represent the six constellations that lie on the other side of the equator. The point is that six names were written on the two stones of the ephod. Each group of names represented six constellations.
92 The division of the heavens into 12 distinct sections can only be grasped by the mind, for when one looks at the sky one does not see 12 distinct areas in the sky.
93 On one of the stones of the ephod.
94 Each stone contained six names. There were no boundaries between them. The stone, as it were, took in all the names in the same way that the sky encompasses all the stars.
95 Of the ephod.
96 That is, six names were not written on one stone and six on another, with their boundaries left to the imagination. See notes 92 and 93.
97 Each tribe’s name was inscribed on a separate stone.
98 To correspond to the stars that do not move out of their fixed orbits (Weiser).
99 They were removed from the folds of the breastplate.
100 They were of the same size.
101 They were both sapphires.
102 Each stone corresponded to a different constellation.
103 Which were placed upon the ephod.
104 See verse 12.
105 Judgment descended upon the children of Israel via each stone which represented a constellation.

106 According to I.E. ur is a variation of or and should thus be translated as light. Hence, according to I.E., Is. 44:16 should be rendered: I am warm, I have seen the light (Krinsky). It should be noted that Nahmanides’ text of I.E. reads: “The Urim and Thummim were made out of gold.”
107 The root of tummim (thummim) is taf, mem, mem.
108 I.E. does not identify the material that the Thummim were made of.

109 It has been established by irrefutable proof that the 12 constellations of the upper world determine the fate of all human beings who dwell in the lower world. Or the importance of the number twelve has been established by the fact that there are 12 constellations in the upper world and 12 tribes of Israel in the lower world (Weiser).
110 The reference is either to the number 12 or to how the ephod functioned.
111 It was a duplicate of the ephod made by Moses. Hence astrologically speaking it “worked.”
112 The priest received an answer only at a propitious time.
113 Of how the ephod worked.
114 In his Bible translation.
115 I.E. makes the same point in Genesis. See I.E. on Gen. 2:11 and the notes thereto.
116 That is, Saadiah Gaon explained sappir to as a white stone. See I.E. on Ex. 24:10.
117 That is, sappir is a red stone. As noted before, sapphire is usually blue, sometimes white, hardly ever red. See chapter 24, note 3.
118 Of the breastplate.
119 Hebrew, odem (a red stone).
120 That the sappir is a red stone. In other words, one should not assume that there was only one red stone on the breastplate.
121 The color of lightning. I.E. probably means yellow.
122 Its place is third among the five colors.
123 The root of pukh is peh, vav, kaf.

124 Which Saadiah understood to mean: and she darkened or blackened her eyes. Pukh is a “black mineral powder, for increasing brilliance of eyes by darkening edges of lids.” (Hebrew and English Lexicon of the Old Testament, edited by Brown, Driver, Briggs, Oxford University Press, Oxford).
125 In other words, the root of nofekh is nun, peh, kaf. Hence nofekh and pukh are two different words.
126 Wherein all three stem letters are present.
127 Al mus in Arabic.
128 For its root is heh, lamed, mem. The yod of yahalom is a form letter.
129 Which is not a root letter; the root of yitzhar is tzadi, heh, resh.
130 Al chelmah in Arabic.
131 The Hebrew word for a dream is chalom.
132 That a stone can induce dreams.
133 A magnetic stone.
134 The original root of sharsherot is shin, resh, shin. However, the resh was doubled and a new quadriliteral root, shin, resh, shin, resh, formed. The latter is the root of sharsherot.
135 The root of sharshot is shin, resh, shin.

136 It has no synonym. According to Sarim, I.E. believes that gavlut, choshen, and some of the other terms used by Scripture in relation to the choshen are not Hebrew words. We consequently do not know their meaning.

137 I.E.’s point is that the root resh, kaf, samekh (the root of ve-yirkesu and me-rukhse) means twisted. He renders Ps. 31:21: from the twisted actions of men. He similarly explains that ve-yirkesu et ha-choshen…al chesehev ha-ephod means that the choshen shall be twisted (that is, attached, for when one attaches something by a thread he twists it) upon the skillfully woven band of the ephod (Meijler). For other interpretations, see Krinsky.

138 It is interesting to note that I.E. believes that people also addressed legal questions to the Urim and Thummim. This goes against the accepted Rabbinic doctrine that laws are to be decided by legal authorities rather than by supernatural means.
139 The Hebrew term used by I.E. is sarbal.
140 That is, the me’il differs from a cloak in that the me’il has an opening on top for the head.
141 Zevachim 88:b. Also see Rashi on verse 33.
142 Nahmanides accepted this opinion.
143 The plate. Tzitz is masculine but I.E. uses the feminine pronoun (hi) because he is referring to atzabah, the Arabic equivalent of tzitz.

144 The Hebrew reads, ve-hi netunah al ha-mitznefet, ve-enennah ki-demut keter ki hu al ha-metzach le-vado. It is rather strange that I.E. first employs pronouns which refer to the Arabic form of the word and then employs a pronoun which refers to the Hebrew form of the word. It should be noted that Vat. Ebr. 38 has a totally different reading. It reads: “The Gaon renders tzitz (plate) atzabah. It is placed on the mitre. The mitre does not have the shape of head-tires, for the head-tires are similar to the high hats which men in this and surrounding countries place upon their heads as a head covering. However, the mitres are made out of long thin material which is twisted only around the head.” There is no inconsistency in the tenses in this reading.
145 Whereas a crown covers the entire head.
146 Worn by an ordinary priest, in contrast to the mitznefet (mitre) worn by the high priest.
147 Worn by the high priest.
148 In other words, the mitre had a shape which allowed the priest to attach the plate to it.
149 In other words, the high priest was not donning a woman’s garment.
150 Rashi.

151 According to Rashi, verse 37 appears to contradict itself and Ex. 39:31. For verse 37 states, And thou shalt put it (the plate) on a thread of blue. However, it goes on to say, and it (the plate) shall be upon the mitre. This implies that the plate was on the mitre, not upon the thread. Furthermore, Ex. 39:31 states, And they tied unto it [the plate] a thread of blue. In other words, verse 37 implies that the plate was placed upon the thread, but Ex. 39:31 implies that the thread was placed on top of the plate.

152 Rashi explains that the plate was perforated at three points, viz., at the top and at the two ends of the plate. A thread was inserted through each of these perforations. Each thread was thus doubled when pulled through. Hence Rashi speaks of six threads. The threads were then tied together at the back of the neck. The thread in the center passed over the head and was bound with the ends of the two other threads. Rashi explains: “All the verses are now harmonized, a thread upon the plate, and the plate upon the thread, and a thread upon the mitre on top.” The first refers to the threads on the outer side of the plate, the second to the threads on the inner side of the plate, and the third to the threads that passed through the middle perforation.
153 Attached to both extremities of the plate.
154 In other words, al here means with. Hence verse 37 does not contradict Ex. 39:31. See note 152. Also see note 153.
155 Contra Rashi. See note 154.
156 The two far sides.
157 In other words, upon the forefront of the mitre it [the plate] shall be means that the plate shall be on the forehead.
158 The front of the mitre.
159 In other words, on the mitre does not mean on the mitre per se, as Rashi says (see note 152) but upon the forehead. Hence Ex. 39:31 does not contradict Ex. 28:37.
160 In the sense of with. The word al usually has the meaning of on. Hence I.E.’s comment.
161 Al used in the sense of with.
162 Translated according to I.E.

163 In other words, contra Rashi on this verse, the mitre and the head-tire are not identical, for if they were, Scripture would interchange these terms. I.E. literally reads: “Now you will never find.” This is a very laconic statement. Some would emend it to: Now we do not find [the mitre] to be worn [by all the priests]. In other words, the mitre is not to be identified with the head-tire.
164 In other words, the migba’at had the shape of a high hat.
165 Hebrew, mitznefet.
166 Hence it is not to be identified with the migba’at.

167 According to I.E. the meaning of the verse is: The mitre shall be removed…this shall no more be the same; the material making up the mitre shall no longer be wound from the bottom up or from the top down; i.e., the miztnefet shall no longer be wound about the head.
168 Not to be confused with the word keter (crown), as the keter covers the entire head.
169 In that the root of the word tzitz is used in connection with nezer.
170 The word tzitz in our chapter and the word yatzitz in Ps. 132:18.
171 According to I.E. the plate atones for improper thoughts.
172 Ha-ketonet, with the definite article.
173 The definite article is omitted, as it does not refer to the chequered tunic.
174 Here too the definite article is omitted because the reference is to non-chequered tunics.
175 Saadiah Gaon renders ve-shibatzta ha-ketonet as: you shall make the tunic eye-like (Weiser); that is, the tunic shall consist of eye-like designs.
176 I.E.’s explanation of Saadiah Gaon’s interpretation.

177 Our verse reads, And thou shalt put them upon Aaron thy brother, and upon his sons with him. I.E. explains that the verse is to be read as if written: And thou shalt put them upon Aaron thy brother, and thou shalt put them upon his sons with him. The first “them” refers to Aaron’s garments and the second “them” to his sons’ garments.
178 You shall declare them to be holy (Weiser).
179 The meaning of which is, the priest shall declare him to be unclean. Translated according to I.E.
180 Or to perform any other service (Weiser).

chapter.title: Chapter 29
chapter.p: 1. AND THIS IS THE THING THAT THOU SHALT DO UNTO THEM. To Aaron and his sons.

[TAKE.] There is no difference1 between lekach (take)2 and kach (take).3 We find the same to be true of tzak (pour out)4 and yetzak (pour)5 in Pour out (tzak) for the people, that they may eat (II Kings 4:41) and in And also pour (yetzak) water into it (Ezek. 24:3).

[ONE YOUNG BULLOCK.] The fact that Scripture notes that the par (bull) was a ben bakar (of the herd)6 indicates that the par (bull) was young. The same applies to the phrase bene yonah (turtle-doves)7 (Lev. 1:14), and the phrase se’_ir izzim (a goat) (Lev. 4:23).8

[AND TWO RAMS.] An ayal (ram)9 is older than a keves (lamb). The fact that the drink offering for an ayal (ram) consists of a third of a hin10 and that of a keves (lamb) a quarter of a hin11 proves this.12
2. AND UNLEAVENED…CAKES. They were thick, as wafers13 unleavened proves.14
[WITH OIL.] Scripture reads ba-shemen (with oil).15 The reference, in keeping with the rule,16 is to olive oil.17

[Of FINE WHEATEN FLOUR.] The word solet (fine flour) refers to flour made from wheat cleansed of all impurities. It is called samid in Arabic.18 It is produced in the land of the Ishmaelites. There is no better bread than bread made from it.19

Many connect the word solet to the word salita20 (thou hast trodden)21 in Thou hast trodden light all them that err from Thy statutes (Ps. 119:118);22 and to sillah (trodden) in The Lord hath trodden All my mighty men in the midst of me (Lam. 1:15).23 They say that makkolet (food) in food to your household (I Kings 5:25)24 is similar.25 Others say that solet means ground.26
3. AND BRING THEM IN THE BASKET. You shall bring the bread, which is in the basket as the law requires,27 to the door of the tent of meeting.28 The same applies to the bullock and the rams.29
5. AND THOU SHALT TAKE THE GARMENTS. The breastplate (choshen) is called a garment30 because it covers that part of the body which lies opposite the heart.

6. AND THOU SHALT SET. It is also31 not beyond the realm of possibility that Moses placed the mitre on Aaron last.32 Scripture mentions the mitre before the girdle33 at the opening of the Torah portion34 because the mitre is more important than the girdle.35

7. HIS HEAD. Only on Aaron’s head,36 as he was the anointed priest. Now Aaron was anointed before the mitre was placed on his head,37 for Moses poured the oil only upon the head.38 We similarly read, It is like the precious oil upon the head, Coming down upon the beard; Even Aaron’s beard (Ps. 133:2).39
8. AND THOU SHALT BRING HIS SONS. To the door of the tent of meeting.

9. AND THOU SHALT GIRD THEM WITH GIRDLES. Girdles takes in Aaron’s girdle and the girdle of his sons.40 Similarly the breeches.41 After stating them, Scripture goes on to explain that the reference is to Aaron and his sons. It is similar to And she opened it, and saw it, even the child (Ex. 2:6).42
[AND BIND.] The word ve-chavashta (and bind) is similar to the word chovesh (healer) in I will not be a healer (Is. 3:7).43

AND THOU SHALT CONSECRATE. The one who translated the Torah into Aramaic44 is of the opinion that u-milleta yad (and thou shalt consecrate)45 is similar to u-milu yadav (so shall they consecrate it)46 (Ezek. 43:26).47 However, what shall we do with milu yedkhem ha-yom48 (consecrate yourselves today to the Lord) (Ex. 32:29)?49

Saadiah Gaon explains the word yad to mean obligation.50 Others say that the term melu’im (consecration)51 is used because it indicates that they are complete, full, and trained.52 However, what will they do with u-mile’u yadav (so shall they consecrate it53) (Ezek. 43:26)?54

10. AND THOU SHALT BRING THE BULLOCK. This has already been mentioned.55 Its meaning is as follows. When you shall bring the bullock,56 Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands upon it.57 Some say that the meaning of and Aaron shall lay58 is: Aaron alone shall first lay his hands upon the head of the bullock. His sons shall then do the same. Now with regard to the ram, Scripture later states, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands upon the head of the ram (v. 15). Scripture thus describes exactly what happened. They should lay their hands together, not one after the other.59
11. AND THOU SHALT KILL THE BULLOCK. Moses slaughtered the bullock.

[BEFORE THE LORD.] Scripture reads, before the Lord,60 because the ark was in the center of the western side of the tabernacle. The incense altar was directly aligned with it. So was the altar of the burnt offerings.61
12. HE SHALL POUR OUT.62 The priest who pours shall pour out.63
13. AND THOU SHALT TAKE. Bullock and goats do not have a fat tail (alyah).64

[KIDNEYS.] Some say that kelayot (kidneys) are so called because the word kelayot is related to the word kaletah (pineth) in My soul yearneth, yea even pineth for the courts of the Lord (Ps. 84:3). For the power of sexual desire is located in the kidneys.
14. BUT THE FLESH OF THE BULLOCK. Flesh takes in the head and the pieces of the bullock.
AND ITS DUNG.65 Logically speaking,66 it67 was to be washed and then it68 was to be burned.69.
AND HE SHALL MAKE THEM SMOKE (ve-hiktir).70 The reference is to the enumerated organs.71

[SIN-OFFERING.] A sin offering is called a chatat 72 because it is brought to atone for a sin. The same applies to the asham (guilt-offering).73 Hence the meaning of ve-chitte’u et ha-mizbe’ach (they shall purify the altar)74 is: they shall remove the sin from the altar.
15. THOU SHALT ALSO TAKE THE ONE RAM. Any one of the two rams which you decide to choose.75

16. AND THOU SHALT SLAY THE RAM, AND THOU SHALT TAKE ITS BLOOD AND DASH IT ROUND ABOUT AGAINST THE ALTAR. Not on the corners of the altar.76 Look, he [Moses] shall dash all the blood round about against the altar and not upon the base of the altar.77
17. AND THE RAM. Scripture does not mention that Moses was commanded to cut the bullock into pieces. It was therefore entirely burned. Hence Scripture does not mention the bullock’s legs.78
AND WASH.79 By command.80
18. AND THOU SHALT MAKE THE WHOLE RAM SMOKE. Hence the fat tail and the fat81 are not mentioned.82
19. AND THOU SHALT TAKE. This second ram served as the ram of consecration.83
20. THEN THOU SHALT KILL…TIP. The word tenukh (tip) has no counterpart.84 Saadiah Gaon says that it refers to the soft tissue which is connected to the circle of the ear.85
THE GREAT TOE. The plural of bohen (great toe) is behonot (Jud. 1:6). This is grammatically inconsistent.86 This noun is thus vocalized according to two paradigms.87 There are many such nouns.
[AND DASH THE BLOOD.] The blood of the second ram shall be dashed88 like the blood of the first ram.89 The reference is only to the remaining blood.90
21. AND THOU SHALT TAKE OF THE BLOOD THAT IS UPON THE ALTAR…AND SPRINKLE IT UPON AARON, AND UPON HIS GARMENTS. Beneath his garments91 and upon his garments.
22. AND THOU SHALT TAKE OF THE RAM THE FAT. The reference is to the fat that is upon the innards, as stated in the Torah portion Va-Yikra.92

THE RIGHT THIGH. The thigh that is on the right side93 and the breast were taken from the ram of consecration. From that day on, the thigh and the breast of peace offerings were to be given to Aaron and his sons.94 However, Moses alone ate the breast of the ram of consecration because he was a high priest.95
23. AND ONE LOAF OF BREAD. The reference is to the unleavened bread (v. 2).
24. AND SHALT WAVE THEM. While they96 are in the hands of Aaron and his sons.97
25. AND THOU SHALT TAKE THEM FROM THEIR HANDS. Our verse states, from their hands. Elsewhere Scripture states, from off their hands (Lev. 8:28). They mean the same thing.
A SWEET SAVOUR. The chet is doubled in nicho’ach (sweet savour).98
[A SWEET SAVOUR BEFORE THE LORD.] The one who understands the secret of man’s soul99 will understand this.100
AN OFFERING. The word issheh (offering) is an adjective. It is related to the word esh (fire). Scripture elsewhere states, from the fire (Num. 18:9).101
26. AND THOU SHALT TAKE. From Aaron’s ram. Aaron’s sons are not mentioned,102 as Aaron was the principal.
[PORTION.] The word manah means a portion.
27. AND THOU SHALT SANCTIFY. From this day and henceforth.103 Waving and heaving are not identical.104 For what is heaved is lifted up. It is not waved.105
The meaning of even their heave-offering (v. 28) is: the heave offerings which they will separate from peace offerings, shall be heaved in honor of God.106
29. AND THE HOLY GARMENTS OF AARON SHALL BE FOR HIS SONS AFTER HIM. Shall be for his son who is anointed in his place.107
[AFTER HIM.] After his death.

30. SEVEN DAYS. The word yilbasham (put them on) is vocalized with a long rather than a short kamatz.108 The word amilam (I will cut them off) in Verily, in the name of the Lord I will cut them off (Ps. 118:10) is similar.109
31. AND SEETHE. By command.110 It is similar to and thou shalt smite the rock (Ex. 17:6),111 and to So Solomon built the house (I Kings 6:14).112
32. AND AARON AND HIS SONS SHALL EAT. The bread remaining in the basket.113
33. AND THEY SHALL EAT THOSE THINGS. The verse is abridged.114
[THEM.] The word otam (them) also refers to something else.115
BUT A STRANGER. Who is not of Aaron’s seed.
34. AND IF AUGHT. The ram of consecration is so called because they are consecrated by it.116

35. THEE. The word otakhah has an etnach117 beneath it.118 Otakhah is a combination of otakh (thee) (Gen. 39:9), which is vocalized with a long kamatz beneath the tav, and otekha (thee)119 in for thee have I seen (Gen. 7:1).
36. AND EVERY DAY SHALT THOU OFFER THE BULLOCK. Every day of the seven days of consecration.

[BESIDE THE OTHER OFFERINGS OF ATONEMENT.] Its meaning is, in addition to the two rams.120 Scripture further states, As hath been done this day, so the Lord hath commanded to do,121 to make atonement for you (Lev. 8:34).
37. MOST HOLY. The meaning of kodesh kodashim (most holy) is holy like any other holy object.122

WHATSOEVER TOUCHES THE ALTAR SHALL BE HOLY. This is similar to Whatsoever shall touch the flesh thereof shall be holy (Lev. 6:20).123 Some say that the verse speaks only of the bread. Scripture is telling us that if the bread is not holy, that is, if the bread is unclean, then it shall not touch the altar.124

38. NOW THIS IS. Its meaning is: now this is the sacrifice.125 Similarly, the meaning of This they shall give (Ex. 30:13) is: this amount they shall give.126 Similarly And this is that thou shalt make it 127 (Gen. 6:15).128 Moses shall do this129 during the seven days of consecration. Afterwards130 Aaron and his sons shall do likewise.

39. THE ONE LAMB. The heh prefixed to the word keves (lamb) also serves as a prefix to the word echad (one).131 The phrase is to be read as if written, et ha-keves ha-echad (the one lamb).132 Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that the meaning of et ha-keves echad is, the lamb, one lamb.133
40. A TENTH PART. A tenth part of an ephah.
[A HIN.] Also note that hin is an Egyptian measure.134
41. AND. The word u-kheniskah (and according to the drink offering thereof)135 refers to boker (morning).136

42. IT SHALL BE A CONTINUAL BURNT-OFFERING THROUGHOUT YOUR GENERATIONS. They shall bring these offerings when they enter the land of Canaan. For the Israelites offered burnt offerings only for fifty days in the desert of Sinai. This is what Scripture means by It is a continual burnt-offering, which was offered in mount Sinai (Num. 28:6). The tabernacle was placed at the edge of the camp at the bottom of the mount,137 as the tribes were intermingled.138 On the first day of the second month139 they began to know the number of each tribe and to make standards (Num. 1 and 2).140 After they traveled a distance of a three-day journey from Mount Sinai, the ark journeyed141 in the midst of the camps (Num. 10:33).142

Logically speaking, the Israelites offered burnt offerings and sacrifices only at Sinai and on Yom Kippur in the second year. This is what Scripture states regarding Aaron’s service.143 The Torah there writes, And he [Aaron] did as the Lord commanded Moses (Lev. 16:34).144

Scripture similarly states, Did ye bring unto Me sacrifices and offerings in the wilderness forty years, O house of Israel? (Amos 5:25). Israel spent about thirty-eight years in a wasteland, in a howling wilderness (Deut. 32:10). Where did they get half a hin of olive oil and a half hin of wine daily?145 How could they carry almost fourteen thousand hin around with them?146 Where did they get two lambs daily in the first year? Where did they get the animals for the additional sacrifices on the Sabbath and the festivals?

The statement we and our cattle (Num. 20:4)147 does not refute our contention, for Israel was then at Kadesh,148 and they bought cattle from the settled population. Furthermore, they looted the Midianites and the lands of Sihon and Og in that year. They thus had an abundance of cattle.149
[I WILL MEET.]150 Scripture clearly explains the reason that the tabernacle is called the ohel mo’ed (the tent of meeting).151
WITH YOU. Israel.152 We find this to be the case when the congregation was called together.153

TO SPEAK THERE UNTO THEE. To speak there alone to you.154 However, Yefet says that the meaning of I will meet with you is: with Moses and occasionally with Aaron.155 He maintains that to speak there unto thee156 hints that God will continually speak there with Moses. He offers, And there I will meet with the children of Israel (v. 43) as proof.157

43. AND [THE TENT] SHALL BE SANCTIFIED BY MY GLORY. I believe that the tent of meeting was the place of meeting because it took in everything, namely, the tabernacle and all its utensils, the ark, and the three objects.158 The tent will be sanctified by My glory, which will rest on the cherubim.159

44. AND I WILL SANCTIFY THE TENT OF MEETING. It is because of the glory that the tent is holy, for it was sanctified by the glory.160 The altar that stood161 before the opening of the tent of meeting was similarly sanctified.162
AARON ALSO AND HIS SONS WILL I SANCTIFY. I will sanctify Aaron and his sons, who minister in the tent of meeting and upon the altar.

45. AND I WILL DWELL. Scripture describes how God’s glory will dwell among the children of Israel when the standards will be set up.163 Four standards were set up on the four sides.164 Additionally, there was a separation between the camp of the Levites and the camp of the Israelites165 because they too camped on all four sides,166 There was another barrier beyond this barrier where the tent of meeting was placed amidst the children of Israel.

Now a person who experienced a seminal emission did not have to leave the camp of Israel.167 Neither was there a place set aside beyond the border of the camp for a person to sit down [and relieve himself].168 The commandment for a person who experienced a seminal emission to leave the camp169 applied only to the camp of Israel when it went to war against the enemy.170 The commandment When thou goest forth in camp against thine enemies (Deut. 23:10) similarly does not speak of the entire camp of Israel, men, women, and children. It is only males, and then only a small number of them, who sally out to wage war. Now when the soldiers of Israel carried the ark with them as Phineas did,171 they were unable to set up a barrier between themselves and the place of the ark.172

46. AND THEY SHALL KNOW. Its meaning is, then they shall know that the only reason that I took them out of Egypt was so that they would make a sanctuary for Me that I may dwell among them. This is what Scripture means by ye shall serve God upon this mountain (Ex. 3:12).173
chapter.ftnote: 1 In meaning.
2 The kal imperativel form of the root lamed, kof, chet used in our verse.
3 The usual kal imperativel form of the root lamed, kof chet.
4 The usual kal imperativel form of the root yod, tzadi, kof.
5 A lesser used kal imperativel form of the root yod, tzadi, kof.
6 The term ben indicates a young animal (Krinsky).
7 The term bene indicates young birds (Krinsky).
8 A mature goat is called a se’ir. A young goat is a se’ir izzim (Krinsky).
9 Our verse speaks of elim (rams). Hence I.E.’s comment.
12 For the bigger the animal, the bigger the drink offering. See Num. 28:14.

13 Hebrew, rekike. Rekike is connected to the word rek (empty, poor, or thin) (Krinsky). See rakkot basar (lean-fleshed) (Gen. 41:19). Thus rekike matzot (wafers unleavened) means thin unleavened bread.
14 The wafers stand in contrast to the bread and cakes. Thus if the wafers are thin, the bread and cakes must be thick.
15 Rather than be-shemen. The reference is to the previously mentioned oil, i.e., the oil mentioned in Ex. 27:20. See note 17.

16 Hebrew, ka-mishpat. The rule referred to by I.E. is either the rule stated in Ex. 27:20 (Krinsky) or the rules of Hebrew referred to in note 17. It is also possible that what I.E. means by shemen zayit ka-mishpat is olive oil prepared according to the rule, that is, beaten olive oil. See Ex. 27:20 (Sarim).
17 The pattach beneath the bet indicates the definite article. Thus the meaning of ba-shemen is, with the oil, i.e., the earlier mentioned oil.
18 This type of flour, or bread made from it is still produced in Moslem countries.
19 Or there is no better bread than it. See note 18.
20 From the root samekh, lamed, heh.
21 This is the opinion of Jonah ibn Janach (Krinsky).
22 Translated according to I.E.

23 Translated according to I.E. According to these commentaries the word solet means trodden grain, that is, grain that has been broken up into pieces (Krinsky). Kimchi accepted this definition of solet.
24 I Kings 5:25 reads: food to his household.

25 The question arises: If solet is connected to salita and sillah, then where does the tav in solet come from? For both salita and sillah come from the root samekh, lamed, heh. These commentaries therefore point out that we find something similar with the word makkolet. Makkolet comes from the root kaf, lamed, heh (Meijler). However, a form tav is added to it in its normal form. The same is true of the tav in solet. See Weiser and Meijler.
26 Finely ground flour.
27 Namely, And thou shalt put them into one basket.
28 In other words, and bring them means: and bring them to the door of the tent of meeting.
29 They too shall be brought to the door of the tent of meeting.
30 Our verse includes it among the priestly garments. However, it was not really a garment. Hence I.E.’s comment.
31 See note 32.

32 After placing all the other garments upon Aaron, for this is what the plain meaning of our text implies. This should be contrasted with I.E. ‘s comments on Ex. 28:4. There he wrote that Moses placed the mitre on Aaron’s head after dressing him in his tunic. I.E. was not sure what the procedure was. Hence he uses the expression, “It is also not beyond the realm of possibility.”
34 Even though the girdle was put on before the mitre, as the mitre was put on last.
35 That is, according to this interpretation. Scripture mentions the mitre before the girdle, even though the girdle was put on first, because the mitre is more important.
36 The anointing oil was poured only upon Aaron’s head.

37 Even though Scripture mentions the donning of the mitre before it mentions the anointment. Nahmanides takes issue with I.E. He writes, “He wound [the mitznefet] around and around the head, but left the middle of the head uncovered, and it was on that place that he poured the oil” (Ramban’s Commentary on the Torah, Chavel translation).
38 Not upon the mitre. Hence the oil had to be poured upon Aaron’s head before the mitre was placed upon it.
39 We thus see that the oil was poured only over Aaron’s head. It was not poured upon the mitre.

40 The term refers both to Aaron’s girdle and to that of his sons because they all wore the same type of girdle (Krinsky). Sarim is of the opinion that Aaron’s girdle differed from the girdle of his sons. According to Sarim, I.E. is explaining that the term girdles refers both to Aaron’s girdle and to the girdle of his sons even though their girdles differed.

41 Moses similarly placed breeches upon Aaron and his sons even though Scripture omits mentioning this. Nahmanides held that Moses did not put breeches on Aaron and his sons. He explains that they put on their breeches in private. Hence Scripture omits the donning of the breeches.
42 See I.E. on Ex. 2:6 and the notes thereto.
43 Literally, a binder, that is, a binder of wounds.
44 Onkelos.
45 Literally, and you shall fill the hand.
46 Literally, and they shall fill its (the altar’s) hands (Targum). See Targum Jonathan on this verse.
47 Onkelos similarly renders u-milleta yad aharon ve-yad banav as u-tekarev kurbana de-aharon ve-kurbana di-venohi (and you shall offer the sacrifice of Aaron and the sacrifice of his children).
48 Literally, fill your hands today.
49 Ex. 32:29 speaks of killing those who worshipped the golden calf. Thus the term “fill your hand” cannot mean offer a sacrifice.
50 According to Saadiah u-milleta yad aharon ve-yad banav means: see to it that Aaron and his sons fulfill their obligation. Thus according to the Gaon, to fill the hand means to do one’s duty.
51 Literally, filled.
52 Thus the phrase to fill the hand means train the hand. See I.E.’s short commentary, “During the days of melu’im the priest learned…to train his hands in the service.”
53 That is, the altar.
54 According to their interpretation we should render it, so shall they train the altar. This makes no sense.
55 In verse 3. The question thus arises, “Why repeat it?”
56 In other words, ve-hikravta (and thou shalt bring) is to be rendered, when thou shalt bring. Hence Scripture is not being redundant. See note 57.
57 This is not mentioned in verse 3.
58 The text literally reads: and Aaron shall lay and his sons their hands on the head of the bullock. Ve-samakh (shall lay) is in the singular. Hence the interpretation quoted by I.E.

59 For the text reads, ve-samekhu (shall lay). Ve-samekhu is in the plural. The commentaries on I.E. differ over how to interpret this comment. Some take it to mean that I.E. indicates there was no difference in procedure between the laying of the hands upon the bullock and the laying of the hands upon the rams; in both cases Aaron and his sons put their hands upon the sacrificial animals in unison (Krinsky). Meijler is of the opinion that I.E. believes that in contrast to the laying of the hands upon the rams, Aaron first laid his hands upon the bullock and then his sons did the same. The difference of opinion revolves around how we interpret “Scripture thus describes exactly what happened.” Krinsky takes it to refer to both instances, while Meijler takes it to refer only to the second instance. For further elucidation, see Filwarg.
60 Before the Lord seems to imply before the ark. However, the bullock was sacrificed before the altar which stood in the temple courtyard.
61 Which stood in the courtyard.

62 Yishpokh. In our text of the Pentateuch the reading is: Thou shalt pour out (tishpokh). Meijler and Krinsky believe that I.E.’s version of the Pentateuch reads yishpokh (he shall pour out). However, Weiser believes that the reading of yishpokh is due to a copyist’s error. According to Weiser, I.E. also reads tishpokh (thou shalt pour out), and I.E. commented thereupon: Yishpokh ha-kohen ha-shofekh (The priest who pours shall pour out). In other words, I.E. explained, that Thou shalt pour is not to be taken literally, for Moses was not commanded to personally pour out the blood. He was told to appoint a priest to carry out this task. Some copyist then dropped the word tishpokh from the heading and made yishpokh into a heading. Hence our reading.
63 All the remaining blood at the base of the altar. See note 63.
64 But rams do. See verse 22. Hence Scripture does not mention the fat tail here as it does when discussing the rams.
65 So Vat. Ebr. 38. Also see Meijler.
66 The dung was not burned.
67 The place in the animal where the dung was collected shall be cleansed (Krinsky). For another interpretation, see note 69.
68 Krinsky explains that the meaning of and its dung shalt thou burn is: and the place where the dung collected thou shalt burn.

69 Filwarg emends u-firsho (and its dung) to u-lefi. He interprets But the flesh of the bullock as follows: Flesh takes in the head and the pieces of the bullock. Now logically speaking, it was to be washed and then it was to be burned; i.e., the bullock was to be washed in the same manner that the ram (v. 17) was. See Weiser, Sarim, and Filwarg.

70 The word ve-hiktir (and he shall make them smoke) does not appear in our verse. Weiser suggests that it has been transposed from verse 13. However, verse 13 reads ve-hiktarta (and make them smoke). Weiser explains that the original comment on verse 13 reads as follows: Ve-hiktarta (and [thou shalt] make them smoke). Commenting on this, I.E. writes: Ve-hiktir (and he shall make them smoke). That is, Moses himself was not commanded to personally place the organs on the fire; another priest would do as well. For some reason, a copyist left out the heading ve-hiktarta and the word ve-hiktir was transposed to verse 14. Meijler, on the other hand, claims that the word ve-hiktir should not be read as a heading but rather as the continuation of the previous sentence. The latter should read: Logically speaking, it was washed and then it was burned. After this, the priest smoked the enumerated organs.
71 The organs listed in verse 13.
72 A sin.
73 Literally, guilt. The sacrifice is referred to as “guilt” because it is brought to atone for one’s guilt.
74 Literally, and they shall sin the altar.
75 In other words, the word ha-echad (the one) is short for ha-echad me-hashenayim (one of the two). I.E. comments thus because the one ram seems to imply that Scripture has a specific ram in mind.
76 As was done with the blood of the bullock. See verse 12.
77 As was done with the blood of the bullock. See verse 12.
78 As it does with regard to the ram.
79 Literally, and thou shalt wash.
80 Moses was to command someone to wash the ram. He did not personally have to do so, as implied by the literal meaning of the verse.
81 Which are mentioned with regard to the second ram. See verse 22.
82 For they are included in the term the whole ram.
83 See verse 31. Also see Lev. 8:22.

84 Hebrew, en lo re’a. This usually indicates that the word appears nowhere else in Scripture. See I.E. on Num. 11:7. However, the word tenukh appears six times in the Book of Leviticus. Hence Krinsky interprets en lo chaver as meaning: it has no counterpart except with regard to the ear.
85 The earlobe.
86 According to the rules of Hebrew grammar the plural of bohen is behanot, not behonot. Compare, goren, geranot. The singular of bahon is behonot (Weiser).
87 The singular and plural follow different paradigms.
88 Against the altar round about.
89 See verse 16.
90 The blood that remains after some blood has first been placed on the tip of the right ear, the right thumb, and the great toe of Aaron and his sons.
91 That is, upon Aaron’s body. The blood and the anointing oil were first sprinkled upon Aaron’s body and then, when Aaron dressed, upon his garments (Krinsky).

93 The word shok (thigh) is feminine. Hence our verse should have read, shok ha-yeminit, rather than shok ha-yamin (the right side). Hence I.E. points out that shok ha-yamin is short for shok tzad ha-yamin (the thigh that is on the right side). Tzad is masculine. Hence the use of the masculine form yamin.
95 Moses served as high priest during the days of consecration.
96 The organs and bread listed in verse 22 and 23.
97 Moses placed his hand beneath the hands of Aaron and his sons and waved their hands along with their contents (Krinsky).
98 The root of nicho’ach is nun, vav, chet. There are two chets in nicho’ach. Hence I.E.’s comment.
99 Namely, that “A human being cannot speak of things above or below him without employing human terminology.” See I.E. on Gen. 1:26.
100 Why the Torah must employ anthropomorphic language (Weiser).
101 In other words, Scripture uses the word esh in place of the word issheh. We thus see that they are related.
102 Even though the ram of sanctification was also theirs (Krinsky).
103 So too Rashi, “Sanctify them for all time.”
104 Our verse speaks of that which is waved (hunaf) and that which is heaved (huram). Hence I.E.’s comment.
105 Heaving, literally lifting, refers to an up and down motion. Waving is a to and fro motion. See Rashi on verse 24.

106 Verse 28 reads, for it is a heave-offering; and it shall be a heave-offering from the children of Israel of their sacrifices of peace-offerings, even their heave-offering unto the Lord. The phrase even their heave-offering unto the Lord appears to be redundant. Hence I.E.’s comment that the verse is to be understood as follows: For it is a heave offering; and it shall be a heave offering from the children of Israel of their sacrifices of peace offerings. Now these heave offerings which they will separate from their peace offerings shall be heaved in honor of God. See Krinsky and Meijler.
107 In other words, for his sons means for those of his sons who are anointed in his place.
108 A tzerah. According to the rules of grammar the word should read yilbashem. Compare, yishlakhem.
109 It too is vocalized with a kamatz in place of a tzere, as the word should have read amilem.
110 Moses did not have to personally seethe the flesh of the ram of consecration.

111 Nahmanides reads, and thy rod, wherewith thou smotest the river (Ex. 17:5). The commentaries believe this to be the correct reading because I.E. explicitly states that the latter was by Moses’ command. See I.E. on Ex. 17:5.
112 Solomon commanded the temple to be built. He obviously did not personally build it.
113 “After the rite described in verse 23 had been carried out” (Cohen). The bread that is in the basket might be taken to mean all the bread in the basket. Hence I.E.’s comment.

114 The subject is missing. According to I.E.’s short commentary on Exodus our verse literally reads: And they shall eat those things who atoned by them. The latter is short for: And the men who atoned by them shall eat those things.

115 The word otam (them) in le-kadesh otam (to sanctify them) also applies to ve-zar lo yokhkal (but a stranger shall not eat). The latter is to be read as if written ve-zar lo yokhkal otam (but a stranger shall not eat them).
116 Literally, their hands become full by it. For the meaning of this expression, see I.E. on verse 9.
117 A note indicating a pause.
118 Hence the tav is vocalized with a kamatz rather than with a sheva, i.e., otakhah rather than otekha.
119 Which is vocalized with a kamatz beneath the kaf.
120 Which were offered for atonement. See Nahmanides.
121 For seven days. See I.E. on Lev. 8:34.
122 The repetition of the word kodesh does not indicate superholiness as most commentators assume. See I.E. on Gen. 9:25.

123 The meaning of which according to I.E. is: Whatsoever shall touch the flesh of the sin offering shall be holy to God; that is, only a priest may eat of it (I.E. on Lev. 6:20). Similarly, Scripture here teaches that any flesh that touches the altar shall be holy to God and only a priest may eat of it.
124 In other words, our verse may be paraphrased as: the bread that touches the altar must be in a state of purity. For another interpretation, see Sarim.
125 So Meijler. In other words, ve-zeh (now this is) is short for ve-zeh ha-korban (now this is the sacrifice).
126 This is short for this amount.
127 Translated literally.
128 The meaning of which is: and this is the size that thou shalt make it.
129 Offer two lambs daily on the altar.
130 After the seven days of consecration. See Num. 28:4.
131 Ha-keves echad is ungrammatical. Hence I.E.’s comment.

132 This is precisely the reading of our texts. However, the parallel reading in Num. 28:4 is ha-keves echad. There too I.E. comments that the heh prefixed to the word keves also serves as a prefix to the word echad and that the phrase is to be read as if written ha-keves ha-echad. I.E. might have been commenting from memory and confused the two sections. However, Shadal, Meijler, and Filwarg believe that I.E. had a version of the Pentateuch in which Ex. 29:39 read: et ha-keves echad.
133 In other words, the word keves is to be read as if written twice, that is, et ha-keves, keves echad. This comment is also repeated in Num. 28:4.
134 I.E. similarly believed that the name Moses and the word chartumim are Egyptian words. See I.E. on Ex. 2:10 and 7:11.
135 U-kheniskah is in the feminine. Hence it cannot refer to keves, which is masculine.

136 That is, to ke-minchat ha-boker (according to the meal-offering of the morning). Minchah is feminine. So Weiser. Filwarg believes that I.E. is of the opinion that boker here is feminine. Hence u-kheniskah refers to it rather than to keves.

137 When it was first erected on the first day of Nisan (Ex. 40:17). Israel journeyed from Sinai on the 20th day of the second month (Num. 10:11,12). The tabernacle was thus at Sinai for 50 days. It was during these 50 days that Israel offered burnt offerings.
138 The Israelites formed an amorphous mass. The only open space available for the tabernacle was at the edge of the camp.
139 Of the second year following the Exodus.

140 That is, it was only on the first day of the second month of the second year that the Israelites were organized into separate groups with their own place around standards, with the tabernacle in the center of the camp.
141 It is unlikely that Israel would offer sacrifices while the ark journeyed (Filwarg).

142 Of the 12 tribes of Israel. It is I.E.’s opinion that for the first three days of their journey from Sinai, the ark traveled before the camp (Num. 10:33). After that, it journeyed in their midst. See I.E. on Num. 10:31. Be that as it may, I.E.’s point is that after 50 days at Sinai, the ark was no longer in the tabernacle and thus no sacrifices were offered. See Filwarg.
143 That is, regarding the service which Aaron was to perform on Yom Kippur.
144 That is, Aaron performed the Yom Kippur service.
145 Necessary for the daily sacrifice. See verses 40 and 41.
146 The total amount of olive oil necessary for the daily burnt offering during their sojourn in the desert of Sinai.
147 Which shows that the Israelites had cattle.
149 At that time, but not before.
150 Hebrew, ivva’ed.
151 Ivva’ed and mo’ed come from the same root.
152 Lakhem (with you) is a plural. Hence I.E.’s comment.

153 God met with the congregation when Moses called them together by sounding trumpets. See Num. 10:3, And when they shall blow with them, all the congregation shall gather themselves unto thee at the door of the tent of meeting. So Meijler and Filwarg. According to Weiser its meaning is: Scripture uses the word ve-no’adu (shall gather themselves), which comes from the same root as mo’ed when it describes the gathering of the congregation. We thus see that the term mo’ed means gathering or meeting.
154 Elekha (unto thee) is in the singular. Hence I.E.’s comment.
155 Hence the use of the plural lakhem (with you).
156 Hence elekha (unto thee) is in the singular.
157 If lakhem refers to Israel, why would Scripture repeat itself in verse 43?
158 The table of showbread, the menorah, and the incense altar.

159 According to I.E., verse 43 should be paraphrased as follows: I will meet with the children of Israel in the tent of meeeting because the tent of meeting takes in the tabernacle and all of its utensils, the ark, the table of showbread, the menorah, and the incense altar. The tent of meeting shall be sanctified by My glory, which will rest on the cherubim. It should be noted that I.E.’s comment is difficult to unravel, and the various commentaries offer differing interpretations and emendations. However, the above seems to be the correct interpretation.
160 Mentioned in verse 33.
161 In the temple courtyard.
162 By God’s glory.

163 In other words, our verse adverts to the time when the camp of Israel will be set up in the form of a square with the tent of meeting in its center. Hence our verse speaks of God dwelling among the children of Israel. See Num. 2-4.

165 I.E. assumed this, as Scripture does not explicitly so state. See I.E. on Deut. 23:10. According to Meijler, I.E. considers the space between the camp of the Levites and that of the Israelites as a barrier.
166 The tribe of Levi camped around the four sides of the tent of meeting.
167 For there was a separation between the camp of Israel and the tent of meeting. See Deut. 23:11.
168 See Deut. 13 and 14.
171 See Num. 31:6 along with I.E.’s comment.
172 Hence all who experienced emissions and all those who had to relieve themselves had to leave the camp.
173 The verse refers to the tabernacle which Israel would build at the foot of Mount Sinai.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 30
chapter.p: 1. AND THOU SHALT MAKE AN ALTAR TO BURN INCENSE UPON. The word miktar (to burn) is an infinitive.1 It is like the word u-mishlo’ach (and of sending)2 in and of sending portions one to another (Esth. 9:19).

2. A CUBIT. The altar was a half a cubit higher than the table.3 Perhaps it was similarly half a cubit higher than the menorah.4 The altar5 was aligned with the cherubim6 which spread their wings upward.

3. AND THOU SHALT OVERLAY IT WITH PURE GOLD. A top is mentioned with regard to the altar of incense. Scripture does not mention a top with regard to the brass altar.7 The altar8 was called the golden altar9 because it was overlaid with gold. The same applies to The pure table (Lev. 24:6).10 It is like the pure candlestick (Lev. 24:4).11
4. UPON THE TWO SIDES OF IT. Scripture states this12 in order to be especially clear.
[WHEREWITH.] THE heh at the end of the word ba-hemmah (wherewith) is superfluous,13 as I have already noted,14 since hemmah is penultimately accented.15
5. AND THOU SHALT MAKE THE STAVES OF ACACIAWOOD. And overlay them with gold like the staves of the ark.16
6. AND THOU SHALT PUT IT BEFORE THE VEIL. On the outside.17
BEFORE THE ARK-COVER. The altar should be aligned with the ark cover.

7. AND AARON SHALL BURN THEREON INCENSE OF SWEET SPICES. Along with other spices (besamim).18 It is possible that the sammim (sweet spices) were the most important ingredient.19 It is also possible that Scripture mentions sammim20 (spices) in order to distinguish between the compounds,21 as one of the compounds22 consisted only of besamim (spices). It did not contain sammim (sweet spices).23
[WHEN HE DRESSETH.] When he fixes the wick and the oil.
8. LIGHTETH THE LAMPS. Scripture employs be-he’alot24 for lighting because the flame of the wick goes up. Be-he’alot is clearly a transitive verb.25
A PERPETUAL INCENSE. When they offer burnt offerings.26 Scripture therefore says, throughout your generations.27
9. YE SHALL OFFER NO STRANGE INCENSE. An incense which is not its exact duplicate.28
10. AND AARON SHALL MAKE ATONEMENT UPON THE HORNS OF IT ONCE IN THE YEAR. On the tenth day of the seventh month.29

[OF ATONEMENT.] The reference is to the blood of the bullock30 and the blood of the he-goat.31 The aforementioned is a yearly obligation. There is no reason for Scripture to mention the blood of the bullock brought by the anointed high priest when he sins and the blood of the bullock brought by the congregation when they sin.32 For they are not placed on the horns of the altar at fixed times.33 They are placed there only on rare occasions.34
May the name of the exalted God be eternally blessed.
He did every good for Israel.
To His messenger35 He revealed every secret
In the Torah portion called Ki Tissa.

12. [WHEN THOU TAKEST THE SUM.] Scripture36 begins to explain the law of the atonement money which each and every one is obligated to give. The atonement money was not a free will offering.37 Scripture makes mention of the atonement money here because it notes above38 that atonement shall be made [upon the horns of the altar of incense] once a year. The atonement money was, as I will explain, similarly to be given once a year.
The description of the laver and its base follow next39 because they are not to be made from free will gifts of the congregation but only from the mirrors of the women who performed tasks.40

Scripture also mentions the anointing oil41 and the sweet incense,42 for the princes alone brought them.43 Now since Scripture mentions the anointing oil it mentions the vessels which were anointed.44 Scripture also mentions the great craftsman, the perfumer,45 and the one whose counsel guided those who constructed the entire tabernacle, namely, Bezalel and Oholiab [who was with him].46
Scripture mentions the Sabbath47 in order to warn the Israelites at the beginning48 not to do God’s work49 on the Sabbath.

Scripture next50 records the prayer offered by Moses before he came down from the mountain. However, it first had to mention the making of the golden calf51 so that we would know why Moses prayed. Scripture then tells of Moses’ descent from the mountain,52 the burning of the calf,53 and Moses’ return to the mountain to pray for Israel a second time.54

Scripture mentions that Moses’ anger caused him to move his tent outside the camp of Israel.55 However, some say that Scripture records what happened.56 Scripture then mentions Moses’ great glory, namely, that Moses saw God’s glory.57 It tells us that God then commanded Moses to descend and hew out tablets.58 It informs us that God inscribed the tablets a second time.59 Scripture mentions60 the conditions upon which God made a treaty with Israel.61 These conditions are recorded in the Torah portion Ve-Ellaeh Ha-Mishpatim.62 Scripture then mentions that the skin of Moses’ face shone when Moses came down from the mountain with the tablets of the covenant in his hand.63

Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that the atonement money was an annual obligation upon Israel. It was obligatory whether their king counted them or not.64 Saadiah Gaon offers the census taken by Moses in the desert as proof.65 Saadiah says that the money collected was used for the congregational sacrifices, the construction of the laver, the making of the anointing oil, and the sweet incense. Part of it was also given to the Sanhedrin.66 Bezalel and Oholiab allude to this.67

[WHEN THOU TAKEST THE SUM.]68 It is customary for the accountants who are intimate with the details of an account to itemize upon pages. However they write the sum of all the items69 at the head of the page.70
Some say that the plague which occurred in the days of David71 struck because Israel did not offer a ransom for their soul. If this is true it refutes the opinion of Saadiah Gaon.72

[WHEN THOU NUMBEREST THEM.] The meaning of that there be no plague among them, when thou numberest them is: if they do not give atonement money at the very moment of the numbering, a plague will strike. However, Yefet says it means that if they are numbered and do not give their ransom, they will fall before their enemies when they go to war.73
13. THIS. This amount. It is similar to And this thou shalt make it74 (Ex. 7:15).75

[EVERY ONE THAT PASSETH.] The meaning of every one that passeth is everyone who passes his twentieth year. Twenty years is about three weeks of years [almost twenty-one years].76 A person’s mind is then fully developed. His body also no longer grows in height.77
[GERAHS.] These gerahs78 refer to the pits of a carob.79
14. EVERY ONE…THAT ARE NUMBERED. Pekudim (that are numbered) is active.80
15. THE RICH. Scripture explains why the rich shall not give more, and the poor shall not give less. The reason for this is that the money is an atonement for one’s soul.81
16. AND THOU SHALT TAKE…AND SHALT APPOINT IT FOR THE SERVICE OF THE TENT OF MEETING. This is explained in the Torah portion Ve-Ellah Pekude.82
[THAT IT MAY BE A MEMORIAL FOR THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] For the tabernacle stood only upon sockets which were made from the atonement money83 as a memorial for the children of Israel.
17. AND THE LORD SPOKE. A new section begins here.84
18. AND THE BASE THEREOF. Kanno means the base thereof.85 The bases that Solomon made86 proves this.87

Now Scripture states that the laver was placed between the tent of meeting and the altar. This shows that the altar was not adjacent to the door of the tent but was close to it The altar was placed in the center88 and was aligned with the altar of incense.89 The laver was placed between the tent and the altar, towards one of the sides.90 However, Scripture does not mention this.91 It does not seem logical for the laver to be aligned with the altar of incense92 and thus be aligned with the ark cover.93

19. SHALL WASH. Scripture mentions that the laver was necessary because of those who served in the tabernacle, namely, Aaron and his sons and their descendants. Moses is not now mentioned, as Moses alone used the laver as long as he lived.94 However, Scripture mentions Moses’ use of the laver when it describes the actual setting up of the laver.95

20. WHEN THEY GO INTO THE TENT OF MEETING, THEY SHALL WASH WITH WATER. The meaning of yirchatzu mayim96 is they shall wash with water.97 The reason the hands and feet have to be washed is that they are the active parts of the body.98 There are many such instances.99
22. MOREOVER THE LORD SPOKE. This is a section unto itself.100

23. TAKE THOU ALSO UNTO THEE. Kach lekha (take unto thee) is similar to lekh leha (get thee out) (Gen. 12:1) and u-kechu lakhem tzon (and take you lambs) (Ex. 12:21).101 According to the plain meaning of the text, aseh lekha saraf (make thee a fiery serpent) (Num. 21:8)102 and also pesal lekha (hew thee) (Ex. 34:1)103 are similar,104 for such is the way of the Hebrew language.105

[MYRRH.] The word mor (myrrh) is difficult.106 Saadiah Gaon translated it as musk. It thus does not come from trees107 even though it has a pleasant odor.108 Perhaps this is the reason Scripture separates it from the spices. For Scripture states, I have gathered my myrrh with my spice (Cant. 5:1). Myrrh is thus gathered.109 Those who provide musk say that it is produced in the throat of a deer.110 Behold,111 Scripture states, And my hands dropped with myrrh (Cant. 5:5).112 Perhaps this is the case when the myrrh is wet.113

[THE CHIEF SPICES.] Scripture reads besamim rosh (the chief spices)114 to indicate that the top of each spice115 is to be taken. The top of the spice is of a much better quality than that which remains at the end.

[AND OF SWEET CINNAMON.]116 Having said kinnemon (cinnamon), what reason is there for Scripture to add besem (sweet)?117 It is possible that Scripture reads, ve-kinnemon besem, because the cinnamon had to be of the best quality. The same also applies to the calamus.118

[HALF SO MUCH, EVEN TWO HUNDRED AND FIFTY.] The ancients, of blessed memory, said that all the ingredients were of equal weight.119 We will accept what they say. However, we do not know why Scripture says, half so much even two hundred and fifty.120 I do not understand the reason for the halves121 for it is the practice in all of the lands of the Ishmaelites not to add even the weight of a mustard seed to anything being weighed. They most certainly do not add anything to any ingredient used in the work of a perfumer.122
24. CASSIA. We know from tradition123 that kiddah is cassia.

25. AND THOU SHALT MAKE IT…A PERFUME COMPOUNDED AFTER THE ART OF THE PERFUMER. Rokach mirkachat (a perfume compounded after the art of the perfumer) is similar to miktar ketoret (to burn incense) (v. 1).124
[IT SHALL BE A HOLY ANOINTING OIL.] This is what Scripture refers to next.125
26. AND THOU SHALT ANOINT THEREWITH THE TENT OF MEETING. This includes the entire tabernacle.126 Our verse mentions the ark.127 the most important object in the tent of meeting.
27. AND THE TABLE. The table is mentioned first128 because it was the largest [object in the sanctuary] and it had many utensils. Scripture then mentions the menorah, which had many utensils.
28. AND THE ALTAR OF BURNT-OFFERING. It had many vessels.129
29. AND THOU SHALT SANCTIFY. With the anointing oil.

[WHATSOEVER TOUCHETH THEM SHALL BE HOLY.] We can derive the meaning of whatsoever toucheth them shall be holy from If one bear hallowed flesh130 (Haggai 2:12), which, according to the plain meaning of the text, is be taken literally.131 The verse132 teaches: if holy flesh touches bread, pottage, wine, oil, or any food it133 becomes holy. The same applies to the altar of burnt offering,134 as Scripture also uses the term “most holy”135 regarding it.136
30. AND THOU SHALT ANOINT AARON AND HIS SONS. Alone, no one else.137
31. THIS SHALL BE A HOLY ANOINTING OIL. All oil made according to this composition shall be used to anoint the seed of Aaron.138

32. SHALL IT NOT BE POURED. Rabbi Merinus139 says that yisakh (poured)140 has the same meaning as yusakh.141 Similarly, va-yisem (he was put)142 in and he was put in a coffin (Gen. 50: 26) has the same meaning as va-yusam.143

[UPON THE FLESH OF MAN SHALL IT NOT BE POURED.] Scripture states, Upon the flesh of man shall it not be poured because it was customary in Israel for men and also for women to anoint themselves with oil. For Scripture states, but thou shalt not anoint thyself with oil (Deut. 28:40). It is prohibited for a priest and certainly for anyone else to anoint themselves with this oil, for the anointing oil was poured upon the head of the anointed.144
ACCORDING TO THE COMPOSITION THEREOF. Oil composed of the exact amount of the above-listed145 spices.
33. WHOSOEVER. The meaning of or whosoever putteth any of it on a stranger (zar) is: or whosoever putteth any of it on someone who is not of Aaron’s family.146

Saadiah Gaon, of blessed memory, says that Israel had a tradition that David and his seed should be anointed with the anointing oil. Other kings were not to be so anointed. The Gaon was compelled to explain thus because Zadok147 took some of the anointing oil that was in the tent of meeting and used it to anoint Solomon.148

Yefet says that on a stranger means on someone who is not an Israelite.149 However, he was mistaken, for Scripture states, and the stranger150 (zar) that draweth nigh shall be put to death (Num. 3:10). The meaning of the latter is: To the end that no stranger (zar), that is not of the seed of Aaron, draw near (Num. 17:5).151

Others say152 that this law153 refers only to the oil made by Moses. However, this also does not appear to me to be correct. For Scripture first states, This shall be a holy anointing oil unto Me throughout your generations (v. 31).154 Furthermore, the Pentateuch states (v. 33), Whosoever, compoundeth any like it,155 or whosoever putteth any of “a similarly compounded oil”156 upon a stranger. Thus there is no difference between the anointing oil made by Moses and its duplicate which was made later.
Scripture157 does not state, “except for the family of David.”158

I believe that all the commandments are obligatory on all the generations of Israel.159 The law stating that no burnt offering should be offered in any but the chosen place160 is an example.161 Nevertheless, we find that Gideon,162 Samuel,163 and also Elijah at Mount Carmel164 brought burnt offerings.165 I mentioned Gideon166 because he offered burnt offerings even though he was not a priest.167 The same is true of Samuel.168 The fact that he was descended from Korah169 is of no avail. These acts were all based on temporary [ad hoc] rulings.170 We can say the same also with regard to Solomon. Solomon was anointed with the anointing oil on the temporary ruling of the prophet Nathan or Gad.

34. TAKE UNTO THEE SWEET SPICES. The ancients,171 of blessed memory, received a tradition that there were eleven types of spices.172 Now the verse173 that notes that spices were to be used in the sweet incense174 does not list the spices that were to be used in the sweet incense. Scripture175 mentions the sweet spices.176 However, Scripture does not mention their weight.177
[SWEET SPICES.] Scripture mentions sammim (sweet spices) a second time178 because it wants to say: take the aforementioned sweet spices,179 and along with them, take pure frankincense.
OF EACH SHALL THERE BE A LIKE WEIGHT. Each spice to be compounded by itself.180 It shall then be mixed.181

35. AND THOU SHALT MAKE…SEASONED WITH SALT. Memullach (seasoned with salt) means seasoned with salt from Sodom.182 Others say that memullach means thinly ground. Or it is related183 to the word melechah (salt) in A salt land (Jer. 17:6).184
36. AND THOU SHALT BEAT SOME OF IT VERY SMALL. As thin as you are able to make it.185 This is the perpetual incense186 which was offered on the golden altar.
37. AND THE INCENSE WHICH THOU SHALT MAKE. This187 alludes to Moses.
YE SHALL NOT MAKE. Israel is being spoken to.188
IT SHALL BE UNTO THEE HOLY. The priest, or all of Israel.189 Remember the days of old (Deut. 32:7) is similar.190
38. WHOSOEVER. Scripture first warns.191 It then mentions the punishment,192 as is the law.193
chapter.ftnote: 1 In the form of a noun. See Weiser. Also see I.E.’s short commentary.
2 Which is an infinitive in the form of a noun.
3 Of showbread. The table was a cubit and a half high.

4 In other words, the menorah, like the table, was a cubit and a half high. The Torah does not give the height of the menorah. I.E. believes that it is possible that the menorah was the height of the table for aesthetic purposes.
5 Which stood in the sanctuary.
6 Which stood in the Holy of Holies.
7 The altar of burnt offerings, which stood in the courtyard. This altar did not have a top. It was hollow and filled in with earth (Rashi).
8 Of incense.
10 It was made of acacia wood but is referred to as the pure (gold) table because it was overlaid with gold. See Ex. 25:23,24.
11 The meaning of which is, the candlestick made of pure gold. See I.E. on Ex. 25:31. Similarly the pure table means the table made of pure gold.
12 Upon the two sides of it following upon the two sides thereof.
13 Ba-hemmah is a variant of ba-hem.
14 See I.E. on Ex. 1:1 and the notes thereto.
15 If the heh were an integral part of the word the word would be ultimately accented. See I.E. on Ex. 1:1 and the notes thereto.
17 On the outside of the veil, i.e., in the sanctuary rather than in the Holy of Holies.

18 Our verse reads, “And Aaron shall burn upon them ketoret sammim (incense of sweet spices).” I.E. explains that the incense consisted of sammim (sweet spices) plus besamim (spices). I.E.’s comment is based on Ex. 25:6, which reads, spices (besammim) for the anointing oil, and for the sweet incense (ketoret sammim). See I.E. on the latter.
19 Hence the word besamim is not mentioned in its name and the incense is called ketoret sammim.
20 With regard to the incense of sweet spices (ketoret sammim).
21 The anointing oil and the incense of sweet spices.
22 The anointing oil.
23 While the incense of sweet spices (ketoret sammim) consisted of sweet spices plus spices. Hence only the former is mentioned in its name.
24 From the root ayin, lamed, heh, which means to go up.
25 Meaning to cause a flame to go up.

26 The law concerning the bringing of incense is contingent on the bringing of offerings. The law is suspended when offerings are not brought. Hence incense was offered only at Sinai, where Israel offered sacrifices. See I.E. on Ex. 29:42 (Krinsky).
27 The meaning of which is, following your entrance into Canaan. See I.E. on Ex. 29:42.
28 An incense which is not made exactly in accordance with the prescription that Scripture lays down for the incense. See verse 34.
29 The Day of Atonement.
30 Brought by the high priest on the Day of Atonement. See Lev. 16:3,6,18.
31 Brought by the people on the Day of Atonement. See Lev. 16:9,18.
32 The blood of these two offerings was also placed on the corners of the altar of incense. See Lev. 4:1-21.
33 As is the blood of the above-mentioned Day of Atonement offerings.
34 When the high priest or congregation sins.
35 Moses.
36 Now.
37 Everything described up to now was made from donations. See Ex. 25:2.
38 Verse 10.
39 Verses 17-21.
40 Ex. 38:8. This contrasts with the atonement money which every male over 20 was obligated to give.
41 Verses 22 and 33.
42 Verses 34-38.
43 In contrast to the atonement money which every male over 20 gave and the mirrors which only the serving women donated.
44 With this oil. Chapter 31:7-11.
45 The reference seems to be to Bezalel. However, it might refer to Moses. See Krinsky.
48 Before they started to work on the tabernacle.
49 The construction of the tabernacle.
55 Ex. 33:7. The first part of the clause is an assumption. See next note.

56 That Moses removed his tent from Israel. In other words, Scripture did not intend to imply that Moses was angry at Israel and therefore removed his tent from their midst. It merely records what happened.

57 Ex. 33:23. What I.E. must mean by “that Moses saw God’s glory” is that God promised Moses that he would show him His glory. Moses actually saw God’s glory after he hewed out the second pair of tablets. See Chapter 34.
58 A second set of tablets. See Ex. 34:1.
62 These conditions are the same ones that are first mentioned in Ex. 23:12-33. See I.E. on Ex. 24:11 and the notes thereto.
64 In other words, it was obligatory whether or not the people were counted.

65 II Chron. 24:6 refers to the money collected to repair the temple as the tax of Moses. According to Saadiah the reference is to the annual tax instituted by Moses in the desert. Hence the paraphrase “the tax of Moses in the desert.”
66 In later times.

67 Ex. 31:1-11 tells us that Bezalel and Oholiab were given the charge of constructing the tabernacle. Scripture tells of this here because part of the atonement money was given to them. Bezalel and Oholiab were the equivalent of the Sanhedrin because they were in charge of constructing the tabernacle.
68 Ki Tissa literally means when you lift up.
69 Of any particular page.
70 Hence Scripture speaks of raising up the sum, for the sum is raised to the top of the page. See I.E. on Gen. 41:13 and the notes thereto.
71 II Sam. 24.

72 According to Saadiah there was an annual obligation to give half a shekel as a ransom for one’s soul. Now if this is an annual obligation it is highly unlikely that David forgot to collect it when he counted the people (Weiser).
73 In other words, that there be no plague among them, when thou numberest them refers to defeat by their enemies.
74 Translated literally.
75 The meaning of which is, and this size thou shalt make it. In other words, here too “this” is an abridged form.
76 According to I.E. the number seven has a special significance. See I.E. on Gen. 8:5 and the notes thereto.
77 A person is then mentally and physically mature.
78 According to I.E. the word gerah is related to the word gargir [berry or pit].
79 A gerah weighed the same as a pit of a carob.

80 Pekudim is a passive form. However, it is to be interpreted as an active. Pekudim is to be rendered, that number. Rashi on verse 13 similarly comments: “Those who count.” Vat. Ebr. 38 and other editions of I.E. read, “Pekudim is passive.” In other words, contra Rashi, pekudim is to be rendered, that are numbered.
81 All souls are equally precious. See Krinsky.
82 Ex. 38:25-28 tells us what the atonement money was used for, namely, to make sockets and hooks.

84 Hence verse 17 opens with And the Lord spoke (Meijler). It is possible that I.E. had before him manuscripts of the Pentateuch in which verse 17 did not start a new section. Hence I.E. pointed out that it opens a new section (Filwarg).
85 Hebrew, mekhonoto.
86 For the lavers.
87 II Chron. 4:14 reads, and the lavers made he [Solomon] upon the bases (mekhonot). We thus see that kanno means mekhonoto; i.e., kanno means its base.
88 Of the courtyard, which faced the front of the tabernacle.
89 Which was aligned with the door of the tabernacle.
90 It was not centered between the altar and the opening of the tabernacle. Rashi, quoting Zebachim 59b, similarly writes: “The laver was removed a little toward the south.”

91 Scripture does not mention the place of the laver (Weiser). Or, Scripture does not mention that the laver was off center (Meijler). According to Filwarg and Krinsky, I.E. discusses the altar mentioned in our verse. Scripture states, and thou shalt put it between the tent of meeting and the altar. However, it does not identify which altar it is referring to. I.E. points out that the reference is to the altar of the burnt offering, for it is illogical to assume that the laver was placed in the sanctuary between the tent of meeting and the altar of incense.
92 This would be the case if the laver was placed directly between the altar and the opening of the tent of meeting.
93 For it is unseemly to wash oneself before the ark.
94 His descendants who were not priests, did not use the laver.
96 Literally, they shall wash water. Hence I.E.’s comment.

97 In Hebrew, rechitzat mayim. In other words, yirchatzu mayim means yirchatzu rechitzat mayim, for the noun rechitzat is implied in the verb yirchatzu (Filwarg). In his short commentary I.E. notes that yirchatzu mayim is short for yirchatzu ba-mayim. He might mean the same here.

98 Hebrew, ha-po’alim. They are the parts of the body that are usually soiled. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, ha-pu’alim, the ones acted upon, i.e., being washed. According to this reading we should render: The meaning of yirchatzu mayim is, they shall wash with water, for it is the hands and feet that are being washed.
99 Where a verb is implied or where a preposition is missing. See note 94.
100 See note 82.
101 In that the word lekha (plural, lakhem) follows the word for emphasis.
102 According to the rabbis the word lekha indicates that Moses had to bear the expense of making the fiery serpent. Lekha should be interpreted as mishelkah (from what is yours). See Avoda Zara 44a.
103 According to the rabbis the word lekha indicates that Moses was to keep the chips from the tablets. See Nedarim 37b, pesolatan shelkha yehe.
104 According to the Midrash.
105 It is Hebrew style to add the word lekha (to you) to a verb for emphasis.
106 It is difficult to ascertain its meaning.

107 As do the other ingredients of the anointing oil. Musk is an animal product. By trees I.E. probably means plants. Nahmanides reads, “It thus is not a spice,” rather than, “It thus does not come from trees.”
108 As the other ingredients of the anointing oil do.
109 In other words, Cant. 5:1 indicates that musk is gathered. Thus, contrary to Saadiah, it appears to be a plant product.
110 It is thus not gathered.
111 An additional reason not to identify musk with mor.
112 However, musk is dry (Filwarg).
113 In other words, Cant. 5:5 refers to wet mor.
114 Besamim rosh literally means head spices, hence I.E.’s comment.
115 The top of each plant.
116 Hebrew, ve-kinnemon besem.
117 In other words, the phrase ve-kinnemon besem is redundant, for kinnemon is a type of spice (bosem).
118 Scripture reads, u-keneh bosem (and sweet calamus). The same question that was raised regarding ve-kinnemon besem can be raised here; i.e., having stated keneh, why add bosem?

119 Each type of spice used in the anointing oil weighed 500 shekalim. See Keritot 5a. Krinsky points out that the Rabbinic comment applied only to cinnamon and not to calamus, for according to the rabbis 250 shekalim-weight of calamus was used in the anointing oil. See Keritot 5a. Krinsky tries to limit I.E.’s remarks to the cinnamon. However, he admits that he is pressing the point, for I.E. reads “all,” and the meaning of “all” is all the ingredients.
120 If 500 shekalim of sweet cinnamon was used.

121 That is, why the cinnamon was brought in two halves, each consisting of 250 shekalim. According to the rabbis, the reason for bringing the cinnamon in two halves was to gain the overweights. We thus read, “Said Rabbi Judah: Why are the five hundred shekels of sweet cinnamon taken in two portions of two hundred and fifty each? Since the total quantity is five hundred, why not bring the whole at a time? From the fact that the cinnamon is brought in two portions we may infer that there was an overweight each time (that is, the division was for the purpose of adding a greater overweight of cinnamon)” (Keritot 5a, Soncino translation).
122 I.E. assumes that what was common practice in his day was also common practice in Rabbinic times.
123 Keritot 6a.
124 Rokach is an infinitive in the form of a noun. So is miktar (see I.E. on verse 1). Thus rokach mirkachat means to make a perfume. See I.E.’s short commentary on Exodus.
125 The next verse reads, And thou shalt anoint therewith. Therewith refers to the anointing oil.
126 Everything in the tabernacle. From I.E.’s short commentary.
127 Here rather than in the following verses.
128 In our verse, which lists the objects to be anointed.
129 Hence it is listed before the laver which, along with it, stood in the temple courtyard.
130 The entire verse reads: If one bear hallowed flesh in the skirt of his garment, and with the skirt do touch bread, or pottage, or wine, or oil, or any food, shall it become holy?
131 In other words, hallowed flesh means holy flesh. I.E. comments thus for it is possible to interpret the meaning as unclean flesh. See I.E. on Num. 11:18.
132 Haggai 2:12.
133 That which is touched.
134 Whatever touches it becomes holy.
136 Hence whatever touches the altar becomes holy. See Ex. 29:37.
137 Even though they are relatives of Aaron (Krinsky).
138 In other words, “this” does not refer only to this very oil. It refers to any oil that is its exact duplicate.
139 Jonah ibn Janach.
140 Literally, he will pour. Al besar adam lo yisakh (upon the flesh of man shall it not be poured) literally means, upon the flesh of man he shall not pour.
141 The meaning of which is, it will not be poured. Thus al besar adam lo yisakh is to be interpreted: upon the flesh of man shall it not be poured.
142 Literally, he put.
143 The meaning of which is, and he was put. See I.E. on Ex. 50:26 and the notes thereto.
144 A high priest or a king.
145 Verse 22.
146 In other words, zar refers to someone not of Aaron’s family.
147 The high priest.
148 See I Kings 1:39. Solomon was not a descendant of Aaron. Thus anointing him apparently violated the dictates of our verse. Hence Saadiah’s interpretation.
149 Hence it was possible to anoint Solomon with the anointing oil.
150 Translated literally.
151 We thus see, contra Yefet, that zar refers to anyone not of Aaron’s family. Also translated literally.
152 Keritot 5a. So too Rashi.
153 Whosoever putteth any of it on a stranger, he shall be cut off from his people.
154 The meaning of which according to I.E. is, oil later made according to this composition. See I.E. on verse 31.
155 Like it indicates that Scripture speaks of a duplicate, and not the original anointing oil made by Moses.
156 “A similarly compounded oil” is I.E.’s paraphrase of “it.”
157 I.E. now takes issue with Saadiah, who claims that whosoever putteth any of it on a stranger does not apply to the Davidic dynasty.
158 Scripture does not state whosoever putteth any of it on a stranger with the exception of the house of David shall be cut off from his people.
159 Thus the law prohibiting a stranger to use the anointing oil applied to the house of David.
161 Of a law which is eternally binding. This law was in effect in all generations.
164 I Kings 8:23.
165 Even though this violated the law prohibiting offerings to be brought outside of the chosen place.
