166 Who lived before the temple was built and thus could not have violated the law against offering sacrifices in any but the chosen place. I.E. accepts the Rabbinic opinion that Elijah was a priest. Hence he was not bothered by Elijah’s offering sacrifices.
167 And thus was prohibited from offering burnt offerings.
168 He too was mentioned by I.E. because he offered burnt offerings even though he was not a priest.
169 Who was a Levite. See I Chron. 6:1-23.
170 Hebrew, hora’at sha’ah. According to I.E. a prophet may temporarily suspend a law.
171 The rabbis of the Talmud.
172 Only four are mentioned in Biblical text. See Keritot 6b: “Rabbi Johanan said: Eleven kinds of spices were named to Moses at Sinai.”

174 Ex. 25:6 reads: Spices (besamim) for the anointing oil, and for the sweet incense. However, it nowhere lists which spices (besamim) were to be placed in the sweet incense. We thus see that Scripture relied on the oral tradition with regard to the ingredients of the sweet incense.
175 In our verse.

176 Hebrew, sammim. I.E.’s point is that Scripture does not at all mention the spices (besamim) used in the sweet incense. However, our verse does mention the sweet spices (sammim) that were used in the sweet incense.
177 Meijler. Their weight is given by tradition. Thus even with regard to the spices (sammim) we need tradition.
178 In our verse.
179 That is, take the just-mentioned sweet spices.

180 I.E. explains the word bad to mean alone. Thus according to I.E. the phrase bad be-vad yiheyeh (of each shall there be a like weight) means each one shall be alone, i.e., each spice to be compounded by itself. See Rashi.
181 With the other spices.
182 Keritot 6a. The reference is to sea salt. See Baba Batra 20b.
183 Weiser suggests emending o (or) to ulai (perhaps). See next note.

184 That is, a destroyed or cut-off land. Each piece of salt is to be destroyed, i.e., thinly ground. So Weiser and Filwarg. According to Weiser we should render I.E. as follows: Others say that memullach means thinly ground. It is possibly related to the word melechah (salt) in A salt land (Jer. 17:6). Krinsky renders, A salt land, a cut-off land. He explains, “Or it is related to the word melechah (salt) in A salt land as follows: Memullach means cut off from profane use, as it is related to the word melechah in Jer. 17:6. In other words, the sweet incense is to be cut off from all profane use, for it is a holy compound.
185 For Scripture employs the infinitive hadek (very small). The infinitive indicates a continuous action. Hence I.E.’s comment (Weiser).
186 Spoken of in verse 8.
187 The word thou alludes to Moses.
188 For Scripture here employs the plural.
189 Lekha (unto thee) refers either to the priest or to all of Israel. Lekha is a singular. Hence I.E.’s comment.

190 In Deuteronomy 32:7, Moses addresses Israel and tells them: Remember (zekhor) the days of old. Consider (binu) the years of many generations. Zekhor is singular. Binu is plural. We thus see that Scripture often switches from the singular to the plural without any change in person. It is thus possible that here too the switch from the plural to the singular does not indicate a change in person and that it is Israel who is being addressed.
191 Not to make a copy of the sweet incense.
192 In our verse.
193 One is not punished without first being warned. See San. 56b.

chapter.title: Chapter 31
chapter.p: 1. AND THE LORD SPOKE. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon asked, “Why were Bezalel and Oholiab chosen?”1 He answered that Bezalel was chosen because he was descended from Judah, whom Jacob compared to a lion’s whelp (Gen. 49:9). Oholiab was chosen because he was descended from Dan, whom Moses also compared to a lion’s whelp (Deut. 33:22). The lion is narrow at the end. The temple was similarly narrow at the end.2 Now this is a preacher’s homily,3 for Bezalel and Oholiab did not build the temple.4 The width of the tabernacle which they made did not vary.5 There is no basis for Saadiah Gaon’s question. Bezalel and Oholiab were chosen because there was no one in Israel who equaled them.6
2. SEE. With a respectful eye.7

[I HAVE CALLED BY NAME BEZALEL.] Bezalel is the one being called.8 The meaning of I have called by name Bezalel is: I have called Bezalel’s name because he has no equal in ability to construct the tabernacle.9

[BEZALEL THE SON OF URI, THE SON OF HUR.] According to the plain meaning of the text, Caleb the son of Jephunneh10 is not to be identified with Caleb the son of Hezron.11 There is indisputable evidence that this is so.12 Intelligent people will understand the proof.
3. AND I HAVE FILLED HIM. This is similar to And Joshua the son of Nun was full of the spirit of wisdom (Deut. 34:9).

[AND I HAVE FILLED HIM WITH THE SPIRIT OF GOD, IN WISDOM, AND IN UNDERSTANDING.] Scripture states, And the spirit of the Lord shall rest upon him (Is. 11:2). It then goes on to explain that the spirit of the Lord is The spirit of wisdom and understanding (Ibid.).

Wisdom (chokhmah)13 refers to the type of intelligence that is stored in the back of the brain.14 The word tevunah (understanding) and also the word binah (reason)15 are related to the word ben (between). They16 refer to the intellectual faculty that lies in the middle cavity of the brain between knowledge17 and wisdom.18 For wisdom is situated in the posterior cavity of the brain, and knowledge, which is gathered by the senses, is located in the cavities of the brain that are adjacent to the forehead. Knowledge is called al takyil in Arabic. Understanding is called al fakrah and wisdom al hakhmah.

Now Bezalel was endowed with every wisdom. He mastered the science of mathematics, geometry, proportions,19 astronomy, biology, and the secret of the human soul.20 He also towered over the people of his generation in that he knew all manner of workmanship.21 Many intelligent people do not possess even one practical skill. Hence Scripture prefixes a vav22 to the word kol (and) and reads, u-vekhol melakhah (and in all manner of workmanship).23
6. WITH HIM. Equal to him in workmanship but not in the science of cutting.24 Observe, the meaning of and in all manner of workmanship is (v. 3) to devise skilful works (v. 4).25

AND IN THE HEARTS OF ALL THAT ARE WISE-HEARTED I HAVE PUT WISDOM. To do work.26 Also one finds in human nature the ability to devise intricate geometric forms without ever having studied this science.27
[THAT THEY MAY MAKE ALL THAT I HAVE COMMANDED.] Scripture now goes on to mention all the objects which they were required to make.
7. THE TENT OF MEETING. Scripture starts with the tent of meeting because it includes everything in the tabernacle. It mentions the ark and the ark cover because of their great importance.
AND ALL THE FURNITURE OF THE TENT. The curtain, the veil, the boards, and the bars. It mentions the table28 in accordance with what I have already noted.29

10. AND THE PLAITED GARMENTS. The bigde ha-serad (the plaited garments) were garments used to cover the ark, the table, the altar, [and] the menorah when journeying.30 Scripture goes on to explain, And of the blue, and purple, and scarlet, they made plaited garments (bigde serad) (Ex. 39:1). Each is listed separately31 as the Torah portion Ba-Midbar Sinai (Num. 4:6-14) states.

Scripture then states, [And of the blue, and purple, and the scarlet] they made plaited garments…and [they] made the holy garments [for Aaron] (Ex. 39:1). It then goes on to list them.32 Observe! The word serad is related to the word sarid (remain) in escape or remain (Jer. 44:14).33
11. FOR THE HOLY PLACE. They are for the need of the holy place.34
12. SAYING. Every time the word lemor (saying) is used with va-yedabber35 (he spoke),36 its meaning is, saying to him.37 Here38 its meaning is, to tell Israel.39

13. THOU. Since God commanded Israel to construct the tabernacle, Israel might think that they should occupy themselves with the construction of the tabernacle on the Sabbath. Hence Scripture states, Verily40ye shall keep My sabbaths.

One of the great sages said that it is well-known that only one Sabbath is God’s Sabbath.41 Now, if this is so, then what is the meaning of My sabbaths?42 He answered that the world will exist for six thousand years.43 The seventh millennium and also the Sabbatical year are thus Sabbaths. However, My sabbaths refers to the many Sabbaths of the year.44

Note that we do not find the term shabbat used with reference to the festivals.45 The term used is shabbaton46 (a solemn rest).47 There is a controversy48 regarding the meaning of from the morrow after the sabbath49 (Lev. 23:15).50 The traditional interpretation is correct. However, as I will explain in its place, it requires interpretation.51
The Day of Atonement is called Israel’s Sabbath,52 not God’s Sabbath.53
FOR IT IS A SIGN. I will explain at the end of the chapter what the Sabbath signifies.
WHO SANCTIFY YOU. When you sanctify the Sabbath, which I sanctified, and refrain from doing any work on the Sabbath day.54

14. YE SHALL KEEP THE SABBATH…EVERY ONE THAT PROFANETH IT SHALL SURELY BE PUT TO DEATH. Mot yumat (he shall surely be put to death) means: it is possible he will be put to death.55 It is similar to and its owner also shall be put to death (Ex. 21:29).56 The verse stating I [God] will cut off whosoever doeth any work on the Sabbath in secret or in front of a57 witness58 is proof of the above.59

15. SIX DAYS. Scripture goes on to explain that they are permitted to do work on the other six days of the week.60 The word ye’aseh (shall be done)61 governs the word melakhah (work).62 Perhaps the word kol (any)63 or devar ma’aseh (an act of)64 is missing. Now its meaning is, you shall kill him if he does work in public.65

16. SHALL KEEP. They shall keep count of the days of the week so that they do not forget which day is the Sabbath. One shall set his affairs in order and take care of his needs on the sixth day so that he will keep the Sabbath and not desecrate it. The meaning of la’asot (to observe)66 in la’asot et ha-shabbat (to observe the Sabbath) is thus similar67 to the meaning of la’asot (to dress) in and he hastened to dress (la’asot) it.68 (Gen. 18:7).
17. IT IS A SIGN BETWEEN ME AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. Scripture employs the terms covenant69 and sign70 with regard to circumcision.71 It does the same with regard to the Sabbath.72

Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says: When people find a male circumcised in such a way that the glans penis is uncovered,73 then they will know that he is an Israelite.74 Similarly when a person refrains from doing any work or engaging in business on the Sabbath.75
However, I believe that the meaning of It is a sign is, for in six days the Lord made heaven and earth.76 Thus the one who does work on the Sabbath denies the work of creation.

[FOR IN SIX DAYS THE LORD MADE HEAVEN AND EARTH, AND ON THE SEVENTH DAY HE CEASED FROM WORK AND RESTED.] The Torah employs human language so that those who hear its words will understand. Scripture’s statement,77 And rested, is to be taken metaphorically because God…fainteth not, neither is weary (Is. 40:28).78 Look, the hosts of heaven, namely, the glorious corporeal entities79 which God created, circle the sky day and night eternally.80 This is certainly the case with the glorious incorporeal entities.81 It is most certainly true of the Creator of all, Who Inhabits eternity (Is. 57:15), and is enthroned of old (Ps. 55:20), who does all by command without any movement on His part.

18. AND HE GAVE. Empty heads ask, “What did Moses do on the mount for forty days and forty nights?” They do not know that if Moses spent this number and double its double in years with God, he would barely know one part of a thousand of God’s work and ways and the secret of all the precepts which God commanded him. They think that deeds are most important.82 This is not so. What is important is heart together with deed.83 Heart and tongue train a person [to observe the commandments].84 We thus read, in thy mouth,85 and in thy heart,86 that thou mayest do it87 (Deut. 30:14). Our ancients said, “God desires the heart.”88

Loving God and cleaving to the Lord with all of one’s soul is the basis of the commandments. This cannot be completely accomplished if a person does not know the ways of the Lord and is not acquainted with God’s work in the upper and lower worlds. The prophet thus states, But let him that glorieth glory in this, That he understandeth and knoweth Me (Jer. 9:23). It will then become clear to a person that God exercises mercy, Justice, and righteous, in the earth (Ibid.).89
A person cannot know God if he does not know his own spirit, soul, and body. For of what use is a person’s wisdom to him if he does not know the makeup of his soul?

Now Moses, who prophesied in the desert for forty years and was party to many secrets which God revealed to him on Mount Sinai, said before his death, O Lord God, Thou hast begun to show Thy servant Thy greatness (Deut. 3:24). Thus it was only then that Moses began to understand God’s greatness and that the Lord’s greatness was shown to him. This is truth,90 for His greatness is unsearchable (Ps. 145:3).
TABLES OF STONE. I have already explained this.91

[WITH THE FINGER OF GOD.] Scripture’s statement with the finger of God is an anthropomorphism,92 for the Lord’s will is accomplished by the word coming out of God’s mouth. God’s mouth is employed metaphorically. God is said to act like human kings. This is how For He commanded, and they were created (Ps. 118:27) is to be understood.93 God’s words appear to man to be standing in heaven.94 Scripture clearly states, Thy word standeth fast in heaven (Ps. 119:89).95 The intelligent will understand.96

Abraham the author says: I must dwell at length97 on the incident of the golden calf. Some of the ancients said that Hur98 was killed.99 Aaron thus was afraid.100 There is an opinion101 that Aaron feared for Israel,102 that if they killed him God in return would destroy all of Israel.103

Let us now turn to the plain meaning of the text. If the making of the golden calf entailed idolatry, why was Aaron afraid that he would be killed?104 Did not many pious Israelites of later generations, whose level of piety did not even reach to the bottom of the sole of Aaron’s foot, die for the sake of the unity of God’s name? Look! Daniel’s companions were thrown into a fiery furnace because they refused to bow before an image.105 How then could Aaron make an idol, which is worse than bowing down to it? Was not Aaron one of God’s holy people? Was he not a prophet to Israel?

Many commandments were given by him and his brother Moses.106 If Aaron was afraid to die107 then Hur was superior to him. If Aaron made an idol then Moses was obligated to kill him before he killed those who worshipped the calf. However, Moses prayed for Aaron and killed the worshippers. How could Aaron and his seed later on, for all eternity, make atonement for the children of Israel?108 Do not pay attention to Take thee a bull-calf109 for a sin-offering (Lev. 9:2), for the bull-calf was not brought because Aaron made the golden calf. On the Day of Atonement all anointed priests110 are similarly commanded to bring a young bullock for a sin offering.111

We cannot say that the bullock was brought because of their father’s sin,112 because all the priests were descended from Eleazar and Ithamar.113 Phinehas114 was also already born by the time the golden calf was made.115 Furthermore, the portion dealing with the laws of the Day of Atonement commands Israel to bring a he-goat for a sin offering.116 Now Israel did not make an image in the form of a he-goat.117 The red heifer118 similarly was not brought to atone for idolatry.119 It was brought to purify the unclean.

All philosophers admit that God will not choose a person whom He knows will ultimately worship idols to serve as His messenger.120 Not every prophet is a messenger.121 Now Scripture tells us that shortly before Moses died, he said, Thy Thummim and Thy Urim be with Thy holy one (Deut. 33:8).122 However, he did not mention the incident of the calf.123 The only sin found in Aaron was the sin found in Moses, which was the incident of the waters of Meribah,124 which I will explain in its place.125

Some say that Israel fooled Aaron. Israel made a mold of a calf. Aaron was unaware of this and cast the gold into the fire. They offer as proof, I cast it into the fire, and there came out this calf (Deut. 32:24). However, this is incorrect, for if Aaron was a fool whom simpletons could deceive, why would God have chosen him? Furthermore, why did Aaron build an altar before the calf and command that Israel slaughter sacrifices and burnt offerings upon it?126

Others say that the individual named Aaron who made the calf was not Aaron the brother of Moses. This too is nonsense, for the congregation that gathered,127 only gathered against the one who stood in place of Moses. Scripture clearly states, behold, Aaron and Hur are with you (Ex. 24:14).128 If the one who made the calf was someone else named Aaron, why didn’t Aaron kill him? Why didn’t Moses kill him when he came down from the mountain? Moses even prayed on his behalf.129 It is not fitting for a pious man to make an idol for others so that they do not die.130

There are also many who say that the meaning of Tomorrow shall be a feast to the Lord (Ex. 32:5) is that those who served the calf would be killed by Moses.131 But the meaning of Tomorrow shall be a feast (chag) to the Lord can only mean that after Aaron built the altar before the calf, he commanded that an announcement be made in the camp that they should slaughter sacrifices the next day on the altar which he built. The meaning of chag (feast) is a sacrifice, as in bind the offering with thick ropes (Ps. 118:27).132 This is what Israel did, for we read, and they arose early on the morrow, and offered burnt-offerings (Ex. 31:6).

Thoughts are of no avail,133 for one who curses God is killed for what he said.134 The case is the same with a person who says, Let us go and serve other gods (Deut. 13:7).135 The one who explains I am Esau thy first-born (Gen. 27:19) as meaning, I am what I am, but Esau is your first-born, is not offering the plain meaning of the text. Neither is he explaining the text in accordance with the rules of rhetoric.136

If a person asks his neighbor in a law court, “Are you the one to whom I lent the following sum of money?” and his neighbor responds, “I am,” he cannot later say, “What I meant was, I am his neighbor.” The same also applies to what Daniel said to Nebuchadnezzar: My lord, the dream137 be to them that hate thee (Dan. 4:16).138 Daniel spoke according to the rules of etiquette.139

I will now cite for you the opinion of the Gaon. Rabbi Saadiah said that Aaron, like Jehu, acted with guile.140 Hence Aaron built the altar.141 Saadiah Gaon raised the following question against his own interpretation: “If Aaron acted with guile, then why was God angry with him?” The Gaon answered that God was angry with Aaron because he did not immediately kill those who worshipped the calf, as Moses did when he arrived.

However, this too is incorrect, for Aaron called out, Tomorrow shall be a feast to the Lord (YHVH) (32:5). Aaron employed the name YHVH. This name is a proper noun in honor of the Lord. It is not used for any other being.142 It is not like the name Elohim (God), which is used in many different ways. Furthermore, why didn’t Aaron mention this when he responded to Moses?143 For Aaron said, I cast it into the fire (Ex. 32:24). Aaron’s answer is not in keeping with the question.144

I will now begin to briefly explain part of the secret.145 Far be it, far be it for Aaron to make an idol. Israel also did not ask for an idol. What happened was that Israel thought that Moses, who, as I have explained, had led them on their journey from the Red Sea, had died,146 for Israel noticed that the manna did not come down at Mount Sinai. Furthermore, Moses tarried on the mountain for forty days. A human being does not have the stamina to live that long without food. Also, Moses did not tell them when he would descend.147 Moses himself did not know this, for God told him, “Come up to Me onto the mount and be there until I give you the tablets of stone.”148

The word elohim (god) refers to a glorious being dwelling in an image of a body.149 Israel said as follows: who shall go before us (Ex. 32:l).150 If you pay attention to Israel’s first journey151 you will understand this.152

The calf was thus made for the glory of God.153 Hence Aaron built an altar before the calf and announced that they should offer sacrifices on the morrow for the glory of God.154 Israel did as Aaron commanded them. Aaron’s answer was155 that the people gathered themselves upon him (Ex. 32:l).156 I have already noted that whenever the verb kahal (gathered) is followed by the word al (upon) it has a negative connotation.157 However, if it is followed by the word el (to), as in And all the men of Israel assembled themselves (va-yikkhal) unto (el) king Solomon (I Kings 8:2), then it has a positive connotation. This is the meaning of thou knowest the people, that they are set on evil (Ex. 32:22). The meaning of the verse is: I did not do evil to them. For they merely asked for a being that would go before them.158 I made the calf for the glory of God.159 However, [the calf became an object of worship] because there was a mixed multitude among Israel. This what Aaron meant by ve-ra hu (they are set on evil).160 Aaron did not say ra hu (they are evil). A small group of Israelites thought that the calf was an idol. They brought sacrifices and bowed to the calf and said, This is thy god, O Israel (Ex. 32:4).

Do not be amazed that Scripture states, for thy people161…have dealt corruptly; they have turned aside quickly out of the way which I commanded them (Ex. 32:7,8), for Scripture does not say all thy people.162 Can you not see that Achan alone violated the ban163 and yet Scripture states, Israel hath sinned; yea, they have even transgressed My covenant…and have also stolen, and dissembled also, and they have even put it among their own stuff (Josh. 7:11). Now, only three thousand Israelites,164 which comes to a half of a tenth of a tenth of the Israelite camp,165 worshipped the golden calf as a god,166 that is, said, This is thy god, O Israel (Ex. 32:4), or thought so in their hearts. The sum of the matter is that we would not be acting properly if we maintain that the calf was made to serve as an idol as the simple-minded believe.

Do not be surprised that God was furious with Aaron, because he was167 the cause of their sin. For look, Aaron was punished along with his brother Moses concerning the incident at the waters of Meribah.168 However, Moses and Aaron did not deliberately sin.169 Nevertheless, Scripture states regarding them, Because ye believed not in Me (Num. 20:12); ye rebelled (Num. 27:14), and ye trespassed against Me (Deut. 33:51).

The astrologers say that the great conjunction of the two upper bodies170 was in the constellation of Taurus.171 This is a lie. The conjunction took place in Aquarius. According to the science of astrology this172 is Israel’s constellation. Many have tested this secret, generation after generation.173 I too have seen this to be the case. Look! They placed it at the midpoint of the sky.174
chapter.ftnote: 1 To construct the tabernacle.

2 See Mishnah Middot 4:7, “The sanctuary was narrow behind and wide in front, and it was like a lion, as it is written, Ah, Ariel (literally, lion of God), Ariel, the city where David encamped (Is. 29:1); as a lion is narrow behind and wide in front so the sanctuary was narrow behind and wide in front” (Danby translation).
3 Saadiah Gaon’s interpretation is not in keeping with the plain meaning of the text.
4 Which was wide in front and narrow in the back. They built the tabernacle, which was rectangular.

5 The tabernacle was not shaped like a lion; that is, it was not “narrow behind and wide in front.” There is thus no basis for Saadiah’s assertion that Bezalel and Oholiab were chosen to build the tabernacle because they were descended from people who were described as “lion’s whelps.”
6 In artistic skill.
7 Some editions read: be-anan kavod (in a glorious cloud). This meaning is difficult. Some emend it to read, be-inyon kavod (respectfully).

8 The word karati (I have called) is to be connected to bezalel ben uri (Bezalel the son of Uri) rather than to the word be-shem (by name). Thus karati be-shem bezalel ben uri (I have called by name Bezalel the son of Uri) is to be rendered: I have called Bezalel the son of Uri by name. I.E. comments thus because karati be-shem bezalel ben uri could conceivably be translated: I have called upon the name of Bezalel the son of Uri. Compare, va-yikra be-shem Adonai (and called upon the name of the Lord) (Gen. 12:8).
9 For Scripture continues, and I have filled him with the spirit of God, in wisdom…to devise skilful works, to work in gold, etc.

11 Caleb the son of Hezron was the father of Hur. Hur was the father of Uri. Uri was the father of Bezalel (I Chron. 2:19,20). The Talmud (San. 69b) identifies Caleb the son of Hezron with Caleb the son of Jephunneh. I.E. disagrees. For a full discussion, see Vol. 1, p. 355, note 20.

12 Caleb the son of Jephunneh was 39 years of age at the time that Bezalel constructed the tabernacle. For Caleb said, Forty years old was I when Moses the servant of the Lord sent me from Kadesh-barnea to spy out the land (Josh. 14:7). Now the tabernacle was constructed in the first year of the Exodus, and the spies were sent in the second year of the Exodus. Caleb was thus 39 years of age when Bezalel constructed the tabernacle. I.E. reasons that it is highly unlikely for a 39-year-old man to be a great-grandfather. In fact, the only way the sages of the Talmud could explain the aforementioned was to maintain that the early generations had children at the age of eight. See San. 69b and Vol. 1, p. 355, note 20.

13 I.E. divides intelligence into three parts: chokhmah (wisdom), binah (understanding), and da’at (knowledge). The kabbalists gave similar names to the first three sefirot (emanations). The term Chabad, which is the name of a well-known hassidic movement, is an acronym of these three terms.

14 Literally, wisdom is the form stored in the back of the brain of the head. I.E. divides the brain into three parts. Having similarly divided intelligence into three parts, I.E. held that each branch of intelligence has its particular compartment in the brain.
15 Tevunah and binah come from the same root and mean the same thing.
16 Tevunah and binah.
17 Where knowledge is stored.
18 Where wisdom is stored.

19 Hebrew, arakhim, one of the categories of medieval science. See erech in J. Klatzkin’s Otzar Ha-Munnachim Ha-Pilosofiyim, Vol. I, Berlin, 1928. Also see, H.A. Wolfson, The Classification of Sciences in Medieval Jewish Philosophy, in The Hebrew Union College Jubilee Volume, Cinn., 1925.
20 This is implied in I have filled him with the spirit of God, in wisdom, etc.
21 Scripture states that Bezalel was an expert in all workmanship, to devise skilful works, to work in gold, etc. (v. 4).
22 The vav means and.
23 Scripture wants to indicate that in addition to knowledge of the sciences, Bezalel also possessed knowledge of all manner of workmanship.
24 Hence Scripture singles out Bezalel’s skill in cutting of stones for setting, and in carving (literally, cutting) of wood (v. 5). For other interpretations, see Netter, and Krinsky.
25 In other words, verses 4 and 5 explain the last phrase in verse 3. I.E. explains the meaning of verse 3 here because he deals with Bezalel’s skills.

26 The work for the tabernacle’s construction. According to I.E., and in the hearts of all that are wise-hearted I have put wisdom should be interpreted as if written: and in the hearts of all that are wise-hearted I have put wisdom to do the work.

27 According to I.E., and in the hearts of all that are wise-hearted I have put wisdom means: I have endowed these people with the natural ability to create the various designs necessary for the temple’s construction. I.E.’s interpretation solves the problem as to where these men acquired the skill to construct the tabernacle.
28 It mentions the table before it mentions the other articles that stood in the sanctuary.
29 The table had many ritual objects associated with it. See I.E. on Ex. 25:22.

30 In other words, the bigde ha-serad are not to be identified with the holy garments. See Rashi, “I say, according to the plain meaning of the text it is impossible to maintain that Scripture speaks of the priestly garments.”
31 Unlike Aaron’s garments, each one of the plaited garments was a separate color of wool, blue, purple, or scarlet.
32 It then goes on to list Aaron’s garments in verses 2-26. We thus see that the bigde ha-serad are not to be identified with Aaron’s garments.

33 Filwarg explains that sarid means one who remains alone. Hence bigde serad means garments made of one type of material. Meijler explains that the word “remains” indicates a lower quality. He explains that the bigde ha-serad were called the remaining garments because they were inferior to the priestly garments.
34 “For the holy place” is short for: for the need of the holy place.
35 That is, follows spoke.
36 Or va-yomer (spoke) as in our verse.
37 In other words, when Scripture reads, va-yedabber el moshe lemor (he spoke to him saying), its meaning is, he spoke to Moses, saying to him.

38 Our verse reads: va-yomer Adonai el moshe lemor (and the Lord spoke unto Moses, saying). According to I.E. this should be interpreted: And the Lord told Moses to tell the [following to the] children of Israel. [He told him] Speak thou also unto the children of Israel, saying to them (lemor), Verily ye shall keep My sabbaths. So Zarza, Weiser, Krinsky, Netter, and Sarim. However, this interpretation is very difficult.
39 It should be noted that our verse reads: va-yomer, not va-yeddaber. However, I.E. considers va-yomer and va-yedabber as synonyms.
40 Literally, but. I.E. explains the use of the term ach (but).
41 God rested only on one day, namely, the very first Sabbath. Hence only it is God’s Sabbath.
42 If only one Sabbath is God’s Sabbath, then our verse should read, My sabbath.

43 See Rosh Ha-Shanah 31a: “The world will last six thousand years, and one thousand years it will be waste.” The Talmud there explains that Psalm 92, A psalm, a song, for the Sabbath day, refers to the latter. This “Sabbath” is called the Lord’s because on this Sabbath, God’s name alone shall be exalted. Hence our verse speaks of My sabbaths, the reference being to the Sabbath and to the seventh millennium.
44 Hence the plural is employed.
45 Hence the festivals are not included in My sabbaths.
46 So Vat. Ebr. 38. See Meijler, Netter, and Weiser. The printed texts read: “Note that we do not find the term Sabbath used with reference to the festivals. We only find what is written.”
48 Between the sages and Boethusians.
49 Translated literally.
50 According to the sages the sabbath in Lev. 23:15 refers to the festival of Passover. According to the Boethusians the word Sabbath is to be taken literally. See Menachot 66a.

51 The law contained in Lev. 23:15 refers to the day after the festival of Passover. However, Scripture refers to it as the morrow after the sabbath because the festival of Passover fell on a Sabbath the year this law was given. See I.E. on Lev. 23:11.
52 See Lev: 23:32, It (the Day of Atonement) shall be unto you a sabbath of solemn rest (shabbat shabbaton).
53 Hence it is not included in My sabbaths.
54 Hence, Ye shall keep the Sabbath, etc. that follows.
55 If the circumstances warrant it.
56 Which is not to be taken literally. See I.E. on Ex. 21:29.
57 Two witnesses are required to establish guilt.
58 I.E.’s paraphrase of for whosoever doeth any work therein, that soul shall be cut off from among his people.
59 That mot yumat does not mean he shall surely be put to death, for not everyone who violates the Sabbath is executed.
60 I.E. takes issue with the Rabbinic opinion that there is an obligation to work during the six days of the week. See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 20:9.
61 A masculine.
62 A feminine. This presents a problem, for according to Hebrew grammar, verbs and the nouns which they govern must be of the same gender.

63 In other words, ye’aseh melakhah is short for ye’aseh kol melakah (shall any sort of work be done). Filwarg points out that I.E. is of the opinion that in such cases verbs and nouns do not have to agree. Thus Esth. 1:20 reads: ve-khol ha-nashim yittenu (all the wives will give). Yittenu is masculine. Nashim is feminine. See I.E. on Esth. 1:20.

64 In other words, ye’aseh melakhah is short for ye’aseh devar ma’aseh melakhah (shall an act of work be done). Devar and ma’aseh are masculine. Filwarg suggests interpreting ye’aseh melakhah as short for ye’aseh devar melakhah (shall an act of work be done), or ye’aseh melakhah as short for ye’aseh ma’aseh melakhah (shall acts of work be done).
65 The meaning of whosoever doeth any work on the sabbath, he shall surely be put to death is: you shall kill him if he does work in public.
66 The literal meaning of la’asot is, to do or to make. Hence I.E.’s comment.
67 In that in both verses la’asot means to prepare.
68 Or prepare it.
69 Hebrew, berit.
70 Hebrew, ot.
72 Verses 16 and 17. The question thus arises, “Do circumcision and the Sabbath symbolize the same thing?”
73 Some ancient peoples practiced partial circumcision. Jewish law requires full circumcision.
74 Hence the use of the term ot (sign).
75 People will know that he is an Israelite. Thus according to Saadiah Gaon the Sabbath is the same sort of sign that circumcision is.
76 In other words, the Sabbath is a sign that God made heaven and earth in six days.
77 Literally, Scripture said.
78 Hence, and God rested has nothing to do with God being tired.
79 The planets and stars.
80 They do not tire.
81 The angels. They do not tire.
82 They (the empty heads) think that the mere observance of the commandments is the most important element in Judaism.

83 One must understand the reason for the commandments. According to I.E. this takes a vast amount of time. It should be noted that I.E. wrote a work called Sefer Yesod Morah Ve-Sod Torah (Treatise on the Foundation of Awe and the Secret of the Torah) on the commandments.

84 Some commandments are observed by speech. The purpose of these commandments is to train a person to observe all of God’s commandments. Here too mere verbal utterance is insufficient. One must know and understand what one is saying.
85 This refers to commandments that are observed by speech. Praying and reciting the shema are examples.
86 This indicates that one must understand what one is observing.
87 This refers to the commandments that are observed by actions.
88 San. 6b.
89 Maimonides makes the same point in the Guide of the Perplexed.
90 Either Deut. 3:24 is not to be taken as hyperbole, or what I.E. has just said is true.
91 See I.E. on Ex. 24:12.
92 The Torah employs human language so that those who hear its words will understand.
93 I.E. makes the same point in his comments on Gen. 1:3.
94 So Weiser. Literally, God’s words standing in heaven with regard to the lowly.
95 “Your decrees stand in heaven” (I.E. on Ps. 119:89).
96 That the Torah employs human language. So Weiser.
97 I.E. criticizes the Genonim for their lengthy comments. See I.E.’s introduction to his commentary on the Pentateuch, p. 1. Hence his apology.
98 The Talmud claims that he was the son of Miriam. See next note.
99 For resisting the making of the golden calf. See Shemot Rabba 41:10; Va-Yikra Rabba 10:3; San. 7a; and Pirke De-Rabbi Eliezer 45.
100 Aaron feared that the people might kill him if he did not accede to their wishes.
101 I.E. does not identify this source.
102 This commentator refuses to believe that Aaron acted out of fear for his own life.
103 For killing Aaron.
104 Like Hur.
105 See Dan. 3.
106 Aaron was more than an ordinary prophet. See I.E. on Ex. 7:7 and on Gen. 27:19 and the notes thereto.
107 Rather than make an idol.
108 If Aaron made an idol.
109 Hebrew, egel.
110 High priests.
112 All priest are descended from Aaron.

113 The sons of Aaron. These two sons had already been born when Aaron made the golden calf. They did not participate in the making or the worship of the golden calf. There is thus no reason why their descendants should have to bring a young bullock annually to atone for their ancestor’s making of the golden calf.
114 The son of Eleazar. Phinehas was the ancestor of high priests from the family of Zadok.
115 Hence there was no reason for his descendants to atone for the sin of the golden calf.

117 If the young bullock brought as a sin offering by the high priest on the Day of Atonement is interpreted as an atonement for the sin of making the golden calf, then a similar reason should be offered for the he-goat brought by the congregation on the Day of Atonement. However, Israel made a calf, not a he-goat. We thus see that Israel’s sin offering was not to atone for the sin of the golden calf. The same must be true of the offering brought by the high priest.
119 That is, to atone for the sin of the golden calf. This is the opinion of Rabbi Moshe Ha-Darshan. See Rashi on Num. 19:2.
120 To serve as His messenger to reveal commandments. Aaron served as such a messenger. See I.E. on Ex. 7:7.

121 That is, a messenger who reveals God’s commandments to Israel. Only Moses and Aaron served as such. See I.E. 27:19. I.E. comments thus because Jewish tradition considers Solomon and David as prophets. Yet David and Solomon sinned. Hence I.E. differentiates between a mere prophet and a prophet who is sent to reveal commandments.

122 The verse continues, Whom Thou didst prove at Massah, With whom Thou didst strive at the waters of Meribah. I.E. believes that the verse refers to Aaron. He interprets the first part of the verse as meaning, Aaron is fit to wear the Thummim and Urim because of his piety. He interprets the second part of the verse as meaning that the only stain on Aaron’s piety was the incident at the waters of Meribah. See I.E. on Deut. 33:8.
123 In Deut. 33:8.
124 For the incident at the waters of Meribah, see Num. 20:1-12.
126 If Aaron was tricked, he would have been shocked upon seeing the calf. He would not have commanded that an altar be built before the calf and burnt offerings be offered upon it.
127 That is, the congregation that gathered against Aaron and demanded that he make a god for them.
128 Moses appointed Aaron in his place till he returned.
129 Not only did Moses not kill the individual called Aaron, he prayed on his behalf.

130 The opinion that Aaron made the calf because he was afraid that Israel would kill him if he refused and that God in return would destroy Israel is also wrong. For it is not fitting that a pious man make an idol for others so that they do not die. Ibn Ezra here rejects the earlier quoted opinion that Aaron made the calf because he was afraid that God would destroy Israel if they killed Aaron. It should be noted that I.E. occasionally leaves out the first part of a clause. He expects the reader to fill it in.
131 This interpretation maintains that a feast (chag) to the Lord refers to the slaughter of the worshippers of the golden calf.
132 Translated according to I.E.

133 One should not maintain that while most people understood Tomorrow shall be a feast (chag) to the Lord to mean they would offer sacrifices on the next day, Aaron’s private meaning was: Tomorrow worshippers of the golden calf will be slaughtered.
134 He cannot claim that his intention was not to curse God.
135 He is killed for what he said. He cannot claim that he didn’t mean what he said.
136 See I.E. on Gen. 27:13 (Vol. 1, p. 262) and the notes thereto.
137 Nebuchadnezzar had a dream which signified that he would live as a beast for seven years.
138 According to the Talmud what Daniel meant was: God (My lord), the dream be upon Nebuchadnezzar (the dream be to them that hate thee). See Shavuot 35b.

139 According to I.E. the term my lord does not refer to God but to Nebuchadnezzar, for Daniel was addressing the king, and the rules of etiquette required that he say, My lord, the dream be to them that hate thee. Hence one cannot take his words out of context and interpret it the way the Talmud does.

140 King Jehu proclaimed a festival for Baal. His intention was not to serve Baal but to trick the worshippers of Baal to come to Baal’s temple, where Jehu would kill them. See II Kings 10:18-28. Aaron similarly wanted to identify those Israelites who wanted to worship the calf.
141 Hence Aaron built the altar before the golden calf.
142 If Aaron intended to trap the idol worshippers he would not have said, Tomorrow shall be a feast to the Lord (YHVH), for this is a call to worship YHVH and only YHVH.
143 Moses asked Aaron: What did this people unto thee, that thou hast brought a great sin upon them? (Ex. 32:21).
144 Aaron’s answer does not answer Moses’ question.
145 That is, the true meaning of the account of the making of the golden calf.
146 I.E. believes that Moses, rather than the pillar of fire, led Israel from the Red Sea to the wilderness of Sinai. See I.E. on Ex. 15:22.
147 If Moses had told them that he would be on the mount for forty days, they would not have assumed that he died there.
148 I.E.’s paraphrase of Ex. 24:12.

149 In other words, Israel did not ask Aaron to make an idol. They requested that he make an image which had the power to lead them. Thus aseh lanu elohim (Ex. 32:1) does not mean: make us a god. It means: make us an image which will be inhabited by a heavenly power.
150 Israel said: Up, make us a god (elohim) who shall go before us (Ex. 32:1). We thus see that they sought an elohim who would lead them.
151 Israel’s first journey from Egypt.

152 Scripture tells us that when Israel left Egypt, the Lord went before them by day in a pillar of cloud, to lead them the way; and by night in a pillar of fire (Ex. 13:21). After Egypt drowned in the Red Sea, Moses led Israel. See note 158. Now that Moses was dead, Israel sought a substitute for Moses. See I.E.’s short commentary: “They only sought someone to go before them to find them a resting place.”
153 God’s spirit was to rest on the calf and lead them in the same way that it rested in the pillars of fire and cloud. See I.E. on Ex. 13:21.
154 His spirit would rest on the calf.
155 Aaron did not actually say this. I.E.’s point is that Ex. 32:1 can be quoted in Aaron’s defense.
156 The point is that Aaron did not make the calf on his own. The people gathered upon him and demanded that he make an elohim to lead them.
158 I.E.’s interpretation of Make us a god, which shall go before us (Ex. 32:23).
159 I.E.’s interpretation of and I cast it into the fire and there came out this calf (Ex. 24:24).
160 According to I.E. ve-ra hu means there is evil in him; that is, some of the people are evil (Weiser).
161 Thy people implies that all the people sinned.
162 Thus only some of them sinned.
163 The prohibition against taking any loot from Jericho for personal use. See Josh. 6:17.
164 The Bible tells us that the Levites executed 3,000 Israelites for worshipping the calf (Ex. 32:28).
165 That is, one half of a percent, for 3,000 is half of a percent of 600,000. In other words, only one half of a percent of the Israelite camp actually worshipped the golden calf as a god.
167 He was inadvertently the cause of their sin.
169 Scripture charges Moses and Aaron with disbelief, rebellion, etc., even though they did not deliberately sin against God.
170 Meijler believes that the reference is to the sun and the moon. Weiser believes that I.E. refers to Saturn and Jupiter.
171 They believed that the calf was supposed to draw its supernatural power from Taurus.
172 Aquarius.
173 They have found that Israel’s luck improves when the above heavenly bodies are propitiously aligned in Aquarius.

174 They made the calf at the time when the sun was at the midpoint of the sky beneath Aquarius (Meijler). Or they made the calf when Aquarius was at the mid-point of the sky (Weiser). Either way, I.E.’s point is that they made the calf when Aquarius was in the most favorable position.

chapter.title: Chapter 32
chapter.p: 2. AND AARON SAID UNTO THEM: BREAK OFF THE GOLDEN RINGS. Pareku (break off) is vocalized like barekhu (bless). It is a pi’el.
It was the custom of the Egyptians to place rings in their ears.1 It is similarly written with regard to the Midianites, because they were Ishmaelites (Jud. 8:24).2
3. AND ALL THE PEOPLE BROKE OFF THE GOLDEN RINGS WHICH WERE IN THEIR EARS. In the ears of the above-mentioned sons, daughters, and wives.3

4. AND HE RECEIVED IT AT THEIR HAND, AND FASHIONED IT WITH A GRAVING TOOL. The word va-yatzar (and fashioned it) is related to the word tzurah (form).4 It is like the word va-yatzar (fashioned) in Thus he fashioned the two pillars of brass (I Kings 7:15).

[WITH A GRAVING TOOL.] The word cheret (graving tool) means an image.5 Be-cheret enosh (in common script) (Is. 8:1) similarly means in the form of a person.6 There is no reason to connect cheret to the word ha-charitim (the veils) (Is. 3:22).7
A MOLTEN CALF. The word masekhah means molten. It is similar to the word nasakh (hath melted)8 in The image perchance, which the craftsman hath melted (Is. 40:19).
5. AND WHEN AARON SAW THIS. In his heart.9 The word saw here is similar to the word saw in Then I saw (Eccles. 2:13),10 and the word saw in Now Jacob saw that there was corn in Egypt (Gen. 42:1).11
6. AND THEY ROSE UP EARLY ON THE MORROW. Following the day that the altar was built.12

9. AND THE LORD SAID. Stiffnecked means that they refuse to do as God commanded. They are like a person who runs along on his way and does not turn his head back to the one who calls him. This expression is employed with regard to the Israelites for the following reason. Scripture tells us that Israel served idols in Egypt. It reports that God sent prophets to them saying, “Let every man cast away the idols of Egypt.”13

Moses related this incident14 to their children15 before he died.16 Moses employed different terminology. However, the import of the words is the same as here. Scripture here states that God told Moses, Go, get thee down; for thy people…have dealt corruptly (v. 7). However, Moses later quoted God as saying, Arise, get thee down (Deut. 19:12). Scripture there17 writes, This is thy god, O Israel (v. 8).18 Scripture goes on to say here, Now therefore let Me alone (ve-attah ha-nichah li) (v. 10). However, it later reads, let Me alone (heref mi-menni) (Deut. 9:14). Scripture here reads, that My wrath may wax hot against them, and that I may consume them (v. 10). However, it later reads, that I may destroy them and blot out their name (Deut. 9:14). Scripture here reads, and I will make of thee a great nation (v. 10). However, Moses later quoted God as saying, and I will make of thee a nation mightier [and greater than they] (Deut. 9:14). The meanings are the same.

[10. NOW THEREFORE LET ME ALONE, THAT MY WRATH MAY WAX HOT AGAINST THEM, AND THAT I MAY CONSUME THEM.] God hinted to Moses that were He not concerned with Moses’ glory, He would destroy Israel.19 Hence Moses was compelled to pray.20

11. AND MOSES BESOUGHT. We encounter verbs from the root chet, lamed, heh that have this meaning21 only with regard to the face. Compare, Many will entreat (yechallu) the favour of the liberal man (Prov. 19:6). I believe that it is similar to and her face was no more (I Sam. 1:18).22 They are all similar.23 It is therefore incorrect to say chillitikha or achallekha,24 for chillitikha and achallekha are related to the word chillah (sick) in wherewith the Lord hath made it sick (Deut. 29:21).25

Some commentaries say that this prayer is the same prayer found in the Torah portion Ve-Hayah Ekev.26 This prayer should have been recorded following Moses’ return to the mountain (v. 31).27 Therefore the Lord repented of the evil (v. 14) after Moses prayed and fell upon his face for forty days (Deut. 10:10).28 If God repented first,29 what reason was there for Moses to say, peradventure I shall make atonement for your sin (v. 30)? The sequence of events was as follows: Moses descended, burned the calf, and killed its worshippers. He then returned to pray to God on behalf of Israel and on behalf of Aaron,30 who was the cause.31
Others say that the prayer O Lord God, destroy not Thy people (Deut. 9:26) is not the prayer which is mentioned here.32

I believe that the contents of both prayers are the same.33 I will later explain this point. For how could Moses beg God [not to destroy Israel] before he burned the calf, caused Israel to drink, and killed its worshippers?34 God only hinted to Moses35 that he should pray after he descended and removed the calf. Hence after Moses removed their sin36 Scripture reads, peradventure I shall make atonement for your sin (v. 30). We similarly read, And I took your sin, the calf which ye had made, [and burnt it with fire] (Deut. 9:21).

It was only because God told Moses, Now therefore let Me alone, that My wrath may wax hot against them (v. 10) that Moses37 mentioned the prayer that he prayed38 when he fell down before the Lord.39 Actually, this chapter40 should have been written after And Moses returned unto the Lord (v. 31). However, there is no chronological order in the Torah. Scripture was only concerned with connecting the statement Whosoever hath sinned against Me, [him will I blot out] (v. 33) with And now go, lead the people (v. 34).41 Scripture42 goes on to state, And the Lord smote the people (v. 35).

BESOUGHT. Look.43 Scripture writes, So I fell down before the Lord the forty days and forty nights that I fell down; because the Lord had said he would destroy you (Deut. 9:25). This is what let Me alone, that I may destroy them (Deut. 9:14) refers to.44 The mind cannot accept the idea that Moses prayed on behalf of Israel while an idol was among them.45 He first removed the idol.

Now, Lord, why doth Thy wrath wax hot against Thy people46 is similar to O Lord God, destroy not Thy people and Thine inheritance (Deut. 9:26). Scripture then goes on to say, that Thou didst bring out by Thy great power and by Thy outstretched arm (Deut. 9:29). This is parallel to that Thou hast brought forth out of the land of Egypt with great power and with a mighty hand.47

Scripture writes, Remember Thy servants, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob (Deut. 9:27). This is parallel to Remember Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, Thy servants, to whom Thou didst swear by Thine own self (v. 13). Its meaning48 is, remember the oath which you swore to them.49 Scripture does not mention the oath in the verse that reads, Remember Thy servants (Deut. 9:27). For there is a difference in meaning between zekhor la’avadekha (remember Thy servants) (Deut. 9:27) and zekhor adatekha (remember Thy congregation) in Remember Thy congregation, which Thou hast gotten of old (Ps. 74:2), because of the lamed.50
Now, lest the land whence Thou broughtest us out say (Deut. 9:28) is parallel to Wherefore should the Egyptians speak, saying (v. 12).

12. [FOR EVIL DID HE BRING THEM FORTH.] The meaning of be-ra’a hotzi’am (for evil did He bring them forth) is, as our ancients hint,51 that they went out of Egypt under a star called ra (evil).52 Now Egypt will say that God does not have the ability to overcome the power of this star and save those who cleave to him. Hence when He saw that He was unable to overcome the star, He killed them.53 This will desecrate God’s name.

Now54 Moses fell before God forty days.55 God then told him, for I will not go up in the midst of thee (Ex. 33:3). They will thus not inherit the land.56 Moses then said everything contained in the portion that opens with the words, See, Thou sayest unto me (Ex. 33:12).57 God then commanded him to descend, hew out tablets, and carry them in his hands up to the mountain.58 God then descended in a cloud59 and the skin of Moses’ face sent forth beams.60 God then wrote the second tablets.61 Scripture therefore reads, At that time the Lord said unto me: Hew thee two tables of stone like unto the first…and make thee an ark of wood (Deut. 10:1). Israel was thus told to make the ark. This is the ark that Bezalel made.62

14. AND THE LORD REPENTED. Heaven forbid for the Lord to repent.63 Rather, Scripture employed human terminology. Compare, And God went up (Gen. 35:13);64 And the Lord came down (Gen. 11:5);65 Let the Lord rejoice in His works (Ps. 105:31), and, And it grieved Him at His heart (Gen. 6:6).66 Look, Samuel said, And also the Glory of Israel will not lie nor repent (I Sam. 15:29). Nevertheless, Scripture there reads, It repenteth Me (I Sam. 15:11).67
There are those who explain68 va-yinachem (repented) by the Arabic word wa’ad.69 However, there is no need for this.
15. AND MOSES TURNED. Scripture here tells us,70 and the mount burned with fire (Deut. 9:15).

The meaning of and Moses turned is that Moses looked around like a person who looks around and contemplates his course of action71. Moses saw that he had to descend quickly. Va-yifen (turned) here is similar to va-yifen koh va-kho (and he looked this way and that way) (Ex. 2:12).

[IN HIS HAND.] In his possession.72 It is similar to And take with thee ten men.73 For we cannot understand how Moses was able to bring down one tablet in his hand. It is next to impossible to believe that he carried down two tablets in his hand.74

[TABLES THAT WERE WRITTEN ON BOTH THEIR SIDES.] Now since Scripture explicitly tells us that the tablets were written on both sides, they could not have been made out of any of the stones that are mentioned with regard to the breastplate,75 for what was seen on one side would then be seen on the other side. The word ketuvim (written) does not mean seen.76 Ketuvim means written. Scripture tells us that what was written on one side was also written on the other side.77 Each tablet was thus thick.

There is no need to assume that the mem and the samekh which were inscribed in the tablets were miraculously suspended,78 for there is a difference of opinion regarding the meaning of the term ashurit.79 Some believe that the word ashurit means a praise-worthy script.80 Others maintain that it refers to the script which they brought up from Assyria.81 Furthermore, if the letters were visible on the reverse side, then the letters would appear backwards.82

There is no room for one to argue with me and ask whether these stones were precious.83 The answer is that the stones were very precious because the writing of God was engraved upon them. The stones had to be thick. Where would Moses find very precious stones that were a cubit in length, a cubit and a half in width,84 and a cubit in height? Furthermore, where would Moses get the raw material to hew out two tablets of precious stones of the same dimensions as the first stones?

Now we do not know the way the Ten Statements were written on the two tablets without Moses having to turn them over.85 Hence after telling us that were written on both their sides, Scripture goes on to say, on the one side and on the other side were they written.

We have no way of knowing whether each one of the tablets was completely covered with writing, or whether some blank spaces were left on the four corners as we do today with our books. We similarly do not know whether the writing was thick or thin. There is no reason for us to speculate concerning things for which we do not have a tradition.

16. AND THE TABLES WERE THE WORK OF GOD. Our ancients said that it was decreed86 that they be like this.87 I have already explained this at the beginning of the Book of Bereshit.88 However, I believe that the meaning of the work of God is that they were created in their proper dimensions.89 This is mentioned because of the second tablets, which Moses hewed out.90

[GRAVEN.] Some say that the word charut91 means charush92 (graven).93 Others invert the letters94 and come up with the word chatar (dig) (Ezek. 8:8).95 Actually, the word has no counterpart [is a hapax legomenon]. It is possibly similar in meaning to the word patu’ach (engraved).96
17. AND WHEN JOSHUA HEARD. And when Joshua, who remained at the foot of the mountain, heard.

AS THEY SHOUTED. The word be-re’o (as they shouted) is related to the word tru’ah (shouting).97 As the word de’iy (my knowledge) in I will fetch my knowledge from afar (Job. 36:3) is derived from yada, so is the word yara derived from re’o.98 The same applies to lamah tri’iy re’a (why dost thou cry out aloud) (Micah 4:9).99

18. AND HE SAID. Saadiah Gaon says that Joshua also said this.100 However, I believe that these are the words of Moses.101 And it came to pass, as soon as he came nigh unto the camp which follows (v. 19) is proof of this.
BEING OVERCOME. The word chalushah (overcome) is a noun. It is similar to the word gevurah102 (mastery).
THE NOISE OF THEM THAT SING. Anot (that sing) means tunes. This is what and rose up to make merry refers to (v. 6).

THAT HE SAW THE CALF AND THE DANCING. The heh103 prefixed to the word egel (calf) also refers to the word u-mecholot (and the dancing). The verse should be understood as follows: that he saw the calf and the dancing around it.

Moses was overcome by great jealousy.104 He therefore broke the tablets which were in his hands and served, as it were, as a document of witness105 Moses thus106 tore up the contract.107 As Scripture states, he did this in the sight of all of Israel.

20. AND HE TOOK THE CALF. Some say that the meaning of and burnt it with fire is that he melted it in fire.108 However, there is no need for this, for there is a substance109 which, when put into the fire along with the gold, causes the gold to immediately catch fire, turn black, and never again turn back into gold. This has been tested and found to be true.

AND STREWED IT UPON THE WATER. The reference is to the water from the brook that descended out of the mountain.110 Moses commanded all of Israel to drink from these waters. This was similar to and of the dust that is on the floor of the tabernacle the priest shall take, and put it into the water (Num. 5:17).111 Now the water caused a sign to appear on the face of those who served the calf or their bellies swelled up. For otherwise, how could the Levites know who worshipped the golden calf? We have already said that very few of the Israelites had evil thoughts.112 The intention of all113 was to do good.
21. AND MOSES SAID. Observe. Moses asked why Aaron needed to make the calf.114
22. AND AARON SAID: LET NOT THE ANGER OF MY LORD WAX HOT. Aaron called Moses my lord because of Moses’ great station.
[THAT THEY ARE SET ON EVIL.] I have already explained the meaning of that they are set on evil.115 Similarly, So they said unto me (v. 23)116 and, And I said unto them (v. 24).117

25. AND WHEN MOSES SAW THAT THE PEOPLE WERE BROKEN LOOSE. The word paru’a (broken loose) is similar to yippare’a (cast off restraint) in Where there is no vision, the people cast off restraint (Prov. 28:18), and va-tifre’u (ye have set at nought) in But ye have set at nought all my counsel (Prov. 1:25).
[FOR A DERISION.] Scripture employs an adjective (le-shimtzah) in place of an infinitive.118 The meaning of le-shimtzah (for a derision) is that they will be a derision, a blemish, a defamation.119

AMONG THEIR ENEMIES. Kamehem (their enemies)120 is similar to kamim alai (rise up against me)121 in Many are they that rise up against me (Ps. 3:2) and the abridged form kamai (rise up against me)122 in that rise up against me (Ps. 18:49). However, the Aramaic translation connects kamehem to the word kamtem (ye are risen) in And, behold, ye are risen up in your fathers’ stead (Num. 32:14).123

26. THEN MOSES STOOD. It is the practice of all camps that stay in one place for about a year124 to erect booths and have gates.125 In such a case, there is no need to set aside a place outside the camp as a latrine.126
WHOSO IS ON THE LORD’S SIDE. Shall draw close to me; shall come near to me; shall come to me or shall gather to me.127
THE SONS OF LEVI. Who were of Moses’ family.
27. AND HE SAID UNTO THEM. Moses referred to the Lord as the God of Israel because those who worshipped the calf thought that the Lord was to be identified with the calf.128

AND SLAY EVERY MAN HIS BROTHER. Even if it be his brother.129 Many interpret Who said of his father, and of his mother: I have not seen him (Deut. 33:9) as referring to this incident.130 They had to explain his father and his mother as referring to the father of the mother.131 However, as I will explain, there is no need for this interpretation.
28. AND THE SONS OF LEVI DID. Not all the sons of Levi.132
29. AND MOSES SAID. Its meaning is, and Moses already said to them.133 It is similar to Then the Lord God formed (Gen. 2:7).134 There are many other such examples.135
[CONSECRATE.] The word milu (consecrate), which is in the kal, is grammatically irregular. It is sometimes transitive and at other times intransitive.136

[FOR EVERY MAN HATH BEEN AGAINST HIS SON.] Even if the worshipper be his son or brother he must kill him. They will be rewarded with a blessing for doing this. This is what At that time137 the Lord separated the tribe of Levi (Deut. 10:8) refers to. Its meaning is that God told Moses at Mount Sinai the reason the tribe of Levi was set aside. Scripture therefore reads, Now these are the generations of Aaron and Moses in the day that the Lord spoke with Moses in mount Sinai138 (Num. 3:1).

Now Aaron, his sons, and the Levites were separated139 to serve the Lord at the time that the tabernacle was erected. Korah’s quarrel140 took place at that time. Korah was a first-born.141 Korah rebelled when God set aside the Levites in place of the first-born who were holy.142 God did this because the first-born143 brought the burnt offerings before the calf and they slaughtered peace offerings upon the altar, which was made before the calf.
30. AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE MORROW. Following his descent.144

AND NOW I WILL GO UP. To return to the mountain to fall before the Lord and atone for Israel as I have explained.145 Perhaps God will write another pair of tablets in order to make a covenant with Israel. This is the meaning of Behold, I make a covenant (Ex. 34:10).146 For the tablets were, as it were, a document of witness.

31. AND MOSES RETURNED. The Nagid147 says that a lamed has been dropped and compensated for148 in the word anna (oh), which is short for al na (please consent). He maintains that the word al149 is related to the word ho’il (consent).150 However, this is far-fetched. On the contrary, its meaning is: please (anna) don’t do this.151 Anna is an expression of appeasement,152 or confession, as here.153 Anna (I beseech Thee) in I beseech Thee, O Lord, for I am Thy servant (Ps. 116:16) is similar.

32. YET NOW…BLOT ME, I PRAY THEE, OUT OF THY BOOK. I have already explained in my comments on And the books were opened, in the Book of Daniel (7:10), that all the decrees regarding masses and individuals are contingent upon the arrangements in the sky.154 Our sages have already admitted that children, longevity, and prosperity [depend upon the influence of the stars].155 However, God, as I have explained, increases the good which the heavenly arrangements have decreed because of a person’s fear of the Lord.

33. AND THE LORD SAID. Saadiah Gaon says that this is what And the Lord repented (v. 14) refers to, for God had said that He would destroy all.156 The meaning of our verse is: Look. I will blot out of My book only those who sinned against Me in their minds.157 The aforementioned is to be understood after the manner of that I may take the house of Israel in their own heart (Ezek. 14:5).158 They were not killed159 because they did not actually worship the calf. This is the meaning of: And the Lord smote the people, because the calf was made and doubt160 came to people privately.161

34. AND NOW GO, LEAD THE PEOPLE UNTO THE PLACE OF WHICH I HAVE SPOKEN UNTO THEE. That is, unto the place of the Canaanite (Ex. 3:8). This was said in anger.162 God told Moses, I have forgiven their sin because of you. Now you, who love them so much, go lead them.
IN THE DAY. The beginning of every year is the day of accounting.163
35. AND THE LORD SMOTE. It is possible that there was no plague in the first year.164 The Torah merely reports what happened after they journeyed from Mount Sinai.165

Most letters of the alphabet are so shaped that it is possible to inscribe them in this manner. However, the final mem and samekh are round and cannot be so engraved. Hence Rabbi Chisda says that these letters stood on the tablets miraculously. I.E., as will soon be seen, disagrees with this interpretation.
79 The Hebrew square script is called ketav ashuri. There is a difference of opinion in the Talmud as to the origin of this term. See San. 22a.

The Talmud, which maintains that the mem and the samekh were miraculously suspended on the tablets, accepts this opinion. So does I.E. in his comments on Ex. 1:9. Nevertheless, he argues that one does not have to assume that the mem and the samekh were miraculously suspended on the tablets, as he believes that the tablets were written on both sides and not chiseled through.

81 Hebrew, ashur. Hence the term ashurit. According to this opinion the Torah was given in ketav ivri, the ancient Hebrew script. In this script neither the samekh nor the mem is oval. According to this opinion there is no need to assume that the mem and the samekh were miraculously suspended on the tablets. I.E. quotes these two opinions in order to show that the rabbis themselves were divided as to whether the mem and the samekh were miraculously suspended on the tablets.
82 They could thus be read on only one side. What point would there be then for the writing to be chiseled through?
