159 By the Levites.
160 That is, they thought that the calf was a god. They thus doubted the truth of the existence of only one God.
161 I.E.’s interpretation and paraphrase of verse 35.
162 Hence the place is not mentioned.
163 On the day when God judges each individual he will take the person’s sin into consideration.

164 The number of Israelites did not diminish between the first census, which took place before the erection of the tabernacle (Ex. 38:26), and the second census a month after the erection of the tabernacle (Num. 1:1).

165 In other words, And the Lord smote, etc., refers to what happened to Israel after they journeyed from Mount Sinai on the twentieth day of the second month in the second year following the Exodus (Num 10:11).

chapter.title: Chapter 33
chapter.p: 1. AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES: DEPART, GO UP HENCE. Scripture reads go up because one who goes towards the left side1 goes up.2 Abraham therefore went down into Egypt (Gen. 12:10)3 because he was in the south.4
[JACOB.] I will do all of this5 because of the oath which I swore to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
2. AND I WILL SEND AN ANGEL BEFORE THEE. To help you.
[AN ANGEL.] Scripture does not read the angel6 because the angel7 refers to the angel which is known to have God’s name in him.8
3. FOR I WILL NOT GO UP IN THE MIDST OF THEE. They will not erect the tabernacle,9 for I will not rest in the midst of Israel.
[LEST I CONSUME THEE IN THE WAY.] I will immediately consume them if they once again act in this manner.

Akhelkha (I consume thee) is vocalized with a segol10 in place of a pattach, and its lamed does not have a dagesh in it even though the rules of grammar require it.11 Compare the word achavvekha (I will tell thee)12 in I will tell thee, hear thou me (Job 15:17).13

4. AND WHEN THE PEOPLE HEARD THESE EVIL TIDINGS. What evil tidings?14 The reference is to what is written afterwards, And the Lord said unto Moses, etc. (v. 5).15 And the Lord said unto Moses (Ex. 4:19) is similar.16 I have already explained17 the meaning of Can He give bread also (Ps. 78:20).18 It19 is like And He commanded the skies above (Ps. 78:23),20 the meaning of which is, and He had already commanded the skies.21 This is also the case here.22 There is no need for the Geonic interpretation to the effect that they always did so.23

6. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL STRIPPED THEMSELVES OF THEIR ORNAMENTS. Et edyam means of their ornaments.24 The reference is to their fine garments and ornaments such as rings worn on the ears and fingers. The word edyam is to be interpreted in light of va-edekh edi (I decked thee also with ornaments) (Ezek. 16:11).25 Israel stripped themselves of their ornaments because they mourned over the incident of the calf.
7. NOW MOSES USED TO TAKE THE TENT. Scripture employs an imperfect26 in place of a perfect.27 We find the same in They made a calf in Horeb (Ps. 106:19).28
THE TENT. His tent.29 It is like and they came into the tent (Ex. 18:7).30

[NOW MOSES USED TO TAKE THE TENT AND PITCH IT WITHOUT THE CAMP, AFAR OFF FROM THE CAMP; AND HE CALLED IT THE TENT OF MEETING.] Look. Moses was separated from Israel because of the Glory that used to speak with him. This took place after he brought down the inscribed second tablets31 and Israel began to construct the tabernacle. Moses called his tent the tent of meeting because God met with him there until the tabernacle was erected. There is no chronological order in the Torah.32
Some say that the tent refers to the tabernacle and that Scripture tells us where the tabernacle was located during the fifty days before the banners were set up.33
9. AND IT CAME TO PASS. This34 too was a sign.35 Israel saw that as soon as Moses came to the tent from the camp of the Israelites he immediately saw the pillar of cloud.

10. AND WHEN ALL THE PEOPLE SAW. This took place after what is reported in the section beginning with the words, See, Thou sayest unto me (v. 12), for what is recorded in the latter chapter occurred during the forty days that Moses fell before the Lord concerning the incident of the calf. After this, Moses descended and hewed out the stones. God then passed by Moses, and this led to the fulfillment of God’s word, and thou shalt see My back (v. 23).36
11. AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES FACE TO FACE. I will explain this in a section that will soon follow.37

BUT HIS MINISTER JOSHUA, THE SON OF NUN, A YOUNG MAN. Joshua lived a hundred and ten years.38 Our sages said that Joshua spent seven years conquering Canaan and seven years dividing it up.39 If this is the case, then Joshua was now fifty-six years old.40 Why then did Scripture call him a young man? This is its grammatical explanation. His minister Joshua, the son of Nun, performed the service of a young man.41
12. AND MOSES SAID UNTO THE LORD: SEE, THOU SAYEST UNTO ME. See means see the predicament in which I find myself.42
I will now grammatically explain the section.43
[I KNOW THEE.] Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that yedatikha (I know thee) means I have honored thee. However, this is incorrect, for that I may know Thee (v. 13) just as You know me follows.44

14. [MY PRESENCE.] Saadiah Gaon says that the meaning of the word panai (my presence)45 means my anger, as in u-fanehah lo hayu lah od (and her countenance was no more sad) (I Sam. 1:18).46 Now, what will the Gaon do with the word panekha (thy presence) in If Thy presence go not with me (v. 15)?47
I believe that panai means I, myself. It is similar to the word panekha (thine own person) in and that thou go to battle in thine own person (panekha) (II Sam. 17:11).

16. SO THAT WE ARE DISTINGUISHED. Ve-niflinu (so that we are distinguished) comes from the same root as ve-hiflah (shall make a division) in And the Lord shall make a division (Ex. 9:4). It belongs to those roots which end in a heh.48

18. THY GLORY. Your very self, for Scripture explicitly states, And it shall come to pass, while My glory passeth by, that I will put thee in a cleft of the rock, and will cover thee with My hand until I have passed by (v. 22).

[19. AND WILL PROCLAIM THE NAME OF THE LORD.] Scripture writes with regard to Abraham, and (he) called upon the name (be-shem) of the Lord (Gen. 12:8).49 People were the ones who were called upon to serve the Lord.50 The word be-shem (upon the name) is therefore connected51 to God’s glorious name. However, this is not the case with and proclaimed the name of the Lord (Ex. 34:5),52 for here the Lord is the one who calls.53 It is the same case with and will proclaim the name of the Lord before thee.54

20. SEE ME. The word yirani (see me)55 is vocalized with a kamatz.56 It is vocalized like ro’ani (seeth me)57 in And sayest58 none seeth me (Is. 47:10), and le-hotzi’anu (to bring us forth)59 in to bring us forth out of Egypt (Ex. 14:11), and yeshivani (bring me back)60 in If the Lord shall indeed bring me back to Jerusalem (II Sam. 15:8).
[AND LIVE.] The meaning of va-chai (and live) is, and will live.61

[FOR MAN SHALL NOT SEE ME AND LIVE.] For he will immediately die. Thus, upon seeing God’s messenger, Manoah said, We shall surely die, because we have seen an angel (Jud. 13:22).62 Jacob similarly said, I have seen an angel face to face, and my life is preserved (Gen. 32:31).63 How much more is this true for one who beholds the Lord?
Some say for man shall not see Me [and live] means: only he who lives forever64 shall see Me.65 However, this is not in keeping with the text.66

Others say that the word lo (not) is also to be applied to the word va-chai (and live). Our text is to be read as if written, for neither man, nor he who lives, shall see Me.67 The reference is to the angels.68

21. AND THOU SHALT STAND UPON THE ROCK. The reference is to the top of the mountain,69 for Scripture clearly states, and present thyself there to Me on the top of the mount (Ex. 34:2). God told Moses to stand there and God himself would place him in a cleft of the rock when the Lord’s glory passed by (v. 22). For Scripture clearly states, that I will put thee in a cleft of the rock (v. 22). Scripture does not say that Moses should place himself in a cleft of the rock.
I will now explain the meaning of the portion.

Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that God told Moses:70 Bring up this people from this place wherein they sinned and I will forgive them71 in another place.72 Moses replied: If your anger is not removed from Israel in this place then carry us not up hence.73 However, the following appears to me to be the correct interpretation of the chapter. God told Moses, and I will send an angel before thee (v. 2).74 Moses then responded, and Thou hast not let me know whom Thou wilt send with me (v. 12), that is, whether this angel is the one concerning whom Scripture writes, for My name is in him (Ex. 23:21). God answered Moses, My presence shall go with thee, and I will give thee rest (v. 14). The meaning of thee is: because I will go only with thee, but I will not rest in the midst of the children of Israel. Moses therefore responded, if Thy presence go not up with this nation, mentioned earlier by Moses in that this nation is Thy people (v. 13), [carry us not up hence].75 Hence Moses employed the plural al ta’alenu (carry us not up).76 For wherein now shall it be known that I have found grace in Thy sight…is it not in that Thou goest with us (v. 16) is positive proof that this explanation77 is correct.

God then answered Moses, I will do this thing also that thou hast spoken, for thou hast found grace in My sight (v. 17). Moses was extremely happy to hear this and therefore said, let the Lord, I pray Thee, go in the midst of us (Ex. 34:9). The latter stands in marked contrast to for I will not go up in the midst of thee (v. 3).

Moses desired to see the Lord.78 God answered him, for man shall not see Me and live (v. 20). This is the truth. For the senses only feel that which is transient. Therefore and they saw the God of Israel (Ex. 24:10), I saw the Lord sitting upon a throne (Is. 6:1), and the prophecies of Ezekiel79 were all visions of God.
Look, Scripture here states, and thou shalt see My back. It states elsewhere, and the similitude of the Lord doth he80 behold (Num. 12:8). These things require a long explanation.

Saadiah Gaon says that face81 refers to the face of the light. Let the face of the sun serve as an example.82 The back83 refers to the remaining light that cleaves to a person.84 There is no need for all of this.85 However, before I explain this let me say the following: Know that God only spoke to Moses face to face from the third series of forty days86 onward. Moses’ face shone because God passed by his face. Moses’ prophecy at first was through the angel who appeared in the bush.87 Scripture there states, And the Lord said (Ex. 3:7).88 The same is true of And the Lord went before them (Ex. 13:21),89 for the messenger speaks in place of the one who sent him.90 The day that Moses saw what he requested was, to him, what the day of the giving of the Torah was to Israel. No human being who lived before or after Moses ever reached Moses’ status.

Our sages said that God showed Moses the knot of the tefillin.91 There words are correct. However, its meaning is not in accordance with that of the wise men of this generation who interpret the Rabbinical statement literally. On the contrary, it has a deeply hidden secret meaning.
Abraham the author states: I have already explained that the name of God, which is written but not pronounced,92 is a proper name.93 This proper name refers to the Glory.94
If you add up all of the letters of God’s proper name you get seventy-two.95 The sages therefore said that it is God’s explicit name.96

If you add the square of one, the first number, to the square of five, the true middle number,97 you will get the numerical equivalent of God’s name.98 This is also true regarding the five moving stars.99
When you add up the letters that one enunciates in naming half of the letters that make up God’s name100 you will also get the numerical equivalent of God’s name.101
When you add up the squares of the first four square numbers102 you get the numerical equivalent of half of God’s name.103
When you multiply the first half of God’s name104 by the second half of God’s name105 you get the sum of the square of the odd numbers.106

When you subtract the square of the first letter of God’s name107 from the sum of the squares of the first two letters108 of God’s name, the remainder will be equivalent to the cube of the second letter of God’s name.109

If you subtract the square of the first two letters of God’s name110 from the square of the first three letters of God’s name,111 the remainder112 will be equivalent to the cube of the third letter of God’s name.113

This glorious God is similar to the number one which stands by itself and has no need for any number before it.114 If you consider the role that the number one plays in a sum of numbers, you will discover that one is the first of all the numbers in any sum, and that all sums consist of ones. God similarly is the One who is all.115 This is therefore the secret of the prayers and praises.116 It is the meaning of Thus will I magnify Myself, and sanctify Myself (Ezek. 38:23)117 and of in whom I will he glorified (Is. 49:3).118

Now the One has no image. He encompasses all the images,119 for they all came from Him. Observe, the heavenly bodies, namely, the lights and the stars, have no front or back. This is certainly the case with man’s heavenly soul. This is surely the case with those who serve on high.120 This is beyond the shadow of a doubt the case with the Most High.121

Now there is a vertical line between the two points.122 The point closest to the Creator123 is known as “the prince of the face”124 and “the prince of power.”125 The point which lies on the opposite end of the line marks the end of power.126 Man moves frontward.127 The body which is on high moves towards the right.128 Plants grow upward.129

Now Moses was able to know and perceive intellectually how human beings cleave to the Creator of the world130 who is called “the back” (v. 23). It is the nature of the Glory131 that no created being may have the power to know this.132 This is the meaning of for man shall not see Me and live (Ex. 33:20). This is so because man’s soul is in a body.133

Now, after an intelligent person dies, his soul reaches a very high stage. It is a state which it could not reach while the individual was alive. Look, Moses134 became all-encompassing.135 God therefore told Moses, I know thee by name (v. 12),136 for only God knows the individuals and their parts in an all-encompassing manner.
Man is the most important being upon the earth. Hence the form of the cherubim.137 Israel is the most important type of human being.138 Hence the statement regarding the knot of the tefillin.139

The Shi’ur Komah140 therefore141 writes that God created all corporeal beings and all beings more glorious than corporeal beings.142 The accidents143 are of less significance than the corporeal beings.144

Furthermore, Rabbi Ishmael says,145 “Whoever knows the measure of the Creator of the world146 is assured of a place in the world to come. I and Rabbi Akiba vouch for this.” This is the meaning of Let us make man in our image, after our likeness (Gen. 1:26).147

Note, all plants, all that live on the earth, all fowl, cattle, animal, creeping thing and all human beings148 are tied to the forty-eight forms of the sphere.149 This is the meaning of [and when thou seest the sun and the moon and the stars, even all the host of heaven…] which the Lord thy God hath allotted unto all the peoples under the whole heaven (Deut 4:19).150 Those who added “to give light”151 did so to explain the verse. It is possible that they knew this152 but did not want to reveal this secret to the students. And that He had not allotted unto them (Deut. 29:25)153 is positive proof of this.154

It is known that the seven moving stars155 have 120 possible conjunctions.156 The seven moving stars form the great conjunction in only one way.157 There are twenty-one two-star conjunctions.158 It is the same case with five-star conjunctions.159 This number results from seven.160

The stars can be in a three-star conjunction in thirty-five ways,161 for this number too is a result of the conjunctions of the seven moving stars.162 The same is true of a four-star conjunction.163 Now the stars can be in a six-star conjunction in seven ways.164

The influence of the conjunction which takes in all peoples of the earth165 varies in accordance with the constellation of every one166 of the seven sections167 which constitute the inhabited world.168 Scripture says concerning them, Thou hast set all the borders of the earth; Thou hast made summer and winter (Ps. 74:17), which differ in all of the areas.

Change does not come from the sun itself but because of its movement towards the north and south. Now the conjunction of the sun and moon in Aries169 occurs every 960 years. These two turn from the constellation with which they are in conjunction to the ninth constellation170 every twenty years. They make this cycle twelve times for a total of two hundred and forty years.171 From there172 they travel in the same manner and in an identical time period in the constellations of “dust,”173 the constellations of “air,”174 and the constellations of “water.”175

Do not think that the four elements are in heaven176 and that there is heat in the sun and coldness in the moon and Saturn.177 Heaven forbid.178 The creations that are high and above are glorious.179 Scripture says concerning them, For He commanded, and they were created (Ps. 148:5). He hath established them for ever and ever; He hath made a decree which shall not be transgressed (Ps. 148:6).180 They were created in this way181 only because of those whom they affect.182

The seven moving stars183 cannot change their nature. They cannot violate that which God has assigned to them. The same applies to the hosts of heaven. The inhabitants of the lower world are affected by them in accordance with their184 makeup. Hence they cannot benefit or harm. Thus they cannot help one who bows down to them, for what was decreed for him in accordance with the arrangements of the stars at the time of his birth shall befall him. He can only be saved from his fate if he cleaves to and is protected by a power that is higher and more powerful than the stars.

I will explain with a worthy parable. The arrangement of the stars had it that a river would overpower a city and kill or flood its inhabitants. A prophet came and warned the people to turn to God before the arrival of the day of their calamity. The people turned to God with all their heart. Because the people cleaved unto God, God put it into their hearts to go out of the city to pray unto the Lord. They did this. On the appointed day the river suddenly overflowed, as is its nature. We have witnessed this many times. The river flooded the entire city. Now God’s decree was not altered and He saved them.

Imagine the following: The seven moving stars are like horses that run along a path. They do not run with the intention of doing good or bad. They act in accordance with their nature. Now imagine that a blind man is in their path. The blind man does not know how the horses act. He does not know when they go to the right and when they go to the left. The blind man depends on a person with sight who knows the way the horses run. Now the person with sight will guard the blind man. When the horses run to one side he will lead the blind person to the other side. The course of the horse’s running does not change but the blind man is saved. It is because of this that Scripture states, [the sun, and the moon and the stars, even all the host of heaven…] which the Lord thy God hath allotted [unto all the peoples under the whole heaven] (Deut. 4:19); But you hath the Lord taken…to be unto Him a people of inheritance (Deut. 4:20). The portion of Jacob is not like these, For He is the former of all things (Jer. 51:19). This is the meaning of so that we are distinguished, I and Thy people (v. 16). This is what the rabbis mean by “Israel has no constellation”185 as long as they keep the Torah.186 If Israel does not keep the Torah, then the star rules over them, as has been proven, for any conjunction combined with Aquarius187 is an evil arrangement. It results in harm befalling Israel. This is admitted by the astrologers.

Now the stars were arranged in a conjunction which decreed that Israel should remain in exile in Egypt for many more years.188 God delivered them because they cried out unto the Lord and turned to Him (Ex. 2:23). What is true for the group189 is true for the individual.190 Therefore But he that keepeth the law, happy is he (Prov. 29:18). Observe, I know thee by name (v. 12) is similar to For the Lord knoweth the way of the righteous191 (Ps. 1:6).192

Note, Show me, I pray Thee, Thy glory (v. 18) does not refer to seeing with the eyes.193 Observe. Al panekha (before thee) (v. 19)194 means: before thy inner face. It refers to the face of the heart.195 Kol tuvi (all my goodness) does not mean all. Neither does it mean in all or with all.196

And I will be gracious to whom I will be gracious (v. 19) refers to Moses, for Scripture tells us, I will make all My goodness pass before thee (Ibid.). However, before I pass before thee I will show mercy to you;197 that is, I will cover you with My hand (v. 22). Look, this is its (v. 22) meaning. The hand served as a type of cover,198 as in the case of a person who uses his hand to ward off the light of the sun so that his soul does not separate from his body.

Observe. Scripture states, and thou shalt see My back (v. 23) because God is all, His glory fills all, from Him is all, and He encompasses all of their images.199 This is the meaning of and the similitude of the Lord doth he behold (Num. 12:8).
22. AND I WILL COVER THEE. Ve-sakkoti (and I will cover thee) has the same meaning whether spelled with a sin or a samekh.200

Some commentaries say that kappi (My hand) is to be interpreted My cloud,201 as in al kappayim kissah or (He covereth His hands (or cloud) with the lightning) (Job. 36:32) and hen al kappayim chakkotikh (Behold, I have graven thee upon the palms of My hands) (Is. 49:16).202 However, it is to be translated literally.203

23. BUT MY FACE SHALL NOT BE SEEN. Yera’u (shall be seen) refers to My face. However, this is not the Case with yera’u (shall be seen) in they204 shall not be seen before My face empty (Ex. 34:20),205 for shall be seen here refers to the males.206
chapter.ftnote: 1 That is, goes north. For when a person faces east, north is on his left side.
2 The Land of Israel is north of the desert of Sinai. Hence Scripture states, go up.
3 That is, Scripture speaks of Abraham’s journey to Egypt in terms of going down. See Gen. 12:10, And Abram went down into Egypt.
4 When he came to Egypt. Our texts read, ki hu be-darom (because he was in the south). Sarim suggests emending our text to read, ki hi be-darom [for it (Egypt) is in the south].
5 Sending an angel before the Israelites, driving out the inhabitants of Canaan, and giving their land to the Israelites.
6 It reads an angel (malakh).
7 Hebrew, ha-malakh.
9 The construction of which was described earlier.
10 Beneath the kaf.
11 That the word be vocalized with a pattach beneath the kaf and that a dagesh be placed in the lamed.
12 In other words, akhelkha should have followed the vocalization of achavvekha.
13 It should be noted that in our editions of Scripture the vav of achavvekha does not have a dagesh in it. However, it is obvious that it did in I.E.’s edition. See Minchat Shai on Job 15:17.
14 Evil tidings are recorded in verse 3 and in verse 5. Hence I.E.’s comment.

15 In other words, verse 5 should come before verse 4. I.E. comments thus because verse 4 tells us, and no man did put on him his ornaments. However, verse 5 reads, And the Lord said unto Moses…therefore now put off thy ornaments. Hence And the Lord said should be interpreted, and the Lord had said (Weiser).
16 Here too the meaning of and the Lord said is, and the Lord had said. See I.E. on Ex. 4:19.
17 The reference is to I.E.’s comments on Ps. 78:20.

18 According to I.E. bread refers to meat, not to the manna (I.E. on Ps. 78:20). I.E. comments thus because the first part of Ps. 78:20 reads, Behold, He smote the rock, that waters gushed out. Therefore Can He give bread also, which follows, cannot refer to the manna, for the manna fell before the rock was struck (see Ex. 16,17:1-8). I.E. explains bread to mean meat, as Israel asked for meat after the rock had been struck. See Num. 11:1-22.
19 Verse 5.
20 The reference is to the manna which fell from heaven.
21 For the manna fell before the striking of the rock which is earlier mentioned. See note 16.

22 And the Lord said (v. 5) means, and the Lord had already said. I.E. comments thus because he believes that what is reported in verse 5 transpired before that which is reported in verse 4. See note 14.

23 Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, that they should always do so. The point is that verse 5 is in correct chronological sequence, for it relates that God told Israel that they must permanently keep their jewelry off. Thus And the Lord said unto Moses is to be taken literally.

24 Et here has the meaning of min (from). I.E. comments thus because va-yitnatzelu (stripped themselves) is a reflexive verb. Therefore, if we do not translate et as min, our verse would read, and the children of Israel stripped themselves their ornaments.

25 Ezek. 16:11 tells us that God decked Israel with ornaments. It then goes on to list the ornaments. It mentions earrings, nose rings, beautiful and costly garments, bracelets, and necklaces. See Ezek. 16:11-13.
26 Yikkach. Yikkach means will take. J.P.S. renders used to take.
27 Lakach (took).
28 Ps. 106:19 employs the future, ya’asu (they will make), in place of the perfect, asu.
29 The tent means Moses’ tent. Hence the heh (the) prefaced to ohel (tent).
30 The reference being to Moses’ tent.
31 See Ex. 34.
32 For what is recorded in our verse did not occur at this point in time. As I.E. explains, it occurred later.

33 The tabernacle was set up on the first of Nisan (Ex. 40:17). Israel journeyed according to their banners on the twentieth of Iyyar, 50 days later. I.E. assumes that Israel took their journey on the very day that the banners were set up.
34 Like the shining of Moses’ skin. See Ex. 34:34.
35 Of Moses’ closeness to God (Weiser).
36 It was only after this that God spoke to Moses face to face (see I.E. on verse 21). Hence what is recorded here had to have happened later on.
37 See I.E.’s comments on verse 21.
39 Zevachim 118b.

40 Joshua lived 110 years. We deduct from this the 40 years of wandering in the desert, and the 14 years of conquering and dividing Canaan; 110 minus 54 = 56. Hence Joshua was 56 when Israel left Egypt.
41 In other words, the word sherut is to be inserted before the word na’ar.
42 In other words, the word see cannot be taken to pertain to the words that follow, for words cannot be seen. Hence I.E. interprets see to mean see my predicament.
43 Verses 12-23.

44 I.E.’s paraphrase of show me (hodi’eni) thy ways, that I may know Thee (ve-eda’akah) (v. 13). Now ve-eda’akah in verse 13 cannot mean I will respect, for hodi’eni and ve-eda’akah come from the same root. Hence if ve-eda’akah means I will honor Thee, then hodi’eni must mean honor me. If this is the case, then verse 13 reads, honor me with Your ways so that I may honor You. This makes no sense. Hence we must translate ve-eda’akah as: that I will know Thee. Now if ve-eda’akah means that I will know thee, then yedatikha, which precedes it, must be rendered I know Thee.
45 Literally, My face.
46 Which Saadiah Gaon renders: and she was no longer angry.
47 We cannot render panekha (thy presence) in this verse as anger because then the verse would read, If Thy anger go not with me, carry us not up hence.
48 Its root is peh, lamed, heh.
49 Hebrew, va-yikra, be-shem Adonai.
50 Gen. 12:8 should be understood as follows: Abraham called to people in the Lord’s name; i.e., Abraham called upon people to worship the Lord.
51 By the cantillical notes.
52 Hebrew, va-yikra ve-shem, Adonai. Here the word ve-shem (the name) is not connected by a cantillical note to Adonai (the Lord). In fact, the cantillical notes connect it to va-yikra.
53 Ex. 34:5 should be understood as, And the Lord proclaimed the name of the Lord.
54 Its meaning is, I the Lord will proclaim the name of the Lord before thee, for here too ve-shem is connected to Adonai.
55 According to the rules of Hebrew grammar, yirani should be vocalized with a tzere beneath the alef.
56 In our editions of the Pentateuch yirani is vocalized with a pattach.
57 Which has a kamatz rather than a tzere beneath the alef. The same goes for ro’ani, le-hotzi’anu, and yeshivani. Hence I.E.’s comment.
58 The Biblical text says, Thou hast said. I.E. most probably quoted from memory and erred.
59 Le-hotzi’anu is vocalized with a kamatz beneath the alef.
60 In I.E.’s edition of the Bible yeshivani was vocalized with a kamatz beneath the bet. However, our texts of the Bible read yeshiveni (tzere beneath the bet).
61 I.E. comments thus because he will soon quote a different interpretation of va-chai.
62 Translated according to I.E.
63 Translated according to I.E.
64 Angels or the soul following the death of the body. This interpretation takes va-chai (and live) to mean, but he that lives, i.e., he that lives forever.

65 According to this interpretation the meaning of ki lo yirani ha-adam va-chai (for no man shall see Me and live) is: for no man shall see Me, but he that lives shall see Me. So Weiser. Filwarg interprets I.E. as saying, some say, for no man shall see Me (ki lo yirani ha-adam) and if he does he shall live forever (va-chai).
66 For va-chai means, and shall live. Furthermore, the other interpretations require us to read too much into the text.

67 Our text reads, ki lo yirani ha-adam va-chai (for man shall not see Me and live). This interpretation suggests that our verse be interpreted, ki lo yirani ha-adam ve-lo ha-chai, for no man or living being (angel) shall see Me.
68 “He who lives” refers to the angels.
69 The rock refers to the top of the mountain.
70 Verse 1.
71 Their sin of making the calf.
72 Saadiah Gaon’s paraphrase of verse 1.
73 Verse 15.
74 That is, God told Moses to bring the people to the land of Canaan (v. 1). He then added, and I will send an angel before thee.
75 That is, If Thy presence go not up (v. 15) is to be interpreted: If thy presence go not up with this nation.
76 Because the reference is to Moses and the people.
77 Moses requested that God’s presence should accompany Israel.
78 Verse 18.
79 Ezekiel saw God sitting on a throne which was placed on a platform borne by four creatures, each of which had four faces. See chapters 1 and 10 of Ezekiel.
80 Moses.
81 In My face shall not be seen (v. 24).
82 A person cannot look at the face of the sun. Similarly, a person cannot look at the light emanating from God. The aforementioned is referred to as God’s face.
83 God’s back. See verse 33.

84 That is, to the back of the divine light, which a person is able to behold (Weiser). See Saadiah Gaon’s Book Of Beliefs And Opinions, 2:11: “God has a special light which He creates and makes manifest to His prophets in order that they may infer therefrom that it is a prophetic communication emanating from God that they hear. When one of them sees this light, he says: “I have seen the glory of the Lord…” However, when they beheld this light, they were unable to look upon it because of its power and brilliance. Indeed, whoever looked upon it incurred the disintegration of his entire makeup and the flight of his spirit from his body.

Moses accordingly asked his Master to give him the strength to look upon this light. The latter, however, answered him that the first rays of this light were so powerful that he would be unable to view them clearly with his naked eyes, lest he perish. He would rather cover him up with a cloud or the like until the first rays of this light had passed, because the greatest strength of every radiant body is contained in its initial approach. All of this was implied in the statement of Scripture: And I…will cover thee with My hand until I have passed by. Then when, the first portion of the light had passed, God removed from Moses the thing that had covered him, so that he might be able to look at the back of the light, as Scripture says: And I will take away My hand, and thou shalt see My back” (Saadiah Gaon, The Book Of Beliefs And Opinion. Translated by Samuel Rosenblatt, Yale University Press, 1948, p. 130).
85 Saadiah’s interpretation of God’s face and back is wrong.
86 That Moses spent in prayer following Israel’s making of the golden calf. See Deut. 10:10.
88 Even though it wasn’t actually the Lord.
89 Even though the reference is to the angel of the Lord.
90 The angel represents the Lord and delivers His message. Hence God’s angel is referred to as the Lord in Scripture.
91 The knot of God’s tefillin. According to the rabbis, My back is to be interpreted as: what is in back of Me. See Berakhot 7a. Also see Rashi. For God wearing tefillin, see Berakhot 6a.
92 That is, YHVH, the tetragrammaton.
93 See I.E. on Ex. 3:15.
94 It refers to God Himself (Weiser).
95 Yod =10; heh =5; vav = 6. If we arrange God’s name as Y(10), YH (15), YHV(21), YHVH (26), we get 72.
96 That is, the sages of the Talmud therefore refer to God’s name as the 72-letter name of God.
97 Between one and nine. I.E. refers to five as the true middle number because some schools of thought taught that there are only nine basic numbers. See chapter 11 of I.E.’s Yesod Mora.
98 1 squared + 5 squared = 26. YHVH = 26.
99 Saturn, Jupiter, Mercury, Venus, and Mars. The five moving stars can be in conjunction with each other in 26 ways. For these 26 ways, see Krinsky.
100 Yod, heh. Yod is spelled yod (10), vav (6) dalet (4). Heh is spelled heh (5), alef (1).
101 YHVH = 26. Thus yod, heh spelled out = YHVH.
104 Yod, heh, that is, 15.
105 Vav, heh, that is, 11. Multiplying 15 by 11 = 165.
106 The first five odd numbers, 1, 3, 5, 7, 9. Their squares 1 + 9 + 25 + 49 + 81 = 165.
107 Yod. Yod (10) squared = 100.
108 Yod, heh (15). 15 squared = 225.
110 Yod, heh (15); 15 squared = 225.
111 Yod, heh, vav. Yod, heh, vav = 21. 21 squared = 441. 441 – 225 = 216.
113 Vav. Vav cubed = 216.

114 All numbers have a number before them; i.e., if a person says I have five books then what he is saying in effect is I have one book, two books, three books, four books, five books. Thus five assumes the numbers that precede it. However, 1 does not depend on any number before it. It stands by itself. This is the case with God. God stands by Himself. He is not dependent on any being that came before Him.
115 So Meijler.
116 The purpose of all prayers is to praise God as One, and the One from whom all existence comes.
117 Ezek. 38:23 reads: Thus will I magnify Myself, and sanctify Myself, and I will make Myself known in the eyes of many nations; and they shall know that I am the Lord.
118 Is. 49:3 reads: Thou art My servant, Israel, in whom I will be glorified. God will be glorified by Israel’s proclaiming His oneness.
119 All shapes and forms owe their existence to God (Weiser).
120 The angels.
121 Thus and thou shalt see My back; but My face shall not be seen (v. 23) is not to be taken literally.
122 The upper and lower worlds form two opposite poles. There is, at it were, a line connecting them (Weiser).
123 Hebrew, ha-po’el. Motot interprets this as referring to the active intellect.
124 The prince of the face refers to the angel who sees God’s face. It may also refer to the tenth sphere (I. Levin, Yalkut Ibn Ezra, p. 195).
125 The reference might be to the ninth sphere, the sphere which propels the other spheres. See I. Levin, p. 195.
126 The end of God’s power, for there is nothing beneath the lowest world. See Weiser.
127 Towards his creator.

128 The spheres in which the fixed and moving stars are embedded appear to move from right to left (west to east) to one facing north. (Motot, quoted by I. Levin, p. 195). Thus the spheres aspire to move towards the “right” of God. See Weiser.
129 Even plants aspire to move towards the source of their being.
130 Moses was able to perceive the manner in which human beings are connected to God.
131 Of God.
132 “This” refers to Moses’ request, Show me, I pray Thee, Thy glory.
133 The body and its lusts hinder man’s soul from reaching its full potential.
134 After seeing God’s back.

135 God knows the individual as part of the whole. See I.E. on Gen. 18:21 and the notes thereto. By seeing God’s back, Moses was able to know the whole. According to I.E. ultimate knowledge is knowledge of the general category and not of the individual parts. For the individual perishes while the species endures. See chapter 10 of the Yesod Mora.
136 Moses now sttod out more than he ever had before.
137 The cherubim in Ezekiel’s vision had human forms. See Ezek. 1:5.
138 See Book II of Judah Ha-Levi’s Kuzari.

139 See note 89. The Rabbinic statement expresses God’s love for Israel. See Berakhot 6a, “Rabbi Nachman bar Yitzchak said to Rabbi Chiyya bar Avin, What is written in the tefillin of the Master of the universe? He answered, who is like Thy people Israel, a nation one in the earth (I Chron. 17:21).”

140 Measurement of Stature, a mystical work giving the dimensions of God. Most scholars believe it to have been composed in the Geonic period. However, Saul Lieberman believes it to be a Tannaitic Midrash on Song of Songs.
141 Because all things have their origin in God.
142 Angels and souls (Weiser).

143 Hebrew, mikrim. An Aristotelian term for that which is incidental, e.g., white. That the house is white is an accident. Accidents are the opposite of substance. They have no independent existence. They exist only in another being. Accidents are in a state of flux, while substance remains the same.

144 In other words, incorporeal beings are superior to corporeal beings. However, the accidents are inferior to the corporeal beings. Man should choose to cleave to that which is above him rather than to that which is below him.
145 In the Shi’ur Komah.
146 A grossly anthropomorphic statement. I.E. apparently interprets this to mean that whoever knows the manner in which God encompasses all things is assured of a place in the world to come.
147 Man can attain immortality like his creator.
148 With the exception of Israel.
149 The stars of the eighth sphere (the sphere bearing the constellations) are arranged in 48 forms. See I.E. on Ex. 20:3 and the notes thereto.
150 That is, all people are under the dominion of the stars.

151 That is, the 70 scholars who translated the Torah into Greek. These sages rendered Deut. 4:19 as follows: which the Lord thy God hath allotted to give light to all the peoples under the whole heaven. See Megillah 9b.
152 That “all plants, all that live on the earth; all fowl, cattle, animal, creeping thing and all human beings are tied to the forty-eight forms of the sphere.”

153 According to I.E., Deut. 29:25 deals with the worship of the hosts of heaven. Its meaning is that God did not place Israel under the dominion of the stars. Nevertheless, Israel worshipped the stars.
154 For here, had not allotted cannot be interpreted as meaning, had not allotted to give light, for Deut. 29:25 deals with idol worship, that is, the worship of the stars (Meijler).

155 The Sun, Moon, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn. In the notes which follow, the aforementioned will be referred to as follows: Sun/su., Moon/mo, Mercury/me, Venus/v, Mars/ma, Jupiter/j, and Saturn/sa.
156 I.E. then goes on to list these 120 conjunctions.
157 The seven moving stars can be in simultaneous conjunction in only one way.

158 The seven moving stars can be in a two-star conjunction in 21 ways. They are: sa/j, sa/ma, sa/su, sa/v, sa/me, sa/mo; j/ma, j/s, j/v, j/me, j/mo; ma/su, ma/v, ma/me, ma/mo; su/v, su/v, su/mo, v/me, v/mo, me/mo.
159 The seven moving stars can form 21 five-star conjunctions. They are: sa/j/ma/su/v; sa/j/ma/su/me, sa/j/ma/su/mo, etc.
160 So Weiser. The 21 possible conjunctions result from the seven moving stars.
161 Sa/j/ma, sa/j/su, sa/j/v, sa/j/me, sa/j/mo, etc.
162 So Weiser.
163 The seven moving stars can be in a four-star conjunction in 35 ways, i.e., sa/j/ma/su, sa/j/ma/v, sa/j/ma/me, etc.
164 These are: sa/j/ma/su/v/me, sa/j/ma/su/me/mo, sa/j/ma/su/v/mo, etc.
165 That is, the above-mentioned great conjunction. See note 155.
166 Each one of these seven areas is under the influence of a given constellation.
167 The inhabited world was believed to be divided into seven sections. See I.E. on Gen. 1:2.
168 Literally, the conjunction which takes in all peoples of the earth in accordance with the constellation of every one of the seven sections that constitute the inhabited world.

169 Which is part of the constellations of “fire.” There are four elements: dust, fire, air, and water. Three of the 12 constellations correspond to each one of these four elements. Aries, Leo, and Sagittarius form the fire constellations.
170 Sagittarius.
172 Form the constellation of fire.
173 Taurus, Virgo, and Capricorn.
174 Gemini, Libra, and Aquarius.
175 The sun and the moon travel in each one of the group of constellations for 240 years; 4 × 240 = 960.
176 That is, that the heavenly bodies are made out of the four elements.
177 The sun was believed to be hot and dry, the moon cold and wet, and Saturn cold and dry. See chapter 4 of I.E.’s Reshit Chokhmah.

178 According to medieval science the sun itself was not hot. However, it heated the earth because of the earth’s composition. See Book II of Judah Ha-Levi’s Kuzari: “We say that the rays of light belong to the sun itself, although in reality this is not so: it is the terrestrial bodies which, being opposite to it, are affected by it, and reflect its light.”
179 They are not made out of the four elements which belong to the lower world. Hence they cannot share its properties; i.e., they cannot be hot, cold, dry, or wet.
180 If the heavenly bodies were made out of the four elements they would eventually come to an end. See I.E. on Ps. 148:5.
181 To be hot and dry, cold and wet, cold and dry. See note 177.
182 That is, to have this effect on earth. That is, the sun is said to be hot and dry because it has this effect on the earth.
183 Literally, the ministers.
184 The reference is to the inhabitants of the world.
185 Sabbath 156a; Nedarim 32a.
186 “As long as they keep the Torah,” is not part of the Rabbinic statement. It is I.E.’s interpretation of “Israel has no constellation.”
187 Aquarius is Israel’s constellation. See I.E. to Ex. 31:18.
188 Than they actually were.
189 The people of Israel.
190 The individual Israelite. As long as an Israelite clings to God he is not under the dominion of the stars.
191 Translated according to I.E.
192 God knows that individual as a part of the whole. See note 135.
193 Moses did not ask to physically see God.
194 Literally, before thy face.
195 That is, it refers to the mind.

196 Kol tuvi is not to be interpreted, I will reveal all My goodness to you. Neither is it to be interpreted, I will reveal My goodness in all things, or I will reveal My goodness with all things. Its meaning is, I will reveal My attributes to you (Weiser).
197 I.E.’s paraphrase of verse 19.
198 God shielded Moses’ mind from comprehending more than it could. Otherwise Moses would have died.
199 Moses was shown how all of creation has its origin in God. This is called seeing God’s back (Meijler).
200 Ve-sakkoti is spelled with a sin in our verse.
201 In Is. 49:16. I.E. quotes this opinion in the name of Saadiah Gaon.
202 They render this verse, Behold, I have graven thee upon My clouds.
203 Kappi is to be rendered My hand.
204 Translated literally. They refers to the males making the festival pilgrimage.
205 Translated literally. In other words, ve-lo yera’u fani rekam (they shall not be seen before My face empty) should not be translated as My face shall not be seen empty.
206 Making the festival pilgrimage.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 34
chapter.p: 1. AND THE LORD SAID UNTO MOSES: HEW THEE. Pesal lekha (hew thee)1 is similar to lekh lekha (get thee out) (Gen. 12:1) and ve-attah kach lekha (take thou also unto thee) (Ex. 30:23).
[LIKE UNTO THE FIRST.] The same size as the first.

Saadiah Gaon says that the second tablets were more precious than the first, for the second tablets were given on a holy day, on the Day of Atonement. This was not the case with the first tablets. The first tablets descended2 on the seventeenth day of Tamuz,3 on a weekday. Furthermore, three covenants are mentioned with regard to the second tablets;4 and that it may go well with thee (Deut. 5:16) was inscribed on the second tablets;5 and the first tablets were broken. Now these things6 are similar to that which is seen in a dream.7 They neither help nor hinder.8 Both tablets had God’s writing on them.9 Furthermore, the first tablets were the work of God whereas the second tablets were the work of Moses.10
2. AND BE READY BY THE MORNING, AND COME UP. This is the third time,11 and each time Moses stayed on the mountain for forty days and forty nights.12

3. AND NO MAN SHALL COME UP WITH THEE. Scripture states, And no man shall come up with thee, because Aaron and his sons ascended and descended the mountain with Moses after God revealed himself to Israel.13 Aaron also ascended the mountain with Moses before God’s revelation.14
THROUGHOUT ALL THE MOUNT. Even somewhere far removed from the place of God’s glory.

4. AND HE HEWED TWO TABLES OF STONE…AND TOOK IN HIS HAND TWO TABLES OF STONE. It is Hebrew style to speak thus and say, and took in his hand two tables of stone.15 The verse does not say, and took in his hand the two tables.16 Our verse is similar to Then the Lord caused to rain upon Sodom and upon Gomorrah brimstone and fire from the Lord (Gen. 19:24).17 Scripture does not say, “from Himself.”18 We similarly find Scripture using the phrase the children of Israel five times in one verse.19 It is elegant to write thus.20
5. AND THE LORD DESCENDED. Some say that and stood refers to the cloud,21 for God was passing by.22
Note that the mountain symbolizes23 the celestial angels who are on a higher level than human beings, as the mountain is higher than the ground.24
AND PROCLAIMED THE NAME OF THE LORD. Note, it was the Lord who was proclaiming.25 God thus taught Moses how to proclaim26 the name of the Lord.27

6. AND THE LORD PASSED BY. Do not be amazed that the Lord called out, “the Lord,” for God alone is the knower, the content of his thought, and the object of his thought.28 This is a very difficult concept.29

Saadiah Gaon says that the first Lord30 is connected to and proclaimed.31 Now if this is so, then why didn’t the master of the cantillical notes32 connect them?33 Actually, Scripture repeats the Lord’s name twice in our verse in the same manner that it repeats Abraham’s name in Abraham, Abraham (Gen. 22:11); Jacob’s name in Jacob, Jacob (Gen. 46:2); Moses’ name in Moses, Moses (Ex. 3:4).34 Our verse is to be similarly read.35

It is written36 that there are thirteen attributes.37 Saadiah Gaon said that the Lord’s glorious name38 is included in the number. If so, then it is not an attribute.39 He also says that the second time the divine name40 is mentioned, it means Lord.41 However, this is an error, for our verse does not read “Lord.”42 The term Lord is an honorific substitute used by the reader.43

Rabbi Nissim says that the phrase long-suffering44 is really two attributes. God is long-suffering to the good and God is long-suffering to the bad. This too is incorrect, for an attribute is not to be added because of a change of persona.45 Furthermore, God is long-suffering to the wicked,46 not to the ones who have not sinned against Him.47 Observe. Ve-nakkeh (clear) is an attribute unto itself.48 The thirteen attributes end here.49

According to the plain meaning of the text, ve-nakkeh lo yenakkeh50 (and that will by no means clear the guilty) (v. 7) is one attribute,51 for ve-nakkeh (clear) is an infinitive.52 It is similar to anneh (afflict) in anneh53 te’anneh oto54 (if thou afflict them in any wise) (Ex. 22:22). Ve-nakkeh lo yenakkeh teaches that God will by no means clear the rebellious. God forgives only those who repent, as the prophets teach.55 The word ve-nakkeh was therefore counted as one of the thirteen attributes.56 The phrase poked avon avot (visiting the iniquity of the fathers) (v. 7) is also an attribute of mercy.57

Note that there are seven priestly garments.58 However, the plate59 was counted among the priestly garments60 because it is similar to an ornament. Look. Eleven tribes61 were born in Paddan-aram. Benjamin alone was born in the land of Canaan.62 However, Scripture writes concerning all of them, These are the sons of Jacob, that were born to him in Paddan-aram (Gen. 35:26). It does so because Scripture speaks of the majority.63 It is not concerned with excluding the one exception.64 Scripture similarly states, Thy fathers went down into Egypt with threescore and ten persons (Deut. 10:22). However, Manasseh and Ephraim65 did not descend to Egypt, for they were born there.66

Now, they included the Lord’s revered name among the attributes even though it is a proper name.67 I have already mentioned in the Torah portion Ve-Ellah Shemot that the name YHVH (Lord) is at times an adjective68 and at times an attribute.69 The Lord, the Lord (YHVH YHVH) are two attributes.
[GOD.] The word El (God) is the third attribute.
MERCIFUL. Rachum (merciful) is the fourth attribute.
AND GRACIOUS. Chanun (gracious) is the fifth attribute.
LONG-SUFFERING. Erekh appayim (long-suffering) is the sixth attribute.
AND ABUNDANT IN GOODNESS. Rav chesed (abundant in goodness) is the seventh attribute. The word rav (abundant) is also connected to the word emet (truth).70
TRUTH. Rav emet (abundant in truth) is the eighth attribute.
KEEPING MERCY UNTO THE THOUSANDTH GENERATION. Notzer chesed la-alafim (keeping mercy unto the thousandth generation) is the ninth attribute.
FORGIVING INIQUITY. Nose avon (forgiving iniquity) is the tenth attribute.
TRANSGRESSION. Nose pesha (forgiving transgression) is the eleventh attribute.71
SIN. Nose chatta’ah (forgiving sin) is the twelfth attribute.
CLEAR. Ve-nakkeh (and clear) is the thirteenth attribute.
[THE LORD.]72 The name of the Lord, when an adjective, includes angels73 and humans, those above and those below.74
GOD. The term El (God) means powerful. He wisely does that which is proper.
MERCIFUL. As in Like as a father hath mercy75 upon his children (Ps. 103:13). He watches over them so that they do not fall.
GRACIOUS. As in for I am gracious (Ex. 22:26), to save the one who falls and is unable to rise.76
LONG-SUFFERING. He does not become quickly angry at the wicked.
AND ABUNDANT IN GOODNESS. To the righteous and the wicked.
ABUNDANT IN TRUTH. He fulfills and keeps His word.
KEEPING MERCY. Keeping the mercy of a father77 to his children, provided that the children are righteous.

FORGIVING INIQUITY. Pay attention to what I am about to say.78 Look. Scripture writes, be thou strong therefore, and be to a man79 (I Kings 2:2).80 But was he81 not a man? Its meaning82 can only be, be a famous man of valor. However, Scripture writes, for I83 am too old to be to a man84 (Ruth 1:12).85 Its meaning is, I am too old to be sexually approached by a man,86 or, I am too old to be a woman to a man, for the speaker87 was a female.88

Behold. That I89may come90 into her91 (Gen 34:21)92 refers to sexual intercourse, for Rachel was a female.93 However, that came94 in to thee this night95 (Gen. 19:5) does not have the same meaning, for Lot was a man.96

Now Scripture tells us that one who sins shall bear his iniquity (ve-nasa avono) (Lev. 5:1); that is, his sin shall not be forgiven except by the punishment which shall befall him. Ve-nasa (shall bear)97 has the same meaning as tissa (shalt bear it) in And if thou scornest, thou alone shalt bear it (Prov. 9:12). However, Pharaoh said, Now therefore forgive (sa),98 I pray thee, my sin only this once (Ex. 10:17), because Moses was a righteous person.99 The general rule is that Scripture is always expressing approbation when it tells us that someone bears his own sin.

The term nasa is used in two ways in reference to sin. One, God will forgive the sinner. In this case it is for the benefit of the one whose sin is forgiven.100 The second way in which this verb is used is to inform us that some evil person shall bear his sin.101 Now this term102 has a negative connotation for the one who must bear his sin, but it has a positive connotation for the one whose sin is forgiven, as in then he103 shall bear (ve-nasa) her iniquity (Num. 30:16), for the sin will be removed from her104 and be upon him.105

FORGIVING…TRANSGRESSION. Note that pesha (transgression) is a more serious violation than avon (iniquity), for the transgressor removes himself, as it were, from the authority of God.106 Compare, tifsha (revolted)107 in then Edom revolted from under the hand of Judah (II Kings 8:22).108 Now avon (iniquity) is less of a violation than pesha (transgression). It109 refers to a deliberate violation of God’s command.

[SIN.] The word chatta’ah means sin.110 Chatta’ah is a noun. It is not like the word chatta’ah (sinful) in ha-mamlakha111 ha-chatta’ah (the sinful kingdom) (Amos 9:8), for the word chatta’ah in the latter is an adjective. The word chatta’ah (sin) takes in all sins committed in thought112 and in error; avon relates to violations of the law committed verbally or in deed.

Now we looked at the prayer which Moses offered because of the incident of the spies.113 Moses pronounced the name of the Lord.114 The latter is a noun. The attributes which follow were stated with regard to this name.115 Moses did not mention the Lord’s name a second time;116 that is, he did not mention the adjectival name of the Lord117 because the Lord wanted to destroy Israel.118

Moses did not mention El (God)119 because there was no reason to mention this attribute.120 He also did not mention rachum (merciful)121 because the Israelites were not simpletons.122 Moses did not mention channun (gracious)123 because no one oppressed Israel and they had no need to cry to God for help.124 Moses mentioned erekh appayim (slow to anger)125 because they were wicked.

Moses noted126 that God is plenteous in lovingkindness (ve-rav emet). Its meaning is that God is plenteous in lovingkindness to all.127 Moses did not mention emet (truth)128 because they were guilty.129 Moses mentioned130 that God forgives avon (iniquity) and pesha (transgression). He omitted chatta’ah (sin) because Israel did not err.131

Moses132 included himself among the Israelites and said, and pardon our iniquity (avonenu) and our sin (chattatenu) (v. 9) because of his great humility. Moses did not add the phrase pesha’enu (our transgression) because of his great saintliness, for Moses would not rebel.133

8. AND MOSES MADE HASTE. Those whose heads are empty say that when God said, and unto the fourth generation (v. 7) Moses hastened134 lest the Lord add, and unto the fifth generation. This is a great error. The mind rebels against the thought that Moses would interrupt the Lord while He was speaking, for if Moses acted in this manner he would have immediately incurred the death penalty. It was only after the voice ceased135 that Moses hastened to pray. Furthermore, the Decalogue reads the same.136 Now all of Israel heard this.137 How then could Moses even think that God would add, unto the fifth generation. There was no need to add “of them that hate Me”138 because He mentions, and that will by no means clear the guilty.139

[AND BOWED.] The word va-yikkod comes from a double root.140 It is related to the word kadkod (skull). Moses placed his skull on the ground. Va-yikkod follows the paradigm of va-yittom (spent)141 in and when the money was all spent (Gen. 47:15). Similarly va-yikkedu (then they bowed their heads) (Ex. 4:31) is similar to va-yittemu (were ended) (Deut. 34:8).142 Pay no heed to those who add roots because of a word’s form.143 The word yiddemu (they are still) in they are as still as a stone (Ex. 15:16) should be understood in this manner.144
9. AND HE SAID. The meaning of let the Lord, I pray Thee, go in the midst of us is, when we journey,145 as in And I will walk among you (Lev. 26:12).146

FOR IT IS A STIFF NECKED PEOPLE. According to Rabbi Merinus, ki am kesheh oref hu (for it is a stiffnecked people) should be rendered, even though it is a stiffnecked people.147 Similarly, refa’ah nafshi ki chatati lakh (heal my soul; for I have sinned against Thee) (Ps. 41:5) should be rendered, heal my soul; even though I have sinned against Thee.148 However, I believe that the meaning of refa’ah nafshi ki chatati lakh is, heal my soul because I confess149 that I have sinned against Thee and I have become ill because of my sins. The meaning of our verse similarly is: I confess that it is a stiff necked people but pardon150 [our iniquity and our sin].151

10. AND HE SAID: BEHOLD, I MAKE A COVENANT. This is what for after the tenor of these words I have made a covenant with thee and with Israel (v. 27) refers to. The reference is to the conditions starting from Observe thou (v. 11). It is because of this152 that I will write a second pair of tablets. The latter shall serve as a document of witness. All of this, namely, that I have forgiven their sin, was because of your honor. I will therefore do marvels for you so that all who see you will marvel, and know that I have placed My glory upon you. The aforementioned is something that I have not wrought since the day that I created heaven and earth.153 The reference is to the shining of Moses’ face. Observe. Scripture writes that at the time of Moses’ death, unlike the nature of all old people, his eye was not dim, nor his natural force abated (Deut. 34:7).
[SUCH AS HAVE NOT BEEN WROUGHT IN ALL THE EARTH, NOR IN ANY NATION.] Its meaning is, such a thing has been unheard of among the nations.
Rabbi Saadiah Gaon explains it as follows: such a thing has not been wrought in the land of Egypt,154 from which you exited, or among any of the other nations.

11. OBSERVE THOU. I believe that the Lord is addressing Moses.155 God is telling Moses to keep these things156 and to then relate them to the children of Israel. Shemor (observe) is to be taken in the sense of shameru (kept) in They157kept His testimonies, and the statute that He gave them (Ps. 99:7), in accordance with the way I have explained it in its place.158

[BEHOLD, I AM DRIVING OUT BEFORE THEE.] Your opening words to Israel shall be,159 behold I am driving out before thee. 160 This section161 is similar to Behold, I send an angel before thee (Ex. 23:20)162 and the section which precedes it (Ex. 23:12-19).163
[I AM DRIVING OUT.] The word goresh (I am driving out) is a transitive verb in the kal. It is the same case with the word gerushah (one divorced) in A widow, or one divorced (Lev. 21:14).
12. TAKE HEED TO THYSELF. This verse is similar to Thou shalt not bow down to their gods (Ex. 23:24).164
13. BUT YE SHALL BREAK DOWN THEIR ALTARS. This is similar to but thou shalt utterly overthrow them (Ibid.).165
14. [A JEALOUS GOD.] Scripture mentions a jealous God here as it does in the Decalogue.166

15. LEST THOU MAKE A COVENANT. This is similar to Thou shalt make no covenant with them, nor with their gods (Ex. 23:32).167 Our verse adds, lest thou make a covenant…and their daughters go astray168 as an explanation.
17. [MOLTEN GODS.] The phrase “the gods of the nations” takes in all idol worship.169 The reason our verse reads molten gods is because of the golden calf.
18. [THE FEAST OF UNLEAVENED BREAD.] Scripture mentions the feast of unleavened bread here as it does in an earlier chapter.170

Look. The feast of unleavened bread serves as a memorial, for Scripture states, for in it thou camest out from Egypt (Ex. 23:15). It is because of this that Scripture mentions the law dealing with the firstling of an ass (v. 20), which is also in memory of the Exodus from Egypt.171 We similarly find Scripture mentioning laws pertaining to the harvest172 along with the harvest festival,173 namely, And when ye reap the harvest of your land, thou shalt not reap the corner of thy field, etc. (Lev. 23:22). It similarly mentions the laws pertaining to the harvest in the Torah portion Kedoshim Teheyu.174 It is because Passover recalls the Exodus that Scripture mentions, All that openeth the womb is Mine (v. 19).175
19. [THY CATTLE.] The word miknekha (thy cattle) is a feminine here.176 There are many other nouns that are both masculine and feminine.177
21. SIX DAYS THOU SHALT WORK. Scripture earlier reads similarly.178
[IN PLOWING TIME AND IN HARVEST THOU SHALT REST.] Scripture states, in plowing time and in harvest thou shalt rest because human life is dependent principally on these activities.

Anan,179 may his name be erased like a cloud,180 says that the reference is to sexual relations.181 Will Anan not be covered with shame? We will grant that it is in the hand of man to plow (charish).182 However, Anan is silent (yacharish)183 with regard to the word harvest.184

Scripture does not mention the Sabbatical year in this section.185 What we ordinarily mean by a full day consists of the movement of the upper sphere186 from east to west in twenty-four hours. A day of the sun187 consists of three hundred and sixty-five days and about a quarter of a day, for this is how long it takes the sun to make a circuit from its point of departure in the west until it returns to its place.188 Those who know the science of the constellations will understand this.

22. AND THE FEAST OF INGATHERING. Scripture states this189 in two places.190 Scripture there reads, at the end of the year (Ex. 23:16) because the end of the year is the beginning of the next year.191 This is the proof.192 The sun enters the constellation of Libra193 close to the tenth day.194 The new year never occurs after the end of the festival of Sukkot. Scripture therefore reads, at the turn of the year.195 Do not rely on Samuel’s circuits.196 Only rely on Rav Ada’s circuit197 even though it requires two adjustments. One, because the sun at times travels in a longer circuit and at times it travels in a shorter circuit. This difference is not in the sun’s movement, for the sun always travels in a consistent course. Its speed only appears to vary when viewed against a point in the sphere of the constellations.198 A second adjustment has to be made because of the movement of the epicycle at the head of Aries.199
23. THREE TIMES IN THE YEAR. Scripture mentions the God of Israel in this section200 because of the incident of the golden calf.201

24. FOR I WILL CAST OUT. Scripture explains in this chapter what it does not mention in the earlier one,202 for there was no need to mention it in the earlier chapter.203 Now since God commanded204 all male Israelites to see His face,205 and all of Israel is doing His will, the Lord will undoubtedly guard their land from their enemies. Scripture explains this point very clearly.206
[NEITHER SHALL ANY MAN COVET THY LAND.] I will make your neighbors so fearful that they will not even covet your land.207 They certainly will not think of waging war.
26. THE CHOICEST FIRST-FRUITS OF THY LAND. Scripture reads similarly in the earlier chapter.208

These are the conditions.209 From Now these are the ordinances (Ex. 21:1) until And six years (Ex. 23:10) consists of ordinances. The high priest and the judge, namely, the king, are obligated to study them and know them.210 The obligations of the congregation, which are the same as those noted here,211 are then mentioned.212
27. AND THE LORD SAID. Even though these things were already written,213 Moses wrote them again with the Decalogue.214 This section was therefore written twice.

28. AND HE WAS THERE. Many think that Moses spent eighty days on the mountain until God gave him the tablets.215 They are mistaken. On the contrary, the words of our ancient sages216 are, as I have already noted, correct.217 Look, Moses spent forty days on the mountain until God gave him the first tablets. Scripture clearly states, and Moses was in the mount forty days and forty nights (Ex. 24:18).218 Moses himself similarly states, So I fell down before the Lord the forty days and forty nights (Deut. 9:25).219 Moses then220 said everything that is recorded in the section starting with the words See Thou sayest unto me (Ex. 33:12). Moses then descended and hewed the tablets and personally brought them up to Mount Sinai. Observe, Scripture states, And the Lord passed by before him (v. 6), and later goes on to say, And he was there with the Lord forty days and forty nights; he did neither eat bread, nor drink water. As was his practice the first time, so was his practice the second time.221
AND HE WROTE UPON THE TABLES. God wrote upon the tablets,222 for Scripture explicitly states, and I will write upon the tables the words that were on the first tables, which thou didst break (v. 1).

29. THAT MOSES KNEW NOT THAT THE SKIN OF HIS FACE SENT FORTH BEAMS WHILE HE TALKED WITH HIM. The meaning of while He talked with him is, while God talked with him. This occurred because the glory223 was seen upon Moses’ face. Moses’ face therefore shone like the brightness of the firmament.

[SENT FORTH BEAMS.] The word karan (sent forth beams) is related to the word karnayim (rays) in Rays hath He at His side (Hab. 3:4),224 for the opening part of the verse explicitly states, And a brightness appeareth as the light. Now since Rays hath He at His side follows,225 our verse repeats the same idea in different words226 as is the custom of Scripture.

May the bones of Chivi the transgressor227 be crushed, for Chivi said that Moses’ face turned dry as a horn228 because he did not eat bread. Chivi similarly explains, and they were afraid (v. 30) as meaning they were afraid because Moses’ face was ugly. Now why did this cursed wretch not open his eyes. A person will only fear to approach someone because there is something strange in him which he has never ever seen before.229 There is no person who has never looked upon the face of a corpse that does not fear to approach a dead body. Furthermore, if this is the case,230 why was the veil not always upon the face of Moses? Why did Moses always remove the veil (v. 33) when he spoke with Israel? Did Chivi not see that when Moses was one hundred and twenty years old (Deut. 34:7) his eye was not dim, nor his natural force abated? This was most certainly so231 when Moses was eighty years old.232
30. AND WHEN AARON. Who was first in rank.
AND ALL THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. The reference is to the leaders with whom it was the practice of Moses to speak. Scripture similarly states, And Moses called unto them233 (v. 31).
31. RETURNED UNTO HIM. This shows that they turned away from Moses after they went out to meet him because they were greatly frightened.
[32. AND AFTERWARD.] Afterward all the children of Israel who stood at the foot of the mount came near.
32. AND HE GAVE THEM IN COMMANDMENT. All of the conditions already mentioned.234

33. A VEIL. Masveh (veil) is a garment (kesut).235 Some say that the word suto (vesture) in And his vesture in the blood of grapes (Gen. 49: 11)236 is similar. Do not be amazed that the vav in masveah is enunciated while the vav is suto is silent, for we find the same with the words avlatah (wickedness) (Hos. 10:13) and olatah (iniquity) (Job 5:16).237 We similarly find ul yamim (an infant of days) (Is. 65:20) and avilim (urchins) (Job. 19:18);238 el tokh ha-machneh (within the camp) (Deut. 23:11) and also va-yevatter otam ba-tavekh (and divided them in the midst) (Gen. 15:10).239

Some say that the light was renewed upon Moses’ face every time Moses came to the tent of meeting and spoke with God. When Moses left the tent the light remained240 as long as he related God’s words to the children of Israel. When Moses finished speaking he put on the veil, for he knew that the light would depart and his face would return to its prior state. It would be an insult to Moses if the Israelites saw his face without light radiating from it. Moses therefore put on the veil. However, when he came in to speak with God he would remove241 the veil to receive the light.

Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that the light was not removed from Moses’ face until the day of his death. Therefore Moses’ eye was not dimmed.242 This is correct. However, Saadiah says that Moses put on the veil so that the Israelites would not be afraid when they quarreled with each other.243 However, I believe that Moses put on a veil out of respect to the light which God newly created upon his face. He did not want Israel to constantly see it. He wanted them to see it only when he spoke God’s words. He removed the veil when he came into the tent of meeting to speak with God face to face. This is the meaning of But when Moses went in, etc. (v. 34).

35. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL SAW THE FACE OF MOSES, THAT THE SKIN OF MOSES’ FACE SENT FORTH BEAMS. Observe. The meaning of and Moses put the veil back upon his face244 is that Moses always acted in this manner.245 This was his practice in dealing with the Israelites until the day that God’s glory gathered him to Himself. Moses’ grave is unknown,246 the Lord being merciful unto him.247
Blessed is He who chose Moses and placed His holy spirit in him.
