211 In our chapter, verses 11-26.
213 Ibid.
214 Before getting the second pair of tablets. “The matter of the second of the second Tablets was like that of the first in every respect,” Nahmanides on verse 28, Chavel translation.

215 Forty days for the first tablets and 40 days in prayer (Deut. 9:18), which culminated with the giving of the second tablets (Krinsky). It should be noted that while I.E. rejects this opinion here, he appears to accept it in Deut. 10:1 (Sarim).
216 According to the sages of the Talmud, Moses spent 120 days on Sinai. See Shemot Rabbah 47:12.
217 See I.E. on Ex. 33:10.
218 This is stated with regard to the first tablets.
219 In prayer on behalf of Israel. The rabbis assume that this took place on mount Sinai, for Scripture states before the Lord.
220 At the end of the 40 days of prayer.
221 As Moses spent 40 days on Sinai the first time, so did he spend 40 days the second time. Moses thus spent 120 days on Sinai, 80 days when receiving the tablets and 40 in prayer.
222 According to I.E. the subject of va-yikhtov (and He wrote) is God.
223 God’s glory.
224 Keren means a horn. Hence the word karan. Literally, it means horned. I.E. therefore explains that karan should be understood as sent forth beams.
225 That is, since Rays hath He at His side follows And a brightness appeareth as the light.

226 This is known as parallelism. The point is karnayim (rays) hath He at His side means the same as And a brightness appeareth as the light. Hence karnayim means rays; similarly the word karan in our verse, which is etymologically related to it, means rays.
227 For Chivi see I.E. on Ex. 14:23 and the notes thereto.
228 Chivi interprets karan or panav (the skin of his face sent forth horns) as the skin of his face horned, i.e. turned hard as a horn.
229 People are used to seeing ugly people. Hence there was no reason why the Israelites should have feared to approach Moses.
230 That the people feared to approach Moses because of his ugliness.
231 That Moses’ face was fresh and youthful rather than dry as a horn as Chivi maintains.
232 Moses was 80 years old at the time of the Exodus. See Ex. 7:7.
233 The reference is to Aaron and the rulers.
234 Verses 11-26.
235 It is a garment which covers the face (Krinsky). According to I.E., masveh and kesut come from the same root (samekh, vav, heh) and have the same meaning.
236 See I.E. on Gen. 49:11 and the notes thereto.
237 They come from the same root.
238 Ul and avilim come from the same root. However, the vav is not sounded in ul.
239 Tokh and tavekh come from the same root. However, the vav is silent in tokh. Similarly masveh and suto.
240 Upon Moses’ face.
241 So Vat. Ebr. 38. However, some of the printed editions have “he would put.” This appears to be an error. See Netter and Weiser.
242 When he reached the age of 120. See Deut. 34:7.
243 That is, when they had a dispute and came to Moses for judgment, for the light on Moses’ face would prevent them from presenting their case freely (Weiser).
244 In other words, ve-heshiv is not to be taken as a perfect but as an imperfect.
245 Scripture is not describing something that happened once but something which Moses continually practiced.
246 Since I.E. mentions Moses’ death he notes that Moses’ grave is unknown.
247 So that his grave not become an object of worship. The Lord being merciful unto him is a quote from Genesis 19:16 which I.E. applied to Moses.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 35
chapter.p: Blessed is the most high God
Who led his people with might;
Through his messenger
Whose face shined as the light of the sun.
He commanded Moses1 on the mountain
To prepare a tent for his dwelling, as stated in
The Torah portion Va-Yakhel.
1. AND MOSES ASSEMBLED. Moses assembled the people so that all of them would hear, from him, the report about the tabernacle and would donate to its construction.2

Elleh ha-devarim (these are the words) is to be interpreted as referring to the making of the tabernacle and its vessels.3 Scripture therefore reads, that ye should do them. This is its meaning:4 God commanded me that you make what I will tell you.5 Now even though you are obligated to do heaven’s work, the Lord commanded you to be careful and not do any work on the Sabbath.6 One who violates this law before witnesses will be put to death by a court of law.7 Scripture explains elsewhere8 that he will be stoned.

3. YE SHALL KINDLE NO FIRE. Since Scripture earlier mentioned with regard to the first and the seventh day of the festival of unleavened bread, no manner of work shall be done in them, save that which every man must eat (Ex. 12:16), namely, that it is permitted to prepare food9 on these days, it now states with regard to the Sabbath, ye shall kindle no fire to bake bread or to cook meat, for fire is required in preparing all food.
Rabbi Saadiah Gaon composed a very important work refuting those who dispute with the ancients regarding the Sabbath lights.10
4. AND MOSES SPOKE. Moses now began to explain to the entire congregation what God had commanded him.

5. TAKE. The word kechu (take) is the opposite of tenu (give). However, when a mem follows a word from the root lamed, kof, chet,11 then it has the meaning of give. The meaning of kechu li (take me) in Take me, I pray thee, a little water (I Kings 17:10)12 is, take for me,13 take on my account. It is the same case with Take (kechu) ye from among you (me-ittekhem) an offering unto the Lord (la-Adonai).14

[WHOSOEVER IS OF A WILLING HEART.] The phrase kol nediv libbo (whosoever is of a willing heart) is irregular.15 It should be interpreted as if written kol asher nedavo libbo (all whose heart made them willing). We find the same with bi-gedol zero’akha16 (By the greatness of Thine arm) (Ex. 15:16), which should be interpreted as if written bi-zero’akha ha-gadol (by Thy great arm); and zekher rav tuvekha (the fame of Thy great goodness)17 (Ps. 145:7), which should be interpreted as if written zekher tuvekha ha-rav (the fame of goodness which is great).

Rabbi Joshua says that the vav of libbo is superfluous.18 It is similar to the vav of chayeto in chayeto19 sadai (every beast of the field) (Ps. 104:11) and the vav of beno in beno20 be’or (Balaam the son of Beor) (Num. 24:3).

[LET HIM BRING IT.] After stating let him bring it, Scripture continues to explain, and goes on to say that the reference is to the Lord’s offering.21 There are many such instances, one of them being, and he hath commanded me, my brother (I Sam. 20:29).22

[AND SILVER.] Some say that the word kesef (silver) is etymologically related to the word nikhsefah (yearneth) (Ps. 94:3),23 and that silver is so called because it is a delight to the eyes.24 Nechoshet (brass) is also so called because women practice magic (me-nachashot) with brass (nechoshet).25

6. AND SCARLET. The word shani (scarlet) is here spelled without a mem. We also find it spelled with a mem. Compare shanim (scarlet) in Though your sins be as scarlet (Is. 1:18). Perhaps the latter is a plural.26
7. AND SKINS. The word orot (skins) is masculine.27 Luchot (tables) is similar.28 So is bechorot (firstlings) in and the firstlings of…thy flock (Deut. 14:23).29
ACACIA-WOOD. Shittim (acacia),30 like the word nashim (women), is spelled with a mem.31
8. AND OIL. Scripture does not mention pure beaten olive oil32 because this is known.33 Scripture therefore reads la-ma’or (for the light), as is the custom.34

Moses now mentioned that those who were “willing-hearted” should bring their offerings.35 He then went on to say that those who were certain that they were experts in the crafts should come and make [all that the Lord hath commanded].36
Moses began37 with the tabernacle38 because it takes in everything.39 The tent40 served as its cover. He then mentions its covering.41 Its covering takes in the two coverings.42
11. ITS CLASPS. The clasps of the tabernacle and the tent.43
ITS BARS, ITS PILLARS, AND ITS SOCKETS. The pillars for the veil and the screen.44 Scripture then mentions45 the holy vessels which were placed behind the veil.46
13. AND THE SHOWBREAD. For the table was constructed for the showbread.47
14. THE CANDLESTICK. Scripture mentions the oil for the light because the menorah was made for it.48

15. AND THE ALTAR. Scripture concludes the account of the holy vessels. It then mentions the screen for the door. Now the vessels of the oil for the lighting, and the vessels of the anointing oil and the sweet incense, shall be placed between the veil and the screen of the door49 of the tabernacle because they are holy.
16. THE LAVER AND ITS BASE. Observe, the laver and its base had no staves50. It is possible that they were carried on wagons.

17. THE HANGINGS OF THE COURT, THE PILLARS THEREOF (AMMUDAV), AND THEIR SOCKETS (ADONEHAH).51 Our verse is similar52 to and a great (gedolah)53 and strong (chazak)54wind (ru’ach)55 (I Kings 19:11) and to A fire (esh) not blown (nuppach)56 by man shall consume him (te’okhlehu)57 (Job 20:26).
19. THE PLAITED GARMENTS. Necessary for the journey.58
20. DEPARTED. We learn from this that the entire congregation of Israel came to the tent of meeting group by group.59
21. AND THEY CAME, EVERY ONE WHOSE HEART STIRRED HIM UP. The reference is to the wise-hearted.60 The meaning of nesa’o libbo (whose heart stirred him up) is, whosoever had an exalted heart.61

[22. MEN AND WOMEN.] The meaning of al nashim (and women) is, with women.62 Al here is similar to al (with)63 in with (al) the bread of the first-fruits for a wave-offering (Lev. 23:20). There are many other such instances.64

22. AS MANY AS WERE WILLING-HEARTED. Nediv lev (willing-hearted)65 includes willing-hearted women. The term is used in the same sense as ha-shafan (and the rock-badger)66 (Lev. 11:5) and shor seh khevasim (the ox, the sheep) (Deut. 14:4).67
NOSE-RINGS. Chach is an earring.68
AND EAR-RINGS. Nezem is a nose-ring.69
AND SIGNET-RINGS. Taba’at (signet-ring) is a ring which is placed on the finger.
AND GIRDLES. Kumaz (girdle) is a ring which is placed around the arm.70
23. AND EVERY MAN. Or woman.71 In addition,72 the women spun the blue and the purple, the scarlet, the fine linen73 and also the goats’ hair,74 a craft which required exceptional skill.75

27. AND THE RULERS BROUGHT THE ONYX STONES, AND THE STONES TO BE SET. They had these items because when Israel left Egypt and despoiled the Egyptians,76 every Israelite asked for articles in accordance with his status.77 Now it was truly a great thing that the rulers possessed oil for the light many months after Israel left Egypt. Scripture next mentions the men and women together78 and backtracks and speaks of the women whose heart stirred them up to do the work.79 It mentions the chief,80 whom all should obey because there is no one as wise as he among them.
31. AND HE HATH FILLED HIM. Look. God bore witness that Bezalel was saturated with wisdom, understanding, and knowledge, and in addition was skilled in all manner of workmanship.
32. AND TO DEVISE SKILFUL WORKS. Ve-la-chashov machashavot (and to devise skilful works) is to be interpreted as meaning: and to devise in his heart designs which were never seen.

[IN GOLD, AND IN SILVER.] For some people are skilled in working with gold but not in working with silver. Others are skilled stone masons but are not skilled wood carvers. However, Bezalel was a master of all of these crafts.

34. [AND HE HATH PUT IN HIS HEART THAT HE MAY TEACH.] In addition to the above, God put in his heart the ability to teach because there are many wise men who teach with great difficulty. Now Oholiab was Bezalel’s colleague in all the crafts and in the skill of teaching to others. Scripture therefore says with regard to both of them, even of them that do any workmanship, and of those that devise skilful works81 (v. 35).
chapter.ftnote: 1 So Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed texts say, for commanding him.
2 I.E comments thus because Moses did not gather all the people together to hear the other commandments.

3 Our verse states, These are the words (elleh ha-devarim) which the Lord hath commanded, that ye should do (la’asot) them. Now one cannot “do” words. Hence I.E. interprets devarim as things. He explains the verse as follows: These are the things which the Lord hath commanded that you make. So Sarim. However, Krinsky claims that I.E. explains our verse as meaning: These are the words regarding the construction of the tabernacle and its vessels which the Lord hath commanded that you make. According to this interpretation the word devarim means words as it usually does.
4 Of verses 2 and 3.
5 Verse 2.
6 Verse 3.
7 I.E.’s paraphrase of the last part of verse 3.
9 That is, it is permitted to do the work necessary for the preparation of food.
10 The reference is to the Karaites, who prohibit a candle that is lit before the onset of the Sabbath from continuing to burn on the Sabbath.

11 As it does in our verse, for our verse reads, kechu me-ittekhem. Others emend to a lamed not a mem, because I Kings 17:10 reads, kechu li. If this is the case, then the lamed referred to is the lamed in la-Adonai.
12 Translated literally.
13 Literally, because the taking is for me.
14 Its meaning is, take for me an offering for the Lord.

15 It is irregular for the following two reasons: a) Nediv, which is an adjective, is in the construct. An adjective does not usually come in the construct. b) Libbo is a declined noun. A declined noun is not usually preceded by a word in the construct (Filwarg). It should be noted that the literal meaning of kol nediv libbo is, whosoever willing of his heart.
16 Bi-gedol (by the greatness of), an adjective, is in the construct with zero’akha (Thine arm), which is a declined noun.
17 Translated literally. Rav (great), an adjective, is in the construct with tuvekha (Thy goodness), which is a declined noun.

18 In other words, our phrase is to be read as if written, kol nediv lev (whosoever is of a willing heart). This only eliminates libbo’s irregularity. It does not explain the. irregularity of nediv (Filwarg).
19 Chayeto is be interpreted as if written chayyat.
20 Beno is to be interpreted as if written ben.
21 The Lord’s offering appears to be redundant. Hence I.E. notes that it is the style of Scripture to occasionally elaborate. See I.E. on Ex. 2:6; 3:14.
22 Translated literally. My brother explains and he hath commanded me.
23 They both come from the root kaf, samekh, peh.
24 The phrase “a delight to the eyes” is a quote from Gen. 3:6.
25 They employ brass objects in their magical practices (Filwarg).
26 Hence it is spelled with a mem. According to this interpretation, shani is the singular form for scarlet and shanim is its plural form.
27 Even though it has a feminine ending, for the word or (skin) is masculine.
28 Luchot is masculine even though it has a feminine ending, for the word lu’ach (tablet) is masculine.
29 Bechorot is masculine even though it has a feminine ending, for the word bechor (firstling) is masculine.
30 The plural of shittah, which is a feminine noun. Feminine nouns usually end in a tav in the future. Hence I.E.’s comment.
31 Even though it is feminine.
32 Scripture reads, and oil for the light. However, in view of Ex: 27:20 it should have read: and pure beaten olive oil for the light.
33 It is known that the oil employed in the lighting of the menorah must be pure beaten olive oil. See Ex. 27:20.

34 Whenever Scripture refers to something that is known it employs the definite article. Hence Scripture reads la-ma’or, which, according to I. E., means for the light, rather than le-ma’or, for light.
35 Verse 5.
36 Verse 10.
37 His list in verse 6 of what God commanded the Israelites to make.
38 The reference is to the woven curtains. See Rashi and Ex. 26:1-6.
39 The term mishkan (tabernacle) does not refer only to the woven curtains. It also refers to the entire sanctuary. See Ex. 25:9.
40 It is mentioned next in the verse. The tent was made out of goats’ hair. See Ex. 26:7-11.
41 Which were placed over the woven curtains.
42 Which were placed over the covering of goats. See Ex. 26:14.
45 In verse 12.
46 In the Holy of Holies.

47 The showbread was not actually placed upon the table at this time. Hence I.E. points out that the showbread was mentioned at this time because the table was made for it. So Filwarg. Krinsky explains that I.E. interpreted and the showbread to mean: and the other utensils necessary for the preparation of the showbread.
48 The oil was mentioned earlier in verse 8. Why mention it again?
49 Scripture mentions these articles after mentioning the veil (v. 12) but before mentioning the screen (v. 15). Hence I.E. concludes that they were placed between the veil and the screen.
50 Unlike the ark and the table of showbread, the laver and its base had no staves by which to be carried.
51 Ammudav is masculine. Adonehah is feminine. Ammudav and adonehah both refer to chatzer (courtyard). Scripture thus treats chatzer both as a feminine and a masculine.
52 In its treatment of a word both as a masculine and a feminine in one verse.
53 Gedolah is feminine.
54 Chazak is masculine.
55 Scripture thus treats ru’ach both as a feminine and a masculine.
56 Nuppach is masculine.
57 Te’okhlehu is feminine. Scripture thus treats esh both as a feminine and a masculine.
58 According to I.E. the bigde ha-sered served to cover the holy vessels when Israel journeyed. See I.E. on Ex. 31:10.
59 There was no room in the tent of meeting for the entire congregation of Israel to gather there at one time. Hence I.E.’s comment.
60 Mentioned in verse 10.

61 Nesa’o libbo literally means whose heart exalted him. I.E. takes this to mean whose heart exalted him over other craftsmen. He identifies those whose heart stirred them up with the “wise-hearted” mentioned in verse 10. I.E. interprets thus because nowhere else does Scripture indicate that the “wise-hearted” actually came to make the vessels that God had commanded to be made. See Krinsky and Netter.
62 In other words, al here has the meaning of with. I.E. comments thus because al usually means on.
63 That is, it has the meaning of with.
64 Where al has the meaning of with.
65 Even though nediv lev is masculine.
66 Which, while in the masculine, also includes females, for Scripture does not prohibit only the eating of male shefanim.
67 The nouns shor and seh khevasim are in the masculine. However the terms also include the female of the species, for the Torah permits cows and female sheep to be eaten.
68 J.P.S. translates chach as nose-ring.
69 J.P.S. translates nezem as ear-ring.
70 A metal armband.
71 The term ish (man) includes women.
72 Aside from bringing what the men brought, the women spun the blue, the purple, etc.
73 Verse 25.
74 Verse 26.
75 Literally, wisdom.
77 The rulers asked for precious stones.
78 Verse 29.
79 According to I.E. the term la’asot (to be made) refers to the work done by the women (Weiser).
80 Bezalel, in verse 30.
81 I.E. assumes that as Bezalel and Oholiab were colleagues in workmanship, and…skilful works, so were they colleagues in the ability to teach these skills.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 36
chapter.p: 1. SHALL WORK. Look. Bezalel himself shall make the glorious object.1 However, he and Oholiab shall teach.2

2. CALLED. The heh of the word le-korvah (to come) is superfluous. It is like the heh in the word u-le-dovkah (and to cleave)3 in and to cleave unto Him (Deut. 11:22). A great scholar erred in saying that the word le-omdah (it might stand) (Ezek. 17:14) is similar, for the heh in le-omdah has a mappik4 in it.5 Omed is an intransitive verb.6 The meaning of le-omdah (it might stand) is therefore7 to stand by it.8
3. AND THEY RECEIVED. All the offering which they9 had brought.
AND THEY. The Israelites10 continued to bring free-will offerings to Moses every morning.
4. AND ALL THE WISE MEN…CAME. To Moses’ tent and said, The people bring much more [than enough for the service of the work] (v. 5).

5. [MUCH MORE THAN ENOUGH.] The mem of mi-de (much more than enough) means: much more than. It is, in keeping with my interpretation,11 like the mem of mi-kol (more than all) in I have more understanding than all my teachers (Ps. 119:99).12
6. AND THEY CAUSED IT TO BE PROCLAIMED. Va-ya’aviru (and they caused to be proclaimed) is similar to va-ya’avor (and there went)13 in And there went a cry throughout the host (I Kings 22:36).
7. FOR THE STUFF. The work which was done.14
[SUFFICIENT.] The mem of dayyam (sufficient) refers to all of the wise men.15
FOR ALL THE WORK. That they had to do.
AND TOO MUCH. Ve-hoter (and too much) is an infinitive. Its meaning is, ho-tirah (and they produced more than enough).16
8. MADE. Scripture begins with the making of the tabernacle.
TWINED. Moshzar (twined) means long in Arabic.

Note that the single digit numbers17 are grammatically irregular in Hebrew. This is also the case in Aramaic. They are similarly irregular in Arabic. The heh18 at the end of a word indicates the feminine; the masculine does not have any sign.19 Now the heh in the number sheloshah (three) indicates the masculine.20 The same is true of the numbers arba’ah (four), shemonah (eight), asarah (ten).21 From there22 through twenty the masculine numbers do not have a heh at the end. We thus say achad asar (eleven),23 shenem asar (twelve),24 tishah asar (nineteen). The feminine25 is written with a heh.26 However, its vocalization is changed27 so that it reads esreh.28 This is done so that the word not be confused with the masculine.29 Hence we say shetem esreh (twelve). The same applies to all of the numbers.30 Look. Shalosh (three), arba (four), and eser (ten) are feminine. If their sum is in the construct then it ends in a tav both in the masculine and in the feminine. Compare, sheloshet ha-anashim ha-elleh (these three men) (Ezek. 14:16); and u-sheloshet neshe vanav (and the three wives of his sons) (Gen. 7:13). Now the masculine form for the number eight is shemonah, as the rule says.31 The feminine is unique in that one says shemoneh (eight)32 in the same way that one says ashte esreh (eleven).33
9. [CUBITS.] It is possible that the reason our verse reads ba-ammah (cubits)34 is that it refers to a specific cubit. It possibly refers to the noble cubit of the first temple.35

12. [THE LOOPS.] The tav of ha-lula’ot (the loops)36 indicates the feminine. The singular form of the word is lulah.37 The heh [in lulah] takes the place of the alef.38 Some say that the word lalat (near to be delivered) in was with child, near to be delivered (I Sam. 4:19) comes from the same root.39
19. FOR THE TENT. La-ohel (for tent) means to serve as a tent.40

33. [TO PASS THROUGH.] The word livro’ach (to pass through) is a kal. It has the same meaning as the hifil mavri’ach (pass through).41 We find the same with the words yereh (shoot)42 and va-yoreh (and he shot)43 (II Kings 13:17).44 There are many such instances.45
chapter.ftnote: 1 The ark. See Ex. 37:1. Va-asah (shall work or shall make) is in the singular. Hence I.E.’s interpretation (Filwarg, Krinsky).
2 Hence Oholiab’s name is coupled with that of Bezalel.
3 Which is also superfluous.
4 A dot.
5 The heh with a mappik means it.
6 I.E. comments thus because an intransitive verb does not usually have a heh with a mappik suffixed to it. The heh with a mappik usually indicates the direct object.
7 Since le-omdah is intransitive.

8 The covenant. In other words, heh with a mappik does not mean to stand it but to stand by it, for omed is intransitive (see note 6). I.E. interprets Ezek. 17:14 as follows: To keep his covenant and to stand (abide) by it.
9 The children of Israel.
10 Ve-hem (and they) refers to the Israelites.

12 I.E. takes issue with the Rabbinic interpretation that mi-kol in mi-kol melammedai hiskalti (I have more understanding than all my teachers) means: from all. See Abot 4:1: “Ben Zoma said: Who is wise? He who learns from all men; as it is said, From all (mi-kol) my teachers I have gotten understanding.” According to I.E. it means: more than all.
13 The root ayin, bet, resh means to pass over. It usually refers to people or objects. Hence I.E. points out that the term is also used in reference to sound.
14 The Hebrew reads, ve-hamlakhah hayetah. Its literal meaning is: and the work was, which I.E.’s interprets as the work which was done. I.E. disagrees with the definition of melakhah as stuff.
15 The mem of dayyam is a suffix meaning for them, the reference being to the wise men mentioned in verse 4.

16 In other words, the infinitive form ve-hoter is here to be interpreted as a feminine perfect, for ve-hoter refers to melakhah, which is feminine. The work which they had done produced more than enough. So Filwarg.

17 Literally, the ones, reading ha-achadim (the ones), as in Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed editions read, “Note that the number one (ha-echad) is grammatically irregular.” The problem with this reading is that I.E. nowhere discusses “the number one” in his comment. Weiser suggests that our text is defective. On the other hand, Filwarg and others interpret ha-echad as achadim.
18 That is, a heh preceded by a kamatz.
19 The masculine singular does not have any sign indicating that the word is masculine.
20 In other words, in the single digit numbers the feminine ending indicates that the word is masculine.
21 I.E. is being brief. The same applies to chamishah (five), shishah (six), shivah (seven), and tishah (nine).
22 Ten.
23 Rather than achad asarah.
24 And similarly from thirteen through eighteen.
25 The feminine form of the numbers eleven through twenty.
26 As is the rule with feminine nouns. We thus say achat esreh (11), shetem esreh (12), shelosh esreh (13), etc.
27 It is not vocalized with a kamatz as is usual in the feminine, but with a tzere. See note 19.
28 Not asarah.
29 Asarah (ten).
30 Eleven through nineteen in the feminine.
31 The rule stating that numbers 3-10 end in a kamatz heh in the masculine.
32 Segol heh is usually a masculine ending. Compare, moreh (teacher), sadeh (field) (Weiser).
33 Ashte esreh (eleven), a feminine, is vocalized with a tzere even though the tzere is the construct form of masculine nouns ending in a segol.
34 The kamatz beneath the bet indicates the definite article.
35 See I.E. on Ex 26:16 and the notes thereto.
36 Lula’ot is spelled lamed, vav, lamed, alef, vav, tav.
37 Lulah is spelled lamed, vav, lamed, heh.
38 There is no alef in lulah (see notes 36 and 37). Hence I.E.’s comment.

39 A woman about to deliver experiences labor pains. These pains can metaphorically be described as attaching themselves or looping themselves to the woman. Hence the term lalat. According to I.E. we should render I Sam. 4:19: was with child, seized by labor pains.
40 La-ohel (for tent) literally means to tent. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.

41 Mavri’ach is a participle. What I.E. means is that the word livro’ach (to pass through), which is an infinitive in the kal has the same meaning as the word le-havri’ach (to pass through), which is a hifil infinitive. Indeed, this is precisely what I.E. says in his short commentary.
42 Yereh is a kal.
43 Yoreh is a hifil.
44 Both of these words have a similar meaning even though they belong to different conjugational forms.
45 Where words in different conjugational forms have similar meanings.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 37
chapter.p: 1. AND BEZALEL MADE. Bezalel made the ark because of its importance.1 Bezalel also made all the holy vessels.2 Now Scripture3 mentions the tabernacle,4 the tent,5 the veil,6 and the screen,7 for they serve a similar purpose.8 Scripture then mentions the holy anointing oil with the incense of sweet spices9 because there are spices in the anointing oil and also in the sweet incense.10
chapter.ftnote: 1 This is why our verse specifies that Bezalel made the ark.

2 Though Scripture does not specifically say so. However, see Nahmanides, who writes: “Scripture states without elaboration, and he made the table (v. 10), and he made the candelabrum (v. 17). In the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra, this alludes to Bezalel, who made all the sacred vessels. But this is not my opinion, for in the case of the court of the Tabernacle it likewise says, and he made the court (Ex. 38:9), [and it would not be reasonable to say that Bezalel alone made the court]. Rather, this refers back to every wise-hearted man (Ex. 36:8) as mentioned in the making of the Tabernacle” (Nahmanides on Ex. 36:8, Chavel translation).
3 In chapter 36.

8 The first two served as coverings and the latter two as partitions. According to Krinsky, Sarim, and Weiser, I.E.’s point is that Scripture tells us about the making of the sanctuary’s structure before writing about the making of its furniture, because it is the way of the world to first build a house and then to put in the furniture.
9 In verse 39.
10 I.E. was bothered by the juxtaposition of the anointing oil and the incense of the sweet spices. These two preparations did not serve a similar purpose. Why, then, list them next to each other?

chapter.title: CHAPTER 38
chapter.p: 8. [OF THE MIRRORS.] Be-marot (of the mirrors) has a bet rather than a mem prefaced to it.1 It is proper Hebrew to do so.2 We find the same in the verse ve-ha-notar ba-basar u-va-lachem (and that which remaineth of the flesh and of the bread) (Lev. 8:32).3 It is the same case in Arabic.

[THAT DID SERVICE.] Scripture states this because it is the custom of all women to beautify themselves. They look at their faces in brass or glass mirrors every morning to arrange the head coverings4 upon their heads. These head coverings are mentioned in the Book of Isaiah.5 The custom of Israel was the same as the Moslem practice unto this very day.6 Now there were in Israel women who served God and removed themselves from the pleasures of this world. These women gave their mirrors as a free-will offering because they had no need to beautify themselves. They rather came daily to the door of the tent of meeting to pray and to hear the words of the commandments. Scripture states, that did service (tzave’u)7 at the door of the tent of meeting because there were many such women.
[THE LAVER.] Scripture does not mention the dimensions of the laver as it does in the case of the lavers that Solomon made.8 The laver9 was rather made out of all the mirrors that were brought.10
[THE BASE.] The ken,11 that is, the base,12 was in all instances the same size as the laver13 as is normally the case.

[12. AND FOR THE WEST SIDE.] Scripture14 refers to the west as the hinder part15 because the tent’s opening was on the east, which is referred to as the face. Scripture16 refers to the sides which were close to the door17 as shoulders,18 for they19 are compared to the shoulders of a human being.
Give thanks to God and ascribe power to Him
O “Father of a multitude,”20
Now that you have reached the opening of the
Torah portion Ellah Pekude.

21. THESE ARE THE ACCOUNTS OF THE TABERNACLE. Its meaning is: these are the accounts of the vessels of the tabernacle, for the word tabernacle includes everything.21 Scripture goes on to explain why the structure was referred to as a mishkan (tabernacle).22 It was so called because the tablets of testimony were placed in it.23 Now Scripture was brief.24 The tablets were truly a testimony, because God’s writing was inscribed upon them.

[THROUGH THE SERVICE OF THE LEVITES.] Its meaning is: through the service of the Levites who carry the tabernacle and all of its vessels which Ithamar appointed to them. For the Gershonites and the Merarites were the Levites under the direction of Ithamar, who listed all the objects they were assigned to carry.25
22. AND BEZALEL. Scripture notes that Bezalel and Oholiab, who were first in rank,26 executed all of their tasks properly.

24. ALL THE GOLD. Saadiah Gaon asks, “Why does Scripture note what was done with the silver but does not mention what the donated gold was used for?”27 He answers, “Look. Scripture notes that the menorah was made out of a talent of gold.28 This was also the case with the ark cover29 and the gold utilized for the ark and the altar of incense.”30

Now this is incorrect.31 Only the menorah was entirely made of gold. This was not the case with the ark. The ark was only overlaid with gold on the inside and on the outside. The same was true of the altar of incense. The table, the staves, the boards, and the bars were all overlaid with gold. The ark cover was made completely of gold.32 According to the tradition passed on to us by our fathers the ark cover was made from a talent of gold because it was very broad and very wide.

I believe that Scripture mentions what they did with the silver because the silver was given for atonement.33 Observe. Scripture notes that the tabernacle, which included all the vessels, stood on the silver which the Israelites were obligated to give.34 This served as a memorial for the children of Israel.35
Who can estimate36 how much gold was needed to overlay all the vessels of the tabernacle?37
25. AND THE SILVER. Look. We learn from the sum mentioned in this verse that a talent consists of three thousand shekalim. And the silver of them that were numbered of the congregation proves this.38
26. A BEKA. Half a shekel. Its meaning is: when the shekel will be broken, behold its half.39
FOR EVERY ONE THAT PASSED. All those that passed twenty complete years. I have already explained the reason for this.40
27. FOR CASTING. La-tzeket (for casting) comes from a root whose first letter is a yod.41 It is similar to the word la-redet42 (to descend).43
28. AND OF THE THOUSAND SEVEN HUNDRED SEVENTY AND FIVE SHEKELS. Which did not serve to complete a talent.44
29. AND THE BRASS. Scripture also45 mentions the brass vessels.46
chapter.ftnote: 1 The usual way to say “of the mirrors” is mi-marot, for a mem prefaced to a word means from or of. On the other hand, a bet prefaced to a word means in or with. Hence our verse should have read mi-marot rather than be-marot.
2 In other words, the bet may be used in place of a mem.
3 Here too a bet is used in place of a mem, for we would expect ve-ha-notar me-ha-basar u-me-ha-lachem.
4 Hebrew, pe’arim.
5 Is. 3:20 speaks of the pe’arim (the headtires).
6 Moslem women in I.E.’s day placed head coverings on their heads. Hence I.E.’s comment.
7 Tzave’u is in the plural.
8 Each one of the lavers made by Solomon contained forty baths (I Kings 7:38).
9 Mentioned in our verse.
10 It had no preconceived measure. It measured whatever size all the brass mirrors came to.
11 Referred to in our verse.
12 Weiser renders: The ken (base), which is the same as the mekhonah (base) mentioned in I Kings 7:38, was in all instances the same size as the laver.
13 “By the same size” I.E. means that a larger laver had a larger base, a smaller laver had a smaller base.
15 Hebrew, yerakhim.
16 In verses 14 and 15.
17 Of the tabernacle.
18 Verses 14 and 15 refer to each of the sides of the tabernacle as a katef (side), which literally means a shoulder.
19 The sides.
20 An allusion to Abraham ibn Ezra. See Gen. 17:5, where Abraham is a shortened form for father of a multitude of nations.
21 It does not refer only to the sanctuary’s structure; it refers to its contents as well.
22 The word mishkan literally means a resting place.
23 Hence Scripture reads, even the tabernacle of the testimony.
24 Even the tabernacle of the testimony is short for: even the tabernacle of the tablets of testimony.

26 They were the chief workers. “Everything was done through (Bezalel’s) direction, for he acted as instructor to all the wise men, and they did their work in his presence and showed him all that they had done” (Nahmanides).
27 Scripture, in verses 27 and 28, itemizes what the silver was used for. However, it does not do the same for the gold.
29 According to Ex. 25:17 the ark cover was made of pure gold. However, it does not state how much gold was used to make it.

30 Saadiah Gaon apparently held that since Scripture tells us that the menorah was made from a talent of gold, the same was true of the ark, the table, and the altar of incense. Thus Scripture does in fact tell us what the gold was utilized for. The remaining gold was then used for various other items. See I.E.’s short commentary on this verse. We thus know what four talents of gold was used for.
31 That the ark, table, and altar of incense were each made from a talent of gold.
32 As noted in Ex. 25:17.
34 The silver which the Israelites were obligated to give to atone for their souls. See Ex. 30:14.
36 In advance.

37 There is no way to estimate in advance precisely how much gold would be needed to overlay each one of the objects that were to be covered by gold. Hence Scripture did not itemize the amount of gold needed for each object. Nahmanides similarly comments, “Now since one cannot know exactly how much gold went into the covering of each of these vessels, Scripture did not say that Moses gave it over to them by number and weight” (Nahmanides on v. 8, Chavel translation).

38 Those numbered came to 603,350 (v. 26). Each one of those numbered gave half a shekel (v. 26). The aforementioned thus contributed 301,775 shekalim. Our verse gives the amount as 100 talents and 1,775 shekalim. Thus 100 talents = 300,000 shekalim, which is another way of saying that one talent = 3,000 shekalim.
39 Beka is related to the verb baka. Baka means to break. When the shekel is broken, i.e., divided, we have half a shekel.
40 See I.E. on Ex. 30:13.
41 Its root is yod, tzadi, kof.
42 Its root is yod, resh, dalet.
43 I.E.’s point is that the form la-tzeket is similar to the form la-redet. La-tzeket is not the usual form of kal infinitives. Hence I.E.’s comment.
44 Which were in excess of a talent. See note 40.
45 In other words, not only does Scripture mention what the silver was used for, it does the same with the brass.
46 Scripture lists the vessels which were made from the brass which the Israelites donated to the tabernacle.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 39
chapter.p: 1. PLAITED GARMENTS.1 These garments are the ones that are mentioned in the Torah portion Be-Midbar Sinai (in the wilderness of Sinai).2 God commanded that the ark be covered with the veil3 as a mark of honor.4 A sealskin covering was placed over the veil. A blue cloth covering was placed over this covering.5

Logically speaking, the blue cloth covering was employed as an ark covering6 as a mark of honor7 when the weather was clear. However, if it rained then they would remove the blue cover and they would place a sealskin cover over it.8

A blue cloth and a cloth of scarlet were placed over the table of showbread. A cover of sealskin was placed over them.9 A blue cloth was placed over the menorah and the golden altar. A purple cloth was placed over the altar. A sealskin was placed over all of them.10
After mentioning the plaited garments Scripture mentions the holy garments of Aaron the high priest and then commences to describe them.
2. AND HE MADE THE EPHOD. Scripture describes11 how they placed the gold amidst the blue.12
6. [AND THEY WROUGHT THE ONYX STONES.] The meaning of va-ya’as (and they wrought)13 is, they set. It is like the word la’asot (to dress)14 in and he hastened to dress it (Gen. 18:7).15
22. [ALL OF BLUE.] Kelil tekhelet means entirely of blue. The word kelil is in the construct.16
28. AND THE MITRE OF FINE LINEN. Worn by Aaron.
AND THE GOODLY HEAD-TIRES. Which were worn by Aaron’s sons. The mitre and the head-tire differ.17
32. THUS WAS FINISHED. Va-tekhel (thus was finished)18 is vocalized like the word ve-terev (was so much)19 in but Benjamin’s portion was so much (Gen. 43:34).20

33. AND THEY BROUGHT THE TABERNACLE. Look. Et metarav21 vi-yetedotehah22 (the cords thereof, and the pins thereof) (v. 40) is similar to et kale he-chatzer et ammudav23 ve-et adonehah24 (the hangings of the court, the pillars thereof, and their sockets) (Ex. 35:17).25
chapter.ftnote: 1 Hebrew, bigde serad. According to I.E. the reference is to the garments which were used as covers for the tabernacle’s furniture when Israel journeyed. See I.E. on Ex. 31:10 and the notes thereto.
2 Num. 4:5-13. See I.E. on Ex. 31:10.
4 The veil that separated the Holy and the Holy of Holies was placed over the ark because of the ark’s great sanctity.
5 Over the sealskin covering. See Num. 4:6 and I.E.’s comments thereto.
6 Over the sealskin covering (Meijler).
7 The other items in the tabernacle were covered with sealskin. However, the ark was covered with blue, a symbol of royalty, because it was the most holy object in the tabernacle.
8 Over the blue cover.
10 Over the coverings of the menorah, the golden altar, and the brass altar. See Num. 4:9-14.
11 In verse 3.
12 Which it did not do in its earlier description of the priestly garments.
13 Va-ya’as usually has the meaning of: and they made. However, one cannot make onyx stones. Hence I.E.’s comment.
14 Which literally means to make.
15 We thus see that the verb asah does not always mean to make. See I.E. on Gen. 18:7.
16 Hence the kaf is vocalized with a sheva. I.E. comments thus because we find the kaf vocalized with a kamatz in kalil toktar in Lev. 6:15 (Weiser).
17 The terms refer to two specific types of head coverings. See I.E. on Ex. 28:37.
18 From the root kaf, lamed, heh.
19 From the root resh, bet, heh.
20 Both va-tekhel and ve-terev are short forms of a verb ending in a heh.
21 Metarav, which refers to the court, has a masculine ending. It thus treats chatzer (court) as a masculine noun.
22 Yetedotehah, referring to the court (chatzer), has a feminine ending. We thus have two words in the same verse referring to the same word in two genders.
23 Ammudav, which refers to the court (chatzer), has a masculine ending. It thus treats (court) as a masculine noun.
24 Adonehah, which refers to the court, has a feminine ending.
25 Here too we have chatzer treated both as a masculine and as a feminine in one verse.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 40
chapter.p: 2. ON THE FIRST DAY. We find the following difference of opinion. Some say that the eighth day of consecration1 fell on the first day of the month of Nisan.2 They were forced to say that Moses erected the tabernacle on the twenty-third day of Adar.3 Now on the first day of consecration Moses took the tabernacle apart and put it together4 in order to train the priests.5 They say6 that the goat that Moses inquired about and, behold, it was burnt (Lev. 10:16) was a new moon offering.7 Now God commanded that Moses erect the tabernacle on the first day of the first month and that he not take it apart until the ark journeyed.8

Now we find it stated in the Sifre9 that Mishael and Elzaphan10 were the ones who were unclean by the dead body of a man (Num. 9:6).11 The eighth was thus the eighth day of the month.12 There is, as it were, proof of this.13 First of all, why didn’t Scripture mention that Moses set up the tabernacle and took it apart?14

After the tabernacle was taken down there was no door of the tent of meeting. However, Scripture states, And at the door of the tent of meeting shall ye abide day and night (Lev. 8:35). Furthermore, Scripture writes, And unto the children of Israel thou shalt speak, saying: Take ye a he-goat for a sin-offering (Lev. 9:3). It was this he-goat that Moses inquired about.15 Additionally, if this16 was a goat that served as a new moon offering, why didn’t Scripture mention two bullocks, one ram, and seven he-lambs?17 Scripture should have read, beside the burnt offering of the new moon, as it does when it states,18 beside the burnt-offering of the morning (Num. 28:23).19

Look. According to the plain meaning of the text, the tabernacle was first erected on the first day of the first month. Observe, they raised up this first tabernacle on the first day of the first month. They began to build the first temple, which was the second tabernacle, on the second day of the second month, called Iyyar, as Scripture clearly states, in the second day of the second month (II Chron. 3:2).20

Our Talmud writes that Israel left Egypt on the fifth day of the week.21 If they transmitted this as a tradition then we will accept it. However, if we analyze the text logically then we must conclude that they left Egypt before the fifth day of the week because there is at least three days’ difference between a simple year22 and the beginning of the next year.23 This is so because a defective year consists of three hundred and fifty-three days, three hundred and fifty of which are taken up by weeks.24 In minimal leap years25 there is a difference of five days.26

Now it appears that Moses arranged the bread on the table27 on a Sabbath,28 for Scripture states, Every sabbath day he shall set if29 in order (Lev. 24:8).30 The tabernacle was thus erected either on the sixth day31 or on the Sabbath day.32 This appears to be the case even though the proof just offered is not irrefutable, for one can argue that the meaning of every sabbath he shall set it in order is, every Sabbath the priest shall set it in order after the tabernacle has been raised and Moses has arranged the bread.33

Observe. In describing the actual erecting of the sanctuary, Scripture tells that Moses raised up the tabernacle.34 He erected, as I have explained, the two corner boards.35 The Levites who were of his family set up the rest of the tabernacle, for it was not the work of one person.36 He37 laid its sockets below.38 He then set the boards and bars in place.39 He then raised up the pillars for the veil and the screen of the door of the tabernacle.40

Afterwards Moses spread the tent41 and put the covering of the tent over it.42 He then placed the ark43 on the western side44 and placed the tablets in the ark.45 He set the staves on the ark and placed the ark cover on top of the ark.46
Moses put in the table and arranged the showbread upon it.47 Now Scripture indicates that this took place in the morning.48 Scripture states, and he lighted the lamp s(v. 25) afterwards at night.49
Moses offered the burnt offering in the morning, that is, the daily burnt offering. He did the same in the afternoon.50

On this day51 Moses anointed the tabernacle and all of its vessels,52 the altar of the burnt offering and all of its vessels, the laver and its base.53 The congregation was gathered at the door of the tent of meeting and Aaron and his sons washed themselves with water.54 Moses placed the holy garments upon Aaron.55 He also dressed Aaron’s sons.56 They57 were anointed with the holy oil.58 He59 brought one young bullock and two rams to the altar.60 He sacrificed the bullock and performed purification on the altar.61 He caused the designated parts62 to turn into smoke63 and slaughtered the ram.64 He dashed its blood on the altar and caused the ram to turn into smoke.65 He also slaughtered the ram of consecration and dashed its blood on the altar.66 He took the designated parts along with the right thigh and one unleavened cake and one cake of oil bread and turned all of it into smoke on the altar.67 Moses did this on each one of the seven days of consecration.68 Scripture clearly writes, And thou shalt offer the bullock of sin-offering to the day…(Ex. 29:36), that is, daily,69…and you shall anoint the altar, to sanctify it.70 Scripture further writes, Seven days thou shalt make atonement for the altar (Ex. 29:37) and thou shalt anoint it, to sanctify it (Ex. 29:36). Now its meaning is,71 Thus shall you do all the seven days of consecration.

Scripture states, And it came to pass on the day that Moses had made an end of setting up the tabernacle, and had anointed it and sanctified the altar for seven days of consecration (Num. 7:1).72 The princes of Israel then73 began to bring the dedication offering of the altar.74 Aaron similarly offered a bull-calf as a personal sin offering,75 and he also offered his own ram as a burnt offering.76 As the people’s burnt offering he sacrificed a calf and a lamb. Aaron slaughtered the goat of the sin offering77 and treated it as a sin offering.78 He dealt with it as he did with his own calf sin offering79 with regard to dashing its blood and causing the designated parts to go up in smoke.80 However, a priest does not eat the priest’s sin offering. The flesh of the bullock81 was therefore burned outside the camp.82 The sin offering of the congregation, which is a he-goat, is eaten by the priests.

All of this took place after the morning burnt offering was offered. After all of this, he [Aaron] offered the burnt offering and sin offering of Nahshon.83 The dedication of the altar was thus finished after nineteen days of the first month84 had passed.85 Do not pay attention to the one who argues, “If this is the case86 then when did they offer the festival sacrifices?”87 Israel observed the festival of Passover88 in the desert of Sinai for only one night.89 They did not keep the festival of unleavened bread,90 for Scripture clearly states, And it shall be when the Lord shall bring thee [into the land of the Canaanite] (Ex. 13:5)…Seven days thou shalt eat unleavened bread (Ex. 13:6).91 And this day shall be unto you for a memorial (Ex. 12:14) refers to the next generation. It commands the next generation to establish the day that Israel left Egypt, as a holy convocation. Look! They journeyed from Goshen on the first day.92 Furthermore, Israel did not have bread93 from which to make unleavened bread for seven days in the desert of Sinai even though they were close to an inhabited place.94 It was a great thing that they found material out of which to make unleavened bread to eat with the bitter herbs and paschal lamb on the one night,95 for they were a very great multitude of people.

Now logically speaking, Moses offered the daily burnt offering96 during the seven days of consecration and two lambs on the Sabbath day.97 He offered the Sabbath burnt offering and then the consecration burnt offerings on which day of the seven days of consecration fell on a Sabbath. All of this is correct. However, what shall we do with the dedication of the altar98 on the Sabbath day?99 Some say that they skipped the Sabbath day.100 They only counted the days that they dedicated the altar.101 Others say that the princes’ burnt offering was offered on the Sabbath.102 However, the peace offerings103 were slaughtered and eaten on the first day of the week. Their proof is as follows. The prince104 who sacrifices105 offers six lambs on the Sabbath106 aside from the congregation’s burnt offering.107

The first group108 says that when they circled Jericho for six days with the armed body in the lead109 they similarly skipped the Sabbath.110 Behold, they circled Jericho for seven days.111 They say the same with regard to the fourteen days.112 They skipped the Day of Atonement and did not count it.
[34. THEN THE CLOUD COVERED.] Logically speaking, when the tabernacle was erected and Moses went out, the cloud covered the tabernacle and the glory of the Lord filled it.113

35. AND MOSES WAS NOT ABLE TO ENTER. Then God called Moses and told him to enter the tent. Moses used to speak with God face to face in the place where the high priest entered once a year with a cloud of incense,114 because Moses was, as it were, a member of the house.115 I was forced to say this116 because Moses put the tablets in the ark. He similarly placed over the ark the covering with the cherubim on top. God’s glory was always upon them.117

Now what happened when Aaron and his sons took down the veil of the screen118 outside the place where the ark was kept?119 How did they approach it?120 I therefore say that Moses alone entered beyond the veil. Aaron and his sons then took down the screen, which is called the veil.121 Moses used to take the screen and immediately cover the ark of the covenant with it so that Aaron and his sons would not see it. Scripture writes, and they shall cover the ark of testimony (Num. 4:5)122 because they assisted Moses. Others say that the priests covered the ark but did not face it.123

Scripture states, and there was fire therein by night, and then goes on to say, throughout all their journeys (v. 38). This124 also indicates that at times the cloud journeyed at night.125 Now we do not find it written that they journeyed at night.126 The one who says this127 explains or if it continued by day and by night (Num. 9:21) as referring to one day.128 Now what will they do with the phrase their journeys (v. 38)? Scripture does not read: throughout all their encampments.129 The correct meaning of or…by day and by night is: or day and night; or: or day or night.130 It is similar to And he that curseth his father and his mother,131 shall surely be put to death (Ex. 21:17).132 I had to say this because I noticed that the prayer which Moses uttered on the occasion of the scouts states, and thou goest before them, in a pillar of cloud by day, and in a pillar of fire by night (Num. 14:14).133
chapter.ftnote: 1 The day after the seven days of consecration. See Lev. 9:1-24. For the seven days of consecration, see Lev. 8:1-36. During these days of consecration Aaron and his sons were invested in their duties, the tabernacle furniture was anointed, and special sacrifices were offered in the tabernacle.
2 See Seder Olam 7:1: “The seven days of consecration began on the 23 of Adar and concluded on the first day of Nisan.”

3 That is, that Moses first erected the tabernacle on the 23 day of Adar. They were forced to say this because Scripture tells us that special sacrifices were offered during the period of consecration. These sacrifices could not be offered without the tabernacle standing.

4 On the next day. See I.E. on Num. 9:1. In other words, Moses set up the tabernacle and took it down during each one of the first seven days of consecration. On the eighth day, “God commanded that Moses erect the tabernacle on the first day of the first month and that he not take it apart until the ark journeyed.” See note 8.
5 In the service.
6 In keeping with their opinion that the eighth day of consecration described in Lev. 9 took place on the first day of Nisan.
7 Concerning the offerings brought on the new moon see Num. 28:11-15.

8 See Num. 10:11,35. According to this opinion when our verse relates that God told Moses, On the first day of the first month shalt thou rear up the tabernacle, it means: on the first day of the first month shalt thou rear up the tabernacle and not take it apart until the ark journeys. Those who interpret our verse thus do so because they believe that Moses first erected the tabernacle on the 23 day of Nisan.
9 Sifre on Num. 9:6.

10 Mishael and Elzaphan were the nephews of Aaron. They carried the bodies of Nadab and Abihu from the tabernacle after their demise in the sanctuary on the eighth day of consecration. See Lev 10:1-5.
11 They consequently could not offer the Passover sacrifice on the 14th of Nisan.

12 A person who touches a dead body is unclean for seven days (Num. 19:11). If Mishael and Elzaphan were unclean on the 14th of Nisan because they removed the dead bodies of their cousins from the tabernacle on the eighth day, then that day had to fall on the 8th day of Nisan rather than on the first. Now if the eight day fell on the 8th of Nisan, then the first day of consecration fell on the first day of Nisan. The tabernacle was thus erected for the first time on the first day of Nisan.
13 That the tabernacle was first set up on the first day of Nisan.
14 As maintained by those who say that the temple was built for the first time on the 23rd of Adar. See note 8.
15 Rather than the he-goat offered on the new moon, as stated by those who maintain that the eight day fell on the first day of Nisan.
16 The goat which Moses inquired about.

17 If the eighth day took place on a new moon then why does Lev. 9 only mention the new moon he-goat and not the other new moon offerings? For two bullocks, one ram, seven he-lambs, and a he-goat were offered on the new moon. See Num. 28:11-15.
18 With regard to the Passover offerings.

19 If the consecration offerings brought on the eighth day were offered on the new moon, Scripture should have indicated that these offerings were brought in addition to the burnt offering of the new moon.
20 II Chron. 3:2 reads: And he began to build [the House of God] in the second day of the second month.
21 Sabbath 87b; Seder Olam 5:3. See I.E. on Ex. 16:1.
22 That is, a defective year. A defective year is one that consists of 353 days. A Hebrew year can consist of 353, 354, or 355 days. See note 36 to Gen. 8.

23 That is, there is at least a three-day difference between the day of the week on which the year begins from one year to the other, if the first of the two years is a defective year. The difference will be more if the year has 354 or 355 days.
24 There are 50 weeks in a regular year, for 50 × 7 = 350. Thus a defective year consists of 50 weeks plus 3 days.
25 A leap year consists of 383 days.

26 There is a difference of five days between the end of the last year and the beginning of the next. A minimal leap year consists of 383 days (353 days plus a month). 383 days comes to 54 weeks and 5 days.
27 Verse 4 tells us that Moses was to bring the table into the tabernacle and arrange the bread on it on the day the tabernacle was erected. The tabernacle was thus erected on a Sabbath.

28 Hence it is not possible for the 15th day of Nisan in the previous year to have fallen on a Thursday. For if the 15th of Nisan fell on a Thursday, then the first day of Nisan also had to fall on a Thursday and consequently could not fall on a Saturday or a Friday the following year.
29 The showbread.
30 Thus the showbread could be placed on the table only on a Sabbath.
31 Very close to the onset of the Sabbath (Filwarg).

32 In view of the fact that the Torah states that the showbread should be on the table before the Lord continually, I.E. believes it unlikely for Moses to have set up the tabernacle a day or more before the Sabbath, thus leaving the table bereft of the bread.

33 In other words, Lev. 24:8 does not apply to the first time that Moses set up the tabernacle. Moses could have set up the tabernacle on any day of the week and placed the showbread on it. After this, the bread had to be placed on the table only on a Sabbath.
34 Verse 18.

35 According to I.E. the two corner boards mentioned in Ex. 26:23 were set up first when the tabernacle was raised. The rest of the tabernacle was then attached to these boards. See I.E. on Ex. 26:18. I.E. now adds the fact that Moses set up these two boards and that Scripture considers it as if he had erected the entire tabernacle.
36 It was beyond the ability of Moses to raise up the entire tabernacle by himself.
37 By command.
38 Verse 18.
39 Ibid.
40 Ibid. I.E. thus notes that “the pillars” in verse 18 refers both to the pillars for the veil and to the pillars for the screen of the tabernacle door. See Ex. 26:32,37.
41 Over the tabernacle. Verse 19.
42 Ibid.
43 Verse 21.
44 Of the tabernacle.
45 Verse 20.
46 Verse 20.
47 Verse 22.
48 For the setting of the table preceded the morning offering.
49 For that is when the menorah was lit. See Ex. 27:21.
50 I.E.’s interpretation of and offered upon it the burnt-offering (v. 29).
51 On the first day of Nisan.
54 Ibid., v. 6.
57 Aaron and his sons.
59 Moses.
61 Lev. 8:15. Also see Ex. 29:11,12.
62 The organs that Scripture commands be burned on the altar.
63 Lev. 8:17. Also see Ex. 29:13.
64 Lev. 8:19. Also see Ex. 29:16.
65 Lev. 8:21. Also see Ex. 29:18.
66 Lev. 8:23. Also see Ex. 29:20.
67 Lev. 8:26. Also see Ex. 29:23.
68 Lev. 8:33,34. Also see Ex. 29:35.
69 In other words, la-yom (literally, to the day) means daily, the reference being to the seven days mentioned in the previous verse (Krinsky).
70 I.E.’s paraphrase of Ex. 29:36.
71 The meaning of Seven days thou shalt make atonement for the altar.

72 Num. 7:1 reads, And it came to pass on the day that Moses had made an end of setting up the tabernacle, and had anointed it and sanctified it. And sanctified the altar for seven days is I.E.’s interpretation of and sanctified it.
73 On the eighth day.

74 See Num. 7:1-89. Among other things, each prince offered one young bullock, one ram, one he-lamb of the first year, for a burnt-offering; one male of the goats for a sin-offering; and for the sacrifice of peace-offerings, two oxen, five rams, five he-goats, five he-lambs of the first year (Num. 7:15-17).
77 The people’s sin offering.
80 But not with regard to eating its flesh.
81 Aaron’s sin offering. The Pentateuch refers to it as a bull-calf.
84 The month of Nisan, when Passover falls.
85 The seven days of consecration plus the 12 days that the princes offered their sacrifice. See Num. 7:1-83.
86 Reading im ken matai as in Vat. Ebr. 38, rather than ki ematai as in the printed texts.

87 According to I.E. the princes of Israel started to bring their dedication sacrifices on the eight day of Nisan. Thus five of the princes offered their dedication sacrifices during the time of the festival seasons. Those who have this opinion believe that if the priests were occupied with the dedication sacrifices of the princes they had no time to offer the Passover sacrifices. According to Meijler this opinion holds that Scripture should have mentioned the Passover sacrifices along with the sacrifices offered by the princes on the days that coincided with Passover. This question relates only to I.E.’s point of view. According to the opinion that the “eighth day” fell on the first of Nisan, the princes finished bringing their dedication offerings on the 12th day of Nisan, three days before the start of Passover, and consequently there is no problem.

88 That is, they sacrificed the paschal lamb on the 14th of Nisan and ate its flesh on the night of the 15th. It should be noted that in Scripture, Passover refers to the 14th of Nisan, when the paschal lamb is sacrificed, and the feast of unleavened bread to the seven days which follow. See note 86.

89 See Num. 9:1-6. Scripture there tells us that Israel observed the Passover in the first month of the second year following the Exodus from Egypt. The feast of unleavened bread is not mentioned. It is I.E.’s contention that this is the only Passover that Israel celebrated during their sojourn in the wilderness of Sinai.
90 Which begins on the eve of the 15th of Nisan and lasts for seven days. See Ex. 12:15.
91 We thus see that the obligation to observe the feast of unleavened bread begins only when Israel enters the land of Canaan.

92 That is, on the first of what would eventually be the seven days of the festival of unleavened bread, for Israel left Egypt on the 15th of Nisan. See Num. 33:3. I.E.’s point is that Israel did not observe the festival of unleavened bread till they entered Canaan. He points out that they did not keep this festival in Egypt where they could buy flour for their unleavened bread because they did not spend the seven days of the festival period in Egypt.
93 That is, flour. Hence they could not celebrate the festival of unleavened bread in the desert of Sinai.
94 Where they could have bought provisions if they felt themselves obligated to do so.
95 On which they celebrated the Passover. See note 85.
98 That is, the sacrifices offered for the dedication of the altar.

99 Each one of the 12 princes of Israel offered dedication sacrifices on each one of the 12 days following the seven days of consecration. See note 72. Now only those sacrifices mandated by the Torah may be sacrificed on the Sabbath. Personal offerings cannot be sacrificed on the Sabbath. Hence the question raised by I.E.
100 The princes of Israel did not offer their dedication sacrifice on the Sabbath.

101 In other words, when the Torah tells us that the princes of Israel offered 12 sacrifices on the 12 days following the seven days of consecration it does not mean that they offered them on 12 successive days, for they skipped the Sabbath day.
102 See note 72.
103 Which the prince should have offered on the Sabbath. See note 72.
104 The reference is not to any of the princes mentioned in our chapter but rather to the prince mentioned in Ezek. 46.
105 Literally, the one who sends. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, The prince, that is, the king.
106 See Ezek. 46:4, And the burnt-offering that the prince shall offer unto the Lord shall be in the sabbath day six lambs without blemish and a ram without blemish.

107 That is, aside from the congregation’s burnt offering, six lambs sent by the prince are sacrificed on the Sabbath. These six lambs are burnt offerings. We thus see that a prince’s burnt offering may be sacrificed on the Sabbath.
108 The group mentioned earlier, who maintain that the princes did not offer their altar dedication sacrifices on the Sabbath.
110 In order not to violate the Sabbath. This opinion apparently held that the Sabbath fell during the six days.

111 Josh. 6:15. They circled Jericho once a day for six days and seven times on the seventh day. This opinion maintains that they did not circle Jericho for seven successive days, for if they had done so they would have desecrated the Sabbath. This interpretation maintains that And it came to pass on the seventh day (Ibid.) does not refer to the Sabbath but rather to the seventh day of circling. It should be noted that according to the rabbis, Jericho fell on a Sabbath. See Tal. Jer. Sabbath 1:5, Seder Olam 11, Ba-Midbar Rabbah 14:1; 23:6.

112 The 14 days comprised the seven on which King Solomon celebrated the dedication of the temple plus the seven days of Sukkot. See I Kings 8:65: So Solomon held the feast at that time, and all Israel with him, a great congregation…before the Lord our God, seven days and seven days, even fourteen days. They say that these 14 days were not celebrated back to back, for if they had been, then Israel would have eaten on the Day of Atonement. It should be noted that according to the rabbis these 14 days were celebrated back to back and that Israel ate on Yom Kippur that year. See Mo’ed Katan 9a. Also see Kimchi on I Kings 8:65.
113 Literally, then the cloud. In other words, God’s glory did not fill the tabernacle while Moses was in it.
114 That is, in the Holy of Holies. See Lev. 16:13.
115 God’s house. Hence God called to him to enter the Holy of Holies on ordinary days.
116 That Moses entered the Holy of Holies whenever God spoke to him (Meijler).
117 Upon the cherubim. Hence Moses had already seen God’s glory (Krinsky). He was thus, as it were, a member of God’s house.
118 Which separated the Holy from the Holy of Holies.
119 See Num. 4:5: when the camp setteth forward, Aaron shall go in, and his sons, and they shall take down the veil of the screen, and cover the ark of testimony with it.
120 Since God’s glory was upon the ark.
121 I.E. interprets parokhet ha-masekh (the veil of the screen) as the parokhet, that is, the screen.
122 Translated literally.
123 So that they would not gaze upon God’s glory.
124 In addition to Num. 14:14. See below.
125 Some conclude on the basis of the aforementioned that at times the cloud journeyed at night.
126 Scripture never explicitly states that Israel journeyed at night.
127 That Scripture never explicitly states that Israel journeyed at night.

128 Num. 9:21 states, And sometimes the cloud was from evening until morning; and when the cloud was taken up in the morning, they journeyed; or if it continued by day and by night (o yomam va-laylah), when the cloud was taken up, they journeyed. Now o yomam va-laylah can be translated in two ways: a) Or it continued by day and by night. b) Or it continued for a day or for a night. According to the latter translation our verse reads, “or if it continued by day or by night (o yomam va-laylah) when the cloud was taken up, they journeyed.” Thus the verse teaches that Israel at times traveled at night. Hence those who maintain that Israel did not journey at night interpret o yomam va-laylah as referring to a 24-hour period, that is, a day and a night. This opinion interprets o yomam va-laylah as: or it continued by day and by night, that is, a full day consisting of a day and a night.

129 If Scripture intended to teach that they journeyed during the day and camped at night, then our verse should have read: For the cloud of the Lord was upon the tabernacle by day, and there was fire therein by night, in the sight of all the house of Israel, throughout all their “encampments,” rather than For the cloud of the Lord was upon the tabernacle by day, and there was fire therein by night, in the sight of all the house of Israel, throughout all their “journeys.” The latter implies that Israel journeyed at night.

130 In other words, Israel journeyed at night. Our text literally reads, “Its meaning is (u-pirusho), or day and night, or, or day or night.” This reading is a bit difficult. I.E. is trying to prove that Israel journeyed at night. Hence why mention the interpretation, or day and night (see note 122). Indeed, Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, “Its meaning is (u-pirusho), or day or night.” If we emend pirusho to pirush then our text reads, “The meaning of (u-pirush) Or…by day and by night is: or day or night.” This is probably the reading upon which our text is based, for pirusho seems to be a scribal error for pirush.
131 Hebrew, aviv ve-immo (his father and his mother).

132 Translated literally. The meaning of Ex. 21:17 is, And he that curseth his father “or” his mother shall surely be put to death. We thus see that the vav sometimes has the meaning of or. Similarly, yomam va-laylah is not to be rendered day and night but rather day or night.
133 This verse implies that Israel journeyed at night, for prima facie, and Thou goest before them also refers to and in a pillar of fire by night.
